tuple: ['What is psychology?', 'The field of psychology explores questions like these.']
['What does it study?', 'Psychology refers to the scientific study of the mind and behavior.']
['How do psychologists acquire knowledge?', 'Psychologists use the scientific method to acquire knowledge.']

['How does the scientific method work?', 'To apply the scientific method, a researcher with a question about how or why something happens will propose a tentative explanation, called a hypothesis, to explain the phenomenon.']

['What is a hypothesis?', 'A hypothesis should fit into the context of a scientific theory, which is a broad explanation or group of explanations for some aspect of the natural world that is consistently supported by evidence over time.']
['What is the theory?', 'A theory is the best understanding we have of that part of the natural world.']
['What happens after that?', 'The researcher then makes observations or carries out an experiment to test the validity of the hypothesis.']
['What do those results show?', 'Those results are then published or presented at research conferences so that others can replicate or build on the results.']
['What is perceivable and measurable?', 'Scientists test that which is perceivable and measurable.']

['What are the perceivable and measurable things?', 'For example, the hypothesis that a bird sings because it is happy is not a hypothesis that can be tested since we have no way to measure the happiness of a bird.']
['What does it mean when we have no way to measure it?', 'We must ask a different question, perhaps about the brain state of the bird, since this can be measured.']
['What is the difference between perceivable and measurable?', 'However, we can ask individuals about whether they sing because they are happy since they are able to tell us.']
['What is empirical science?', 'Thus, psychological science is empirical, based on measurable data.']

['Why does science differ from psychology?', 'In general, science deals only with matter and energy, that is, those things that can be measured, and it cannot arrive at knowledge about values and morality.']

['What do you have to say about that?', 'This is one reason why our scientific understanding of the mind is so limited, since thoughts, at least as we experience them, are neither matter nor energy.']
['What else is scientific?', 'The scientific method is also a form of empiricism.']

['What is empiricism?', 'An empirical method for acquiring knowledge is one based on observation, including experimentation, rather than a method based only on forms of logical argument or previous authorities.']
['What was the historical background of psychology?', 'It was not until the late 1800s that psychology became accepted as its own academic discipline.']
['What was considered its most important contribution?', 'Before this time, the workings of the mind were considered under the auspices of philosophy.']
['What was psychology like?', 'Given that any behavior is, at its roots, biological, some areas of psychology take on aspects of a natural science like biology.']
['Is there anything else interesting about the article?', 'No biological organism exists in isolation, and our behavior is influenced by our interactions with others.']
['Are we alone?', 'Therefore, psychology is also a social science.']

['What was the rationale for studying psychology?', 'Often, students take their first psychology course because they are interested in helping others and want to learn more about themselves and why they act the way they do.']

['What else was the rationale?', 'Sometimes, students take a psychology course because it either satisfies a general education requirement or is required for a program of study such as nursing or pre-med.']
['Why did they take psychology as their major?', 'Many of these students develop such an interest in the area that they go on to declare psychology as their major.']
['What is the result of this study?', 'As a result, psychology is one of the most popular majors on college campuses across the United States (Johnson & Lubin, 2011).']
['Who else studied psychology?', 'A number of well-known individuals were psychology majors.']

['Who were the famous individuals?', 'Just a few famous names on this list are Facebook’s creator Mark Zuckerberg, television personality and political satirist Jon Stewart, actress Natalie Portman, and filmmaker Wes Craven (Halonen, 2011).']

['How many people study psychology in the United States?', 'About 6 percent of all bachelor degrees granted in the United States are in the discipline of psychology (U.S. Department of Education, 2016).']
['Why is this title important?', 'An education in psychology is valuable for a number of reasons.']
['Why is that?', 'Psychology students hone critical thinking skills and are trained in the use of the scientific method.']
['What are critical thinking skills?', 'Critical thinking is the active application of a set of skills to information for the understanding and evaluation of that information.']

['What else is interesting about critical thinking?', 'The evaluation of information—assessing its reliability and usefulness— is an important skill in a world full of competing “facts,” many of which are designed to be misleading.']

['What kind of skills are critical thinking?', 'For example, critical thinking involves maintaining an attitude of skepticism, recognizing internal biases, making use of logical thinking, asking appropriate questions, and making observations.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects of this article?', 'Psychology students also can develop better communication skills during the course of their undergraduate coursework (American Psychological Association, 2011).']

['What are other benefits of studying psychology?', 'Together, these factors increase students’ scientific literacy and prepare students to critically evaluate the various sources of information they encounter.']
['What does it mean?', 'In addition to these broad-based skills, psychology students come to understand the complex factors that shape one’s behavior.']
['What does it mean to appreciate?', 'They appreciate the interaction of our biology, our environment, and our experiences in determining who we are and how we will behave.']

['What is the next major topic to address?', 'They learn about basic principles that guide how we think and behave, and they come to recognize the tremendous diversity that exists across individuals and across cultural boundaries (American Psychological Association, 2011).']

['What did the history of psychology consist of?', 'Psychology is a relatively young science with its experimental roots in the 19th century, compared, for example, to human physiology, which dates much earlier.']
['What other topics are covered?', 'As mentioned, anyone interested in exploring issues related to the mind generally did so in a philosophical context prior to the 19th century.']

['Who was the first psychologist?', 'Two 19th century scholars, Wilhelm Wundt and William James, are generally credited as being the founders of psychology as a science and academic discipline that was distinct from philosophy.']
['What other aspects are covered?', 'This section will provide an overview of the shifts in paradigms that have influenced psychology from Wundt and James through today.']
['who was Wilhelm Wundt?', 'Wilhelm Wundt (1832–1920) was a German scientist who was the first person to be referred to as a psychologist.']
['When was his book published?', 'His famous book entitled Principles of Physiological Psychology was published in 1873.']

['What was his main contribution to Psychology?', 'Wundt viewed psychology as a scientific study of conscious experience, and he believed that the goal of psychology was to identify components of consciousness and how those components combined to result in our conscious experience.']

['What is his method of study?', 'Wundt used introspection (he called it “internal perception”), a process by which someone examines their own conscious experience as objectively as possible, making the human mind like any other aspect of nature that a scientist observed.']

['What other contributions did Wundt make?', 'He believed in the notion of voluntarism—that people have free will and should know the intentions of a psychological experiment if they were participating (Danziger, 1980).']
['Was he successful in this?', 'Wundt considered his version experimental introspection; he used instruments such as those that measured reaction time.']
['What else did he do?', 'He also wrote Volkerpsychologie in 1904 in which he suggested that psychology should include the study of culture, as it involves the study of people.']
['Who were his students?', 'Edward Titchener, one of his students, went on to develop structuralism.']
['What was structuralism?', 'Its focus was on the contents of mental processes rather than their function (Pickren & Rutherford, 2010).']
['What did Wundt do after his work was completed?', 'Wundt established his psychology laboratory at the University at Leipzig in 1879.']
['Was he successful with this?', 'In this laboratory, Wundt and his students conducted experiments on, for example, reaction times.']
['How were they conducted?', 'A subject, sometimes in a room isolated from the scientist, would receive a stimulus such as a light, image, or sound.']
['What would they do?', 'The subject’s reaction to the stimulus would be to push a button, and an apparatus would record the time to reaction.']
['How accurate were the measurements?', 'Wundt could measure reaction time to one-thousandth of a second (Nicolas & Ferrand, 1999).']
['Who is part of this group?', 'William James, John Dewey, and Charles Sanders Peirce helped establish functional psychology.']
['What was this theory about?', 'They accepted Darwin’s theory of evolution by natural selection and viewed this theory as an explanation of an organism’s characteristics.']
['How did this theory relate to psychology?', 'Key to that theory is the idea that natural selection leads to organisms that are adapted to their environment, including their behavior.']
['What does this mean?', 'Adaptation means that a trait of an organism has a function for the survival and reproduction of the individual, because it has been naturally selected.']
['What did James think of functionalism?', 'As James saw it, psychology’s purpose was to study the function of behavior in the world, and as such, his perspective was known as functionalism.']
['What else did he think of functionalism?', 'Functionalism focused on how mental activities helped an organism fit into its environment.']

['What else can you tell me about functionalism?', 'Functionalism has a second, more subtle meaning in that functionalists were more interested in the operation of the whole mind rather than of its individual parts, which were the focus of structuralism.']

['What did he do to get this point across?', 'Like Wundt, James believed that introspection could serve as one means by which someone might study mental activities, but James also relied on more objective measures, including the use of various recording devices, and examinations of concrete products of mental activities and of anatomy and physiology (Gordon, 1995).']
['what else did you study?', 'Freud and Psychoanalytic']
['What did you study?', 'Theory.']
['What did you learn about Sigmund Freud?', 'Perhaps one of the most influential and well-known figures in psychology’s history was Sigmund Freud.']
['What was Freud a doctor of?', 'Freud (1856–1939) was an Austrian neurologist who was fascinated by patients suffering from “hysteria” and neurosis.']

['What was hysteria?', 'Hysteria was an ancient diagnosis for disorders, primarily of women with a wide variety of symptoms, including physical symptoms and emotional disturbances, none of which had an apparent physical cause.']
['What did Freud believe?', 'Freud theorized that many of his patients’ problems arose from the unconscious mind.']
['What does the unconscious mind consist of?', 'In Freud’s view, the unconscious mind was a repository of feelings and urges of which we have no awareness.']
['How can we gain access to the unconscious mind?', 'Gaining access to the unconscious, then, was crucial to the successful resolution of the patient’s problems.']

['What is one way of gaining access to the unconscious?', 'According to Freud, the unconscious mind could be accessed through dream analysis, by examinations of the first words that came to people’s minds, and through seemingly innocent slips of the tongue.']

['What did Freud believe?', 'Psychoanalytic theory focuses on the role of a person’s unconscious, as well as early childhood experiences, and this particular perspective dominated clinical psychology for several decades (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['What did Freud believe?', 'Freud’s ideas were influential, and you will learn more about them when you study lifespan development, personality, and therapy.']
['What is therapy?', 'For instance, many therapists believe strongly in the unconscious and the impact of early childhood experiences on the rest of a person’s life.']

['What was the most common method of psychoanalysis?', 'The method of psychoanalysis, which involves the patient talking about their experiences and selves, while not invented by Freud, was certainly popularized by him and is still used today.']
['What other ideas was Freud famous for?', 'Many of Freud’s other ideas, however, are controversial.']

['Who are some critics of Freud?', 'Drew Westen (1998) argues that many of the criticisms of Freud’s ideas are misplaced, in that they attack his older ideas without taking into account later writings.']

['Did he continue to write about Freud?', 'Westen also argues that critics fail to consider the success of the broad ideas that Freud introduced or developed, such as the importance of childhood experiences in adult motivations, the role of unconscious versus conscious motivations in driving our behavior, the fact that motivations can cause conflicts that affect behavior, the effects of mental representations of ourselves and others in guiding our interactions, and the development of personality over time.']
['What else did he say?', 'Westen identifies subsequent research support for all of these ideas.']

['What are some other things you can tell me about Functionalism?', 'More modern iterations of Freud’s clinical approach have been empirically demonstrated to be effective (Knekt et al., 2008; Shedler, 2010).']

['What are modern applications?', 'Some current practices in psychotherapy involve examining unconscious aspects of the self and relationships, often through the relationship between the therapist and the client.']

['What else can you tell me about functionalism?', 'Freud’s historical significance and contributions to clinical practice merit his inclusion in a discussion of the historical movements within psychology.']

['what is Wertheimer?', 'Max Wertheimer (1880–1943), Kurt Koffka (1886–1941), and Wolfgang Köhler (1887–1967) were three German psychologists who immigrated to the United States in the early 20th century to escape Nazi Germany.']
['what is Gestalt?', 'These scholars are credited with introducing psychologists in the United States to various Gestalt principles.']

['what are some examples?', 'The word Gestalt roughly translates to “whole;” a major emphasis of Gestalt psychology deals with the fact that although a sensory experience can be broken down into individual parts, how those parts relate to each other as a whole is often what the individual responds to in perception.']

['what is an example of this?', 'For example, a song may be made up of individual notes played by different instruments, but the real nature of the song is perceived in the combinations of these notes as they form the melody, rhythm, and harmony.']
['what is the difference between structuralism and Gestalt?', 'In many ways, this particular perspective would have directly contradicted Wundt’s ideas of structuralism (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['How did they accomplish their works?', 'Unfortunately, in moving to the United States, these scientists were forced to abandon much of their work and were unable to continue to conduct research on a large scale.']

['What happened after that?', 'These factors along with the rise of behaviorism (described next) in the United States prevented principles of Gestalt psychology from being as influential in the United States as they had been in their native Germany (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['What other issues were faced?', 'Despite these issues, several Gestalt principles are still very influential today.']

['What are the remaining principles of Gestalt psychology?', 'Considering the human individual as a whole rather than as a sum of individually measured parts became an important foundation in humanistic theory late in the century.']
['What else is significant about their work?', 'The ideas of Gestalt have continued to influence research on sensation and perception.']
['What kind of psychology is this?', 'Structuralism, Freud, and the Gestalt psychologists were all concerned in one way or another with describing and understanding inner experience.']

['What was interesting about this?', 'But other researchers had concerns that inner experience could be a legitimate subject of scientific inquiry and chose instead to exclusively study behavior, the objectively observable outcome of mental processes.']
["Who's this about?", 'Early work in the field of behavior was conducted by the Russian physiologist Ivan Pavlov (1849–1936).']

['What was his main focus?', 'Pavlov studied a form of learning behavior called a conditioned reflex, in which an animal or human produced a reflex (unconscious) response to a stimulus and, over time, was conditioned to produce the response to a different stimulus that the experimenter associated with the original stimulus.']
['What kind of reflexes did he work with?', 'The reflex Pavlov worked with was salivation in response to the presence of food.']

['How was this conditioned?', 'The salivation reflex could be elicited using a second stimulus, such as a specific sound, that was presented in association with the initial food stimulus several times.']
['When did it become conditioned?', 'Once the response to the second stimulus was “learned,” the food stimulus could be omitted.']
['What else does he study?', 'Pavlov’s “classical conditioning” is only one form of learning behavior studied by behaviorists.']
['Who was Watson?', 'John B. Watson (1878–1958) was an influential American psychologist whose most famous work occurred during the early 20th century at Johns Hopkins University.']
["What was Watson's views on conscious experience?", 'While Wundt and James were concerned with understanding conscious experience, Watson thought that the study of consciousness was flawed.']

['What did Watson think of the conscious experience?', 'Because he believed that objective analysis of the mind was impossible, Watson preferred to focus directly on observable behavior and try to bring that behavior under control.']

["What was Watson's theory?", 'Watson was a major proponent of shifting the focus of psychology from the mind to behavior, and this approach of observing and controlling behavior came to be known as behaviorism.']
['How was the study of behaviorism related to the mind?', 'A major object of study by behaviorists was learned behavior and its interaction with inborn qualities of the organism.']

['What were some of the animal experiments?', 'Behaviorism commonly used animals in experiments under the assumption that what was learned using animal models could, to some degree, be applied to human behavior.']

['What was the best example of animal behavior?', 'Indeed, Tolman (1938) stated, “I believe that everything important in psychology (except … such matters as involve society and words) can be investigated in essence through the continued experimental and theoretical analysis of the determiners of rat behavior at a choice-point in a maze.”']
['What is a behaviorist?', 'Behaviorism dominated experimental psychology for several decades, and its influence can still be felt today (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['How did behaviorism help the field of psychology?', 'Behaviorism is largely responsible for establishing psychology as a scientific discipline through its objective methods and especially experimentation.']
['How is behaviorism used today?', 'In addition, it is used in behavioral and cognitive-behavioral therapy.']
['What other uses does it have?', 'Behavior modification is commonly used in classroom settings.']
['What other uses has it had?', 'Behaviorism has also led to research on environmental influences on human behavior.']
['Who was Skinner?', 'B. F. Skinner (1904–1990) was an American psychologist.']
['What did he study?', 'Like Watson, Skinner was a behaviorist, and he concentrated on how behavior was affected by its consequences.']
['What did he call those consequences?', 'Therefore, Skinner spoke of reinforcement and punishment as major factors in driving behavior.']

['Did he perform any experiments?', 'As a part of his research, Skinner developed a chamber that allowed the careful study of the principles of modifying behavior through reinforcement and punishment.']

['What kind of chamber did he create?', 'This device, known as an operant conditioning chamber (or more familiarly, a Skinner box), has remained a crucial resource for researchers studying behavior (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['What was the Skinner box?', 'The Skinner box is a chamber that isolates the subject from the external environment and has a behavior indicator such as a lever or a button.']
['What are the buttons used for?', 'When the animal pushes the button or lever, the box is able to deliver a positive reinforcement of the behavior (such as food) or a punishment (such as a noise).']

['What happened with Skinner?', 'Skinner’s focus on positive and negative reinforcement of learned behaviors had a lasting influence in psychology that has waned somewhat since the growth of research in cognitive psychology.']
['Whose influence did it wane on?', 'Despite this, conditioned learning is still used in human behavioral modification (Greengrass, 2004).']
['What was the main aspect of their study?', 'During the early 20th century, American psychology was dominated by behaviorism and psychoanalysis.']
['Was that good?', 'However, some psychologists were uncomfortable with what they viewed as limited perspectives being so influential to the field.']
['What was their opinion?', 'They objected to the pessimism and determinism (all actions driven by the unconscious) of Freud.']
['What else did they object to?', 'They also disliked the reductionism, or simplifying nature, of behaviorism.']
['Was behaviorism right?', 'Behaviorism is also deterministic at its core, because it sees human behavior as entirely determined by a combination of genetics and environment.']

['What else did they dislike?', 'Some psychologists began to form their own ideas that emphasized personal control, intentionality, and a true predisposition for “good” as important for our self-concept and our behavior.']
['What was this?', 'Thus, humanism emerged.']
['What was humanism?', 'Humanism is a perspective within psychology that emphasizes the potential for good that is innate to all humans.']
['Who was the main proponent?', 'Two of the most well-known proponents of humanistic psychology are Abraham Maslow and Carl Rogers (O’Hara, n.d.).']
['Who is Maslow?', 'Abraham Maslow (1908–1970) was an American psychologist who is best known for proposing a hierarchy of human needs in motivating behavior.']
['Who is Rogers?', 'Although this concept will be discussed in more detail in a later chapter, a brief overview will be provided here.']

['Why are those two important?', 'Maslow asserted that so long as basic needs necessary for survival were met (e.g., food, water, shelter), higher-level needs (e.g., social needs) would begin to motivate behavior.']
['How are those needs met?', 'According to Maslow, the highest-level needs relate to self-actualization, a process by which we achieve our full potential.']
['Why is this important?', 'Obviously, the focus on the positive aspects of human nature that are characteristic of the humanistic perspective is evident (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['What are the other characteristics?', 'Humanistic psychologists rejected, on principle, the research approach based on reductionist experimentation in the tradition of the physical and biological sciences, because it missed the “whole” human being.']
['What else can you tell me about this article?', 'Beginning with Maslow and Rogers, there was an insistence on a humanistic research program.']

['Did they have this program approved?', 'This program has been largely qualitative (not measurement-based), but there exist a number of quantitative research strains within humanistic psychology, including research on happiness, self-concept, meditation, and the outcomes of humanistic psychotherapy (Friedman, 2008).']
['Who is Carl Rogers?', 'Carl Rogers (1902–1987) was also an American psychologist who, like Maslow, emphasized the potential for good that exists within all people.']
['What did he do?', 'Rogers used a therapeutic technique known as client-centered therapy in helping his clients deal with problematic issues that resulted in their seeking psychotherapy.']

['Why was that?', 'Unlike a psychoanalytic approach in which the therapist plays an important role in interpreting what conscious behavior reveals about the unconscious mind, client-centered therapy involves the patient taking a lead role in the therapy session.']

['What else did he believe?', 'Rogers believed that a therapist needed to display three features to maximize the effectiveness of this particular approach: unconditional positive regard, genuineness, and empathy.']
['What is unconditional positive regard?', 'Unconditional positive regard refers to the fact that the therapist accepts their client for who they are, no matter what they might say.']

['What are the features of genuineness and empathy?', 'Provided these factors, Rogers believed that people were more than capable of dealing with and working through their own issues (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
["What's so interesting about this?", 'Humanism has been influential to psychology as a whole.']
['Who are the authors?', 'Both Maslow and Rogers are well-known names among students of psychology (you will read more about both later in this text), and their ideas have influenced many scholars.']
['Did they have any theories?', 'Furthermore, Rogers’ client-centered approach to therapy is still commonly used in psychotherapeutic settings today (O’hara, n.d.)']

['What was the central question in this chapter?', 'Behaviorism’s emphasis on objectivity and focus on external behavior had pulled psychologists’ attention away from the mind for a prolonged period of time.']
['What did the humanistic psychologists do?', 'The early work of the humanistic psychologists redirected attention to the individual human as a whole, and as a conscious and self-aware being.']

['What was the role of linguistics and neuroscience?', 'By the 1950s, new disciplinary perspectives in linguistics, neuroscience, and computer science were emerging, and these areas revived interest in the mind as a focus of scientific inquiry.']
['What was the cognitive revolution?', 'This particular perspective has come to be known as the cognitive revolution (Miller, 2003).']

['Did this lead to an increased interest in psychology?', 'By 1967, Ulric Neisser published the first textbook entitled Cognitive Psychology, which served as a core text in cognitive psychology courses around the country (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['Who is Chomsky?', 'Although no one person is entirely responsible for starting the cognitive revolution, Noam Chomsky was very influential in the early days of this movement.']
['Did Chomsky have something to do with the cognitive revolution?', 'Chomsky (1928–), an American linguist, was dissatisfied with the influence that behaviorism had had on psychology.']

['Why was he dissatisfied?', 'He believed that psychology’s focus on behavior was short-sighted and that the field had to re-incorporate mental functioning into its purview if it were to offer any meaningful contributions to understanding behavior (Miller, 2003).']

['What is this about?', 'European psychology had never really been as influenced by behaviorism as had American psychology; and thus, the cognitive revolution helped reestablish lines of communication between European psychologists and their American counterparts.']

['What else happened in this time?', 'Furthermore, psychologists began to cooperate with scientists in other fields, like anthropology, linguistics, computer science, and neuroscience, among others.']

['What was the outcome of this collaboration?', 'This interdisciplinary approach often was referred to as the cognitive sciences, and the influence and prominence of this particular perspective resonates in modern-day psychology (Miller, 2003).']
['What is the relevance of this?', 'Culture impacts individuals, groups, and society.']

['What does the research say?', 'An ongoing issue researchers are trying to correct is that certain populations have been over-studied and the results of these studies have been applied to other populations.']
['What has this led to?', 'For example, Henrich, Heine, and Norenzayan discuss how WEIRD societies have been overstudied and the results have been wrongly applied to non-WEIRD societies (2010).']
['What does WEIRD stand for?', 'WEIRD stands for western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic.']

['What are the implications of this?', 'Henrich, Heine, and Norenzayan found that there are many differences between people in the WEIRD group and people in less industrialized, less urban, and non-Western societies.']
['What are these differences?', 'These differences occur in a variety of areas, including perception, cooperation, and moral reasoning.']
['What is culture?', 'That is, people vary depending on their culture and environment.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects in this article?', 'Multicultural psychologists develop theories and conduct research with diverse populations, typically within one country.']
['What is a cross-cultural study?', 'Cross-cultural psychologists compare populations across countries, such as participants from the United States compared to participants from China.']
["what was Sumner's role in this?", 'In 1920, Francis Cecil Sumner was the first African American to receive a PhD in psychology in the United States.']

['what happened after his degree?', 'Sumner established a psychology degree program at Howard University, leading to the education of a new generation of African American psychologists (Black, Spence, and Omari, 2004).']

['what else was significant?', 'Much of the work of early psychologists from diverse backgrounds was dedicated to challenging intelligence testing and promoting innovative educational methods for children.']
['who contested such testing with Mexican American children?', 'George I. Sanchez contested such testing with Mexican American children.']

['what was their argument?', 'As a psychologist of Mexican heritage, he pointed out that the language and cultural barriers in testing were keeping children from equal opportunities (Guthrie, 1998).']
['what happened after he had his PhD?', 'By 1940, he was teaching with his doctoral degree at University of Texas at Austin and challenging segregated educational practices (Romo, 1986).']
['What are some notable African American researchers and psychologists?', 'Two famous African American researchers and psychologists are Mamie Phipps Clark and her husband, Kenneth Clark.']

['What are Clark known for?', 'They are best known for their studies conducted on African American children and doll preference, research that was instrumental in the Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court desegregation case.']

['What happened after Brown v. Board of Education?', 'The Clarks applied their research to social services and opened the first child guidance center in Harlem (American Psychological Association, 2019).']

['What other interesting information can you share?', 'The American Psychological Association has several ethnically based organizations for professional psychologists that facilitate interactions among members.']

['What does the association do?', 'Since psychologists belonging to specific ethnic groups or cultures have the most interest in studying the psychology of their communities, these organizations provide an opportunity for the growth of research on the interplay between culture and psychology.']
['What does this title refer to?', 'Although rarely given credit, women have been contributing to psychology since its inception as a field of study.']
['What are the contributions of women to psychology?', 'In 1894, Margaret Floy Washburn was the first woman awarded the doctoral degree in psychology.']
['What did she do with her degree?', 'She wrote The Animal Mind: A Textbook of Comparative Psychology, and it was the standard in the field for over 20 years.']

['What else happened in the 1890s?', 'In the mid 1890s, Mary Whiton Calkins completed all requirements toward the PhD in psychology, but Harvard University refused to award her that degree because she was a woman.']
['What did they decide?', 'She had been taught and mentored by William James, who tried and failed to convince Harvard to award her the doctoral degree.']

['What else did she do?', 'Her memory research studied primacy and recency (Madigan & O’Hara, 1992), and she also wrote about how structuralism and functionalism both explained self-psychology (Calkins, 1906).']

['what is the first piece of information I gave you?', 'Another influential woman, Mary Cover Jones, conducted a study she considered to be a sequel to John B. Watson’s study of Little Albert (you’ll learn about this study in the chapter on Learning).']
['What was the study about?', 'Jones unconditioned fear in Little Peter, who had been afraid of rabbits (Jones, 1924).']

['What are some names of women in psychology?', 'Ethnic minority women contributing to the field of psychology include Martha Bernal and Inez Beverly Prosser; their studies were related to education.']
['What was significant about these women?', 'Bernal, the first Latina to earn her doctoral degree in psychology (1962) conducted much of her research with Mexican American children.']
['Which other women are significant?', 'Prosser was the first African American woman awarded the PhD in 1933 at the University of Cincinnati (Benjamin, Henry, & McMahon, 2005).']
['What is contemporary psychology?', 'Contemporary psychology is a diverse field that is influenced by all of the historical perspectives described in the preceding section.']
['What are some of the other influences?', 'Reflective of the discipline’s diversity is the diversity seen within the American Psychological Association (APA).']
['What does the APA do?', 'The APA is a professional organization representing psychologists in the United States.']
['What is its mission?', 'The APA is the largest organization of psychologists in the world, and its mission is to advance and disseminate psychological knowledge for the betterment of people.']

['What are some specialties of the APA?', 'There are 54 divisions within the APA, representing a wide variety of specialties that range from Societies for the Psychology of Religion and Spirituality to Exercise and Sport Psychology to Behavioral Neuroscience and Comparative Psychology.']

['Are there a lot of psychologists in the APA?', 'Reflecting the diversity of the field of psychology itself, members, affiliate members, and associate members span the spectrum from students to doctoral-level psychologists, and come from a variety of places including educational settings, criminal justice, hospitals, the armed forces, and industry (American Psychological Association, 2014).']
['Who was the first president?', 'G. Stanley Hall was the first president of the APA.']

['What else did Hall do?', 'Before he earned his doctoral degree, he was an adjunct instructor at Wilberforce University, a historically Black college/university (HBCU), while serving as faculty at Antioch College.']
['What was he trained in?', 'Hall went on to work under William James, earning his PhD.']
['Did Hall continue teaching or working?', 'Eventually, he became the first president of Clark University in Massachusetts when it was founded (Pickren & Rutherford, 2010).']
['What are some of the current advancements in this study?', 'The Association for Psychological Science (APS) was founded in 1988 and seeks to advance the scientific orientation of psychology.']
['Why was this established?', 'Its founding resulted from disagreements between members of the scientific and clinical branches of psychology within the APA.']
["What is the association's main purpose?", 'The APS publishes five research journals and engages in education and advocacy with funding agencies.']
['Where are the members from?', 'A significant proportion of its members are international, although the majority is located in the United States.']

['Are there any other major organizations in psychology?', 'Other organizations provide networking and collaboration opportunities for professionals of several ethnic or racial groups working in psychology, such as the National Latina/o Psychological Association (NLPA), the Asian American Psychological Association (AAPA), the Association of Black Psychologists (ABPsi), and the Society of Indian Psychologists (SIP).']
['What can you tell me about the other organizations?', 'Most of these groups are also dedicated to studying psychological and social issues within their specific communities.']

['What are the main topics?', 'This section will provide an overview of the major subdivisions within psychology today in the order in which they are introduced throughout the remainder of this textbook.']

['Who are the notable psychologists in this section?', 'This is not meant to be an exhaustive listing, but it will provide insight into the major areas of research and practice of modern-day psychologists.']
['What is Biopsychology?', 'As the name suggests, biopsychology explores how our biology influences our behavior.']

['What is biological psychology?', 'While biological psychology is a broad field, many biological psychologists want to understand how the structure and function of the nervous system is related to behavior.']

['What else is important about biological psychology?', 'As such, they often combine the research strategies of both psychologists and physiologists to accomplish this goal (as discussed in Carlson, 2013).']

['What does this article state about?', 'The research interests of biological psychologists span a number of domains, including but not limited to, sensory and motor systems, sleep, drug use and abuse, ingestive behavior, reproductive behavior, neurodevelopment, plasticity of the nervous system, and biological correlates of psychological disorders.']

['Who is involved?', 'Given the broad areas of interest falling under the purview of biological psychology, it will probably come as no surprise that individuals from all sorts of backgrounds are involved in this research, including biologists, medical professionals, physiologists, and chemists.']
['What is this part of?', 'This interdisciplinary approach is often referred to as neuroscience, of which biological psychology is a component (Carlson, 2013).']

['What is biopsychology?', 'While biopsychology typically focuses on the immediate causes of behavior based in the physiology of a human or other animal, evolutionary psychology seeks to study the ultimate biological causes of behavior.']

['What are some examples?', 'To the extent that a behavior is impacted by genetics, a behavior, like any anatomical characteristic of a human or animal, will demonstrate adaption to its surroundings.']
['What are the surroundings?', 'These surroundings include the physical environment and, since interactions between organisms can be important to survival and reproduction, the social environment.']
['What are some of the other factors?', 'The study of behavior in the context of evolution has its origins with Charles Darwin, the co-discoverer of the theory of evolution by natural selection.']

['What did he discover?', 'Darwin was well aware that behaviors should be adaptive and wrote books titled, The Descent of Man (1871) and The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals (1872), to explore this field.']
['What is the significance of this?', 'Evolutionary psychology, and specifically, the evolutionary psychology of humans, has enjoyed a resurgence in recent decades.']
['What is the evidence?', 'To be subject to evolution by natural selection, a behavior must have a significant genetic cause.']
['What can we infer from this?', 'In general, we expect all human cultures to express a behavior if it is caused genetically, since the genetic differences among human groups are small.']

['What is their approach?', 'The approach taken by most evolutionary psychologists is to predict the outcome of a behavior in a particular situation based on evolutionary theory and then to make observations, or conduct experiments, to determine whether the results match the theory.']

['What else can we learn from this?', 'It is important to recognize that these types of studies are not strong evidence that a behavior is adaptive, since they lack information that the behavior is in some part genetic and not entirely cultural (Endler, 1986).']

['What are the remaining questions?', 'Demonstrating that a trait, especially in humans, is naturally selected is extraordinarily difficult; perhaps for this reason, some evolutionary psychologists are content to assume the behaviors they study have genetic determinants (Confer et al., 2010).']

['What is one drawback of evolution?', 'One other drawback of evolutionary psychology is that the traits that we possess now evolved under environmental and social conditions far back in human history, and we have a poor understanding of what these conditions were.']
['What were these conditions?', 'This makes predictions about what is adaptive for a behavior difficult.']

['What else makes predictions difficult?', 'Behavioral traits need not be adaptive under current conditions, only under the conditions of the past when they evolved, about which we can only hypothesize.']
['What are some other important things to know about the material?', 'There are many areas of human behavior for which evolution can make predictions.']
['What are some examples?', 'Examples include memory, mate choice, relationships between kin, friendship and cooperation, parenting, social organization, and status (Confer et al., 2010).']

['What is the most important fact to know about Biopsychology and Evolutionary Psychology?', 'Evolutionary psychologists have had success in finding experimental correspondence between observations and expectations.']

['What are some examples of this?', 'In one example, in a study of mate preference differences between men and women that spanned 37 cultures, Buss (1989) found that women valued earning potential factors greater than men, and men valued potential reproductive factors (youth and attractiveness) greater than women in their prospective mates.']
['How does this relate to evolution?', 'In general, the predictions were in line with the predictions of evolution, although there were deviations in some cultures.']

['What is sensation and perception?', 'Scientists interested in both physiological aspects of sensory systems as well as in the psychological experience of sensory information work within the area of sensation and perception.']
['Are there other fields of study?', 'As such, sensation and perception research is also quite interdisciplinary.']
['Do you have any other questions?', 'Imagine walking between buildings as you move from one class to another.']
['What kind of sensory information do you get?', 'You are inundated with sights, sounds, touch sensations, and smells.']
['Are there any other types of sensations?', 'You also experience the temperature of the air around you and maintain your balance as you make your way.']
['What other information do you collect while walking?', 'These are all factors of interest to someone working in the domain of sensation and perception.']

["What's the most important thing in this content for us to know?", 'As described in a later chapter that focuses on the results of studies in sensation and perception, our experience of our world is not as simple as the sum total of all of the sensory information (or sensations) together.']
['Why is it not simple?', 'Rather, our experience (or perception) is complex and is influenced by where we focus our attention, our previous experiences, and even our cultural backgrounds.']

['What is Cognitive Psychology?', 'As mentioned in the previous section, the cognitive revolution created an impetus for psychologists to focus their attention on better understanding the mind and mental processes that underlie behavior.']

['What did the cognitive revolution accomplish?', 'Thus, cognitive psychology is the area of psychology that focuses on studying cognitions, or thoughts, and their relationship to our experiences and our actions.']

['What else is significant about the cognitive revolution?', 'Like biological psychology, cognitive psychology is broad in its scope and often involves collaborations among people from a diverse range of disciplinary backgrounds.']
['What else has this led to?', 'This has led some to coin the term cognitive science to describe the interdisciplinary nature of this area of research (Miller, 2003).']

['What are some important aspects of cognitive psychology?', 'Cognitive psychologists have research interests that span a spectrum of topics, ranging from attention to problem solving to language to memory.']
['What are the approaches used to study these topics?', 'The approaches used in studying these topics are equally diverse.']

['Can you elaborate on these topics?', 'Given such diversity, cognitive psychology is not captured in one chapter of this text per se; rather, various concepts related to cognitive psychology will be covered in relevant portions of the chapters in this text on sensation and perception, thinking and intelligence, memory, lifespan development, social psychology, and therapy.']
['What is Developmental Psychology?', 'Developmental psychology is the scientific study of development across a lifespan.']
['What is the study of development?', 'Developmental psychologists are interested in processes related to physical maturation.']

['What else does development include?', 'However, their focus is not limited to the physical changes associated with aging, as they also focus on changes in cognitive skills, moral reasoning, social behavior, and other psychological attributes.']

['What is Developmental Psychology?', 'Early developmental psychologists focused primarily on changes that occurred through reaching adulthood, providing enormous insight into the differences in physical, cognitive, and social capacities that exist between very young children and adults.']
['What are some important discoveries?', 'For instance, research by Jean Piaget demonstrated that very young children do not demonstrate object permanence.']
['What is object permanence?', 'Object permanence refers to the understanding that physical things continue to exist, even if they are hidden from us.']
['How do we learn object permanence?', 'If you were to show an adult a toy, and then hide it behind a curtain, the adult knows that the toy still exists.']
['Is there any difference in learning between children and adults?', 'However, very young infants act as if a hidden object no longer exists.']
['What else do you know about this topic?', 'The age at which object permanence is achieved is somewhat controversial (Munakata, McClelland, Johnson, and Siegler, 1997).']

['What does Developmental Psychology study?', 'While Piaget was focused on cognitive changes during infancy and childhood as we move to adulthood, there is an increasing interest in extending research into the changes that occur much later in life.']
['Why is this?', 'This may be reflective of changing population demographics of developed nations as a whole.']
['How has this changed?', 'As more and more people live longer lives, the number of people of advanced age will continue to increase.']
['What is an example?', 'Indeed, it is estimated that there were just over 40 million people aged 65 or older living in the United States in 2010.']
['How is that number expected to change?', 'However, by 2020, this number is expected to increase to about 55 million.']
['What else is important?', 'By the year 2050, it is estimated that nearly 90 million people in this country will be 65 or older (Department of Health and Human Services, n.d.).']
['What is this about?', 'Personality psychology focuses on patterns of thoughts and behaviors that make each individual unique.']

['Who invented this concept?', 'Several individuals (e.g., Freud and Maslow) that we have already discussed in our historical overview of psychology, and the American psychologist Gordon Allport, contributed to early theories of personality.']
['What are their theories?', 'These early theorists attempted to explain how an individual’s personality develops from their given perspective.']
['What are their theories?', 'For example, Freud proposed that personality arose as conflicts between the conscious and unconscious parts of the mind were carried out over the lifespan.']
['Did he have more?', 'Specifically, Freud theorized that an individual went through various psychosexual stages of development.']

['How does he explain this?', 'According to Freud, adult personality would result from the resolution of various conflicts that centered on the migration of erogenous (or sexual pleasure-producing) zones from the oral (mouth) to the anus to the phallus to the genitals.']
['What is his theory against?', 'Like many of Freud’s theories, this particular idea was controversial and did not lend itself to experimental tests (Person, 1980).']
['What does it mean to study personality?', 'More recently, the study of personality has taken on a more quantitative approach.']

['What do the quantitative studies focus on?', 'Rather than explaining how personality arises, research is focused on identifying personality traits, measuring these traits, and determining how these traits interact in a particular context to determine how a person will behave in any given situation.']

['What are the five dimensions?', 'Personality traits are relatively consistent patterns of thought and behavior, and many have proposed that five trait dimensions are sufficient to capture the variations in personality seen across individuals.']

['What are the five dimensions?', 'These five dimensions are known as the “Big Five” or the Five Factor model, and include dimensions of conscientiousness, agreeableness, neuroticism, openness, and extraversion.']

['Are there other dimensions?', 'Each of these traits has been demonstrated to be relatively stable over the lifespan (e.g., Rantanen, Metsäpelto, Feldt, Pulkinnen, and Kokko, 2007; Soldz & Vaillant, 1999; McCrae & Costa, 2008) and is influenced by genetics (e.g., Jang, Livesly, and Vernon, 1996).']
['what is social psychology?', 'Social psychology focuses on how we interact with and relate to others.']

['what is something else?', 'Social psychologists conduct research on a wide variety of topics that include differences in how we explain our own behavior versus how we explain the behaviors of others, prejudice, and attraction, and how we resolve interpersonal conflicts.']
['what else?', 'Social psychologists have also sought to determine how being among other people changes our own behavior and patterns of thinking.']

['What is one example of this that you can tell me about?', 'There are many interesting examples of social psychological research, and you will read about many of these in a later chapter of this textbook.']
['What happened after that chapter?', 'Until then, you will be introduced to one of the most controversial psychological studies ever conducted.']
['Who conducted this study?', 'Stanley Milgram was an American social psychologist who is most famous for research that he conducted on obedience.']
['What was the Eichmann trial?', 'After the holocaust, in 1961, a Nazi war criminal, Adolf Eichmann, who was accused of committing mass atrocities, was put on trial.']

['What was the public opinion about his guilt?', 'Many people wondered how German soldiers were capable of torturing prisoners in concentration camps, and they were unsatisfied with the excuses given by soldiers that they were simply following orders.']
['Why was that thought so?', 'At the time, most psychologists agreed that few people would be willing to inflict such extraordinary pain and suffering, simply because they were obeying orders.']
['What did Milgram find out?', 'Milgram decided to conduct research to determine whether or not this was true.']

['What did he find out?', 'As you will read later in the text, Milgram found that nearly two-thirds of his participants were willing to deliver what they believed to be lethal shocks to another person, simply because they were instructed to do so by an authority figure (in this case, a man dressed in a lab coat).']

['Why were they willing to do this?', 'This was in spite of the fact that participants received payment for simply showing up for the research study and could have chosen not to inflict pain or more serious consequences on another person by withdrawing from the study.']

['What happened after the experiment?', 'No one was actually hurt or harmed in any way, Milgram’s experiment was a clever ruse that took advantage of research confederates, those who pretend to be participants in a research study who are actually working for the researcher and have clear, specific directions on how to behave during the research study (Hock, 2009).']

['Did anyone object to his experiments?', 'Milgram’s and others’ studies that involved deception and potential emotional harm to study participants catalyzed the development of ethical guidelines for conducting psychological research that discourage the use of deception of research subjects, unless it can be argued not to cause harm and, in general, requiring informed consent of participants.']

['What is I-O psychology?', 'Industrial-Organizational psychology (I-O psychology) is a subfield of psychology that applies psychological theories, principles, and research findings in industrial and organizational settings.']
['What are some of the most common aspects of I-O psychology?', 'I-O psychologists are often involved in issues related to personnel management, organizational structure, and workplace environment.']

['What problems do psychologists solve?', 'Businesses often seek the aid of I-O psychologists to make the best hiring decisions as well as to create an environment that results in high levels of employee productivity and efficiency.']
['What else is unique about I-O psychology?', 'In addition to its applied nature, I-O psychology also involves conducting scientific research on behavior within I-O settings (Riggio, 2013).']
['What is it about?', 'Health psychology focuses on how health is affected by the interaction of biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors.']
['What is the approach?', 'This particular approach is known as the biopsychosocial model.']
['What are the fields of study?', 'Health psychologists are interested in helping individuals achieve better health through public policy, education, intervention, and research.']

['What else does the field focus on?', 'Health psychologists might conduct research that explores the relationship between one’s genetic makeup, patterns of behavior, relationships, psychological stress, and health.']

['What can be done about the relationship between health and these?', 'They may research effective ways to motivate people to address patterns of behavior that contribute to poorer health (MacDonald, 2013).']

['What is sport and exercise psychology?', 'Researchers in sport and exercise psychology study the psychological aspects of sport performance, including motivation and performance anxiety, and the effects of sport on mental and emotional wellbeing.']
['What else does it focus on?', 'Research is also conducted on similar topics as they relate to physical exercise in general.']

['Is there anything else that is important about it?', 'The discipline also includes topics that are broader than sport and exercise but that are related to interactions between mental and physical performance under demanding conditions, such as fire fighting, military operations, artistic performance, and surgery.']
['What is Clinical Psychology?', 'Clinical psychology is the area of psychology that focuses on the diagnosis and treatment of psychological disorders and other problematic patterns of behavior.']
['How is it applied?', 'As such, it is generally considered to be a more applied area within psychology; however, some clinicians are also actively engaged in scientific research.']

['Is there another type of psychology?', 'Counseling psychology is a similar discipline that focuses on emotional, social, vocational, and health-related outcomes in individuals who are considered psychologically healthy.']

['What are some of the important things to learn about Clinical Psychology?', 'As mentioned earlier, both Freud and Rogers provided perspectives that have been influential in shaping how clinicians interact with people seeking psychotherapy.']

['What was one of the theories that they were working with?', 'While aspects of the psychoanalytic theory are still found among some of today’s therapists who are trained from a psychodynamic perspective, Roger’s ideas about client-centered therapy have been especially influential in shaping how many clinicians operate.']

['What other theories did they work with?', 'Furthermore, both behaviorism and the cognitive revolution have shaped clinical practice in the forms of behavioral therapy, cognitive therapy, and cognitive-behavioral therapy.']

['What else does the article talk about?', 'Issues related to the diagnosis and treatment of psychological disorders and problematic patterns of behavior will be discussed in detail in later chapters of this textbook.']
['What is forensic psychology?', 'Forensic psychology is a branch of psychology that deals questions of psychology as they arise in the context of the justice system.']

['What does it do in the justice system?', 'For example, forensic psychologists (and forensic psychiatrists) will assess a person’s competency to stand trial, assess the state of mind of a defendant, act as consultants on child custody cases, consult on sentencing and treatment recommendations, and advise on issues such as eyewitness testimony and children’s testimony (American Board of Forensic Psychology, 2014).']
['What can they advise on?', 'In these capacities, they will typically act as expert witnesses, called by either side in a court case to provide their research- or experience-based opinions.']

['What else do they do as expert witnesses?', 'As expert witnesses, forensic psychologists must have a good understanding of the law and provide information in the context of the legal system rather than just within the realm of psychology.']
['What else can they do?', 'Forensic psychologists are also used in the jury selection process and witness preparation.']
['What else do they do?', 'They may also be involved in providing psychological treatment within the criminal justice system.']
['What is the criminal profile?', 'Criminal profilers are a relatively small proportion of psychologists that act as consultants to law enforcement.']
['What are the different careers?', 'Psychologists can work in many different places doing many different things.']

['What are some of the specialties?', 'In general, anyone wishing to continue a career in psychology at a 4-year institution of higher education will have to earn a doctoral degree in psychology for some specialties and at least a master’s degree for others.']
['What is a doctoral degree?', 'In most areas of psychology, this means earning a PhD in a relevant area of psychology.']
["What does the 'PhD' mean?", 'Literally, PhD refers to a doctor of philosophy degree, but here, philosophy does not refer to the field of philosophy per se.']
['Why not?', 'Rather, philosophy in this context refers to many different disciplinary perspectives that would be housed in a traditional college of liberal arts and sciences.']

['What are the requirements to earn a PhD?', 'The requirements to earn a PhD vary from country to country and even from school to school, but usually, individuals earning this degree must complete a dissertation.']
['What is a dissertation?', 'A dissertation is essentially a long research paper or bundled published articles describing research that was conducted as a part of the candidate’s doctoral training.']
['Do you have to be involved in research?', 'In the United States, a dissertation generally has to be defended before a committee of expert reviewers before the degree is conferred.']
['What are the jobs of PhDs in psychology?', 'Once someone earns a PhD, they may seek a faculty appointment at a college or university.']
['What type of duties do they have?', 'Being on the faculty of a college or university often involves dividing time between teaching, research, and service to the institution and profession.']

['How much time do they spend on each?', 'The amount of time spent on each of these primary responsibilities varies dramatically from school to school, and it is not uncommon for faculty to move from place to place in search of the best personal fit among various academic environments.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects of this article?', 'The previous section detailed some of the major areas that are commonly represented in psychology departments around the country; thus, depending on the training received, an individual could be anything from a biological psychologist to a clinical psychologist in an academic setting.']
['Why do people want to teach in academic settings?', 'Often times, schools offer more courses in psychology than their full-time faculty can teach.']
['Are adjunct faculty members and instructors considered full-time or part-time?', 'In these cases, it is not uncommon to bring in an adjunct faculty member or instructor.']

['What qualifications do these people have?', 'Adjunct faculty members and instructors usually have an advanced degree in psychology, but they often have primary careers outside of academia and serve in this role as a secondary job.']
['Why did they have a second job?', 'Alternatively, they may not hold the doctoral degree required by most 4-year institutions and use these opportunities to gain experience in teaching.']
['Are there any other jobs they do?', 'Furthermore, many 2-year colleges and schools need faculty to teach their courses in psychology.']

['How do they get these jobs?', 'In general, many of the people who pursue careers at these institutions have master’s degrees in psychology, although some PhDs make careers at these institutions as well.']
['What are other careers in academic settings?', 'Some people earning PhDs may enjoy research in an academic setting.']
['Who is a PhD?', 'However, they may not be interested in teaching.']
['What would these people do instead?', 'These individuals might take on faculty positions that are exclusively devoted to conducting research.']
['What kind of research would they do?', 'This type of position would be more likely an option at large, research-focused universities.']

['What are other careers in academic settings?', 'In some areas in psychology, it is common for individuals who have recently earned their PhD to seek out positions in postdoctoral training programs that are available before going on to serve as faculty.']
['How do you become a faculty?', 'In most cases, young scientists will complete one or two postdoctoral programs before applying for a full-time faculty position.']

['What is a postdoctoral program?', 'Postdoctoral training programs allow young scientists to further develop their research programs and broaden their research skills under the supervision of other professionals in the field.']

['What are some of the options for career development?', 'Individuals who wish to become practicing clinical psychologists have another option for earning a doctoral degree, which is known as a PsyD.']
['What is the PsyD?', 'A PsyD is a doctor of psychology degree that is increasingly popular among individuals interested in pursuing careers in clinical psychology.']

['What are some key characteristics of the PsyD?', 'PsyD programs generally place less emphasis on research-oriented skills and focus more on application of psychological principles in the clinical context (Norcross & Castle, 2002).']

['Is this the full study material?', 'Regardless of whether earning a PhD or PsyD, in most states, an individual wishing to practice as a licensed clinical or counseling psychologist may complete postdoctoral work under the supervision of a licensed psychologist.']

['How long does it take to be licensed?', 'Within the last few years, however, several states have begun to remove this requirement, which would allow people to get an earlier start in their careers (Munsey, 2009).']
['What are the state requirements?', 'After an individual has met the state requirements, their credentials are evaluated to determine whether they can sit for the licensure exam.']
['What are the exams?', 'Only individuals that pass this exam can call themselves licensed clinical or counseling psychologists (Norcross, n.d.).']
['How do licensed psychologists work?', 'Licensed clinical or counseling psychologists can then work in a number of settings, ranging from private clinical practice to hospital settings.']
['Do they do the same work as psychiatrists?', 'It should be noted that clinical psychologists and psychiatrists do different things and receive different types of education.']
['What degrees do psychiatrists have?', 'While both can conduct therapy and counseling, clinical psychologists have a PhD or a PsyD, whereas psychiatrists have a doctor of medicine degree (MD).']
['What are some examples of the differences?', 'As such, licensed clinical psychologists can administer and interpret psychological tests, while psychiatrists can prescribe medications.']
['What are some career options outside of academic settings?', 'Individuals earning a PhD can work in a variety of settings, depending on their areas of specialization.']
['What other types of careers do they have?', 'For example, someone trained as a biopsychologist might work in a pharmaceutical company to help test the efficacy of a new drug.']

['What else does that career involve?', 'Someone with a clinical background might become a forensic psychologist and work within the legal system to make recommendations during criminal trials and parole hearings, or serve as an expert in a court case.']

['What can you tell me about this material?', 'While earning a doctoral degree in psychology is a lengthy process, usually taking between 5–6 years of graduate study (DeAngelis, 2010), there are a number of careers that can be attained with a master’s degree in psychology.']
['How long does it take to get licensed?', 'People who wish to provide psychotherapy can become licensed to serve as various types of professional counselors (Hoffman, 2012).']

["What other options are there for a master's degree?", 'Relevant master’s degrees are also sufficient for individuals seeking careers as school psychologists (National Association of School Psychologists, n.d.), in some capacities related to sport psychology (American Psychological Association, 2014), or as consultants in various industrial settings (Landers, 2011, June 14).']

['What do undergrads have to do?', 'Undergraduate coursework in psychology may be applicable to other careers such as psychiatric social work or psychiatric nursing, where assessments and therapy may be a part of the job.']

['How can we become a psychologist?', 'As mentioned in the opening section of this chapter, an undergraduate education in psychology is associated with a knowledge base and skill set that many employers find quite attractive.']

['What other jobs do they have?', 'It should come as no surprise, then, that individuals earning bachelor’s degrees in psychology find themselves in a number of different careers, as shown in Table 1.1.']
['What else can you tell me?', 'Examples of a few such careers can involve serving as case managers, working in sales, working in human resource departments, and teaching in high schools.']
['What else did you tell me?', 'The rapidly growing realm of healthcare professions is another field in which an education in psychology is helpful and sometimes required.']

['What can you tell me about healthcare?', 'For example, the Medical College Admission Test (MCAT) exam that people must take to be admitted to medical school now includes a section on the psychological foundations of behavior.']
['What is this about?', 'Scientific research is a critical tool for successfully navigating our complex world.']
['Why is it so important?', 'Without it, we would be forced to rely solely on intuition, other people’s authority, and blind luck.']

['What else is said in this passage?', 'While many of us feel confident in our abilities to decipher and interact with the world around us, history is filled with examples of how very wrong we can be when we fail to recognize the need for evidence in supporting claims.']

['What were some of those examples?', 'At various times in history, we would have been certain that the sun revolved around a flat earth, that the earth’s continents did not move, and that mental illness was caused by possession.']

['What else is mentioned in this passage?', 'It is through systematic scientific research that we divest ourselves of our preconceived notions and superstitions and gain an objective understanding of ourselves and our world.']
['What is the goal of research?', 'The goal of all scientists is to better understand the world around them.']
['What are some topics of research?', 'Psychologists focus their attention on understanding behavior, as well as the cognitive (mental) and physiological (body) processes that underlie behavior.']

['What else is important about research?', 'In contrast to other methods that people use to understand the behavior of others, such as intuition and personal experience, the hallmark of scientific research is that there is evidence to support a claim.']
['How is science different from other knowledge?', 'Scientific knowledge is empirical:']
['Why is it empirical?', 'It is grounded in objective, tangible evidence that can be observed time and time again, regardless of who is observing.']
['What did you want to know about brain, mind, and behavior?', 'While behavior is observable, the mind is not.']
['Why is that?', 'If someone is crying, we can see behavior.']
['What is the cause of the cry?', 'However, the reason for the behavior is more difficult to determine.']
['Why is that?', 'Sometimes we can learn the reason for someone’s behavior by simply asking a question, like “Why are you crying?”']
['Why would you ask that?', 'However, there are situations in which an individual is either uncomfortable or unwilling to answer the question honestly, or is incapable of answering.']
['How is that true?', 'For example, infants would not be able to explain why they are crying.']
['What happens in such circumstances?', 'In such circumstances, the psychologist must be creative in finding ways to better understand behavior.']

['Why do we need to know about knowledge?', 'This chapter explores how scientific knowledge is generated, and how important that knowledge is in forming decisions in our personal lives and in the public domain.']

['What are some of the problems that may arise from using research information?', 'Trying to determine which theories are and are not accepted by the scientific community can be difficult, especially in an area of research as broad as psychology.']

['What are some of the challenges you had with this information?', 'More than ever before, we have an incredible amount of information at our fingertips, and a simple internet search on any given research topic might result in a number of contradictory studies.']

['Why would that be important?', 'In these cases, we are witnessing the scientific community going through the process of reaching a consensus, and it could be quite some time before a consensus emerges.']
['What might that mean for us?', 'For example, the explosion in our use of technology has led researchers to question whether this ultimately helps or hinders us.']
['Is there any other information that you want me to know?', 'The use and implementation of technology in educational settings has become widespread over the last few decades.']
['What does that mean?', 'Researchers are coming to different conclusions regarding the use of technology.']

['Is there any other information that you want me to know?', 'To illustrate this point, a study investigating a smartphone app targeting surgery residents (graduate students in surgery training) found that the use of this app can increase student engagement and raise test scores (Shaw & Tan, 2015).']

['What was that study about?', 'Conversely, another study found that the use of technology in undergraduate student populations had negative impacts on sleep, communication, and time management skills (Massimini & Peterson, 2009).']

['What does that mean?', "Until sufficient amounts of research have been conducted, there will be no clear consensus on the effects that technology has on a student's acquisition of knowledge, study skills, and mental health."]
['What does this information consist of?', 'In the meantime, we should strive to think critically about the information we encounter by exercising a degree of healthy skepticism.']

['What is the healthy skepticism?', 'This is especially important when we consider how much information in advertising campaigns and on the internet claims to be based on “scientific evidence” when in actuality it is a belief or perspective of just a few individuals trying to sell a product or draw attention to their perspectives.']

['What are the main ideas of Use of Research Information?', 'We should be informed consumers of the information made available to us because decisions based on this information have significant consequences.']
['What are some consequences?', 'One such consequence can be seen in politics and public policy.']
['How can research be used to make a decision?', 'Imagine that you have been elected as the governor of your state.']
['What responsibilities do you have?', 'One of your responsibilities is to manage the state budget and determine how to best spend your constituents’ tax dollars.']
['What are some things that you have to consider?', 'As the new governor, you need to decide whether to continue funding early intervention programs.']
['What do these programs accomplish?', 'These programs are designed to help children who come from low-income backgrounds, have special needs, or face other disadvantages.']

['What are the benefits of these programs?', "These programs may involve providing a wide variety of services to maximize the children's development and position them for optimal levels of success in school and later in life (Blann, 2005)."]
['How is this information useful?', 'While such programs sound appealing, you would want to be sure that they also proved effective before investing additional money in these programs.']

['What evidence does this have?', 'Fortunately, psychologists and other scientists have conducted vast amounts of research on such programs and, in general, the programs are found to be effective (Neil & Christensen, 2009; Peters-Scheffer, Didden, Korzilius, & Sturmey, 2011).']

['How long are the benefits?', 'While not all programs are equally effective, and the short-term effects of many such programs are more pronounced, there is reason to believe that many of these programs produce long-term benefits for participants (Barnett, 2011).']
['What else do you think about this topic?', 'If you are committed to being a good steward of taxpayer money, you would want to look at research.']
['What happens next?', 'After examining the research, you would be best equipped to make decisions about which programs to fund.']
['What does Use of Research Information mean?', 'Ultimately, it is not just politicians who can benefit from using research in guiding their decisions.']
['What can we all benefit from research in guiding our decisions?', 'We all might look to research from time to time when making decisions in our lives.']
['What is the best example you can give to illustrate the usage of research?', "Imagine you just found out that your sister Maria's child, Umberto, was recently diagnosed with autism."]
['What can you do to help her with the autism?', 'There are many treatments for autism that help decrease the negative impact of autism on the individual.']

['What treatments do you mean?', 'Some examples of treatments for autism are applied behavior analysis (ABA), social communication groups, social skills groups, occupational therapy, and even medication options.']
['What can you do to help her?', 'You would likely want to review the research and learn about the efficacy of each treatment so you could best advise your sister.']
['What can you tell me about the significance of research?', 'In the end, research is what makes the difference between facts and opinions.']
['What are facts and opinions?', 'Facts are observable realities, and opinions are personal judgments, conclusions, or attitudes that may or may not be accurate.']
['How are facts established?', 'In the scientific community, facts can be established only using evidence collected through empirical research.']
['What is the significance of these researchers?', 'Psychological research has a long history involving important figures from diverse backgrounds.']

['What are some notable names?', 'While the introductory chapter discussed several researchers who made significant contributions to the discipline, there are many more individuals who deserve attention in considering how psychology has advanced as a science through their work.']
['Which women?', 'For instance, Margaret Floy Washburn (1871–1939) was the first woman to earn a PhD in psychology.']
['What did she study?', 'Her research focused on animal behavior and cognition (Margaret Floy Washburn, PhD, n.d.).']
