['What did she study?', 'Mary Whiton Calkins (1863–1930) was a preeminent first-generation American psychologist who opposed the behaviorist movement, conducted significant research into memory, and established one of the earliest experimental psychology labs in the United States (Mary Whiton Calkins, n.d.).']
['Who was the first African American to receive a PhD in psychology?', 'Francis Sumner (1895–1954) was the first African American to receive a PhD in psychology in 1920.']
['What was the title of his dissertation?', 'His dissertation focused on issues related to psychoanalysis.']
['What did he do after his PhD?', 'Sumner also had research interests in racial bias and educational justice.']

['How is he known?', 'Sumner was one of the founders of Howard University’s department of psychology, and because of his accomplishments, he is sometimes referred to as the “Father of Black Psychology.”']
['When did she get her PhD?', 'Thirteen years later, Inez Beverly Prosser (1895–1934) became the first African American woman to receive a PhD in psychology.']

['What did she research?', 'Prosser’s research highlighted issues related to education in segregated versus integrated schools, and ultimately, her work was very influential in the hallmark Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court ruling that segregation of public schools was unconstitutional (Ethnicity and Health in America Series: Featured Psychologists, n.d.).']

['Where does this text come from?', 'Although the establishment of psychology’s scientific roots occurred first in Europe and the United States, it did not take much time until researchers from around the world began to establish their own laboratories and research programs.']

['Who did it?', 'For example, some of the first experimental psychology laboratories in South America were founded by Horatio Piñero (1869–1919) at two institutions in Buenos Aires, Argentina (Godoy & Brussino, 2010).']

['Who else did it?', 'In India, Gunamudian David Boaz (1908–1965) and Narendra Nath Sen Gupta (1889–1944) established the first independent departments of psychology at the University of Madras and the University of Calcutta, respectively.']

['What happened in India?', 'These developments provided an opportunity for Indian researchers to make important contributions to the field (Gunamudian David Boaz, n.d.; Narendra Nath Sen Gupta, n.d.).']

['What can you tell me about the historical aspects of APA?', 'When the American Psychological Association (APA) was first founded in 1892, all of the members were White males (Women and Minorities in Psychology, n.d.).']

['Who was the first female member?', 'However, by 1905, Mary Whiton Calkins was elected as the first female president of the APA, and by 1946, nearly one-quarter of American psychologists were female.']

['What else can you tell me about the demographics?', 'Psychology became a popular degree option for students enrolled in the nation’s historically Black higher education institutions, increasing the number of Black Americans who went on to become psychologists.']

['What are other aspects of the history?', 'Given demographic shifts occurring in the United States and increased access to higher educational opportunities among historically underrepresented populations, there is reason to hope that the diversity of the field will increasingly match the larger population, and that the research contributions made by the psychologists of the future will better serve people of all backgrounds (Women and Minorities in Psychology, n.d.).']
['How is scientific knowledge advanced?', 'Scientific knowledge is advanced through a process known as the scientific method.']

['How does the scientific method work?', 'Basically, ideas (in the form of theories and hypotheses) are tested against the real world (in the form of empirical observations), and those empirical observations lead to more ideas that are tested against the real world, and so on.']
['What else can you tell me about the scientific method?', 'In this sense, the scientific process is circular.']
['What does that mean?', 'The types of reasoning within the circle are called deductive and inductive.']
['What does deductive reasoning mean?', 'In deductive reasoning, ideas are tested in the real world; in inductive reasoning, real-world observations lead to new ideas.']

['What happens after you test your ideas?', 'These processes are inseparable, like inhaling and exhaling, but different research approaches place different emphasis on the deductive and inductive aspects.']
['How does this relate to science?', 'In the scientific context, deductive reasoning begins with a generalization—one hypothesis—that is then used to reach logical conclusions about the real world.']
['What is the hypothesis?', 'If the hypothesis is correct, then the logical conclusions reached through deductive reasoning should also be correct.']
['What is an argument?', 'A deductive reasoning argument might go something like this:']
['What does energy have to do with it?', 'All living things require energy to survive (this would be your hypothesis).']
['How do ducks survive?', 'Ducks are living things.']
['What are they doing to require energy?', 'Therefore, ducks require energy to survive (logical conclusion).']
['Is this what it is about?', 'In this example, the hypothesis is correct; therefore, the conclusion is correct as well.']
['What is the problem?', 'Sometimes, however, an incorrect hypothesis may lead to a logical but incorrect conclusion.']
['What happened in the other example?', 'Consider this argument: all ducks are born with the ability to see.']
['What is this about?', 'Quackers is a duck.']
['Does this mean quackers is blind?', 'Therefore, Quackers was born with the ability to see.']
['Why does it have to do with it?', 'Scientists use deductive reasoning to empirically test their hypotheses.']

['Is this all there is to it?', 'Returning to the example of the ducks, researchers might design a study to test the hypothesis that if all living things require energy to survive, then ducks will be found to require energy to survive.']
['what is deductive reasoning?', 'Deductive reasoning starts with a generalization that is tested against real-world observations; however, inductive reasoning moves in the opposite direction.']
['what is inductive reasoning?', 'Inductive reasoning uses empirical observations to construct broad generalizations.']
['why does this matter?', 'Unlike deductive reasoning, conclusions drawn from inductive reasoning may or may not be correct, regardless of the observations on which they are based.']
['what is an example of this?', 'For instance, you may notice that your favorite fruits—apples, bananas, and oranges—all grow on trees; therefore, you assume that all fruit must grow on trees.']

['are there other examples?', 'This would be an example of inductive reasoning, and, clearly, the existence of strawberries, blueberries, and kiwi demonstrate that this generalization is not correct despite it being based on a number of direct observations.']
['how is this used in scientific research?', 'Scientists use inductive reasoning to formulate theories, which in turn generate hypotheses that are tested with deductive reasoning.']
['what happens after you test it?', 'In the end, science involves both deductive and inductive processes.']
['What are some examples of the empirical observations?', 'For example, case studies, which you will read about in the next section, are heavily weighted on the side of empirical observations.']

['Are there any other examples of empirical observations?', 'Thus, case studies are closely associated with inductive processes as researchers gather massive amounts of observations and seek interesting patterns (new ideas) in the data.']
['What kind of experiments are conducted?', 'Experimental research, on the other hand, puts great emphasis on deductive reasoning.']
['What is a theory?', 'A theory is a well-developed set of ideas that propose an explanation for observed phenomena.']

['What is a hypothesis?', 'Theories are repeatedly checked against the world, but they tend to be too complex to be tested all at once; instead, researchers create hypotheses to test specific aspects of a theory.']

['What is a hypothesis?', 'A hypothesis is a testable prediction about how the world will behave if our idea is correct, and it is often worded as an if-then statement (e.g., if I study all night, I will get a passing grade on the test).']
['Why is this important?', 'The hypothesis is extremely important because it bridges the gap between the realm of ideas and the real world.']
['What is the process of scientific research?', 'As specific hypotheses are tested, theories are modified and refined to reflect and incorporate the result of these tests Figure 2.5.']
['What is the research question?', 'To see how this process works, let’s consider a specific theory and a hypothesis that might be generated from that theory.']

['What is the James-Lange theory of emotion?', 'As you’ll learn in a later chapter, the James-Lange theory of emotion asserts that emotional experience relies on the physiological arousal associated with the emotional state.']
['How do they do that?', 'If you walked out of your home and discovered a very aggressive snake waiting on your doorstep, your heart would begin to race and your stomach churn.']
['What will happen to you as your heart races?', 'According to the James-Lange theory, these physiological changes would result in your feeling of fear.']

['What is a hypothesis?', 'A hypothesis that could be derived from this theory might be that a person who is unaware of the physiological arousal that the sight of the snake elicits will not feel fear.']
['What is a scientific hypothesis?', 'A scientific hypothesis is also falsifiable, or capable of being shown to be incorrect.']
['What is the importance of scientific hypothesis in human behavior?', 'Recall from the introductory chapter that Sigmund Freud had lots of interesting ideas to explain various human behaviors.']

['What other ideas were there?', 'However, a major criticism of Freud’s theories is that many of his ideas are not falsifiable; for example, it is impossible to imagine empirical observations that would disprove the existence of the id, the ego, and the superego—the three elements of personality described in Freud’s theories.']

['What are some other examples of unfalsifiable ideas?', 'Despite this, Freud’s theories are widely taught in introductory psychology texts because of their historical significance for personality psychology and psychotherapy, and these remain the root of all modern forms of therapy.']
['What was the main idea of that section?', 'In contrast, the James-Lange theory does generate falsifiable hypotheses, such as the one described above.']

['What is the next topic you need to know?', 'Some individuals who suffer significant injuries to their spinal columns are unable to feel the bodily changes that often accompany emotional experiences.']

['Why was that hypotheses?', 'Therefore, we could test the hypothesis by determining how emotional experiences differ between individuals who have the ability to detect these changes in their physiological arousal and those who do not.']

['Does this hypothesis hold true?', 'In fact, this research has been conducted and while the emotional experiences of people deprived of an awareness of their physiological arousal may be less intense, they still experience emotion (Chwalisz, Diener, & Gallagher, 1988).']
['What is scientific research?', 'Scientific research’s dependence on falsifiability allows for great confidence in the information that it produces.']
['What happens after it is falsifiable?', 'Typically, by the time information is accepted by the scientific community, it has been tested repeatedly.']

['What are the approaches to research?', 'There are many research methods available to psychologists in their efforts to understand, describe, and explain behavior and the cognitive and biological processes that underlie it.']
['What methods are used?', 'Some methods rely on observational techniques.']

['Are there other methods?', 'Other approaches involve interactions between the researcher and the individuals who are being studied—ranging from a series of simple questions to extensive, in-depth interviews—to well-controlled experiments.']
['What are three approaches to research?', 'Each of these research methods has unique strengths and weaknesses, and each method may only be appropriate for certain types of research questions.']

['What type of questions?', 'For example, studies that rely primarily on observation produce incredible amounts of information, but the ability to apply this information to the larger population is somewhat limited because of small sample sizes.']
['How do you make it wider?', 'Survey research, on the other hand, allows researchers to easily collect data from relatively large samples.']

['What is the drawbacks of survey research?', 'While this allows for results to be generalized to the larger population more easily, the information that can be collected on any given survey is somewhat limited and subject to problems associated with any type of self-reported data.']
['What else did you learn in the article?', 'Some researchers conduct archival research by using existing records.']

['What is an archival research?', 'While this can be a fairly inexpensive way to collect data that can provide insight into a number of research questions, researchers using this approach have no control on how or what kind of data was collected.']
['How are all of these research methods similar?', 'All of the methods described thus far are correlational in nature.']
['How do they correlate?', 'This means that researchers can speak to important relationships that might exist between two or more variables of interest.']
['What can they not do?', 'However, correlational data cannot be used to make claims about cause-and-effect relationships.']

['What is the difference between a qualitative and a quantitative approach to research?', 'Correlational research can find a relationship between two variables, but the only way a researcher can claim that the relationship between the variables is cause and effect is to perform an experiment.']
['How is experimental research different?', 'In experimental research, which will be discussed later in this chapter, there is a tremendous amount of control over variables of interest.']
['Are there any other differences between these two approaches?', 'While this is a powerful approach, experiments are often conducted in artificial settings.']
['Why is this?', 'This calls into question the validity of experimental findings with regard to how they would apply in real-world settings.']
['Why is this bad?', 'In addition, many of the questions that psychologists would like to answer cannot be pursued through experimental research because of ethical concerns.']
['What kind of cases are there?', 'In 2011, the New York Times published a feature story on Krista and Tatiana Hogan, Canadian twin girls.']
['How are they special?', 'These particular twins are unique because Krista and Tatiana are conjoined twins, connected at the head.']
['How is that special?', 'There is evidence that the two girls are connected in a part of the brain called the thalamus, which is a major sensory relay center.']
['What does this center do?', 'Most incoming sensory information is sent through the thalamus before reaching higher regions of the cerebral cortex for processing.']
['What are Clinical Case Studies?', 'The implications of this potential connection mean that it might be possible for one twin to experience the sensations of the other twin.']
['What is an example?', 'For instance, if Krista is watching a particularly funny television program, Tatiana might smile or laugh even if she is not watching the program.']
['What is the importance of this?', 'This particular possibility has piqued the interest of many neuroscientists who seek to understand how the brain uses sensory information.']
['What is observational research?', 'In observational research, scientists are conducting a clinical or case study when they focus on one person or just a few individuals.']
['Are there a lot of case studies?', 'Indeed, some scientists spend their entire careers studying just 10–20 individuals.']
['Why do they spend so long studying them?', 'Obviously, when they focus their attention on a very small number of people, they can gain a precious amount of insight into those cases.']
['How is that different from other types of research?', 'The richness of information that is collected in clinical or case studies is unmatched by any other single research method.']
['What kinds of information?', 'This allows the researcher to have a very deep understanding of the individuals and the particular phenomenon being studied.']
['What kind of insight?', 'As it turns out, the major benefit of this particular approach is also a weakness.']
['What is the weakness?', 'As mentioned earlier, this approach is often used when studying individuals who are interesting to researchers because they have a rare characteristic.']
['What type of characteristic?', 'Therefore, the individuals who serve as the focus of case studies are not like most other people.']

['Are they more like them than others?', 'If scientists ultimately want to explain all behavior, focusing attention on such a special group of people can make it difficult to generalize any observations to the larger population as a whole.']
['What is generalize?', 'Generalizing refers to the ability to apply the findings of a particular research project to larger segments of society.']

['How does generalize help?', 'Again, case studies provide enormous amounts of information, but since the cases are so specific, the potential to apply what’s learned to the average person may be very limited.']
['What is naturalistic observation?', 'If you want to understand how behavior occurs, one of the best ways to gain information is to simply observe the behavior in its natural context.']
['How does it work in practice?', 'However, people might change their behavior in unexpected ways if they know they are being observed.']
['How can this be explained?', 'As an example, imagine that your professor asks everyone in your class to raise their hand if they always wash their hands after using the restroom.']

['What did you learn from the discussion about the paradox?', 'This is very similar to the phenomenon mentioned earlier in this chapter: many individuals do not feel comfortable answering a question honestly.']
['Why not?', 'But if we are committed to finding out the facts about hand washing, we have other options available to us.']
['What can you tell me about naturalistic observation?', 'Suppose we send a classmate into the restroom to actually watch whether everyone washes their hands after using the restroom.']

['How do we find out whether people wash their hands?', 'We want our researcher to be inconspicuous—perhaps standing at one of the sinks pretending to put in contact lenses while secretly recording the relevant information.']
['What is the secret information about?', 'This type of observational study is called naturalistic observation: observing behavior in its natural setting.']

['What is the example of another example you can give?', 'To better understand peer exclusion, Suzanne Fanger collaborated with colleagues at the University of Texas to observe the behavior of preschool children on a playground.']
['How did they do this?', 'They equipped a few of the children with wireless microphones (which the children quickly forgot about) and observed while taking notes from a distance.']

['What is interesting about this?', 'Also, the children in that particular preschool (a “laboratory preschool”) were accustomed to having observers on the playground (Fanger, Frankel, & Hazen, 2012).']

['What is an important fact to know about Naturalistic Observation?', 'It is critical that the observer be as unobtrusive and as inconspicuous as possible: when people know they are being watched, they are less likely to behave naturally.']
['What other facts did the teacher provide for us to read?', 'If you have any doubt about this, ask yourself how your driving behavior might differ in two situations:']

['What are the two situations?', 'In the first situation, you are driving down a deserted highway during the middle of the day; in the second situation, you are being followed by a police car down the same deserted highway.']
['How did this research get started?', 'It should be pointed out that naturalistic observation is not limited to research involving humans.']

['Is there any other interesting fact?', 'Indeed, some of the best-known examples of naturalistic observation involve researchers going into the field to observe various kinds of animals in their own environments.']

['Can you provide any further information?', 'As with human studies, the researchers maintain their distance and avoid interfering with the animal subjects so as not to influence their natural behaviors.']
['What kind of studies were done using this method?', 'Scientists have used this technique to study social hierarchies and interactions among animals ranging from ground squirrels to gorillas.']
['What can you tell me about these studies?', 'The information provided by these studies is invaluable in understanding how those animals organize socially and communicate with one another.']
['What other examples of naturalistic observation are there?', 'The anthropologist Jane Goodall, for example, spent nearly five decades observing the behavior of chimpanzees in Africa.']

['What happened next?', 'As an illustration of the types of concerns that a researcher might encounter in naturalistic observation, some scientists criticized Goodall for giving the chimps names instead of referring to them by numbers—using names was thought to undermine the emotional detachment required for the objectivity of the study (McKie, 2010).']

['What are the most important aspects of naturalistic observation?', 'The greatest benefit of naturalistic observation is the validity, or accuracy, of information collected unobtrusively in a natural setting.']

['How is the validity or accuracy important in an ecological setting?', 'Having individuals behave as they normally would in a given situation means that we have a higher degree of ecological validity, or realism, than we might achieve with other research approaches.']
['What is the next most important aspect of naturalistic observation?', 'Therefore, our ability to generalize the findings of the research to real-world situations is enhanced.']
['Is there anything else you find interesting in this article?', 'If done correctly, we need not worry about people or animals modifying their behavior simply because they are being observed.']
['What other aspects of naturalistic observation is interesting?', 'Sometimes, people may assume that reality programs give us a glimpse into authentic human behavior.']

['What is the problem with reality programs?', 'However, the principle of inconspicuous observation is violated as reality stars are followed by camera crews and are interviewed on camera for personal confessionals.']
['What are the results of that violation?', 'Given that environment, we must doubt how natural and realistic their behaviors are.']
['what are some disadvantages of this?', 'The major downside of naturalistic observation is that they are often difficult to set up and control.']
['What are some benefits?', 'The benefit of realistic data comes at a cost.']
['Can you give me more information about the cost?', 'As a researcher you have no control of when (or if) you have behavior to observe.']
['Do you have any more information about the cost?', 'In addition, this type of observational research often requires significant investments of time, money, and a good dose of luck.']
["What's special about naturalistic observation?", 'Sometimes studies involve structured observation.']
['What are these studies?', 'In these cases, people are observed while engaging in set, specific tasks.']
['What are the tasks?', 'An excellent example of structured observation comes from Strange Situation by Mary Ainsworth (you will read more about this in the chapter on lifespan development).']
['What is Strange Situation?', 'The Strange Situation is a procedure used to evaluate attachment styles that exist between an infant and caregiver.']
['How does it work?', 'In this scenario, caregivers bring their infants into a room filled with toys.']
['What happens in the room?', 'The Strange Situation involves a number of phases, including a stranger coming into the room, the caregiver leaving the room, and the caregiver’s return to the room.']

['What does the infant do when the stranger enters the room?', 'The infant’s behavior is closely monitored at each phase, but it is the behavior of the infant upon being reunited with the caregiver that is most telling in terms of characterizing the infant’s attachment style with the caregiver.']
['What other problems does naturalistic observation have?', 'Another potential problem in observational research is observer bias.']

['What can lead to observer bias?', 'Generally, people who act as observers are closely involved in the research project and may unconsciously skew their observations to fit their research goals or expectations.']

['What steps should be taken to reduce observer bias?', 'To protect against this type of bias, researchers should have clear criteria established for the types of behaviors recorded and how those behaviors should be classified.']

['What else can be done to prevent observer bias?', 'In addition, researchers often compare observations of the same event by multiple observers, in order to test inter-rater reliability: a measure of reliability that assesses the consistency of observations by different observers.']
['What do surveys involve?', 'Often, psychologists develop surveys as a means of gathering data.']

['What kind of data?', 'Surveys are lists of questions to be answered by research participants, and can be delivered as paper-and-pencil questionnaires, administered electronically, or conducted verbally.']
['How do they get this data?', 'Generally, the survey itself can be completed in a short time, and the ease of administering a survey makes it easy to collect data from a large number of people.']
['What are surveys?', 'Surveys allow researchers to gather data from larger samples than may be afforded by other research methods.']
['What are samples?', 'A sample is a subset of individuals selected from a population, which is the overall group of individuals that the researchers are interested in.']
['What do researchers want to know?', 'Researchers study the sample and seek to generalize their findings to the population.']
['How do they generalize their findings?', 'Generally, researchers will begin this process by calculating various measures of central tendency from the data they have collected.']
['What is meant by these measures of central tendency?', 'These measures provide an overall summary of what a typical response looks like.']
['What are the three measures of central tendency?', 'There are three measures of central tendency: mode, median, and mean.']
['How are they described?', 'The mode is the most frequently occurring response, the median lies at the middle of a given data set, and the mean is the arithmetic average of all data points.']

['How do these different measures fit together?', 'Means tend to be most useful in conducting additional analyses like those described below; however, means are very sensitive to the effects of outliers, and so one must be aware of those effects when making assessments of what measures of central tendency tell us about a data set in question.']
['What are the strengths of survey?', 'There is both strength and weakness of the survey in comparison to case studies.']
['What is the weakness of survey?', 'By using surveys, we can collect information from a larger sample of people.']
['What is the benefit of a larger sample?', 'A larger sample is better able to reflect the actual diversity of the population, thus allowing better generalizability.']

['What is better generalizability?', 'Therefore, if our sample is sufficiently large and diverse, we can assume that the data we collect from the survey can be generalized to the larger population with more certainty than the information collected through a case study.']

['What else can be generalized?', 'However, given the greater number of people involved, we are not able to collect the same depth of information on each person that would be collected in a case study.']
['What is the weakness of surveys?', "Another potential weakness of surveys is something we touched on earlier in this chapter: People don't always give accurate responses."]
["Why don't they give accurate responses?", 'They may lie, misremember, or answer questions in a way that they think makes them look good.']
['How does one lie in a survey?', 'For example, people may report drinking less alcohol than is actually the case.']
['What are surveys?', 'Any number of research questions can be answered through the use of surveys.']

['What can be learned from surveys?', 'One real-world example is the research conducted by Jenkins, Ruppel, Kizer, Yehl, and Griffin (2012) about the backlash against the US Arab-American community following the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001.']
['What did they find out?', 'Jenkins and colleagues wanted to determine to what extent these negative attitudes toward Arab-Americans still existed nearly a decade after the attacks occurred.']

['How did they determine this?', 'In one study, 140 research participants filled out a survey with 10 questions, including questions asking directly about the participant’s overt prejudicial attitudes toward people of various ethnicities.']

['How did the surveys help?', 'The survey also asked indirect questions about how likely the participant would be to interact with a person of a given ethnicity in a variety of settings (such as, “How likely do you think it is that you would introduce yourself to a person of Arab-American descent?”).']
['What else did they learn?', 'The results of the research suggested that participants were unwilling to report prejudicial attitudes toward any ethnic group.']

['Did they find anything else interesting?', 'However, there were significant differences between their pattern of responses to questions about social interaction with Arab-Americans compared to other ethnic groups: they indicated less willingness for social interaction with Arab-Americans compared to the other ethnic groups.']

['How did this effect their study?', 'This suggested that the participants harbored subtle forms of prejudice against Arab-Americans, despite their assertions that this was not the case (Jenkins et al., 2012).']
['What is archive research?', 'Some researchers gain access to large amounts of data without interacting with a single research participant.']
['What is the advantage of archival research?', 'Instead, they use existing records to answer various research questions.']
['What is archival research?', 'This type of research approach is known as archival research.']
['What does this research involve?', 'Archival research relies on looking at past records or data sets to look for interesting patterns or relationships.']

['What is Archival Research?', 'For example, a researcher might access the academic records of all individuals who enrolled in college within the past ten years and calculate how long it took them to complete their degrees, as well as course loads, grades, and extracurricular involvement.']

['What are the benefits of this research?', 'Archival research could provide important information about who is most likely to complete their education, and it could help identify important risk factors for struggling students.']
['What are the differences between archival research and other research methods?', 'In comparing archival research to other research methods, there are several important distinctions.']
['What are these distinctions?', 'For one, the researcher employing archival research never directly interacts with research participants.']
['What else can you tell me about archival research?', 'Therefore, the investment of time and money to collect data is considerably less with archival research.']
['How about the investment of time and money to collect information?', 'Additionally, researchers have no control over what information was originally collected.']
['What else is unique about archival research?', 'Therefore, research questions have to be tailored so they can be answered within the structure of the existing data sets.']

['What other unique aspects of archival research are there?', 'There is also no guarantee of consistency between the records from one source to another, which might make comparing and contrasting different data sets problematic.']
['What is longitudinal research?', 'Sometimes we want to see how people change over time, as in studies of human development and lifespan.']
['What is longitudinal research?', 'When we test the same group of individuals repeatedly over an extended period of time, we are conducting longitudinal research.']
['What kind of research do we conduct?', 'Longitudinal research is a research design in which data-gathering is administered repeatedly over an extended period of time.']
['What kind of data do we collect?', 'For example, we may survey a group of individuals about their dietary habits at age 20, retest them a decade later at age 30, and then again at age 40.']
['what other approaches to research are there?', 'Another approach is cross-sectional research.']
['What is the difference between longitudinal and cross-sectional research?', 'In cross-sectional research, a researcher compares multiple segments of the population at the same time.']
['What might be some examples?', 'Using the dietary habits example above, the researcher might directly compare different groups of people by age.']

['What is another example?', 'Instead of studying a group of people for 20 years to see how their dietary habits changed from decade to decade, the researcher would study a group of 20-year-old individuals and compare them to a group of 30-year-old individuals and a group of 40-year-old individuals.']

['Why does the researcher do this?', 'While cross-sectional research requires a shorter-term investment, it is also limited by differences that exist between the different generations (or cohorts) that have nothing to do with age per se, but rather reflect the social and cultural experiences of different generations of individuals make them different from one another.']
["How do we determine a person's age when there is no identifiable history?", 'To illustrate this concept, consider the following survey findings.']
['What are the survey findings?', 'In recent years there has been significant growth in the popular support of same-sex marriage.']
['What has this led to?', 'Many studies on this topic break down survey participants into different age groups.']
['What are the age groups?', 'In general, younger people are more supportive of same-sex marriage than are those who are older (Jones, 2013).']

['Why is this important?', 'Longitudinal research is a powerful approach because the same individuals are involved in the research project over time, which means that the researchers need to be less concerned with differences among cohorts affecting the results of their study.']
['What are longitudinal studies?', 'Often longitudinal studies are employed when researching various diseases in an effort to understand particular risk factors.']
['How are they conducted?', 'Such studies often involve tens of thousands of individuals who are followed for several decades.']

['Are they used to establish generalizations?', 'Given the enormous number of people involved in these studies, researchers can feel confident that their findings can be generalized to the larger population.']

['Is there anything else significant that you want to know about longitudinal studies?', 'The Cancer Prevention Study-3 (CPS-3) is one of a series of longitudinal studies sponsored by the American Cancer Society aimed at determining predictive risk factors associated with cancer.']

['What was CPS-3?', 'When participants enter the study, they complete a survey about their lives and family histories, providing information on factors that might cause or prevent the development of cancer.']
['How long do they have to complete the survey?', 'Then every few years the participants receive additional surveys to complete.']
['What happens when they complete all the surveys?', 'In the end, hundreds of thousands of participants will be tracked over 20 years to determine which of them develop cancer and which do not.']
['What are longitudinal and cross sectional studies?', 'Clearly, this type of research is important and potentially very informative.']

['Why is that?', 'For instance, earlier longitudinal studies sponsored by the American Cancer Society provided some of the first scientific demonstrations of the now well-established links between increased rates of cancer and smoking (American Cancer Society, n.d.).']
['What kind of research is it?', 'As with any research strategy, longitudinal research is not without limitations.']
['What limitations are there?', 'For one, these studies require an incredible time investment by the researcher and research participants.']
['How long does it take to complete?', 'Given that some longitudinal studies take years, if not decades, to complete, the results will not be known for a considerable period of time.']
['What else is important?', 'In addition to the time demands, these studies also require a substantial financial investment.']
['What other limitations?', 'Many researchers are unable to commit the resources necessary to see a longitudinal project through to the end.']
['What are the benefits of longitudinal research?', 'Research participants must also be willing to continue their participation for an extended period of time, and this can be problematic.']
['Why is this problematic?', 'People move, get married and take new names, get ill, and eventually die.']
['Why do people choose to discontinue their participation?', 'Even without significant life changes, some people may simply choose to discontinue their participation in the project.']

['Are there ways to minimize this?', 'As a result, the attrition rates, or reduction in the number of research participants due to dropouts, in longitudinal studies are quite high and increases over the course of a project.']
['What can be done about this?', 'For this reason, researchers using this approach typically recruit many participants fully expecting that a substantial number will drop out before the end.']
['Why would they do this?', 'As the study progresses, they continually check whether the sample still represents the larger population, and make adjustments as necessary.']

['What is the topic of the paper?', 'There is no question that a relationship exists between ice cream and crime (e.g., Harper, 2013), but it would be pretty foolish to decide that one thing actually caused the other to occur.']
['What was the main idea of the material?', 'It is much more likely that both ice cream sales and crime rates are related to the temperature outside.']
['Why is this?', 'When the temperature is warm, there are lots of people out of their houses, interacting with each other, getting annoyed with one another, and sometimes committing crimes.']
['Do they get grumpy?', 'Also, when it is warm outside, we are more likely to seek a cool treat like ice cream.']

['What is correlation?', 'Correlation means that there is a relationship between two or more variables (such as ice cream consumption and crime), but this relationship does not necessarily imply cause and effect.']
['How do you determine correlation?', 'When two variables are correlated, it simply means that as one variable changes, so does the other.']
['What does the coefficient mean?', 'We can measure correlation by calculating a statistic known as a correlation coefficient.']

['Is there anything more important to know about correlation coefficient?', 'A correlation coefficient is a number from -1 to +1 that indicates the strength and direction of the relationship between variables.']
['What does this number correspond to?', 'The correlation coefficient is usually represented by the letter r.']
['What do you find out about the correlation coefficient?', 'The number portion of the correlation coefficient indicates the strength of the relationship.']

['What does 1 mean?', 'The closer the number is to 1 (be it negative or positive), the more strongly related the variables are, and the more predictable changes in one variable will be as the other variable changes.']
['What is 0?', 'The closer the number is to zero, the weaker the relationship, and the less predictable the relationships between the variables becomes.']
['What are the other two numbers?', 'For instance, a correlation coefficient of 0.9 indicates a far stronger relationship than a correlation coefficient of 0.3.']
['What does the zero mean?', 'If the variables are not related to one another at all, the correlation coefficient is 0.']
['What examples are given of 0 and zero?', 'The example above about ice cream and crime is an example of two variables that we might expect to have no relationship to each other.']
['What sign of the correlation coefficient indicates the direction of the relationship?', 'The sign—positive or negative—of the correlation coefficient indicates the direction of the relationship.']
['What does a positive correlation mean?', 'A positive correlation means that the variables move in the same direction.']
['What does that mean?', 'Put another way, it means that as one variable increases so does the other, and conversely, when one variable decreases so does the other.']
['What does a negative correlation mean?', 'A negative correlation means that the variables move in opposite directions.']
['What does that mean?', 'If two variables are negatively correlated, a decrease in one variable is associated with an increase in the other and vice versa.']
['What is an example of a correlation?', 'The example of ice cream and crime rates is a positive correlation because both variables increase when temperatures are warmer.']

['What other examples of positive correlations are there?', 'Other examples of positive correlations are the relationship between an individual’s height and weight or the relationship between a person’s age and number of wrinkles.']

['What other examples of positive correlations are there?', 'One might expect a negative correlation to exist between someone’s tiredness during the day and the number of hours they slept the previous night: the amount of sleep decreases as the feelings of tiredness increase.']

['What are some examples of negative correlations?', 'In a real-world example of negative correlation, student researchers at the University of Minnesota found a weak negative correlation (r = -0.29) between the average number of days per week that students got fewer than 5 hours of sleep and their GPA (Lowry, Dean, & Manders, 2010).']
['What is one thing to note about negative correlations?', 'Keep in mind that a negative correlation is not the same as no correlation.']
['What are some examples of no correlation?', 'For example, we would probably find no correlation between hours of sleep and shoe size.']
['What do correlations mean?', 'As mentioned earlier, correlations have predictive value.']
['What kind of value does it have?', 'Imagine that you are on the admissions committee of a major university.']
['What are the criteria for admission?', 'You are faced with a huge number of applications, but you are able to accommodate only a small percentage of the applicant pool.']
['What are you looking for?', 'You might try to correlate your current students’ college GPA with their scores on standardized tests like the SAT or ACT.']

['What are you looking for from those correlations?', 'By observing which correlations were strongest for your current students, you could use this information to predict relative success of those students who have applied for admission into the university.']
['Why is correlation important?', 'Correlational research is useful because it allows us to discover the strength and direction of relationships that exist between two variables.']
['How can correlation be limited?', 'However, correlation is limited because establishing the existence of a relationship tells us little about cause and effect.']

['What can cause a correlation?', 'While variables are sometimes correlated because one does cause the other, it could also be that some other factor, a confounding variable, is actually causing the systematic movement in our variables of interest.']

['What can be an example of a confounding variable?', 'In the ice cream/crime rate example mentioned earlier, temperature is a confounding variable that could account for the relationship between the two variables.']

['What is the most important information from the document?', 'Even when we cannot point to clear confounding variables, we should not assume that a correlation between two variables implies that one variable causes changes in another.']
['What can be a confounding variable?', 'This can be frustrating when a cause-and-effect relationship seems clear and intuitive.']

['What else is important from the article?', 'Think back to our discussion of the research done by the American Cancer Society and how their research projects were some of the first demonstrations of the link between smoking and cancer.']

['What else can you tell me about the article?', 'It seems reasonable to assume that smoking causes cancer, but if we were limited to correlational research, we would be overstepping our bounds by making this assumption.']
['What does correlation have to do with causality?', 'Unfortunately, people mistakenly make claims of causation as a function of correlations all the time.']
['What do people mean by these claims?', 'Such claims are especially common in advertisements and news stories.']

['What are some examples of the claims?', 'For example, recent research found that people who eat cereal on a regular basis achieve healthier weights than those who rarely eat cereal (Frantzen, Treviño, Echon, Garcia-Dominic, & DiMarco, 2013; Barton et al., 2005).']
['What do you think of this claim?', 'Guess how the cereal companies report this finding.']
['What is the limitation of correlations?', 'While correlational research is invaluable in identifying relationships among variables, a major limitation is the inability to establish causality.']
['What do psychologists do instead?', 'Psychologists want to make statements about cause and effect, but the only way to do that is to conduct an experiment to answer a research question.']

['What kind of experiments do psychologists conduct?', 'The next section describes how scientific experiments incorporate methods that eliminate, or control for, alternative explanations, which allow researchers to explore how changes in one variable cause changes in another variable.']
['What are some misconceptions about this topic?', 'The temptation to make erroneous cause-and-effect statements based on correlational research is not the only way we tend to misinterpret data.']
['What other types of mistakes can people make?', 'We also tend to make the mistake of illusory correlations, especially with unsystematic observations.']

['What are some examples of illusory correlations?', 'Illusory correlations, or false correlations, occur when people believe that relationships exist between two things when no such relationship exists.']
['What are some examples?', 'One well-known illusory correlation is the supposed effect that the moon’s phases have on human behavior.']
['What happens when the moon is full?', 'Many people passionately assert that human behavior is affected by the phase of the moon, and specifically, that people act strangely when the moon is full.']
['What is the moon used for?', 'There is no denying that the moon exerts a powerful influence on our planet.']
['What kind of influence does it exert?', 'The ebb and flow of the ocean’s tides are tightly tied to the gravitational forces of the moon.']
['What do people think about it?', 'Many people believe, therefore, that it is logical that we are affected by the moon as well.']
['What does that mean?', 'After all, our bodies are largely made up of water.']
['What are other studies?', 'A meta-analysis of nearly 40 studies consistently demonstrated, however, that the relationship between the moon and our behavior does not exist (Rotton & Kelly, 1985).']
['Does it mean anything else?', 'While we may pay more attention to odd behavior during the full phase of the moon, the rates of odd behavior remain constant throughout the lunar cycle.']
['What can you tell me about illusions?', 'Often we read or hear about them and simply accept the information as valid.']

['What else can you tell me about illusions?', 'Or, we have a hunch about how something works and then look for evidence to support that hunch, ignoring evidence that would tell us our hunch is false; this is known as confirmation bias.']
['What other examples do you give?', 'Other times, we find illusory correlations based on the information that comes most easily to mind, even if that information is severely limited.']

['What is the drawback?', 'And while we may feel confident that we can use these relationships to better understand and predict the world around us, illusory correlations can have significant drawbacks.']

['What other drawbacks are there?', 'For example, research suggests that illusory correlations—in which certain behaviors are inaccurately attributed to certain groups—are involved in the formation of prejudicial attitudes that can ultimately lead to discriminatory behavior (Fiedler, 2004).']
['What is causality?', 'As you’ve learned, the only way to establish that there is a cause-and-effect relationship between two variables is to conduct a scientific experiment.']
['What is the difference between experiment and study?', 'Experiment has a different meaning in the scientific context than in everyday life.']
['What do you mean?', 'In everyday conversation, we often use it to describe trying something for the first time, such as experimenting with a new hair style or a new food.']
['What is a scientific experiment?', 'However, in the scientific context, an experiment has precise requirements for design and implementation.']
['What is the experimental hypothesis?', 'In order to conduct an experiment, a researcher must have a specific hypothesis to be tested.']

['How does the researcher formulate a hypothesis?', 'As you’ve learned, hypotheses can be formulated either through direct observation of the real world or after careful review of previous research.']

['How does the researcher know it is a hypothesis?', 'For example, if you think that the use of technology in the classroom has negative impacts on learning, then you have basically formulated a hypothesis—namely, that the use of technology in the classroom should be limited because it decreases learning.']

['How does the student know the technology negatively impacts learning?', 'You may have noticed that your classmates who take notes on their laptops perform at lower levels on class exams than those who take notes by hand, or those who receive a lesson via a computer program versus via an in-person teacher have different levels of performance when tested.']

['What are some important things to remember about this document?', 'These sorts of personal observations are what often lead us to formulate a specific hypothesis, but we cannot use limited personal observations and anecdotal evidence to rigorously test our hypothesis.']
['What can we use to rigorously test our hypothesis?', 'Instead, to find out if real-world data supports our hypothesis, we have to conduct an experiment.']
['What is the most basic experimental design?', 'The most basic experimental design involves two groups: the experimental group and the control group.']
['What are the two groups designed to be like?', 'The two groups are designed to be the same except for one difference— experimental manipulation.']

['What is experimental manipulation?', 'The experimental group gets the experimental manipulation—that is, the treatment or variable being tested (in this case, the use of technology)—and the control group does not.']

['What is important about this difference?', 'Since experimental manipulation is the only difference between the experimental and control groups, we can be sure that any differences between the two are due to experimental manipulation rather than chance.']

['What are some of the interesting details in this article?', 'In our example of how the use of technology should be limited in the classroom, we have the experimental group learn algebra using a computer program and then test their learning.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'We measure the learning in our control group after they are taught algebra by a teacher in a traditional classroom.']

['Is there any special technique they used for the experiment?', 'It is important for the control group to be treated similarly to the experimental group, with the exception that the control group does not receive the experimental manipulation.']
['What are you going to use the data for?', 'We also need to precisely define, or operationalize, how we measure learning of algebra.']

['What does that mean?', 'An operational definition is a precise description of our variables, and it is important in allowing others to understand exactly how and what a researcher measures in a particular experiment.']

['What other variables are important?', 'In operationalizing learning, we might choose to look at performance on a test covering the material on which the individuals were taught by the teacher or the computer program.']
['Do you have any other variables?', 'We might also ask our participants to summarize the information that was just presented in some way.']

['What do you mean by operationalizing learning?', 'Whatever we determine, it is important that we operationalize learning in such a way that anyone who hears about our study for the first time knows exactly what we mean by learning.']
['What is the advantage?', 'This aids peoples’ ability to interpret our data as well as their capacity to repeat our experiment should they choose to do so.']

['How do we design the experiment?', 'Once we have operationalized what is considered use of technology and what is considered learning in our experiment participants, we need to establish how we will run our experiment.']

['What is the sample size?', 'In this case, we might have participants spend 45 minutes learning algebra (either through a computer program or with an in-person math teacher) and then give them a test on the material covered during the 45 minutes.']
['What is an experimenter?', 'Ideally, the people who score the tests are unaware of who was assigned to the experimental or control group, in order to control for experimenter bias.']
['What is experimenter bias?', 'Experimenter bias refers to the possibility that a researcher’s expectations might skew the results of the study.']

['Why might it skew the results?', 'Remember, conducting an experiment requires a lot of planning, and the people involved in the research project have a vested interest in supporting their hypotheses.']

['Why do they not reveal the groups to the people who score the tests?', 'If the observers knew which child was in which group, it might influence how they interpret ambiguous responses, such as sloppy handwriting or minor computational mistakes.']
['How is that advantageous?', 'By being blind to which child is in which group, we protect against those biases.']

['How is the study conducted?', 'This situation is a single-blind study, meaning that one of the groups (participants) are unaware as to which group they are in (experiment or control group) while the researcher who developed the experiment knows which participants are in each group.']
['What is double blind testing?', 'In a double-blind study, both the researchers and the participants are blind to group assignments.']
['Why would they do this?', 'Because by doing so, we can control for both experimenter and participant expectations.']
['What does that mean?', 'If you are familiar with the phrase placebo effect, you already have some idea as to why this is an important consideration.']
['What is the placebo effect?', "The placebo effect occurs when people's expectations or beliefs influence or determine their experience in a given situation."]
['What does that mean?', 'In other words, simply expecting something to happen can actually make it happen.']
['What is a placebo effect?', 'The placebo effect is commonly described in terms of testing the effectiveness of a new medication.']
['What kind of medication?', 'Imagine that you work in a pharmaceutical company, and you think you have a new drug that is effective in treating depression.']
['How do you demonstrate that it is effective?', 'To demonstrate that your medication is effective, you run an experiment with two groups:']
['What happens to the two groups?', 'The experimental group receives the medication, and the control group does not.']
['What happens after the experiment is completed?', 'But you don’t want participants to know whether they received the drug or not.']
['What kind of experiment?', 'Imagine that you are a participant in this study, and you have just taken a pill that you think will improve your mood.']

['What happens to you after the pill has been taken?', 'Because you expect the pill to have an effect, you might feel better simply because you took the pill and not because of any drug actually contained in the pill—this is the placebo effect.']

['What would happen if there was a placebo?', 'To make sure that any effects on mood are due to the drug and not due to expectations, the control group receives a placebo (in this case a sugar pill).']

['What if you did not want to be in the control group?', 'Now everyone gets a pill, and once again neither the researcher nor the experimental participants know who got the drug and who got the sugar pill.']

['What does the test group think the drug does?', 'Any differences in mood between the experimental and control groups can now be attributed to the drug itself rather than to experimenter bias or participant expectations.']
['How does this title describe research?', 'In a research experiment, we strive to study whether changes in one thing cause changes in another.']

['What are these variables?', 'To achieve this, we must pay attention to two important variables, or things that can be changed, in any experimental study: the independent variable and the dependent variable.']
['What are independent variables?', 'An independent variable is manipulated or controlled by the experimenter.']
['What are the reasons for this?', 'In a well-designed experimental study, the independent variable is the only important difference between the experimental and control groups.']

['What are some examples of independent variables?', 'In our example of how technology use in the classroom affects learning, the independent variable is the type of learning by participants in the study.']
['What is the dependent variable?', 'A dependent variable is what the researcher measures to see how much effect the independent variable had.']
['What is the dependent variable measured?', 'In our example, the dependent variable is the learning exhibited by our participants.']
['How are independent and dependent variables related?', 'We expect that the dependent variable will change as a function of the independent variable.']
['Does this mean that the dependent variable will not change as a function of the independent variable?', 'In other words, the dependent variable depends on the independent variable.']
['What are some examples of dependent variables?', 'A good way to think about the relationship between the independent and dependent variables is with this question:']
['What is the sample size that we use?', 'Now that our study is designed, we need to obtain a sample of individuals to include in our experiment.']
['What do we need to determine who we are going to include?', 'Our study involves human participants so we need to determine who to include.']

['What is a participant?', 'Participants are the subjects of psychological research, and as the name implies, individuals who are involved in psychological research actively participate in the process.']
['Do we need to use college students?', 'Often, psychological research projects rely on college students to serve as participants.']

['What are some notable research studies on college students?', 'In fact, the vast majority of research in psychology subfields has historically involved students as research participants (Sears, 1986; Arnett, 2008).']
['Does using college students make sense?', 'College students tend to be younger, more educated, more liberal, and less diverse than the general population.']

['Does using college students cause problems?', 'Although using students as test subjects is an accepted practice, relying on such a limited pool of research participants can be problematic because it is difficult to generalize findings to the larger population.']
['What will you be doing?', 'Our hypothetical experiment involves high school students, and we must first generate a sample of students.']
['Why are samples used?', 'Samples are used because populations are usually too large to reasonably involve every member in our particular experiment.']
['Do we have to pick a random sample?', 'If possible, we should use a random sample (there are other types of samples, but for the purposes of this chapter, we will focus on random samples).']
['What is a random sample?', 'A random sample is a subset of a larger population in which every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected.']

['Why is it preferred?', 'Random samples are preferred because if the sample is large enough we can be reasonably sure that the participating individuals are representative of the larger population.']

['What does representative mean?', 'This means that the percentages of characteristics in the sample—sex, ethnicity, socioeconomic level, and any other characteristics that might affect the results—are close to those percentages in the larger population.']
['What is the purpose of selecting and assigning experimental participants?', 'In our example, let’s say we decide our population of interest is algebra students.']

['What is the population of interest?', 'But all algebra students is a very large population, so we need to be more specific; instead we might say our population of interest is all algebra students in a particular city.']
['What else do we need to consider?', 'We should include students from various income brackets, family situations, races, ethnicities, religions, and geographic areas of town.']

['How many students do we need to select?', 'With this more manageable population, we can work with the local schools in selecting a random sample of around 200 algebra students who we want to participate in our experiment.']
['How did you learn about this?', 'In summary, because we cannot test all of the algebra students in a city, we want to find a group of about 200 that reflects the composition of that city.']

['Why do we want to find a group of about 200 that reflects the composition of that', 'With a representative group, we can generalize our findings to the larger population without fear of our sample being biased in some way.']

['What does the Selecting and Assigning Experimental Participants page say?', 'Now that we have a sample, the next step of the experimental process is to split the participants into experimental and control groups through random assignment.']
['What happens with random assignment?', 'With random assignment, all participants have an equal chance of being assigned to either group.']
['How does the random assignment occur?', 'There is statistical software that will randomly assign each of the algebra students in the sample to either the experimental or the control group.']
["What's the best way to assign people?", 'Random assignment is critical for sound experimental design.']
['Why?', 'With sufficiently large samples, random assignment makes it unlikely that there are systematic differences between the groups.']

['Is there anything else important to note about the random assignment?', 'So, for instance, it would be very unlikely that we would get one group composed entirely of males, a given ethnic identity, or a given religious ideology.']

['What is the disadvantage of this assignment?', 'This is important because if the groups were systematically different before the experiment began, we would not know the origin of any differences we find between the groups:']
['What is the advantage?', 'Random assignment allows us to assume that any differences observed between experimental and control groups result from the manipulation of the independent variable.']
['What does the article discuss?', 'While experiments allow scientists to make cause-and-effect claims, they are not without problems.']
['How do experiments fail?', 'True experiments require the experimenter to manipulate an independent variable, and that can complicate many questions that psychologists might want to address.']
['What can complicate the questions?', 'For instance, imagine that you want to know what effect sex (the independent variable) has on spatial memory (the dependent variable).']
['How can you control sex?', 'Although you can certainly look for differences between males and females on a task that taps into spatial memory, you cannot directly control a person’s sex.']
['Why not control sex?', 'We categorize this type of research approach as quasi-experimental and recognize that we cannot make cause-and-effect claims in these circumstances.']
['What are some of the considerations?', 'Experimenters are also limited by ethical constraints.']

['What kinds of ethical constraints?', 'For instance, you would not be able to conduct an experiment designed to determine if experiencing abuse as a child leads to lower levels of self-esteem among adults.']
['Why not?', 'To conduct such an experiment, you would need to randomly assign some experimental participants to a group that receives abuse, and that experiment would be unethical.']

['What does it entail?', 'Once data is collected from both the experimental and the control groups, a statistical analysis is conducted to find out if there are meaningful differences between the two groups.']
['Is there any other interesting tidbits?', 'A statistical analysis determines how likely any difference found is due to chance (and thus not meaningful).']

['How else can we interpret experimental findings?', 'For example, if an experiment is done on the effectiveness of a nutritional supplement, and those taking a placebo pill (and not the supplement) have the same result as those taking the supplement, then the experiment has shown that the nutritional supplement is not effective.']

['Are there any other interesting tidbits?', 'Generally, psychologists consider differences to be statistically significant if there is less than a five percent chance of observing them if the groups did not actually differ from one another.']
['Can you explain the significance rule?', 'Stated another way, psychologists want to limit the chances of making “false positive” claims to five percent or less.']
['What does this tell us about experiments?', 'The greatest strength of experiments is the ability to assert that any significant differences in the findings are caused by the independent variable.']

['What does the design look like?', 'This occurs because random selection, random assignment, and a design that limits the effects of both experimenter bias and participant expectancy should create groups that are similar in composition and treatment.']
['What happens after random selection?', 'Therefore, any difference between the groups is attributable to the independent variable, and now we can finally make a causal statement.']

['What is the example of a causal statement?', 'If we find that watching a violent television program results in more violent behavior than watching a nonviolent program, we can safely say that watching violent television programs causes an increase in the display of violent behavior.']
['What is reporting research?', 'When psychologists complete a research project, they generally want to share their findings with other scientists.']
['What is reporting research written about?', 'The American Psychological Association (APA) publishes a manual detailing how to write a paper for submission to scientific journals.']

['What are some journals?', 'Unlike an article that might be published in a magazine like Psychology Today, which targets a general audience with an interest in psychology, scientific journals generally publish peer-reviewed journal articles aimed at an audience of professionals and scholars who are actively involved in research themselves.']
['what is the role of peer reviewed journals?', 'A peer-reviewed journal article is read by several other scientists (generally anonymously) with expertise in the subject matter.']
['how does the peer review process work?', 'These peer reviewers provide feedback—to both the author and the journal editor—regarding the quality of the draft.']

['what does the peer reviewer look for?', 'Peer reviewers look for a strong rationale for the research being described, a clear description of how the research was conducted, and evidence that the research was conducted in an ethical manner.']
['what are other things the peer reviewer looks for?', "They also look for flaws in the study's design, methods, and statistical analyses."]
['what else does the peer reviewer look for?', 'They check that the conclusions drawn by the authors seem reasonable given the observations made during the research.']
['what else does the peer reviewer do?', 'Peer reviewers also comment on how valuable the research is in advancing the discipline’s knowledge.']

['what does peer reviewer do?', 'This helps prevent unnecessary duplication of research findings in the scientific literature and, to some extent, ensures that each research article provides new information.']

['what else does the peer reviewer do?', 'Ultimately, the journal editor will compile all of the peer reviewer feedback and determine whether the article will be published in its current state (a rare occurrence), published with revisions, or not accepted for publication.']
['what is peer review?', 'Peer review provides some degree of quality control for psychological research.']
['why is it helpful?', 'Poorly conceived or executed studies can be weeded out, and even well-designed research can be improved by the revisions suggested.']

['what are the results?', 'Peer review also ensures that the research is described clearly enough to allow other scientists to replicate it, meaning they can repeat the experiment using different samples to determine reliability.']
['what else is important?', 'Sometimes replications involve additional measures that expand on the original finding.']
['what does this do?', 'In any case, each replication serves to provide more evidence to support the original research findings.']

['why is this important?', 'Successful replications of published research make scientists more apt to adopt those findings, while repeated failures tend to cast doubt on the legitimacy of the original article and lead scientists to look elsewhere.']

['what is another example?', 'For example, it would be a major advancement in the medical field if a published study indicated that taking a new drug helped individuals achieve a healthy weight without changing their diet.']
['who can duplicate the results?', 'But if other scientists could not replicate the results, the original study’s claims would be questioned.']
['What is the Replication crisis?', 'In recent years, there has been increasing concern about a “replication crisis” that has affected a number of scientific fields, including psychology.']

['What can we learn about the replication crisis?', 'Some of the most well-known studies and scientists have produced research that has failed to be replicated by others (as discussed in Shrout & Rodgers, 2018).']

['What can we learn about the scientists that failed to be replicated?', 'In fact, even a famous Nobel Prize-winning scientist has recently retracted a published paper because she had difficulty replicating her results (Nobel Prize-winning scientist Frances Arnold retracts paper, 2020 January 3).']

['Is there any positive spinoff of the replication crisis?', 'These kinds of outcomes have prompted some scientists to begin to work together and more openly, and some would argue that the current “crisis” is actually improving the ways in which science is conducted and in how its results are shared with others (Aschwanden, 2018).']
['What are reliability and validity?', 'Reliability and validity are two important considerations that must be made with any type of data collection.']
['What does reliability mean?', 'Reliability refers to the ability to consistently produce a given result.']
['What does it mean in psychology?', 'In the context of psychological research, this would mean that any instruments or tools used to collect data do so in consistent, reproducible ways.']
['What is one example of reliability?', 'There are a number of different types of reliability.']

['What are some examples?', 'Some of these include inter-rater reliability (the degree to which two or more different observers agree on what has been observed), internal consistency (the degree to which different items on a survey that measure the same thing correlate with one another), and test-retest reliability (the degree to which the outcomes of a particular measure remain consistent over multiple administrations).']
['What is inconsistent measurement?', 'Unfortunately, being consistent in measurement does not necessarily mean that you have measured something correctly.']
['Does the system need any further explanation?', 'To illustrate this concept, consider a kitchen scale that would be used to measure the weight of cereal that you eat in the morning.']
['What would cause a inaccurate measurement?', 'If the scale is not properly calibrated, it may consistently under- or overestimate the amount of cereal that’s being measured.']

['What is a valid measurement?', 'While the scale is highly reliable in producing consistent results (e.g., the same amount of cereal poured onto the scale produces the same reading each time), those results are incorrect.']
['What does validity mean?', 'This is where validity comes into play.']

['How can you explain validity?', 'Validity refers to the extent to which a given instrument or tool accurately measures what it’s supposed to measure, and once again, there are a number of ways in which validity can be expressed.']

['What is an example of valid measurement?', 'Ecological validity (the degree to which research results generalize to real-world applications), construct validity (the degree to which a given variable actually captures or measures what it is intended to measure), and face validity (the degree to which a given variable seems valid on the surface) are just a few types that researchers consider.']
['What is the difference between validity and reliability?', 'While any valid measure is by necessity reliable, the reverse is not necessarily true.']
['How do you know if an instrument is valid or reliable?', 'Researchers strive to use instruments that are both highly reliable and valid.']
['What is ethical research?', 'Today, scientists agree that good research is ethical in nature and is guided by a basic respect for human dignity and safety.']
['What are some ethical problems?', 'However, as you will read in the feature box, this has not always been the case.']
['What are some ethical problems today?', 'Modern researchers must demonstrate that the research they perform is ethically sound.']
['How do you demonstrate ethical research?', 'This section presents how ethical considerations affect the design and implementation of research conducted today.']

['What are the guidelines?', 'Any experiment involving the participation of human subjects is governed by extensive, strict guidelines designed to ensure that the experiment does not result in harm.']
['What else is included?', 'Any research institution that receives federal support for research involving human participants must have access to an institutional review board (IRB).']
['What is the IRB?', 'The IRB is a committee of individuals often made up of members of the institution’s administration, scientists, and community members.']
['What is the purpose of the IRB?', 'The purpose of the IRB is to review proposals for research that involves human participants.']

['What happens when the proposal is reviewed?', 'The IRB reviews these proposals with the principles mentioned above in mind, and generally, approval from the IRB is required in order for the experiment to proceed.']
['What is the Research Involving Human Participants (RIHP)?', 'An institution’s IRB requires several components in any experiment it approves.']
['What are the components?', 'For one, each participant must sign an informed consent form before they can participate in the experiment.']

['What must the form say?', 'An informed consent form provides a written description of what participants can expect during the experiment, including potential risks and implications of the research.']
['What else must it say?', 'It also lets participants know that their involvement is completely voluntary and can be discontinued without penalty at any time.']
['What else must it say?', 'Furthermore, the informed consent guarantees that any data collected in the experiment will remain completely confidential.']
['What else must the form say?', 'In cases where research participants are under the age of 18, the parents or legal guardians are required to sign the informed consent form.']

['What is the information about informed consent?', 'While the informed consent form should be as honest as possible in describing exactly what participants will be doing, sometimes deception is necessary to prevent participants’ knowledge of the exact research question from affecting the results of the study.']

['What is deception?', 'Deception involves purposely misleading experiment participants in order to maintain the integrity of the experiment, but not to the point where the deception could be considered harmful.']

['What kind of deception?', 'For example, if we are interested in how our opinion of someone is affected by their attire, we might use deception in describing the experiment to prevent that knowledge from affecting participants’ responses.']
