['What else is important about informed consent?', 'In cases where deception is involved, participants must receive a full debriefing upon conclusion of the study—complete, honest information about the purpose of the experiment, how the data collected will be used, the reasons why deception was necessary, and information about how to obtain additional information about the study.']
['Who conducts research?', 'Many psychologists conduct research involving animal subjects.']

['What animals are used?', 'Often, these researchers use rodents or birds as the subjects of their experiments—the APA estimates that 90% of all animal research in psychology uses these species (American Psychological Association, n.d.).']

['Why do they use animals?', 'Because many basic processes in animals are sufficiently similar to those in humans, these animals are acceptable substitutes for research that would be considered unethical in human participants.']
['Why do animal researchers need to have ethical concerns?', 'This does not mean that animal researchers are immune to ethical concerns.']
['What should scientists do when confronted with ethical issues?', 'Indeed, the humane and ethical treatment of animal research subjects is a critical aspect of this type of research.']
['How do scientists ensure that animal research is ethical?', 'Researchers must design their experiments to minimize any pain or distress experienced by animals serving as research subjects.']

['What was a significant part of the information?', 'Whereas IRBs review research proposals that involve human participants, animal experimental proposals are reviewed by an Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).']
['who is an IACUC?', 'An IACUC consists of institutional administrators, scientists, veterinarians, and community members.']
['What do they do?', 'This committee is charged with ensuring that all experimental proposals require the humane treatment of animal research subjects.']
['What else do they do?', 'It also conducts semi-annual inspections of all animal facilities to ensure that the research protocols are being followed.']
["What happens if an animal research isn't done according to protocol?", 'No animal research project can proceed without the committee’s approval.']
['What does genetics do for us?', 'Psychological researchers study genetics in order to better understand the biological factors that contribute to certain behaviors.']
['Are all humans alike?', 'While all humans share certain biological mechanisms, we are each unique.']
['Why is that?', 'And while our bodies have many of the same parts—brains and hormones and cells with genetic codes—these are expressed in a wide variety of behaviors, thoughts, and reactions.']
['What is the study material based on?', 'To explore these questions, let’s start by focusing on a specific genetic disorder, sickle cell anemia, and how it might manifest in two affected sisters.']
['What is sickle cell anemia?', 'Sickle-cell anemia is a genetic condition in which red blood cells, which are normally round, take on a crescent-like shape.']

['How does this shape affect how the blood works?', 'The changed shape of these cells affects how they function: sickle-shaped cells can clog blood vessels and block blood flow, leading to high fever, severe pain, swelling, and tissue damage.']
['What is sickle-cell anemia?', 'Many people with sickle-cell anemia—and the particular genetic mutation that causes it—die at an early age.']

['How does this affect their life spans?', 'While the notion of “survival of the fittest” may suggest that people with this disorder have a low survival rate and therefore the disorder will become less common, this is not the case.']
['How is this different?', 'Despite the negative evolutionary effects associated with this genetic mutation, the sickle-cell gene remains relatively common among people of African descent.']
['Does this make sense?', 'The explanation is illustrated with the following scenario.']
['What are the two female examples?', 'Imagine two young women—Luwi and Sena—sisters in rural Zambia, Africa.']
['What are their inherited traits?', 'Luwi carries the gene for sickle-cell anemia; Sena does not carry the gene.']
['What does the gene for sickle-cell anemia do?', 'Sickle-cell carriers have one copy of the sickle-cell gene but do not have full-blown sickle-cell anemia.']
['What happens to sickle-cell carriers?', 'They experience symptoms only if they are severely dehydrated or are deprived of oxygen (as in mountain climbing).']

['What else is important in this article?', 'Carriers are thought to be immune from malaria (an often deadly disease that is widespread in tropical climates) because changes in their blood chemistry and immune functioning prevent the malaria parasite from having its effects (Gong, Parikh, Rosenthal, & Greenhouse, 2013).']
['What else is known about sickle-cell carriers?', 'However, full-blown sickle-cell anemia, with two copies of the sickle-cell gene, does not provide immunity to malaria.']
['What are some examples of mutations that affect genes?', 'While walking home from school, both sisters are bitten by mosquitoes carrying the malaria parasite.']
['Are they both sick?', 'Luwi is protected against malaria because she carries the sickle-cell mutation.']
['Is she healthy?', 'Sena, on the other hand, develops malaria and dies just two weeks later.']
['What happened to Luwi?', 'Luwi survives and eventually has children, to whom she may pass on the sickle-cell mutation.']

['What are some of the important aspects of the study material?', 'Malaria is rare in the United States, so the sickle-cell gene benefits nobody: the gene manifests primarily in minor health problems for carriers with one copy, or a severe full-blown disease with no health benefits for carriers with two copies.']
['How is that related to the study material?', 'However, the situation is quite different in other parts of the world.']

['What is the situation in other parts of the world?', 'In parts of Africa where malaria is prevalent, having the sickle-cell mutation does provide health benefits for carriers (protection from malaria).']
['What is the story of malaria?', "The story of malaria fits with Charles Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection."]

['What is evolution by natural selection?', 'In simple terms, the theory states that organisms that are better suited for their environment will survive and reproduce, while those that are poorly suited for their environment will die off.']

['What are some examples of natural selection?', 'In our example, we can see that, as a carrier, Luwi’s mutation is highly adaptive in her African homeland; however, if she resided in the United States (where malaria is rare), her mutation could prove costly—with a high probability of the disease in her descendants and minor health problems of her own.']
['What is Genetic variation?', 'Genetic variation, the genetic difference between individuals, is what contributes to a species’ adaptation to its environment.']
['When does genetic variation begin?', 'In humans, genetic variation begins with an egg, about 100 million sperm, and fertilization.']
['What happens during egg production?', 'Roughly once per month, active ovaries release an egg from follicles.']
['What happens to the egg after production?', "During the egg's journey from the ovary through the fallopian tubes, to the uterus, a sperm may fertilize the egg."]
['What is the basic structure of DNA?', 'The egg and the sperm each contain 23 chromosomes.']
['What do chromosomes do?', 'Chromosomes are long strings of genetic material known as deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA).']
['How does DNA make up the genes?', 'DNA is a helix-shaped molecule made up of nucleotide base pairs.']

['What are the genes responsible for?', 'In each chromosome, sequences of DNA make up genes that control or partially control a number of visible characteristics, known as traits, such as eye color, hair color, and so on.']
['What are the alleles?', 'A single gene may have multiple possible variations, or alleles.']
['What is an allele?', 'An allele is a specific version of a gene.']
['How do the alleles work?', 'So, a given gene may code for the trait of hair color, and the different alleles of that gene affect which hair color an individual has.']
['What are some important points to keep in mind?', 'When a sperm and egg fuse, their 23 chromosomes combine to create a zygote with 46 chromosomes (23 pairs).']

['What is a pair of pairs?', 'Therefore, each parent contributes half the genetic information carried by the offspring; the resulting physical characteristics of the offspring (called the phenotype) are determined by the interaction of genetic material supplied by the sperm and egg (called the genotype).']
['What is genotype?', 'A person’s genotype is the genetic makeup of that individual.']
['What is phenotype?', 'Phenotype, on the other hand, refers to the individual’s inherited physical characteristics, which are a combination of genetic and environmental influences.']

['What is the meaning of parent?', 'Note that, in genetics and reproduction, "parent" is often used to describe the individual organisms that contribute genetic material to offspring, usually in the form of gamete cells (sperm and egg).']

['What are the implications of genetic parenthood?', 'The concept of a genetic parent is distinct from social and legal concepts of parenthood, and may differ from those whom people consider their parents.']
['What is genetic variation?', 'Most traits are controlled by multiple genes, but some traits are controlled by one gene.']
['What type of traits are controlled by one gene?', 'A characteristic like cleft chin, for example, is influenced by a single gene from each parent.']

['What happens to people with a single gene?', 'In this example, we will call the gene for cleft chin “B,” and the gene for smooth chin “b.” Cleft chin is a dominant trait, which means that having the dominant allele either from one parent (Bb) or both parents (BB) will always result in the phenotype associated with the dominant allele.']
['What is homozygous?', 'When someone has two copies of the same allele, they are said to be homozygous for that allele.']
['What is heterozygous?', 'When someone has a combination of alleles for a given gene, they are said to be heterozygous.']

['What happens if a person has only one allele for that gene?', 'For example, smooth chin is a recessive trait, which means that an individual will only display the smooth chin phenotype if they are homozygous for that recessive allele (bb).']
['What is one example of genetic variation?', 'Imagine that a person with a cleft chin mates with a person with a smooth chin.']
['Are both individuals going to have the chin?', 'The answer to that depends on which alleles each parent carries.']
['Does the person that carries the allele get it or not?', 'If the person with a cleft is homozygous for cleft chin (BB), their offspring will always have cleft chin.']
['If a person is heterozygous for this gene, will that mean their offspring', 'It gets a little more complicated, however, if the person is heterozygous for this gene (Bb).']

["What happens to the other person's offspring?", 'Since the other person has a smooth chin—therefore homozygous for the recessive allele (bb)—we can expect the offspring to have a 50% chance of having a cleft chin and a 50% chance of having a smooth chin.']

['What are some of the examples?', 'In sickle cell anemia, heterozygous carriers (like Luwi from the example) can develop blood resistance to malaria infection while those who are homozygous (like Sena) have a potentially lethal blood disorder.']
['What does the article tell us about sickle cell anemia?', 'Sickle-cell anemia is just one of many genetic disorders caused by the pairing of two recessive genes.']
['What is another example?', 'For example, phenylketonuria (PKU) is a condition in which individuals lack an enzyme that normally converts harmful amino acids into harmless byproducts.']

['What problems can PKU cause?', 'If someone with this condition goes untreated, they will experience significant deficits in cognitive function, seizures, and an increased risk of various psychiatric disorders.']
['What happens if someone has PKU?', 'Because PKU is a recessive trait, each parent must have at least one copy of the recessive allele in order to produce a child with the condition.']
['What are some traits that genetic variation determines?', 'So far, we have discussed traits that involve just one gene, but few human characteristics are controlled by a single gene.']
['What is polygenic?', 'Most traits are polygenic: controlled by more than one gene.']
['What are some examples of polygenic traits?', 'Height is one example of a polygenic trait, as are skin color and weight.']
['What are gene mutations?', 'Gene mutations provide one source of harmful genes.']
['What is a mutation?', 'A mutation is a sudden, permanent change in a gene.']

['What effect do mutations have?', 'While many mutations can be harmful or lethal, once in a while, a mutation benefits an individual by giving that person an advantage over those who do not have the mutation.']

['Why do some mutations benefit individuals?', 'Recall that the theory of evolution asserts that individuals best adapted to their particular environments are more likely to reproduce and pass on their genes to future generations.']

['What is important about genetic variance?', 'In order for this process to occur, there must be competition—more technically, there must be variability in genes (and resultant traits) that allow for variation in adaptability to the environment.']

['What else is important about genetic variance?', 'If a population consisted of identical individuals, then any dramatic changes in the environment would affect everyone in the same way, and there would be no variation in selection.']

["How can genetic variance help a person's performance?", 'In contrast, diversity in genes and associated traits allows some individuals to perform slightly better than others when faced with environmental change.']
['Why is this important?', 'This creates a distinct advantage for individuals best suited for their environments in terms of successful reproduction and genetic transmission.']
['What are the interactions between genes and the environment?', 'Genes do not exist in a vacuum.']

['Are there any other factors that affect gene expression?', 'Although we are all biological organisms, we also exist in an environment that is incredibly important in determining not only when and how our genes express themselves, but also in what combination.']

['Is the range of reaction a term for gene-environment interactions?', 'Each of us represents a unique interaction between our genetic makeup and our environment; range of reaction is one way to describe this interaction.']

['Why is the range of reaction important?', 'Range of reaction asserts that our genes set the boundaries within which we can operate, and our environment interacts with the genes to determine where in that range we will fall.']

['What is an example of this relationship?', 'For example, if an individual’s genetic makeup predisposes them to high levels of intellectual potential and they are reared in a rich, stimulating environment, then they will be more likely to achieve full potential than if they were raised under conditions of significant deprivation.']

['How do these interaction determine how much a person can do?', 'According to the concept of range of reaction, genes set definite limits on potential, and environment determines how much of that potential is achieved.']
['What is the disagreement?', 'Some disagree with this theory and argue that genes do not set a limit on a person’s potential with reaction norms being determined by the environment.']

['Is there anything else significant about the discussion?', 'For example, when individuals experience neglect or abuse early in life, they are more likely to exhibit adverse psychological and/or physical conditions that can last throughout their lives.']

['Does the theory have validity?', 'These conditions may develop as a function of the negative environmental experiences in individuals from dissimilar genetic backgrounds (Miguel, Pereira, Silveira, & Meaney, 2019; Short & Baram, 2019).']
["What's the most important information in this chapter?", 'Another perspective on the interaction between genes and the environment is the concept of genetic environmental correlation.']
['How does that concept work?', 'Stated simply, our genes influence our environment, and our environment influences the expression of our genes.']
['What else does that mean?', 'Not only do our genes and environment interact, as in range of reaction, but they also influence one another bidirectionally.']
['What is one example?', 'For example, the child of an NBA player would probably be exposed to basketball from an early age.']
['How would this affect him?', 'Such exposure might allow the child to realize their full genetic, athletic potential.']

['How do genes and environment interact?', 'Thus, the parents’ genes, which the child shares, influence the child’s environment, and that environment, in turn, is well suited to support the child’s genetic potential.']

['What is epigenetics?', 'In another approach to gene-environment interactions, the field of epigenetics looks beyond the genotype itself and studies how the same genotype can be expressed in different ways.']
['What is the difference between phenotypes and genotypes?', 'In other words, researchers study how the same genotype can lead to very different phenotypes.']

['What is one example of how phenotypes are altered in response to different environmental context', 'As mentioned earlier, gene expression is often influenced by environmental context in ways that are not entirely obvious.']

['What are other examples of gene-environment interactions?', 'For instance, identical twins share the same genetic information (identical twins develop from a single fertilized egg that split, so the genetic material is exactly the same in each; in contrast, fraternal twins usually result from two different eggs fertilized by different sperm, so the genetic material varies as with non-twin siblings).']

['Does this mean that they are mutated and different from the other twins?', 'But even with identical genes, there remains an incredible amount of variability in how gene expression can unfold over the course of each twin’s life.']
['What can we learn from this?', 'Sometimes, one twin will develop a disease and the other will not.']
['What else can we learn from this example?', 'In one example, Aliya, an identical twin, died from cancer at age 7, but her twin, now 19 years old, has never had cancer.']

['What can we learn from this?', 'Although these individuals share an identical genotype, their phenotypes differ as a result of how that genetic information is expressed over time and through their unique environmental interactions.']
['How is the epigenetic perspective different from range of reaction?', 'The epigenetic perspective is very different from range of reaction, because here the genotype is not fixed and limited.']
['What are some aspects of gene-environment interactions?', 'Genes affect more than our physical characteristics.']

['What are some other characteristics?', 'Indeed, scientists have found genetic linkages to a number of behavioral characteristics, ranging from basic personality traits to sexual orientation to spirituality (for examples, see Mustanski et al., 2005; Comings, Gonzales, Saucier, Johnson, & MacMurray, 2000).']

['Is there anything else that they have found in relation to genetic linkages?', 'Genes are also associated with temperament and a number of psychological disorders, such as depression and schizophrenia.']

['What is the relationship between genetics and environment?', 'So while it is true that genes provide the biological blueprints for our cells, tissues, organs, and body, they also have a significant impact on our experiences and our behaviors.']
['What is the content about?', 'Let’s look at the following findings regarding schizophrenia in light of our three views of gene-environment interactions.']

['What was the study about?', 'Of adoptees whose biological mothers had schizophrenia (high genetic risk) and who were raised in disturbed family environments, 36.8% were likely to develop schizophrenia.']

['How many percent were the other groups?', 'Of adoptees whose biological mothers had schizophrenia (high genetic risk) and who were raised in healthy family environments, 5.8% were likely to develop schizophrenia.']

['What percent of people had schizophrenia?', 'Of adoptees with a low genetic risk (whose mothers did not have schizophrenia) and who were raised in disturbed family environments, 5.3% were likely to develop schizophrenia.']

['How many percent of people who were raised in healthy family environments were likely to develop schizophrenia?', 'Of adoptees with a low genetic risk (whose mothers did not have schizophrenia) and who were raised in healthy family environments, 4.8% were likely to develop schizophrenia.']
['What is the conclusion of the study?', 'The study shows that adoptees with high genetic risk were most likely to develop schizophrenia if they were raised in disturbed home environments.']

['what is the impact of genetics and the environment?', 'This research lends credibility to the notion that both genetic vulnerability and environmental stress are necessary for schizophrenia to develop, and that genes alone do not tell the full tale.']
['What is the nervous system?', 'Psychologists striving to understand the human mind may study the nervous system.']
['What are the human cells and organs?', "Learning how the body's cells and organs function can help us understand the biological basis of human psychology."]
['What are the two basic cell types?', 'The nervous system is composed of two basic cell types: glial cells (also known as glia) and neurons.']
['What are the glial cells for?', 'Glial cells are traditionally thought to play a supportive role to neurons, both physically and metabolically.']

['What else do they support?', 'Glial cells provide scaffolding on which the nervous system is built, help neurons line up closely with each other to allow neuronal communication, provide insulation to neurons, transport nutrients and waste products, and mediate immune responses.']

['How many are there in the brain?', "For years, researchers believed that there were many more glial cells than neurons; however, more recent work from Suzanna Herculano-Houzel's laboratory has called this long-standing assumption into question and has provided important evidence that there may be a nearly 1:1 ratio of glia cells to neurons."]

['What is the 1:1 ratio?', 'This is important because it suggests that human brains are more similar to other primate brains than previously thought (Azevedo et al, 2009; Herculano-Houzel, 2012; Herculano-Houzel, 2009).']
['What else does the brain contain?', 'Neurons, on the other hand, serve as interconnected information processors that are essential for all of the tasks of the nervous system.']
['How do the neurons function?', 'This section briefly describes the structure and function of neurons.']
['What are neurons?', 'Neurons are the central building blocks of the nervous system, 100 billion strong at birth.']
['How does the neuron structure work?', 'Like all cells, neurons consist of several different parts, each serving a specialized function.']
['What are the parts of a neuron?', 'A neuron’s outer surface is made up of a semipermeable membrane.']
['What does the membrane do?', 'This membrane allows smaller molecules and molecules without an electrical charge to pass through it, while stopping larger or highly charged molecules.']
['Where is the nucleus?', 'The nucleus of the neuron is located in the soma, or cell body.']
['What else is the soma used for?', 'The soma has branching extensions known as dendrites.']
['Why do they have dendrites?', 'The neuron is a small information processor, and dendrites serve as input sites where signals are received from other neurons.']
['How do the signals move?', 'These signals are transmitted electrically across the soma and down a major extension from the soma known as the axon, which ends at multiple terminal buttons.']
['What is inside the terminal buttons?', 'The terminal buttons contain synaptic vesicles that house neurotransmitters, the chemical messengers of the nervous system.']
['How long are the axons?', 'Axons range in length from a fraction of an inch to several feet.']

['What does the myelin sheath do?', 'In some axons, glial cells form a fatty substance known as the myelin sheath, which coats the axon and acts as an insulator, increasing the speed at which the signal travels.']
['How is this fatty substance spread?', 'The myelin sheath is not continuous and there are small gaps that occur down the length of the axon.']
['How do these gaps get filled?', 'These gaps in the myelin sheath are known as the Nodes of Ranvier.']

['What else can you tell me about the myelin sheath?', 'The myelin sheath is crucial for the normal operation of the neurons within the nervous system: the loss of the insulation it provides can be detrimental to normal function.']
['What happens when axons are damaged?', 'To understand how this works, let’s consider an example.']
['How can you determine if a gene is damaged?', 'PKU, a genetic disorder discussed earlier, causes a reduction in myelin and abnormalities in white matter cortical and subcortical structures.']

['What symptoms might you experience?', 'The disorder is associated with a variety of issues including severe cognitive deficits, exaggerated reflexes, and seizures (Anderson & Leuzzi, 2010; Huttenlocher, 2000).']

['How is multiple sclerosis related to the fatty substance?', 'Another disorder, multiple sclerosis (MS), an autoimmune disorder, involves a large-scale loss of the myelin sheath on axons throughout the nervous system.']

['What are the consequences of this damage?', 'The resulting interference in the electrical signal prevents the quick transmittal of information by neurons and can lead to a number of symptoms, such as dizziness, fatigue, loss of motor control, and sexual dysfunction.']
['What are the treatments for MS?', 'While some treatments may help to modify the course of the disease and manage certain symptoms, there is currently no known cure for multiple sclerosis.']

['What is the most important information in this paragraph?', 'In healthy individuals, the neuronal signal moves rapidly down the axon to the terminal buttons, where synaptic vesicles release neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft.']
['What is the synaptic cleft?', 'The synaptic cleft is a very small space between two neurons and is an important site where communication between neurons occurs.']

['What happens to the neurotransmitters in this space?', 'Once neurotransmitters are released into the synaptic cleft, they travel across it and bind with corresponding receptors on the dendrite of an adjacent neuron.']
['What else does the paragraph cover?', 'Receptors, proteins on the cell surface where neurotransmitters attach, vary in shape, with different shapes “matching” different neurotransmitters.']

['What is a lock-and-key relationship?', 'The neurotransmitter and the receptor have what is referred to as a lock-and-key relationship—specific neurotransmitters fit specific receptors similar to how a key fits a lock.']
['What is the receptor specific for?', 'The neurotransmitter binds to any receptor that it fits.']
['Where do we begin?', 'We begin at the neuronal membrane.']
['Why is this?', 'The neuron exists in a fluid environment—it is surrounded by extracellular fluid and contains intracellular fluid (i.e., cytoplasm).']

['How does the membrane help?', 'The neuronal membrane keeps these two fluids separate—a critical role because the electrical signal that passes through the neuron depends on the intra- and extracellular fluids being electrically different.']
['Why is that?', 'This difference in charge across the membrane, called the membrane potential, provides energy for the signal.']
['What is the role of ions in brain fluids?', 'The electrical charge of the fluids is caused by charged molecules (ions) dissolved in the fluid.']

['What does the membrane do to the ions?', 'The semipermeable nature of the neuronal membrane somewhat restricts the movement of these charged molecules, and, as a result, some of the charged particles tend to become more concentrated either inside or outside the cell.']
['What happens between signals?', 'Between signals, the neuron membrane’s potential is held in a state of readiness, called the resting potential.']

['What is the resting potential like?', 'Like a rubber band stretched out and waiting to spring into action, ions line up on either side of the cell membrane, ready to rush across the membrane when the neuron goes active and the membrane opens its gates.']
['Where do the ions line up?', 'Ions in high-concentration areas are ready to move to low-concentration areas, and positive ions are ready to move to areas with a negative charge.']
['Which of the following is a signal?', 'In the resting state, sodium (Na+) is at higher concentrations outside the cell, so it will tend to move into the cell.']
['What is the resting state?', 'Potassium (K+), on the other hand, is more concentrated inside the cell, and will tend to move out of the cell.']
['What will move out of the cell?', 'In addition, the inside of the cell is slightly negatively charged compared to the outside, due to the activity of the sodium-potassium pump.']
['What activity of the sodium-potassium pump?', 'This pump actively transports three sodium ions out of the cell for every two potassium ions in, creating a net negative charge inside the cell.']
['What causes a net negative charge?', 'This provides an additional force on sodium, causing it to move into the cell.']
["What's the process called?", 'From this resting potential state, the neuron receives a signal and its state changes abruptly.']

['What happens after the signal is received?', 'When a neuron receives signals at the dendrites—due to neurotransmitters from an adjacent neuron binding to its receptors—small pores, or gates, open on the neuronal membrane, allowing Na+ ions, propelled by both charge and concentration differences, to move into the cell.']
['What happens with the influx?', 'With this influx of positive ions, the internal charge of the cell becomes more positive.']
['What happens with the internal charge?', 'If that charge reaches a certain level, called the threshold of excitation, the neuron becomes active and the action potential begins.']
['What is this signal known as?', 'Many additional pores open, causing a massive influx of Na+ ions and a huge positive spike in the membrane potential, the peak action potential.']
['How does this occur?', 'At the peak of the spike, the sodium gates close and the potassium gates open.']
['How does this lead to repolarization?', 'As positively charged potassium ions leave, the cell quickly begins repolarization.']
['What happens as the cell repolarizes?', 'At first, it hyperpolarizes, becoming slightly more negative than the resting potential, and then it levels off, returning to the resting potential.']
['What happens during the spike?', 'This positive spike constitutes the action potential: the electrical signal that typically moves from the cell body down the axon to the axon terminals.']
['How does the signal move?', 'The electrical signal moves down the axon with the impulses jumping in a leapfrog fashion between the Nodes of Ranvier.']
['What is the nodes of ranvier?', 'The Nodes of Ranvier are natural gaps in the myelin sheath.']

['What happens at each node?', 'At each point, some of the sodium ions that enter the cell diffuse to the next section of the axon, raising the charge past the threshold of excitation and triggering a new influx of sodium ions.']
['How does it go from node to node?', 'The action potential moves all the way down the axon in this fashion until reaching the terminal buttons.']
['What is the function of an action potential?', 'The action potential is an all-or-none phenomenon.']
['What does this mean?', 'In simple terms, this means that an incoming signal from another neuron is either sufficient or insufficient to reach the threshold of excitation.']
['Why is this so?', 'There is no in-between, and there is no turning off an action potential once it starts.']
['How is this similar to the process of signaling?', 'Think of it like sending an email or a text message.']
['Does this help?', 'You can think about sending it all you want, but the message is not sent until you hit the send button.']
['Is this an analogy?', 'Furthermore, once you send the message, there is no stopping it.']
['What happens at every point along the axon?', 'Because it is all or none, the action potential is recreated, or propagated, at its full strength at every point along the axon.']
['How does it compare to a firecracker?', 'Much like the lit fuse of a firecracker, it does not fade away as it travels down the axon.']

['What else was interesting about this?', 'It is this all-or-none property that explains the fact that your brain perceives an injury to a distant body part like your toe as equally painful as one to your nose.']

["What happened next in the signal's journey?", 'As noted earlier, when the action potential arrives at the terminal button, the synaptic vesicles release their neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft.']

['What did the neurotransmitters do?', 'The neurotransmitters travel across the synapse and bind to receptors on the dendrites of the adjacent neuron, and the process repeats itself in the new neuron (assuming the signal is sufficiently strong to trigger an action potential).']

['What happened after the signal was delivered?', 'Once the signal is delivered, excess neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft drift away, are broken down into inactive fragments, or are reabsorbed in a process known as reuptake.']
['How is this process known as reuptake?', 'Reuptake involves the neurotransmitter being pumped back into the neuron that released it, in order to clear the synapse.']

['Why does it clear the synapse?', 'Clearing the synapse serves both to provide a clear “on” and “off” state between signals and to regulate the production of neurotransmitter (full synaptic vesicles provide signals that no additional neurotransmitters need to be produced).']
['What is an electrochemical event?', 'Neuronal communication is often referred to as an electrochemical event.']

['What is the electric and chemical components of this signal?', 'The movement of the action potential down the length of the axon is an electrical event, and movement of the neurotransmitter across the synaptic space represents the chemical portion of the process.']
['What is the chemical part?', 'However, there are some specialized connections between neurons that are entirely electrical.']
['What happens when there is only an electrical pathway?', 'In such cases, the neurons are said to communicate via an electrical synapse.']
['What is the physical connection between neurons?', 'In these cases, two neurons physically connect to one another via gap junctions, which allows the current from one cell to pass into the next.']

['How fast is this current?', 'There are far fewer electrical synapses in the brain, but those that do exist are much faster than the chemical synapses that have been described above (Connors & Long, 2004).']

['What are the types of neurotransmitters?', 'There are several different types of neurotransmitters released by different neurons, and we can speak in broad terms about the kinds of functions associated with different neurotransmitters.']
['Who studied the brain?', 'Much of what psychologists know about the functions of neurotransmitters comes from research on the effects of drugs in psychological disorders.']

['What disorders?', 'Psychologists who take a biological perspective and focus on the physiological causes of behavior assert that psychological disorders like depression and schizophrenia are associated with imbalances in one or more neurotransmitter systems.']
['What did the research find?', 'In this perspective, psychotropic medications can help improve the symptoms associated with these disorders.']
['What is a psychotropic medication?', 'Psychotropic medications are drugs that treat psychiatric symptoms by restoring neurotransmitter balance.']
['What type of drugs can interact with the neurotransmitter system?', 'Psychoactive drugs can act as agonists or antagonists for a given neurotransmitter system.']
['What are the characteristics of an agonist?', 'Agonists are chemicals that mimic a neurotransmitter at the receptor site.']
['What are the characteristics of an antagonist?', 'An antagonist, on the other hand, blocks or impedes the normal activity of a neurotransmitter at the receptor.']
['How do the agonists and antagonists work?', 'Agonists and antagonists represent drugs that are prescribed to correct the specific neurotransmitter imbalances underlying a person’s condition.']
['What kind of imbalances can happen?', "For example, Parkinson's disease, a progressive nervous system disorder, is associated with low levels of dopamine."]

['What kind of drug does it mimic?', "Therefore, a common treatment strategy for Parkinson's disease involves using dopamine agonists, which mimic the effects of dopamine by binding to dopamine receptors."]
['What is overactive dopamine?', 'Certain symptoms of schizophrenia are associated with overactive dopamine neurotransmission.']
['What is an antagonist for dopamine?', 'The antipsychotics used to treat these symptoms are antagonists for dopamine—they block dopamine’s effects by binding its receptors without activating them.']
['What is a receptor without activating them?', 'Thus, they prevent dopamine released by one neuron from signaling information to adjacent neurons.']

['What are reuptake inhibitors?', 'In contrast to agonists and antagonists, which both operate by binding to receptor sites, reuptake inhibitors prevent unused neurotransmitters from being transported back to the neuron.']

['Why do they prevent unused neurotransmitters from being transported back?', 'This allows neurotransmitters to remain active in the synaptic cleft for longer durations, increasing their effectiveness.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about reuptake inhibitors?', 'Depression, which has been consistently linked with reduced serotonin levels, is commonly treated with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).']
['How do they treat depression?', 'By preventing reuptake, SSRIs strengthen the effect of serotonin, giving it more time to interact with serotonin receptors on dendrites.']
['Which common SSRIs are available on the market today?', 'Common SSRIs on the market today include Prozac, Paxil, and Zoloft.']
['What is LSD?', 'The drug LSD is structurally very similar to serotonin, and it affects the same neurons and receptors as serotonin.']
['Are there any other drugs that are considered psychotropics?', 'Psychotropic drugs are not instant solutions for people suffering from psychological disorders.']
['Why is that?', 'Often, an individual must take a drug for several weeks before seeing improvement, and many psychoactive drugs have significant negative side effects.']
['What are the side effects?', 'Furthermore, individuals vary dramatically in how they respond to the drugs.']
['What is pharmacotherapy?', 'To improve chances for success, it is not uncommon for people receiving pharmacotherapy to undergo psychological and/or behavioral therapies as well.']

['What are the results of that?', 'Some research suggests that combining drug therapy with other forms of therapy tends to be more effective than any one treatment alone (for one such example, see March et al., 2007).']

['What is the central nervous system?', 'The nervous system can be divided into two major subdivisions: the central nervous system (CNS) and the peripheral nervous system (PNS), shown in Figure 3.13.']
['How is the central nervous system connected to other parts of the body?', 'The CNS is comprised of the brain and spinal cord; the PNS connects the CNS to the rest of the body.']
['What parts of the peripheral nervous system are we talking about?', 'In this section, we focus on the peripheral nervous system; later, we look at the brain and spinal cord.']

['What is it made of?', 'The peripheral nervous system is made up of thick bundles of axons, called nerves, carrying messages back and forth between the CNS and the muscles, organs, and senses in the periphery of the body (i.e., everything outside the CNS).']
['Does it have any subdivisions?', 'The PNS has two major subdivisions: the somatic nervous system and the autonomic nervous system.']
['What is the somatic nervous system?', 'The somatic nervous system is associated with activities traditionally thought of as conscious or voluntary.']
['What is it involved in?', 'It is involved in the relay of sensory and motor information to and from the CNS; therefore, it consists of motor neurons and sensory neurons.']
['Are these motor neurons or sensory neurons?', 'Motor neurons, carrying instructions from the CNS to the muscles, are efferent fibers (efferent means “moving away from”).']
['What else is known about sensory neurons?', 'Sensory neurons, carrying sensory information to the CNS, are afferent fibers (afferent means “moving toward”).']
['How do you remember this?', 'A helpful way to remember this is that efferent = exit and afferent = arrive.']
['What else do you know about neurons?', 'Each nerve is basically a bundle of neurons forming a two-way superhighway, containing thousands of axons, both efferent and afferent.']
['What is the autonomic nervous system?', 'The autonomic nervous system controls our internal organs and glands and is generally considered to be outside the realm of voluntary control.']
['What do you know about the autonomic nervous system?', 'It can be further subdivided into the sympathetic and parasympathetic divisions.']

['What are the divisions called?', 'The sympathetic nervous system is involved in preparing the body for stress-related activities; the parasympathetic nervous system is associated with returning the body to routine, day-to-day operations.']
['What do these divisions do?', 'The two systems have complementary functions, operating in tandem to maintain the body’s homeostasis.']
['What is homeostasis?', 'Homeostasis is a state of equilibrium, or balance, in which biological conditions (such as body temperature) are maintained at optimal levels.']
['What is the sympathetic nervous system?', 'The sympathetic nervous system is activated when we are faced with stressful or high-arousal situations.']
['What happens in these situations?', 'The activity of this system was adaptive for our ancestors, increasing their chances of survival.']

['What can you describe as an example of how the sympathetic nervous system works?', 'Imagine, for example, that one of our early ancestors, out hunting small game, suddenly disturbs a large bear with her cubs.']
['How does the hunter react?', "At that moment, the hunter's body undergoes a series of changes—a direct function of sympathetic activation—preparing them to face the threat."]

['What other things does the body do during sympathetic activation?', 'The pupils dilate, the heart rate and blood pressure increase, the bladder relaxes, and the liver releases glucose; adrenaline surges into the bloodstream.']

['What does this response do?', 'This constellation of physiological changes, known as the fight or flight response, allows the body access to energy reserves and heightened sensory capacity so that it might fight off a threat or run away to safety.']

['What does stress do to our nervous system?', 'While it is clear that such a response would be critical for survival for our ancestors, who lived in a world full of real physical threats, many of the high-arousal situations we face in the modern world are more psychological in nature.']

['What are some examples of psychological stress?', 'For example, think about how you feel when you have to stand up and give a presentation in front of a roomful of people, or right before taking a big test.']

['Is there anything else interesting about this article?', 'You are in no real physical danger in those situations, and yet you have evolved to respond to a perceived threat with the fight or flight response.']

['What effect does that have?', 'This kind of response is not nearly as adaptive in the modern world; in fact, we suffer negative health consequences when faced constantly with psychological threats that we can neither fight nor flee.']

['How does stress affect our bodies?', 'Recent research suggests that an increase in susceptibility to heart disease (Chandola, Brunner, & Marmot, 2006) and impaired function of the immune system (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005) are among the many negative consequences of persistent and repeated exposure to stressful situations.']
['How can we reduce stress?', 'Some of this tendency for stress reactivity can be wired by early experiences of trauma.']
['What is parasympathetic?', 'Once the threat has been resolved, the parasympathetic nervous system takes over and returns bodily functions to a relaxed state.']

['What is the relaxation?', 'Our hunter’s heart rate and blood pressure return to normal, the pupils constrict, bladder control is restored, and the liver begins to store glucose in the form of glycogen for future use.']
['What are these restorative processes?', 'These restorative processes are associated with activation of the parasympathetic nervous system.']
['What is the brain?', 'The brain is a remarkably complex organ comprised of billions of interconnected neurons and glia.']
['What is the brain divided into?', 'It is a bilateral, or two-sided, structure that can be separated into distinct lobes.']

['What are the functions of the lobes?', 'Each lobe is associated with certain types of functions, but, ultimately, all of the areas of the brain interact with one another to provide the foundation for our thoughts and behaviors.']

['What other areas of the brain are involved?', 'In this section, we discuss the overall organization of the brain and the functions associated with different brain areas, beginning with what can be seen as an extension of the brain, the spinal cord.']
['What does the spinal cord do?', 'It can be said that the spinal cord is what connects the brain to the outside world.']
['Why is that?', 'Because of it, the brain can act.']
['What else can you tell me about the spinal cord?', 'The spinal cord is like a relay station, but a very smart one.']
['What does the spinal cord have to do with reflexes?', 'It not only routes messages to and from the brain, but it also has its own system of automatic processes, called reflexes.']

['what is the top of the spinal cord?', 'The top of the spinal cord is a bundle of nerves that merges with the brain stem, where the basic processes of life are controlled, such as breathing and digestion.']
['when does the spinal cord end?', 'In the opposite direction, the spinal cord ends just below the ribs—contrary to what we might expect, it does not extend all the way to the base of the spine.']
['What segments are in the spinal cord?', 'The spinal cord is functionally organized in 30 segments, corresponding with the vertebrae.']
['How does each segment communicate?', 'Each segment is connected to a specific part of the body through the peripheral nervous system.']
['How does the nervous system communicate?', 'Nerves branch out from the spine at each vertebra.']
['What are the branches?', 'Sensory nerves bring messages in; motor nerves send messages out to the muscles and organs.']
['What else is important about the spinal cord?', 'Messages travel to and from the brain through every segment.']
['What are sensory messages?', 'Some sensory messages are immediately acted on by the spinal cord, without any input from the brain.']
['What are two examples?', 'Withdrawal from a hot object and the knee jerk are two examples.']
['What are the parameters?', 'When a sensory message meets certain parameters, the spinal cord initiates an automatic reflex.']
['What is an automatic reflex?', 'The signal passes from the sensory nerve to a simple processing center, which initiates a motor command.']
['What else can you tell me about this part of the topic?', 'Seconds are saved, because messages don’t have to go the brain, be processed, and get sent back.']
['What else can you tell me about this part of the topic?', 'In matters of survival, the spinal reflexes allow the body to react extraordinarily fast.']
['What does this document say?', 'The spinal cord is protected by bony vertebrae and cushioned in cerebrospinal fluid, but injuries still occur.']
['What happens when the spinal cord is injured?', 'When the spinal cord is damaged in a particular segment, all lower segments are cut off from the brain, causing paralysis.']
['Where is the damage located?', 'Therefore, the lower on the spine damage occurs, the fewer functions an injured individual will lose.']
["What was Bob Woodruff's occupation?", 'Bob Woodruff, a reporter for ABC, suffered a traumatic brain injury after a bomb exploded next to the vehicle he was in while covering a news story in Iraq.']
['Was his brain injury a physical injury?', 'As a consequence of these injuries, Woodruff experienced many cognitive deficits including difficulties with memory and language.']
['Did he recover?', 'However, over time and with the aid of intensive amounts of cognitive and speech therapy, Woodruff has shown an incredible recovery of function (Fernandez, 2008, October 16).']
['What was one of the factors that made this recovery possible?', 'One of the factors that made this recovery possible was neuroplasticity.']
['What does neuroplasticity mean?', 'Neuroplasticity refers to how the nervous system can change and adapt.']

['What else is interesting about this article?', "Neuroplasticity can occur in a variety of ways including personal experiences, developmental processes, or, as in Woodruff's case, in response to some sort of damage or injury that has occurred."]

['What are some examples of neuroplasticity?', 'Neuroplasticity can involve creation of new synapses, pruning of synapses that are no longer used, changes in glial cells, and even the birth of new neurons.']

['What else can be said about neuroplasticity?', "Because of neuroplasticity, our brains are constantly changing and adapting, and while our nervous system is most plastic when we are very young, as Woodruff's case suggests, it is still capable of remarkable changes later in life."]

['What is cerebral cortex?', 'The surface of the brain, known as the cerebral cortex, is very uneven, characterized by a distinctive pattern of folds or bumps, known as gyri (singular: gyrus), and grooves, known as sulci (singular: sulcus), shown in Figure 3.15.']
['How are these folds different?', 'These gyri and sulci form important landmarks that allow us to separate the brain into functional centers.']

['What are the sulci?', 'The most prominent sulcus, known as the longitudinal fissure, is the deep groove that separates the brain into two halves or hemispheres: the left hemisphere and the right hemisphere.']

['What is one interesting aspect of the two hemispheres?', 'There is evidence of specialization of function—referred to as lateralization—in each hemisphere, mainly regarding differences in language functions.']
['What do we know about how the hemispheres work together?', 'The left hemisphere controls the right half of the body, and the right hemisphere controls the left half of the body.']

['What other interesting aspects about the hemispheres are in this section?', 'Decades of research on lateralization of function by Michael Gazzaniga and his colleagues suggest that a variety of functions ranging from cause-and-effect reasoning to self-recognition may follow patterns that suggest some degree of hemispheric dominance (Gazzaniga, 2005).']

['Are there any other interesting aspects of this section?', 'For example, the left hemisphere has been shown to be superior for forming associations in memory, selective attention, and positive emotions.']
['How about the right hemisphere?', 'The right hemisphere, on the other hand, has been shown to be superior in pitch perception, arousal, and negative emotions (Ehret, 2006).']

['What else is important to know?', 'However, it should be pointed out that research on which hemisphere is dominant in a variety of different behaviors has produced inconsistent results, and therefore, it is probably better to think of how the two hemispheres interact to produce a given behavior rather than attributing certain behaviors to one hemisphere versus the other (Banich & Heller, 1998).']
['What is the most important thing to know about this?', 'The two hemispheres are connected by a thick band of neural fibers known as the corpus callosum, consisting of about 200 million axons.']

['What does this help with?', 'The corpus callosum allows the two hemispheres to communicate with each other and allows for information being processed on one side of the brain to be shared with the other side.']

['What is the study material about?', 'Normally, we are not aware of the different roles that our two hemispheres play in day-to-day functions, but there are people who come to know the capabilities and functions of their two hemispheres quite well.']
['What does it have to do with epilepsy?', 'In some cases of severe epilepsy, doctors elect to sever the corpus callosum as a means of controlling the spread of seizures.']
['What is severing it?', 'While this is an effective treatment option, it results in individuals who have "split brains."']
['What happened after the surgery?', 'After surgery, these split-brain patients show a variety of interesting behaviors.']

['What kinds of behaviors?', 'For instance, a split-brain patient is unable to name a picture that is shown in the patient’s left visual field because the information is only available in the largely nonverbal right hemisphere.']
['How did they recreate it?', 'However, they are able to recreate the picture with their left hand, which is also controlled by the right hemisphere.']

['How does the left hemisphere react?', 'When the more verbal left hemisphere sees the picture that the hand drew, the patient is able to name it (assuming the left hemisphere can interpret what was drawn by the left hand).']

['what is one important thing you learned from the study material?', 'Much of what we know about the functions of different areas of the brain comes from studying changes in the behavior and ability of individuals who have suffered damage to the brain.']

['what kinds of damage do the brains of those with severe strokes suffer from?', 'For example, researchers study the behavioral changes caused by strokes to learn about the functions of specific brain areas.']
['what causes strokes?', 'A stroke, caused by an interruption of blood flow to a region in the brain, causes a loss of brain function in the affected region.']
['why does the study focus on strokes?', 'The damage can be in a small area, and, if it is, this gives researchers the opportunity to link any resulting behavioral changes to a specific area.']
['what is the effect on those affected by strokes?', 'The types of deficits displayed after a stroke will be largely dependent on where in the brain the damage occurred.']
['What are the names of these hemispheres?', 'Consider Theona, an intelligent, self-sufficient woman, who is 62 years old.']
['Why did she become the study example?', 'Recently, she suffered a stroke in the front portion of her right hemisphere.']
['What caused her stroke?', 'As a result, she has great difficulty moving her left leg.']

['What is the importance of the right hemisphere?', '(As you learned earlier, the right hemisphere controls the left side of the body; also, the brain’s main motor centers are located at the front of the head, in the frontal lobe.)']
['What other problems does she have?', 'Theona has also experienced behavioral changes.']

['What type of changes has she had?', 'For example, while in the produce section of the grocery store, she sometimes eats grapes, strawberries, and apples directly from their bins before paying for them.']

['What caused this change?', 'This behavior—which would have been very embarrassing to her before the stroke—is consistent with damage in another region in the frontal lobe—the prefrontal cortex, which is associated with judgment, reasoning, and impulse control.']
['What does the forebrain consist of?', 'The two hemispheres of the cerebral cortex are part of the forebrain, which is the largest part of the brain.']

['Are there any other parts of the forebrain?', 'The forebrain contains the cerebral cortex and a number of other structures that lie beneath the cortex (called subcortical structures): thalamus, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and the limbic system (a collection of structures).']

['What does the cerebral cortex do?', 'The cerebral cortex, which is the outer surface of the brain, is associated with higher level processes such as consciousness, thought, emotion, reasoning, language, and memory.']
['What are the lobes?', 'Each cerebral hemisphere can be subdivided into four lobes, each associated with different functions.']
['What are the four lobes of the brain?', 'The four lobes of the brain are the frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes.']
['What part of the brain is this?', 'The frontal lobe is located in the forward part of the brain, extending back to a fissure known as the central sulcus.']
['What are some of the functions of the frontal lobe?', 'The frontal lobe is involved in reasoning, motor control, emotion, and language.']

['What does this lobe contain?', 'It contains the motor cortex, which is involved in planning and coordinating movement; the prefrontal cortex, which is responsible for higher-level cognitive functioning; and Broca’s area, which is essential for language production.']
["What was Broca's area?", 'People who suffer damage to Broca’s area have great difficulty producing language of any form.']
['What kind of a person was Padma?', 'For example, Padma was an electrical engineer who was socially active and a caring, involved parent.']
['Did she ever have problems speaking?', 'About twenty years ago, she was in a car accident and suffered damage to her Broca’s area.']
['What happened to her speech?', 'She completely lost the ability to speak and form any kind of meaningful language.']
['Why was her speech affected?', 'There is nothing wrong with her mouth or her vocal cords, but she is unable to produce words.']
['How else did the accident affect her?', 'She can follow directions but can’t respond verbally, and she can read but no longer write.']
['What can she do?', 'She can do routine tasks like running to the market to buy milk, but she could not communicate verbally if a situation called for it.']
['What is the frontal lobe?', 'Probably the most famous case of frontal lobe damage is that of a man by the name of Phineas Gage.']
['What was the cause of this damage?', 'On September 13, 1848, Gage (age 25) was working as a railroad foreman in Vermont.']
['Where did this accident happen?', 'He and his crew were using an iron rod to tamp explosives down into a blasting hole to remove rock along the railway’s path.']
['Did he die from this accident?', 'Unfortunately, the iron rod created a spark and caused the rod to explode out of the blasting hole, into Gage’s face, and through his skull.']
['How was Gage affected?', 'Although lying in a pool of his own blood with brain matter emerging from his head, Gage was conscious and able to get up, walk, and speak.']
['What did he do after the accident?', 'But in the months following his accident, people noticed that his personality had changed.']
['What happened to Gage?', 'Many of his friends described him as no longer being himself.']
['What was he no longer?', 'Before the accident, it was said that Gage was a well-mannered, soft-spoken man, but he began to behave in odd and inappropriate ways after the accident.']
['How did this affect Gage?', 'Such changes in personality would be consistent with loss of impulse control—a frontal lobe function.']

['what did the rod do to the frontal lobe?', "Beyond the damage to the frontal lobe itself, subsequent investigations into the rod's path also identified probable damage to pathways between the frontal lobe and other brain structures, including the limbic system."]

['what did the damage do to the limbic system?', 'With connections between the planning functions of the frontal lobe and the emotional processes of the limbic system severed, Gage had difficulty controlling his emotional impulses.']
['What is the purpose of this lobe?', 'However, there is some evidence suggesting that the dramatic changes in Gage’s personality were exaggerated and embellished.']

["What can you tell me about Gage's case?", "Gage's case occurred in the midst of a 19th century debate over localization—regarding whether certain areas of the brain are associated with particular functions."]

['Was he an early proponent of localization?', 'On the basis of extremely limited information about Gage, the extent of his injury, and his life before and after the accident, scientists tended to find support for their own views, on whichever side of the debate they fell (Macmillan, 1999).']
['What is significant about the parietal lobe?', 'The brain’s parietal lobe is located immediately behind the frontal lobe, and is involved in processing information from the body’s senses.']
['What senses does it process?', 'It contains the somatosensory cortex, which is essential for processing sensory information from across the body, such as touch, temperature, and pain.']
['Is that the correct name of the lobe?', 'The somatosensory cortex is an area of the brain which processes touch and sensation.']
['What does the somatosensory cortex do?', 'The somatosensory cortex is fascinating because each different area of the cortex processes sensations from a different part of your body.']

['Can you elaborate on that?', 'Furthermore, the larger the surface area of the specific body part and the greater amount of nerves in that body part, the larger the area dedicated to processing sensation from that body part in the somatosensory cortex.']
['What body parts are larger?', 'For example, fingers take up a lot more space than toes.']
['What is the role of fingers?', 'As you can notice from, the amount of space to process sensation from fingers is much greater than that of toes.']

['What is the temporal lobe?', 'The temporal lobe is located on the side of the head (temporal means “near the temples”), and is associated with hearing, memory, emotion, and some aspects of language.']
['What does it do for hearing?', 'The auditory cortex, the main area responsible for processing auditory information, is located within the temporal lobe.']
['What else is located in the temporal lobe?', 'Wernicke’s area, important for speech comprehension, is also located here.']

['What is its role in speech comprehension?', 'Whereas individuals with damage to Broca’s area have difficulty producing language, those with damage to Wernicke’s area can produce sensible language, but they are unable to understand it.']

["What's a special characteristic of the occipital lobe?", 'The occipital lobe is located at the very back of the brain, and contains the primary visual cortex, which is responsible for interpreting incoming visual information.']

['How does the visual cortex process information?', 'The occipital cortex is organized retinotopically, which means there is a close relationship between the position of an object in a person’s visual field and the position of that object’s representation on the cortex.']
['What else does the occipital lobe do?', 'You will learn much more about how visual information is processed in the occipital lobe when you study sensation and perception.']
['What is the thalamus?', 'Other areas of the forebrain, located beneath the cerebral cortex, include the thalamus and the limbic system.']
['What does the thalamus do?', 'The thalamus is a sensory relay for the brain.']
['What sensory relays do it perform?', 'All of our senses, with the exception of smell, are routed through the thalamus before being directed to other areas of the brain for processing.']
['What role does the limbic system play?', 'The limbic system is involved in processing both emotion and memory.']

['What else does the limbic system do?', 'Interestingly, the sense of smell projects directly to the limbic system; therefore, not surprisingly, smell can evoke emotional responses in ways that other sensory modalities cannot.']

['What structures make up the limbic system?', 'The limbic system is made up of a number of different structures, but three of the most important are the hippocampus, the amygdala, and the hypothalamus.']
['What role does the hippocampus play?', 'The hippocampus is an essential structure for learning and memory.']
['What role does the amygdala play?', 'The amygdala is involved in our experience of emotion and in tying emotional meaning to our memories.']
['What role does the hypothalamus play?', 'The hypothalamus regulates a number of homeostatic processes, including the regulation of body temperature, appetite, and blood pressure.']
['What else does it regulate?', 'The hypothalamus also serves as an interface between the nervous system and the endocrine system and in the regulation of sexual motivation and behavior.']
['what is the case about?', 'In 1953, Henry Gustav Molaison (H. M.) was a 27-year-old man who experienced severe seizures.']
['What did they do to try to get rid of them?', 'In an attempt to control his seizures, H. M. underwent brain surgery to remove his hippocampus and amygdala.']

['What happened after the surgery?', 'Following the surgery, H.M’s seizures became much less severe, but he also suffered some unexpected—and devastating—consequences of the surgery: he lost his ability to form many types of new memories.']
['what was his new memory?', 'For example, he was unable to learn new facts, such as who was president of the United States.']
['what else did he lose?', 'He was able to learn new skills, but afterward he had no recollection of learning them.']
['what else did he lose?', 'For example, while he might learn to use a computer, he would have no conscious memory of ever having used one.']
['what else did he lose?', 'He could not remember new faces, and he was unable to remember events, even immediately after they occurred.']

['what did this cause for him?', 'Researchers were fascinated by his experience, and he is considered one of the most studied cases in medical and psychological history (Hardt, Einarsson, & Nader, 2010; Squire, 2009).']
['did the research help him?', 'Indeed, his case has provided tremendous insight into the role that the hippocampus plays in the consolidation of new learning into explicit memory.']
['What is the midbrain?', 'The midbrain is comprised of structures located deep within the brain, between the forebrain and the hindbrain.']
['What is the reticular formation?', 'The reticular formation is centered in the midbrain, but it actually extends up into the forebrain and down into the hindbrain.']
['What does it regulate?', 'The reticular formation is important in regulating the sleep/wake cycle, arousal, alertness, and motor activity.']
['what is one thing you should know about the midbrain?', 'The substantia nigra (Latin for “black substance”) and the ventral tegmental area (VTA) are also located in the midbrain.']
['what are they for?', 'Both regions contain cell bodies that produce the neurotransmitter dopamine, and both are critical for movement.']
['what was a disease related to it?', 'Degeneration of the substantia nigra and VTA is involved in Parkinson’s disease.']
['what else was special about them?', 'In addition, these structures are involved in mood, reward, and addiction (Berridge & Robinson, 1998; Gardner, 2011; George, Le Moal, & Koob, 2012).']
['What is the hindbrain?', 'The hindbrain is located at the back of the head and looks like an extension of the spinal cord.']
['What does the hindbrain contain?', 'It contains the medulla, pons, and cerebellum.']
['What does the medulla control?', 'The medulla controls the automatic processes of the autonomic nervous system, such as breathing, blood pressure, and heart rate.']
['What is the pons?', 'The word pons literally means “bridge,” and as the name suggests, the pons serves to connect the hindbrain to the rest of the brain.']
['How else does it help control the nervous system?', 'It also is involved in regulating brain activity during sleep.']
["What's the brainstem?", 'The medulla, pons, and various structures are known as the brainstem, and aspects of the brainstem span both the midbrain and the hindbrain.']

['What is cerebellum?', 'The cerebellum (Latin for “little brain”) receives messages from muscles, tendons, joints, and structures in our ear to control balance, coordination, movement, and motor skills.']
['What else does cerebellum do?', 'The cerebellum is also thought to be an important area for processing some types of memories.']
['What type of memories?', 'In particular, procedural memory, or memory involved in learning and remembering how to perform tasks, is thought to be associated with the cerebellum.']
['What did this help with?', 'Recall that H. M. was unable to form new explicit memories, but he could learn new tasks.']
['Why?', 'This is likely due to the fact that H. M.’s cerebellum remained intact.']
['What has brain imaging provided?', 'You have learned how brain injury can provide information about the functions of different parts of the brain.']
['What was a result of this discovery?', 'Increasingly, however, we are able to obtain that information using brain imaging techniques on individuals who have not suffered brain injury.']

['What is some more information?', 'In this section, we take a more in-depth look at some of the techniques that are available for imaging the brain, including techniques that rely on radiation, magnetic fields, or electrical activity within the brain.']
['What is a CT scan?', 'A computerized tomography (CT) scan involves taking a number of x-rays of a particular section of a person’s body or brain.']

['What does the CT scan tell you?', 'The x-rays pass through tissues of different densities at different rates, allowing a computer to construct an overall image of the area of the body being scanned.']
['Does the CT scan detect disease?', 'A CT scan is often used to determine whether someone has a tumor or significant brain atrophy.']
['What is positron emission tomography?', 'Positron emission tomography (PET) scans create pictures of the living, active brain.']
['What is a tracer?', 'An individual receiving a PET scan drinks or is injected with a mildly radioactive substance, called a tracer.']
['What happens to the tracer in the brain?', 'Once in the bloodstream, the amount of tracer in any given region of the brain can be monitored.']
['Why is it monitored?', 'As a brain area becomes more active, more blood flows to that area.']
['How is the brain mapped?', 'A computer monitors the movement of the tracer and creates a rough map of active and inactive areas of the brain during a given behavior.']

['How is it used in therapy?', 'PET scans show little detail, are unable to pinpoint events precisely in time, and require that the brain be exposed to radiation; therefore, this technique has been replaced by the fMRI as an alternative diagnostic tool.']
['How is it used today?', 'However, combined with CT, PET technology is still being used in certain contexts.']
['What is an example?', 'For example, CT/PET scans allow better imaging of the activity of neurotransmitter receptors and open new avenues in schizophrenia research.']
['What was the result of this combined technology?', 'In this hybrid CT/PET technology, CT contributes clear images of brain structures, while PET shows the brain’s activity.']
["What's the most important information we learned?", 'In magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), a person is placed inside a machine that generates a strong magnetic field.']
['What happens when the field gets strong?', 'The magnetic field causes the hydrogen atoms in the body’s cells to move.']
['What happens when the field is turned off?', 'When the magnetic field is turned off, the hydrogen atoms emit electromagnetic signals as they return to their original positions.']
['What else happens during the scan?', 'Tissues of different densities give off different signals, which a computer interprets and displays on a monitor.']

['What else is significant about this process?', 'Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) operates on the same principles, but it shows changes in brain activity over time by tracking blood flow and oxygen levels.']
['Is this type of scan more or less accurate than PET?', 'The fMRI provides more detailed images of the brain’s structure, as well as better accuracy in time, than is possible in PET scans.']

['Does it tell the difference between healthy and sick brains?', 'With their high level of detail, MRI and fMRI are often used to compare the brains of healthy individuals to the brains of individuals diagnosed with psychological disorders.']
['What do the comparisons show?', 'This comparison helps determine what structural and functional differences exist between these populations.']

['What was the main idea of this document?', 'In some situations, it is helpful to gain an understanding of the overall activity of a person’s brain, without needing information on the actual location of the activity.']
['How does EEG help?', 'Electroencephalography (EEG) serves this purpose by providing a measure of a brain’s electrical activity.']
['What is EEG?', 'An array of electrodes is placed around a person’s head.']

['How do the electrodes work?', 'The signals received by the electrodes result in a printout of the electrical activity of their brain, or brainwaves, showing both the frequency (number of waves per second) and amplitude (height) of the recorded brainwaves, with an accuracy within milliseconds.']
['What is the most important thing in this article?', 'Such information is especially helpful to researchers studying sleep patterns among individuals with sleep disorders.']
['What is the endocrine system?', 'The endocrine system consists of a series of glands that produce chemical substances known as hormones.']
['What are hormones?', 'Like neurotransmitters, hormones are chemical messengers that must bind to a receptor in order to send their signal.']

['Do hormones interact with cells?', 'However, unlike neurotransmitters, which are released in close proximity to cells with their receptors, hormones are secreted into the bloodstream and travel throughout the body, affecting any cells that contain receptors for them.']
['Are hormones similar to neurotransmitters?', 'Thus, whereas neurotransmitters’ effects are localized, the effects of hormones are widespread.']
['Are there any other differences between hormones and neurotransmitters?', 'Also, hormones are slower to take effect, and tend to be longer lasting.']

['What is the endocrine system?', 'Hormones are involved in regulating all sorts of bodily functions, and they are ultimately controlled through interactions between the hypothalamus (in the central nervous system) and the pituitary gland (in the endocrine system).']
['Are there any problems associated with the endocrine system?', 'Imbalances in hormones are related to a number of disorders.']
['What happens in this section?', 'This section explores some of the major glands that make up the endocrine system and the hormones secreted by these glands.']
['What is the pituitary gland?', 'The pituitary gland descends from the hypothalamus at the base of the brain, and acts in close association with it.']

['What is it used for?', 'The pituitary is often referred to as the “master gland” because its messenger hormones control all the other glands in the endocrine system, although it mostly carries out instructions from the hypothalamus.']

['Is there anything else interesting about the pituitary gland?', 'In addition to messenger hormones, the pituitary also secretes growth hormone, endorphins for pain relief, and a number of key hormones that regulate fluid levels in the body.']
['What does the thyroid do?', 'Located in the neck, the thyroid gland releases hormones that regulate growth, metabolism, and appetite.']
['What can happen to the thyroid?', 'In hyperthyroidism, or Grave’s disease, the thyroid secretes too much of the hormone thyroxine, causing agitation, bulging eyes, and weight loss.']
['How else can this affect your body?', 'In hypothyroidism, reduced hormone levels cause sufferers to experience tiredness, and they often complain of feeling cold.']
['What is one way to get rid of this problem?', 'Fortunately, thyroid disorders are often treatable with medications that help reestablish a balance in the hormones secreted by the thyroid.']
['What are adrenal glands?', 'The adrenal glands sit atop our kidneys and secrete hormones involved in the stress response, such as epinephrine (adrenaline) and norepinephrine (noradrenaline).']
['What is the pancreas?', 'The pancreas is an internal organ that secretes hormones that regulate blood sugar levels: insulin and glucagon.']

['What do these hormones regulate?', 'These pancreatic hormones are essential for maintaining stable levels of blood sugar throughout the day by lowering blood glucose levels (insulin) or raising them (glucagon).']

['How is diabetes treated?', 'People who suffer from diabetes do not produce enough insulin; therefore, they must take medications that stimulate or replace insulin production, and they must closely control the amount of sugars and carbohydrates they consume.']
['What is it about?', 'The gonads secrete sexual hormones, which are important in reproduction, and mediate both sexual motivation and behavior.']
['What are they referred to as?', 'The female gonads are the ovaries; the male gonads are the testes.']
['What hormones do they secrete?', 'Ovaries secrete estrogens and progesterone, and the testes secrete androgens, such as testosterone.']
['What does consciousness refer to?', 'Consciousness describes our awareness of internal and external stimuli.']
['What are some examples of internal stimuli?', 'Awareness of internal stimuli includes feeling pain, hunger, thirst, sleepiness, and being aware of our thoughts and emotions.']

['What are some examples of external stimuli?', 'Awareness of external stimuli includes experiences such as seeing the light from the sun, feeling the warmth of a room, and hearing the voice of a friend.']
['What kind of consciousness do we experience?', 'We experience different states of consciousness and different levels of awareness on a regular basis.']
