['What are the levels of awareness?', 'We might even describe consciousness as a continuum that ranges from full awareness to a deep sleep.']

['Is there anything else of note regarding the continuum?', 'Sleep is a state marked by relatively low levels of physical activity and reduced sensory awareness that is distinct from periods of rest that occur during wakefulness.']
['What are the characteristics of wakefulness?', 'Wakefulness is characterized by high levels of sensory awareness, thought, and behavior.']
['What are some other states of consciousness?', 'Beyond being awake or asleep, there are many other states of consciousness people experience.']
['What other states are mentioned?', 'These include daydreaming, intoxication, and unconsciousness due to anesthesia.']
['What is anesthesia?', 'We might also experience unconscious states of being via drug-induced anesthesia for medical purposes.']
['What other aspects of awareness are important?', 'Often, we are not completely aware of our surroundings, even when we are fully awake.']
['Are we aware of what our environment is like?', 'You were capable of engaging in the all of the complex tasks involved with operating a motor vehicle even though you were not aware of doing so.']
['Is there anything else interesting that you can tell me about consciousness?', 'Many of these processes, like much of psychological behavior, are rooted in our biology.']
['What are Biological Rhythms?', 'Biological rhythms are internal rhythms of biological activity.']
['What type of activity does that include?', 'A woman’s menstrual cycle is an example of a biological rhythm—a recurring, cyclical pattern of bodily changes.']
['What type of cycles?', 'One complete menstrual cycle takes about 28 days—a lunar month—but many biological cycles are much shorter.']
['Are there other examples?', 'For example, body temperature fluctuates cyclically over a 24-hour period.']
['What do we know about body temperature?', 'Alertness is associated with higher body temperatures, and sleepiness with lower body temperatures.']
['What is an example of a biological rhythm?', 'This pattern of temperature fluctuation, which repeats every day, is one example of a circadian rhythm.']
['What is the definition of circadian rhythm?', 'A circadian rhythm is a biological rhythm that takes place over a period of about 24 hours.']

['What are some examples of circadian rhythm?', 'Our sleep-wake cycle, which is linked to our environment’s natural light-dark cycle, is perhaps the most obvious example of a circadian rhythm, but we also have daily fluctuations in heart rate, blood pressure, blood sugar, and body temperature.']
['What are some other examples of circadian rhythm?', 'Some circadian rhythms play a role in changes in our state of consciousness.']
['what does homeostasis mean in the brain?', 'In the brain, the hypothalamus, which lies above the pituitary gland, is a main center of homeostasis.']
['What is homeostasis?', 'Homeostasis is the tendency to maintain a balance, or optimal level, within a biological system.']

['Which specific parts of the brain control sleep, wake cycles, and internal clocks?', 'The brain’s clock mechanism is located in an area of the hypothalamus known as the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN).']

['Why is this important?', 'The axons of light-sensitive neurons in the retina provide information to the SCN based on the amount of light present, allowing this internal clock to be synchronized with the outside world (Klein, Moore, & Reppert, 1991; Welsh, Takahashi, & Kay, 2010).']
['What does the circadian cycle consist of?', 'Generally, and for most people, our circadian cycles are aligned with the outside world.']
['Are there any specific examples of this?', 'For example, most people sleep during the night and are awake during the day.']
['What does melatonin have to do with the circadian cycle?', 'One important regulator of sleep-wake cycles is the hormone melatonin.']

['What does melatonin do?', 'The pineal gland, an endocrine structure located inside the brain that releases melatonin, is thought to be involved in the regulation of various biological rhythms and of the immune system during sleep (Hardeland, Pandi-Perumal, & Cardinali, 2006).']
['What are some effects of light on melatonin?', 'Melatonin release is stimulated by darkness and inhibited by light.']
['What are some of the problems with circadian rhythms?', 'There are individual differences in regard to our sleep-wake cycle.']
['What is one example of this?', 'For instance, some people would say they are morning people, while others would consider themselves to be night owls.']

['What is this called?', 'These individual differences in circadian patterns of activity are known as a person’s chronotype, and research demonstrates that morning larks and night owls differ with regard to sleep regulation (Taillard, Philip, Coste, Sagaspe, & Bioulac, 2003).']
['What is sleep regulation?', 'Sleep regulation refers to the brain’s control of switching between sleep and wakefulness as well as coordinating this cycle with the outside world.']
['What is Disruptions of Normal Sleep?', 'Whether lark, owl, or somewhere in between, there are situations in which a person’s circadian clock gets out of synchrony with the external environment.']
['How does this happen?', 'One way that this happens involves traveling across multiple time zones.']
['What happens when you travel?', 'When we do this, we often experience jet lag.']
['What is jet lag?', 'Jet lag is a collection of symptoms that results from the mismatch between our internal circadian cycles and our environment.']

['What are the symptoms?', 'These symptoms include fatigue, sluggishness, irritability, and insomnia (i.e., a consistent difficulty in falling or staying asleep for at least three nights a week over a month’s time) (Roth, 2007).']
['What is a disruption?', 'Individuals who do rotating shift work are also likely to experience disruptions in circadian cycles.']
['What is rotation?', 'Rotating shift work refers to a work schedule that changes from early to late on a daily or weekly basis.']
['What hours do people work?', 'For example, a person may work from 7:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. on Monday, 3:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. on Tuesday, and 11:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. on Wednesday.']
['Why are they disrupted?', 'In such instances, the individual’s schedule changes so frequently that it becomes difficult for a normal circadian rhythm to be maintained.']
['What else can disrupt your sleep cause?', 'This often results in sleeping problems, and it can lead to signs of depression and anxiety.']

['What else can it cause?', 'These kinds of schedules are common for individuals working in health care professions and service industries, and they are associated with persistent feelings of exhaustion and agitation that can make someone more prone to making mistakes on the job (Gold et al., 1992; Presser, 1995).']

['What are the results of the study?', 'Rotating shift work has pervasive effects on the lives and experiences of individuals engaged in that kind of work, which is clearly illustrated in stories reported in a qualitative study that researched the experiences of middle-aged nurses who worked rotating shifts (West, Boughton & Byrnes, 2009).']
['How did this affect their lives?', 'Several of the nurses interviewed commented that their work schedules affected their relationships with their family.']
['How was it affected?', 'One of the nurses said,']

['What did the page mainly discuss?', 'While disruptions in circadian rhythms can have negative consequences, there are things we can do to help us realign our biological clocks with the external environment.']

['How can we realign our biological clocks?', 'Some of these approaches, such as using a bright light as shown in Figure 4.4, have been shown to alleviate some of the problems experienced by individuals suffering from jet lag or from the consequences of rotating shift work.']

['Are there any other approaches mentioned that are helpful?', 'Because the biological clock is driven by light, exposure to bright light during working shifts and dark exposure when not working can help combat insomnia and symptoms of anxiety and depression (Huang, Tsai, Chen, & Hsu, 2013).']
['What is Insufficient sleep?', 'When people have difficulty getting sleep due to their work or the demands of day-to-day life, they accumulate a sleep debt.']
['What is a sleep debt?', 'A person with a sleep debt does not get sufficient sleep on a chronic basis.']
['What are the consequences?', 'The consequences of sleep debt include decreased levels of alertness and mental efficiency.']
['How did this happen?', 'Interestingly, since the advent of electric light, the amount of sleep that people get has declined.']

['What else has changed?', 'While we certainly welcome the convenience of having the darkness lit up, we also suffer the consequences of reduced amounts of sleep because we are more active during the nighttime hours than our ancestors were.']
['What does this lead to?', 'As a result, many of us sleep less than 7–8 hours a night and accrue a sleep debt.']

['Do we know how much sleep is required?', 'While there is tremendous variation in any given individual’s sleep needs, the National Sleep Foundation (n.d.) cites research to estimate that newborns require the most sleep (between 12 and 18 hours a night) and that this amount declines to just 7–9 hours by the time we are adults.']
['What are the signs of having sleep debt?', 'If you lie down to take a nap and fall asleep very easily, chances are you may have sleep debt.']

['Why do you have the sleep debt?', 'Given that college students are notorious for suffering from significant sleep debt (Hicks, Fernandez, & Pellegrini, 2001; Hicks, Johnson, & Pellegrini, 1992; Miller, Shattuck, & Matsangas, 2010), chances are you and your classmates deal with sleep debt-related issues on a regular basis.']
['What is the minimum amount of sleep required?', 'In 2015, the National Sleep Foundation updated their sleep duration hours, to better accommodate individual differences.']
['What is the recommendation?', 'Table 4.1 shows the new recommendations, which describe sleep durations that are “recommended”, “may be appropriate”, and “not recommended”.']
['What did you learn about this topic?', 'Sleep debt and sleep deprivation have significant negative psychological and physiological consequences Figure 4.5.']
['How can not sleeping make you mentally alert?', 'As mentioned earlier, lack of sleep can result in decreased mental alertness and cognitive function.']
['What are some of the other side effects of not sleeping?', 'In addition, sleep deprivation often results in depression-like symptoms.']
['What are some of the effects of not sleeping?', 'These effects can occur as a function of accumulated sleep debt or in response to more acute periods of sleep deprivation.']

['What else is a negative effect of not sleeping?', 'It may surprise you to know that sleep deprivation is associated with obesity, increased blood pressure, increased levels of stress hormones, and reduced immune functioning (Banks & Dinges, 2007).']
['What else did you learn?', 'A sleep deprived individual generally will fall asleep more quickly than if they were not sleep deprived.']
["What happens if you haven't slept in days?", 'Some sleep-deprived individuals have difficulty staying awake when they stop moving (example sitting and watching television or driving a car).']

['What can one do when driving?', 'That is why individuals suffering from sleep deprivation can also put themselves and others at risk when they put themselves behind the wheel of a car or work with dangerous machinery.']
['What else did you learn?', 'Some research suggests that sleep deprivation affects cognitive and motor function as much as, if not more than, alcohol intoxication (Williamson & Feyer, 2000).']

["What happens if you haven't slept?", 'Research shows that the most severe effects of sleep deprivation occur when a person stays awake for more than 24 hours (Killgore & Weber, 2014; Killgore et al., 2007), or following repeated nights with fewer than four hours in bed (Wickens, Hutchins, Lauk, Seebook, 2015).']
['What else did you learn?', 'For example, irritability, distractibility, and impairments in cognitive and moral judgment can occur with fewer than four hours of sleep.']
['What else can happen?', 'If someone stays awake for 48 consecutive hours, they could start to hallucinate.']
['What does inadequate sleep mean?', 'The amount of sleep we get varies across the lifespan.']
['What is an average amount of sleep per night?', 'When we are very young, we spend up to 16 hours a day sleeping.']
['Is this an average amount of time based on age or gender?', 'As we grow older, we sleep less.']

['Are there studies about this?', 'In fact, a meta-analysis, which is a study that combines the results of many related studies, conducted within the last decade indicates that by the time we are 65 years old, we average fewer than 7 hours of sleep per day (Ohayon, Carskadon, Guilleminault, & Vitiello, 2004).']
['What are some interesting facts about our study material?', 'We spend approximately one-third of our lives sleeping.']

['How long do we spend sleeping?', 'Given the average life expectancy for U.S. citizens falls between 73 and 79 years old (Singh & Siahpush, 2006), we can expect to spend approximately 25 years of our lives sleeping.']

['Did most animals sleep?', 'Some animals never sleep (e.g., some fish and amphibian species); other animals sleep very little without apparent negative consequences (e.g., giraffes); yet some animals (e.g., rats) die after two weeks of sleep deprivation (Siegel, 2008).']
['Did we ever learn why we sleep?', 'This section will consider these questions and explore various explanations for why we sleep.']
['What are the features of sleep?', 'You have read that sleep is distinguished by low levels of physical activity and reduced sensory awareness.']

['What else is the definition of sleep?', 'As discussed by Siegel (2008), a definition of sleep must also include mention of the interplay of the circadian and homeostatic mechanisms that regulate sleep.']
['What else is there about sleep that is noteworthy?', 'Homeostatic regulation of sleep is evidenced by sleep rebound following sleep deprivation.']
['What is sleep rebound?', 'Sleep rebound refers to the fact that a sleep-deprived individual will fall asleep more quickly during subsequent opportunities for sleep.']

['Does sleep have certain phases?', 'Sleep is characterized by certain patterns of activity of the brain that can be visualized using electroencephalography (EEG), and different phases of sleep can be differentiated using EEG as well.']
['What is the first thing you need to do when reading this material?', 'Sleep-wake cycles seem to be controlled by multiple brain areas acting in conjunction with one another.']
['What areas are involved in this process?', 'Some of these areas include the thalamus, the hypothalamus, and the pons.']

['What is it responsible for?', 'As already mentioned, the hypothalamus contains the SCN—the biological clock of the body—in addition to other nuclei that, in conjunction with the thalamus, regulate slow-wave sleep.']
['What else do these parts control?', 'The pons is important for regulating rapid eye movement (REM) sleep (National Institutes of Health, n.d.).']

['What are the main aspects of this study material?', 'Sleep is also associated with the secretion and regulation of a number of hormones from several endocrine glands including: melatonin, follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), and growth hormone (National Institutes of Health, n.d.).']
['What is the pineal gland?', 'You have read that the pineal gland releases melatonin during sleep.']
['What does melatonin do?', 'Melatonin is thought to be involved in the regulation of various biological rhythms and the immune system (Hardeland et al., 2006).']

['What is the pituitary gland?', 'During sleep, the pituitary gland secretes both FSH and LH which are important in regulating the reproductive system (Christensen et al., 2012; Sofikitis et al., 2008).']

['What else is secreted by the pituitary gland during sleep?', 'The pituitary gland also secretes growth hormone, during sleep, which plays a role in physical growth and maturation as well as other metabolic processes (Bartke, Sun, & Longo, 2013).']

['Why Do We Sleep?', 'Given the central role that sleep plays in our lives and the number of adverse consequences that have been associated with sleep deprivation, one would think that we would have a clear understanding of why it is that we sleep.']
['What else do you find interesting?', 'Unfortunately, this is not the case; however, several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the function of sleep.']
['What is an example of a hypothesis?', 'One popular hypothesis of sleep incorporates the perspective of evolutionary psychology.']

['What is evolutionary psychology?', 'Evolutionary psychology is a discipline that studies how universal patterns of behavior and cognitive processes have evolved over time as a result of natural selection.']
['Why is it important?', 'Variations and adaptations in cognition and behavior make individuals more or less successful in reproducing and passing their genes to their offspring.']

['What is one of the hypotheses that incorporates this perspective?', 'One hypothesis from this perspective might argue that sleep is essential to restore resources that are expended during the day.']
['How are resources expended expended?', 'Just as bears hibernate in the winter when resources are scarce, perhaps people sleep at night to reduce their energy expenditures.']
['What else can you tell me about this hypothesis?', 'While this is an intuitive explanation of sleep, there is little research that supports this explanation.']

['What else is said about this hypothesis?', 'In fact, it has been suggested that there is no reason to think that energetic demands could not be addressed with periods of rest and inactivity (Frank, 2006; Rial et al., 2007), and some research has actually found a negative correlation between energetic demands and the amount of time spent sleeping (Capellini, Barton, McNamara, Preston, & Nunn, 2008).']
['What was another theory about this?', 'Another evolutionary hypothesis of sleep holds that our sleep patterns evolved as an adaptive response to predatory risks, which increase in darkness.']
['What does this mean?', 'Thus we sleep in safe areas to reduce the chance of harm.']
['Did it change the rest of the theory?', 'Again, this is an intuitive and appealing explanation for why we sleep.']
['What were other theories?', 'Perhaps our ancestors spent extended periods of time asleep to reduce attention to themselves from potential predators.']
['Did the theory change?', 'Comparative research indicates, however, that the relationship that exists between predatory risk and sleep is very complex and equivocal.']

['What else is important?', 'Some research suggests that species that face higher predatory risks sleep fewer hours than other species (Capellini et al., 2008), while other researchers suggest there is no relationship between the amount of time a given species spends in deep sleep and its predation risk (Lesku, Roth, Amlaner, & Lima, 2006).']

['What is the adaptive function of sleep?', 'It is quite possible that sleep serves no single universally adaptive function, and different species have evolved different patterns of sleep in response to their unique evolutionary pressures.']

['What is one of the benefits?', 'While we have discussed the negative outcomes associated with sleep deprivation, it should be pointed out that there are many benefits that are associated with adequate amounts of sleep.']

['What are some of these benefits?', 'A few such benefits listed by the National Sleep Foundation (n.d.) include maintaining healthy weight, lowering stress levels, improving mood, and increasing motor coordination, as well as a number of benefits related to cognition and memory formation.']
['Why do we sleep?', 'Another theory regarding why we sleep involves sleep’s importance for cognitive function and memory formation (Rattenborg, Lesku, Martinez-Gonzalez, & Lima, 2007).']

['What is the purpose of cognitive function?', 'Indeed, we know sleep deprivation results in disruptions in cognition and memory deficits (Brown, 2012), leading to impairments in our abilities to maintain attention, make decisions, and recall long-term memories.']
['How does it affect our ability to perform these tasks?', 'Moreover, these impairments become more severe as the amount of sleep deprivation increases (Alhola & Polo-Kantola, 2007).']

['What are some other cognitive benefits of sleep?', 'Furthermore, slow-wave sleep after learning a new task can improve resultant performance on that task (Huber, Ghilardi, Massimini, & Tononi, 2004) and seems essential for effective memory formation (Stickgold, 2005).']

['What else is important to know about cognitive function?', 'Understanding the impact of sleep on cognitive function should help you understand that cramming all night for a test may be not effective and can even prove counterproductive.']
['What is the most important information you can find in this section?', 'Getting the optimal amount of sleep has also been associated with other cognitive benefits.']

['What other benefits can getting enough sleep have?', 'Research indicates that included among these possible benefits are increased capacities for creative thinking (Cai, Mednick, Harrison, Kanady, & Mednick, 2009; Wagner, Gais, Haider, Verleger, & Born, 2004), language learning (Fenn, Nusbaum, & Margoliash, 2003; Gómez, Bootzin, & Nadel, 2006), and inferential judgments (Ellenbogen, Hu, Payne, Titone, & Walker, 2007).']
['What other benefits can getting enough sleep have?', 'It is possible that even the processing of emotional information is influenced by certain aspects of sleep (Walker, 2009).']
['What is the relationship between sleep and human beings?', 'Sleep is not a uniform state of being.']

['Is there anything interesting about this topic?', 'Instead, sleep is composed of several different stages that can be differentiated from one another by the patterns of brain wave activity that occur during each stage.']
['What brain wave activity is dominant?', 'While awake, our brain wave activity is dominated by beta waves.']

['What does the dominant brain wave activity look like?', 'As compared to the brain wave patterns while asleep, beta waves have the highest frequency (13–30 Hz) and lowest amplitude, and they tend to show more variability.']
['What is the difference between these two?', 'As we begin to fall asleep, our brain wave activity changes.']
['What are the changes?', 'These changes can be visualized using an EEG and are distinguished from one another by both the frequency and amplitude of the brain wave.']
['What is the frequency?', 'The frequency of a brain wave is how many brain waves occur in a second, and frequency is measured in Hertz (Hz).']
['What is amplitude?', 'Amplitude is the height of the brain wave.']
['What is one of the stages in sleep?', 'Sleep can be divided into two different general phases: REM sleep and non-REM (NREM) sleep.']
['What is REM?', 'Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep is characterized by darting movements of the eyes under closed eyelids.']
['What is the difference?', 'Brain waves during REM sleep appear very similar to brain waves during wakefulness.']

['What is the difference between those two?', 'In contrast, non-REM (NREM) sleep is subdivided into three stages distinguished from each other and from wakefulness by characteristic patterns of brain waves.']
['Is there anything else important?', 'The first three stages of sleep are NREM sleep, typically followed by REM sleep.']
['What happens during these stages?', 'In this section, we will discuss each of these stages of sleep and their associated patterns of brain wave activity.']
['What else is included in the study material?', 'As we begin to fall asleep, we enter NREM sleep, and brain wave patterns decrease in frequency and increase in amplitude.']
["What's stage 1?", 'The first stage of NREM sleep is known as stage 1 sleep.']
["What's stage 1?", 'Stage 1 sleep is a transitional phase that occurs between wakefulness and sleep, the period during which we drift off to sleep.']
['What else happens during stage 1?', 'During this time, there is a slowdown in both the rates of respiration and heartbeat.']
['What else happens during stage 1?', 'In addition, stage 1 sleep involves a marked decrease in both overall muscle tension and core body temperature.']
['What does stage 1 sleep involve?', 'In terms of brain wave activity, stage 1 sleep is associated with both alpha and theta waves.']
["Is this related to the brain's activity?", 'The early portion of stage 1 sleep produces alpha waves.']

['How are these waves related to sleep?', 'These patterns of electrical activity (waves) resemble that of someone who is very relaxed, yet awake, but they have less variability (are more synchronized) and are relatively lower in frequency (8–12 Hz) and higher in amplitude than beta waves.']
['What else is interesting about the brain activity?', 'As an individual continues through stage 1 sleep, there is an increase in theta wave activity.']
['What is theta wave activity?', 'Theta waves are even lower frequency (4–7 Hz), and higher in amplitude, than the alpha wave patterns.']

['Does it take a lot of effort to wake someone up from stage 1 sleep?', 'It is relatively easy to wake someone from stage 1 sleep; in fact, people often report that they have not been asleep if they are awoken during stage 1 sleep.']
['what did you learn about stage 2 sleep?', 'As we move into stage 2 sleep, the body goes into a state of deep relaxation.']
['what happens to the brain?', 'Theta waves still dominate the activity of the brain, but they are interrupted by brief bursts of activity known as sleep spindles.']
['what do they produce?', 'A sleep spindle is a rapid burst of higher frequency brain waves that may be important for learning and memory (Fogel & Smith, 2011; Poe, Walsh, & Bjorness, 2010).']
['what else did you learn about stage 2 sleep?', 'In addition, the appearance of K-complexes is often associated with stage 2 sleep.']
['what is a K-complex?', 'A K-complex is a very high amplitude pattern of brain activity that may in some cases occur in response to environmental stimuli.']
['What do they do?', 'Thus, K-complexes might serve as a bridge to higher levels of arousal in response to what is going on in our environments (Halász, 1993; Steriade & Amzica, 1998).']

['What is the content about?', 'NREM stage 3 sleep is often referred to as deep sleep or slow-wave sleep because this stage is characterized by low frequency (less than 3 Hz), high amplitude delta waves.']
['What are delta waves?', 'These delta waves have the lowest frequency and highest amplitude of our sleeping brain wave patterns.']

['What is unique about stage 3?', 'During this time, an individual’s heart rate and respiration slow dramatically, and it is much more difficult to awaken someone from sleep during stage 3 than during earlier stages.']

['What else do you want to know about stage 3?', 'Interestingly, individuals who have increased levels of alpha brain wave activity (more often associated with wakefulness and transition into stage 1 sleep) during stage 3 often report that they do not feel refreshed upon waking, regardless of how long they slept (Stone, Taylor, McCrae, Kalsekar, & Lichstein, 2008).']
['What is REM sleep?', 'As mentioned earlier, REM sleep is marked by rapid movements of the eyes.']

['What is significant about rapid eye movements?', 'The brain waves associated with this stage of sleep are very similar to those observed when a person is awake, as shown in Figure 4.11, and this is the period of sleep in which dreaming occurs.']
['What else is significant about REM sleep?', 'It is also associated with paralysis of muscle systems in the body with the exception of those that make circulation and respiration possible.']

['What else are significant about paradoxical sleep?', 'Therefore, no movement of voluntary muscles occurs during REM sleep in a normal individual; REM sleep is often referred to as paradoxical sleep because of this combination of high brain activity and lack of muscle tone.']
['How does REM affect memory?', 'Like NREM sleep, REM has been implicated in various aspects of learning and memory (Wagner, Gais, & Born, 2001; Siegel, 2001).']

['What is the main point of REM Sleep?', 'If people are deprived of REM sleep and then allowed to sleep without disturbance, they will spend more time in REM sleep in what would appear to be an effort to recoup the lost time in REM.']
['Why will they try to recoup?', 'This is known as the REM rebound, and it suggests that REM sleep is also homeostatically regulated.']

['What else is important about REM Sleep?', 'Aside from the role that REM sleep may play in processes related to learning and memory, REM sleep may also be involved in emotional processing and regulation.']

['How is it involved in emotional processing and regulation?', 'In such instances, REM rebound may actually represent an adaptive response to stress in nondepressed individuals by suppressing the emotional salience of aversive events that occurred in wakefulness (Suchecki, Tiba, & Machado, 2012).']
['What are the negative consequences of Sleep Deprivation?', 'Sleep deprivation in general is associated with a number of negative consequences (Brown, 2012).']
["What's the most important thing that you learned from this page?", 'Dreams and their associated meanings vary across different cultures and periods of time.']

['What other information did you learn about dreams?', 'By the late 19th century, Austrian psychiatrist Sigmund Freud had become convinced that dreams represented an opportunity to gain access to the unconscious.']
['What did Freud gain access to?', 'By analyzing dreams, Freud thought people could increase self-awareness and gain valuable insight to help them deal with the problems they faced in their lives.']
['What else did Freud do with dreams?', 'Freud made distinctions between the manifest content and the latent content of dreams.']
['What is manifest content?', 'Manifest content is the actual content, or storyline, of a dream.']
['What is latent content?', 'Latent content, on the other hand, refers to the hidden meaning of a dream.']

['What are examples of hidden meaning?', 'For instance, if a woman dreams about being chased by a snake, Freud might have argued that this represents the woman’s fear of sexual intimacy, with the snake serving as a symbol of a man’s penis.']
['Who did Freud believe dream content belonged to?', 'Freud was not the only theorist to focus on the content of dreams.']
['What other theory or philosopher did focus on the content of dreams?', 'The 20th century Swiss psychiatrist Carl Jung believed that dreams allowed us to tap into the collective unconscious.']
['What does the collective unconscious mean?', 'The collective unconscious, as described by Jung, is a theoretical repository of information he believed to be shared by everyone.']

['What does Jung believe about dream symbols?', 'According to Jung, certain symbols in dreams reflected universal archetypes with meanings that are similar for all people regardless of culture or location.']

['What does Rosalind Cartwright say about dreams?', 'The sleep and dreaming researcher Rosalind Cartwright, however, believes that dreams simply reflect life events that are important to the dreamer.']
['Why is she thought to be correct?', 'Unlike Freud and Jung, Cartwright’s ideas about dreaming have found empirical support.']

['What are examples of empirical support?', 'For example, she and her colleagues published a study in which women going through divorce were asked several times over a five month period to report the degree to which their former spouses were on their minds.']
['Who were they studying?', 'These same women were awakened during REM sleep in order to provide a detailed account of their dream content.']

['Did they find that the women were overly critical of their former spouse?', 'There was a significant positive correlation between the degree to which women thought about their former spouses during waking hours and the number of times their former spouses appeared as characters in their dreams (Cartwright, Agargun, Kirkby, & Friedman, 2006).']

['What were other studies that showed this correlation?', 'Recent research (Horikawa, Tamaki, Miyawaki, & Kamitani, 2013) has uncovered new techniques by which researchers may effectively detect and classify the visual images that occur during dreaming by using fMRI for neural measurement of brain activity patterns, opening the way for additional research in this area.']
['What is the activation-synthesis theory?', 'Alan Hobson, a neuroscientist, is credited for developing activation-synthesis theory of dreaming.']

['What was the theory about?', 'Early versions of this theory proposed that dreams were not the meaning-filled representations of angst proposed by Freud and others, but were rather the result of our brain attempting to make sense of ("synthesize") the neural activity ("activation") that was happening during REM sleep.']
['What was the most recent version?', 'Recent adaptations (e.g., Hobson, 2002) continue to update the theory based on accumulating evidence.']
['What is the evidence?', 'For example, Hobson (2009) suggests that dreaming may represent a state of protoconsciousness.']
['What else is happening in the state of protoconsciousness?', 'In other words, dreaming involves constructing a virtual reality in our heads that we might use to help us during wakefulness.']
['What is the evidence?', 'Among a variety of neurobiological evidence, John Hobson cites research on lucid dreams as an opportunity to better understand dreaming in general.']
['How is lucid dreaming different?', 'Lucid dreams are dreams in which certain aspects of wakefulness are maintained during a dream state.']
['Why would someone dream that way?', 'In a lucid dream, a person becomes aware of the fact that they are dreaming, and as such, they can control the dream’s content (LaBerge, 1990).']
['What is the purpose of our study material?', 'Many people experience disturbances in their sleep at some point in their lives.']

['Are there any studies of the subject?', 'Depending on the population and sleep disorder being studied, between 30% and 50% of the population suffers from a sleep disorder at some point in their lives (Bixler, Kales, Soldatos, Kaels, & Healey, 1979; Hossain & Shapiro, 2002; Ohayon, 1997, 2002; Ohayon & Roth, 2002).']
['Does the material have any other useful information?', 'This section will describe several sleep disorders as well as some of their treatment options.']
['What is Insomnia?', 'Insomnia, a consistent difficulty in falling or staying asleep, is the most common of the sleep disorders.']
['Why does this make it difficult to sleep?', 'Individuals with insomnia often experience long delays between the times that they go to bed and actually fall asleep.']
['What else can be difficult about sleep?', 'In addition, these individuals may wake up several times during the night only to find that they have difficulty getting back to sleep.']

['Is this something that is always happening?', 'As mentioned earlier, one of the criteria for insomnia involves experiencing these symptoms for at least three nights a week for at least one month’s time (Roth, 2007).']
['What are some of the things we might know about insomnia?', 'It is not uncommon for people suffering from insomnia to experience increased levels of anxiety about their inability to fall asleep.']

['How is this anxiety related to insomnia?', 'This becomes a self-perpetuating cycle because increased anxiety leads to increased arousal, and higher levels of arousal make the prospect of falling asleep even more unlikely.']
['What are some other factors that can lead to insomnia?', 'Chronic insomnia is almost always associated with feeling overtired and may be associated with symptoms of depression.']
['What is it?', 'There may be many factors that contribute to insomnia, including age, drug use, exercise, mental status, and bedtime routines.']
['What are some treatment options?', 'Not surprisingly, insomnia treatment may take one of several different approaches.']
['What else is known about treatment?', 'People who suffer from insomnia might limit their use of stimulant drugs (such as caffeine) or increase their amount of physical exercise during the day.']

['What else is known?', 'Some people might turn to over-the-counter (OTC) or prescribed sleep medications to help them sleep, but this should be done sparingly because many sleep medications result in dependence and alter the nature of the sleep cycle, and they can increase insomnia over time.']
['What else is known?', 'Those who continue to have insomnia, particularly if it affects their quality of life, should seek professional treatment.']
['What is a form of therapy?', 'Some forms of psychotherapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, can help sufferers of insomnia.']

['What is a type of therapy that involves cognitive processes and problem behaviors?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy is a type of psychotherapy that focuses on cognitive processes and problem behaviors.']

['What other ways are insomnia treated?', 'The treatment of insomnia likely would include stress management techniques and changes in problematic behaviors that could contribute to insomnia (e.g., spending more waking time in bed).']

['Can cognitive-behavioral therapy help a person with insomnia?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy has been demonstrated to be quite effective in treating insomnia (Savard, Simard, Ivers, & Morin, 2005; Williams, Roth, Vatthauer, & McCrae, 2013).']
['What are Parasomnias?', 'A parasomnia is one of a group of sleep disorders in which unwanted, disruptive motor activity and/or experiences during sleep play a role.']
['What can happen in their sleep?', 'Parasomnias can occur in either REM or NREM phases of sleep.']
['What are some examples of Parasomnias?', 'Sleepwalking, restless leg syndrome, and night terrors are all examples of parasomnias (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']
["what's this about?", 'In sleepwalking, or somnambulism, the sleeper engages in relatively complex behaviors ranging from wandering about to driving an automobile.']
['what happens during sleepwalking?', 'During periods of sleepwalking, sleepers often have their eyes open, but they are not responsive to attempts to communicate with them.']
['when does it occur?', 'Sleepwalking most often occurs during slow-wave sleep, but it can occur at any time during a sleep period in some affected individuals (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']
['What is somnambulism?', 'Historically, somnambulism has been treated with a variety of pharmacotherapies ranging from benzodiazepines to antidepressants.']
['What are the outcomes?', 'However, the success rate of such treatments is questionable.']
['What are some things to be aware of?', 'Guilleminault et al. (2005) found that sleepwalking was not alleviated with the use of benzodiazepines.']

['What else was found?', 'However, all of their somnambulistic patients who also suffered from sleep-related breathing problems showed a marked decrease in sleepwalking when their breathing problems were effectively treated.']
["What's that?", 'REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) occurs when the muscle paralysis associated with the REM sleep phase does not occur.']
['What happens instead?', 'Individuals who suffer from RBD have high levels of physical activity during REM sleep, especially during disturbing dreams.']

['What kinds of behaviors do they have?', 'These behaviors vary widely, but they can include kicking, punching, scratching, yelling, and behaving like an animal that has been frightened or attacked.']
['What happens when the people do that?', 'People who suffer from this disorder can injure themselves or their sleeping partners when engaging in these behaviors.']
['What happens after that?', 'Furthermore, these types of behaviors ultimately disrupt sleep, although affected individuals have no memories that these behaviors have occurred (Arnulf, 2012).']
['What is REM sleep behavior disorder?', 'This disorder is associated with a number of neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s disease.']

["How is this disorder related to Parkinson's?", 'In fact, this relationship is so robust that some view the presence of RBD as a potential aid in the diagnosis and treatment of a number of neurodegenerative diseases (Ferini-Strambi, 2011).']
['What are the treatments?', 'Clonazepam, an anti-anxiety medication with sedative properties, is most often used to treat RBD.']
['How does this medication work?', 'It is administered alone or in conjunction with doses of melatonin (the hormone secreted by the pineal gland).']

['What else is used to treat this disorder?', 'As part of treatment, the sleeping environment is often modified to make it a safer place for those suffering from RBD (Zangini, Calandra-Buonaura, Grimaldi, & Cortelli, 2011).']
['What is restless leg syndrome?', 'A person with restless leg syndrome has uncomfortable sensations in the legs during periods of inactivity or when trying to fall asleep.']
['How does this impact the individual?', 'This discomfort is relieved by deliberately moving the legs, which, not surprisingly, contributes to difficulty in falling or staying asleep.']

['What else is important to know about this?', 'Restless leg syndrome is quite common and has been associated with a number of other medical diagnoses, such as chronic kidney disease and diabetes (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']
['What are some treatments?', 'There are a variety of drugs that treat restless leg syndrome: benzodiazepines, opiates, and anticonvulsants (Restless Legs Syndrome Foundation, n.d.).']

["What's the most common night terror?", 'Night terrors result in a sense of panic in the sufferer and are often accompanied by screams and attempts to escape from the immediate environment (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']

['What happens after they scream and attempt to escape?', 'Although individuals suffering from night terrors appear to be awake, they generally have no memories of the events that occurred, and attempts to console them are ineffective.']
['What happens after they get to the end?', 'Typically, individuals suffering from night terrors will fall back asleep again within a short time.']
['Why do they have night terrors?', 'Night terrors apparently occur during the NREM phase of sleep (Provini, Tinuper, Bisulli, & Lagaresi, 2011).']

['Is there any treatment for night terrors?', 'Generally, treatment for night terrors is unnecessary unless there is some underlying medical or psychological condition that is contributing to the night terrors (Mayo Clinic, n.d.).']
['What are the symptoms of sleep apnea?', 'Sleep apnea is defined by episodes during which a sleeper’s breathing stops.']
['How long do these episodes last?', 'These episodes can last 10–20 seconds or longer and often are associated with brief periods of arousal.']
['How do you know that it is happening?', 'While individuals suffering from sleep apnea may not be aware of these repeated disruptions in sleep, they do experience increased levels of fatigue.']

['How do you catch this?', 'Many individuals diagnosed with sleep apnea first seek treatment because their sleeping partners indicate that they snore loudly and/or stop breathing for extended periods of time while sleeping (Henry & Rosenthal, 2013).']
['How do you know that you have this?', 'Sleep apnea is much more common in overweight people and is often associated with loud snoring.']
['What are some other important aspects of this article?', 'Surprisingly, sleep apnea may exacerbate cardiovascular disease (Sánchez-de-la-Torre, Campos-Rodriguez, & Barbé, 2012).']

['What are the risks to thin people?', 'While sleep apnea is less common in thin people, anyone, regardless of their weight, who snores loudly or gasps for air while sleeping, should be checked for sleep apnea.']
['what is some information you want to share about it?', 'While people are often unaware of their sleep apnea, they are keenly aware of some of the adverse consequences of insufficient sleep.']
['how do people think it contributes to problems?', 'Consider a patient who believed that as a result of his sleep apnea he “had three car accidents in six weeks.']
['how do you think it was his fault?', 'They were ALL my fault.']
['what was wrong with him?', 'Two of them I didn’t even know I was involved in until afterwards” (Henry & Rosenthal, 2013, p. 52).']

['how long did he have sleep apnea?', 'It is not uncommon for people suffering from undiagnosed or untreated sleep apnea to fear that their careers will be affected by the lack of sleep, illustrated by this statement from another patient, “I’m in a job where there’s a premium on being mentally alert.']
['why did he think that?', 'I was really sleepy… and having trouble concentrating….']
['what was so scary about that?', 'It was getting to the point where it was kind of scary” (Henry & Rosenthal, 2013, p. 52).']
['What are the types of sleep apnea?', 'There are two types of sleep apnea: obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea.']
['What happens in obstructive sleep apnea?', 'Obstructive sleep apnea occurs when an individual’s airway becomes blocked during sleep, and air is prevented from entering the lungs.']
['What happens in central sleep apnea?', 'In central sleep apnea, disruption in signals sent from the brain that regulate breathing cause periods of interrupted breathing (White, 2005).']
['What is a treatment for sleep apnea?', 'One of the most common treatments for sleep apnea involves the use of a special device during sleep.']

['What do they use the device for?', 'A continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device includes a mask that fits over the sleeper’s nose and mouth, which is connected to a pump that pumps air into the person’s airways, forcing them to remain open, as shown in Figure 4.13.']
['Did the mask get smaller?', 'Some newer CPAP masks are smaller and cover only the nose.']
['What was the test done on the smaller mask?', 'This treatment option has proven to be effective for people suffering from mild to severe cases of sleep apnea (McDaid et al., 2009).']
['Was there anything else interesting?', 'However, alternative treatment options are being explored because consistent compliance by users of CPAP devices is a problem.']

['What alternative method is being explored?', 'Recently, a new EPAP (expiratory positive air pressure) device has shown promise in double-blind trials as one such alternative (Berry, Kryger, & Massie, 2011).']
['What is SIDS?', 'In sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) an infant stops breathing during sleep and dies.']
['Who are at a greater risk?', 'Infants younger than 12 months appear to be at the highest risk for SIDS, and boys have a greater risk than girls.']
['What are some risk factors?', 'A number of risk factors have been associated with SIDS including premature birth, smoking within the home, and hyperthermia.']
['What else can you tell me about SIDS?', 'There may also be differences in both brain structure and function in infants that die from SIDS (Berkowitz, 2012; Mage & Donner, 2006; Thach, 2005).']
['what is SIDS?', 'The substantial amount of research on SIDS has led to a number of recommendations to parents to protect their children.']

['what recommendations are there?', 'For one, research suggests that infants should be placed on their backs when put down to sleep, and their cribs should not contain any items which pose suffocation threats, such as blankets, pillows or padded crib bumpers (cushions that cover the bars of a crib).']

['what other recommendations are there?', 'Infants should not have caps placed on their heads when put down to sleep in order to prevent overheating, and people in the child’s household should abstain from smoking in the home.']

['did these recommendations help?', 'Recommendations like these have helped to decrease the number of infant deaths from SIDS in recent years (Mitchell, 2009; Task Force on Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, 2011).']
['How is Narcolepsy different from other sleep disorders?', 'Unlike the other sleep disorders described in this section, a person with narcolepsy cannot resist falling asleep at inopportune times.']

['What causes these episodes?', 'These sleep episodes are often associated with cataplexy, which is a lack of muscle tone or muscle weakness, and in some cases involves complete paralysis of the voluntary muscles.']

['What causes the paralysis?', 'This is similar to the kind of paralysis experienced by healthy individuals during REM sleep (Burgess & Scammell, 2012; Hishikawa & Shimizu, 1995; Luppi et al., 2011).']
['What else can happen to them?', 'Narcoleptic episodes take on other features of REM sleep.']
['What else?', 'For example, around one third of individuals diagnosed with narcolepsy experience vivid, dream-like hallucinations during narcoleptic attacks (Chokroverty, 2010).']
['What else is significant about Narcolepsy?', 'Surprisingly, narcoleptic episodes are often triggered by states of heightened arousal or stress.']
['What else is notable about narcolepsy?', 'The typical episode can last from a minute or two to half an hour.']
['Why do people experience narcolepsy episodes?', 'Once awakened from a narcoleptic attack, people report that they feel refreshed (Chokroverty, 2010).']

['Why do people have narcolepsy?', 'Obviously, regular narcoleptic episodes could interfere with the ability to perform one’s job or complete schoolwork, and in some situations, narcolepsy can result in significant harm and injury (e.g., driving a car or operating machinery or other potentially dangerous equipment).']
['What are the treatments?', 'Generally, narcolepsy is treated using psychomotor stimulant drugs, such as amphetamines (Mignot, 2012).']
['What is stimulation?', 'These drugs promote increased levels of neural activity.']

['Why are the drugs used to do this?', 'Narcolepsy is associated with reduced levels of the signaling molecule hypocretin in some areas of the brain (De la Herrán-Arita & Drucker-Colín, 2012; Han, 2012), and the traditional stimulant drugs do not have direct effects on this system.']
['What will happen next?', 'Therefore, it is quite likely that new medications that are developed to treat narcolepsy will be designed to target the hypocretin system.']

['What does Narcolepsy affect people?', 'There is a tremendous amount of variability among sufferers, both in terms of how symptoms of narcolepsy manifest and the effectiveness of currently available treatment options.']

['What symptoms does narcolepsy cause?', 'This is illustrated by McCarty’s (2010) case study of a 50-year-old woman who sought help for the excessive sleepiness during normal waking hours that she had experienced for several years.']
['What else did she experience?', 'She indicated that she had fallen asleep at inappropriate or dangerous times, including while eating, while socializing with friends, and while driving her car.']
['What else did the woman experience?', 'During periods of emotional arousal, the woman complained that she felt some weakness in the right side of her body.']
['Why did she experience that?', 'Although she did not experience any dream-like hallucinations, she was diagnosed with narcolepsy as a result of sleep testing.']
['What else can you tell me about this case?', 'In her case, the fact that her cataplexy was confined to the right side of her body was quite unusual.']
['Was there any treatment for the woman?', 'Early attempts to treat her condition with a stimulant drug alone were unsuccessful.']
['How did she respond to the stimulant drug?', 'However, when a stimulant drug was used in conjunction with a popular antidepressant, her condition improved dramatically.']

["What are some of the things that we're going to learn?", 'While we all experience altered states of consciousness in the form of sleep on a regular basis, some people use drugs and other substances that result in altered states of consciousness as well.']
['What will we learn about psychedelics?', 'This section will present information relating to the use of various psychoactive drugs and problems associated with such use.']
['What else will be in the section?', 'This will be followed by brief descriptions of the effects of some of the more well-known drugs commonly used today.']

['What is DSM-5?', 'The fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) is used by clinicians to diagnose individuals suffering from various psychological disorders.']
['What are substance use disorders?', 'Drug use disorders are addictive disorders, and the criteria for specific substance (drug) use disorders are described in DSM-5.']

['What is addiction?', 'A person who has a substance use disorder often uses more of the substance than they originally intended to and continues to use that substance despite experiencing significant adverse consequences.']

['What other disorders are associated with addiction?', 'In individuals diagnosed with a substance use disorder, there is a compulsive pattern of drug use that is often associated with both physical and psychological dependence.']
['What type of addiction is physical dependence?', 'Physical dependence involves changes in normal bodily functions—the user will experience withdrawal from the drug upon cessation of use.']

['What is the difference between physical and psychological dependence?', 'In contrast, a person who has psychological dependence has an emotional, rather than physical, need for the drug and may use the drug to relieve psychological distress.']
['What is tolerance?', 'Tolerance is linked to physiological dependence, and it occurs when a person requires more and more drug to achieve effects previously experienced at lower doses.']
['How does tolerance affect an individual?', 'Tolerance can cause the user to increase the amount of drug used to a dangerous level—even to the point of overdose and death.']
['What is the first topic?', 'Drug withdrawal includes a variety of negative symptoms experienced when drug use is discontinued.']
['What is drug withdrawal?', 'These symptoms usually are opposite of the effects of the drug.']
['What is an example?', 'For example, withdrawal from sedative drugs often produces unpleasant arousal and agitation.']
['What else is important about drug withdrawal?', 'In addition to withdrawal, many individuals who are diagnosed with substance use disorders will also develop tolerance to these substances.']
['What is psychological dependence?', 'Psychological dependence, or drug craving, is a recent addition to the diagnostic criteria for substance use disorder in DSM-5.']
['What else is important about the substance use disorders?', 'This is an important factor because we can develop tolerance and experience withdrawal from any number of drugs that we do not abuse.']
['What is physical dependence?', 'In other words, physical dependence in and of itself is of limited utility in determining whether or not someone has a substance use disorder.']
['What can we learn about drug categories?', 'The effects of all psychoactive drugs occur through their interactions with our endogenous neurotransmitter systems.']
['What are the effects of these drugs?', 'Many of these drugs, and their relationships, are shown in Table 4.2.']
['Can you describe the relationships between drugs and their effects?', 'As you have learned, drugs can act as agonists or antagonists of a given neurotransmitter system.']
['How do they act as agonists or antagonists?', 'An agonist facilitates the activity of a neurotransmitter system, and antagonists impede neurotransmitter activity.']
['What is the most important information in this study material?', 'Ethanol, which we commonly refer to as alcohol, is in a class of psychoactive drugs known as depressants.']
['What is a depressant?', 'A depressant is a drug that tends to suppress central nervous system activity.']
['What are some other types of depressants?', 'Other depressants include barbiturates and benzodiazepines.']
['What are the side effects of depressants?', 'These drugs share in common their ability to serve as agonists of the gamma-Aminobutyric acid (GABA) neurotransmitter system.']

['What effect does GABA have on your body?', 'Because GABA has a quieting effect on the brain, GABA agonists also have a quieting effect; these types of drugs are often prescribed to treat both anxiety and insomnia.']
['What is the main idea of this chapter?', 'Acute alcohol administration results in a variety of changes to consciousness.']
['What are some effects of alcohol?', 'At rather low doses, alcohol use is associated with feelings of euphoria.']
['What else is mentioned about alcohol?', 'As the dose increases, people report feeling sedated.']
['What else did they say?', 'Generally, alcohol is associated with decreases in reaction time and visual acuity, lowered levels of alertness, and reduction in behavioral control.']

['How does alcohol affect the brain?', 'With excessive alcohol use, a person might experience a complete loss of consciousness and/or difficulty remembering events that occurred during a period of intoxication (McKim & Hancock, 2013).']

['What are some other effects?', 'In addition, if a pregnant person consumes alcohol, their infant may be born with a cluster of birth defects and symptoms collectively called fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) or fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS).']

['What happens to a person when they drink alcohol?', 'With repeated use of many central nervous system depressants, such as alcohol, a person becomes physically dependent upon the substance and will exhibit signs of both tolerance and withdrawal.']
['What else can cause physical dependence?', 'Psychological dependence on these drugs is also possible.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Therefore, the abuse potential of central nervous system depressants is relatively high.']

['What is drug withdrawal?', 'Drug withdrawal is usually an aversive experience, and it can be a life-threatening process in individuals who have a long history of very high doses of alcohol and/or barbiturates.']
['What do you think of this?', 'This is of such concern that people who are trying to overcome addiction to these substances should only do so under medical supervision.']
['What are stimulants?', 'Stimulants are drugs that tend to increase overall levels of neural activity.']
['What is the neurotransmitter system?', 'Many of these drugs act as agonists of the dopamine neurotransmitter system.']
['What is abuse liability?', 'Dopamine activity is often associated with reward and craving; therefore, drugs that affect dopamine neurotransmission often have abuse liability.']
['What are some examples of stimulants?', 'Drugs in this category include cocaine, amphetamines (including methamphetamine), cathinones (i.e., bath salts), MDMA (ecstasy), nicotine, and caffeine.']
['What is the most popular way of taking cocaine?', 'Cocaine can be taken in multiple ways.']
['What other ways of taking it are there?', 'While many users snort cocaine, intravenous injection and inhalation (smoking) are also common.']
['What is crack?', 'The freebase version of cocaine, known as crack, is a potent, smokable version of the drug.']
['How is cocaine absorbed into the body?', 'Like many other stimulants, cocaine agonizes the dopamine neurotransmitter system by blocking the reuptake of dopamine in the neuronal synapse.']
['What are some facts you found interesting?', 'Amphetamines have a mechanism of action quite similar to cocaine in that they block the reuptake of dopamine in addition to stimulating its release.']
['What is ADHD?', 'While amphetamines are often abused, they are also commonly prescribed to people diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']

['Why are stimulants prescribed?', 'It may seem counterintuitive that stimulant medications are prescribed to treat a disorder that involves hyperactivity, but the therapeutic effect comes from increases in neurotransmitter activity within certain areas of the brain associated with impulse control.']
['What is Impulse control?', 'These brain areas include the prefrontal cortex and basal ganglia.']
['What are some examples of stimulants?', 'In recent years, methamphetamine (meth) use has become increasingly widespread.']

['What is a stimulant?', 'Methamphetamine is a type of amphetamine that can be made from ingredients that are readily available (e.g., medications containing pseudoephedrine, a compound found in many over-the-counter cold and flu remedies).']

['How do people get meth?', 'Despite recent changes in laws designed to make obtaining pseudoephedrine more difficult, methamphetamine continues to be an easily accessible and relatively inexpensive drug option (Shukla, Crump, & Chrisco, 2012).']

['What is the definition of stimulants?', 'Stimulant users seek a euphoric high, feelings of intense elation and pleasure, especially in those users who take the drug via intravenous injection or smoking.']
['What are some examples of stimulants?', 'MDMA (3.4-methelynedioxy-methamphetamine, commonly known as "ecstasy" or "Molly") is a mild stimulant with perception-altering effects.']
['What are some effects of MDMA?', 'It is typically consumed in pill form.']
['What effects do people have after taking it?', 'Users experience increased energy, feelings of pleasure, and emotional warmth.']
['What can be dangerous about stimulants?', 'Repeated use of these stimulants can have significant adverse consequences.']
['What are some other side effects?', 'Users can experience physical symptoms that include nausea, elevated blood pressure, and increased heart rate.']
['What other side effects can stimulants cause?', 'In addition, these drugs can cause feelings of anxiety, hallucinations, and paranoia (Fiorentini et al., 2011).']
['Why do these drugs alter the brain?', 'Normal brain functioning is altered after repeated use of these drugs.']
['What else can happen after repeated use?', 'For example, repeated use can lead to overall depletion among the monoamine neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin).']
['Why is this problematic?', 'Depletion of certain neurotransmitters can lead to mood dysphoria, cognitive problems, and other factors.']

['Why are some people addicted to these drugs?', "This can lead to people compulsively using stimulants such as cocaine and amphetamines, in part to try to reestablish the person's physical and psychological pre-use baseline."]
['How is the problem addressed?', '(Jayanthi & Ramamoorthy, 2005; Rothman, Blough, & Baumann, 2007).']
['What is caffeine?', 'Caffeine is another stimulant drug.']

['What is the potency?', 'While it is probably the most commonly used drug in the world, the potency of this particular drug pales in comparison to the other stimulant drugs described in this section.']
['Why is it used?', 'Generally, people use caffeine to maintain increased levels of alertness and arousal.']
['Where is it found?', 'Caffeine is found in many common medicines (such as weight loss drugs), beverages, foods, and even cosmetics (Herman & Herman, 2013).']

['What is the action of caffeine?', 'While caffeine may have some indirect effects on dopamine neurotransmission, its primary mechanism of action involves antagonizing adenosine activity (Porkka-Heiskanen, 2011).']
['Why does it affect sleep?', 'Adenosine is a neurotransmitter that promotes sleep.']
['Why does it diminish?', 'Caffeine is an adenosine antagonist, so caffeine inhibits the adenosine receptors, thus decreasing sleepiness and promoting wakefulness.']

['What are some of the symptoms that caffeine can cause?', 'While caffeine is generally considered a relatively safe drug, high blood levels of caffeine can result in insomnia, agitation, muscle twitching, nausea, irregular heartbeat, and even death (Reissig, Strain, & Griffiths, 2009; Wolt, Ganetsky, & Babu, 2012).']
['What did Kromann and Nielson study?', 'In 2012, Kromann and Nielson reported on a case study of a 40-year-old woman who suffered significant ill effects from her use of caffeine.']

['How was the woman able to sustain her caffeine consumption?', 'The woman used caffeine in the past to boost her mood and to provide energy, but over the course of several years, she increased her caffeine consumption to the point that she was consuming three liters of soda each day.']

['Why did she want to stop caffeine?', 'Although she had been taking a prescription antidepressant, her symptoms of depression continued to worsen and she began to suffer physically, displaying significant warning signs of cardiovascular disease and diabetes.']

['Did she go into rehab?', 'Upon admission to an outpatient clinic for treatment of mood disorders, she met all of the diagnostic criteria for substance dependence and was advised to dramatically limit her caffeine intake.']
['Did she have any other issues?', 'Once she was able to limit her use to less than 12 ounces of soda a day, both her mental and physical health gradually improved.']

['Did her study have a big impact?', 'Despite the prevalence of caffeine use and the large number of people who confess to suffering from caffeine addiction, this was the first published description of soda dependence appearing in scientific literature.']

['what did you find interesting in the study material?', 'Nicotine is highly addictive, and the use of tobacco products is associated with increased risks of heart disease, stroke, and a variety of cancers.']
['did you learn anything about nicotine?', 'Nicotine exerts its effects through its interaction with acetylcholine receptors.']
['what are the acetylcholine receptors?', 'Acetylcholine functions as a neurotransmitter in motor neurons.']
['what else did you learn about nicotine?', 'In the central nervous system, it plays a role in arousal and reward mechanisms.']

['what did you learn about smoking?', 'Nicotine is most commonly used in the form of tobacco products like cigarettes or chewing tobacco; therefore, there is a tremendous interest in developing effective smoking cessation techniques.']

['what techniques have been used?', 'To date, people have used a variety of nicotine replacement therapies in addition to various psychotherapeutic options in an attempt to discontinue their use of tobacco products.']

['are they effective?', 'In general, smoking cessation programs may be effective in the short term, but it is unclear whether these effects persist (Cropley, Theadom, Pravettoni, & Webb, 2008; Levitt, Shaw, Wong, & Kaczorowski, 2007; Smedslund, Fisher, Boles, & Lichtenstein, 2004).']
['does vaping contain nicotine?', 'Vaping as a means to deliver nicotine is becoming increasingly popular, especially among teens and young adults.']
['what is vaping?', 'Vaping uses battery-powered devices, sometimes called e-cigarettes, that deliver liquid nicotine and flavorings as a vapor.']

['does vaping have any dangers?', 'Originally reported as a safe alternative to the known cancer-causing agents found in cigarettes, vaping is now known to be very dangerous and has led to serious lung disease and death in users (Shmerling, 2019).']
['What is opioid?', 'An opioid is one of a category of drugs that includes heroin, morphine, methadone, and codeine.']
['What effects do opioids have?', 'Opioids have analgesic properties; that is, they decrease pain.']

['How are opioids made?', 'Humans have an endogenous opioid neurotransmitter system—the body makes small quantities of opioid compounds that bind to opioid receptors reducing pain and producing euphoria.']
['How is opioid abused?', 'Thus, opioid drugs, which mimic this endogenous painkilling mechanism, have an extremely high potential for abuse.']
['What is opium?', 'Natural opioids, called opiates, are derivatives of opium, which is a naturally occurring compound found in the poppy plant.']
['Are opioids legal?', 'There are now several synthetic versions of opiate drugs (correctly called opioids) that have very potent painkilling effects, and they are often abused.']

['Does opiates help people?', 'For example, the National Institutes of Drug Abuse has sponsored research that suggests the misuse and abuse of the prescription pain killers hydrocodone and oxycodone are significant public health concerns (Maxwell, 2006).']
['Is there any government control?', 'In 2013, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration recommended tighter controls on their medical use.']
['What are opioids?', 'Historically, heroin has been a major opioid drug of abuse.']
['How does heroin get into the body?', 'Heroin can be snorted, smoked, or injected intravenously.']
['What effect does it have on the body?', 'Heroin produces intense feelings of euphoria and pleasure, which are amplified when the heroin is injected intravenously.']
['What happens after the initial effects?', 'Following the initial "rush," users experience 4–6 hours of "going on the nod," alternating between conscious and semiconscious states.']
['How does it get into the bloodstream?', 'Heroin users often shoot the drug directly into their veins.']

['How are the injection sites and their location important?', 'Some people who have injected many times into their arms will show "track marks,"  while other users will inject into areas between their fingers or between their toes, so as not to show obvious track marks and, like all abusers of intravenous drugs, have an increased risk for contraction of both tuberculosis and HIV.']
['What do opioids do?', 'Aside from their utility as analgesic drugs, opioid-like compounds are often found in cough suppressants, anti-nausea, and anti-diarrhea medications.']

['What does the opioid withdrawal look like?', 'Given that withdrawal from a drug often involves an experience opposite to the effect of the drug, it should be no surprise that opioid withdrawal resembles a severe case of the flu.']
['What happens if you die?', 'While opioid withdrawal can be extremely unpleasant, it is not life-threatening (Julien, 2005).']
['What other effects does this have?', 'Still, people experiencing opioid withdrawal may be given methadone to make withdrawal from the drug less difficult.']
['What is methadone?', 'Methadone is a synthetic opioid that is less euphorigenic than heroin and similar drugs.']
['How is this helpful?', 'Methadone clinics help people who previously struggled with opioid addiction manage withdrawal symptoms through the use of methadone.']
['What else has been used?', 'Other drugs, including the opioid buprenorphine, have also been used to alleviate symptoms of opiate withdrawal.']
['What is codeine?', 'Codeine is an opioid with relatively low potency.']
['What is it used for?', 'It is often prescribed for minor pain, and it is available over-the-counter in some other countries.']
['What are some negative effects?', 'Like all opioids, codeine does have abuse potential.']

['How much abuse do opioids have?', 'In fact, abuse of prescription opioid medications is becoming a major concern worldwide (Aquina, Marques-Baptista, Bridgeman, & Merlin, 2009; Casati, Sedefov, & Pfeiffer-Gerschel, 2012).']
['what is a hallucinogen?', 'A hallucinogen is one of a class of drugs that results in profound alterations in sensory and perceptual experiences.']
['what kinds of experiences do they cause?', 'In some cases, users experience vivid visual hallucinations.']

['what other things can they experience?', 'It is also common for these types of drugs to cause hallucinations of body sensations (e.g., feeling as if you are a giant) and a skewed perception of the passage of time.']
['What are some of the characteristics of hallucinogens?', 'As a group, hallucinogens are incredibly varied in terms of the neurotransmitter systems they affect.']

['What else is significant about the neurotransmitter systems?', 'Mescaline and LSD are serotonin agonists, and PCP (angel dust) and ketamine (an animal anesthetic) act as antagonists of the NMDA glutamate receptor.']
['Are these drugs dangerous?', 'In general, these drugs are not thought to possess the same sort of abuse potential as other classes of drugs discussed in this section.']
['What are the four states of consciousness?', 'Our states of consciousness change as we move from wakefulness to sleep.']
['What other ways do we change our consciousness?', 'We also alter our consciousness through the use of various psychoactive drugs.']

['Are there any other ways we change our consciousness?', 'This final section will consider hypnotic and meditative states as additional examples of altered states of consciousness experienced by some individuals.']
['What is Hypnosis?', 'Hypnosis is a state of extreme self-focus and attention in which minimal attention is given to external stimuli.']
['Can this help me?', 'In the therapeutic setting, a clinician may use relaxation and suggestion in an attempt to alter the thoughts and perceptions of a patient.']
['Does it help you learn?', 'Hypnosis has also been used to draw out information believed to be buried deeply in someone’s memory.']

['How does this affect you?', 'For individuals who are especially open to the power of suggestion, hypnosis can prove to be a very effective technique, and brain imaging studies have demonstrated that hypnotic states are associated with global changes in brain functioning (Del Casale et al., 2012; Guldenmund, Vanhaudenhuyse, Boly, Laureys, & Soddu, 2012).']
['What is Hypnosis?', 'Historically, hypnosis has been viewed with some suspicion because of its portrayal in popular media and entertainment.']
['What do you think of that?', 'Therefore, it is important to make a distinction between hypnosis as an empirically based therapeutic approach versus as a form of entertainment.']
['What does this distinction mean?', 'Contrary to popular belief, individuals undergoing hypnosis usually have clear memories of the hypnotic experience and are in control of their own behaviors.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'While hypnosis may be useful in enhancing memory or a skill, such enhancements are very modest in nature (Raz, 2011).']

['What is one of the four parts that appear consistent in bringing people into the state of suggest', 'While there are variations, there are four parts that appear consistent in bringing people into the state of suggestibility associated with hypnosis (National Research Council, 1994).']
['What are the four parts of hypnosis?', 'These components include:']
['What is the difference between hypnosis and suggestion?', 'The participant is guided to focus on one thing, such as the hypnotist’s words or a ticking watch.']
['Does the person lose consciousness?', 'The participant is made comfortable and is directed to be relaxed and sleepy.']
['How does the hypnotist help the person?', 'The participant is told to be open to the process of hypnosis, trust the hypnotist and let go.']
['How does the participant react?', 'The participant is encouraged to use their imagination.']

['How can someone be hypnotized?', 'People vary in terms of their ability to be hypnotized, but a review of available research suggests that most people are at least moderately hypnotizable (Kihlstrom, 2013).']

['What can you do in a hypnotic state?', 'Hypnosis in conjunction with other techniques is used for a variety of therapeutic purposes and has shown to be at least somewhat effective for pain management, treatment of depression and anxiety, smoking cessation, and weight loss (Alladin, 2012; Elkins, Johnson, & Fisher, 2012; Golden, 2012; Montgomery, Schnur, & Kravits, 2012).']
['What does the theory say?', 'Two theories attempt to answer this question:']
['What are the two theories?', 'One theory views hypnosis as dissociation and the other theory views it as the performance of a social role.']

['What does dissociation mean?', 'According to the dissociation view, hypnosis is effectively a dissociated state of consciousness, much like our earlier example where you may drive to work, but you are only minimally aware of the process of driving because your attention is focused elsewhere.']
['What is one thing this theory has in common with other theories?', 'This theory is supported by Ernest Hilgard’s research into hypnosis and pain.']
['How did he research?', 'In Hilgard’s experiments, he induced participants into a state of hypnosis, and placed their arms into ice water.']

['Why did he do that?', 'Participants were told they would not feel pain, but they could press a button if they did; while they reported not feeling pain, they did, in fact, press the button, suggesting a dissociation of consciousness while in the hypnotic state (Hilgard & Hilgard, 1994).']

['What is the social-cognitive theory of hypnosis?', 'Taking a different approach to explain hypnosis, the social-cognitive theory of hypnosis sees people in hypnotic states as performing the social role of a hypnotized person.']
['What does it take to become hypnotized?', 'As you will learn when you study social roles, people’s behavior can be shaped by their expectations of how they should act in a given situation.']

['What happens to the mind when hypnotized?', 'Some view a hypnotized person’s behavior not as an altered or dissociated state of consciousness, but as their fulfillment of the social expectations for that role (Coe, 2009; Coe & Sarbin, 1966).']
['What is meditation?', 'Meditation is the act of focusing on a single target (such as the breath or a repeated sound) to increase awareness of the moment.']
['How is meditation achieved?', 'While hypnosis is generally achieved through the interaction of a therapist and the person being treated, an individual can perform meditation alone.']
['What happens after that?', 'Often, however, people wishing to learn to meditate receive some training in techniques to achieve a meditative state.']

['What is meditation?', 'Although there are a number of different techniques in use, the central feature of all meditation is clearing the mind in order to achieve a state of relaxed awareness and focus (Chen et al., 2013; Lang et al., 2012).']
['What does meditation have to do with mindfulness?', 'Mindfulness meditation has recently become popular.']

['What is mindfulness?', 'In the variation of mindful meditation, the meditator’s attention is focused on some internal process or an external object (Zeidan, Grant, Brown, McHaffie, & Coghill, 2012).']
['What are some of the benefits of meditation?', 'Meditative techniques have their roots in religious practices, but their use has grown in popularity among practitioners of alternative medicine.']

['How do people who meditate have less stress?', 'Research indicates that meditation may help reduce blood pressure, and the American Heart Association suggests that meditation might be used in conjunction with more traditional treatments as a way to manage hypertension, although there is not sufficient data for a recommendation to be made (Brook et al., 2013).']
