['What other benefits does meditation have?', 'Like hypnosis, meditation also shows promise in stress management, sleep quality (Caldwell, Harrison, Adams, Quin, & Greeson, 2010), treatment of mood and anxiety disorders (Chen et al., 2013; Freeman et al., 2010; Vøllestad, Nielsen, & Nielsen, 2012), and pain management (Reiner, Tibi, & Lipsitz, 2013).']
['What is it about?', 'Sensory receptors are specialized neurons that respond to specific types of stimuli.']
['How is that different from sensation?', 'When sensory information is detected by a sensory receptor, sensation has occurred.']
['What can a receptor detect?', 'For example, light that enters the eye causes chemical changes in cells that line the back of the eye.']
['What happens after the chemical changes?', 'These cells relay messages, in the form of action potentials (as you learned when studying biopsychology), to the central nervous system.']
['What is transduction?', 'The conversion from sensory stimulus energy to action potential is known as transduction.']

['What are some examples of sensations?', 'You have probably known since elementary school that we have five senses: vision, hearing (audition), smell (olfaction), taste (gustation), and touch (somatosensation).']
['What is different about these five senses?', 'It turns out that this notion of five senses is oversimplified.']

['We have a lot more.', 'We also have sensory systems that provide information about balance (the vestibular sense), body position and movement (proprioception and kinesthesia), pain (nociception), and temperature (thermoception).']
['What is an absolute threshold?', 'The sensitivity of a given sensory system to the relevant stimuli can be expressed as an absolute threshold.']
['What is the definition of an absolute threshold?', 'Absolute threshold refers to the minimum amount of stimulus energy that must be present for the stimulus to be detected 50% of the time.']
['What happens if this is not detected 50% of the time?', 'Another way to think about this is by asking how dim can a light be or how soft can a sound be and still be detected half of the time.']
['What is the ultimate threshold?', 'The sensitivity of our sensory receptors can be quite amazing.']
['How amazing?', 'It has been estimated that on a clear night, the most sensitive sensory cells in the back of the eye can detect a candle flame 30 miles away (Okawa & Sampath, 2007).']
['What is a more basic threshold?', 'Under quiet conditions, the hair cells (the receptor cells of the inner ear) can detect the tick of a clock 20 feet away (Galanter, 1962).']
['What does subliminal messages mean?', 'It is also possible for us to get messages that are presented below the threshold for conscious awareness—these are called subliminal messages.']
['What is the threshold?', 'A stimulus reaches a physiological threshold when it is strong enough to excite sensory receptors and send nerve impulses to the brain:']
['What is the absolute threshold?', 'This is an absolute threshold.']
['What is the subliminal messages?', 'A message below that threshold is said to be subliminal:']
['What is the benefit of subliminal messages?', 'We receive it, but we are not consciously aware of it.']

['What are the uses of subliminal messages?', 'Over the years there has been a great deal of speculation about the use of subliminal messages in advertising, rock music, and self-help audio programs.']
['What is the evidence?', 'Research evidence shows that in laboratory settings, people can process and respond to information outside of awareness.']

['Why does this happen?', 'But this does not mean that we obey these messages like zombies; in fact, hidden messages have little effect on behavior outside the laboratory (Kunst-Wilson & Zajonc, 1980; Rensink, 2004; Nelson, 2008; Radel, Sarrazin, Legrain, & Gobancé, 2009; Loersch, Durso, & Petty, 2013).']
['What is the basis of sensation?', 'Absolute thresholds are generally measured under incredibly controlled conditions in situations that are optimal for sensitivity.']
['Why is this important?', 'Sometimes, we are more interested in how much difference in stimuli is required to detect a difference between them.']
['What is this known as?', 'This is known as the just noticeable difference (jnd) or difference threshold.']
['What happens to the difference threshold?', 'Unlike the absolute threshold, the difference threshold changes depending on the stimulus intensity.']
['What happens as the intensity increases?', 'As an example, imagine yourself in a very dark movie theater.']

['What would you be doing in that theater?', 'If an audience member were to receive a text message that caused the cell phone screen to light up, chances are that many people would notice the change in illumination in the theater.']
['What happens when the intensity of a stimulus increases?', 'However, if the same thing happened in a brightly lit arena during a basketball game, very few people would notice.']
['What happens when the intensity decreases?', 'The cell phone brightness does not change, but its ability to be detected as a change in illumination varies dramatically between the two contexts.']
["What is Weber's Law?", 'Ernst Weber proposed this theory of change in difference threshold in the 1830s, and it has become known as Weber’s law:']
['What does the difference threshold consist of?', 'The difference threshold is a constant fraction of the original stimulus, as the example illustrates.']

['What is the content of perception about?', 'While our sensory receptors are constantly collecting information from the environment, it is ultimately how we interpret that information that affects how we interact with the world.']
['what does perception mean?', 'Perception refers to the way sensory information is organized, interpreted, and consciously experienced.']
['How does it process?', 'Perception involves both bottom-up and top-down processing.']

['How does bottom up and top down processing work?', 'Bottom-up processing refers to sensory information from a stimulus in the environment driving a process, and top-down processing refers to knowledge and expectancy driving a process, as shown in Figure 5.2 (Egeth & Yantis, 1997; Fine & Minnery, 2009; Yantis & Egeth, 1999).']
['I have an interesting question for you. What would be the best way to explain perception?', 'Imagine that you and some friends are sitting in a crowded restaurant eating lunch and talking.']

['What happens in that restaurant?', 'It is very noisy, and you are concentrating on your friend’s face to hear what they are saying, then the sound of breaking glass and clang of metal pans hitting the floor rings out.']
['What was the source of that sound?', 'The server dropped a large tray of food.']
['How would you react to the sound?', 'Although you were attending to your meal and conversation, that crashing sound would likely get through your attentional filters and capture your attention.']
['How would you react?', 'You would have no choice but to notice it.']
['How did you respond to the sound?', 'That attentional capture would be caused by the sound from the environment: it would be bottom-up.']

['What is a top down process?', "Alternatively, top-down processes are generally goal directed, slow, deliberate, effortful, and under your control (Fine & Minnery, 2009; Miller & Cohen, 2001; Miller & D'Esposito, 2005)."]

['What happens in top-down processes?', 'If you had a yellow key fob, you would probably look for yellowness of a certain size in specific locations, such as on the counter, coffee table, and other similar places.']
['What else happens in top down processes?', 'You would not look for yellowness on your ceiling fan, because you know keys are not normally lying on top of a ceiling fan.']

['What can you tell me about top down processes?', 'That act of searching for a certain size of yellowness in some locations and not others would be top-down—under your control and based on your experience.']
['What is one important aspect of the section?', 'One way to think of this concept is that sensation is a physical process, whereas perception is psychological.']

['What is an example?', 'For example, upon walking into a kitchen and smelling the scent of baking cinnamon rolls, the sensation is the scent receptors detecting the odor of cinnamon, but the perception may be “Mmm, this smells like the bread Grandma used to bake when the family gathered for holidays.”']
['What are perceptions?', 'Although our perceptions are built from sensations, not all sensations result in perception.']
["What happens when sensations don't result in perceptions?", 'In fact, we often don’t perceive stimuli that remain relatively constant over prolonged periods of time.']
['How can we adapt to constant stimuli?', 'This is known as sensory adaptation.']
['What else was interesting in the information?', 'Imagine going to a city that you have never visited.']
['Why is there such an issue?', 'You check in to the hotel, but when you get to your room, there is a road construction sign with a bright flashing light outside your window.']
['What did you do when the room was occupied?', 'Unfortunately, there are no other rooms available, so you are stuck with a flashing light.']
['What did you do?', 'You decide to watch television to unwind.']
['What else can you tell me about the light?', 'The flashing light was extremely annoying when you first entered your room.']

['What else did you feel?', 'It was as if someone was continually turning a bright yellow spotlight on and off in your room, but after watching television for a short while, you no longer notice the light flashing.']

['Why do you no longer notice it?', 'The light is still flashing and filling your room with yellow light every few seconds, and the photoreceptors in your eyes still sense the light, but you no longer perceive the rapid changes in lighting conditions.']
['What is the main message?', 'That you no longer perceive the flashing light demonstrates sensory adaptation and shows that while closely associated, sensation and perception are different.']
['What does this help me with?', 'There is another factor that affects sensation and perception: attention.']
['What does attention help me with?', 'Attention plays a significant role in determining what is sensed versus what is perceived.']
['How does this help me?', 'Imagine you are at a party full of music, chatter, and laughter.']
['What happens?', 'You get involved in an interesting conversation with a friend, and you tune out all the background noise.']
['What happens?', 'If someone interrupted you to ask what song had just finished playing, you would probably be unable to answer that question.']

['What is one significant finding regarding perception?', 'One of the most interesting demonstrations of how important attention is in determining our perception of the environment occurred in a famous study conducted by Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris (1999).']
['What was this study about?', 'In this study, participants watched a video of people dressed in black and white passing basketballs.']
['Why were the participants asked to count?', 'Participants were asked to count the number of times the team dressed in white passed the ball.']
['What was the video showing?', 'During the video, a person dressed in a black gorilla costume walks among the two teams.']
["Why didn't the participants notice him?", 'Nearly half of the people who watched the video didn’t notice the gorilla at all, despite the fact that he was clearly visible for nine seconds.']

["Why didn't they notice the gorilla?", 'Because participants were so focused on the number of times the team dressed in white was passing the ball, they completely tuned out other visual information.']

['What is inattentional blindness?', 'Inattentional blindness is the failure to notice something that is completely visible because the person was actively attending to something else and did not pay attention to other things (Mack & Rock, 1998; Simons & Chabris, 1999).']
['What is the first chapter in Perception about?', 'In a similar experiment, researchers tested inattentional blindness by asking participants to observe images moving across a computer screen.']
['What were the participants asked to do?', 'They were instructed to focus on either white or black objects, disregarding the other color.']
['How was the test done?', 'When a red cross passed across the screen, about one third of subjects did not notice it (Most, Simons, Scholl, & Chabris, 2000).']
['What is perception?', 'Motivation can also affect perception.']

['Can you tell me about motivation?', 'If so, then you have experienced how motivation to detect a meaningful stimulus can shift our ability to discriminate between a true sensory stimulus and background noise.']
['What is signal detection?', 'The ability to identify a stimulus when it is embedded in a distracting background is called signal detection theory.']
['What does signal detection have to do with sleep?', 'This might also explain why a mother is awakened by a quiet murmur from her baby but not by other sounds that occur while she is asleep.']
['What is the signal detection theory?', 'Signal detection theory has practical applications, such as increasing air traffic controller accuracy.']
['What is a signal?', 'Controllers need to be able to detect planes among many signals (blips) that appear on the radar screen and follow those planes as they move through the sky.']

['How did he develop this theory?', 'In fact, the original work of the researcher who developed signal detection theory was focused on improving the sensitivity of air traffic controllers to plane blips (Swets, 1964).']
['What does the article say?', 'Our perceptions can also be affected by our beliefs, values, prejudices, expectations, and life experiences.']

['What does the article say about vision?', 'As you will see later in this chapter, individuals who are deprived of the experience of binocular vision during critical periods of development have trouble perceiving depth (Fawcett, Wang, & Birch, 2005).']
['What else is mentioned in the article about perception?', 'The shared experiences of people within a given cultural context can have pronounced effects on perception.']

['How is this stated?', 'For example, Marshall Segall, Donald Campbell, and Melville Herskovits (1963) published the results of a multinational study in which they demonstrated that individuals from Western cultures were more prone to experience certain types of visual illusions than individuals from non-Western cultures, and vice versa.']
['What types of visual illusions were more prone to experience?', 'One such illusion that Westerners were more likely to experience was the Müller-Lyer illusion:']
['What happens when you look at a figure in the Müller-Lyer illusion?', 'The lines appear to be different lengths, but they are actually the same length.']

['What types of environmental features were experienced on a regular basis by people in a given cultural', 'These perceptual differences were consistent with differences in the types of environmental features experienced on a regular basis by people in a given cultural context.']

['What types of environmental features were experienced on a regular basis by people in an Asian culture?', 'People in Western cultures, for example, have a perceptual context of buildings with straight lines, what Segall’s study called a carpentered world (Segall et al., 1966).']

['What types of environmental features were experienced on a regular basis by people in an East Asian culture', 'In contrast, people from certain non-Western cultures with an uncarpentered view, such as the Zulu of South Africa, whose villages are made up of round huts arranged in circles, are less susceptible to this illusion (Segall et al., 1999).']
['What is a culture?', 'It is not just vision that is affected by cultural factors.']

['What is other factors that affect perception?', 'Indeed, research has demonstrated that the ability to identify an odor, and rate its pleasantness and its intensity, varies cross-culturally (Ayabe-Kanamura, Saito, Distel, Martínez-Gómez, & Hudson, 1998).']

['What does this article mention?', 'Children described as thrill seekers are more likely to show taste preferences for intense sour flavors (Liem, Westerbeek, Wolterink, Kok, & de Graaf, 2004), which suggests that basic aspects of personality might affect perception.']

['What else does this article mention?', 'Furthermore, individuals who hold positive attitudes toward reduced-fat foods are more likely to rate foods labeled as reduced fat as tasting better than people who have less positive attitudes about these products (Aaron, Mela, & Evans, 1994).']
['What are two things that happen in the form of waves?', 'Visual and auditory stimuli both occur in the form of waves.']

['Why are they important?', 'Although the two stimuli are very different in terms of composition, wave forms share similar characteristics that are especially important to our visual and auditory perceptions.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'In this section, we describe the physical properties of the waves as well as the perceptual experiences associated with them.']
['What are the two physical characteristics of a wave?', 'Two physical characteristics of a wave are amplitude and wavelength.']
['What does amplitude refer to?', 'The amplitude of a wave is the distance from the center line to the top point of the crest or the bottom point of the trough.']
['What does wavelength refer to?', 'Wavelength refers to the length of a wave from one peak to the next.']
['How is wavelength related to frequency?', 'Wavelength is directly related to the frequency of a given wave form.']
['What does frequency mean?', 'Frequency refers to the number of waves that pass a given point in a given time period and is often expressed in terms of hertz (Hz), or cycles per second.']
['What kind of frequency is being measured?', 'Longer wavelengths will have lower frequencies, and shorter wavelengths will have higher frequencies.']
['what is the visible spectrum?', 'The visible spectrum is the portion of the larger electromagnetic spectrum that we can see.']

['what else does the electromagnetic spectrum include?', 'As Figure 5.7 shows, the electromagnetic spectrum encompasses all of the electromagnetic radiation that occurs in our environment and includes gamma rays, x-rays, ultraviolet light, visible light, infrared light, microwaves, and radio waves.']

['what does the wavelength refer to?', 'The visible spectrum in humans is associated with wavelengths that range from 380 to 740 nm—a very small distance, since a nanometer (nm) is one billionth of a meter.']
['what else can be learned about the electromagnetic spectrum?', 'Other species can detect other portions of the electromagnetic spectrum.']

['what are some examples of species that can detect different portions?', 'For instance, honeybees can see light in the ultraviolet range (Wakakuwa, Stavenga, & Arikawa, 2007), and some snakes can detect infrared radiation in addition to more traditional visual light cues (Chen, Deng, Brauth, Ding, & Tang, 2012; Hartline, Kass, & Loop, 1978).']
['What else can you tell me about light wavelengths?', 'In humans, light wavelength is associated with perception of color.']

['Can you tell me the specific wavelengths of red, green, and violet?', 'Within the visible spectrum, our experience of red is associated with longer wavelengths, greens are intermediate, and blues and violets are shorter in wavelength.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?', '(An easy way to remember this is the mnemonic ROYGBIV: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet.)']
['What is the amplitude of light waves?', 'The amplitude of light waves is associated with our experience of brightness or intensity of color, with larger amplitudes appearing brighter.']
['What are the physical properties of sound waves?', 'Like light waves, the physical properties of sound waves are associated with various aspects of our perception of sound.']
['What is pitch?', 'The frequency of a sound wave is associated with our perception of that sound’s pitch.']
['What is frequency associated with?', 'High-frequency sound waves are perceived as high-pitched sounds, while low-frequency sound waves are perceived as low-pitched sounds.']

['Where do they fall in the audible range?', 'The audible range of sound frequencies is between 20 and 20000 Hz, with greatest sensitivity to those frequencies that fall in the middle of this range.']
['What do sound waves have to do with the environment?', 'As was the case with the visible spectrum, other species show differences in their audible ranges.']
['What are some examples of the audible ranges?', 'For instance, chickens have a very limited audible range, from 125 to 2000 Hz.']
['How about some other examples?', 'Mice have an audible range from 1000 to 91000 Hz, and the beluga whale’s audible range is from 1000 to 123000 Hz.']
['Are there any more?', 'Our pet dogs and cats have audible ranges of about 70–45000 Hz and 45–64000 Hz, respectively (Strain, 2003).']
['What is the relationship between the loudness of a given sound and the amplitude of', 'The loudness of a given sound is closely associated with the amplitude of the sound wave.']
['What is the relationship between amplitude and loudness?', 'Higher amplitudes are associated with louder sounds.']
['What is the relationship between loudness and frequency?', 'Loudness is measured in terms of decibels (dB), a logarithmic unit of sound intensity.']
['How do dB compare to other measures of sound intensity?', 'A typical conversation would correlate with 60 dB; a rock concert might check in at 120 dB.']

['How are loud and hustling leaves related to hearing range?', 'A whisper 5 feet away or rustling leaves are at the low end of our hearing range; sounds like a window air conditioner, a normal conversation, and even heavy traffic or a vacuum cleaner are within a tolerable range.']
['How are loud and hustling leaves related to dangers?', 'However, there is the potential for hearing damage from about 80 dB to 130 dB:']
['What are sounds in the danger zone?', 'These are sounds of a food processor, power lawnmower, heavy truck (25 feet away), subway train (20 feet away), live rock music, and a jackhammer.']

['What is the danger to hearing?', 'About one-third of all hearing loss is due to noise exposure, and the louder the sound, the shorter the exposure needed to cause hearing damage (Le, Straatman, Lea, & Westerberg, 2017).']

['What other hazards are associated with loud sounds?', 'Listening to music through earbuds at maximum volume (around 100–105 decibels) can cause noise-induced hearing loss after 15 minutes of exposure.']
['What are other dangers?', 'Although listening to music at maximum volume may not seem to cause damage, it increases the risk of age-related hearing loss (Kujawa & Liberman, 2006).']
['How are loud and hustling leaves related to pain?', 'The threshold for pain is about 130 dB, a jet plane taking off or a revolver firing at close range (Dunkle, 1982).']

['What is the relationship between frequency and amplitude?', 'Although wave amplitude is generally associated with loudness, there is some interaction between frequency and amplitude in our perception of loudness within the audible range.']
['Are there any examples?', 'For example, a 10 Hz sound wave is inaudible no matter the amplitude of the wave.']
['How would it sound at other amplitudes?', 'A 1000 Hz sound wave, on the other hand, would vary dramatically in terms of perceived loudness as the amplitude of the wave increased.']
["What's the main idea of this section?", 'Of course, different musical instruments can play the same musical note at the same level of loudness, yet they still sound quite different.']
['What is this known as?', 'This is known as the timbre of a sound.']
['What is timbre?', 'Timbre refers to a sound’s purity, and it is affected by the complex interplay of frequency, amplitude, and timing of sound waves.']
['What is the visual system?', 'The visual system constructs a mental representation of the world around us.']

['What do the visual system and cognition accomplish?', 'This contributes to our ability to successfully navigate through physical space and interact with important individuals and objects in our environments.']
['How does this relate to the physical organs of the eye?', 'This section will provide an overview of the basic anatomy and function of the visual system.']
['What is another interesting topic mentioned?', 'In addition, we will explore our ability to perceive color and depth.']
['What organs play a role in vision?', 'The eye is the major sensory organ involved in vision.']
['Where does light enter the eye?', 'Light waves are transmitted across the cornea and enter the eye through the pupil.']
['What is the cornea?', 'The cornea is the transparent covering over the eye.']
['What role does it play in vision?', 'It serves as a barrier between the inner eye and the outside world, and it is involved in focusing light waves that enter the eye.']
['What is the pupil?', 'The pupil is the small opening in the eye through which light passes, and the size of the pupil can change as a function of light levels as well as emotional arousal.']
['When light levels are low, how does the pupil change?', 'When light levels are low, the pupil will become dilated, or expanded, to allow more light to enter the eye.']
['How does the pupil change when light levels are high?', 'When light levels are high, the pupil will constrict, or become smaller, to reduce the amount of light that enters the eye.']
['What is the iris?', 'The pupil’s size is controlled by muscles that are connected to the iris, which is the colored portion of the eye.']
['What is the lens?', 'After passing through the pupil, light crosses the lens, a curved, transparent structure that serves to provide additional focus.']
['What else does the lens do?', 'The lens is attached to muscles that can change its shape to aid in focusing light that is reflected from near or far objects.']

['What is the fovea?', 'In a normal-sighted individual, the lens will focus images perfectly on a small indentation in the back of the eye known as the fovea, which is part of the retina, the light-sensitive lining of the eye.']
['What is the fovea?', 'The fovea contains densely packed specialized photoreceptor cells.']
['What are photoreceptor cells?', 'These photoreceptor cells, known as cones, are light-detecting cells.']
['What are the cones?', 'The cones are specialized types of photoreceptors that work best in bright light conditions.']
['What else can the cones detect?', 'Cones are very sensitive to acute detail and provide tremendous spatial resolution.']
['What else do the cones have to do?', 'They also are directly involved in our ability to perceive color.']

['What is the anatomy of the visual system about?', 'While cones are concentrated in the fovea, where images tend to be focused, rods, another type of photoreceptor, are located throughout the remainder of the retina.']

['What else is interesting about rods?', 'Rods are specialized photoreceptors that work well in low light conditions, and while they lack the spatial resolution and color function of the cones, they are involved in our vision in dimly lit environments as well as in our perception of movement on the periphery of our visual field.']

['What was the significance of rods and cones?', 'We have all experienced the different sensitivities of rods and cones when making the transition from a brightly lit environment to a dimly lit environment.']
['What was the relationship between these two objects?', 'Imagine going to see a blockbuster movie on a clear summer day.']
['Is there a movie in this theatre?', 'As you walk from the brightly lit lobby into the dark theater, you notice that you immediately have difficulty seeing much of anything.']
['How did this affect you?', 'After a few minutes, you begin to adjust to the darkness and can see the interior of the theater.']
['What was the major part of rods?', 'In the bright environment, your vision was dominated primarily by cone activity.']
['What happened in the dark?', 'As you move to the dark environment, rod activity dominates, but there is a delay in transitioning between the phases.']

['Is this a problem?', 'If your rods do not transform light into nerve impulses as easily and efficiently as they should, you will have difficulty seeing in dim light, a condition known as night blindness.']
['What do rods and cones do?', 'Rods and cones are connected (via several interneurons) to retinal ganglion cells.']
['How do these cells communicate?', 'Axons from the retinal ganglion cells converge and exit through the back of the eye to form the optic nerve.']
['What is the optic nerve used for?', 'The optic nerve carries visual information from the retina to the brain.']
['What is the blind spot?', 'There is a point in the visual field called the blind spot:']
['What is the blind spot used for?', 'Even when light from a small object is focused on the blind spot, we do not see it.']
['Why does this happen?', 'We are not consciously aware of our blind spots for two reasons:']
['Why does this happen?', 'First, each eye gets a slightly different view of the visual field; therefore, the blind spots do not overlap.']

['How is this affected?', 'Second, our visual system fills in the blind spot so that although we cannot respond to visual information that occurs in that portion of the visual field, we are also not aware that information is missing.']
['What other information is provided?', 'The optic nerve from each eye merges just below the brain at a point called the optic chiasm.']
['What is the optic chiasm?', 'As Figure 5.13 shows, the optic chiasm is an X-shaped structure that sits just below the cerebral cortex at the front of the brain.']

['Where does it connect?', 'At the point of the optic chiasm, information from the right visual field (which comes from both eyes) is sent to the left side of the brain, and information from the left visual field is sent to the right side of the brain.']
['What is the visual system?', 'Once inside the brain, visual information is sent via a number of structures to the occipital lobe at the back of the brain for processing.']
['How does the information get processed?', 'Visual information might be processed in parallel pathways which can generally be described as the “what pathway” and the “where/how” pathway.']

['What is the what pathway?', 'The “what pathway” is involved in object recognition and identification, while the “where/how pathway” is involved with location in space and how one might interact with a particular visual stimulus (Milner & Goodale, 2008; Ungerleider & Haxby, 1994).']

['What else are the pathways used for?', 'For example, when you see a ball rolling down the street, the “what pathway” identifies what the object is, and the “where/how pathway” identifies its location or movement in space.']
['What did we learn about color and depth perception?', 'We do not see the world in black and white; neither do we see it as two-dimensional (2-D) or flat (just height and width, no depth).']
['What are the most important things we learned in this section?', 'Let’s look at how color vision works and how we perceive three dimensions (height, width, and depth).']
['What is a typical example of a color vision trait?', 'Normal-sighted individuals have three different types of cones that mediate color vision.']
['How are these cone types related?', 'Each of these cone types is maximally sensitive to a slightly different wavelength of light.']

['What is the trichromatic theory of color vision?', 'According to the trichromatic theory of color vision, shown in Figure 5.14, all colors in the spectrum can be produced by combining red, green, and blue.']
['What is the relationship between red, green, and blue?', 'The three types of cones are each receptive to one of the colors.']
['What is the opponent-process theory?', 'The trichromatic theory of color vision is not the only theory—another major theory of color vision is known as the opponent-process theory.']
['How is color coded?', 'According to this theory, color is coded in opponent pairs: black-white, yellow-blue, and green-red.']
['How does the opponent-process theory work?', 'The basic idea is that some cells of the visual system are excited by one of the opponent colors and inhibited by the other.']
['What is an example of this?', 'So, a cell that was excited by wavelengths associated with green would be inhibited by wavelengths associated with red, and vice versa.']
['What else is known about opponent-process theory?', 'One of the implications of opponent processing is that we do not experience greenish-reds or yellowish-blues as colors.']
['What other implications?', 'Another implication is that this leads to the experience of negative afterimages.']
['What is an afterimage?', 'An afterimage describes the continuation of a visual sensation after removal of the stimulus.']
['What is an example of this?', 'For example, when you stare briefly at the sun and then look away from it, you may still perceive a spot of light although the stimulus (the sun) has been removed.']
['What do these negative after images mean?', 'When color is involved in the stimulus, the color pairings identified in the opponent-process theory lead to a negative afterimage.']
['How can I test this?', 'You can test this concept using the flag in Figure 5.16.']
['What are the opponent-process and trichromatic theories?', 'But these two theories—the trichromatic theory of color vision and the opponent-process theory—are not mutually exclusive.']
['How do they differ?', 'Research has shown that they just apply to different levels of the nervous system.']
['What are some of the differences?', 'For visual processing on the retina, trichromatic theory applies: the cones are responsive to three different wavelengths that represent red, blue, and green.']
['What else?', 'But once the signal moves past the retina on its way to the brain, the cells respond in a way consistent with opponent-process theory (Land, 1959; Kaiser, 1997).']
['What is depth perception?', 'Our ability to perceive spatial relationships in three-dimensional (3-D) space is known as depth perception.']
['What is it used for?', 'With depth perception, we can describe things as being in front, behind, above, below, or to the side of other things.']
['Why is it three dimensional?', 'Our world is three-dimensional, so it makes sense that our mental representation of the world has three-dimensional properties.']
['what is depth perception?', 'We use a variety of cues in a visual scene to establish our sense of depth.']
['What are these?', 'Some of these are binocular cues, which means that they rely on the use of both eyes.']
['What are some examples?', 'One example of a binocular depth cue is binocular disparity, the slightly different view of the world that each of our eyes receives.']
['What is binocular disparity?', 'To experience this slightly different view, do this simple exercise: extend your arm fully and extend one of your fingers and focus on that finger.']
['What happens?', 'Now, close your left eye without moving your head, then open your left eye and close your right eye without moving your head.']
['What happens?', 'You will notice that your finger seems to shift as you alternate between the two eyes because of the slightly different view each eye has of your finger.']

['How is depth perception different from 3-D movies?', 'A 3-D movie works on the same principle: the special glasses you wear allow the two slightly different images projected onto the screen to be seen separately by your left and your right eye.']
['Does this make the images appear to move?', 'As your brain processes these images, you have the illusion that the leaping animal or running person is coming right toward you.']
['What is depth perception?', 'Although we rely on binocular cues to experience depth in our 3-D world, we can also perceive depth in 2-D arrays.']
['How do we perceive depth in 2-D arrays?', 'Think about all the paintings and photographs you have seen.']
['What do paintings and photographs look like?', 'Generally, you pick up on depth in these images even though the visual stimulus is 2-D.']
['How do we pick up on depth?', 'When we do this, we are relying on a number of monocular cues, or cues that require only one eye.']

['Can you see depth with one eye?', 'If you think you can’t see depth with one eye, note that you don’t bump into things when using only one eye while walking—and, in fact, we have more monocular cues than binocular cues.']
['What are monocular cues?', 'An example of a monocular cue would be what is known as linear perspective.']
['What does linear perspective refer to?', 'Linear perspective refers to the fact that we perceive depth when we see two parallel lines that seem to converge in an image.']
['What else are the monocular depth cues?', 'Some other monocular depth cues are interposition, the partial overlap of objects, and the relative size and closeness of images to the horizon.']
['What is auditory perception?', 'Our auditory system converts pressure waves into meaningful sounds.']
['What does this mean?', 'This translates into our ability to hear the sounds of nature, to appreciate the beauty of music, and to communicate with one another through spoken language.']
['What is this section about?', 'This section will provide an overview of the basic anatomy and function of the auditory system.']

['What will it include?', 'It will include a discussion of how the sensory stimulus is translated into neural impulses, where in the brain that information is processed, how we perceive pitch, and how we know where sound is coming from.']
['What can you tell me about the auditory system?', 'The ear can be separated into multiple sections.']
['What parts are there?', 'The outer ear includes the pinna, which is the visible part of the ear that protrudes from our heads, the auditory canal, and the tympanic membrane, or eardrum.']
['What is the middle ear?', 'The middle ear contains three tiny bones known as the ossicles, which are named the malleus (or hammer), incus (or anvil), and the stapes (or stirrup).']
['What is the inner ear?', 'The inner ear contains the semi-circular canals, which are involved in balance and movement (the vestibular sense), and the cochlea.']
['What does the cochlea do?', 'The cochlea is a fluid-filled, snail-shaped structure that contains the sensory receptor cells (hair cells) of the auditory system.']
['What is it about that we are learning?', 'Sound waves travel along the auditory canal and strike the tympanic membrane, causing it to vibrate.']
['What happens with this vibration?', 'This vibration results in movement of the three ossicles.']
['What happens to the ossicles?', 'As the ossicles move, the stapes presses into a thin membrane of the cochlea known as the oval window.']

['What happens to the oval window?', 'As the stapes presses into the oval window, the fluid inside the cochlea begins to move, which in turn stimulates hair cells, which are auditory receptor cells of the inner ear embedded in the basilar membrane.']
['What is the basilar membrane?', 'The basilar membrane is a thin strip of tissue within the cochlea.']
['what are the hair cells responsible for?', 'The activation of hair cells is a mechanical process: the stimulation of the hair cell ultimately leads to activation of the cell.']
['how do these hair cells interact with other cells?', 'As hair cells become activated, they generate neural impulses that travel along the auditory nerve to the brain.']

['what else does the brain do?', 'Auditory information is shuttled to the inferior colliculus, the medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus, and finally to the auditory cortex in the temporal lobe of the brain for processing.']

['what is the auditory cortex?', 'Like the visual system, there is also evidence suggesting that information about auditory recognition and localization is processed in parallel streams (Rauschecker & Tian, 2000; Renier et al., 2009).']
['What is pitch perception?', 'Different frequencies of sound waves are associated with differences in our perception of the pitch of those sounds.']
['What frequency is the lowest pitched sound?', 'Low-frequency sounds are lower pitched, and high-frequency sounds are higher pitched.']
['What theories have been proposed to account for pitch perception?', 'Several theories have been proposed to account for pitch perception.']
['What are the proposed theories?', 'We’ll discuss two of them here: temporal theory and place theory.']
['What is the temporal theory?', 'The temporal theory of pitch perception asserts that frequency is coded by the activity level of a sensory neuron.']
['What does that mean?', 'This would mean that a given hair cell would fire action potentials related to the frequency of the sound wave.']

['What would that mean in practice?', 'While this is a very intuitive explanation, we detect such a broad range of frequencies (20–20,000 Hz) that the frequency of action potentials fired by hair cells cannot account for the entire range.']

['What happens to the cells when they are too stimulated?', 'Because of properties related to sodium channels on the neuronal membrane that are involved in action potentials, there is a point at which a cell cannot fire any faster (Shamma, 2001).']
['What is the place theory of pitch perception?', 'The place theory of pitch perception suggests that different portions of the basilar membrane are sensitive to sounds of different frequencies.']

['What other parts of the basilar membrane are sensitive?', 'More specifically, the base of the basilar membrane responds best to high frequencies and the tip of the basilar membrane responds best to low frequencies.']

['What are the hair cells?', 'Therefore, hair cells that are in the base portion would be labeled as high-pitch receptors, while those in the tip of basilar membrane would be labeled as low-pitch receptors (Shamma, 2001).']
['What are two theories of pitch perception?', 'In reality, both theories explain different aspects of pitch perception.']
['What is the range of pitch?', 'At frequencies up to about 4000']
['', 'Hz, it is clear that both the rate of action potentials and place contribute to our perception of pitch.']
['How is pitch perception affected by noise?', 'However, much higher frequency sounds can only be encoded using place cues (Shamma, 2001).']
['What is sound localization?', 'The ability to locate sound in our environments is an important part of hearing.']
['What do we use sound localization for?', 'Localizing sound could be considered similar to the way that we perceive depth in our visual fields.']

['How does this compare to depth perception?', 'Like the monocular and binocular cues that provided information about depth, the auditory system uses both monaural (one-eared) and binaural (two-eared) cues to localize sound.']
['What is sound localization?', 'Each pinna interacts with incoming sound waves differently, depending on the sound’s source relative to our bodies.']
['What does it do?', 'This interaction provides a monaural cue that is helpful in locating sounds that occur above or below and in front or behind us.']

['Why is this important?', 'The sound waves received by your two ears from sounds that come from directly above, below, in front, or behind you would be identical; therefore, monaural cues are essential (Grothe, Pecka, & McAlpine, 2010).']

['What are binaural cues?', 'Binaural cues, on the other hand, provide information on the location of a sound along a horizontal axis by relying on differences in patterns of vibration of the eardrum between our two ears.']
['What is one type of binaural cue?', 'If a sound comes from an off-center location, it creates two types of binaural cues: interaural level differences and interaural timing differences.']

['What does interaural level difference mean?', 'Interaural level difference refers to the fact that a sound coming from the right side of your body is more intense at your right ear than at your left ear because of the attenuation of the sound wave as it passes through your head.']
['What is another type of binaural cue?', 'Interaural timing difference refers to the small difference in the time at which a given sound wave arrives at each ear.']
['How do these differences help in sound localization?', 'Certain brain areas monitor these differences to construct where along a horizontal axis a sound originates (Grothe et al., 2010).']
['What is Deafness?', 'Deafness is the partial or complete inability to hear.']
['Did you just learn that?', 'Some people are born without hearing, which is known as congenital deafness.']
['What happens to people after that?', 'Other people suffer from conductive hearing loss, which is due to a problem delivering sound energy to the cochlea.']

['What problems does it have?', 'Causes for conductive hearing loss include blockage of the ear canal, a hole in the tympanic membrane, problems with the ossicles, or fluid in the space between the eardrum and cochlea.']
['Are there other kinds of hearing loss?', 'Another group of people suffer from sensorineural hearing loss, which is the most common form of hearing loss.']

['What causes it?', 'Sensorineural hearing loss can be caused by many factors, such as aging, head or acoustic trauma, infections and diseases (such as measles or mumps), medications, environmental effects such as noise exposure (noise-induced hearing loss, as shown in Figure 5.20), tumors, and toxins (such as those found in certain solvents and metals).']

['What is the reason for hearing loss?', 'Given the mechanical nature by which the sound wave stimulus is transmitted from the eardrum through the ossicles to the oval window of the cochlea, some degree of hearing loss is inevitable.']
['What are the causes of conductive hearing loss?', 'With conductive hearing loss, hearing problems are associated with a failure in the vibration of the eardrum and/or movement of the ossicles.']

['How can hearing problems be dealt with?', 'These problems are often dealt with through devices like hearing aids that amplify incoming sound waves to make vibration of the eardrum and movement of the ossicles more likely to occur.']
['What causes hearing loss?', 'When the hearing problem is associated with a failure to transmit neural signals from the cochlea to the brain, it is called sensorineural hearing loss.']
['What is the name of one disease that results in sensorineural hearing loss?', "One disease that results in sensorineural hearing loss is Ménière's disease."]

["What other symptoms can be seen in Ménière's disease?", "Although not well understood, Ménière's disease results in a degeneration of inner ear structures that can lead to hearing loss, tinnitus (constant ringing or buzzing), vertigo (a sense of spinning), and an increase in pressure within the inner ear (Semaan & Megerian, 2011)."]
['How can this disease be treated?', 'This kind of loss cannot be treated with hearing aids, but some individuals might be candidates for a cochlear implant as a treatment option.']
['How are cochlear implants used to treat hearing loss?', 'Cochlear implants are electronic devices that consist of a microphone, a speech processor, and an electrode array.']
['How does the microphone work?', 'The device receives incoming sound information and directly stimulates the auditory nerve to transmit information to the brain.']
['What is the newest study done on this topic?', 'Vision and hearing have received an incredible amount of attention from researchers over the years.']
['What are the other modalities?', 'While there is still much to be learned about how these sensory systems work, we have a much better understanding of them than of our other sensory modalities.']
['What are the other senses?', 'In this section, we will explore our chemical senses (taste and smell) and our body senses (touch, temperature, pain, balance, and body position).']

['What are the chemical senses?', 'Taste (gustation) and smell (olfaction) are called chemical senses because both have sensory receptors that respond to molecules in the food we eat or in the air we breathe.']
['Are there any interactions between the senses?', 'There is a pronounced interaction between our chemical senses.']
['What is an example of this?', 'For example, when we describe the flavor of a given food, we are really referring to both gustatory and olfactory properties of the food working in combination.']
['What kind of sensations are taste receptors involved in?', 'You have learned since elementary school that there are four basic groupings of taste: sweet, salty, sour, and bitter.']
['What other groupings are there?', 'Research demonstrates, however, that we have at least six taste groupings.']
['What is umami?', 'Umami is our fifth taste.']
['What does it taste like?', 'Umami is actually a Japanese word that roughly translates to yummy, and it is associated with a taste for monosodium glutamate (Kinnamon & Vandenbeuch, 2009).']

['Does anyone know of any other tastes?', 'There is also a growing body of experimental evidence suggesting that we possess a taste for the fatty content of a given food (Mizushige, Inoue, & Fushiki, 2007).']
['What is taste?', 'Molecules from the food and beverages we consume dissolve in our saliva and interact with taste receptors on our tongue and in our mouth and throat.']
['What kind of receptors?', 'Taste buds are formed by groupings of taste receptor cells with hair-like extensions that protrude into the central pore of the taste bud.']
['Can they be destroyed?', 'Taste buds have a life cycle of ten days to two weeks, so even destroying some by burning your tongue won’t have any long-term effect; they just grow right back.']

['What happens to the taste buds after being destroyed?', 'Taste molecules bind to receptors on this extension and cause chemical changes within the sensory cell that result in neural impulses being transmitted to the brain via different nerves, depending on where the receptor is located.']

['Where does the taste information go in the brain?', 'Taste information is transmitted to the medulla, thalamus, and limbic system, and to the gustatory cortex, which is tucked underneath the overlap between the frontal and temporal lobes (Maffei, Haley, & Fontanini, 2012; Roper, 2013).']
['What can you tell me about the nose?', 'Olfactory receptor cells are located in a mucous membrane at the top of the nose.']

['What is a smell receptor?', 'Small hair-like extensions from these receptors serve as the sites for odor molecules dissolved in the mucus to interact with chemical receptors located on these extensions.']

['What is the olfactory bulb?', 'Once an odor molecule has bound a given receptor, chemical changes within the cell result in signals being sent to the olfactory bulb: a bulb-like structure at the tip of the frontal lobe where the olfactory nerves begin.']

['Where else is the bulb located?', 'From the olfactory bulb, information is sent to regions of the limbic system and to the primary olfactory cortex, which is located very near the gustatory cortex (Lodovichi & Belluscio, 2012; Spors et al., 2013).']
['What can you tell me about smell and the olfactory system?', 'There is tremendous variation in the sensitivity of the olfactory systems of different species.']
['What do dogs smell like?', 'We often think of dogs as having far superior olfactory systems than our own, and indeed, dogs can do some remarkable things with their noses.']
['How can dogs sense danger?', 'There is some evidence to suggest that dogs can “smell” dangerous drops in blood glucose levels as well as cancerous tumors (Wells, 2010).']

['What can you tell me about the olfactory system?', 'Dogs’ extraordinary olfactory abilities may be due to the increased number of functional genes for olfactory receptors (between 800 and 1200), compared to the fewer than 400 observed in humans and other primates (Niimura & Nei, 2007).']
['What are pheromones?', 'Many species respond to chemical messages, known as pheromones, sent by another individual (Wysocki & Preti, 2004).']
['What do these messages communicate?', 'Pheromonal communication often involves providing information about the reproductive status of a potential mate.']
['How does the message attract a mate?', 'So, for example, when a female rat is ready to mate, it secretes pheromonal signals that draw attention from nearby male rats.']

['What happens after the male rats perceive these signals?', 'Pheromonal activation is actually an important component in eliciting sexual behavior in the male rat (Furlow, 1996, 2012; Purvis & Haynes, 1972; Sachs, 1997).']

['How do humans react to pheromones?', 'There has also been a good deal of research (and controversy) about pheromones in humans (Comfort, 1971; Russell, 1976; Wolfgang-Kimball, 1992; Weller, 1998).']
['What are the various receptors on the skin?', 'A number of receptors are distributed throughout the skin to respond to various touch-related stimuli.']
['What are some of these receptors?', 'These receptors include Meissner’s corpuscles, Pacinian corpuscles, Merkel’s disks, and Ruffini corpuscles.']
['What do the receptors detect?', 'Meissner’s corpuscles respond to pressure and lower frequency vibrations, and Pacinian corpuscles detect transient pressure and higher frequency vibrations.']
['What other receptors do?', 'Merkel’s disks respond to light pressure, while Ruffini corpuscles detect stretch (Abraira & Ginty, 2013).']
['What is the information on skin receptors?', 'In addition to the receptors located in the skin, there are also a number of free nerve endings that serve sensory functions.']

['What is nociception?', 'These nerve endings respond to a variety of different types of touch-related stimuli and serve as sensory receptors for both thermoception (temperature perception) and nociception (a signal indicating potential harm and maybe pain) (Garland, 2012; Petho & Reeh, 2012; Spray, 1986).']

['What happens with the information?', 'Sensory information collected from the receptors and free nerve endings travels up the spinal cord and is transmitted to regions of the medulla, thalamus, and ultimately to somatosensory cortex, which is located in the postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe.']
['What is pain perception?', 'Pain is an unpleasant experience that involves both physical and psychological components.']
['Why do we feel pain?', 'Feeling pain is quite adaptive because it makes us aware of an injury, and it motivates us to remove ourselves from the cause of that injury.']
['Why remove ourselves from the cause of that injury?', 'In addition, pain also makes us less likely to suffer additional injury because we will be gentler with our injured body parts.']
['What kinds of pain are discussed?', 'Generally speaking, pain can be considered to be neuropathic or inflammatory in nature.']
['What is inflammatory pain?', 'Pain that signals some type of tissue damage is known as inflammatory pain.']
['What causes this type of pain?', 'In some situations, pain results from damage to neurons of either the peripheral or central nervous system.']
['What happens after that?', 'As a result, pain signals that are sent to the brain get exaggerated.']
['What is that called?', 'This type of pain is known as neuropathic pain.']
['How is pain treated?', 'Multiple treatment options for pain relief range from relaxation therapy to the use of analgesic medications to deep brain stimulation.']

['What other treatments are available?', 'The most effective treatment option for a given individual will depend on a number of considerations, including the severity and persistence of the pain and any medical/psychological conditions.']
['How do people experience pain?', 'Some individuals are born without the ability to feel pain.']
['How is that caused?', 'This very rare genetic disorder is known as congenital insensitivity to pain (or congenital analgesia).']
['Can you explain why they are deficient?', 'While those with congenital analgesia can detect differences in temperature and pressure, they cannot experience pain.']
["Why can't they feel pain?", 'As a result, they often suffer significant injuries.']
['What happens if a child bites their tongue over and over?', 'Young children have serious mouth and tongue injuries because they have bitten themselves repeatedly.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects?', 'Not surprisingly, individuals suffering from this disorder have much shorter life expectancies due to their injuries and secondary infections of injured sites (U.S. National Library of Medicine, 2013).']
['What is the vestibular sense?', 'The vestibular sense contributes to our ability to maintain balance and body posture.']
['Where is it located?', 'As Figure 5.24 shows, the major sensory organs (utricle, saccule, and the three semicircular canals) of this system are located next to the cochlea in the inner ear.']

['What are these organs made of?', 'The vestibular organs are fluid-filled and have hair cells, similar to the ones found in the auditory system, which respond to movement of the head and gravitational forces.']
['What happens when the cells are stimulated?', 'When these hair cells are stimulated, they send signals to the brain via the vestibular nerve.']

['Why is this important?', 'Although we may not be consciously aware of our vestibular system’s sensory information under normal circumstances, its importance is apparent when we experience motion sickness and/or dizziness related to infections of the inner ear (Khan & Chang, 2013).']

['What is Vestibular sense?', 'In addition to maintaining balance, the vestibular system collects information critical for controlling movement and the reflexes that move various parts of our bodies to compensate for changes in body position.']

['What is Proprioception?', 'Therefore, both proprioception (perception of body position) and kinesthesia (perception of the body’s movement through space) interact with information provided by the vestibular system.']

['What else is contained within the document?', 'These sensory systems also gather information from receptors that respond to stretch and tension in muscles, joints, skin, and tendons (Lackner & DiZio, 2005; Proske, 2006; Proske & Gandevia, 2012).']
['Where does the information travel to?', 'Proprioceptive and kinesthetic information travels to the brain via the spinal column.']

['What else does the brain do?', 'Several cortical regions in addition to the cerebellum receive information from and send information to the sensory organs of the proprioceptive and kinesthetic systems.']

['What happened after this?', 'In the early part of the 20th century, Max Wertheimer published a paper demonstrating that individuals perceived motion in rapidly flickering static images—an insight that came to him as he used a child’s toy tachistoscope.']

['what did Max Wertheimer do after this?', 'Wertheimer, and his assistants Wolfgang Köhler and Kurt Koffka, who later became his partners, believed that perception involved more than simply combining sensory stimuli.']
['what did they believe?', 'This belief led to a new movement within the field of psychology known as Gestalt psychology.']
['what is the concept of gestalt?', 'The word gestalt literally means form or pattern, but its use reflects the idea that the whole is different from the sum of its parts.']
['how does the idea reflect?', 'In other words, the brain creates a perception that is more than simply the sum of available sensory inputs, and it does so in predictable ways.']
['why does it do so?', 'Gestalt psychologists translated these predictable ways into principles by which we organize sensory information.']
['what was this about?', 'As a result, Gestalt psychology has been extremely influential in the area of sensation and perception (Rock & Palmer, 1990).']
['What is one of the gestalt principles?', 'One Gestalt principle is the figure-ground relationship.']
['What is figure-ground relationship?', 'According to this principle, we tend to segment our visual world into figure and ground.']
['What are the figure and ground?', 'Figure is the object or person that is the focus of the visual field, while the ground is the background.']
['What other principle are we studying?', 'As Figure 5.25 shows, our perception can vary tremendously, depending on what is perceived as figure and what is perceived as ground.']

['Why is the figure-ground relationship important?', 'Presumably, our ability to interpret sensory information depends on what we label as figure and what we label as ground in any particular case, although this assumption has been called into question (Peterson & Gibson, 1994; Vecera & O’Reilly, 1998).']
['What else can you tell me about this study material?', 'Another Gestalt principle for organizing sensory stimuli into meaningful perception is proximity.']
['What does proximity mean?', 'This principle asserts that things that are close to one another tend to be grouped together, as Figure 5.26 illustrates.']
['What is the proximity concept?', 'How we read something provides another illustration of the proximity concept.']
['When we read a letter the first time we get it on the tongue. The second time', 'For example, we read this sentence like this, notl iket hiso rt hat.']
['How do we perceive words?', 'We group the letters of a given word together because there are no spaces between the letters, and we perceive words because there are spaces between each word.']
['How can we perceive distance?', 'Here are some more examples:']
['What is the principle of similarity?', 'We might also use the principle of similarity to group things in our visual fields.']
['What is the principle of similarity?', 'According to this principle, things that are alike tend to be grouped together.']
['What is one example of the principle of similarity?', 'For example, when watching a football game, we tend to group individuals based on the colors of their uniforms.']
['What is one example of the principle of hierarchy?', 'When watching an offensive drive, we can get a sense of the two teams simply by grouping along this dimension.']
['what are the laws of continuity?', 'Two additional Gestalt principles are the law of continuity (or good continuation) and closure.']
['what does this rule mean?', 'The law of continuity suggests that we are more likely to perceive continuous, smooth flowing lines rather than jagged, broken lines.']
['what is closure?', 'The principle of closure states that we organize our perceptions into complete objects rather than as a series of parts.']

['What are the principles?', 'According to Gestalt theorists, pattern perception, or our ability to discriminate among different figures and shapes, occurs by following the principles described above.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'You probably feel fairly certain that your perception accurately matches the real world, but this is not always the case.']
['How do you know?', 'Our perceptions are based on perceptual hypotheses: educated guesses that we make while interpreting sensory information.']
['Are these hypotheses always correct?', 'These hypotheses are informed by a number of factors, including our personalities, experiences, and expectations.']
['What does this mean for us?', 'We use these hypotheses to generate our perceptual set.']

['What are some examples of hypotheses?', 'For instance, research has demonstrated that those who are given verbal priming produce a biased interpretation of complex ambiguous figures (Goolkasian & Woodbury, 2010).']
['What is a fact about birds?', 'Birds build nests and migrate as winter approaches.']
['What is an interesting fact about birds?', 'Infants suckle for nurishment.']
['What is an interesting fact about infants?', 'Dogs shake water off wet fur.']
['What is an interesting fact about dogs?', 'Salmon swim upstream to spawn, and spiders spin intricate webs.']
['What is an interesting fact about salmon?', 'They all are unlearned behaviors.']
['What is an unlearned behavior?', 'Both instincts and reflexes are innate (unlearned) behaviors that organisms are born with.']
['What are reflexes?', 'Reflexes are a motor or neural reaction to a specific stimulus in the environment.']

['What are reflexes?', 'They tend to be simpler than instincts, involve the activity of specific body parts and systems (e.g., the knee-jerk reflex and the contraction of the pupil in bright light), and involve more primitive centers of the central nervous system (e.g., the spinal cord and the medulla).']
['What are instincts?', 'In contrast, instincts are innate behaviors that are triggered by a broader range of events, such as maturation and the change of seasons.']
['What are instincts?', 'They are more complex patterns of behavior, involve movement of the organism as a whole (e.g., sexual activity and migration), and involve higher brain centers.']
['What are reflexes and instincts?', 'Both reflexes and instincts help an organism adapt to its environment and do not have to be learned.']
['Can you give me some examples?', 'For example, every healthy human baby has a sucking reflex, present at birth.']
['What is the function of this reflex?', 'Babies are born knowing how to suck on a nipple, whether artificial (from a bottle) or human.']
['What about for the baby?', 'Nobody teaches the baby to suck, just as no one teaches a sea turtle hatchling to move toward the ocean.']
['What is learning?', 'Learning, like reflexes and instincts, allows an organism to adapt to its environment.']

['What happens with learned behaviors?', 'But unlike instincts and reflexes, learned behaviors involve change and experience: learning is a relatively permanent change in behavior or knowledge that results from experience.']
['Why would they need to learn something?', 'In contrast to the innate behaviors discussed above, learning involves acquiring knowledge and skills through experience.']

['How do you use the surfing scenario?', 'Looking back at our surfing scenario, Julian will have to spend much more time training with his surfboard before he learns how to ride the waves like his father.']

['What is learning?', 'Learning to surf, as well as any complex learning process (e.g., learning about the discipline of psychology), involves a complex interaction of conscious and unconscious processes.']
['How is this process studied?', 'Learning has traditionally been studied in terms of its simplest components—the associations our minds automatically make between events.']
['Why do people make these associations?', 'Our minds have a natural tendency to connect events that occur closely together or in sequence.']
['What is associative learning?', 'Associative learning occurs when an organism makes connections between stimuli or events that occur together in the environment.']

['What is the basis of this learning?', 'You will see that associative learning is central to all three basic learning processes discussed in this chapter; classical conditioning tends to involve unconscious processes, operant conditioning tends to involve conscious processes, and observational learning adds social and cognitive layers to all the basic associative processes, both conscious and unconscious.']

['What are the other two types of learning processes?', 'These learning processes will be discussed in detail later in the chapter, but it is helpful to have a brief overview of each as you begin to explore how learning is understood from a psychological perspective.']
['What does classical conditioning entail?', 'In classical conditioning, also known as Pavlovian conditioning, organisms learn to associate events—or stimuli—that repeatedly happen together.']
['What are the benefits of this?', 'We experience this process throughout our daily lives.']
['What kinds of things do people experience?', 'For example, you might see a flash of lightning in the sky during a storm and then hear a loud boom of thunder.']
['What happens when these two things happen?', 'The sound of the thunder naturally makes you jump (loud noises have that effect by reflex).']
['Why does this happen?', 'Because lightning reliably predicts the impending boom of thunder, you may associate the two and jump when you see lightning.']
['What is the study of conditioning?', 'Psychological researchers study this associative process by focusing on what can be seen and measured—behaviors.']
['What kind of conditioning is there?', 'In operant conditioning, organisms learn, again, to associate events—a behavior and its consequence (reinforcement or punishment).']
['How does this affect us?', 'A pleasant consequence encourages more of that behavior in the future, whereas a punishment deters the behavior.']
['What examples do you have of classical and operant conditioning?', 'Imagine you are teaching your dog, Hodor, to sit.']
['How do you teach this?', 'You tell Hodor to sit, and give him a treat when he does.']
['What happens next?', 'After repeated experiences, Hodor begins to associate the act of sitting with receiving a treat.']
['How does he learn this?', 'He learns that the consequence of sitting is that he gets a doggie biscuit.']

['Why does it want to do it?', 'Conversely, if the dog is punished when exhibiting a behavior, it becomes conditioned to avoid that behavior (e.g., receiving a small shock when crossing the boundary of an invisible electric fence).']
['What do you know about observational learning?', 'Observational learning extends the effective range of both classical and operant conditioning.']

['What does it mean to be observational?', 'In contrast to classical and operant conditioning, in which learning occurs only through direct experience, observational learning is the process of watching others and then imitating what they do.']
['What happens in a society with this kind of learning?', 'A lot of learning among humans and other animals comes from observational learning.']
['What else is observed?', 'To get an idea of the extra effective range that observational learning brings, consider Ben and his son Julian from the introduction.']
['What happens with this kind of learning?', 'By watching his father, he can imitate the moves that bring success and avoid the moves that lead to failure.']

['What are some of the key concepts covered in this chapter?', 'All of the approaches covered in this chapter are part of a particular tradition in psychology, called behaviorism, which we discuss in the next section.']
['What other approaches are discussed?', 'However, these approaches do not represent the entire study of learning.']

['What does that mean?', 'Separate traditions of learning have taken shape within different fields of psychology, such as memory and cognition, so you will find that other chapters will round out your understanding of the topic.']
['Why would these traditions differ?', 'Over time these traditions tend to converge.']

['What kind of convergences have occurred?', 'For example, in this chapter you will see how cognition has come to play a larger role in behaviorism, whose more extreme adherents once insisted that behaviors are triggered by the environment with no intervening thought.']
['What is classical conditioning?', 'Even if you are new to the study of psychology, chances are that you have heard of Pavlov and his famous dogs.']
['Who is Pavlov?', 'Pavlov (1849–1936), a Russian scientist, performed extensive research on dogs and is best known for his experiments in classical conditioning.']

['What is classical conditioning?', 'As we discussed briefly in the previous section, classical conditioning is a process by which we learn to associate stimuli and, consequently, to anticipate events.']
['What was the most important topic of discussion?', 'Pavlov came to his conclusions about how learning occurs completely by accident.']
['What was the name of the scientist?', 'Pavlov was a physiologist, not a psychologist.']
['What does physiology study?', 'Physiologists study the life processes of organisms, from the molecular level to the level of cells, organ systems, and entire organisms.']
['What was his area of interest?', 'Pavlov’s area of interest was the digestive system (Hunt, 2007).']
['Did he research anything else?', 'In his studies with dogs, Pavlov measured the amount of saliva produced in response to various foods.']

['What was interesting?', "Over time, Pavlov (1927) observed that the dogs began to salivate not only at the taste of food, but also at the sight of food, at the sight of an empty food bowl, and even at the sound of the laboratory assistants' footsteps."]
['Why was saliva production so important to his research?', 'Salivating to food in the mouth is reflexive, so no learning is involved.']
['What did he observe?', 'However, dogs don’t naturally salivate at the sight of an empty bowl or the sound of footsteps.']
['What is the definition of classical conditioning?', "These unusual responses intrigued Pavlov, and he wondered what accounted for what he called the dogs' “psychic secretions” (Pavlov, 1927)."]
['What did Pavlov do next?', 'To explore this phenomenon in an objective manner, Pavlov designed a series of carefully controlled experiments to see which stimuli would cause the dogs to salivate.']
['What did he find?', 'He was able to train the dogs to salivate in response to stimuli that clearly had nothing to do with food, such as the sound of a bell, a light, and a touch on the leg.']

['What else did he learn from these experiments?', 'Through his experiments, Pavlov realized that an organism has two types of responses to its environment: (1) unconditioned (unlearned) responses, or reflexes, and (2) conditioned (learned) responses.']
['What did Pavlov experiment on?', 'In Pavlov’s experiments, the dogs salivated each time meat powder was presented to them.']
['What is unconditioned stimulus?', 'The meat powder in this situation was an unconditioned stimulus (UCS): a stimulus that elicits a reflexive response in an organism.']
['What is the unconditioned response?', 'The dogs’ salivation was an unconditioned response (UCR): a natural (unlearned) reaction to a given stimulus.']
['What are the conditioning and extinction stages?', 'Before conditioning, think of the dogs’ stimulus and response like this:']
['what is classical conditioning?', 'In classical conditioning, a neutral stimulus is presented immediately before an unconditioned stimulus.']
['how did pavlov train?', 'Pavlov would sound a tone (like ringing a bell) and then give the dogs the meat powder.']
['what was the tone?', 'The tone was the neutral stimulus (NS), which is a stimulus that does not naturally elicit a response.']
['why did it not elicit response?', 'Prior to conditioning, the dogs did not salivate when they just heard the tone because the tone had no association for the dogs.']
['What is the tone?', 'When Pavlov paired the tone with the meat powder over and over again, the previously neutral stimulus (the tone) also began to elicit salivation from the dogs.']
['What does CS mean?', 'Thus, the neutral stimulus became the conditioned stimulus (CS), which is a stimulus that elicits a response after repeatedly being paired with an unconditioned stimulus.']
['What did the dogs respond to?', 'Eventually, the dogs began to salivate to the tone alone, just as they previously had salivated at the sound of the assistants’ footsteps.']
['What is the CR?', 'The behavior caused by the conditioned stimulus is called the conditioned response (CR).']
['How does the CS relate to salivation?', 'In the case of Pavlov’s dogs, they had learned to associate the tone (CS) with being fed, and they began to salivate (CR) in anticipation of food.']
['What are some real-world examples?', 'Consider the case of Moisha, who was diagnosed with cancer.']
['Why did she want to get chemotherapy?', 'When she received her first chemotherapy treatment, she vomited shortly after the chemicals were injected.']
['Did this happen frequently?', 'In fact, every trip to the doctor for chemotherapy treatment shortly after the drugs were injected, she vomited.']
['Did the treatment work?', 'Moisha’s treatment was a success and her cancer went into remission.']
['What happened after the treatment?', "Now, when she visits her oncologist's office every 6 months for a check-up, she becomes nauseous."]

['What was a classical stimulus and response?', 'In this case, the chemotherapy drugs are the unconditioned stimulus (UCS), vomiting is the unconditioned response (UCR), the doctor’s office is the conditioned stimulus (CS) after being paired with the UCS, and nausea is the conditioned response (CR).']
['What else can you tell me about classical conditioning?', "Let's assume that the chemotherapy drugs that Moisha takes are given through a syringe injection."]
['What happens after she sees the syringe?', "After entering the doctor's office, Moisha sees a syringe, and then gets her medication."]
['How does this change her behavior?', "In addition to the doctor's office, Moisha will learn to associate the syringe with the medication and will respond to syringes with nausea."]

['What else can you tell me about classical conditioning?', "This is an example of higher-order (or second-order) conditioning, when the conditioned stimulus (the doctor's office) serves to condition another stimulus (the syringe)."]
['What is second order conditioning?', 'It is hard to achieve anything above second-order conditioning.']

['What does this mean?', "For example, if someone rang a bell every time Moisha received a syringe injection of chemotherapy drugs in the doctor's office, Moisha likely will never get sick in response to the bell."]
['Are we done with the first example of classical conditioning?', 'Consider another example of classical conditioning.']
['What is another example you could give?', 'Let’s say you have a cat named Tiger, who is quite spoiled.']
['Why is she so spoiled?', 'You keep her food in a separate cabinet, and you also have a special electric can opener that you use only to open cans of cat food.']
['What does the cat eat?', 'For every meal, Tiger hears the distinctive sound of the electric can opener (“zzhzhz”) and then gets her food.']
['What happens after she gets her food?', 'Tiger quickly learns that when she hears “zzhzhz” she is about to get fed.']
['What happens after she gets her food?', 'She will likely get excited and run to where you are preparing her food.']
['Why is she so excited?', 'This is an example of classical conditioning.']
['What does it mean?', 'In that case, Tiger hears “squeak” (the cabinet), “zzhzhz” (the electric can opener), and then she gets her food.']
['How does this work?', 'Tiger will learn to get excited when she hears the “squeak” of the cabinet.']
['What else is significant about this model?', 'Pairing a new neutral stimulus (“squeak”) with the conditioned stimulus (“zzhzhz”) is called higher-order conditioning, or second-order conditioning.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means you are using the conditioned stimulus of the can opener to condition another stimulus: the squeaky cabinet.']
['Are there other higher-order conditions?', 'It is hard to achieve anything above second-order conditioning.']
