['What else should you know about this model?', 'For example, if you ring a bell, open the cabinet (“squeak”), use the can opener (“zzhzhz”), and then feed Tiger, Tiger will likely never get excited when hearing the bell alone.']
['How does it apply to animals?', 'Classical conditioning also applies to humans, even babies.']
['What example does it provide?', 'For example, Elan buys formula in blue canisters for their six-month-old daughter, Angelina.']
['What happens with the formula canisters?', 'Whenever Elan takes out a formula container, Angelina gets excited, tries to reach toward the food, and most likely salivates.']
['What is a typical example?', 'So far, all of the examples have involved food, but classical conditioning extends beyond the basic need to be fed.']
['What are some examples?', 'Consider our earlier example of a dog whose owners install an invisible electric dog fence.']
['How does the dog react?', 'A small electrical shock (unconditioned stimulus) elicits discomfort (unconditioned response).']

['Does that stop the dog from escaping?', 'When the unconditioned stimulus (shock) is paired with a neutral stimulus (the edge of a yard), the dog associates the discomfort (unconditioned response) with the edge of the yard (conditioned stimulus) and stays within the set boundaries.']
['What other responses do you see?', 'In this example, the edge of the yard  elicits fear and anxiety in the dog.']
['What is the unconditioned stimulus?', 'Fear and anxiety are the conditioned response.']
["what's a general process involved?", 'Now that you know how classical conditioning works and have seen several examples, let’s take a look at some of the general processes involved.']

['what are some general processes?', 'In classical conditioning, the initial period of learning is known as acquisition, when an organism learns to connect a neutral stimulus and an unconditioned stimulus.']

['what happens during acquisition?', 'During acquisition, the neutral stimulus begins to elicit the conditioned response, and eventually the neutral stimulus becomes a conditioned stimulus capable of eliciting the conditioned response by itself.']
['what is important about timing?', 'Timing is important for conditioning to occur.']
['what is typically the timing?', 'Typically, there should only be a brief interval between presentation of the conditioned stimulus and the unconditioned stimulus.']
['what is this interval?', 'Depending on what is being conditioned, sometimes this interval is as little as five seconds (Chance, 2009).']
['can the interval be longer?', 'However, with other types of conditioning, the interval can be up to several hours.']

['What is taste aversion?', 'Taste aversion is a type of conditioning in which an interval of several hours may pass between the conditioned stimulus (something ingested) and the unconditioned stimulus (nausea or illness).']
['What are the four stages in classical conditioning?', 'Here’s how it works.']
['How does it work?', 'Between classes, you and a friend grab a quick lunch from a food cart on campus.']
['What did you eat?', 'You share a dish of chicken curry and head off to your next class.']
['What happens next?', 'A few hours later, you feel nauseous and become ill.']

['What did you do?', 'Although your friend is fine and you determine that you have intestinal flu (the food is not the culprit), you’ve developed a taste aversion; the next time you are at a restaurant and someone orders curry, you immediately feel ill.']
['What is this example?', 'While the chicken dish is not what made you sick, you are experiencing taste aversion: you’ve been conditioned to be averse to a food after a single, bad experience.']

['What is taste aversion?', 'Research into taste aversion suggests that this response may be an evolutionary adaptation designed to help organisms quickly learn to avoid harmful foods (Garcia & Rusiniak, 1980; Garcia & Koelling, 1966).']

['What other benefits can this have?', 'Not only may this contribute to species survival via natural selection, but it may also help us develop strategies for challenges such as helping cancer patients through the nausea induced by certain treatments (Holmes, 1993; Jacobsen et al., 1993; Hutton, Baracos, & Wismer, 2007; Skolin et al., 2006).']
['What were the limitations of taste aversion?', 'Garcia and Koelling (1966) showed not only that taste aversions could be conditioned, but also that there were biological constraints to learning.']
['What are some examples?', 'In their study, separate groups of rats were conditioned to associate either a flavor with illness, or lights and sounds with illness.']

['How did the rats respond?', 'Results showed that all rats exposed to flavor-illness pairings learned to avoid the flavor, but none of the rats exposed to lights and sounds with illness learned to avoid lights or sounds.']

['What else did Garcia and Koelling do?', 'This added evidence to the idea that classical conditioning could contribute to species survival by helping organisms learn to avoid stimuli that posed real dangers to health and welfare.']
['What did Rescorla prove?', 'Robert Rescorla demonstrated how powerfully an organism can learn to predict the UCS from the CS.']
['How did he prove that?', 'Take, for example, the following two situations.']
['What are the situations?', 'Ari’s dad always has dinner on the table every day at 6:00.']
['What time does Ari eat dinner?', 'Soraya’s mom switches it up so that some days they eat dinner at 6:00, some days they eat at 5:00, and other days they eat at 7:00.']
['What happens after they eat?', "For Ari, 6:00 reliably and consistently predicts dinner, so Ari will likely start feeling hungry every day right before 6:00, even if he's had a late snack."]
['How does Soraya feel about it?', 'Soraya, on the other hand, will be less likely to associate 6:00 with dinner, since 6:00 does not always predict that dinner is coming.']

['How else does Rescorla prove it?', 'Rescorla, along with his colleague at Yale University, Alan Wagner, developed a mathematical formula that could be used to calculate the probability that an association would be learned given the ability of a conditioned stimulus to predict the occurrence of an unconditioned stimulus and other factors; today this is known as the Rescorla-Wagner model (Rescorla & Wagner, 1972)']
['How would you explain this?', 'In Tiger’s case, imagine what would happen if you stopped using the electric can opener for her food and began to use it only for human food.']
['Why would she still hear it?', 'Now, Tiger would hear the can opener, but she would not get food.']
['Why did she need to be motivated?', 'In classical conditioning terms, you would be giving the conditioned stimulus, but not the unconditioned stimulus.']
['What were the dogs experiments?', 'Pavlov explored this scenario in his experiments with dogs: sounding the tone without giving the dogs the meat powder.']
['What was he doing there?', 'Soon the dogs stopped responding to the tone.']
['What was extinction?', 'Extinction is the decrease in the conditioned response when the unconditioned stimulus is no longer presented with the conditioned stimulus.']
['What was the next section?', 'When presented with the conditioned stimulus alone, the dog, cat, or other organism would show a weaker and weaker response, and finally no response.']
['What was the result?', 'In classical conditioning terms, there is a gradual weakening and disappearance of the conditioned response.']

['What else is included in this section?', 'As we just discussed, Pavlov found that when he repeatedly presented the bell (conditioned stimulus) without the meat powder (unconditioned stimulus), extinction occurred; the dogs stopped salivating to the bell.']
['What happened after extinction?', 'However, after a couple of hours of resting from this extinction training, the dogs again began to salivate when Pavlov rang the bell.']

['What else did he find?', 'When you finally got it fixed and started using it to open Tiger’s food again, Tiger would remember the association between the can opener and her food—she would get excited and run to the kitchen when she heard the sound.']

['What is spontaneous recovery?', 'The behavior of Pavlov’s dogs and Tiger illustrates a concept Pavlov called spontaneous recovery: the return of a previously extinguished conditioned response following a rest period.']
['Are there any further things you want to know about this topic?', 'Of course, these processes also apply in humans.']
['Do you have any examples of such?', 'For example, let’s say that every day when you walk to campus, an ice cream truck passes your route.']
['How do you learn to like the truck?', 'Day after day, you hear the truck’s music (neutral stimulus), so you finally stop and purchase a chocolate ice cream bar.']
['What happens after you buy it?', 'You take a bite (unconditioned stimulus) and then your mouth waters (unconditioned response).']

['What happens during this phase?', 'This initial period of learning is known as acquisition, when you begin to connect the neutral stimulus (the sound of the truck) and the unconditioned stimulus (the taste of the chocolate ice cream in your mouth).']
['What is the result of this?', 'During acquisition, the conditioned response gets stronger and stronger through repeated pairings of the conditioned stimulus and unconditioned stimulus.']

['What happens after this?', 'Several days (and ice cream bars) later, you notice that your mouth begins to water (conditioned response) as soon as you hear the truck’s musical jingle—even before you bite into the ice cream bar.']
['What was the final conclusion?', 'Then one day you head down the street.']
['What happened next?', 'You hear the truck’s music (conditioned stimulus), and your mouth waters (conditioned response).']
['Are you able to get the ice cream?', 'However, when you get to the truck, you discover that they are all out of ice cream.']
['What happens next?', 'You leave disappointed.']
['What is going on here?', 'The next few days you pass by the truck and hear the music, but don’t stop to get an ice cream bar because you’re running late for class.']
['What happened then?', 'You begin to salivate less and less when you hear the music, until by the end of the week, your mouth no longer waters when you hear the tune.']
['How does extinction work?', 'This illustrates extinction.']

['What happens next?', 'The conditioned response weakens when only the conditioned stimulus (the sound of the truck) is presented, without being followed by the unconditioned stimulus (chocolate ice cream in the mouth).']
['What else happens in this section?', 'Then the weekend comes.']
['What happens next?', 'Monday morning arrives and you take your usual route to campus.']
['What happens next?', 'You round the corner and hear the truck again.']
['What happens next?', 'Your mouth begins to water again.']
['What is the most important part of this article?', 'After a break from conditioning, the conditioned response reappears, which indicates spontaneous recovery.']
['What is acquisition?', 'Acquisition and extinction involve the strengthening and weakening, respectively, of a learned association.']
['What are the other two processes?', 'Two other learning processes—stimulus discrimination and stimulus generalization—are involved in determining which stimuli will trigger learned responses.']

['What are the responses?', 'Animals (including humans) need to distinguish between stimuli—for example, between sounds that predict a threatening event and sounds that do not—so that they can respond appropriately (such as running away if the sound is threatening).']
['What is stimulus discrimination?', 'When an organism learns to respond differently to various stimuli that are similar, it is called stimulus discrimination.']
['What is stimulus generalization?', 'In classical conditioning terms, the organism demonstrates the conditioned response only to the conditioned stimulus.']

['What is another example?', 'Pavlov’s dogs discriminated between the basic tone that sounded before they were fed and other tones (e.g., the doorbell), because the other sounds did not predict the arrival of food.']
['What other examples?', 'Similarly, Tiger, the cat, discriminated between the sound of the can opener and the sound of the electric mixer.']
['Why does she discriminate?', 'When the electric mixer is going, Tiger is not about to be fed, so she does not come running to the kitchen looking for food.']
['What is the other example?', 'In our other example, Moisha, the cancer patient, discriminated between oncologists and other types of doctors.']
['How does she discriminate?', 'She learned not to feel ill when visiting doctors for other types of appointments, such as her annual physical.']

['What is stimulus discrimination?', 'On the other hand, when an organism demonstrates the conditioned response to stimuli that are similar to the condition stimulus, it is called stimulus generalization, the opposite of stimulus discrimination.']
['What is stimulus generalization?', 'The more similar a stimulus is to the condition stimulus, the more likely the organism is to give the conditioned response.']
['What is a common example of stimulus generalization?', 'For instance, if the electric mixer sounds very similar to the electric can opener, Tiger may come running after hearing its sound.']

['What does this mean?', 'But if you do not feed her following the electric mixer sound, and you continue to feed her consistently after the electric can opener sound, she will quickly learn to discriminate between the two sounds (provided they are sufficiently dissimilar that she can tell them apart).']

['Are there any other examples of stimulus generalization?', 'In our other example, Moisha continued to feel ill whenever visiting other oncologists or other doctors in the same building as her oncologist.']
['Who is the founder of Behaviorism?', 'John B. Watson, shown in Figure 6.8, is considered the founder of behaviorism.']

['What does behaviorism mean?', 'Behaviorism is a school of thought that arose during the first part of the 20th century, which incorporates elements of Pavlov’s classical conditioning (Hunt, 2007).']

['Why is this important?', 'In stark contrast with Freud, who considered the reasons for behavior to be hidden in the unconscious, Watson championed the idea that all behavior can be studied as a simple stimulus-response reaction, without regard for internal processes.']

['What was his reasoning?', 'Watson argued that in order for psychology to become a legitimate science, it must shift its concern away from internal mental processes because mental processes cannot be seen or measured.']
['How does he say this?', 'Instead, he asserted that psychology must focus on outward observable behavior that can be measured.']
['Who are the main figures?', 'Watson’s ideas were influenced by Pavlov’s work.']
['What were they influenced by?', 'According to Watson, human behavior, just like animal behavior, is primarily the result of conditioned responses.']

['What was their main thesis?', 'Whereas Pavlov’s work with dogs involved the conditioning of reflexes, Watson believed the same principles could be extended to the conditioning of human emotions (Watson, 1919).']

['What is the first thing you need to know about this subject?', 'In 1920, while chair of the psychology department at Johns Hopkins University, Watson and his graduate student, Rosalie Rayner, conducted research on a baby nicknamed Little Albert.']
['How did they conduct the research?', 'Rayner and Watson’s experiments with Little Albert demonstrated how fears can be conditioned using classical conditioning.']
['What was the experiment about?', 'Through these experiments, Little Albert was exposed to and conditioned to fear certain things.']
['What things did he encounter?', 'Initially he was presented with various neutral stimuli, including a rabbit, a dog, a monkey, masks, cotton wool, and a white rat.']
['Was he afraid of any of them?', 'He was not afraid of any of these things.']
['What happened next?', 'Then Watson, with the help of Rayner, conditioned Little Albert to associate these stimuli with an emotion—fear.']
['Did he hate the rats at first?', 'For example, Watson handed Little Albert the white rat, and Little Albert enjoyed playing with it.']
['How did the rats get scary?', 'Then Watson made a loud sound, by striking a hammer against a metal bar hanging behind Little Albert’s head, each time Little Albert touched the rat.']
['What was his reaction?', 'Little Albert was frightened by the sound—demonstrating a reflexive fear of sudden loud noises—and began to cry.']
['How did they train him to fear them?', 'Watson repeatedly paired the loud sound with the white rat.']
['Did he start to hate the rats?', 'Soon Little Albert became frightened by the white rat alone.']

['Was there anything else interesting in this section?', 'Days later, Little Albert demonstrated stimulus generalization—he became afraid of other furry things: a rabbit, a furry coat, and even a Santa Claus mask.']
['What was he trying to do?', 'Watson had succeeded in conditioning a fear response in Little Albert, thus demonstrating that emotions could become conditioned responses.']

['What was the final outcome?', 'It had been Watson’s intention to produce a phobia—a persistent, excessive fear of a specific object or situation— through conditioning alone, thus countering Freud’s view that phobias are caused by deep, hidden conflicts in the mind.']
['What happened next?', 'However, there is no evidence that Little Albert experienced phobias in later years.']
['How did that work out?', 'Little Albert’s mother moved away, ending the experiment.']
['What were the criticisms?', 'While Watson’s research provided new insight into conditioning, it would be considered unethical by today’s standards.']
['What else is important to know?', 'The previous section of this chapter focused on the type of associative learning known as classical conditioning.']

['What can you tell me about classical conditioning?', 'Remember that in classical conditioning, something in the environment triggers a reflex automatically, and researchers train the organism to react to a different stimulus.']
['What type of conditioning did you describe?', 'Now we turn to the second type of associative learning, operant conditioning.']
['What is operant conditioning?', 'In operant conditioning, organisms learn to associate a behavior and its consequence.']
['What happens as a consequence?', 'A pleasant consequence makes that behavior more likely to be repeated in the future.']
['What are some examples of operant conditioning?', 'For example, Spirit, a dolphin at the National Aquarium in Baltimore, does a flip in the air when her trainer blows a whistle.']
['What is her consequence?', 'The consequence is that she gets a fish.']

['What does operant conditioning have to do with riding a bike?', 'Psychologist B. F. Skinner saw that classical conditioning is limited to existing behaviors that are reflexively elicited, and it doesn’t account for new behaviors such as riding a bike.']
['What did Skinner do about it?', 'He proposed a theory about how such behaviors come about.']
['What was his theory?', 'Skinner believed that behavior is motivated by the consequences we receive for the behavior: the reinforcements and punishments.']

['What else did he say about reinforcements and punishments?', 'His idea that learning is the result of consequences is based on the law of effect, which was first proposed by psychologist Edward Thorndike.']

['Did Thorndike have the law of effect?', 'According to the law of effect, behaviors that are followed by consequences that are satisfying to the organism are more likely to be repeated, and behaviors that are followed by unpleasant consequences are less likely to be repeated (Thorndike, 1911).']
['What did he mean by the law of effect?', 'Essentially, if an organism does something that brings about a desired result, the organism is more likely to do it again.']
['What are the consequences for behaviors that bring about a desired result?', 'If an organism does something that does not bring about a desired result, the organism is less likely to do it again.']
['What is an example of the law of effect?', 'An example of the law of effect is in employment.']
['What is it about employment?', 'One of the reasons (and often the main reason) we show up for work is because we get paid to do so.']
["What happens when we don't get paid?", 'If we stop getting paid, we will likely stop showing up—even if we love our job.']

['What are the details of Operant conditioning?', 'Working with Thorndike’s law of effect as his foundation, Skinner began conducting scientific experiments on animals (mainly rats and pigeons) to determine how organisms learn through operant conditioning (Skinner, 1938).']
['What was the method he used?', 'He placed these animals inside an operant conditioning chamber, which has come to be known as a “Skinner box”.']
['What is a Skinner box?', 'A Skinner box contains a lever (for rats) or disk (for pigeons) that the animal can press or peck for a food reward via the dispenser.']
['What else can be used to reward a behavior?', 'Speakers and lights can be associated with certain behaviors.']
['What else is used to reward?', 'A recorder counts the number of responses made by the animal.']
['What are the keywords in the article?', 'In discussing operant conditioning, we use several everyday words—positive, negative, reinforcement, and punishment—in a specialized manner.']
['How are those words used?', 'In operant conditioning, positive and negative do not mean good and bad.']
['', 'Instead, positive means you are adding something, and negative means you are taking something away.']
['What is reinforcement?', 'Reinforcement means you are increasing a behavior, and punishment means you are decreasing a behavior.']
['How does it work?', 'Reinforcement can be positive or negative, and punishment can also be positive or negative.']
['Why?', 'All reinforcers (positive or negative) increase the likelihood of a behavioral response.']
['What is punishers?', 'All punishers (positive or negative) decrease the likelihood of a behavioral response.']
["What's the next step?", 'Now let’s combine these four terms: positive reinforcement, negative reinforcement, positive punishment, and negative punishment.']
['What is reinforcement?', 'The most effective way to teach a person or animal a new behavior is with positive reinforcement.']
['What is positive reinforcement?', 'In positive reinforcement, a desirable stimulus is added to increase a behavior.']
['what kind of reinforcement is it?', 'For example, you tell your five-year-old son, Jerome, that if he cleans his room, he will get a toy.']
['does he clean his room?', 'Jerome quickly cleans his room because he wants a new art set.']
['when does the reinforcement start?', 'Let’s pause for a moment.']
['does the reinforcement work?', 'Some people might say, “Why should I reward my child for doing what is expected?”']
["Isn't it natural that we are rewarded for the things we do and not", 'But in fact we are constantly and consistently rewarded in our lives.']
['do we need more reinforcement?', 'Our paychecks are rewards, as are high grades and acceptance into our preferred school.']
['can we do anything to reinforce it?', 'Being praised for doing a good job and for passing a driver’s test is also a reward.']
['what is the consequence of reinforcement?', 'Positive reinforcement as a learning tool is extremely effective.']

['what are some facts about reinforcement?', 'It has been found that one of the most effective ways to increase achievement in school districts with below-average reading scores was to pay the children to read.']
['how did it work?', 'Specifically, second-grade students in Dallas were paid $2 each time they read a book and passed a short quiz about the book.']
['how did it work?', 'The result was a significant increase in reading comprehension (Fryer, 2010).']
['what else did you find?', 'If Skinner were alive today, he would probably think this was a great idea.']
['why would he?', 'He was a strong proponent of using operant conditioning principles to influence students’ behavior at school.']

['how did he do it?', 'In fact, in addition to the Skinner box, he also invented what he called a teaching machine that was designed to reward small steps in learning (Skinner, 1961)—an early forerunner of computer-assisted learning.']
['did he teach anything else?', 'His teaching machine tested students’ knowledge as they worked through various school subjects.']
['did it work?', 'If students answered questions correctly, they received immediate positive reinforcement and could continue; if they answered incorrectly, they did not receive any reinforcement.']
['why did it work that way?', 'The idea was that students would spend additional time studying the material to increase their chance of being reinforced the next time (Skinner, 1961).']
['What is negative reinforcement?', 'In negative reinforcement, an undesirable stimulus is removed to increase a behavior.']
['What is an example?', 'For example, car manufacturers use the principles of negative reinforcement in their seatbelt systems, which go “beep, beep, beep” until you fasten your seatbelt.']
['What happens when you fasten the seatbelt?', 'The annoying sound stops when you exhibit the desired behavior, increasing the likelihood that you will buckle up in the future.']
['What other examples?', 'Negative reinforcement is also used frequently in horse training.']

['How does the horse get trained?', 'Riders apply pressure—by pulling the reins or squeezing their legs—and then remove the pressure when the horse performs the desired behavior, such as turning or speeding up.']
['What is pressure?', 'The pressure is the negative stimulus that the horse wants to remove.']
['Why is punishment important?', 'Many people confuse negative reinforcement with punishment in operant conditioning, but they are two very different mechanisms.']
['What happens after you give negative reinforcement?', 'Remember that reinforcement, even when it is negative, always increases a behavior.']
['Why is punishment different from reinforcement?', 'In contrast, punishment always decreases a behavior.']
['Does the student explain what positive punishment is?', 'In positive punishment, you add an undesirable stimulus to decrease a behavior.']
['What is an example of positive punishment?', 'An example of positive punishment is scolding a student to get the student to stop texting in class.']
['What happens after you scold the student?', 'In this case, a stimulus (the reprimand) is added in order to decrease the behavior (texting in class).']
['What is negative punishment?', 'In negative punishment, you remove a pleasant stimulus to decrease behavior.']
['What are some examples of negative punishment?', 'For example, when a child misbehaves, a parent can take away a favorite toy.']
['What happens after you take away the favorite toy?', 'In this case, a stimulus (the toy) is removed in order to decrease the behavior.']
['What is punishment?', 'Punishment, especially when it is immediate, is one way to decrease undesirable behavior.']
['What are some examples of undesirable behavior?', 'For example, imagine your four-year-old son, Brandon, hit his younger brother.']
['What would you do?', 'You have Brandon write 100 times “I will not hit my brother" (positive punishment).']
['What is the consequence of that?', 'Chances are he won’t repeat this behavior.']
['How else might you punish someone?', 'While strategies like this are common today, in the past children were often subject to physical punishment, such as spanking.']
['What are the drawbacks?', 'It’s important to be aware of some of the drawbacks in using physical punishment on children.']
['What do the drawbacks mean?', 'First, punishment may teach fear.']
['How does fear teach?', 'Brandon may become fearful of the street, but he also may become fearful of the person who delivered the punishment—you, his parent.']
['How many other problems is fear tied to?', 'Similarly, children who are punished by teachers may come to fear the teacher and try to avoid school (Gershoff et al., 2010).']
['What is corporal punishment banned from?', 'Consequently, most schools in the United States have banned corporal punishment.']
['Why is it banned?', 'Second, punishment may cause children to become more aggressive and prone to antisocial behavior and delinquency (Gershoff, 2002).']

['What else is a drawback?', 'They see their parents resort to spanking when they become angry and frustrated, so, in turn, they may act out this same behavior when they become angry and frustrated.']

['How might they act out this behavior?', 'For example, because you spank Brenda when you are angry with her for her misbehavior, she might start hitting her friends when they won’t share their toys.']

['What is the purpose of positive punishment?', 'While positive punishment can be effective in some cases, Skinner suggested that the use of punishment should be weighed against the possible negative effects.']
['What do psychologists say?', 'Today’s psychologists and parenting experts favor reinforcement over punishment—they recommend that you catch your child doing something good and reward them for it.']
['What is shaping?', 'In his operant conditioning experiments, Skinner often used an approach called shaping.']
['What are the different approaches?', 'Instead of rewarding only the target behavior, in shaping, we reward successive approximations of a target behavior.']
['What happens if the target behavior is not present?', 'Remember that in order for reinforcement to work, the organism must first display the behavior.']
['Why is it important to shape?', 'Shaping is needed because it is extremely unlikely that an organism will display anything but the simplest of behaviors spontaneously.']
['What else can you tell me about shaping?', 'In shaping, behaviors are broken down into many small, achievable steps.']
['What are some of the steps?', 'The specific steps used in the process are the following:']
['What is the second question?', 'Reinforce any response that resembles the desired behavior.']
['What happens after that?', 'Then reinforce the response that more closely resembles the desired behavior.']
['What happens next?', 'You will no longer reinforce the previously reinforced response.']
['What happens next?', 'Next, begin to reinforce the response that even more closely resembles the desired behavior.']
['What happens next?', 'Continue to reinforce closer and closer approximations of the desired behavior.']
['What happens next?', 'Finally, only reinforce the desired behavior.']
['what is shaping?', 'Shaping is often used in teaching a complex behavior or chain of behaviors.']

['how does it work?', 'Skinner used shaping to teach pigeons not only such relatively simple behaviors as pecking a disk in a Skinner box, but also many unusual and entertaining behaviors, such as turning in circles, walking in figure eights, and even playing ping pong; the technique is commonly used by animal trainers today.']
['what else is shaping?', 'An important part of shaping is stimulus discrimination.']
['what is stimulus discrimination?', 'Recall Pavlov’s dogs—he trained them to respond to the tone of a bell, and not to similar tones or sounds.']
['why is this important?', 'This discrimination is also important in operant conditioning and in shaping behavior.']
['What did this teacher ask you to do?', 'Let’s consider parents whose goal is to have their child learn to clean his room.']
['What do they do to get him to do so?', 'They use shaping to help him master steps toward the goal.']
['What does this tell us?', 'Instead of performing the entire task, they set up these steps and reinforce each step.']
['What are these steps?', 'First, he cleans up one toy.']
['Why does he have to clean up one toy?', 'Second, he cleans up five toys.']
['How many toys?', 'Third, he chooses whether to pick up ten toys or put his books and clothes away.']
['How many toys are there?', 'Fourth, he cleans up everything except two toys.']
['Why do he have to leave two toys behind?', 'Finally, he cleans his entire room.']
['What are primary and secondary reinforcers?', 'Rewards such as stickers, praise, money, toys, and more can be used to reinforce learning.']
['What are examples of secondary reinforcers?', 'Let’s go back to Skinner’s rats again.']
['What was the secondary reinforcer?', 'They were rewarded with food each time they pressed the lever.']
['Why would food be an obvious reinforcer?', 'For animals, food would be an obvious reinforcer.']
['What did your child do to get them to do their chores?', 'For your child Chris, it was the promise of a toy when they cleaned their room.']
['What other examples of primary and secondary reinforcers do you see?', 'If you gave Sydney a piece of candy every time Sydney scored a goal, you would be using a primary reinforcer.']
['What are the different types of reinforcers?', 'Primary reinforcers are reinforcers that have innate reinforcing qualities.']
['Are they learned or innate?', 'These kinds of reinforcers are not learned.']
['What other kinds of things are a primary reinforcer?', 'Water, food, sleep, shelter, sex, and touch, among others, are primary reinforcers.']
['What kind of pleasure?', 'Pleasure is also a primary reinforcer.']
['How do we get them?', 'Organisms do not lose their drive for these things.']

['How are they communicated?', 'For most people, jumping in a cool lake on a very hot day would be reinforcing and the cool lake would be innately reinforcing—the water would cool the person off (a physical need), as well as provide pleasure.']
['What are secondary reinforcers?', 'A secondary reinforcer has no inherent value and only has reinforcing qualities when linked with a primary reinforcer.']
['What is one example of a secondary reinforcer?', 'Praise, linked to affection, is one example of a secondary reinforcer, as when you called out “Great shot!” every time Sydney made a goal.']

['What other examples are there?', 'Another example, money, is only worth something when you can use it to buy other things—either things that satisfy basic needs (food, water, shelter—all primary reinforcers) or other secondary reinforcers.']
['How does money affect the person?', 'If you were on a remote island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean and you had stacks of money, the money would not be useful if you could not spend it.']
['How are toys related to the reinforcers?', 'They also are secondary reinforcers.']
['What does a token represent?', 'Sometimes, instead of stickers on a sticker chart, a token is used.']
['What happens when the stickers are used?', 'Tokens, which are also secondary reinforcers, can then be traded in for rewards and prizes.']
['What does a token economy consist of?', 'Entire behavior management systems, known as token economies, are built around the use of these kinds of token reinforcers.']
['Why is this used?', 'Token economies have been found to be very effective at modifying behavior in a variety of settings such as schools, prisons, and mental hospitals.']

['How does this help people?', 'For example, a study by Adibsereshki and Abkenar (2014) found that use of a token economy increased appropriate social behaviors and reduced inappropriate behaviors in a group of eight grade students.']

['How does this help people?', 'Similar studies show demonstrable gains on behavior and academic achievement for groups ranging from first grade to high school, and representing a wide array of abilities and disabilities.']

['How does this work?', 'For example, during studies involving younger students, when children in the study exhibited appropriate behavior (not hitting or pinching), they received a “quiet hands” token.']
['What happens when they hit or pinch?', 'When they hit or pinched, they lost a token.']
['What can be traded in for tokens?', 'The children could then exchange specified amounts of tokens for minutes of playtime.']
['What is a reinforcement schedule?', 'Remember, the best way to teach a person or animal a behavior is to use positive reinforcement.']
['What types of behaviors can you teach by using positive reinforcement?', 'For example, Skinner used positive reinforcement to teach rats to press a lever in a Skinner box.']
['What happened in the Skinner box?', 'At first, the rat might randomly hit the lever while exploring the box, and out would come a pellet of food.']
['What would happen after the rat got that food?', 'It hit the lever again, and received another pellet of food.']
['What did it learn from this experience?', 'Each time the rat hit the lever, a pellet of food came out.']
['What other types of reinforcement are there?', 'When an organism receives a reinforcer each time it displays a behavior, it is called continuous reinforcement.']
['Why is it called continuous reinforcement?', 'This reinforcement schedule is the quickest way to teach someone a behavior, and it is especially effective in training a new behavior.']
['Can you give me an example of continuous reinforcement?', 'Let’s look back at the dog that was learning to sit earlier in the chapter.']
['What did you do to help him learn to sit?', 'Now, each time he sits, you give him a treat.']

['Why do you give him the treat?', 'Timing is important here: you will be most successful if you present the reinforcer immediately after he sits, so that he can make an association between the target behavior (sitting) and the consequence (getting a treat).']
['What can you tell me about partial reinforcement?', 'Once a behavior is trained, researchers and trainers often turn to another type of reinforcement schedule—partial reinforcement.']

['What is intermittent reinforcement?', 'In partial reinforcement, also referred to as intermittent reinforcement, the person or animal does not get reinforced every time they perform the desired behavior.']
['What are the different types of partial reinforcement schedules?', 'There are several different types of partial reinforcement schedules.']
['What is the difference between the schedules?', 'These schedules are described as either fixed or variable, and as either interval or ratio.']
['What does fixed mean?', 'Fixed refers to the number of responses between reinforcements, or the amount of time between reinforcements, which is set and unchanging.']
['What does variable mean?', 'Variable refers to the number of responses or amount of time between reinforcements, which varies or changes.']
['What is interval?', 'Interval means the schedule is based on the time between reinforcements, and ratio means the schedule is based on the number of responses between reinforcements.']
['What are some important aspects of Reinforcement Schedules?', 'Now let’s combine these four terms.']
['What is fixed interval reinforcement schedule?', 'A fixed interval reinforcement schedule is when behavior is rewarded after a set amount of time.']
['What else is known about Fixed Interval Reinforcement schedules?', 'For example, June undergoes major surgery in a hospital.']
['What else happens to them?', 'During recovery, they are expected to experience pain and will require prescription medications for pain relief.']
['How are their pain relieved?', 'June is given an IV drip with a patient-controlled painkiller.']
['How much dose is given to them?', 'Their doctor sets a limit: one dose per hour.']
['How are they rewarded for their behavior?', 'June pushes a button when pain becomes difficult, and they receive a dose of medication.']
['How does this benefit June?', 'Since the reward (pain relief) only occurs on a fixed interval, there is no point in exhibiting the behavior when it will not be rewarded.']

['What is a variable interval reinforcement schedule?', 'With a variable interval reinforcement schedule, the person or animal gets the reinforcement based on varying amounts of time, which are unpredictable.']
['What would Manuel be rewarded for?', 'Say that Manuel is the manager at a fast-food restaurant.']
['Does he get any customers?', 'Every once in a while someone from the quality control division comes to Manuel’s restaurant.']
['What happens after the customer leaves?', 'If the restaurant is clean and the service is fast, everyone on that shift earns a $20 bonus.']

['Does this encourage Manuel to be clean?', 'Manuel never knows when the quality control person will show up, so he always tries to keep the restaurant clean and ensures that his employees provide prompt and courteous service.']
['Is Manuel an effective manager?', 'His productivity regarding prompt service and keeping a clean restaurant are steady because he wants his crew to earn the bonus.']
['What is a Fixed ratio reinforcement schedule?', 'With a fixed ratio reinforcement schedule, there are a set number of responses that must occur before the behavior is rewarded.']
['What type of reinforcement schedule is this used for?', 'Carla sells glasses at an eyeglass store, and she earns a commission every time she sells a pair of glasses.']
['What type of rewards does she use?', 'She always tries to sell people more pairs of glasses, including prescription sunglasses or a backup pair, so she can increase her commission.']
['What else did you find interesting about this scenario?', 'She does not care if the person really needs the prescription sunglasses, Carla just wants her bonus.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'The quality of what Carla sells does not matter because her commission is not based on quality; it’s only based on the number of pairs sold.']
['How would this affect her overall performance?', 'This distinction in the quality of performance can help determine which reinforcement method is most appropriate for a particular situation.']

['What type of reinforcement method is best for a particular situation?', 'Fixed ratios are better suited to optimize the quantity of output, whereas a fixed interval, in which the reward is not quantity based, can lead to a higher quality of output.']
['What are variable ratio reinforcement schedules?', 'In a variable ratio reinforcement schedule, the number of responses needed for a reward varies.']
['What is the greatest advantage of this schedule?', 'This is the most powerful partial reinforcement schedule.']
['What is one of the greatest applications of this schedule?', 'An example of the variable ratio reinforcement schedule is gambling.']
['What are some real-life applications of this?', 'Imagine that Sarah—generally a smart, thrifty woman—visits Las Vegas for the first time.']
["What does Sarah do while she's there?", 'She is not a gambler, but out of curiosity she puts a quarter into the slot machine, and then another, and another.']
['What happens after she puts a quarter into the slot machine?', 'Nothing happens.']
['Is Sarah rewarded after she puts the quarter in?', 'Two dollars in quarters later, her curiosity is fading, and she is just about to quit.']
['How does Sarah feel about quitting?', 'But then, the machine lights up, bells go off, and Sarah gets 50 quarters back.']
['What did Sarah feel after she got her quarters back?', 'That’s more like it!']
['How long did Sarah play the slot machine?', 'Sarah gets back to inserting quarters with renewed interest, and a few minutes later she has used up all her gains and is $10 in the hole.']
["How does Sarah feel after she's in the hole?", 'Now might be a sensible time to quit.']
['What did Sarah do while she was in Vegas?', 'And yet, she keeps putting money into the slot machine because she never knows when the next reinforcement is coming.']
['How does Sarah keep playing the slot machine?', 'She keeps thinking that with the next quarter she could win $50, or $100, or even more.']
['Why does Sarah keep playing?', 'Because the reinforcement schedule in most types of gambling has a variable ratio schedule, people keep trying and hoping that the next time they will win big.']
['Is there anything else interesting in this article?', 'This is one of the reasons that gambling is so addictive—and so resistant to extinction.']

['What are reinforcement schedules?', 'In operant conditioning, extinction of a reinforced behavior occurs at some point after reinforcement stops, and the speed at which this happens depends on the reinforcement schedule.']
['How does it differ from normal extinction?', 'In a variable ratio schedule, the point of extinction comes very slowly, as described above.']
['How long does it take for extinction to occur?', 'But in the other reinforcement schedules, extinction may come quickly.']
['How is that applied?', 'For example, if June presses the button for the pain relief medication before the allotted time the doctor has approved, no medication is administered.']

['What time of day is the medication administered?', 'They are on a fixed interval reinforcement schedule (dosed hourly), so extinction occurs quickly when reinforcement doesn’t come at the expected time.']
['What are the differences between them?', 'Among the reinforcement schedules, variable ratio is the most productive and the most resistant to extinction.']
['Are there any other schedules?', 'Fixed interval is the least productive and the easiest to extinguish.']

['What did Watson and Skinner think about cognition?', 'Strict behaviorists like Watson and Skinner focused exclusively on studying behavior rather than cognition (such as thoughts and expectations).']
['Why did they believe that?', "In fact, Skinner was such a staunch believer that cognition didn't matter that his ideas were considered radical behaviorism."]
['What was their rationale for this?', 'Skinner considered the mind a "black box"—something completely unknowable—and, therefore, something not to be studied.']
['Did they support this view?', 'However, another behaviorist, Edward C. Tolman, had a different opinion.']

['What was the change?', 'Tolman’s experiments with rats demonstrated that organisms can learn even if they do not receive immediate reinforcement (Tolman & Honzik, 1930; Tolman, Ritchie, & Kalish, 1946).']

['What did this lead to?', 'This finding was in conflict with the prevailing idea at the time that reinforcement must be immediate in order for learning to occur, thus suggesting a cognitive aspect to learning.']
['what were the experiment?', 'In the experiments, Tolman placed hungry rats in a maze with no reward for finding their way through it.']
['why was he trying to find out how hungry rats were?', 'He also studied a comparison group that was rewarded with food at the end of the maze.']
['what were the results of his experiment?', 'As the unreinforced rats explored the maze, they developed a cognitive map: a mental picture of the layout of the maze.']
['what was the result of their exploration?', 'After 10 sessions in the maze without reinforcement, food was placed in a goal box at the end of the maze.']

['what was the effect of the food?', 'As soon as the rats became aware of the food, they were able to find their way through the maze quickly, just as quickly as the comparison group, which had been rewarded with food all along.']
['what is latent learning?', 'This is known as latent learning: learning that occurs but is not observable in behavior until there is a reason to demonstrate it.']
['What is Latent Learning?', 'Latent learning also occurs in humans.']
['What is an example of Latent learning?', 'Children may learn by watching the actions of their parents but only demonstrate it at a later date, when the learned material is needed.']
['What can a child learn from their parents?', 'For example, suppose that Ravi’s dad drives him to school every day.']

["Why did Ravi's dad drive him there?", 'In this way, Ravi learns the route from his house to his school, but he’s never driven there himself, so he has not had a chance to demonstrate that he’s learned the way.']
['What happened after the day?', 'One morning Ravi’s dad has to leave early for a meeting, so he can’t drive Ravi to school.']
['What happened next?', 'Instead, Ravi follows the same route on his bike that his dad would have taken in the car.']
['What else happened?', 'This demonstrates latent learning.']
['What is the reason for the latent learning?', 'Ravi had learned the route to school, but had no need to demonstrate this knowledge earlier.']
['What are previous sections of this chapter about?', 'Previous sections of this chapter focused on classical and operant conditioning, which are forms of associative learning.']
['What is observational learning?', 'In observational learning, we learn by watching others and then imitating, or modeling, what they do or say.']
['Who do you imitate?', 'The individuals performing the imitated behavior are called models.']

['Do you have any more interesting information?', 'Research suggests that this imitative learning involves a specific type of neuron, called a mirror neuron (Hickock, 2010; Rizzolatti, Fadiga, Fogassi, & Gallese, 2002; Rizzolatti, Fogassi, & Gallese, 2006).']
['What is observational learning?', 'Humans and other animals are capable of observational learning.']
['How do we test observational learning?', 'For example, in a study of social learning in chimpanzees, researchers gave juice boxes with straws to two groups of captive chimpanzees.']
['How did the chimpanzees react?', 'The first group dipped the straw into the juice box, and then sucked on the small amount of juice at the end of the straw.']
['Why did they do that?', 'The second group sucked through the straw directly, getting much more juice.']
['How did the first group change?', 'All of the “dippers” in the first group switched to sucking through the straws directly.']

['How did they learn to do it?', 'By simply observing the other chimps and modeling their behavior, they learned that this was a more efficient method of getting juice (Yamamoto, Humle, and Tanaka, 2013).']
['What is imitation?', 'Imitation is sometimes called the highest form of flattery.']
['What happens after imitation?', 'But consider Claire’s experience with observational learning.']
['What happened to Claire?', 'Claire’s nine-year-old son, Jay, was getting into trouble at school and was defiant at home.']
['Did Claire scold him?', 'Claire feared that Jay would end up like her brothers, two of whom were in prison.']

['What happened to Jay when he was beating his belt?', 'One day, after yet another bad day at school and another negative note from the teacher, Claire, at her wit’s end, beat her son with a belt to get him to behave.']

['Did they have a different experience after beating his belt?', 'Later that night, as she put her children to bed, Claire witnessed her four-year-old daughter, Anna, take a belt to her teddy bear and whip it.']
['What happened to Claire?', 'Claire was horrified, realizing that Anna was imitating her mother.']
['How did Claire feel after seeing Anna do this?', 'It was then that Claire knew she wanted to discipline her children in a different manner.']

["What was Albert Bandura's connection to the Pythagorean theore", 'Like Tolman, whose experiments with rats suggested a cognitive component to learning, psychologist Albert Bandura’s ideas about learning were different from those of strict behaviorists.']
["What was Albert Bandura's brand of behaviorism?", 'Bandura and other researchers proposed a brand of behaviorism called social learning theory, which took cognitive processes into account.']

['Why did Albert Bandura think that learning took cognitive processes into account?', 'According to Bandura, pure behaviorism could not explain why learning can take place in the absence of external reinforcement.']
['Did Albert Bandura have other ideas about learning?', 'He felt that internal mental states must also have a role in learning and that observational learning involves much more than imitation.']
['Why is imitation different than observation?', 'In imitation, a person simply copies what the model does.']
['What happens when people observe?', 'Observational learning is much more complex.']
['What types of observation do people use?', 'According to Lefrançois (2012) there are several ways that observational learning can occur:']
['What is the first response?', 'You learn a new response.']
['What is the second response?', 'After watching your coworker get chewed out by your boss for coming in late, you start leaving home 10 minutes earlier so that you won’t be late.']
['What else happened?', 'You choose whether or not to imitate the model depending on what you saw happen to the model.']
['What is the final example?', 'When learning to surf, Julian might watch how his father pops up successfully on his surfboard and then attempt to do the same thing.']
['What else happened?', 'On the other hand, Julian might learn not to touch a hot stove after watching his father get burned on a stove.']
['What else happens?', 'You learn a general rule that you can apply to other situations.']
['What are the models?', 'Bandura identified three kinds of models: live, verbal, and symbolic.']
['What kind of model is a live model?', 'A live model demonstrates a behavior in person, as when Ben stood up on his surfboard so that Julian could see how he did it.']

['What kind of model is a verbal model?', 'A verbal instructional model does not perform the behavior, but instead explains or describes the behavior, as when a soccer coach tells his young players to kick the ball with the side of the foot, not with the toe.']

['What kind of model is a symbolic model?', 'A symbolic model can be fictional characters or real people who demonstrate behaviors in books, movies, television shows, video games, or Internet sources.']
['What are the steps in the modeling process?', 'Of course, we don’t learn a behavior simply by observing a model.']

['What is the description of each step in the modeling process?', 'Bandura described specific steps in the process of modeling that must be followed if learning is to be successful: attention, retention, reproduction, and motivation.']
['How do you pay attention?', 'First, you must be focused on what the model is doing—you have to pay attention.']
['What happens next?', 'Next, you must be able to retain, or remember, what you observed; this is retention.']
['How do you perform the behavior?', 'Then, you must be able to perform the behavior that you observed and committed to memory; this is reproduction.']
['How do you motivate yourself?', 'Finally, you must have motivation.']
['How does motivation happen?', 'You need to want to copy the behavior, and whether or not you are motivated depends on what happened to the model.']
['What is the model doing?', 'If you saw that the model was reinforced for their behavior, you will be more motivated to copy them.']
['What is vicarious reinforcement?', 'This is known as vicarious reinforcement.']
['Why not?', 'On the other hand, if you observed the model being punished, you would be less motivated to copy them.']
['What is the difference between reinforcement and punishment?', 'This is called vicarious punishment.']

['What else does this article have to do with?', 'For example, imagine that four-year-old Allison watched her older sister Kaitlyn playing in their mother’s makeup, and then saw Kaitlyn get a time out when their mother came in.']
['Why did the mother punish her?', 'After their mother left the room, Allison was tempted to play in the make-up, but she did not want to get a time-out from her mother.']
['Why did she try to make a behavior change?', 'Once you actually demonstrate the new behavior, the reinforcement you receive plays a part in whether or not you will repeat the behavior.']
['What was the modeling process?', 'Bandura researched modeling behavior, particularly children’s modeling of adults’ aggressive and violent behaviors (Bandura, Ross, & Ross, 1961).']
['How did he investigate this?', 'He conducted an experiment with a five-foot inflatable doll that he called a Bobo doll.']
['Did the experiment yield any results?', 'In the experiment, children’s aggressive behavior was influenced by whether the teacher was punished for her behavior.']
['What else was noted in the article?', 'In one scenario, a teacher acted aggressively with the doll, hitting, throwing, and even punching the doll, while a child watched.']
['What was the response?', 'There were two types of responses by the children to the teacher’s behavior.']
['What were the responses?', 'When the teacher was punished for her bad behavior, the children decreased their tendency to act as she had.']
['What happened when the teacher was praised?', 'When the teacher was praised or ignored (and not punished for her behavior), the children imitated what she did, and even what she said.']
['What did the children do?', 'They punched, kicked, and yelled at the doll.']
['What did Bandura conclude?', 'Bandura concluded that we watch and learn, and that this learning can have both prosocial and antisocial effects.']
['What is an example of prosocial effects?', 'Prosocial (positive) models can be used to encourage socially acceptable behavior.']
['What are examples of antisocial effects?', 'Parents in particular should take note of this finding.']
['How do parents apply this concept?', 'If you want your children to read, then read to them.']
["Why don't you read to them?", 'Let them see you reading.']
['Why do they need to see you reading?', 'Keep books in your home.']
['What books?', 'Talk about your favorite books.']

['What else can you do to encourage reading?', 'If you want your children to be healthy, then let them see you eat right and exercise, and spend time engaging in physical fitness activities together.']
['What other examples of models of behavior can be used?', 'The same holds true for qualities like kindness, courtesy, and honesty.']

['Why is this important?', 'The main idea is that children observe and learn from their parents, even their parents’ morals, so be consistent and toss out the old adage “Do as I say, not as I do,” because children tend to copy what you do instead of what you say.']

['What other examples of models do you have?', 'Besides parents, many public figures, such as Martin Luther King, Jr. and Mahatma Gandhi, are viewed as prosocial models who are able to inspire global social change.']
['What other kinds of problems is observational learning about?', 'The antisocial effects of observational learning are also worth mentioning.']
['What causes the antisocial effects?', 'As you saw from the example of Claire at the beginning of this section, her daughter viewed Claire’s aggressive behavior and copied it.']
['Why does that happen?', 'Research suggests that this may help to explain why victims of abuse often grow up to be abusers themselves (Murrell, Christoff, & Henning, 2007).']
['What else has been found regarding this effect?', 'In fact, about 30% of child abuse victims become abusive parents (U.S. Department of Health & Human Services, 2013).']
['What else does this say about observational learning?', 'We tend to do what we know.']

['What else do we tend to do according to this saying?', 'Children who grow up witnessing their parents deal with anger and frustration through violent and aggressive acts often learn to behave in that manner themselves.']

['What is media violence?', 'Some studies suggest that violent television shows, movies, and video games may also have antisocial effects although further research needs to be done to understand the correlational and causational aspects of media violence and behavior.']

['Why is this?', 'Some studies have found a link between viewing violence and aggression seen in children (Anderson & Gentile, 2008; Kirsch, 2010; Miller, Grabell, Thomas, Bermann, & Graham-Bermann, 2012).']

['What can you tell me about this?', 'These findings may not be surprising, given that a child graduating from high school has been exposed to around 200,000 violent acts including murder, robbery, torture, bombings, beatings, and rape through various forms of media (Huston et al., 1992).']

['Why do they learn this?', 'Not only might viewing media violence affect aggressive behavior by teaching people to act that way in real life situations, but it has also been suggested that repeated exposure to violent acts also desensitizes people to it.']
['Are there any studies?', 'Psychologists are working to understand this dynamic.']
['What are thoughts?', 'Imagine all of your thoughts as if they were physical entities, swirling rapidly inside your mind.']
['What happens in the brain during thought?', 'The brain is endlessly perceiving, processing, planning, organizing, and remembering—it is always active.']
['What can happen in the brain when it is active?', 'Yet, you don’t notice most of your brain’s activity as you move throughout your daily routine.']
['What else is thought involved in?', 'This is only one facet of the complex processes involved in cognition.']
['What else does cognition encompass?', 'Simply put, cognition is thinking, and it encompasses the processes associated with perception, knowledge, problem solving, judgment, language, and memory.']

['Does a scientific study delve into the topic?', 'Scientists who study cognition are searching for ways to understand how we integrate, organize, and utilize our conscious cognitive experiences without being aware of all of the unconscious work that our brains are doing (for example, Kahneman, 2011).']
['What is cognition?', 'Upon waking each morning, you begin thinking—contemplating the tasks that you must complete that day.']
["You might also think of a way to shave your legs and you can't", 'These thoughts are one example of cognition at work.']

['What is one of the most important aspects of cognition?', 'Exceptionally complex, cognition is an essential feature of human consciousness, yet not all aspects of cognition are consciously experienced.']
['What is cognitive psychology?', 'Cognitive psychology is the field of psychology dedicated to examining how people think.']

['What are the major parts of cognitive psychology?', 'It attempts to explain how and why we think the way we do by studying the interactions among human thinking, emotion, creativity, language, and problem solving, in addition to other cognitive processes.']

['What are other aspects of cognitive psychology?', 'Cognitive psychologists strive to determine and measure different types of intelligence, why some people are better at problem solving than others, and how emotional intelligence affects success in the workplace, among countless other topics.']

['Can you tell me what else cognitive psychologists study?', 'They also sometimes focus on how we organize thoughts and information gathered from our environments into meaningful categories of thought, which will be discussed later.']
['What is it about?', 'The human nervous system is capable of handling endless streams of information.']

['What can be processed?', 'The senses serve as the interface between the mind and the external environment, receiving stimuli and translating it into nervous impulses that are transmitted to the brain.']

['What do these nervous impulses do?', 'The brain then processes this information and uses the relevant pieces to create thoughts, which can then be expressed through language or stored in memory for future use.']
['How do the nervous impulses get transmitted?', 'To make this process more complex, the brain does not gather information from external environments only.']
['What else does it gather from?', 'When thoughts are formed, the mind synthesizes information from emotions and memories.']
['What else can emotions and memories contribute?', 'Emotion and memory are powerful influences on both our thoughts and behaviors.']
['What is the first concept?', 'In order to organize this staggering amount of information, the mind has developed a "file cabinet" of sorts in the mind.']
['What are these files called?', 'The different files stored in the file cabinet are called concepts.']
['What do they store?', 'Concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences.']

['What are the details stored in this file cabinet called?', 'Concepts are, in many ways, big ideas that are generated by observing details, and categorizing and combining these details into cognitive structures.']
['Are concepts helpful?', 'You use concepts to see the relationships among the different elements of your experiences and to keep the information in your mind organized and accessible.']

['What is it about?', 'Concepts are informed by our semantic memory (you will learn more about semantic memory in a later chapter) and are present in every aspect of our lives; however, one of the easiest places to notice concepts is inside a classroom, where they are discussed explicitly.']
['What do you study in a classroom?', 'When you study United States history, for example, you learn about more than just individual events that have happened in America’s past.']

['How do you learn about a country or place?', 'You absorb a large quantity of information by listening to and participating in discussions, examining maps, and reading first-hand accounts of people’s lives.']
['How do you remember the information?', 'Your brain analyzes these details and develops an overall understanding of American history.']
['What else does your brain analyze?', 'In the process, your brain gathers details that inform and refine your understanding of related concepts like democracy, power, and freedom.']
['What are the concepts?', 'Concepts can be complex and abstract, like justice, or more concrete, like types of birds.']
['What is an example of an abstract concept?', 'In psychology, for example, Piaget’s stages of development are abstract concepts.']
['Are there other examples of abstract concepts?', 'Some concepts, like tolerance, are agreed upon by many people, because they have been used in various ways over many years.']
['What are other examples of concrete concepts?', 'Other concepts, like the characteristics of your ideal friend or your family’s birthday traditions, are personal and individualized.']
['How do concepts influence our lives?', 'In this way, concepts touch every aspect of our lives, from our many daily routines to the guiding principles behind the way governments function.']
['What is the content of this study material about?', 'Another technique used by your brain to organize information is the identification of prototypes for the concepts you have developed.']
['What is a prototype?', 'A prototype is the best example or representation of a concept.']
['What is an example?', 'Most likely your early experiences with dogs will shape what you imagine.']
['How would your experiences with dogs shape what you imagine?', 'If your first pet was a Golden Retriever, there is a good chance that this would be your prototype for the category of dogs.']
['What are natural and artificial concepts?', 'In psychology, concepts can be divided into two categories, natural and artificial.']
['What makes up a natural concept?', 'Natural concepts are created “naturally” through your experiences and can be developed from either direct or indirect experiences.']
['What types of experiences do you have that give rise to natural concepts?', 'For example, if you live in Essex Junction, Vermont, you have probably had a lot of direct experience with snow.']

['What do you think of the snow?', 'You’ve watched it fall from the sky, you’ve seen lightly falling snow that barely covers the windshield of your car, and you’ve shoveled out 18 inches of fluffy white snow as you’ve thought, “This is perfect for skiing.”']
['Do you have any other personal experiences with snow?', 'You’ve thrown snowballs at your best friend and gone sledding down the steepest hill in town.']
['What else are your experiences with snow?', 'In short, you know snow.']
['What else do you know about snow?', 'You know what it looks like, smells like, tastes like, and feels like.']

['What is your general perception about snow?', 'If, however, you’ve lived your whole life on the island of Saint Vincent in the Caribbean, you may never have actually seen snow, much less tasted, smelled, or touched it.']
['How do you know about snow then?', 'You know snow from the indirect experience of seeing pictures of falling snow—or from watching films that feature snow as part of the setting.']

['Are there any other examples of natural concepts that you like?', 'Either way, snow is a natural concept because you can construct an understanding of it through direct observations, experiences with snow, or indirect knowledge (such as from films or books).']
['What is an artificial concept?', 'An artificial concept, on the other hand, is a concept that is defined by a specific set of characteristics.']
['What is an example of a natural concept?', 'Various properties of geometric shapes, like squares and triangles, serve as useful examples of artificial concepts.']
['What are the characteristics of a triangle?', 'A triangle always has three angles and three sides.']
['What are the characteristics of a square?', 'A square always has four equal sides and four right angles.']

['What are some examples of artificial concepts?', 'Mathematical formulas, like the equation for area (length × width) are artificial concepts defined by specific sets of characteristics that are always the same.']
['Why is that?', 'Artificial concepts can enhance the understanding of a topic by building on one another.']
['How can one build on an artificial concept?', 'For example, before learning the concept of “area of a square” (and the formula to find it), you must understand what a square is.']

['Does the example illustrate any other aspect of an artificial concept?', 'Once the concept of “area of a square” is understood, an understanding of area for other geometric shapes can be built upon the original understanding of area.']
['How is the use of artificial concepts beneficial?', 'The use of artificial concepts to define an idea is crucial to communicating with others and engaging in complex thought.']

['How does the concept of a triangle connect to the theory of artificial concepts?', 'According to Goldstone and Kersten (2003), concepts act as building blocks and can be connected in countless combinations to create complex thoughts.']
['What is a schema?', 'A schema is a mental construct consisting of a cluster or collection of related concepts (Bartlett, 1932).']

['How do schemata work?', 'There are many different types of schemata, and they all have one thing in common: schemata are a method of organizing information that allows the brain to work more efficiently.']
['What happens when the schema is activated?', 'When a schema is activated, the brain makes immediate assumptions about the person or object being observed.']
['What are schemata?', 'There are several types of schemata.']
['What is a role schema?', 'A role schema makes assumptions about how individuals in certain roles will behave (Callero, 1994).']
['What is an example of a role schema?', 'For example, imagine you meet someone who introduces himself as a firefighter.']
['What happens next?', 'When this happens, your brain automatically activates the “firefighter schema” and begins making assumptions that this person is brave, selfless, and community-oriented.']
['What does this mean?', 'Despite not knowing this person, already you have unknowingly made judgments about them.']
['What else does schemata do?', 'Schemata also help you fill in gaps in the information you receive from the world around you.']

['What are the downsides to schemata?', 'While schemata allow for more efficient information processing, there can be problems with schemata, regardless of whether they are accurate: Perhaps this particular firefighter is not brave, they just work as a firefighter to pay the bills while studying to become a children’s librarian.']
['what are Schemata?', 'An event schema, also known as a cognitive script, is a set of behaviors that can feel like a routine.']
['can you explain how this helps us?', 'Think about what you do when you walk into an elevator.']
['how does this happen?', 'First, the doors open and you wait to let exiting passengers leave the elevator car.']
['does this happen frequently?', 'Then, you step into the elevator and turn around to face the doors, looking for the correct button to push.']
['what do you find interesting?', 'Interestingly, event schemata can vary widely among different cultures and countries.']

['what is an example of this?', 'For example, while it is quite common for people to greet one another with a handshake in the United States, in Tibet, you greet someone by sticking your tongue out at them, and in Belize, you bump fists (Cairns Regional Council, n.d.)']
['Are event schemata always automatically created?', 'Because event schemata are automatic, they can be difficult to change.']
['What can you tell me about event schemata?', 'Imagine that you are driving home from work or school.']
['What happens in your mind?', 'This event schema involves getting in the car, shutting the door, and buckling your seatbelt before putting the key in the ignition.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'You might perform this script two or three times each day.']
['What happens after you drive home?', 'As you drive home, you hear your phone’s ring tone.']
['What does this mean?', 'Typically, the event schema that occurs when you hear your phone ringing involves locating the phone and answering it or responding to your latest text message.']
['What does your brain do when this happens?', 'So without thinking, you reach for your phone, which could be in your pocket, in your bag, or on the passenger seat of the car.']
['What do we know about event schemas?', 'This powerful event schema is informed by your pattern of behavior and the pleasurable stimulation that a phone call or text message gives your brain.']

['What is unique about this particular example?', 'Because it is a schema, it is extremely challenging for us to stop reaching for the phone, even though we know that we endanger our own lives and the lives of others while we do it (Neyfakh, 2013).']
['What else was in your introduction?', 'It feels almost impossible to walk in and not face the door.']
['What is your statement about Schemata?', 'Our powerful event schema dictates our behavior in the elevator, and it is no different with our phones.']

['What is this about?', 'Current research suggests that it is the habit, or event schema, of checking our phones in many different situations that makes refraining from checking them while driving especially difficult (Bayer & Campbell, 2012).']

['What does this have to do with driving?', 'Because texting and driving has become a dangerous epidemic in recent years, psychologists are looking at ways to help people interrupt the “phone schema” while driving.']
['How does it help?', 'Event schemata like these are the reason why many habits are difficult to break once they have been acquired.']
['Did you mention anything else in the introduction?', 'As we continue to examine thinking, keep in mind how powerful the forces of concepts and schemata are to our understanding of the world.']
['What is language?', 'Language is a communication system that involves using words and systematic rules to organize those words to transmit information from one individual to another.']
['Is language a form of communication?', 'While language is a form of communication, not all communication is language.']
['How do other animals communicate?', 'Many species communicate with one another through their postures, movements, odors, or vocalizations.']
['Is communication important?', 'This communication is crucial for species that need to interact and develop social relationships with their conspecifics.']

['What makes humans different from other animals?', 'However, many people have asserted that it is language that makes humans unique among all of the animal species (Corballis & Suddendorf, 2007; Tomasello & Rakoczy, 2003).']

['What will this section cover?', 'This section will focus on what distinguishes language as a special form of communication, how the use of language develops, and how language affects the way we think.']
['What is one of the components of language?', 'Language, be it spoken, signed, or written, has specific components: a lexicon and grammar.']
['What is the lexicon?', 'Lexicon refers to the words of a given language.']
['What is it?', 'Thus, lexicon is a language’s vocabulary.']
['What is grammar?', 'Grammar refers to the set of rules that are used to convey meaning through the use of the lexicon (Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']
['What is an example?', 'For instance, English grammar dictates that most verbs receive an “-ed” at the end to indicate past tense.']
['What is Phoneme?', 'Words are formed by combining the various phonemes that make up the language.']
['What is a phoneme?', 'A phoneme (e.g., the sounds “ah” vs. “eh”) is a basic sound unit of a given language, and different languages have different sets of phonemes.']
['What else is important?', 'Phonemes are combined to form morphemes, which are the smallest units of language that convey some type of meaning (e.g., “I” is both a phoneme and a morpheme).']
['What else are important?', 'We use semantics and syntax to construct language.']
['What is syntax?', 'Semantics and syntax are part of a language’s grammar.']
['What is semantics?', 'Semantics refers to the process by which we derive meaning from morphemes and words.']
['What is syntax?', 'Syntax refers to the way words are organized into sentences (Chomsky, 1965; Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['What is the structure of language?', 'We apply the rules of grammar to organize the lexicon in novel and creative ways, which allow us to communicate information about both concrete and abstract concepts.']
['Are there any examples of concrete and abstract concepts?', 'We can talk about our immediate and observable surroundings as well as the surface of unseen planets.']
['What else can we talk about?', 'We can share our innermost thoughts, our plans for the future, and debate the value of a college education.']
['Do we have any examples of concrete concepts?', 'We can provide detailed instructions for cooking a meal, fixing a car, or building a fire.']
['How else do we communicate?', 'Through our use of words and language, we are able to form, organize, and express ideas, schema, and artificial concepts.']

['What does it have to do with language?', 'Given the remarkable complexity of a language, one might expect that mastering a language would be an especially arduous task; indeed, for those of us trying to learn a second language as adults, this might seem to be true.']
['What is the main idea?', 'However, young children master language very quickly with relative ease.']
['What kind of research has been done?', 'B. F. Skinner (1957) proposed that language is learned through reinforcement.']
['What else is known?', 'Noam Chomsky (1965) criticized this behaviorist approach, asserting instead that the mechanisms underlying language acquisition are biologically determined.']
