['What else has been found out?', 'The use of language develops in the absence of formal instruction and appears to follow a very similar pattern in children from vastly different cultures and backgrounds.']
['What is this about?', 'It would seem, therefore, that we are born with a biological predisposition to acquire a language (Chomsky, 1965; Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['What other information did Chomsky give?', 'Moreover, it appears that there is a critical period for language acquisition, such that this proficiency at acquiring language is maximal early in life; generally, as people age, the ease with which they acquire and master new languages diminishes (Johnson & Newport, 1989; Lenneberg, 1967; Singleton, 1995).']
['What are the basic facts?', 'Children begin to learn about language from a very early age.']
['How old?', 'In fact, it appears that this is occurring even before we are born.']
['What happens before being born?', 'Newborns show preference for their mother’s voice and appear to be able to discriminate between the language spoken by their mother and other languages.']

['How does it appear to happen?', 'Babies are also attuned to the languages being used around them and show preferences for videos of faces that are moving in synchrony with the audio of spoken language versus videos that do not synchronize with the audio (Blossom & Morgan, 2006; Pickens, 1994; Spelke & Cortelyou, 1981).']
['What are phonemes?', 'You may recall that each language has its own set of phonemes that are used to generate morphemes, words, and so on.']

['How does a baby perceive different phonemes?', 'Babies can discriminate among the sounds that make up a language (for example, they can tell the difference between the “s” in vision and the “ss” in fission); early on, they can differentiate between the sounds of all human languages, even those that do not occur in the languages that are used in their environments.']

['Does this always happen?', 'However, by the time that they are about 1 year old, they can only discriminate among those phonemes that are used in the language or languages in their environments (Jensen, 2011; Werker & Lalonde, 1988; Werker & Tees, 1984).']
['What is this?', 'After the first few months of life, babies enter what is known as the babbling stage, during which time they tend to produce single syllables that are repeated over and over.']
['How does language develop?', 'As time passes, more variations appear in the syllables that they produce.']

['Are they trying to communicate?', 'During this time, it is unlikely that the babies are trying to communicate; they are just as likely to babble when they are alone as when they are with their caregivers (Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['Why is that?', 'Interestingly, babies who are raised in environments in which sign language is used will also begin to show babbling in the gestures of their hands during this stage (Petitto, Holowka, Sergio, Levy, & Ostry, 2004).']

['What is the first stage of language development?', 'Generally, a child’s first word is uttered sometime between the ages of 1 year to 18 months, and for the next few months, the child will remain in the “one word” stage of language development.']
['How is the one word stage different from other stages?', 'During this time, children know a number of words, but they only produce one-word utterances.']
['What do children have to say at this time?', 'The child’s early vocabulary is limited to familiar objects or events, often nouns.']
['How does the one word stage impact how a child communicates?', 'Although children in this stage only make one-word utterances, these words often carry larger meaning (Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']
['What does this mean?', 'So, for example, a child saying “cookie” could be identifying a cookie or asking for a cookie.']
['what was the first article in the section?', 'As a child’s lexicon grows, they begin to utter simple sentences and to acquire new vocabulary at a very rapid pace.']
['What happens next?', 'In addition, children begin to demonstrate a clear understanding of the specific rules that apply to their language(s).']
['What is the proof of this?', 'Even the mistakes that children sometimes make provide evidence of just how much they understand about those rules.']
['What kinds of mistakes do they make?', 'This is sometimes seen in the form of overgeneralization.']
['What is overgeneralization?', 'In this context, overgeneralization refers to an extension of a language rule to an exception to the rule.']
['What is an example of this?', 'For example, in English, it is usually the case that an “s” is added to the end of a word to indicate plurality.']
['What was the exception?', 'For example, we speak of one dog versus two dogs.']

['How did they interpret this?', 'Young children will overgeneralize this rule to cases that are exceptions to the “add an s to the end of the word” rule and say things like “those two gooses” or “three mouses.”']
['What did the children learn?', 'Clearly, the rules of the language are understood, even if the exceptions to the rules are still being learned (Moskowitz, 1978).']
['What is language?', 'When we speak one language, we agree that words are representations of ideas, people, places, and events.']
['Why do people change their language?', 'The given language that children learn is connected to their culture and surroundings.']
['How is language related to thought?', 'Psychologists have long investigated the question of whether language shapes thoughts and actions, or whether our thoughts and beliefs shape our language.']
['Who started this research?', 'Two researchers, Edward Sapir and Benjamin Lee Whorf, began this investigation in the 1940s.']

['What were their main findings?', 'They wanted to understand how the language habits of a community encourage members of that community to interpret language in a particular manner (Sapir, 1941/1964).']
['Why did they focus on language habits?', 'Sapir and Whorf proposed that language determines thought.']
['What are some examples of language being used differently?', 'For example, in some languages there are many different words for love.']
['What is different about English?', 'However, in English we use the word love for all types of love.']

['What do other researchers think?', 'Researchers have since identified this view as too absolute, pointing out a lack of empiricism behind what Sapir and Whorf proposed (Abler, 2013; Boroditsky, 2011; van Troyer, 1994).']
['What is current research?', 'Today, psychologists continue to study and debate the relationship between language and thought.']
['What are some significant aspects of this topic?', 'Language may indeed influence the way that we think, an idea known as linguistic determinism.']
['What is this centered on?', 'One recent demonstration of this phenomenon involved differences in the way that English and Mandarin Chinese speakers talk and think about time.']

['What do they say about time?', 'English speakers tend to talk about time using terms that describe changes along a horizontal dimension, for example, saying something like “I’m running behind schedule” or “Don’t get ahead of yourself.”']
['What does this mean?', 'While Mandarin Chinese speakers also describe time in horizontal terms, it is not uncommon to also use terms associated with a vertical arrangement.']
['What does this mean?', 'For example, the past might be described as being “up” and the future as being “down.”']

['Why does this happen?', 'It turns out that these differences in language translate into differences in performance on cognitive tests designed to measure how quickly an individual can recognize temporal relationships.']

['How do they recognize time relationships?', 'Specifically, when given a series of tasks with vertical priming, Mandarin Chinese speakers were faster at recognizing temporal relationships between months.']
['Does this have any relevance?', 'Indeed, Boroditsky (2001) sees these results as suggesting that “habits in language encourage habits in thought” (p. 12).']

['What are some examples of language and thought?', 'One group of researchers who wanted to investigate how language influences thought compared how English speakers and the Dani people of Papua New Guinea think and speak about color.']
['What did the Dani people think about color?', 'The Dani have two words for color: one word for light and one word for dark.']
['What about English speakers?', 'In contrast, the English language has 11 color words.']
['What are the conclusions of this research?', 'Researchers hypothesized that the number of color terms could limit the ways that the Dani people conceptualized color.']

['Did they find that this was true?', 'However, the Dani were able to distinguish colors with the same ability as English speakers, despite having fewer words at their disposal (Berlin & Kay, 1969).']

['What are some other examples of language and thought?', 'A recent review of research aimed at determining how language might affect something like color perception suggests that language can influence perceptual phenomena, especially in the left hemisphere of the brain.']
['Is there anything else you can tell me about this?', 'You may recall from earlier chapters that the left hemisphere is associated with language for most people.']

['Is there anything else significant about the left hemisphere?', 'However, the right (less linguistic hemisphere) of the brain is less affected by linguistic influences on perception (Regier & Kay, 2009)']
['What are 7-3?', 'People face problems every day—usually, multiple problems throughout the day.']
['How do they solve those problems?', 'Sometimes these problems are straightforward:']
['What are some examples of straightforward problems?', 'To double a recipe for pizza dough, for example, all that is required is that each ingredient in the recipe be doubled.']
['Why do you think this is a straightforward problem?', 'Sometimes, however, the problems we encounter are more complex.']
['What are some examples of complex problems?', 'For example, say you have a work deadline, and you must mail a printed copy of a report to your supervisor by the end of the business day.']
['Why is this a complex problem?', 'The report is time-sensitive and must be sent overnight.']
['Why is that so difficult to do?', 'You finished the report last night, but your printer will not work today.']
['How do you solve the problem?', 'First, you need to identify the problem and then apply a strategy for solving the problem.']
['How does one approach solving problems?', 'Before finding a solution to the problem, the problem must first be clearly identified.']
['Does the problem have to be numerical?', 'After that, one of many problem solving strategies can be applied, hopefully resulting in a solution.']
['what are problem-solving strategies?', 'A problem-solving strategy is a plan of action used to find a solution.']
['what are different actions?', 'Different strategies have different action plans associated with them.']
['What are some examples?', 'For example, a well-known strategy is trial and error.']
['what does this mean?', 'The old adage, “If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again” describes trial and error.']
['What are some other examples?', 'In terms of your broken printer, you could try checking the ink levels, and if that doesn’t work, you could check to make sure the paper tray isn’t jammed.']
['what else can you try?', 'Or maybe the printer isn’t actually connected to your laptop.']
['do you have any more?', 'When using trial and error, you would continue to try different solutions until you solved your problem.']
['how is it used?', 'Although trial and error is not typically one of the most time-efficient strategies, it is a commonly used one.']
['what is a strategy?', 'Another type of strategy is an algorithm.']
['what is an algorithm?', 'An algorithm is a problem-solving formula that provides you with step-by-step instructions used to achieve a desired outcome (Kahneman, 2011).']
['are there any more specific examples of algorithms?', 'You can think of an algorithm as a recipe with highly detailed instructions that produce the same result every time they are performed.']
['can you tell me any example of an algorithm?', 'Algorithms are used frequently in our everyday lives, especially in computer science.']
['what else can you tell me about algorithms?', 'When you run a search on the Internet, search engines like Google use algorithms to decide which entries will appear first in your list of results.']
['what other algorithms are used in our everyday lives?', 'Facebook also uses algorithms to decide which posts to display on your newsfeed.']
['what is a heuristic?', 'A heuristic is another type of problem solving strategy.']

['can an algorithm be applied to a problem?', 'While an algorithm must be followed exactly to produce a correct result, a heuristic is a general problem-solving framework (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974).']
['What are some examples of strategies?', 'You can think of these as mental shortcuts that are used to solve problems.']
['What is an example of a rule of thumb?', 'A “rule of thumb” is an example of a heuristic.']

['What is one problem with the rule of thumb?', 'Such a rule saves the person time and energy when making a decision, but despite its time-saving characteristics, it is not always the best method for making a rational decision.']

['What else can you tell me about heuristics?', 'Different types of heuristics are used in different types of situations, but the impulse to use a heuristic occurs when one of five conditions is met (Pratkanis, 1989):']
['What is a problem-solving strategy?', 'When the time to make a decision is limited']
['When the information to make a decision is limited', 'When there is access to very little information to use in making the decision']
['When there is no way to get more information about the problem and its underlying variables', 'When an appropriate heuristic happens to come to mind in the same moment']
['What is one strategy for problem-solving?', 'Working backwards is a useful heuristic in which you begin solving the problem by focusing on the end result.']
['What is the result of working backwards?', 'Consider this example:']
['What happened in this example?', 'You live in Washington, D.C. and have been invited to a wedding at 4 PM on Saturday in Philadelphia.']
['What would you need to do in order to get there?', 'Knowing that Interstate 95 tends to back up any day of the week, you need to plan your route and time your departure accordingly.']
['How else do you use the backwards method?', 'You use the working backwards heuristic to plan the events of your day on a regular basis, probably without even thinking about it.']
['What is a useful heuristic?', 'Another useful heuristic is the practice of accomplishing a large goal or task by breaking it into a series of smaller steps.']
['Why is that?', 'Students often use this common method to complete a large research project or long essay for school.']

['What are the smaller steps for that project?', 'For example, students typically brainstorm, develop a thesis or main topic, research the chosen topic, organize their information into an outline, write a rough draft, revise and edit the rough draft, develop a final draft, organize the references list, and proofread their work before turning in the project.']
['What is the purpose of breaking it down?', 'The large task becomes less overwhelming when it is broken down into a series of small steps.']
["What's the importance of problem solving?", 'Not all problems are successfully solved, however.']
["What's one example you can think of of a problem that is a challenge?", 'Imagine a person in a room that has four doorways.']
['Why does the person need to figure out how to get into the room?', 'One doorway that has always been open in the past is now locked.']

['How does the person feel about the situation?', 'The person, accustomed to exiting the room by that particular doorway, keeps trying to get out through the same doorway even though the other three doorways are open.']
['What happened after the person tried to use the other three doorways?', 'The person is stuck—but they just need to go to another doorway, instead of trying to get out through the locked doorway.']
['What is the Mental Set?', 'A mental set is where you persist in approaching a problem in a way that has worked in the past but is clearly not working now.']
['What is functional fixedness?', 'Functional fixedness is a type of mental set where you cannot perceive an object being used for something other than what it was designed for.']
['Who were Duncker and Functional Fixedness?', 'Duncker (1945) conducted foundational research on functional fixedness.']
['Did he conduct an experiment?', 'He created an experiment in which participants were given a candle, a book of matches, and a box of thumbtacks.']
['How did they have to use the thumbtacks?', 'They were instructed to use those items to attach the candle to the wall so that it did not drip wax onto the table below.']
['What happened after the experiment?', 'Participants had to use functional fixedness to overcome the problem.']

['What other examples were used?', 'During the Apollo 13 mission to the moon, NASA engineers at Mission Control had to overcome functional fixedness to save the lives of the astronauts aboard the spacecraft.']
['What happened to the spacecraft during the Apollo 13 mission?', 'An explosion in a module of the spacecraft damaged multiple systems.']
['Why were the astronauts in danger?', 'The astronauts were in danger of being poisoned by rising levels of carbon dioxide because of problems with the carbon dioxide filters.']
['What was the solution?', 'The engineers found a way for the astronauts to use spare plastic bags, tape, and air hoses to create a makeshift air filter, which saved the lives of the astronauts.']
['What is the function of functional fixity?', 'Researchers have investigated whether functional fixedness is affected by culture.']
['What was the study?', 'In one experiment, individuals from the Shuar group in Ecuador were asked to use an object for a purpose other than that for which the object was originally intended.']

['What other objects were utilised for this purpose?', 'For example, the participants were told a story about a bear and a rabbit that were separated by a river and asked to select among various objects, including a spoon, a cup, erasers, and so on, to help the animals.']

['Was the spoon the only object long enough to span the river?', 'The spoon was the only object long enough to span the imaginary river, but if the spoon was presented in a way that reflected its normal usage, it took participants longer to choose the spoon to solve the problem.']
['What is the full name of the researchers who conducted this study?', '(German & Barrett, 2005).']

['What was the purpose of the study?', 'The researchers wanted to know if exposure to highly specialized tools, as occurs with individuals in industrialized nations, affects their ability to transcend functional fixedness.']
['What was the final result?', 'It was determined that functional fixedness is experienced in both industrialized and nonindustrialized cultures (German & Barrett, 2005).']
['How do you make good decisions?', 'In order to make good decisions, we use our knowledge and our reasoning.']
['How can this knowledge and reasoning be wrong?', 'Often, this knowledge and reasoning is sound and solid.']
['Does this knowledge have flaws?', 'Sometimes, however, we are swayed by biases or by others manipulating a situation.']
['What can be a problem?', 'For example, let’s say you and three friends wanted to rent a house and had a combined target budget of $1,600.']
['Why would this be a problem?', 'The realtor shows you only very run-down houses for $1,600 and then shows you a very nice house for $2,000.']
['What can you do to counter this bias?', 'The realtor may be challenging your anchoring bias.']
['What is anchoring bias?', 'An anchoring bias occurs when you focus on one piece of information when making a decision or solving a problem.']

['What happens when you focus on one piece of information?', 'In this case, you’re so focused on the amount of money you are willing to spend that you may not recognize what kinds of houses are available at that price point.']
['What is the confirmation bias?', 'The confirmation bias is the tendency to focus on information that confirms your existing beliefs.']

['How does it affect problem solving?', 'For example, if you think that your professor is not very nice, you notice all of the instances of rude behavior exhibited by the professor while ignoring the countless pleasant interactions he is involved in on a daily basis.']
['What is hindsight bias?', 'Hindsight bias leads you to believe that the event you just experienced was predictable, even though it really wasn’t.']
['What does it lead you to believe?', 'In other words, you knew all along that things would turn out the way they did.']

['What is representative bias?', 'Representative bias describes a faulty way of thinking, in which you unintentionally stereotype someone or something; for example, you may assume that your professors spend their free time reading books and engaging in intellectual conversation, because the idea of them spending their time playing volleyball or visiting an amusement park does not fit in with your stereotypes of professors.']

["What's the availability heuristic?", 'Finally, the availability heuristic is a heuristic in which you make a decision based on an example, information, or recent experience that is that readily available to you, even though it may not be the best example to inform your decision.']
['What does bias do?', 'Biases tend to “preserve that which is already established—to maintain our preexisting knowledge, beliefs, attitudes, and hypotheses” (Aronson, 1995; Kahneman, 2011).']
['What is in the table?', 'These biases are summarized in Table 7.3.']
['How many pitfalls do you need?', 'You need nine.']
['What are they?', 'Here are the answers.']
['What type of example would you use?', 'A four-and-a-half-year-old boy sits at the kitchen table with his father, who is reading a new story aloud to him.']
['Is the boy interested in what he is reading?', 'He turns the page to continue reading, but before he can begin, the boy says, “Wait, Daddy!”']
['What does the father do?', 'He points to the words on the new page and reads aloud, “Go, Pig! Go!”']
['Does the father go on reading?', 'The father stops and looks at his son.']
['How does the boy react?', '“Can you read that?” he asks.']
['Do they continue reading together?', '“Yes, Daddy!”']
['Do they read anything else?', 'And he points to the words and reads again, “Go, Pig! Go!”']

['How does the study of letters connect with what is known as cognitive activity?', 'This father was not actively teaching his son to read, even though the child constantly asked questions about letters, words, and symbols that they saw everywhere: in the car, in the store, on the television.']
['What happened next in this experiment?', 'The dad wondered about what else his son might understand and decided to try an experiment.']
['What did he do?', 'Grabbing a sheet of blank paper, he wrote several simple words in a list: mom, dad, dog, bird, bed, truck, car, tree.']
['How did he test his son?', 'He put the list down in front of the boy and asked him to read the words.']
['What did he read?', '“Dad, dog, bird, bed, truck, car, tree,” he read, slowing down to carefully pronounce bird and truck.']
['What did the boy do?', 'Then, “Did I do it, Daddy?” “You sure did!']
['How did his father react?', 'That is very good.”']

['How did his parents react to this test?', 'The father gave his little boy a warm hug and continued reading the story about the pig, all the while wondering if his son’s abilities were an indication of exceptional intelligence or simply a normal pattern of linguistic development.']
['Why did he do this experiment?', 'Like the father in this example, psychologists have wondered what constitutes intelligence and how it can be measured.']
["What's the most interesting thing in this article?", 'The way that researchers have defined the concept of intelligence has been modified many times since the birth of psychology.']

['Did this lead to new classification systems?', 'British psychologist Charles Spearman believed intelligence consisted of one general factor, called g, which could be measured and compared among individuals.']
['How did he go about classifying people?', 'Spearman focused on the commonalities among various intellectual abilities and de-emphasized what made each unique.']

['Did others also believe that one factor could be classified?', 'Long before modern psychology developed, however, ancient philosophers, such as Aristotle, held a similar view (Cianciolo & Sternberg, 2004).']
['what is the most common view on intelligence?', 'Others psychologists believe that instead of a single factor, intelligence is a collection of distinct abilities.']

['what are the two theories of intelligence?', 'In the 1940s, Raymond Cattell proposed a theory of intelligence that divided general intelligence into two components: crystallized intelligence and fluid intelligence (Cattell, 1963).']
['what is crystallized intelligence?', 'Crystallized intelligence is characterized as acquired knowledge and the ability to retrieve it.']
['how is this used?', 'When you learn, remember, and recall information, you are using crystallized intelligence.']

['what type of information does it help you remember?', 'You use crystallized intelligence all the time in your coursework by demonstrating that you have mastered the information covered in the course.']
['what is fluid intelligence?', 'Fluid intelligence encompasses the ability to see complex relationships and solve problems.']
['how is this used?', 'Navigating your way home after being detoured onto an unfamiliar route because of road construction would draw upon your fluid intelligence.']

['what are some of the differences between these two?', 'Fluid intelligence helps you tackle complex, abstract challenges in your daily life, whereas crystallized intelligence helps you overcome concrete, straightforward problems (Cattell, 1963).']
['How is intelligence defined?', 'Other theorists and psychologists believe that intelligence should be defined in more practical terms.']
['Does anyone care how I define intelligence?', 'Think about this for a moment.']
['what are these parts?', 'Practical intelligence, as proposed by Sternberg, is sometimes compared to “street smarts.”']
['what is street smarts?', 'Being practical means you find solutions that work in your everyday life by applying knowledge based on your experiences.']

['how is it measured?', 'This type of intelligence appears to be separate from traditional understanding of IQ; individuals who score high in practical intelligence may or may not have comparable scores in creative and analytical intelligence (Sternberg, 1988).']
['What is analytical intelligence?', 'Analytical intelligence is closely aligned with academic problem solving and computations.']
['What does analytical intelligence mean?', 'Sternberg says that analytical intelligence is demonstrated by an ability to analyze, evaluate, judge, compare, and contrast.']

['What can you do with analytical intelligence?', 'When reading a classic novel for literature class, for example, it is usually necessary to compare the motives of the main characters of the book or analyze the historical context of the story.']
['What other examples of analytical intelligence are there?', 'In a science course such as anatomy, you must study the processes by which the body uses various minerals in different human systems.']
['What do you think?', 'In developing an understanding of this topic, you are using analytical intelligence.']

['What do you think about the examples you gave of analytical intelligence?', 'When solving a challenging math problem, you would apply analytical intelligence to analyze different aspects of the problem and then solve it section by section.']
['What is creative intelligence?', 'Creative intelligence is marked by inventing or imagining a solution to a problem or situation.']
['How is it defined?', 'Creativity in this realm can include finding a novel solution to an unexpected problem or producing a beautiful work of art or a well-developed short story.']
['What type of problem?', 'Imagine for a moment that you are camping in the woods with some friends and realize that you’ve forgotten your camp coffee pot.']
['Why not?', 'The person in your group who figures out a way to successfully brew coffee for everyone would be credited as having higher creative intelligence.']
['What is the next section called?', 'Multiple Intelligences']
['What did Howard Gardner do with intelligence?', 'Theory was developed by Howard Gardner, a Harvard psychologist and former student of Erik Erikson.']
['How many intelligences are there?', 'In Gardner’s theory, each person possesses at least eight intelligences.']

['What are the names of these intelligences?', 'The eight intelligences are linguistic intelligence, logical-mathematical intelligence, musical intelligence, bodily kinesthetic intelligence, spatial intelligence, interpersonal intelligence, intrapersonal intelligence, and naturalistic intelligence.']
["Were Gardner's theories of intelligence accurate?", 'Among cognitive psychologists, Gardner’s theory has been heavily criticized for lacking empirical evidence.']

["What is the most important thing that you learned about Howard Gardner's theories?", 'However, educators continue to study and use Gardner’s theory, with some colleges even discussing how they integrate Gardner’s theory into their classrooms.']

['What is the most important thing that you learned?', 'Gottfredson describes one possible reason for the continued use of Gardner’s theory: “ . . . that there are multiple independent intelligences, suggesting that everyone can be smart in some way.']
['What was the most important thing that you learned?', 'This is, understandably, a very attractive idea in democratic societies” (2004).']
['What is the next section?', 'Gardner’s inter- and intrapersonal intelligences are often combined into a single type: emotional intelligence.']

['What are the components of emotional intelligence?', 'Emotional intelligence encompasses the ability to understand the emotions of yourself and others, show empathy, understand social relationships and cues, and regulate your own emotions and respond in culturally appropriate ways (Parker, Saklofske, & Stough, 2009).']
['What are some ways in which people show emotions?', 'People with high emotional intelligence typically have well-developed social skills.']

['What can you tell me about emotional intelligence?', 'Some researchers, including Daniel Goleman, the author of Emotional Intelligence: Why It Can Matter More than IQ, argue that emotional intelligence is a better predictor of success than traditional intelligence (Goleman, 1995).']

['Are there any other examples?', 'However, emotional intelligence has been widely debated, with researchers pointing out inconsistencies in how it is defined and described, as well as questioning results of studies on a subject that is difficult to measure and study empirically (Locke, 2005; Mayer, Salovey, & Caruso, 2004)']

['What is the most comprehensive theory of intelligence?', 'The most comprehensive theory of intelligence to date is the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) theory of cognitive abilities (Schneider & McGrew, 2018).']

['How does the Cattell-Horn-Carroll theory describe intelligence?', 'In this theory, abilities are related and arranged in a hierarchy with general abilities at the top, broad abilities in the middle, and narrow (specific) abilities at the bottom.']
['What is the definition of a narrow ability?', 'The narrow abilities are the only ones that can be directly measured; however, they are integrated within the other abilities.']
['What is a general level?', 'At the general level is general intelligence.']
['What are some broad abilities?', 'Next, the broad level consists of general abilities such as fluid reasoning, short-term memory, and processing speed.']
['What is a narrow level?', 'Finally, as the hierarchy continues, the narrow level includes specific forms of cognitive abilities.']
['What is a broad ability?', 'For example, short-term memory would further break down into memory span and working memory capacity.']
['What else does he have to say about intelligence?', 'Intelligence can also have different meanings and values in different cultures.']

['Why do different cultures have different meanings?', 'If you live on a small island, where most people get their food by fishing from boats, it would be important to know how to fish and how to repair a boat.']
['Can you tell me more about this?', 'If you were an exceptional angler, your peers would probably consider you intelligent.']
['Did you have to learn a language?', 'If you were also skilled at repairing boats, your intelligence might be known across the whole island.']
['How would this help you in your work?', 'Think about your own family’s culture.']
['What might be important about that culture?', 'In Irish families, hospitality and telling an entertaining story are marks of the culture.']
['What else did you know about this?', 'If you are a skilled storyteller, other members of Irish culture are likely to consider you intelligent.']
['What is a factor of collective intelligence?', 'Some cultures place a high value on working together as a collective.']
['What is this referred to as?', 'In these cultures, the importance of the group supersedes the importance of individual achievement.']

['What is cultural competence?', 'When you visit such a culture, how well you relate to the values of that culture exemplifies your cultural intelligence, sometimes referred to as cultural competence.']
['What is creativity?', 'Creativity is the ability to generate, create, or discover new ideas, solutions, and possibilities.']

['What are some qualities of people with creativity?', 'Very creative people often have intense knowledge about something, work on it for years, look at novel solutions, seek out the advice and help of other experts, and take risks.']

['What kind of work does this type of work involve?', 'Although creativity is often associated with the arts, it is actually a vital form of intelligence that drives people in many disciplines to discover something new.']

['Can you give me some examples of how creativity is involved with anything?', 'Creativity can be found in every area of life, from the way you decorate your residence to a new way of understanding how a cell works.']
['What are the characteristics of creative people?', 'Creativity is often connected to a person’s ability to engage in divergent thinking.']
['How does this help with creativity?', 'Divergent thinking can be described as thinking “outside the box;” it allows an individual to arrive at unique, multiple solutions to a given problem.']

['What is the opposite of divergent thinking?', 'In contrast, convergent thinking describes the ability to provide a correct or well-established answer or solution to a problem (Cropley, 2006; Gilford, 1967)']
['What is IQ?', 'IQ stands for intelligence quotient and describes a score earned on a test designed to measure intelligence.']
['What else is significant about this section?', 'You’ve already learned that there are many ways psychologists describe intelligence (or more aptly, intelligences).']
['How do psychologists test intelligence?', 'Similarly, IQ tests—the tools designed to measure intelligence—have been the subject of debate throughout their development and use.']

['What can you tell me about the benefits to intelligence testing?', 'While there are certainly many benefits to intelligence testing, it is important to also note the limitations and controversies surrounding these tests.']
['What controversies surround intelligence testing?', 'For example, IQ tests have sometimes been used as arguments in support of insidious purposes, such as the eugenics movement (Severson, 2011).']

['What is some other criticism?', 'The infamous Supreme Court Case, Buck v. Bell, legalized the forced sterilization of some people deemed “feeble-minded” through this type of testing, resulting in about 65,000 sterilizations (Buck v. Bell, 274 U.S. 200; Ko, 2016).']

['What else can you tell me about intelligence testing?', 'Today, only professionals trained in psychology can administer IQ tests, and the purchase of most tests requires an advanced degree in psychology.']
['Does anyone else administer intelligence tests?', 'Other professionals in the field, such as social workers and psychiatrists, cannot administer IQ tests.']
['What is the next section that will be examined?', 'In this section, we will explore what intelligence tests measure, how they are scored, and how they were developed.']
['What is a good way to measure intelligence?', 'It seems that the human understanding of intelligence is somewhat limited when we focus on traditional or academic-type intelligence.']
['What are the main factors that determine intelligence?', 'In the following paragraphs, we will explore how intelligence tests were developed and the history of their use.']
['What is an IQ test?', 'The IQ test has been synonymous with intelligence for over a century.']
["What happened in the 1800's?", 'In the late 1800s, Sir Francis Galton developed the first broad test of intelligence (Flanagan & Kaufman, 2004).']
['What else did he do?', 'Although he was not a psychologist, his contributions to the concepts of intelligence testing are still felt today (Gordon, 1995).']

['Who did he work with?', 'Reliable intelligence testing (you may recall from earlier chapters that reliability refers to a test’s ability to produce consistent results) began in earnest during the early 1900s with a researcher named Alfred Binet.']

['Why did Binet start testing?', 'Binet was asked by the French government to develop an intelligence test to use on children to determine which ones might have difficulty in school; it included many verbally based tasks.']
['What was the response?', 'American researchers soon realized the value of such testing.']

['What else did Binet do?', 'Louis Terman, a Stanford professor, modified Binet’s work by standardizing the administration of the test and tested thousands of different-aged children to establish an average score for each age.']

['What were the results of the tests?', 'As a result, the test was normed and standardized, which means that the test was administered consistently to a large enough representative sample of the population that the range of scores resulted in a bell curve (bell curves will be discussed later).']
['What is standardization?', 'Standardization means that the manner of administration, scoring, and interpretation of results is consistent.']
['What is norming?', 'Norming involves giving a test to a large population so data can be collected comparing groups, such as age groups.']
['How does it work?', 'The resulting data provide norms, or referential scores, by which to interpret future scores.']
['What does a norm mean?', 'Norms are not expectations of what a given group should know but a demonstration of what that group does know.']
['Why do they need to know what people know?', 'Norming and standardizing the test ensures that new scores are reliable.']
['Did they have any results after the tests?', 'This new version of the test was called the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale (Terman, 1916).']
['Was the test successful?', 'Remarkably, an updated version of this test is still widely used today.']
['What happened in 1939?', 'In 1939, David Wechsler, a psychologist who spent part of his career working with World War I veterans, developed a new IQ test in the United States.']
['How did he develop the new test?', 'Wechsler combined several subtests from other intelligence tests used between 1880 and World War I.']

['What were these subtests?', 'These subtests tapped into a variety of verbal and nonverbal skills, because Wechsler believed that intelligence encompassed “the global capacity of a person to act purposefully, to think rationally, and to deal effectively with his environment” (Wechsler, 1958, p. 7).']
['What was the name of his test?', 'He named the test the Wechsler-Bellevue Intelligence Scale (Wechsler, 1981).']
['What else did he accomplish with this test?', 'This combination of subtests became one of the most extensively used intelligence tests in the history of psychology.']

['Who used his test?', 'Although its name was later changed to the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS) and has been revised several times, the aims of the test remain virtually unchanged since its inception (Boake, 2002).']

['What other tests did he develop?', 'Today, there are three intelligence tests credited to Wechsler, the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale-fourth edition (WAIS-IV), the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC-V), and the Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence—IV (WPPSI-IV) (Wechsler, 2012).']

['What can you tell me about the WISC-V?', 'These tests are used widely in schools and communities throughout the United States, and they are periodically normed and standardized as a means of recalibration.']

['Is there anything else important about this test?', 'As a part of the recalibration process, the WISC-V was given to thousands of children across the country, and children taking the test today are compared with their same-age peers.']
['What are the subtests?', 'The WISC-V is composed of 14 subtests, which comprise five indices, which then render an IQ score.']
['What are the five indices?', 'The five indices are Verbal Comprehension, Visual Spatial, Fluid Reasoning, Working Memory, and Processing Speed.']
['What does the test reveal?', 'When the test is complete, individuals receive a score for each of the five indices and a Full Scale IQ score.']

['What is the scoring method?', 'The method of scoring reflects the understanding that intelligence is comprised of multiple abilities in several cognitive realms and focuses on the mental processes that the child used to arrive at their answers to each test item.']
['What is Flynn?', 'Interestingly, the periodic recalibrations have led to an interesting observation known as the Flynn effect.']

['What is Flynn effect?', 'Named after James Flynn, who was among the first to describe this trend, the Flynn effect refers to the observation that each generation has a significantly higher IQ than the last.']

['Is this evidence that younger generations are more intelligent?', 'Flynn himself argues, however, that increased IQ scores do not necessarily mean that younger generations are more intelligent per se (Flynn, Shaughnessy, & Fulgham, 2012).']
['What was the most important point you took from this discussion?', 'Ultimately, we are still left with the question of how valid intelligence tests are.']

['How are the IQ tests valid?', 'Certainly, the most modern versions of these tests tap into more than verbal competencies, yet the specific skills that should be assessed in IQ testing, the degree to which any test can truly measure an individual’s intelligence, and the use of the results of IQ tests are still issues of debate (Gresham & Witt, 1997; Flynn, Shaughnessy, & Fulgham, 2012; Richardson, 2002; Schlinger, 2003).']
['What is it?', 'The results of intelligence tests follow the bell curve, a graph in the general shape of a bell.']
['What is it used for?', 'When the bell curve is used in psychological testing, the graph demonstrates a normal distribution of a trait, in this case, intelligence, in the human population.']
['What else is it used for?', 'Many human traits naturally follow the bell curve.']

['What can you tell me about this?', 'For example, if you lined up all your female schoolmates according to height, it is likely that a large cluster of them would be the average height for an American woman: 5’4”–5’6”.']
['What would happen to that cluster?', 'This cluster would fall in the center of the bell curve, representing the average height for American women.']
['What happens next?', 'There would be fewer women who stand closer to 4’11”.']
['What happens next?', 'The same would be true for women of above-average height: those who stand closer to 5’11”.']
['How can you find one?', 'The trick to finding a bell curve in nature is to use a large sample size.']
['Why is this?', 'Without a large sample size, it is less likely that the bell curve will represent the wider population.']
['What is a representative sample?', 'A representative sample is a subset of the population that accurately represents the general population.']
['What does it do?', 'If, for example, you measured the height of the women in your classroom only, you might not actually have a representative sample.']
['What happened if you did?', 'Perhaps the women’s basketball team wanted to take this course together, and they are all in your class.']
['Why not?', 'Because basketball players tend to be taller than average, the women in your class may not be a good representative sample of the population of American women.']
['What else?', 'But if your sample included all the women at your school, it is likely that their heights would form a natural bell curve.']
['What are the important points in this article?', 'The same principles apply to intelligence tests scores.']
['What does an intelligence test score consist of?', 'Individuals earn a score called an intelligence quotient (IQ).']
['What are some other interesting aspects about this article?', 'Over the years, different types of IQ tests have evolved, but the way scores are interpreted remains the same.']
['What are the mean scores?', 'On most IQ tests, the average (or mean) IQ score is 100.']
['What are standard deviations?', 'Standard deviations describe how data are dispersed in a population and give context to large data sets.']
['Why are standard deviations important?', 'The bell curve uses the standard deviation to show how all scores are dispersed from the average score.']
['How are the standard deviations calculated?', 'In modern IQ testing, one standard deviation is 15 points.']
['Is there anything else of note?', 'So a score of 85 would be described as “one standard deviation below the mean.”']

["Why would the reader say it's average?", 'Any IQ score that falls within one standard deviation above and below the mean (between 85 and 115) is considered average, and 68% of the population has IQ scores in this range.']
['What else is important in this article?', 'An IQ score of 130 or above is considered a superior level.']
['What percentage of the population has an IQ below 70?', 'Only 2.2% of the population has an IQ score below 70 (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013).']

['What else can you tell me about the Bell Curve?', 'If a person earns a score approximately two standard deviations below the mean on an intelligence test, (about 70 on a test with a mean of 100), has major deficits in adaptive functioning, and these cognitive and adaptive deficits were present before the age of 18, they could be diagnosed as having an intellectual disability (ID).']
['What is intellectual disability?', 'Formerly known as mental retardation, the accepted term now is intellectual disability, and it has four subtypes: mild, moderate, severe, and profound.']
['Are there any criteria for ID?', 'The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Psychological Disorders lists criteria for each subgroup (APA, 2013).']
["What's the purpose of the Bell Curve?", 'On the other end of the intelligence spectrum are those individuals whose IQs fall into the highest ranges.']
['How many people fall into the top ranges?', 'Consistent with the bell curve, about 2% of the population falls into this category.']

['What are the top ranges?', 'People are considered to have a higher aptitude for learning (and may be classified as "gifted" within educational systems) if they have an IQ score of 130 or higher, or superior intelligence in a particular area.']
['What else are they considered to have?', 'Long ago, popular belief suggested that people of high intelligence were maladjusted.']
['How were they maladjusted?', 'This idea was disproven through a groundbreaking study of these children.']
['Who did the study?', 'In 1921, Lewis Terman began a longitudinal study of over 1500 children with IQs over 135 (Terman, 1925).']
['How did the study go?', 'His findings showed that these children became well-educated, successful adults who were, in fact, well-adjusted (Terman & Oden, 1947).']

["Did Terman's study show anything else?", 'Additionally, Terman’s study showed that the subjects were above average in physical build and attractiveness, dispelling an earlier popular notion that highly intelligent people were “weaklings.”']
['What else did they find out about the study?', 'Some people with very high IQs elect to join Mensa, an organization dedicated to identifying, researching, and fostering intelligence.']
['Are there any requirements for membership?', 'Members must have an IQ score in the top 2% of the population, and they may be required to pass other exams in their application to join the group.']
['What is the most significant aspect of this information?', 'The value of IQ testing is most evident in educational or clinical settings.']

['What can the test be used for?', 'Children who seem to be experiencing learning difficulties or severe behavioral problems can be tested to ascertain whether the child’s difficulties can be partly attributed to an IQ score that is significantly different from the mean for their age group.']

['What can you tell me about the other advantages of IQ testing?', 'Without IQ testing—or another measure of intelligence—children and adults needing extra support might not be identified effectively.']

['What else is significant about the information?', 'In addition, IQ testing is used in courts to determine whether a defendant has special or extenuating circumstances that preclude them from participating in some way in a trial.']
['Are there any other uses of IQ testing?', 'People also use IQ testing results to seek disability benefits from the Social Security Administration.']
["What's the main idea of this page?", 'The following case study demonstrates the usefulness and benefits of IQ testing.']
['What was the case study?', 'Candace, a 14-year-old girl experiencing problems at school in Connecticut, was referred for a court-ordered psychological evaluation.']
['Why did she need the evaluation?', 'She was in regular education classes in ninth grade and was failing every subject.']
['Did she have a history of failing?', 'Candace had never been a stellar student but had always been passed to the next grade.']
['What kind of problems was she having?', 'Frequently, she would curse at any of her teachers who called on her in class.']
['Did she have other problems?', 'She also got into fights with other students and occasionally shoplifted.']

['What was her response?', 'When she arrived for the evaluation, Candace immediately said that she hated everything about school, including the teachers, the rest of the staff, the building, and the homework.']
['Was she having social problems?', 'Her parents stated that they felt their daughter was picked on, because she was of a different ethnicity than the teachers and most of the other students.']
['What did she say?', 'When asked why she cursed at her teachers, Candace replied, “They only call on me when I don’t know the answer.']
["Why didn't she know the answer?", 'I don’t want to say, ‘I don’t know’ all of the time and look like an idiot in front of my friends.']
["Why didn't she want to look like an idiot?", 'The teachers embarrass me.”']
['What did the evaluation consist of?', 'She was given a battery of tests, including an IQ test.']
['What was the score on the IQ test?', 'Her score on the IQ test was 68.']
['What is the purpose of that article?', 'Despite evidence for the value of intelligence and related evaluations, the methods and interpretations of these tests are continually evolving.']
['What are some examples?', 'Researchers such as Jack A. Naglieri (2020) have developed or improved on testing programs in order to make them more accurate, equitable, and useful.']
['What is important about testing programs?', 'Beyond new testing instruments, some researchers demonstrate value in differentiating tests for different age groups, abilities, and contexts.']
['What is the story about?', 'A young girl, born of teenage parents, lives with her grandmother in rural Mississippi.']
['What does the story say about her?', 'She learns to read when she is just 3 years old.']
['What did she do for her family?', 'As she grows older, she longs to live with her mother, who now resides in Wisconsin.']
['What did she do there?', 'She moves there at the age of 6 years.']
['Did she ever go back to Mississippi?', 'At 9 years of age, she is raped.']
['What did her parents do about it?', 'During the next several years, several different male relatives repeatedly molest her.']
['What happened to her?', 'Her life unravels.']
['What else did she do?', 'She turns to drugs and sex to fill the deep, lonely void inside her.']
['What happened to her next?', 'Her mother then sends her to Nashville to live with her father, who imposes strict behavioral expectations upon her, and over time, her wild life settles once again.']

['What happened to her when she was in Nashville?', 'She begins to experience success in school, and at 19 years old, becomes the youngest and first African-American female news anchor (“Dates and Events,” n.d.).']
['What did she do at that position?', 'The woman—Oprah Winfrey—goes on to become a media giant known for both her intelligence and her empathy.']
['What does nature refer to?', 'Some researchers believe that intelligence is a trait inherited from a person’s parents.']
['Are there studies to prove this?', 'Scientists who research this topic typically use twin studies to determine the heritability of intelligence.']
['What are some examples of twin studies?', 'The Minnesota Study of Twins Reared Apart is one of the most well-known twin studies.']

['What were their findings?', 'In this investigation, researchers found that identical twins raised together and identical twins raised apart exhibit a higher correlation between their IQ scores than siblings or fraternal twins raised together (Bouchard, Lykken, McGue, Segal, & Tellegen, 1990).']
['What did this study show?', 'The findings from this study reveal a genetic component to intelligence.']
['What other studies show that?', 'At the same time, other psychologists believe that intelligence is shaped by a child’s developmental environment.']

['How?', 'If parents were to provide their children with intellectual stimuli from before they are born, it is likely that they would absorb the benefits of that stimulation, and it would be reflected in intelligence levels.']
['What are the two major ideas about why intelligence increases with age?', 'The reality is that aspects of each idea are probably correct.']

['What does the study prove?', 'In fact, one study suggests that although genetics seem to be in control of the level of intelligence, the environmental influences provide both stability and change to trigger manifestation of cognitive abilities (Bartels, Rietveld, Van Baal, & Boomsma, 2002).']

['Did the study prove that intelligence is influenced by nurture?', 'Certainly, there are behaviors that support the development of intelligence, but the genetic component of high intelligence should not be ignored.']
['Is there evidence of this?', 'As with all heritable traits, however, it is not always possible to isolate how and when high intelligence is passed on to the next generation.']
['What is the range of reaction?', 'Range of Reaction is the theory that each person responds to the environment in a unique way based on their genetic makeup.']

['What else do you want to know about the range of reaction?', 'According to this idea, your genetic potential is a fixed quantity, but whether you reach your full intellectual potential is dependent upon the environmental stimulation you experience, especially in childhood.']
['How does this work in practice?', 'Think about this scenario: A couple adopts a child who has average genetic intellectual potential.']
['Why would the child be able to rise above average?', 'They raise her in an extremely stimulating environment.']
['Is the stimulating environment healthy?', 'It is likely that the stimulating environment will improve her intellectual outcomes over the course of her life.']
['Do we know why?', 'If a child with an extremely strong genetic background is placed in an environment that does not stimulate him:']

['What is the result of a good learning environment?', 'Interestingly, according to a longitudinal study of highly gifted individuals, it was found that “the two extremes of optimal and pathological experience are both represented disproportionately in the backgrounds of creative individuals”; however, those who experienced supportive family environments were more likely to report being happy (Csikszentmihalyi & Csikszentmihalyi, 1993, p. 187).']
['What does this study cover?', 'Another challenge to determining origins of high intelligence is the confounding nature of our human social structures.']

['What other challenges are there?', 'It is troubling to note that some ethnic groups perform better on IQ tests than others—and it is likely that the results do not have much to do with the quality of each ethnic group’s intellect.']
['Are there any other examples?', 'The same is true for socioeconomic status.']
['Why is that?', 'Children who live in poverty experience more pervasive, daily stress than children who do not worry about the basic needs of safety, shelter, and food.']
['What else can stress do?', 'These worries can negatively affect how the brain functions and develops, causing a dip in IQ scores.']

['What else do they study?', 'Mark Kishiyama and his colleagues determined that children living in poverty demonstrated reduced prefrontal brain functioning comparable to children with damage to the lateral prefrontal cortex (Kishiyama, Boyce, Jimenez, Perry, & Knight, 2009).']

['What was this debate about?', 'The debate around the foundations and influences on intelligence exploded in 1969, when an educational psychologist named Arthur Jensen published the article “How Much Can We Boost I.Q. and Achievement” in the Harvard Educational Review.']
['What did he say?', 'Jensen had administered IQ tests to diverse groups of students, and his results led him to the conclusion that IQ is determined by genetics.']
['Did he say anything else?', 'He also posited that intelligence was made up of two types of abilities: Level I and Level II.']
['Did he explain the nature-nurture debate?', 'In his theory, Level I is responsible for rote memorization, whereas Level II is responsible for conceptual and analytical abilities.']
['What was he studying?', 'According to his findings, Level I remained consistent among the human race.']
['How did the study find this?', 'Level II, however, exhibited differences among ethnic groups (Modgil & Routledge, 1987).']
['Why did this happen?', 'Jensen’s most controversial conclusion was that Level II intelligence is prevalent among Asian people, then White people, then Black people.']
['What else did Jensen say?', 'Robert Williams was among those who called out racial bias in Jensen’s results (Williams, 1970).']

['Which is the most interesting part of this study material?', 'Obviously, Jensen’s interpretation of his own data caused an intense response in a nation that continued to grapple with the effects of racism (Fox, 2012).']

['What was the response?', "While even some who took issue with Jensen's findings indicated that they did not detect overt racism in his work, Jensen himself made a number of racist statements during an interview with a White nationalist publication, American Renaissance."]

['What was he saying in the interview?', 'He indicated his belief that many Black people were not "educable up to a level for which there’s any economic demand," while also having a higher birth rate than other groups, which would lead to a shift in population and a deterioration of the nation (Taylor, 1992).']

['What else does he have to say about race?', 'However, Jensen’s ideas were not solitary or unique; rather, they represented one of many examples of psychologists asserting racial differences in IQ and cognitive ability.']
['What is one more interesting fact?', 'In fact, Rushton and Jensen (2005) reviewed three decades worth of research on the relationship between race and cognitive ability.']

['What else is significant about this article?', 'Jensen’s belief in the inherited nature of intelligence and the validity of the IQ test to be the truest measure of intelligence are at the core of his conclusions.']

['What type of test was used?', 'In a related story, parents of African American students filed a case against the State of California in 1979, because they believed that the testing method used to identify students with learning disabilities was culturally unfair as the tests were normed and standardized using White children (Larry P. v. Riles).']

['What were the results of this lawsuit?', 'The testing method used by the state disproportionately identified African American children as “mentally retarded," which resulted in many students being incorrectly classified.']
['What happened in this lawsuit?', 'According to a summary of the case, Larry P. v. Riles:']
['What are learning disabilities?', 'Learning disabilities are cognitive disorders that affect different areas of cognition, particularly language or reading.']
['What is wrong with these children?', 'It should be pointed out that learning disabilities are not the same thing as intellectual disabilities.']
['What is the difference?', 'Learning disabilities are considered specific neurological impairments rather than global intellectual or developmental disabilities.']

['How is this different from intellectual disabilities?', 'A person with a language disability has difficulty understanding or using spoken language, whereas someone with a reading disability, such as dyslexia, has difficulty processing what they are reading.']
['What are the effects of a learning disability?', 'Often, learning disabilities are not recognized until a child reaches school age.']
['How do you know if the child has a learning disability?', 'One confounding aspect of learning disabilities is that they most often affect children with average to above-average intelligence.']
['What can be done to help a child who has a learning disability?', 'In other words, the disability is specific to a particular area and not a measure of overall intellectual ability.']

['What other disorders do learning disabilities tend to exhibit?', 'At the same time, learning disabilities tend to exhibit comorbidity with other disorders, like attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']

['What is the research about learning disabilities comorbidity?', 'Anywhere between 30–70% of individuals with diagnosed cases of ADHD also have some sort of learning disability (Riccio, Gonzales, & Hynd, 1994).']
['What are some examples of learning disabilities?', 'Let’s take a look at three examples of common learning disabilities: dysgraphia, dyslexia, and dyscalculia.']
['What is dysgraphia?', 'Children with dysgraphia have a learning disability that results in a struggle to write legibly.']
['Why does it struggle to write?', 'The physical task of writing with a pen and paper is extremely challenging for the person.']
['What is the importance of writing with dysgraphia?', 'These children often have extreme difficulty putting their thoughts down on paper (Smits-Engelsman & Van Galen, 1997).']
['What else is interesting about dysgraphia?', 'This difficulty is inconsistent with a person’s IQ.']
['What does inconsistent with a person’s IQ mean?', 'That is, based on the child’s IQ and/or abilities in other areas, a child with dysgraphia should be able to write, but can’t.']
['What other problems do people have with dysgraphia?', 'Children with dysgraphia may also have problems with spatial abilities.']
['What is dysgraphia?', 'Students with dysgraphia need academic accommodations to help them succeed in school.']
['What do academic accommodations provide?', 'These accommodations can provide students with alternative assessment opportunities to demonstrate what they know (Barton, 2003).']
['What are some examples of alternative assessment opportunities?', 'For example, a student with dysgraphia might be permitted to take an oral exam rather than a traditional paper-and-pencil test.']

['What is one of the ways that dysgraphia can be treated?', 'Treatment is usually provided by an occupational therapist, although there is some question as to how effective such treatment is (Zwicker, 2005).']
['What is Dyslexia?', 'Dyslexia is the most common learning disability in children.']
['What are the things that make a person dyslexic?', 'An individual with dyslexia exhibits an inability to correctly process letters.']
['What is it that causes that problem?', 'The neurological mechanism for sound processing does not work properly in someone with dyslexia.']
['What happens after the neuron is not working properly?', 'As a result, dyslexic children may not understand sound-letter correspondence.']

['How are letters mispronounced?', 'A child with dyslexia may mix up letters within words and sentences—letter reversals, such as those shown in Figure 7.17, are a hallmark of this learning disability—or skip whole words while reading.']
['What are some other things that show Dyslexia?', 'A dyslexic child may have difficulty spelling words correctly while writing.']
['How does the learning disability effect a dyslexic person?', 'Because of the disordered way that the brain processes letters and sound, learning to read is a frustrating experience.']
['Does it take a lot of time to learn to read?', 'Some dyslexic individuals cope by memorizing the shapes of most words, but they never actually learn to read (Berninger, 2008).']
['What is Dyscalculia?', 'Dyscalculia is difficulty in learning or comprehending arithmetic.']
['What does Dyscalculia mean?', 'This learning disability is often first evident when children exhibit difficulty discerning how many objects are in a small group without counting them.']

['What else is Dyscalculia?', 'Other symptoms may include struggling to memorize math facts, organize numbers, or fully differentiate between numerals, math symbols, and written numbers (such as “3” and “three”).']
['What does memory consist of?', 'Memory is an information processing system; therefore, we often compare it to a computer.']
['What are the functions of memory?', 'Memory is the set of processes used to encode, store, and retrieve information over different periods of time.']
['What is Encoding?', 'We get information into our brains through a process called encoding, which is the input of information into the memory system.']
['Why does the brain use this term?', 'Once we receive sensory information from the environment, our brains label or code it.']
['What does this label do?', 'We organize the information with other similar information and connect new concepts to existing concepts.']
['What other ways does this work?', 'Encoding information occurs through automatic processing and effortful processing.']
['What does this mean?', 'If someone asks you what you ate for lunch today, more than likely you could recall this information quite easily.']
['What can you remember about your lunch that day?', 'This is known as automatic processing, or the encoding of details like time, space, frequency, and the meaning of words.']
['Does automatic processing happen without conscious awareness?', 'Automatic processing is usually done without any conscious awareness.']
['What does automatic processing mean?', 'Recalling the last time you studied for a test is another example of automatic processing.']
['Did it require conscious effort?', 'It probably required a lot of work and attention on your part in order to encode that information.']
['What is it known as when you are trying to encode?', 'This is known as effortful processing.']
['What are the examples from the first section?', 'Even a simple sentence is easier to recall when it is meaningful (Anderson, 1984).']

['What other examples from the first section were used?', 'Read the following sentences (Bransford & McCarrell, 1974), then look away and count backwards from 30 by threes to zero, and then try to write down the sentences (no peeking back at this page!).']
['Why were the notes sour?', 'The notes were sour because the seams split.']
['Did the voyage delay because of the seams splitting?', "The voyage wasn't delayed because the bottle shattered."]
['Why was the haystack important?', 'The haystack was important because the cloth ripped.']
['What is going on?', 'By themselves, the statements that you wrote down were most likely confusing and difficult for you to recall.']
['What did you do wrong?', 'Now, try writing them again, using the following prompts: bagpipe, ship christening, and parachutist.']
['How many prompts did you do?', 'Next count backwards from 40 by fours, then check yourself to see how well you recalled the sentences this time.']
['What did you do wrong with your last try?', 'Material is far better encoded when you make it meaningful.']
['What are the types of encoding?', 'There are three types of encoding.']
['What is semantic encoding?', 'The encoding of words and their meaning is known as semantic encoding.']
['Who demonstrated this?', 'It was first demonstrated by William Bousfield (1935) in an experiment in which he asked people to memorize words.']
['What else did he find out about this?', 'The 60 words were actually divided into 4 categories of meaning, although the participants did not know this because the words were randomly presented.']

['What else did he discover?', 'When they were asked to remember the words, they tended to recall them in categories, showing that they paid attention to the meanings of the words as they learned them.']
['What are visual and acoustic encoding?', 'Visual encoding is the encoding of images, and acoustic encoding is the encoding of sounds, words in particular.']
['How does this differ?', 'To see how visual encoding works, read over this list of words: car, level, dog, truth, book, value.']
['How would this work?', 'You would probably have an easier time recalling the words car, dog, and book, and a more difficult time recalling the words level, truth, and value.']
['Why would you recall them?', 'Because you can recall images (mental pictures) more easily than words alone.']
['How did you create the images?', 'When you read the words car, dog, and book you created images of these things in your mind.']
['What type of images?', 'These are concrete, high-imagery words.']
['Which type of words are low-imagery?', 'On the other hand, abstract words like level, truth, and value are low-imagery words.']
['Why do we encode them differently?', 'High-imagery words are encoded both visually and semantically (Paivio, 1986), thus building a stronger memory.']
['What is encoding?', 'Now let’s turn our attention to acoustic encoding.']
['What is acoustic encoding?', 'You are driving in your car and a song comes on the radio that you haven’t heard in at least 10 years, but you sing along, recalling every word.']

['Why is that?', 'In the United States, children often learn the alphabet through song, and they learn the number of days in each month through rhyme: “Thirty days hath September, / April, June, and November; / All the rest have thirty-one, / Save February, with twenty-eight days clear, / And twenty-nine each leap year.”']
['How are these lessons learned?', 'These lessons are easy to remember because of acoustic encoding.']
['How do we encode words?', 'We encode the sounds the words make.']
['Why do we encode sounds?', 'This is one of the reasons why much of what we teach young children is done through song, rhyme, and rhythm.']
['What does encoding refer to?', 'Some years ago, psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving (1975) conducted a series of experiments to find out.']
['What was the experiment?', 'Participants were given words along with questions about them.']
['What were the questions about?', 'The questions required the participants to process the words at one of the three levels.']
['How did they ask them the questions?', 'The visual processing questions included such things as asking the participants about the font of the letters.']

['What else did they ask them about?', 'The acoustic processing questions asked the participants about the sound or rhyming of the words, and the semantic processing questions asked the participants about the meaning of the words.']
['What was the outcome of the experiment?', 'After participants were presented with the words and questions, they were given an unexpected recall or recognition task.']
['What are the advantages of semantic encoding?', 'Words that had been encoded semantically were better remembered than those encoded visually or acoustically.']
['What is the reasoning behind this?', 'Semantic encoding involves a deeper level of processing than the shallower visual or acoustic encoding.']

['What is the Self-Reference effect?', 'Craik and Tulving concluded that we process verbal information best through semantic encoding, especially if we apply what is called the self-reference effect.']

['What does the self-reference effect mean?', 'The self-reference effect is the tendency for an individual to have better memory for information that relates to oneself in comparison to material that has less personal relevance (Rogers, Kuiper, & Kirker, 1977).']
['Why is it necessary to store information?', 'Once the information has been encoded, we have to somehow retain it.']
['What does our brains do to retain the encoded information?', 'Our brains take the encoded information and place it in storage.']
['What does storage mean?', 'Storage is the creation of a permanent record of information.']

['How does memory get stored?', 'In order for a memory to go into storage (i.e., long-term memory), it has to pass through three distinct stages: Sensory Memory, Short-Term Memory, and finally Long-Term Memory.']
['Who was responsible for defining these stages?', 'These stages were first proposed by Richard Atkinson and Richard Shiffrin (1968).']
['What is their model?', "Their model of human memory, called Atkinson and Shiffrin's model, is based on the belief that we process memories in the same way that a computer processes information."]
['What does the Atkinson and Shiffrin model describe?', "Atkinson and Shiffrin's model is not the only model of memory."]
['What other models of memory are there?', 'Baddeley and Hitch (1974) proposed a working memory model in which short-term memory has different forms.']
['Why are there different forms?', 'In their model, storing memories in short-term memory is like opening different files on a computer and adding information.']
['How does it work like a computer?', 'The working memory files hold a limited amount of information.']
['What else is similar?', 'The type of short-term memory (or computer file) depends on the type of information received.']

['What kind of memory does it contain?', 'There are memories in visual-spatial form, as well as memories of spoken or written material, and they are stored in three short-term systems: a visuospatial sketchpad, an episodic buffer (Baddeley, 2000), and a phonological loop.']

['What else is important?', 'According to Baddeley and Hitch, a central executive part of memory supervises or controls the flow of information to and from the three short-term systems, and the central executive is responsible for moving information into long-term memory.']
['What is sensory memory?', 'In the Atkinson-Shiffrin model, stimuli from the environment are processed first in sensory memory: storage of brief sensory events, such as sights, sounds, and tastes.']
['What else did you find interesting in this article?', 'It is very brief storage—up to a couple of seconds.']
['What else do you think about this?', 'We are constantly bombarded with sensory information.']
['What else was important in your response?', 'As long as the professor was dressed appropriately, it does not really matter what she was wearing.']
['Did you find any other interesting information?', 'Sensory information about sights, sounds, smells, and even textures, which we do not view as valuable information, we discard.']
['Does this help with your understanding?', 'If we view something as valuable, the information will move into our short-term memory system.']
['What is short-term memory?', 'Short-term memory (STM) is a temporary storage system that processes incoming sensory memory.']
['Can you tell me more about short-term memory?', 'The terms short-term and working memory are sometimes used interchangeably, but they are not exactly the same.']
['What is the difference between short-term memory and working memory?', 'Short-term memory is more accurately described as a component of working memory.']
['What else does short-term memory do?', 'Short-term memory takes information from sensory memory and sometimes connects that memory to something already in long-term memory.']
['How long does it last?', 'Short-term memory storage lasts 15 to 30 seconds.']
['What can you compare it to?', 'Think of it as the information you have displayed on your computer screen, such as a document, spreadsheet, or website.']
['What happens after this time?', 'Then, information in STM goes to long-term memory (you save it to your hard drive), or it is discarded (you delete a document or close a web browser).']
['What does this mean?', 'Rehearsal moves information from short-term memory to long-term memory.']
['What is active rehearsal?', 'Active rehearsal is a way of attending to information to move it from short-term to long-term memory.']
['How does one do this?', 'During active rehearsal, you repeat (practice) the information to be remembered.']
['How often should you do this?', 'If you repeat it enough, it may be moved into long-term memory.']
['What other examples are there?', 'For example, this type of active rehearsal is the way many children learn their ABCs by singing the alphabet song.']
['What is elaborative rehearsal?', 'Alternatively, elaborative rehearsal is the act of linking new information you are trying to learn to existing information that you already know.']

['How does one do this?', 'For example, if you meet someone at a party and your phone is dead but you want to remember his phone number, which starts with area code 203, you might remember that your uncle Abdul lives in Connecticut and has a 203 area code.']
['How does this work?', 'This way, when you try to remember the phone number of your new prospective friend, you will easily remember the area code.']
