['What else does the article say?', 'Craik and Lockhart (1972) proposed the levels of processing hypothesis that states the deeper you think about something, the better you remember it.']
['What can we remember when we use short-term memory?', 'You may find yourself asking, “How much information can our memory handle at once?”']

['What are the different tests you can try to find out what information you can handle?', 'To explore the capacity and duration of your short-term memory, have a partner read the strings of random numbers out loud to you, beginning each string by saying, “Ready?” and ending each by saying, “Recall,” at which point you should try to write down the string of numbers from memory.']
['Does the series start at 1, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8?', 'Note the longest string at which you got the series correct.']
['What is the maximum number of digits you can store?', 'For most people, the capacity will probably be close to 7 plus or minus 2.']

['What research has been done on the number 7?', 'In 1956, George Miller reviewed most of the research on the capacity of short-term memory and found that people can retain between 5 and 9 items, so he reported the capacity of short-term memory was the "magic number" 7 plus or minus 2.']
['What are some other interesting aspects about this article?', 'However, more contemporary research has found working memory capacity is 4 plus or minus 1 (Cowan, 2010).']

['What kinds of digits are best for recall?', 'Generally, recall is somewhat better for random numbers than for random letters (Jacobs, 1887) and also often slightly better for information we hear (acoustic encoding) rather than information we see (visual encoding) (Anderson, 1969).']
['what is the most important thing I should know about this article?', 'Memory trace decay and interference are two factors that affect short-term memory retention.']

['what else is interesting about the article?', 'Peterson and Peterson (1959) investigated short-term memory using the three letter sequences called trigrams (e.g., CLS) that had to be recalled after various time intervals between 3 and 18 seconds.']

['what was the result of their experiments?', 'Participants remembered about 80% of the trigrams after a 3-second delay, but only 10% after a delay of 18 seconds, which caused them to conclude that short-term memory decayed in 18 seconds.']
['what happens during decay?', 'During decay, the memory trace becomes less activated over time, and the information is forgotten.']
['what else did they do?', 'However, Keppel and Underwood (1962) examined only the first trials of the trigram task and found that proactive interference also affected short-term memory retention.']
['what is proactive interference?', 'During proactive interference, previously learned information interferes with the ability to learn new information.']
['what are the results of these experiments?', 'Both memory trace decay and proactive interference affect short-term memory.']

['What is the most important thing to know?', 'Once the information reaches long-term memory, it has to be consolidated at both the synaptic level, which takes a few hours, and into the memory system, which can take weeks or longer.']
['What is long-term memory?', 'Long-term memory (LTM) is the continuous storage of information.']
['What is unique about long-term memory?', 'Unlike short-term memory, long-term memory storage capacity is believed to be unlimited.']
['What else can you tell me about long-term memory?', 'It encompasses all the things you can remember that happened more than just a few minutes ago.']
['What else is important about long-term memory?', 'One cannot really consider long-term memory without thinking about the way it is organized.']
['What are some examples of how long-term memory is organized?', 'If you did, you probably have associated peanut butter and jelly in your mind.']
['What does this mean?', 'It is generally accepted that memories are organized in semantic (or associative) networks (Collins & Loftus, 1975).']

['What do semantic networks consist of?', 'A semantic network consists of concepts, and as you may recall from what you’ve learned about memory, concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences.']

['How are the concepts organized in the brain?', 'Although individual experiences and expertise can affect concept arrangement, concepts are believed to be arranged hierarchically in the mind (Anderson & Reder, 1999; Johnson & Mervis, 1997, 1998; Palmer, Jones, Hennessy, Unze, & Pick, 1989; Rosch, Mervis, Gray, Johnson, & Boyes-Braem, 1976; Tanaka & Taylor, 1991).']
['What other important aspects about semantic networks?', 'Related concepts are linked, and the strength of the link depends on how often two concepts have been associated.']
['what are the implications of semantic networks for our understanding of Long-term Memory?', 'Semantic networks differ depending on personal experiences.']
['how do semantic networks differ?', 'Importantly for memory, activating any part of a semantic network also activates the concepts linked to that part to a lesser degree.']
['why does it activate less than that part?', 'The process is known as spreading activation (Collins & Loftus, 1975).']
['what is the process known as?', 'If one part of a network is activated, it is easier to access the associated concepts because they are already partially activated.']
['why is it easier to access?', 'When you remember or recall something, you activate a concept, and the related concepts are more easily remembered because they are partially activated.']
['what is the biggest change in this part of study?', 'However, the activations do not spread in just one direction.']

['what is one example of this?', 'When you remember something, you usually have several routes to get the information you are trying to access, and the more links you have to a concept, the better your chances of remembering.']
['What is Long-term Memory?', 'There are two types of long-term memory: explicit and implicit.']

['Why is it important to understand this difference?', 'Understanding the difference between explicit memory and implicit memory is important because aging, particular types of brain trauma, and certain disorders can impact explicit and implicit memory in different ways.']
['What is an explicit memory?', 'Explicit memories are those we consciously try to remember, recall, and report.']
['What are some examples?', 'For example, if you are studying for your chemistry exam, the material you are learning will be part of your explicit memory.']
['How does this differ from a hard drive?', 'In keeping with the computer analogy, some information in your long-term memory would be like the information you have saved on the hard drive.']
['Why is it like this?', 'It is not there on your desktop (your short-term memory), but most of the time you can pull up this information when you want it.']
['What else is important?', 'Not all long-term memories are strong memories, and some memories can only be recalled using prompts.']

['What kind of prompts do you use?', 'For example, you might easily recall a fact, such as the capital of the United States, but you might struggle to recall the name of the restaurant at which you had dinner when you visited a nearby city last summer.']
['What does this mean?', 'A prompt, such as that the restaurant was named after its owner, might help you recall the name of the restaurant.']
['What else can you tell me about explicit memories?', 'Explicit memory is sometimes referred to as declarative memory, because it can be put into words.']
['What else can you tell me?', 'Explicit memory is divided into episodic memory and semantic memory.']
['What is episodic memory?', 'Episodic memory is information about events we have personally experienced (i.e., an episode).']
['How are episodic memories used in everyday life?', 'For instance, the memory of your last birthday is an episodic memory.']
['How are episodic memories reported?', 'Usually, episodic memory is reported as a story.']
['When did Tulving first think of episodic memory?', 'The concept of episodic memory was first proposed about in the 1970s (Tulving, 1972).']

['Did he have other ideas about episodic memories?', 'Since then, Tulving and others have reformulated the theory, and currently scientists believe that episodic memory is memory about happenings in particular places at particular times—the what, where, and when of an event (Tulving, 2002).']
['What else can be learned about episodic memory?', 'It involves recollection of visual imagery as well as the feeling of familiarity (Hassabis & Maguire, 2007).']
['What is semantic memory?', 'Semantic memory is knowledge about words, concepts, and language-based knowledge and facts.']
['How are semantic memories reported?', 'Semantic memory is typically reported as facts.']
['What does semantic mean?', 'Semantic means having to do with language and knowledge about language.']

['How are semantic memories used in everyday life?', 'For example, answers to the following questions like “what is the definition of psychology” and “who was the first African American president of the United States” are stored in your semantic memory.']
['What are Implicit memories?', 'Implicit memories are long-term memories that are not part of our consciousness.']

['What is their significance?', 'Although implicit memories are learned outside of our awareness and cannot be consciously recalled, implicit memory is demonstrated in the performance of some task (Roediger, 1990; Schacter, 1987).']

['What type of tasks do they perform?', 'Implicit memory has been studied with cognitive demand tasks, such as performance on artificial grammars (Reber, 1976), word memory (Jacoby, 1983; Jacoby & Witherspoon, 1982), and learning unspoken and unwritten contingencies and rules (Greenspoon, 1955; Giddan & Eriksen, 1959; Krieckhaus & Eriksen, 1960).']
['How can you use a computer metaphor?', 'Returning to the computer metaphor, implicit memories are like a program running in the background, and you are not aware of their influence.']
['Does it influence anything else?', 'Implicit memories can influence observable behaviors as well as cognitive tasks.']
['What does the computer metaphor represent?', 'In either case, you usually cannot put the memory into words that adequately describe the task.']
['What kind of memory does it have?', 'There are several types of implicit memories, including procedural, priming, and emotional conditioning.']
['How is it researched?', 'Implicit procedural memory is often studied using observable behaviors (Adams, 1957; Lacey & Smith, 1954; Lazarus & McCleary, 1951).']

['What can you tell me about implicit procedural memory?', 'Implicit procedural memory stores information about the way to do something, and it is the memory for skilled actions, such as brushing your teeth, riding a bicycle, or driving a car.']
['How does it improve over time?', 'You were probably not that good at riding a bicycle or driving a car the first time you tried, but you were much better after doing those things for a year.']
['What does the research say?', 'Your improved bicycle riding was due to learning balancing abilities.']
['How did it improve?', 'You likely thought about staying upright in the beginning, but now you just do it.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'Moreover, you probably are good at staying balanced, but cannot tell someone the exact way you do it.']
['Does it affect other aspects of life?', 'Similarly, when you first learned to drive, you probably thought about a lot of things that you just do now without much thought.']
['What is Implicit priming?', 'Implicit priming is another type of implicit memory (Schacter, 1992).']
['What are the effects of priming?', 'During priming exposure to a stimulus affects the response to a later stimulus.']
['What is a stimulus?', 'Stimuli can vary and may include words, pictures, and other stimuli to elicit a response or increase recognition.']
['What do people enjoy?', 'For instance, some people really enjoy picnics.']
['What is interesting about picnics?', 'They love going into nature, spreading a blanket on the ground, and eating a delicious meal.']
['What else is interesting about picnics?', 'Now, unscramble the following letters to make a word.']
['what was the last line of text?', 'Chances are good that it was "plate."']
['Had you read, “Some people really enjoy growing flowers.', 'Had you read, “Some people really enjoy growing flowers.']

['They love going outside to their garden, fertilizing their plants, and watering their flowers,”', 'They love going outside to their garden, fertilizing their plants, and watering their flowers,” you probably would have come up with the word "petal" instead of plate.']
['What is the topic of your study?', 'The reason people are more likely to come up with “plate” after reading about a picnic is that plate is associated (linked) with picnic.']
['What other things did you do in your study?', 'Plate was primed by activating the semantic network.']
['What else did you find?', 'Similarly, “petal” is linked to flower and is primed by flower.']
['Is there anything else interesting you learned?', 'Priming is also the reason you probably said jelly in response to peanut butter.']
['What is implicit emotional conditioning?', 'Implicit emotional conditioning is the type of memory involved in classically conditioned emotion responses (Olson & Fazio, 2001).']
['How do emotions are represented?', 'These emotional relationships cannot be reported or recalled but can be associated with different stimuli.']
['What is an example of such stimulus?', 'For example, specific smells can cause specific emotional responses for some people.']
['Why are they considered implicit?', "If there is a smell that makes you feel positive and nostalgic, and you don't know where that response comes from, it is an implicit emotional response."]
['Can you think of other examples?', 'Similarly, most people have a song that causes a specific emotional response.']
["What is the song's effect?", "That song's effect could be an implicit emotional memory (Yang, Xu, Du, Shi, & Fang, 2011)."]
['What is retrieval?', 'So you have worked hard to encode (via effortful processing) and store some important information for your upcoming final exam.']
['What is retrieval?', 'The act of getting information out of memory storage and back into conscious awareness is known as retrieval.']
['What does this look like?', 'This would be similar to finding and opening a paper you had previously saved on your computer’s hard drive.']
["What's the importance?", 'Our ability to retrieve information from long-term memory is vital to our everyday functioning.']

['What is it used for?', 'You must be able to retrieve information from memory in order to do everything from knowing how to brush your hair and teeth, to driving to work, to knowing how to perform your job once you get there.']
['How do you retrieve information?', 'There are three ways you can retrieve information out of your long-term memory storage system: recall, recognition, and relearning.']
['What does recall mean?', 'Recall is what we most often think about when we talk about memory retrieval: it means you can access information without cues.']
['What can you do with it?', 'For example, you would use recall for an essay test.']
['What is recognition?', 'Recognition happens when you identify information that you have previously learned after encountering it again.']
['How does it work?', 'It involves a process of comparison.']
['What else does it involve?', 'When you take a multiple-choice test, you are relying on recognition to help you choose the correct answer.']
['What else?', 'Here is another example.']
['What is the example?', 'Let’s say you graduated from high school 10 years ago, and you have returned to your hometown for your 10-year reunion.']
['How do you identify your classmates?', 'You may not be able to recall all of your classmates, but you recognize many of them based on their yearbook photos.']
['What else do you know about the third form of retrieval?', 'The third form of retrieval is relearning, and it’s just what it sounds like.']
['What does it involve?', 'It involves learning information that you previously learned.']
["What's a good example?", 'Whitney took Spanish in high school, but after high school she did not have the opportunity to speak Spanish.']
['Why did she have to re learn?', 'Whitney is now 31, and her company has offered her an opportunity to work in their Mexico City office.']
['What did she do to prepare herself?', 'In order to prepare herself, she enrolls in a Spanish course at the local community center.']
['What did she learn?', 'She’s surprised at how quickly she’s able to pick up the language after not speaking it for 13 years; this is an example of relearning.']
['Who is Lashley?', 'Karl Lashley began exploring this problem, about 100 years ago, by making lesions in the brains of animals such as rats and monkeys.']
['What was the cause of these lesions?', 'He was searching for evidence of the engram: the group of neurons that serve as the “physical representation of memory” (Josselyn, 2010).']
['How did he discover the group of neurons?', 'First, Lashley (1950) trained rats to find their way through a maze.']
['What was this training for?', 'Then, he used the tools available at the time—in this case a soldering iron—to create lesions in the rats’ brains, specifically in the cerebral cortex.']
['What happened as a result of these lesions?', 'He did this because he was trying to erase the engram, or the original memory trace that the rats had of the maze.']
['Why does the brain need engrams?', 'Lashley did not find evidence of the engram, and the rats were still able to find their way through the maze, regardless of the size or location of the lesion.']

['What was the evidence he was testing for?', 'Based on his creation of lesions and the animals’ reaction, he formulated the equipotentiality hypothesis: if part of one area of the brain involved in memory is damaged, another part of the same area can take over that memory function (Lashley, 1950).']
['Did he find an actual engram?', 'Although Lashley’s early work did not confirm the existence of the engram, modern psychologists are making progress locating it.']

['What are the modern psychologists doing to locate it?', 'For example, Eric Kandel has spent decades studying the synapse and its role in controlling the flow of information through neural circuits needed to store memories (Mayford, Siegelbaum, & Kandel, 2012).']
['What are the parts of the brain involved with memory?', 'Many scientists believe that the entire brain is involved with memory.']
['What do scientists believe the entire brain is involved with?', 'However, since Lashley’s research, other scientists have been able to look more closely at the brain and memory.']

['Who looked more closely at the brain and memory?', 'They have argued that memory is located in specific parts of the brain, and specific neurons can be recognized for their involvement in forming memories.']
['What other parts of the brain is involved with memory?', 'The main parts of the brain involved with memory are the amygdala, the hippocampus, the cerebellum, and the prefrontal cortex.']
['What are some of the main points of this article?', 'First, let’s look at the role of the amygdala in memory formation.']
['What are some of the other uses?', 'The main job of the amygdala is to regulate emotions, such as fear and aggression.']
['How does this impact memory?', 'The amygdala plays a part in how memories are stored because storage is influenced by stress hormones.']
['What is one interesting experiment mentioned?', 'For example, one researcher experimented with rats and the fear response (Josselyn, 2010).']
['How did they do this?', 'Using Pavlovian conditioning, a neutral tone was paired with a foot shock to the rats.']
['Did they remember it?', 'This produced a fear memory in the rats.']
['What did they do after the shock?', 'After being conditioned, each time they heard the tone, they would freeze (a defense response in rats), indicating a memory for the impending shock.']
['How did the study go further?', 'Then the researchers induced cell death in neurons in the lateral amygdala, which is the specific area of the brain responsible for fear memories.']
['What did they discover?', 'They found the fear memory faded (became extinct).']

['What else can you tell me?', 'Because of its role in processing emotional information, the amygdala is also involved in memory consolidation: the process of transferring new learning into long-term memory.']
['What was the result?', 'The amygdala seems to facilitate encoding memories at a deeper level when the event is emotionally arousing.']
['What is memory processing?', 'Another group of researchers also experimented with rats to learn how the hippocampus functions in memory processing.']

['What was their experiment?', 'They created lesions in the hippocampi of the rats, and found that the rats demonstrated memory impairment on various tasks, such as object recognition and maze running.']

["What happened with the rats' memory?", 'They concluded that the hippocampus is involved in memory, specifically normal recognition memory as well as spatial memory (when the memory tasks are like recall tests) (Clark, Zola, & Squire, 2000).']
['What are some other examples of memory processing?', 'Another job of the hippocampus is to project information to cortical regions that give memories meaning and connect them with other memories.']
['What else does it do?', 'It also plays a part in memory consolidation: the process of transferring new learning into long-term memory.']
['what is the hippocampal used for?', 'Injury to this area leaves us unable to process new declarative memories.']

['what is hippocampal injury?', 'One famous patient, known for years only as H. M., had both his left and right temporal lobes (hippocampi) removed in an attempt to help control the seizures he had been suffering from for years (Corkin, Amaral, González, Johnson, & Hyman, 1997).']
['what happened after the hippocampal injury?', 'As a result, his declarative memory was significantly affected, and he could not form new semantic knowledge.']
['what happened to him?', 'He lost the ability to form new memories, yet he could still remember information and events that had occurred prior to the surgery.']

['What is the Cerebellum involved in?', 'Although the hippocampus seems to be more of a processing area for explicit memories, you could still lose it and be able to create implicit memories (procedural memory, motor learning, and classical conditioning), thanks to your cerebellum.']
['What are some examples of classical conditioning?', 'For example, one classical conditioning experiment is to accustom subjects to blink when they are given a puff of air to the eyes.']

['Was this experiment successful?', 'When researchers damaged the cerebellums of rabbits, they discovered that the rabbits were not able to learn the conditioned eye-blink response (Steinmetz, 1999; Green & Woodruff-Pak, 2000).']

['What are the main differences between prefrontal cortex and cerebellum?', 'Other researchers have used brain scans, including positron emission tomography (PET) scans, to learn how people process and retain information.']
['What has been discovered from these studies?', 'From these studies, it seems the prefrontal cortex is involved.']

['How does the prefrontal cortex help us understand what we are reading?', 'In one study, participants had to complete two different tasks: either looking for the letter a in words (considered a perceptual task) or categorizing a noun as either living or non-living (considered a semantic task) (Kapur et al., 1994).']
['What was the study evaluating?', 'Participants were then asked which words they had previously seen.']
['How well did they do?', 'Recall was much better for the semantic task than for the perceptual task.']
['What were the findings of these studies?', 'According to PET scans, there was much more activation in the left inferior prefrontal cortex in the semantic task.']

['What was the other findings of these studies?', 'In another study, encoding was associated with left frontal activity, while retrieval of information was associated with the right frontal region (Craik et al., 1999).']

['What does the article mainly talk about?', 'There also appear to be specific neurotransmitters involved with the process of memory, such as epinephrine, dopamine, serotonin, glutamate, and acetylcholine (Myhrer, 2003).']

['Are there any other neurotransmitters involved in memory?', 'There continues to be discussion and debate among researchers as to which neurotransmitter plays which specific role (Blockland, 1996).']

['Does Blockland mention how neurotransmitters influence memory?', 'Although we don’t yet know which role each neurotransmitter plays in memory, we do know that communication among neurons via neurotransmitters is critical for developing new memories.']
['How do neurons communicate with each other?', 'Repeated activity by neurons leads to increased neurotransmitters in the synapses and more efficient and more synaptic connections.']
['What is the result of more synaptic connections?', 'This is how memory consolidation occurs.']

["What is the most important information that you've learned so far?", 'It is also believed that strong emotions trigger the formation of strong memories, and weaker emotional experiences form weaker memories; this is called arousal theory (Christianson, 1992).']

['What is the arousal theory?', 'For example, strong emotional experiences can trigger the release of neurotransmitters, as well as hormones, which strengthen memory; therefore, our memory for an emotional event is usually better than our memory for a non-emotional event.']

['What is the next important information?', 'When humans and animals are stressed, the brain secretes more of the neurotransmitter glutamate, which helps them remember the stressful event (McGaugh, 2003).']
['What do people do when they relive an emotional experience?', 'This is clearly evidenced by what is known as the flashbulb memory phenomenon.']
['What are flashbulb memories?', 'A flashbulb memory is an exceptionally clear recollection of an important event.']
['What type of memory do flashbulb memories have?', 'Many people who have lived through historic and momentous events can recall exactly where they were and how they heard about them.']

['How are flashbulb memories used?', 'For example, a Pew Research Center (2011) survey found that for those Americans who were age 8 or older at the time of 9/11 terrorist attacks, 97% can recall the moment they learned of this event, even a decade after it happened.']

['Where can you find more information about flashbulb memories?', 'Many widely discussed examples of flashbulb memories pertain to national or global events, but according to their initial definition by researchers Brown and Kulik (1977) as well as additional work by more recent researchers, such a widely shared event is not required (Hirst & Phelps, 2016).']

["How do flashbulb memories interact with a person's personality?", 'Family members might always remember how they heard about an important event in their lives, or people in a school may recall nearly everything about the way they experienced a major event in that setting.']

['What is the most significant information about flashbulb memories?', 'And although most studies (and many conversations) involve negative memories, positive events can also elicit flashbulb memories.']

['What is the problem?', 'You may pride yourself on your amazing ability to remember the birthdates and ages of all of your friends and family members, or you may be able recall vivid details of your 5th birthday party at Chuck E. Cheese’s.']
['What about other people?', 'However, all of us have at times felt frustrated, and even embarrassed, when our memories have failed us.']
['Why does this happen?', 'There are several reasons why this happens.']
['What is Amnesia?', 'Amnesia is the loss of long-term memory that occurs as the result of disease, physical trauma, or psychological trauma.']
['Did anyone do the study?', 'Endel Tulving (2002) and his colleagues at the University of Toronto studied K. C. for years.']
['Did they use K. C.?', 'K. C. suffered a traumatic head injury in a motorcycle accident and then had severe amnesia.']
['What did they find?', 'Tulving writes,']
['What are the different types of amnesia?', 'There are two common types of amnesia: anterograde amnesia and retrograde amnesia.']
['What caused this type of amnesia?', 'Anterograde amnesia is commonly caused by brain trauma, such as a blow to the head.']
['What happens as a result of the injury?', 'With anterograde amnesia, you cannot remember new information, although you can remember information and events that happened prior to your injury.']
['How does it affect the brain?', 'The hippocampus is usually affected (McLeod, 2011).']

['What does the lack of memory do?', 'This suggests that damage to the brain has resulted in the inability to transfer information from short-term to long-term memory; that is, the inability to consolidate memories.']

['What is a characteristic of this amnesia?', 'Many people with this form of amnesia are unable to form new episodic or semantic memories, but are still able to form new procedural memories (Bayley & Squire, 2002).']
['What is this significant?', 'This was true of H. M., which was discussed earlier.']
['How was he injured?', 'The brain damage caused by his surgery resulted in anterograde amnesia.']
['What did he experience after this injury?', 'H. M. would read the same magazine over and over, having no memory of ever reading it—it was always new to him.']
['What other problems did he have?', 'He also could not remember people he had met after his surgery.']
['How could this affect him?', 'If you were introduced to H. M. and then you left the room for a few minutes, he would not know you upon your return and would introduce himself to you again.']

['What other aspects of this article did you find interesting?', 'However, when presented the same puzzle several days in a row, although he did not remember having seen the puzzle before, his speed at solving it became faster each day (because of relearning) (Corkin, 1965, 1968).']
['What is Retrograde Amnesia?', 'Retrograde amnesia is loss of memory for events that occurred prior to the trauma.']
['What happens with this memory loss?', 'People with retrograde amnesia cannot remember some or even all of their past.']
['Why does this cause issues with their memory?', 'They have difficulty remembering episodic memories.']
['Is there anything else you learned about the topic?', 'You were in a car accident, suffered a head injury, and now have retrograde amnesia.']
['What are the symptoms of retrograde amnesia?', 'You don’t remember anything about your life prior to waking up in the hospital.']

['What else did you learn?', 'This may sound like the stuff of Hollywood movies, and Hollywood has been fascinated with the amnesia plot for nearly a century, going all the way back to the film Garden of Lies from 1915 to more recent movies such as the Jason Bourne spy thrillers.']
['Why is that?', 'However, for real-life sufferers of retrograde amnesia, like former NFL football player Scott Bolzan, the story is not a Hollywood movie.']
['What happened to Scott Bolzan?', 'Bolzan fell, hit his head, and deleted 46 years of his life in an instant.']
['What happened next to him?', 'He is now living with one of the most extreme cases of retrograde amnesia on record.']
['What is memory reconstruction?', 'The formulation of new memories is sometimes called construction, and the process of bringing up old memories is called reconstruction.']
['What can you tell me about memory reconstruction?', 'Yet as we retrieve our memories, we also tend to alter and modify them.']
['Why do we alter and modify them?', 'A memory pulled from long-term storage into short-term memory is flexible.']
['Why is it flexible?', 'New events can be added and we can change what we think we remember about past events, resulting in inaccuracies and distortions.']

['What can you tell me about distortions?', 'People may not intend to distort facts, but it can happen in the process of retrieving old memories and combining them with new memories (Roediger & DeSoto, 2015).']
['What is suggestibility?', 'When someone witnesses a crime, that person’s memory of the details of the crime is very important in catching the suspect.']
['Why is that?', 'Because memory is so fragile, witnesses can be easily (and often accidentally) misled due to the problem of suggestibility.']
['What does suggestibility mean?', 'Suggestibility describes the effects of misinformation from external sources that leads to the creation of false memories.']
['When did sniper case start?', 'In the fall of 2002, a sniper in the DC area shot people at a gas station, leaving Home Depot, and walking down the street.']
['How many people did he shoot?', 'These attacks went on in a variety of places for over three weeks and resulted in the deaths of ten people.']
['What happened after that?', 'During this time, as you can imagine, people were terrified to leave their homes, go shopping, or even walk through their neighborhoods.']
['What else happened during that time?', 'Police officers and the FBI worked frantically to solve the crimes, and a tip hotline was set up.']
['Did they find any suspects?', 'Law enforcement received over 140,000 tips, which resulted in approximately 35,000 possible suspects (Newseum, n.d.).']
['When did this suggestion take place?', 'Most of the tips were dead ends, until a white van was spotted at the site of one of the shootings.']
['What did the police do after this?', 'The police chief went on national television with a picture of the white van.']
['Did this convince anyone?', 'After the news conference, several other eyewitnesses called to say that they too had seen a white van fleeing from the scene of the shooting.']
['Why did this lead them to the van?', 'At the time, there were more than 70,000 white vans in the area.']
['How did they narrow down the search to just white vans?', 'Police officers, as well as the general public, focused almost exclusively on white vans because they believed the eyewitnesses.']
['Did they find the van at all?', 'Other tips were ignored.']
['Did they get the suspects?', 'When the suspects were finally caught, they were driving a blue sedan.']
['What does suggestibility mean?', 'As illustrated by this example, we are vulnerable to the power of suggestion, simply based on something we see on the news.']
['What is suggestibility used for?', 'It is the suggestion that is the cause of the false memory.']

['Why is eyewitness identification important?', 'Even though memory and the process of reconstruction can be fragile, police officers, prosecutors, and the courts often rely on eyewitness identification and testimony in the prosecution of criminals.']
['How do mistakes in eyewitness identification lead to wrong convictions?', 'However, faulty eyewitness identification and testimony can lead to wrongful convictions.']
['What was the case?', 'In 1984, Jennifer Thompson, then a 22-year-old college student in North Carolina, was brutally raped at knifepoint.']

['What was her role in the case?', 'As she was being raped, she tried to memorize every detail of her rapist’s face and physical characteristics, vowing that if she survived, she would help get him convicted.']
['What was the result of her witness statement?', 'After the police were contacted, a composite sketch was made of the suspect, and Jennifer was shown six photos.']
['Was she able to correctly identify one of them?', 'She chose two, one of which was of Ronald Cotton.']
['Why was she so hesitant?', 'After looking at the photos for 4–5 minutes, she said, “Yeah.']
['Why did she say this?', 'This is the one,” and then she added, “I think this is the guy.”']
['How many times did she tell the police that?', 'Positive?”']
['What did the detective do when she told him this?', 'Then she asked the detective if she did OK, and he reinforced her choice by telling her she did great.']
['What was the importance of her witness statement?', 'These kinds of unintended cues and suggestions by police officers can lead witnesses to identify the wrong suspect.']
['Did the prosecutor question her after she was shown the photos?', 'The district attorney was concerned about her lack of certainty the first time, so she viewed a lineup of seven men.']
['What was her response to the prosecutor?', 'She said she was trying to decide between numbers 4 and 5, finally deciding that Cotton, number 5, “Looks most like him.”']
['What was he accused of?', 'He was 22 years old.']
['What is one thing that happened during this case?', 'By the time the trial began, Jennifer Thompson had absolutely no doubt that she was raped by Ronald Cotton.']
['How did the case end?', 'She testified at the court hearing, and her testimony was compelling enough that it helped convict him.']

['What other reasons can cause people to misidentify?', 'Gary Wells and Deah Quinlivan (2009) assert it’s suggestive police identification procedures, such as stacking lineups to make the defendant stand out, telling the witness which person to identify, and confirming witnesses choices by telling them “Good choice,” or “You picked the guy.”']
['Was there a trial for this?', 'After Cotton was convicted of the rape, he was sent to prison for life plus 50 years.']
['Did he stay in prison?', 'After 4 years in prison, he was able to get a new trial.']
['Why was there a new trial?', 'Jennifer Thompson once again testified against him.']
['What was the result of this new trial?', 'This time Ronald Cotton was given two life sentences.']

['How long did he spend in prison?', 'After serving 11 years in prison, DNA evidence finally demonstrated that Ronald Cotton did not commit the rape, was innocent, and had served over a decade in prison for a crime he did not commit.']
['What was the first thing he noticed?', 'Ronald Cotton’s story, unfortunately, is not unique.']
['What was his mistake?', 'There are also people who were convicted and placed on death row, who were later exonerated.']
['What does the Innocence Project do?', 'The Innocence Project is a non-profit group that works to exonerate falsely convicted people, including those convicted by eyewitness testimony.']
['Where can we learn more?', 'To learn more, you can visit http://www.innocenceproject.org.']
['Who did Loftus study?', 'Cognitive psychologist Elizabeth Loftus has conducted extensive research on memory.']
['What was the study on?', 'She has studied false memories as well as recovered memories of childhood sexual abuse.']

['What did she think of these studies?', 'Loftus also developed the misinformation effect paradigm, which holds that after exposure to additional and possibly inaccurate information, a person may misremember the original event.']
['What was the misinformation effect?', 'According to Loftus, an eyewitness’s memory of an event is very flexible due to the misinformation effect.']
["What was Loftus' theory?", 'To test this theory, Loftus and John Palmer (1974) asked 45 U.S. college students to estimate the speed of cars using different forms of questions.']
['Did they ask the participants to do other tasks?', 'The participants were shown films of car accidents and were asked to play the role of the eyewitness and describe what happened.']
['Was the role of the eye witness difficult?', 'They were asked, “About how fast were the cars going when they (smashed, collided, bumped, hit, contacted) each other?”']
['What was the response?', 'The participants estimated the speed of the cars based on the verb used.']
['What is the misinformation effect?', 'Participants who heard the word “smashed” estimated that the cars were traveling at a much higher speed than participants who heard the word “contacted.”']
['What causes the misinformation effect?', 'The implied information about speed, based on the verb they heard, had an effect on the participants’ memory of the accident.']
['Why does this happen?', 'In a follow-up one week later, participants were asked if they saw any broken glass (none was shown in the accident pictures).']
['What happened during the follow-up?', 'Participants who had been in the “smashed” group were more than twice as likely to indicate that they did remember seeing glass.']

['Why did the lead question encourage them to do this?', 'Loftus and Palmer demonstrated that a leading question encouraged them to not only remember the cars were going faster, but to also falsely remember that they saw broken glass.']
['What kind of controversies did this article describe?', 'Other researchers have described how whole events, not just words, can be falsely recalled, even when they did not happen.']

['Did this controversy impact the world?', 'The idea that memories of traumatic events could be repressed has been a theme in the field of psychology, beginning with Sigmund Freud, and the controversy surrounding the idea continues today.']
['What are some of the things the study material addresses?', 'Recall of false autobiographical memories is called false memory syndrome.']

['What causes false memories?', 'This syndrome has received a lot of publicity, particularly as it relates to memories of events that do not have independent witnesses—often the only witnesses to the abuse are the perpetrator and the victim (e.g., sexual abuse).']
['What is one side of this debate?', 'On one side of the debate are those who have recovered memories of childhood abuse years after it occurred.']

['What does this side say?', 'These researchers argue that some children’s experiences have been so traumatizing and distressing that they must lock those memories away in order to lead some semblance of a normal life.']

['How is this different from the previous side?', 'They believe that repressed memories can be locked away for decades and later recalled intact through hypnosis and guided imagery techniques (Devilly, 2007).']
['What is one of the Controversies over Repressed and Recovered Memories?', 'Research suggests that having no memory of childhood sexual abuse is quite common in adults.']

['What does it mean that people have no memory of childhood sexual abuse?', 'For instance, one large-scale study conducted by John Briere and Jon Conte (1993) revealed that 59% of 450 men and women who were receiving treatment for sexual abuse that had occurred before age 18 had forgotten their experiences.']
["How can repressing childhood sexual abuse cause problems in a person's life?", 'Ross Cheit (2007) suggested that repressing these memories created psychological distress in adulthood.']

['Is there a way to help victims of childhood sexual abuse?', 'The Recovered Memory Project was created so that victims of childhood sexual abuse can recall these memories and allow the healing process to begin (Cheit, 2007; Devilly, 2007).']

["what is loftus' challenge?", 'Loftus is not saying that childhood sexual abuse doesn’t happen, but she does question whether or not those memories are accurate, and she is skeptical of the questioning process used to access these memories, given that even the slightest suggestion from the therapist can lead to misinformation effects.']

['what are examples of misinformation effects?', 'For example, researchers Stephen Ceci and Maggie Brucks (1993, 1995) asked three-year-old children to use an anatomically correct doll to show where their pediatricians had touched them during an exam.']
['did they show the wrong part of their body?', 'Fifty-five percent of the children pointed to the genital/anal area on the dolls, even when they had not received any form of genital exam.']

['What is the study about?', 'Ever since Loftus published her first studies on the suggestibility of eyewitness testimony in the 1970s, social scientists, police officers, therapists, and legal practitioners have been aware of the flaws in interview practices.']
['How did the study affect people?', 'Consequently, steps have been taken to decrease suggestibility of witnesses.']
['What are some of the steps taken to decrease suggestibility?', 'One way is to modify how witnesses are questioned.']

['Why is this important?', 'When interviewers use neutral and less leading language, children more accurately recall what happened and who was involved (Goodman, 2006; Pipe, 1996; Pipe, Lamb, Orbach, & Esplin, 2004).']
['What other steps were taken?', 'Another change is in how police lineups are conducted.']
['What is the benefit?', 'It’s recommended that a blind photo lineup be used.']
['Why is this important?', 'This way the person administering the lineup doesn’t know which photo belongs to the suspect, minimizing the possibility of giving leading cues.']
['Does this make a difference?', 'Additionally, judges in some states now inform jurors about the possibility of misidentification.']
['What other steps did the judge take?', 'Judges can also suppress eyewitness testimony if they deem it unreliable.']
['What was interesting about this topic?', '“I’ve a grand memory for forgetting,” quipped Robert Louis Stevenson.']
['What does forgetting refer to?', 'Forgetting refers to loss of information from long-term memory.']
['What are some common causes of forgetting?', 'We all forget things, like a loved one’s birthday, someone’s name, or where we put our car keys.']
['What happens when you forget something?', 'As you’ve come to see, memory is fragile, and forgetting can be frustrating and even embarrassing.']
['What does the article mainly look at?', 'To answer this question, we will look at several perspectives on forgetting.']
['What is encoding failure?', 'Sometimes memory loss happens before the actual memory process begins, which is encoding failure.']
['What happens after the actual memory process begins?', 'This would be like trying to find a book on your e-reader that you never actually purchased and downloaded.']

['Does the e-reader have to be purchased and downloaded?', 'Often, in order to remember something, we must pay attention to the details and actively work to process the information (effortful encoding).']
['Is there anything else interesting?', 'Lots of times we don’t do this.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'For instance, think of how many times in your life you’ve seen a penny.']
['What does the experiment find?', 'When researchers Raymond Nickerson and Marilyn Adams (1979) asked this question, they found that most Americans don’t know which one it is.']
['Why do people forget which one it is?', 'The reason is most likely encoding failure.']
['What do we do to encode the details?', 'Most of us never encode the details of the penny.']
['Do we just encode enough information?', 'We only encode enough information to be able to distinguish it from other coins.']
['Why does this matter?', 'If we don’t encode the information, then it’s not in our long-term memory, so we will not be able to remember it.']
['What kind of memory errors do we make?', 'Psychologist Daniel Schacter (2001), a well-known memory researcher, offers seven ways our memories fail us.']
['What are the seven ways our memories fail us?', 'He calls them the seven sins of memory and categorizes them into three groups: forgetting, distortion, and intrusion.']
['What are the occurrences of Memory Errors?', 'Let’s look at the first sin of the forgetting errors: transience, which means that memories can fade over time.']
['How do they fade over time?', 'Here’s an example of how this happens.']
['What was the example of an example of transience?', 'Nathan’s English teacher has assigned his students to read the novel To Kill a Mockingbird.']
["What is Nathan's response to his teacher's assignment?", 'Nathan comes home from school and tells his mom he has to read this book for class.']
["How does Nathan's mom react to this?", '“Oh, I loved that book!” she says.']
['What did she say?', 'Nathan asks her what the book is about, and after some hesitation she says, “Well . . .']

['What is the book about?', 'I know I read the book in high school, and I remember that one of the main characters is named Scout, and her father is an attorney, but I honestly don’t remember anything else.”']
['What happens next?', 'Nathan wonders if his mother actually read the book, and his mother is surprised she can’t recall the plot.']
['How does this work?', 'What is going on here is storage decay: unused information tends to fade with the passage of time.']
['Who is the psychologist?', 'In 1885, German psychologist Hermann Ebbinghaus analyzed the process of memorization.']
['How did he analyze it?', 'First, he memorized lists of nonsense syllables.']
['Why did he do this?', 'Then he measured how much he learned (retained) when he attempted to relearn each list.']
['What time period was this?', 'He tested himself over different periods of time from 20 minutes later to 30 days later.']
['What was the result?', 'The result is his famous forgetting curve.']
['What else was he testing?', 'Due to storage decay, an average person will lose 50% of the memorized information after 20 minutes and 70% of the information after 24 hours (Ebbinghaus, 1885/1964).']
['How does the forgetting curve work?', 'Your memory for new information decays quickly and then eventually levels out.']
['How do you feel about the memory errors?', 'You probably answered yes to at least one, if not all, of these examples—but don’t worry, you are not alone.']

['Can you tell me something about the examples?', 'We are all prone to committing the memory error known as absentmindedness, which describes lapses in memory caused by breaks in attention or our focus being somewhere else.']
['Does it matter what the movie is about?', '“I just streamed this movie called Oblivion, and it had that famous actor in it.']
['What famous movie has that actor been in?', 'He’s been in all of those movies, like The Shawshank Redemption and The Dark Knight trilogy.']
['Did he have any awards?', 'I think he’s even won an Oscar.']
["Why does that actor's name elude me?", 'Oh gosh, I can picture his face in my mind, and hear his distinctive voice, but I just can’t think of his name!']
['Are you annoyed at all that I can’t remember his name?', 'This is going to bug me until I can remember it!”']
["Are you surprised by the fact that you can’t remember someone's name?", 'This particular error can be so frustrating because you have the information right on the tip of your tongue.']
['Did you know that blocking happens to about 50% of the population?', 'If so, you’ve committed the error known as blocking: you can’t access stored information.']
['', 'Now let’s take a look at the three errors of distortion: misattribution, suggestibility, and bias.']
['What does misattribution mean?', 'Misattribution happens when you confuse the source of your information.']
['What do you mean by suggestibility?', 'Let’s say Alejandra was dating Lucia and they saw the first Hobbit movie together.']
['What does that mean?', 'Then they broke up and Alejandra saw the second Hobbit movie with someone else.']
['What does this mean?', 'Later that year, Alejandra and Lucia get back together.']

['What does this mean?', 'One day, they are discussing how the Hobbit books and movies are different and Alejandra says to Lucia, “I loved watching the second movie with you and seeing you jump out of your seat during that super scary part.”']
['What does this mean?', 'When Lucia responded with a puzzled and then angry look, Alejandra realized she’d committed the error of misattribution.']
['', 'This is exactly what happened to Donald Thomson.']
['What is the second distortion error?', 'The second distortion error is suggestibility.']
['How does suggestibility differ from misattribution?', 'Suggestibility is similar to misattribution, since it also involves false memories, but it’s different.']

['What is the difference between suggestibility and misattribution?', 'With misattribution you create the false memory entirely on your own, which is what the victim did in the Donald Thomson case above.']
['What can cause suggestibility?', 'With suggestibility, it comes from someone else, such as a therapist or police interviewer asking leading questions of a witness during an interview.']
['What is the final distortion error?', 'Memories can also be affected by bias, which is the final distortion error.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'Schacter (2001) says that your feelings and view of the world can actually distort your memory of past events.']
['What is one type of bias?', 'There are several types of bias:']
['What is a stereotype?', 'Stereotypical bias involves racial and gender biases.']

['What is a typical bias?', 'For example, when Asian American and European American research participants were presented with a list of names, they more frequently incorrectly remembered typical African American names such as Jamal and Tyrone to be associated with the occupation basketball player, and they more frequently incorrectly remembered typical']
['American', 'White names such as Greg and Howard to be associated with the occupation of politician (Payne, Jacoby, & Lambert, 2004).']
['What is an egocentric bias?', 'Egocentric bias involves enhancing our memories of the past (Payne et al., 2004).']
['What is hindsight bias?', 'Hindsight bias happens when we think an outcome was inevitable after the fact.']
['What is a consequence of hindsight bias?', 'This is the “I knew it all along” phenomenon.']
['What is a factor that causes hindsight bias?', 'The reconstructive nature of memory contributes to hindsight bias (Carli, 1999).']
['What are some other examples of reconstructive memory?', 'We remember untrue events that seem to confirm that we knew the outcome all along.']

['What does persistent forgetting mean?', 'When you keep remembering something, to the point where you can’t “get it out of your head” and it interferes with your ability to concentrate on other things, it is called persistence.']
['Why does forgetting last so long?', 'It’s Schacter’s seventh and last memory error.']
['What causes memory error?', 'It’s actually a failure of our memory system because we involuntarily recall unwanted memories, particularly unpleasant ones.']

['What are examples of unpleasant memories?', 'For instance, you witness a horrific car accident on the way to work one morning, and you can’t concentrate on work because you keep remembering the scene.']
['What is interference?', 'Sometimes information is stored in our memory, but for some reason it is inaccessible.']
['What can cause this?', 'This is known as interference, and there are two types: proactive interference and retroactive interference.']
['What are these examples of?', 'These are examples of proactive interference: when old information hinders the recall of newly learned information.']
['What else does retroactive interference involve?', 'Retroactive interference happens when information learned more recently hinders the recall of older information.']
['What other examples of interference are available?', 'For example, this week you are studying about memory and learn about the Ebbinghaus forgetting curve.']

['What happened after this?', "Next week you study lifespan development and learn about Erikson's theory of psychosocial development, but thereafter have trouble remembering Ebbinghaus's work because you can only remember Erickson's theory."]

['What is your main point of interest in the study material?', 'Most of us suffer from memory failures of one kind or another, and most of us would like to improve our memories so that we don’t forget where we put the car keys or, more importantly, the material we need to know for an exam.']
['What are the things you want to study about?', 'In this section, we’ll look at some ways to help you remember better, and at some strategies for more effective studying.']
['How can you help your memory?', 'To help make sure information goes from short-term memory to long-term memory, you can use memory-enhancing strategies.']
['What are some strategies?', 'One strategy is rehearsal, or the conscious repetition of information to be remembered (Craik & Watkins, 1973).']
['Does this work?', 'Think about how you learned your multiplication tables as a child.']
['What did you recall?', 'You may recall that 6 x 6 = 36, 6 x 7 = 42, and 6 x 8 = 48.']
['What did you do to recall them?', 'Memorizing these facts is rehearsal.']
['Are there any additional strategies?', 'Another strategy is chunking: you organize information into manageable bits or chunks (Bodie, Powers, & Fitch-Hauser, 2006).']
['How can chunking help memory?', 'Chunking is useful when trying to remember information like dates and phone numbers.']
['What is an example of chunking?', 'Instead of trying to remember 5205550467, you remember the number as 520-555-0467.']

['What other strategies are discussed?', 'So, if you met an interesting person at a party and you wanted to remember his phone number, you would naturally chunk it, and you could repeat the number over and over, which is the rehearsal strategy.']

['How can you enhance memory?', 'You could also enhance memory by using elaborative rehearsal: a technique in which you think about the meaning of new information and its relation to knowledge already stored in your memory (Tigner, 1999).']
['What happens if you think about the relation to knowledge already stored?', 'Elaborative rehearsal involves both linking the information to knowledge already stored and repeating the information.']
['Does repeating the information help recall it?', 'For example, in this case, you could remember that 520 is an area code for Arizona and the person you met is from Arizona.']
['How can you link the two pieces of information together?', 'This would help you better remember the 520 prefix.']
['What happens after you remember the information?', 'If the information is retained, it goes into long-term memory.']
['What are mnemonic devices?', 'Mnemonic devices are memory aids that help us organize information for encoding.']
['What is a typical usage of these devices?', 'They are especially useful when we want to recall larger bits of information such as steps, stages, phases, and parts of a system (Bellezza, 1981).']
['What is an example of using these devices?', 'Brian needs to learn the order of the planets in the solar system, but he’s having a hard time remembering the correct order.']
["What is his friend's suggestion?", 'His friend Kelly suggests a mnemonic device that can help him remember.']

['Does it work?', 'Kelly tells Brian to simply remember the name Mr. VEM J. SUN, and he can easily recall the correct order of the planets: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune.']
['Can you think of other examples?', 'You might use a mnemonic device to help you remember someone’s name, a mathematical formula, or the order of mathematical operations.']
['How does he recall their names?', 'It seems the more vivid or unusual the mnemonic, the easier it is to remember.']
['How do we use an mnemonic?', 'The key to using any mnemonic successfully is to find a strategy that works for you.']
['How can you improve your memory?', 'Some other strategies that are used to improve memory include expressive writing and saying words aloud.']
['How can expressive writing improve memory?', 'Expressive writing helps boost your short-term memory, particularly if you write about a traumatic experience in your life.']
['What else is known about expressive writing?', 'Masao Yogo and Shuji Fujihara (2008) had participants write for 20-minute intervals several times per month.']
['What did they have them write about?', 'The participants were instructed to write about a traumatic experience, their best possible future selves, or a trivial topic.']

['Did they find anything?', 'The researchers found that this simple writing task increased short-term memory capacity after five weeks, but only for the participants who wrote about traumatic experiences.']
['Was this explanation good?', 'Psychologists can’t explain why this writing task works, but it does.']
['How do you remember names?', 'Simply say them out loud to yourself.']

['What else can you say to yourself that would work?', 'A series of studies (MacLeod, Gopie, Hourihan, Neary, & Ozubko, 2010) found that saying a word out loud improves your memory for the word because it increases the word’s distinctiveness.']
['Why does it increase its distinctiveness?', 'This technique works equally well if you just mouth the words.']
['What other ways did MacLeod and his team say you can remember names?', 'Using these techniques increased participants’ memory for the words by more than 10%.']
['How does this work?', 'These techniques can also be used to help you study.']
['What did you study?', 'Based on the information presented in this chapter, here are some strategies and suggestions to help you hone your study techniques.']
['What is the most important thing you learned?', 'The key with any of these strategies is to figure out what works best for you.']
['What does this study material include?', 'Use elaborative rehearsal:']
['Who wrote this article?', 'In a famous article, Fergus Craik and Robert Lockhart (1972) discussed their belief that information we process more deeply goes into long-term memory.']
['What is their theory?', 'Their theory is called levels of processing.']

['What can we do to increase long-term memory?', 'If we want to remember a piece of information, we should think about it more deeply and link it to other information and memories to make it more meaningful.']

['What is an example?', 'For example, if we are trying to remember that the hippocampus is involved with memory processing, we might envision a hippopotamus with excellent memory and then we could better remember the hippocampus.']
['What can we do to use our memory in other ways?', 'Apply the self-reference effect:']

['What does self-reference do?', 'As you go through the process of elaborative rehearsal, it would be even more beneficial to make the material you are trying to memorize personally meaningful to you.']
['What can be done with the material that you are trying to memorize?', 'In other words, make use of the self-reference effect.']
['What can you do when trying to remember the material?', 'Write notes in your own words.']
['Why do you have to write in your own words?', 'Write definitions from the text, and then rewrite them in your own words.']
['What can you do when trying to remember the material?', 'Relate the material to something you have already learned for another class, or think how you can apply the concepts to your own life.']
['What is the purpose of this?', 'When you do this, you are building a web of retrieval cues that will help you access the material when you want to remember it.']
['What else can we do to use our memory?', 'Use distributed practice: Study across time in short durations rather than trying to cram it all in at once.']
['Why do we need to spread the studying out?', 'Memory consolidation takes time, and studying across time allows time for memories to consolidate.']

['Why can it cause this?', 'In addition, cramming can cause the links between concepts to become so active that you get stuck in a link, and it prevents you from accessing the rest of the information that you learned.']
['How can we practice?', 'Rehearse, rehearse, rehearse: Review the material over time, in spaced and organized study sessions.']
['What else can we do to remember?', 'Organize and study your notes, and take practice quizzes/exams.']
['What else can we do?', 'Link the new information to other information you already know well.']
['What else can we do?', 'Study efficiently: Students are great highlighters, but highlighting is not very efficient because students spend too much time studying the things they already learned.']
['What else can we do?', 'Instead of highlighting, use index cards.']
['What else can we do?', 'When you study, separate your cards into those you got right and those you got wrong.']
['What else can we do?', 'Study the ones you got wrong and keep sorting.']
['What happens next?', 'Eventually, all your cards will be in the pile you answered correctly.']
['What else can we do?', 'Be aware of interference:']
['', 'To reduce the likelihood of interference, study during a quiet time without interruptions or distractions (like television or music).']
['What else can we do?', 'Keep moving:']
['You should stay active.', 'Research suggests that regular aerobic exercise (anything that gets your heart rate elevated) is beneficial for memory (van Praag, 2008).']
['What is aerobic exercise?', 'Aerobic exercise promotes neurogenesis: the growth of new brain cells in the hippocampus, an area of the brain known to play a role in memory and learning.']
['What else can we do?', 'Get enough sleep:']
['The brain needs rest and recovery.', 'While you are sleeping, your brain is still at work.']
['What does it do?', 'During sleep the brain organizes and consolidates information to be stored in long-term memory (Abel & Bäuml, 2013).']
['What else can we do?', 'Make use of mnemonic devices:']
['Using memory devices is a proven method for improving your learning.', 'As you learned earlier in this chapter, mnemonic devices often help us to remember and recall information.']
['What are some examples?', 'There are different types of mnemonic devices, such as the acronym.']
['What is an acronym?', 'An acronym is a word formed by the first letter of each of the words you want to remember.']
['What kind of examples are there?', 'For example, even if you live near one, you might have difficulty recalling the names of all five Great Lakes.']
['What is the acronym for these?', 'HOMES is an acronym that represents Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, and Superior: the five Great Lakes.']
['What else can we do to improve our memory?', 'Another type of mnemonic device is an acrostic: you make a phrase of all the first letters of the words.']

['What are some examples?', 'For example, if you are taking a math test and you are having difficulty remembering the order of operations, recalling the following sentence will help you: “Please Excuse My Dear Aunt Sally,” because the order of mathematical operations is Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication, Division, Addition, Subtraction.']
['What are some other types of devices?', 'There also are jingles, which are rhyming tunes that contain key words related to the concept, such as i before e, except after c.']
['What is the title of a poem that you would suggest that describes the development of an infant', 'In this poem, William Wordsworth writes, “the child is father of the man.”']
['What does he mean by this', 'Wordsworth might be suggesting that the person he is as an adult depends largely on the experiences he had in childhood.']
['What are the things we learn in the womb?', 'Consider the following questions:']

['what is lifespan development?', 'These are the types of questions developmental psychologists try to answer, by studying how humans change and grow from conception through childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and death.']

['how is lifespan development different from childhood?', 'They view development as a lifelong process that can be studied scientifically across three developmental domains—physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development.']
['what is physical development?', 'Physical development involves growth and changes in the body and brain, the senses, motor skills, and health and wellness.']
['what is cognitive development?', 'Cognitive development involves learning, attention, memory, language, thinking, reasoning, and creativity.']
['what is psychosocial development?', 'Psychosocial development involves emotions, personality, and social relationships.']
['what else can you tell me about the three developmental domains?', 'We refer to these domains throughout the chapter.']
['Which of the following domains of development is discussed?', 'Across these three domains—physical, cognitive, and psychosocial—the normative approach to development is also discussed.']
['What is this normative approach?', 'This approach asks, “What is normal development?”']

['What is the criteria used to determine normal development?', 'In the early decades of the 20th century, normative psychologists studied large numbers of children at various ages to determine norms (i.e., average ages) of when most children reach specific developmental milestones in each of the three domains (Gesell, 1933, 1939, 1940; Gesell & Ilg, 1946; Hall, 1904).']

['How do the age-related averages determine developmental milestones?', 'Although children develop at slightly different rates, we can use these age-related averages as general guidelines to compare children with same-age peers to determine the approximate ages they should reach specific normative events called developmental milestones (e.g., crawling, walking, writing, dressing, naming colors, speaking in sentences, and starting puberty).']
['How many universal events are there in lifespan development?', 'Not all normative events are universal, meaning they are not experienced by all individuals across all cultures.']

['Do there are any other universal events?', 'Biological milestones, such as puberty, tend to be universal, but social milestones, such as the age when children begin formal schooling, are not necessarily universal; instead, they affect most individuals in a particular culture (Gesell & Ilg, 1946).']

['What is an example of a social milestone?', 'For example, in developed countries children begin school around 5 or 6 years old, but in developing countries, like Nigeria, children often enter school at an advanced age, if at all (Huebler, 2005; United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization [UNESCO], 2013).']
['What is the normative approach?', 'To better understand the normative approach, imagine two new mothers, Louisa and Kimberly, who are close friends and have children around the same age.']
['What age are their children?', 'Louisa’s daughter is 14 months old, and Kimberly’s son is 12 months old.']
['How is the normative approach applied?', 'According to the normative approach, the average age a child starts to walk is 12 months.']
['Why should they choose the normative approach?', 'However, at 14 months Louisa’s daughter still isn’t walking.']
['What should Louisa do?', 'She tells Kimberly she is worried that something might be wrong with her baby.']
['How does Kimberly feel?', 'Kimberly is surprised because her son started walking when he was only 10 months old.']
['What are the theoretical approaches?', 'There are many different theoretical approaches regarding human development.']

['How do these theoretical approaches differ?', 'As we evaluate them in this chapter, recall that developmental psychology focuses on how people change, and keep in mind that all the approaches that we present in this chapter address questions of change:']
['What is continuous development?', 'Continuous development views development as a cumulative process, gradually improving on existing skills.']
['What kind of development does that mean?', 'With this type of development, there is gradual change.']
['How does the change happen?', 'Consider, for example, a child’s physical growth: adding inches to height year by year.']
['What is the opposite of continuous development?', 'In contrast, theorists who view development as discontinuous believe that development takes place in unique stages:']
['What kind of stages?', 'It occurs at specific times or ages.']
['What else is significant about continuous development?', 'With this type of development, the change is more sudden, such as an infant’s ability to conceive object permanence.']
['What are the stage theories?', 'Stage theories hold that the sequence of development is universal.']
['Is that the case?', 'For example, in cross-cultural studies of language development, children from around the world reach language milestones in a similar sequence (Gleitman & Newport, 1995).']
['Does this show that the development is universal?', 'Infants in all cultures coo before they babble.']
['What age do they begin to babble?', 'They begin babbling at about the same age and utter their first word around 12 months old.']
['What else do you find interesting in the article?', 'Yet we live in diverse contexts that have a unique effect on each of us.']
['What else does it say?', 'For example, researchers once believed that motor development follows one course for all children regardless of culture.']

['Did they go back and revisit that theory?', 'However, child care practices vary by culture, and different practices have been found to accelerate or inhibit achievement of developmental milestones such as sitting, crawling, and walking (Karasik, Adolph, Tamis-LeMonda, & Bornstein, 2010).']
['What are some examples of the different courses that people can take?', 'For instance, let’s look at the Aché society in Paraguay.']
['What does their way of life consist of?', 'They spend a significant amount of time foraging in forests.']

['What are some of their other special characteristics?', 'While foraging, Aché mothers carry their young children, rarely putting them down in order to protect them from getting hurt in the forest.']
['What does this do?', 'Consequently, their children walk much later:']
['What else does this have to do with their children?', 'They walk around 23–25 months old, in comparison to infants in Western cultures who begin to walk around 12 months old.']

['Do they have problems learning to walk?', 'However, as Aché children become older, they are allowed more freedom to move about, and by about age 9, their motor skills surpass those of U.S. children of the same age: Aché children are able to climb trees up to 25 feet tall and use machetes to chop their way through the forest (Kaplan & Dove, 1987).']
['What is one of the main takeaways from this article?', 'As you can see, our development is influenced by multiple contexts, so the timing of basic motor functions may vary across cultures.']
['Is that true?', 'However, the functions themselves are present in all societies.']
['What is the study called?', 'This longstanding question is known in psychology as the nature versus nurture debate.']

['What does the debate entail?', 'It seeks to understand how our personalities and traits are the product of our genetic makeup and biological factors, and how they are shaped by our environment, including our guardians, peers, and culture.']
['What is this about?', 'We are all born with specific genetic traits inherited from our parents, such as eye color, height, and certain personality traits.']
['What else do we inherit?', 'Beyond our basic genotype, however, there is a deep interaction between our genes and our environment:']

['What does this say?', 'Our unique experiences in our environment influence whether and how particular traits are expressed, and at the same time, our genes influence how we interact with our environment (Diamond, 2009; Lobo, 2008).']

['What about other genes?', 'This chapter will show that there is a reciprocal interaction between nature and nurture as they both shape who we become, but the debate continues as to the relative contributions of each.']
['What is lifespan theory?', 'There are many theories regarding how babies and children grow and develop into happy, healthy adults.']
['What are these theories?', 'We explore several of these theories in this section.']
['What is the Psychosexual Theory of Development?', 'Sigmund Freud (1856–1939) believed that personality develops during early childhood.']
['What does he believe?', 'For Freud, childhood experiences shape our personalities and behavior as adults.']

['What stage is he referring to?', 'Freud viewed development as discontinuous; he believed that each of us must pass through a series of stages during childhood, and that if we lack proper nurturance and parenting during a stage, we may become stuck, or fixated, in that stage.']
['Is there anything else significant about this theory?', 'Freud’s stages are called the stages of psychosexual development.']

['What is a stage of psychosexual development?', 'According to Freud, children’s pleasure-seeking urges are focused on a different area of the body, called an erogenous zone, at each of the five stages of development: oral, anal, phallic, latency, and genital.']

['What did Freud believe about sexuality?', 'While most of Freud’s ideas have not found support in modern research, we cannot discount the contributions that Freud has made to the field of psychology.']

['How did his theory of sexuality impact psychology?', "Psychologists today dispute Freud's psychosexual stages as a legitimate explanation for how one's personality develops, but what we can take away from Freud’s theory is that personality is shaped, in some part, by experiences we have in childhood."]
['What were the stages?', 'These stages are discussed in detail in the chapter on personality.']
['Who invented this theory?', 'Erik Erikson (1902–1994), another stage theorist, took Freud’s theory and modified it as psychosocial theory.']
['What was different about his theory?', 'Erikson’s psychosocial development theory emphasizes the social nature of our development rather than its sexual nature.']
['What are some other theories?', 'While Freud believed that personality is shaped only in childhood, Erikson proposed that personality development takes place all through the lifespan.']
['Why is this?', 'Erikson suggested that how we interact with others is what affects our sense of self, or what he called the ego identity.']
["What is Erikson's motivation theory?", 'Erikson proposed that we are motivated by a need to achieve competence in certain areas of our lives.']
['What is the stage of development?', 'According to psychosocial theory, we experience eight stages of development over our lifespan, from infancy through late adulthood.']
['What do each stage involve?', 'At each stage there is a conflict, or task, that we need to resolve.']
['What do the tasks require to complete?', 'Successful completion of each developmental task results in a sense of competence and a healthy personality.']
['Why do we need to master the tasks?', 'Failure to master these tasks leads to feelings of inadequacy.']
['What is psychosocial theory of development?', 'According to Erikson (1963), trust is the basis of our development during infancy (birth to 12 months).']
['What does Erikson think about developmental stages?', 'Therefore, the primary task of this stage is trust versus mistrust.']

['What helps to develop trust?', 'Infants are dependent upon their caregivers, so caregivers who are responsive and sensitive to their infant’s needs help their baby to develop a sense of trust; their baby will see the world as a safe, predictable place.']

['What happens when caregivers are unresponsive?', 'Unresponsive caregivers who do not meet their baby’s needs can engender feelings of anxiety, fear, and mistrust; their baby may see the world as unpredictable.']
