['What are some examples of psychosocial theory?', 'As toddlers (ages 1–3 years) begin to explore their world, they learn that they can control their actions and act on the environment to get results.']
['What are some examples of results they get?', 'They begin to show clear preferences for certain elements of the environment, such as food, toys, and clothing.']
['What are some more examples of psychosocial theory?', 'A toddler’s main task is to resolve the issue of autonomy versus shame and doubt, by working to establish independence.']
['What is the name of that stage?', 'This is the “me do it” stage.']
['How does the child determine independence?', 'For example, we might observe a budding sense of autonomy in a 2-year-old child who wants to choose her clothes and dress herself.']
['Why does she want to choose her clothes?', 'Although her outfits might not be appropriate for the situation, her input in such basic decisions has an effect on her sense of independence.']
['Why does she want to choose her clothes?', 'If denied the opportunity to act on her environment, she may begin to doubt her abilities, which could lead to low self-esteem and feelings of shame.']

['How did they develop this idea?', 'Once children reach the preschool stage (ages 3–6 years), they are capable of initiating activities and asserting control over their world through social interactions and play.']
['What does Erikson say about the toddlers and preschoolers?', 'According to Erikson, preschool children must resolve the task of initiative versus guilt.']
['What does he say is the best way to accomplish this task?', 'By learning to plan and achieve goals while interacting with others, preschool children can master this task.']
['Why would they choose to master this task?', 'Those who do will develop self-confidence and feel a sense of purpose.']
["What does Erikson say about those who don't accomplish this task?", 'Those who are unsuccessful at this stage—with their initiative misfiring or stifled—may develop feelings of guilt.']
['What is the task of industry versus inferiority?', 'During the elementary school stage (ages 7–11), children face the task of industry versus inferiority.']
['Why is it that?', 'Children begin to compare themselves to their peers to see how they measure up.']

['What else does the task of industry versus inferiority have to do with?', 'They either develop a sense of pride and accomplishment in their schoolwork, sports, social activities, and family life, or they feel inferior and inadequate when they don’t measure up.']
['What does Psychosocial Theory of Development deal with?', 'In adolescence (ages 12–18), children face the task of identity versus role confusion.']
['What are some characteristics of the psychosocial theory?', 'According to Erikson, an adolescent’s main task is developing a sense of self.']
['What are some characteristics of the self?', 'Adolescents struggle with questions such as “Who am I?” and “What do I want to do with my life?”']
['What happens during identity-versus-role confusion?', 'Along the way, most adolescents try on many different selves to see which ones fit.']

['What can you do to help someone with adolescent identity-versus-rol', 'Adolescents who are successful at this stage have a strong sense of identity and are able to remain true to their beliefs and values in the face of problems and other people’s perspectives.']
['What happens if adolescent is unsuccessful in this stage?', 'These teens will have a weak sense of self and experience role confusion.']
['How does that effect them?', 'They are unsure of their identity and confused about the future.']
['What kind of development is this?', 'People in early adulthood (i.e., 20s through early 40s) are concerned with intimacy versus isolation.']
['What else can you tell me about this theory?', 'After we have developed a sense of self in adolescence, we are ready to share our life with others.']
['What did Erikson say about this?', 'Erikson said that we must have a strong sense of self before developing intimate relationships with others.']
['Can you tell me more about this theory?', 'Adults who do not develop a positive self-concept in adolescence may experience feelings of loneliness and emotional isolation.']
['What do you think will be the biggest challenge of the next lesson?', 'When people reach their 40s, they enter the time known as middle adulthood, which extends to the mid-60s.']
['What is the social task?', 'The social task of middle adulthood is generativity versus stagnation.']

['How does this relate to the lesson?', 'Generativity involves finding your life’s work and contributing to the development of others, through activities such as volunteering, mentoring, and raising children.']

["How else does it contribute to people's lives?", 'Those who do not master this task may experience stagnation, having little connection with others and little interest in productivity and self-improvement.']
['What is Late Adulthood?', 'From the mid-60s to the end of life, we are in the period of development known as late adulthood.']
['What does Erikson think the task of this stage is?', 'Erikson’s task at this stage is called integrity versus despair.']
['What does he mean by integrity versus despair?', 'He said that people in late adulthood reflect on their lives and feel either a sense of satisfaction or a sense of failure.']
['What does satisfaction entail?', 'People who feel proud of their accomplishments feel a sense of integrity, and they can look back on their lives with few regrets.']
['How about the feeling of failure?', 'However, people who are not successful at this stage may feel as if their life has been wasted.']
['What does failure entail?', 'They focus on what “would have,” “should have,” and “could have” been.']
['What happens to them?', 'They face the end of their lives with feelings of bitterness, depression, and despair.']
['What does Erikson have to say about stages?', 'Table 9.1 summarizes the stages of Erikson’s theory.']
['Who else developed this theory?', 'Jean Piaget (1896–1980) is another stage theorist who studied childhood development.']
['What was his theory?', 'Instead of approaching development from a psychoanalytical or psychosocial perspective, Piaget focused on children’s cognitive growth.']
['What else did he believe?', 'He believed that thinking is a central aspect of development and that children are naturally inquisitive.']
['Was there any criticism?', 'However, he said that children do not think and reason like adults (Piaget, 1930, 1932).']

['What was his theory of cognitive development?', 'His theory of cognitive development holds that our cognitive abilities develop through specific stages, which exemplifies the discontinuity approach to development.']
['How does the discontinuity approach work?', 'As we progress to a new stage, there is a distinct shift in how we think and reason.']
['What kind of schemata does Piaget study?', 'Piaget said that children develop schemata to help them understand the world.']
['What is a schema?', 'Schemata are concepts (mental models) that are used to help us categorize and interpret information.']
['What can we say about schemata?', 'By the time children have reached adulthood, they have created schemata for almost everything.']
['How do schemata change?', 'When children learn new information, they adjust their schemata through two processes: assimilation and accommodation.']

['What does it mean that they assimilate?', 'First, they assimilate new information or experiences in terms of their current schemata: assimilation is when they take in information that is comparable to what they already know.']
['What is accommodation?', 'Accommodation describes when they change their schemata based on new information.']
['How do schemata change over time?', 'This process continues as children interact with their environment.']
["How does this help in the development of a child's mental schema?", 'For example, 2-year-old Abdul learned the schema for dogs because his family has a Labrador retriever.']
['What happens when Abdul sees dogs?', 'When Abdul sees other dogs in his picture books, he says, “Look mommy, dog!”']
["Why does he say, 'Look mommy, dog!’?", 'Thus, he has assimilated them into his schema for dogs.']
["What else happened in Abdul's case?", 'One day, Abdul sees a sheep for the first time and says, “Look mommy, dog!”']
['What else can we conclude from the example?', 'Having a basic schema that a dog is an animal with four legs and fur, Abdul thinks all furry, four-legged creatures are dogs.']

['What happens in the next stages of development?', 'When Abdul’s mom tells him that the animal he sees is a sheep, not a dog, Abdul must accommodate his schema for dogs to include more information based on his new experiences.']
["What was the problem with Abdul's schema for dog?", 'Abdul’s schema for dog was too broad, since not all furry, four-legged creatures are dogs.']
['Why did he need to change the schema?', 'He now modifies his schema for dogs and forms a new one for sheep.']
['what was the first thing you learned in your study?', 'Like Freud and Erikson, Piaget thought development unfolds in a series of stages approximately associated with age ranges.']
['what were the stages?', 'He proposed a theory of cognitive development that unfolds in four stages: sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational.']
['What is the first stage of cognitive development?', 'The first stage is the sensorimotor stage, which lasts from birth to about 2 years old.']
['What happens during this stage?', 'During this stage, children learn about the world through their senses and motor behavior.']

['How do they learn about the world?', 'Young children put objects in their mouths to see if the items are edible, and once they can grasp objects, they may shake or bang them to see if they make sounds.']

['What other things happen during this stage?', 'Between 5 and 8 months old, the child develops object permanence, which is the understanding that even if something is out of sight, it still exists (Bogartz, Shinskey, & Schilling, 2000).']
['Does the infant know it has been removed from sight?', 'According to Piaget, young infants do not remember an object after it has been removed from sight.']
["What was Piaget's experiment?", 'Piaget studied infants’ reactions when a toy was first shown to an infant and then hidden under a blanket.']

['How did the infant react?', 'Infants who had already developed object permanence would reach for the hidden toy, indicating that they knew it still existed, whereas infants who had not developed object permanence would appear confused.']

['What is the cognitive theory of development about?', 'In Piaget’s view, around the same time children develop object permanence, they also begin to exhibit stranger anxiety, which is a fear of unfamiliar people.']

['How do children exhibit stranger anxiety?', 'Babies may demonstrate this by crying and turning away from a stranger, by clinging to a caregiver, or by attempting to reach their arms toward familiar faces such as parents.']

['What happens after a child shows these signs?', 'Stranger anxiety results when a child is unable to assimilate the stranger into an existing schema; therefore, she can’t predict what her experience with that stranger will be like, which results in a fear response.']
['What is the second stage?', 'Piaget’s second stage is the preoperational stage, which is from approximately 2 to 7 years old.']
['What is the third stage?', 'In this stage, children can use symbols to represent words, images, and ideas, which is why children in this stage engage in pretend play.']
['What kind of pretend play?', 'A child’s arms might become airplane wings as they zoom around the room, or a child with a stick might become a brave knight with a sword.']

['What else do you find interesting?', 'Children also begin to use language in the preoperational stage, but they cannot understand adult logic or mentally manipulate information (the term operational refers to logical manipulation of information, so children at this stage are considered to be pre-operational).']
['What can they understand about logic?', 'Children’s logic is based on their own personal knowledge of the world so far, rather than on conventional knowledge.']
['Does the theory apply to children of different ages?', 'For example, dad gave a slice of pizza to 10-year-old Keiko and another slice to her 3-year-old brother, Kenny.']
['What happened to Kenny?', 'Kenny’s pizza slice was cut into five pieces, so Kenny told his sister that he got more pizza than she did.']

['What did he learn?', 'Children in this stage cannot perform mental operations because they have not developed an understanding of conservation, which is the idea that even if you change the appearance of something, it is still equal in size as long as nothing has been removed or added.']

['What are the three stages of development mentioned in this document?', 'During this stage, we also expect children to display egocentrism, which means that the child is not able to take the perspective of others.']
['How does the child display egocentrism?', 'A child at this stage thinks that everyone sees, thinks, and feels just as they do.']
['What are the stages of development?', 'Let’s look at Kenny and Keiko again.']
['What are they doing to learn about others?', 'Keiko’s birthday is coming up, so their mom takes Kenny to the toy store to choose a present for his sister.']
['What does Kenny do?', 'He selects an Iron Man action figure for her, thinking that if he likes the toy, his sister will too.']
['What else can you tell me about the stages of development?', 'An egocentric child is not able to infer the perspective of other people and instead attributes his own perspective.']
['what are the 3 stages of cognitive development?', 'Piaget’s third stage is the concrete operational stage, which occurs from about 7 to 11 years old.']

['what else is important about this stage?', 'In this stage, children can think logically about real (concrete) events; they have a firm grasp on the use of numbers and start to employ memory strategies.']

['What else is interesting?', 'They can perform mathematical operations and understand transformations, such as addition is the opposite of subtraction, and multiplication is the opposite of division.']
['What else is interesting?', 'In this stage, children also master the concept of conservation: Even if something changes shape, its mass, volume, and number stay the same.']
['what does this mean?', 'For example, if you pour water from a tall, thin glass to a short, fat glass, you still have the same amount of water.']

['What is concrete operational?', 'Children in the concrete operational stage also understand the principle of reversibility, which means that objects can be changed and then returned back to their original form or condition.']
["Why can't you change water into water?", 'Take, for example, water that you poured into the short, fat glass:']
['Is it ever the same amount that was in the tall, thin glass?', 'You can pour water from the fat glass back to the thin glass and still have the same amount (minus a couple of drops).']
['What is the last stage of cognitive theory of development?', 'The fourth, and last, stage in Piaget’s theory is the formal operational stage, which is from about age 11 to adulthood.']

['What happens during this stage?', 'Whereas children in the concrete operational stage are able to think logically only about concrete events, children in the formal operational stage can also deal with abstract ideas and hypothetical situations.']
['What else can children do in this stage?', 'Children in this stage can use abstract thinking to problem solve, look at alternative solutions, and test these solutions.']
['What happens in adolescence?', 'In adolescence, a renewed egocentrism occurs.']

['What else happens in the adolescence stage?', 'For example, a 15-year-old with a very small pimple on her face might think it is huge and incredibly visible, under the mistaken impression that others must share her perceptions.']
['What does cognitive mean?', 'Thought.']
['What did Piaget think?', 'As with other major contributors of theories of development, several of Piaget’s ideas have come under criticism based on the results of further research.']

['How has his theory of development been criticized?', 'For example, several contemporary studies support a model of development that is more continuous than Piaget’s discrete stages (Courage & Howe, 2002; Siegler, 2005, 2006).']
['What other critiques were made?', 'Many others suggest that children reach cognitive milestones earlier than Piaget describes (Baillargeon, 2004; de Hevia & Spelke, 2010).']

['What does cognitive theory of development tell us about children?', 'According to Piaget, the highest level of cognitive development is formal operational thought, which develops between 11 and 20 years old.']

['How many levels of cognitive development are there?', 'However, many developmental psychologists disagree with Piaget, suggesting a fifth stage of cognitive development, known as the postformal stage (Basseches, 1984; Commons & Bresette, 2006; Sinnott, 1998).']

['What is the post formal stage?', 'In postformal thinking, decisions are made based on situations and circumstances, and logic is integrated with emotion as adults develop principles that depend on contexts.']

['Can you tell me more about the fifth stage?', 'One way that we can see the difference between an adult in postformal thought and an adolescent in formal operations is in terms of how they handle emotionally charged issues.']
["How does cognitive theory of development influence a person's thinking?", 'It seems that once we reach adulthood our problem solving abilities change:']

['How do our problem solving abilities change?', 'As we attempt to solve problems, we tend to think more deeply about many areas of our lives, such as relationships, work, and politics (Labouvie-Vief & Diehl, 1999).']
['How do we learn from our past experiences?', 'Because of this, postformal thinkers are able to draw on past experiences to help them solve new problems.']
['What is another way that they draw on past experiences to help them solve problems?', 'Problem-solving strategies using postformal thought vary, depending on the situation.']

['What is the most common problem they solve?', 'Adults can recognize, for example, that what seems to be an ideal solution to a problem at work involving a disagreement with a colleague may not be the best solution to a disagreement with a significant other.']
['Who was Lev Vygotsky?', 'Lev Vygotsky was a Russian psychologist who proposed a sociocultural theory of development.']
['How did he propose this theory?', 'He suggested that human development is rooted in one’s culture.']
['What did he mean by that?', 'A child’s social world, for example, forms the basis for the formation of language and thought.']
['What is cultural?', 'The language one speaks and the ways a person thinks about things is dependent on one’s cultural background.']
['What else did he believe?', 'Vygotsky also considered historical influences as key to one’s development.']
['What else was he known for?', 'He was interested in the process of development and the individual’s interactions with their environment (John-Steiner & Mahn, 1996).']
['What kind of tasks do they require?', 'A major task beginning in childhood and continuing into adolescence is discerning right from wrong.']
['Who is Kohlberg?', 'Psychologist Lawrence Kohlberg (1927–1987) extended upon the foundation that Piaget built regarding cognitive development.']
["What is Kohlberg's theory about moral development?", 'Kohlberg believed that moral development, like cognitive development, follows a series of stages.']

['How did he research it?', 'To develop this theory, Kohlberg posed moral dilemmas to people of all ages, and then he analyzed their answers to find evidence of their particular stage of moral development.']

['What are the stages of moral development?', "Before reading about the stages, take a minute to consider how you would answer one of Kohlberg's best-known moral dilemmas, commonly known as the Heinz dilemma:"]
['Who is Kohlberg?', 'Kohlberg was not interested in whether you answer yes or no to the dilemma: Instead, he was interested in the reasoning behind your answer.']

['What is Moral Theory of Development?', 'After presenting people with this and various other moral dilemmas, Kohlberg reviewed people’s responses and placed them in different stages of moral reasoning.']

['what are those stages?', 'According to Kohlberg, an individual progresses from the capacity for pre-conventional morality (before age 9) to the capacity for conventional morality (early adolescence), and toward attaining post-conventional morality (once formal operational thought is attained), which only a few fully achieve.']

['What are some of those levels?', 'Kohlberg placed in the highest stage responses that reflected the reasoning that Heinz should steal the drug because his wife’s life is more important than the pharmacist making money.']
['What is the point of this?', 'The value of a human life overrides the pharmacist’s greed.']

['What is the main idea in this chapter?', 'It is important to realize that even those people who have the most sophisticated, post-conventional reasons for some choices may make other choices for the simplest of pre-conventional reasons.']
['Are there any other theories mentioned?', "Many psychologists agree with Kohlberg's theory of moral development but point out that moral reasoning is very different from moral behavior."]
['What does that mean?', 'In other words, we might “talk the talk,” but not “walk the walk.”']
['What is one important fact in the article?', 'Kohlberg (1969) felt that more men than women move past stage four in their moral development.']
['What did he mean by this?', 'He went on to note that women seem to be deficient in their moral reasoning abilities.']
['Did anyone disagree with Kohlberg?', 'These ideas were not well received by Carol Gilligan, a research assistant of Kohlberg, who consequently developed her own ideas of moral development.']

["What were Gilligan's ideas?", 'In her groundbreaking book, In a Different Voice: Psychological Theory and Women’s Development, Gilligan (1982) criticized her former mentor’s theory because it was based only on upper class']
["What other people were in Kohlberg's study?", 'White men and boys.']
['Did Gilligan disagree with Kohlberg?', 'She argued that women are not deficient in their moral reasoning—she proposed that different genders reason differently.']
['How did Gilligan determine gender differences?', 'Girls and women focus more on staying connected and the importance of interpersonal relationships.']
["What was Gilligan's research about?", 'Therefore, in the Heinz dilemma, many girls and women respond that Heinz should not steal the medicine.']

['What was their reasoning?', 'Their reasoning is that if he steals the medicine, is arrested, and is put in jail, then he and his wife will be separated, and she could die while he is still in prison.']

['What are the three areas of development?', 'As discussed at the beginning of this chapter, developmental psychologists often divide our development into three areas: physical development, cognitive development, and psychosocial development.']
['How do they categorize the development?', 'Mirroring Erikson’s stages, lifespan development is divided into different stages that are based on age.']
['What are these stages?', 'We will discuss prenatal, infant, child, adolescent, and adult development.']
['What is prenatal development?', 'From beginning as a one-cell structure to your birth, your prenatal development occurred in an orderly and delicate sequence.']
['What are the three stages of prenatal development?', 'There are three stages of prenatal development: germinal, embryonic, and fetal.']
['What happens to the developing baby during these three stages?', 'Let’s take a look at what happens to the developing baby in each of these stages.']
['What does genetics have to do with mental disorders?', 'In the discussion of biopsychology earlier in the book, you learned about genetics and DNA.']
['How is DNA passed on to a child?', 'DNA is passed on to the child at the moment of conception.']
['What happens at conception?', 'Conception occurs when sperm fertilizes an egg and forms a zygote.']
['What is a zygote?', 'A zygote begins as a one-cell structure that is created when a sperm and egg merge.']
['What happens in this stage?', 'The genetic makeup and sex of the zygote are set at this point.']
['What happens after that?', 'During the first week after conception, the zygote divides and multiplies, going from a one-cell structure to two cells, then four cells, then eight cells, and so on.']
['What is mitosis?', 'This process of cell division is called mitosis.']
['How does the cell divide?', 'Mitosis is a fragile process, and fewer than one-half of all zygotes survive beyond the first two weeks (Hall, 2004).']
['How many cells do they need to survive?', 'After 5 days of mitosis there are 100 cells, and after 9 months there are billions of cells.']
['What happens after this?', 'As the cells divide, they become more specialized, forming different organs and body parts.']
['What happens next?', 'In the germinal stage, the mass of cells has yet to attach itself to the lining of the mother’s uterus.']
['What happens when it does?', 'Once it does, the next stage begins.']
['What is significant about this?', 'After the zygote divides for about 7–10 days and has 150 cells, it travels down the fallopian tubes and implants itself in the lining of the uterus.']
['What does this implant become?', 'Upon implantation, this multi-cellular organism is called an embryo.']
['What happens after the implant?', 'Now blood vessels grow, forming the placenta.']
['What is the placenta?', 'The placenta is a structure connected to the uterus that provides nourishment and oxygen from the mother to the developing embryo via the umbilical cord.']
['What else occurs in these weeks?', 'Basic structures of the embryo start to develop into areas that will become the head, chest, and abdomen.']
['What happens to the heart?', 'During the embryonic stage, the heart begins to beat and organs form and begin to function.']
['What else happens?', 'The neural tube forms along the back of the embryo, developing into the spinal cord and brain.']
['What was the definition of a fetal stage?', 'When the organism is about nine weeks old, the embryo is called a fetus.']

['what was the most important detail in this passage?', 'At this stage, the fetus is about the size of a kidney bean and begins to take on the recognizable form of a human being as the “tail” begins to disappear.']
['What does the fetal stage involve?', 'From 9–12 weeks, the sex organs begin to differentiate.']
['How long is a human baby at this stage?', 'At about 16 weeks, the fetus is approximately 4.5 inches long.']
['What other features are visible in a human at this stage?', 'Fingers and toes are fully developed, and fingerprints are visible.']
['How much does a human weigh at this stage?', 'By the time the fetus reaches the sixth month of development (24 weeks), it weighs up to 1.4 pounds.']
['What else can you find out about the fetal stage?', 'Hearing has developed, so the fetus can respond to sounds.']

['Why does the fetal stage involve so much development?', 'The internal organs, such as the lungs, heart, stomach, and intestines, have formed enough that a fetus born prematurely at this point has a chance to survive outside of the mother’s womb.']
['How does the brain develop?', 'Throughout the fetal stage the brain continues to grow and develop, nearly doubling in size from weeks 16 to 28.']
['What are the last few weeks of development?', 'Around 36 weeks, the fetus is almost ready for birth.']

['How much is a human at this stage?', 'It weighs about 6 pounds and is about 18.5 inches long, and by week 37 all of the fetus’s organ systems are developed enough that it could survive outside the uterus without many of the risks associated with premature birth.']
['Does the human continue to grow during this stage?', 'The fetus continues to gain weight and grow in length until approximately 40 weeks.']
['What are the final few weeks of development?', 'By then, the fetus has very little room to move around and birth becomes imminent.']
['How is the progression through the stages displayed?', 'The progression through the stages is shown in Figure 9.8.']
['what is prenatal influences?', 'During each prenatal stage, genetic and environmental factors can affect development.']
['what are some of the other factors?', 'The developing fetus is completely dependent on the mother for life.']

['why is that?', 'It is important that the mother takes good care of herself and receives prenatal care, which is medical care during pregnancy that monitors the health of both the mother and the fetus.']

['how is prenatal care important?', 'According to the National Institutes of Health ([NIH], 2013), routine prenatal care is important because it can reduce the risk of complications to the mother and fetus during pregnancy.']
['can you tell me more about prenatal influences?', 'In fact, women who are trying to become pregnant or who may become pregnant should discuss pregnancy planning with their doctor.']

['what are some important things to discuss with your doctor?', 'They may be advised, for example, to take a vitamin containing folic acid, which helps prevent certain birth defects, or to monitor aspects of their diet or exercise routines.']
['What happens to the placenta in prenatal influence?', 'Recall that when the zygote attaches to the wall of the mother’s uterus, the placenta is formed.']
['Why does it form?', 'The placenta provides nourishment and oxygen to the fetus.']
['What else does it do?', 'Most everything the mother ingests, including food, liquid, and even medication, travels through the placenta to the fetus, hence the common phrase “eating for two.”']

['Why do bad things happen to the fetus?', 'Anything the mother is exposed to in the environment affects the fetus; if the mother is exposed to something harmful, the child can show life-long effects.']
['What are Teratogens?', 'A teratogen is any environmental agent—biological, chemical, or physical—that causes damage to the developing embryo or fetus.']
['Are there any other types of teratogens?', 'There are different types of teratogens.']
['What are some common drug or alcohol substances?', 'Alcohol and most drugs cross the placenta and affect the fetus.']
['Is alcohol safe to drink during pregnancy?', 'Alcohol is not safe to drink in any amount during pregnancy.']

['What are some other consequences of drinking alcohol during pregnancy?', 'Alcohol use during pregnancy has been found to be the leading preventable cause of intellectual disabilities in children in the United States (Maier & West, 2001).']

['What else can drinking alcohol do during pregnancy?', 'Excessive maternal drinking while pregnant can cause fetal alcohol spectrum disorders with life-long consequences for the child ranging in severity from minor to major.']
['What is FASD?', 'Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) are a collection of birth defects associated with heavy consumption of alcohol during pregnancy.']
['What other symptoms are there for children with FASD?', 'Physically, children with FASD may have a small head size and abnormal facial features.']
['What else do these children exhibit?', 'Cognitively, these children may have poor judgment, poor impulse control, higher rates of ADHD, learning issues, and lower IQ scores.']
['Does drinking alcohol during pregnancy cause any other problems for the mother?', 'These developmental problems and delays persist into adulthood (Streissguth et al., 2004).']

['What are other issues alcohol can cause?', "Based on studies conducted on animals, it also has been suggested that a parent's alcohol consumption during pregnancy may predispose their child to like alcohol (Youngentob et al., 2007)."]
['What are some important aspects of Prenatal Influences?', 'Smoking is also considered a teratogen because nicotine travels through the placenta to the fetus.']
['How does nicotine impact the fetus?', 'When the mother smokes, the developing baby experiences a reduction in blood oxygen levels.']

['What health problems can smoking cause?', 'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (2013), smoking while pregnant can result in premature birth, low-birth-weight infants, stillbirth, and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).']
['What are some of the things that influence a baby?', 'Heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine, almost all prescription medicines, and most over-the counter medications are also considered teratogens.']
['Are there side effects from teratogens?', 'Babies born with a heroin addiction need heroin just like an adult addict.']
['How does the child react to being addicted to heroin?', 'The child will need to be gradually weaned from the heroin under medical supervision; otherwise, the child could have seizures and die.']
['What are some other things that can impact a baby?', 'Other teratogens include radiation, viruses such as HIV and herpes, and rubella (German measles).']

['How can you protect yourself from rubella?', 'Women in the United States are much less likely to be afflicted with rubella because most women received childhood immunizations or vaccinations that protect the body from disease.']
['What is Prenatal Influences?', 'Each organ of the fetus develops during a specific period in the pregnancy, called the critical or sensitive period.']

['What happens during the critical or sensitive period?', 'For example, research with primate models of FASD has demonstrated that the time during which a developing fetus is exposed to alcohol can dramatically affect the appearance of facial characteristics associated with fetal alcohol syndrome.']

['Why would that be?', 'Specifically, this research suggests that alcohol exposure that is limited to day 19 or 20 of gestation can lead to significant facial abnormalities in the offspring (Ashley, Magnuson, Omnell, & Clarren, 1999).']

['What are some other examples of negative effects?', 'Given regions of the brain also show sensitive periods during which they are most susceptible to the teratogenic effects of alcohol (Tran & Kelly, 2003).']
['What did the study of infancy have to do with weight?', 'The average newborn weighs approximately 7.5 pounds.']

['What are some examples of infancy that were explored?', 'Although small, newborns are not completely helpless because their reflexes and sensory capacities help them interact with the environment from the moment of birth.']
['How do newborn reflexes work?', 'All healthy babies are born with newborn reflexes: inborn automatic responses to particular forms of stimulation.']
["What role do newborn reflexes play in the infant's development?", 'Reflexes help the newborn survive until it is capable of more complex behaviors—these reflexes are crucial to survival.']
['How long do newborn reflexes last?', 'They are present in babies whose brains are developing normally and usually disappear around 4–5 months old.']
['What are some examples of newborn reflexes?', 'Let’s take a look at some of these newborn reflexes.']
['What is the rooting reflex?', 'The rooting reflex is the newborn’s response to anything that touches their cheek:']
['What does the rooting reflex do?', 'When you stroke a baby’s cheek, the baby naturally turns the head in that direction and begins to suck.']
['What is the sucking reflex?', 'The sucking reflex is the automatic, unlearned, sucking motions that infants do with their mouths.']
['What are some other examples of newborn reflexes?', 'Several other interesting newborn reflexes can be observed.']

['What are some examples of other reflexes?', 'For instance, if you put your finger into a newborn’s hand, you will witness the grasping reflex, in which a baby automatically grasps anything that touches the palms.']
['What is the Moro reflex?', 'The Moro reflex is the newborn’s response to the sensation of falling.']
['What is the Moro reflex?', 'The baby spreads the arms, pulls them back in, and then (usually) cries.']
['What do you mean by significant?', 'Newborn infants’ sensory abilities are significant, but their senses are not yet fully developed.']
['What are the innate preferences?', 'Many of a newborn’s innate preferences facilitate interaction with caregivers and other humans.']
['What is the least developed sense?', 'Although vision is their least developed sense, newborns already show a preference for faces.']

['Why do they prefer voices?', 'Babies who are just a few days old also prefer human voices, they will listen to voices longer than sounds that do not involve speech (Vouloumanos & Werker, 2004), and they seem to prefer their mother’s voice over a stranger’s voice (Mills & Melhuish, 1974).']
['What else are some important points?', 'In an interesting experiment, 3-week-old babies were given pacifiers that played a recording of the infant’s mother’s voice and of a stranger’s voice.']
['What did the babies do?', 'When the infants heard their mother’s voice, they sucked more strongly at the pacifier (Mills & Melhuish, 1974).']
['What else is significant?', 'Newborns also have a strong sense of smell.']
['Can they distinguish smells?', 'For instance, newborn babies can distinguish the smell of their own mother from that of others.']
['What else does the article cover?', 'In a study by MacFarlane (1978), 1-week-old babies who were being breastfed were placed between two gauze pads.']
['What were the two gauze pads used for?', 'One gauze pad was from the bra of a nursing mother who was a stranger, and the other gauze pad was from the bra of the infant’s own mother.']
['How did the babies react to the difference in smells?', 'More than two-thirds of the week-old babies turned toward the gauze pad with their mother’s scent.']
["What's the first thing you should know about Physical Development?", 'In infancy, toddlerhood, and early childhood, the body’s physical development is rapid.']
["How does a newborn's body develop?", 'On average, newborns weigh between 5 and 10 pounds, and a newborn’s weight typically doubles in six months and triples in one year.']
["How does a 2 year old's body develop?", 'By 2 years old the weight will have quadrupled, so we can expect that a 2 year old should weigh between 20 and 40 pounds.']

["How does a 3 year old's body develop?", 'The average length of a newborn is 19.5 inches, increasing to 29.5 inches by 12 months and 34.4 inches by 2 years old (WHO Multicentre Growth Reference Study Group, 2006).']
['What else can you tell me about physical development?', 'During infancy and childhood, growth does not occur at a steady rate (Carel, Lahlou, Roger, & Chaussain, 2004).']
['What else do you find interesting?', 'Growth slows between 4 and 6 years old: During this time children gain 5–7 pounds and grow about 2–3 inches per year.']
['What else is interesting?', 'Once females reach 8–9 years old, their growth rate outpaces that of males due to a pubertal growth spurt.']
['What else can you tell me about the growth spurt?', 'This growth spurt continues until around 12 years old, coinciding with the start of the menstrual cycle.']
['What else is interesting?', 'By 10 years old, the average female weighs 88 pounds, and the average male weighs 85 pounds.']
['What is the difference between genetic and phenotypic differences?', 'It was previously believed that we are born with all of the brain cells we will ever have.']
['What happened to brain cells?', 'More recent research suggests that neurogenesis (the formation of neurons) can continue through adulthood.']

['What happens in childhood?', 'However, the vast majority of neural connections and pathways occur during the first few years of a child’s life (National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, 2019).']
['What else does blooming have to do with brain cells?', 'This period of rapid neural growth is called blooming.']
['What else is important about physical development?', 'Neural pathways continue to develop through puberty.']
['What else did you learn about physical development?', 'The blooming period of neural growth is then followed by a period of pruning, where neural connections are reduced.']
['How does pruning help the brain?', 'It is thought that pruning causes the brain to function more efficiently, allowing for mastery of more complex skills (Hutchinson, 2011).']
['What happens during physical development?', 'Blooming occurs during the first few years of life, and pruning continues through childhood and into adolescence in various areas of the brain.']
['What happened during physical development?', 'The size of our brains increases rapidly.']
['How much does it increase?', 'For example, the brain of a 2-year-old is 55% of its adult size, and by 6 years old the brain is about 90% of its adult size (Tanner, 1978).']
['Does it increase faster than the rest of your body?', 'During early childhood (ages 3–6), the frontal lobes grow rapidly.']
['Why is that?', 'Recalling our discussion of the 4 lobes of the brain earlier in this book, the frontal lobes are associated with planning, reasoning, memory, and impulse control.']
['Does it increase any faster?', 'Therefore, by the time children reach school age, they are developmentally capable of controlling their attention and behavior.']
['Do the other lobes grow in size too?', 'Through the elementary school years, the frontal, temporal, occipital, and parietal lobes all grow in size.']

['Do there any other interesting information that you would like to share with us?', 'The brain growth spurts experienced in childhood tend to follow Piaget’s sequence of cognitive development, so that significant changes in neural functioning account for cognitive advances (Kolb & Whishaw, 2009; Overman, Bachevalier, Turner, & Peuster, 1992).']
['How does motor development occur?', 'Motor development occurs in an orderly sequence as infants move from reflexive reactions (e.g., sucking and rooting) to more advanced motor functioning.']
['What are some examples?', 'For instance, babies first learn to hold their heads up, then to sit with assistance, and then to sit unassisted, followed later by crawling and then walking.']
['What are motor skills?', 'Motor skills refer to our ability to move our bodies and manipulate objects.']

['How are motor skills developed?', 'Fine motor skills focus on the muscles in our fingers, toes, and eyes, and enable coordination of small actions (e.g., grasping a toy, writing with a pencil, and using a spoon).']
['What are gross motor skills?', 'Gross motor skills focus on large muscle groups that control our arms and legs and involve larger movements (e.g., balancing, running, and jumping).']
['What is physical development?', 'As motor skills develop, there are certain developmental milestones that young children should achieve.']
['What are some of the milestones?', 'For each milestone there is an average age, as well as a range of ages in which the milestone should be reached.']
['What is an example of a milestone?', 'An example of a developmental milestone is sitting.']
['When does a baby start sitting?', 'On average, most babies sit alone at 7 months old.']
['What else is important about sitting?', 'Sitting involves both coordination and muscle strength, and 90% of babies achieve this milestone between 5 and 9 months old.']

['Do any other milestones require coordination and muscle strength?', 'In another example, babies on average are able to hold up their head at 6 weeks old, and 90% of babies achieve this between 3 weeks and 4 months old.']
['What is delayed physical development?', 'If a baby is not holding up their head by 4 months old, they are showing a delay.']

['What should parents do if their baby is not developing at this point?', 'If the child is displaying delays on several milestones, that is reason for concern, and the parent or caregiver should discuss this with the child’s pediatrician.']
['Is there anything else you should know about this?', 'Some developmental delays can be identified and addressed through early intervention.']
['What is Cognitive Development?', 'In addition to rapid physical growth, young children also exhibit significant development of their cognitive abilities.']

['What can you tell me about Piaget?', 'Piaget thought that children’s ability to understand objects—such as learning that a rattle makes a noise when shaken—was a cognitive skill that develops slowly as a child matures and interacts with the environment.']
['How did he prove his theory?', 'Today, developmental psychologists think Piaget was incorrect.']

['What do they say?', 'Researchers have found that even very young children understand objects and how they work long before they have experience with those objects (Baillargeon, 1987; Baillargeon, Li, Gertner, & Wu, 2011).']

['Can you tell me some example?', 'For example, children as young as 3 months old demonstrated knowledge of the properties of objects that they had only viewed and did not have prior experience with them.']
['How do they know that?', 'In one study, 3-month-old infants were shown a truck rolling down a track and behind a screen.']
['What did they see after that?', 'The box, which appeared solid but was actually hollow, was placed next to the track.']
['What happened to the truck?', 'The truck rolled past the box as would be expected.']
['What happened next?', 'Then the box was placed on the track to block the path of the truck.']
['What happened next?', 'When the truck was rolled down the track this time, it continued unimpeded.']
['What happened next?', 'The infants spent significantly more time looking at this impossible event.']
['What did they conclude?', 'Baillargeon (1987) concluded that they knew solid objects cannot pass through each other.']

['What can you tell me about the article?', 'Baillargeon’s findings suggest that very young children have an understanding of objects and how they work, which Piaget (1954) would have said is beyond their cognitive abilities due to their limited experiences in the world.']
['What can you tell me about cognitive development?', 'Just as there are physical milestones that we expect children to reach, there are also cognitive milestones.']
['What are cognitive milestones?', 'It is helpful to be aware of these milestones as children gain new abilities to think, problem solve, and communicate.']

['What examples of cognitive milestones do you have?', 'For example, infants shake their head “no” around 6–9 months, and they respond to verbal requests to do things like “wave bye-bye” or “blow a kiss” around 9–12 months.']
['What other examples are there?', 'We can expect children to grasp the concept that objects continue to exist even when they are not in sight by around 8 months old.']

['What else can you tell me about cognitive development?', 'Because toddlers (i.e., 12–24 months old) have mastered object permanence, they enjoy games like hide and seek, and they realize that when someone leaves the room they will come back (Loop, 2013).']
['How else can you tell me about cognitive development?', 'Toddlers also point to pictures in books and look in appropriate places when you ask them to find objects.']
['What is the basic information about cognitive development?', 'Preschool-age children (i.e., 3–5 years old) also make steady progress in cognitive development.']
['What else is there to know?', 'Not only can they count, name colors, and tell you their name and age, but they can also make some decisions on their own, such as choosing an outfit to wear.']

['What else is interesting about cognitive development?', 'Preschool-age children understand basic time concepts and sequencing (e.g., before and after), and they can predict what will happen next in a story.']
['What else should we know about cognitive development?', 'They also begin to enjoy the use of humor in stories.']
['What else do they enjoy doing?', 'Because they can think symbolically, they enjoy pretend play and inventing elaborate characters and scenarios.']
['What else is interesting about cognitive development?', 'One of the most common examples of their cognitive growth is their blossoming curiosity.']
['What is the blossoming curiosity?', 'Preschool-age children love to ask “Why?”']
['Why was there a change?', 'An important cognitive change occurs in children this age.']
['How did they perceive the world?', 'Recall that Piaget described 2–3 year olds as egocentric, meaning that they do not have an awareness of others’ points of view.']
['What kind of view did they have?', 'Between 3 and 5 years old, children come to understand that people have thoughts, feelings, and beliefs that are different from their own.']
['What else did they learn?', 'This is known as theory-of-mind (TOM).']
['How did the children act out this view?', 'Children can use this skill to tease others, persuade their parents to purchase a candy bar, or understand why a sibling might be angry.']
['What else was significant?', 'When children develop TOM, they can recognize that others have false beliefs (Dennett, 1987; Callaghan et al., 2005).']
['What is this topic about?', 'Cognitive skills continue to expand in middle and late childhood (6–11 years old).']
['What type of skills?', 'Thought processes become more logical and organized when dealing with concrete information.']
['What else happens during this time period?', 'Children at this age understand concepts such as the past, present, and future, giving them the ability to plan and work toward goals.']
['What else?', 'Additionally, they can process complex ideas such as addition and subtraction and cause-and-effect relationships.']
['Is there anything else interesting about the topic?', 'However, children’s attention spans tend to be very limited until they are around 11 years old.']
['What happens to their attention span after that point?', 'After that point, it begins to improve through adulthood.']
['What do we learn about cognitive development?', 'One well-researched aspect of cognitive development is language acquisition.']
['What is this?', 'As mentioned earlier, the order in which children learn language structures is consistent across children and cultures (Hatch, 1983).']

['What else are we learning about language acquisition?', 'You’ve also learned that some psychological researchers have proposed that children possess a biological predisposition for language acquisition.']
['What can you tell me about the content in this section?', 'Starting before birth, babies begin to develop language and communication skills.']

['What does that mean?', 'At birth, babies apparently recognize their mother’s voice and can discriminate between the language(s) spoken by their mothers and foreign languages, and they show preferences for faces that are moving in synchrony with audible language (Blossom & Morgan, 2006; Pickens, 1994; Spelke & Cortelyou, 1981).']

['What is some of the content in this study material?', 'Children communicate information through gesturing long before they speak, and there is some evidence that gesture usage predicts subsequent language development (Iverson & Goldin-Meadow, 2005).']
['What is the evidence?', 'In terms of producing spoken language, babies begin to coo almost immediately.']
['What is cooing?', 'Cooing is a one-syllable combination of a consonant and a vowel sound (e.g., coo or ba).']
['What sounds does a baby make?', 'Interestingly, babies replicate sounds from their own languages.']
['Why do they replicate their own languages?', 'A baby whose parents speak French will coo in a different tone than a baby whose parents speak Spanish or Urdu.']
['What happens after cooing?', 'After cooing, the baby starts to babble.']
['What sounds do they make?', 'Babbling begins with repeating a syllable, such as ma-ma, da-da, or ba-ba.']
['What happens after babbling?', 'When babies are about 12 months old, we expect them to say their first word for meaning, and to start combining words for meaning at about 18 months.']

['What was the biggest change in cognition for you?', 'At about 2 years old, a toddler uses between 50 and 200 words; by 3 years old they have a vocabulary of up to 1,000 words and can speak in sentences.']
['What is the biggest change in cognitive development?', "During the early childhood years, children's vocabulary increases at a rapid pace."]
['What is the vocabulary spurt?', 'This is sometimes referred to as the “vocabulary spurt” and has been claimed to involve an expansion in vocabulary at a rate of 10–20 new words per week.']
['What is the most popular myth?', 'Recent research may indicate that while some children experience these spurts, it is far from universal (as discussed in Ganger & Brent, 2004).']
['How many words do you have now?', 'It has been estimated that, 5 year olds understand about 6,000 words, speak 2,000 words, and can define words and question their meanings.']
['What else can they do with these words?', 'They can rhyme and name the days of the week.']
['Does it get worse?', 'Seven year olds speak fluently and use slang and clichés (Stork & Widdowson, 1974).']

['what was the emergence of language?', 'Behaviorist B. F. Skinner thought that we learn language in response to reinforcement or feedback, such as through parental approval or through being understood.']
['what other evidence is there?', 'For example, when a two-year-old child asks for juice, he might say, “me juice,” to which his mother might respond by giving him a cup of apple juice.']
['who else has studied language?', 'Noam Chomsky (1957) criticized Skinner’s theory and proposed that we are all born with an innate capacity to learn language.']
['what was the LAD?', 'Chomsky called this mechanism a language acquisition device (LAD).']
['is Chomsky right?', 'Both Chomsky and Skinner are right.']
['what else should you know about cognitive development?', 'Remember that we are a product of both nature and nurture.']

['what does the research say?', 'Researchers now believe that language acquisition is partially inborn and partially learned through our interactions with our linguistic environment (Gleitman & Newport, 1995; Stork & Widdowson, 1974).']
['What is Attachment?', 'Psychosocial development occurs as children form relationships, interact with others, and understand and manage their feelings.']
['How important is it to develop attachment?', 'In social and emotional development, forming healthy attachments is very important and is the major social milestone of infancy.']
['What is a good example of attachment?', 'Attachment is a long-standing connection or bond with others.']
['How is attachment developed?', 'Developmental psychologists are interested in how infants reach this milestone.']
['When was attachment research first published?', 'Researchers Harry Harlow, John Bowlby, and Mary Ainsworth conducted studies designed to answer these questions.']
['What did Harlow do?', 'In the 1950s, Harlow conducted a series of experiments on monkeys.']
['What were the experiments?', 'He separated newborn monkeys from their mothers.']
['What else did he do?', 'Each monkey was presented with two surrogate mothers.']
['What happened to the other surrogate?', 'One surrogate monkey was made out of wire mesh, and she could dispense milk.']
['Did the other monkey provide the same amount of milk?', 'The other monkey was softer and made from cloth:']
['Why was it softer?', 'This monkey did not dispense milk.']
['What else did he do?', 'Research shows that the monkeys preferred the soft, cuddly cloth monkey, even though she did not provide any nourishment.']
['What did the monkeys do?', 'The baby monkeys spent their time clinging to the cloth monkey and only went to the wire monkey when they needed to be fed.']

["What was the consensus of Harlow's studies?", 'Prior to this study, the medical and scientific communities generally thought that babies become attached to the people who provide their nourishment.']
['What was the change?', 'However, Harlow (1958) concluded that there was more to the mother-child bond than nourishment.']
['Did he elaborate?', 'Feelings of comfort and security are the critical components to maternal-infant bonding, which leads to healthy psychosocial development.']
['who was the first person to study attachment theory?', 'Building on the work of Harlow and others, John Bowlby developed the concept of attachment theory.']
['what was the most important aspect of the theory?', 'He defined attachment as the affectional bond or tie that an infant forms with the mother (Bowlby, 1969).']
['why is the attachment important?', 'An infant must form this bond with a primary caregiver in order to have normal social and emotional development.']
['what else is important?', 'In addition, Bowlby proposed that this attachment bond is very powerful and continues throughout life.']
['what else did he say?', 'He used the concept of secure base to define a healthy attachment between parent and child (1988).']
['what does secure base mean?', 'A secure base is a parental presence that gives the child a sense of safety as he explores his surroundings.']
['what is another aspect of the theory?', 'Bowlby said that two things are needed for a healthy attachment:']

['how does it work?', 'The caregiver must be responsive to the child’s physical, social, and emotional needs; and the caregiver and child must engage in mutually enjoyable interactions (Bowlby, 1969).']
['Who is the main researcher of Attachment?', 'While Bowlby thought attachment was an all-or-nothing process, Mary Ainsworth’s (1970) research showed otherwise.']
['What was her research about?', 'Ainsworth wanted to know if children differ in the ways they bond, and if so, why.']
['How did she find the answers?', 'To find the answers, she used the Strange Situation procedure to study attachment between mothers and their infants (1970).']
['What is the Strange Situation procedure?', 'In the Strange Situation, the mother (or primary caregiver) and the infant (age 12-18 months) are placed in a room together.']
['What happens in the room?', 'There are toys in the room, and the caregiver and child spend some time alone in the room.']
['What happens after that time?', 'After the child has had time to explore her surroundings, a stranger enters the room.']
['What else happens in the room?', 'The mother then leaves her baby with the stranger.']
['What happens after the stranger leaves?', 'After a few minutes, she returns to comfort her child.']

['What type of attachment?', 'Based on how the infants/toddlers responded to the separation and reunion, Ainsworth identified three types of parent-child attachments: secure, avoidant, and resistant (Ainsworth & Bell, 1970).']
['what was the fourth type?', 'A fourth style, known as disorganized attachment, was later described (Main & Solomon, 1990).']
['What was the most common type?', 'The most common type of attachment—also considered the healthiest—is called secure attachment.']
['What happened in secure attachment?', 'In this type of attachment, the toddler prefers his parent over a stranger.']
['How did this type help?', 'The attachment figure is used as a secure base to explore the environment and is sought out in times of stress.']

['Why was this?', 'Securely attached children were distressed when their caregivers left the room in the Strange Situation experiment, but when their caregivers returned, the securely attached children were happy to see them.']
['Did they have to care for them?', 'Securely attached children have caregivers who are sensitive and responsive to their needs.']
['What is the first concept we will discuss?', 'With avoidant attachment, the child is unresponsive to the parent, does not use the parent as a secure base, and does not care if the parent leaves.']
['What is an avoidant attachment?', 'The toddler reacts to the parent the same way she reacts to a stranger.']
['What is the cause of this reaction?', 'When the parent does return, the child is slow to show a positive reaction.']
['Why is this?', 'Ainsworth theorized that these children were most likely to have a caregiver who was insensitive and inattentive to their needs (Ainsworth, Blehar, Waters, & Wall, 1978).']

['What is resistant attachment?', 'In cases of resistant attachment, children tend to show clingy behavior, but then they reject the attachment figure’s attempts to interact with them (Ainsworth & Bell, 1970).']
['Why do they reject interactions?', 'These children do not explore the toys in the room, as they are too fearful.']
['Are they ever left alone?', 'During separation in the Strange Situation, they became extremely disturbed and angry with the parent.']
['Why do they become angry?', 'When the parent returns, the children are difficult to comfort.']
['What happens to the parents?', 'Resistant attachment is the result of the caregivers’ inconsistent level of response to their child.']
['How did people differ from the norm?', 'Finally, children with disorganized attachment behaved oddly in the Strange Situation.']
['What was the strange situation?', 'They freeze, run around the room in an erratic manner, or try to run away when the caregiver returns (Main & Solomon, 1990).']
['What was the disorganized attachment?', 'This type of attachment is seen most often in kids who have been abused.']
['What was the abuse?', 'Research has shown that abuse disrupts a child’s ability to regulate their emotions.']
['What are some of the critics?', 'While Ainsworth’s research has found support in subsequent studies, it has also met criticism.']

['What other criticism?', 'Some researchers have pointed out that a child’s temperament may have a strong influence on attachment (Gervai, 2009; Harris, 2009), and others have noted that attachment varies from culture to culture, a factor not accounted for in Ainsworth’s research (Rothbaum, Weisz, Pott, Miyake, & Morelli, 2000; van Ijzendoorn & Sagi-Schwartz, 2008).']

['What did you learn about self-concept?', 'Just as attachment is the main psychosocial milestone of infancy, the primary psychosocial milestone of childhood is the development of a positive sense of self.']
['How does it change when a baby is born?', 'Infants don’t have a self-concept, which is an understanding of who they are.']
['Why do they want to touch their image?', 'If you place a baby in front of a mirror, they will reach out to touch their image, thinking it is another baby.']
['Why would a toddler want to touch their image?', 'However, by about 18 months a toddler will recognize that the person in the mirror is themself.']
['What else did you learn about self-concept?', 'In a well-known experiment, a researcher placed a red dot of paint on children’s noses before putting them in front of a mirror (Amsterdam, 1972).']
['What was the mirror test?', 'Commonly known as the mirror test, this behavior is demonstrated by humans and a few other species and is considered evidence of self-recognition (Archer, 1992).']
['How did the toddlers react?', 'At 18 months old they would touch their own noses when they saw the paint, surprised to see a spot on their faces.']
['How do you feel about self-concept?', 'By 24–36 months old children can name and/or point to themselves in pictures, clearly indicating self-recognition.']
['What is Self-Concept?', 'Children from 2–4 years old display a great increase in social behavior once they have established a self-concept.']
['How does social behavior affect self-concept?', 'They enjoy playing with other children, but they have difficulty sharing their possessions.']
['Does play affect self-concept?', 'Also, through play children explore and come to understand their gender roles and can label themselves as a girl or boy (Chick, Heilman-Houser, & Hunter, 2002).']
['What developmental milestones occur with self-concept?', 'By 4 years old, children can cooperate with other children, share when asked, and separate from parents with little anxiety.']
['Why can they cooperate?', 'Children at this age also exhibit autonomy, initiate tasks, and carry out plans.']
['What does this mean for them?', 'Success in these areas contributes to a positive sense of self.']

['What are some other developments with self-concept?', 'Once children reach 6 years old, they can identify themselves in terms of group memberships: “I’m a first grader!” School-age children compare themselves to their peers and discover that they are competent in some areas and less so in others (recall Erikson’s task of industry versus inferiority).']
['What else has this contributed to?', 'At this age, children recognize their own personality traits as well as some other traits they would like to have.']
['What is an example of the development in their self-concept?', 'For example, 10-year-old Layla says, “I’m kind of shy.']
['What does this mean for her?', 'I wish I could be more talkative like my friend Alexa.”']
['Why is self-concept important?', 'Development of a positive self-concept is important to healthy development.']

['What are the benefits of a positive self-concept?', 'Children with a positive self-concept tend to be more confident, do better in school, act more independently, and are more willing to try new activities (Maccoby, 1980; Ferrer & Fugate, 2003).']

['What stages of development do positive self-concepts begin in?', 'Formation of a positive self-concept begins in Erikson’s toddlerhood stage, when children establish autonomy and become confident in their abilities.']
['What else is important about toddlerhood?', 'Development of self-concept continues in elementary school, when children compare themselves to others.']
['How does self-concept affect their motivations?', 'When the comparison is favorable, children feel a sense of competence and are motivated to work harder and accomplish more.']
['What happens in middle school?', 'Self-concept is re-evaluated in Erikson’s adolescence stage, as teens form an identity.']
['What else happens in middle school?', 'They internalize the messages they have received regarding their strengths and weaknesses, keeping some messages and rejecting others.']
['What are some examples of adolescent self-concepts?', 'Adolescents who have achieved identity formation are capable of contributing positively to society (Erikson, 1968).']
['What was the research on self-concept?', 'Diana Baumrind (1971, 1991) thinks parenting style may be a factor.']
['What is significant about parenting style?', 'The way we parent is an important factor in a child’s socioemotional growth.']
['How is parenting style different from other people?', 'Baumrind developed and refined a theory describing four parenting styles: authoritative, authoritarian, permissive, and uninvolved.']

['What is important about authoritative?', 'With the authoritative style, the parent gives reasonable demands and consistent limits, expresses warmth and affection, and listens to the child’s point of view.']
['Why does he listen?', 'Parents set rules and explain the reasons behind them.']

['What kind of rules?', 'They are also flexible and willing to make exceptions to the rules in certain cases—for example, temporarily relaxing bedtime rules to allow for a nighttime swim during a family vacation.']
['Are there other things that are important about authoritative?', 'Of the four parenting styles, the authoritative style is the one that is most encouraged in modern American society.']
['Why is it most encouraged?', 'American children raised by authoritative parents tend to have high self-esteem and social skills.']

['Does it work everywhere?', 'However, effective parenting styles vary as a function of culture and, as Small (1999) points out, the authoritative style is not necessarily preferred or appropriate in all cultures.']
['What were some characteristics of the authoritarian style?', 'In authoritarian style, the parent places high value on conformity and obedience.']
['What else did they use to get conformity?', 'The parents are often strict, tightly monitor their children, and express little warmth.']

['What did they do in the absence of their child?', 'In contrast to the authoritative style, authoritarian parents probably would not relax bedtime rules during a vacation because they consider the rules to be set, and they expect obedience.']
['How was their child affected by this?', 'This style can create anxious, withdrawn, and unhappy kids.']

['What was another thing to know about authoritarian parenting?', 'However, it is important to point out that authoritarian parenting is as beneficial as the authoritative style in some ethnic groups (Russell, Crockett, & Chao, 2010).']

['Did the authoritarian style have any problems?', 'For instance, first-generation Chinese American children raised by authoritarian parents did just as well in school as their peers who were raised by authoritative parents (Russell et al., 2010).']
['What is permissive parenting?', 'For parents who employ the permissive style of parenting, the kids run the show and anything goes.']
['What are the consequences?', 'Permissive parents make few demands and rarely use punishment.']
['What else do they do?', 'They tend to be very nurturing and loving, and may play the role of friend rather than parent.']

['Do they have any rules?', 'In terms of our example of vacation bedtimes, permissive parents might not have bedtime rules at all—instead they allow the child to choose their bedtime whether on vacation or not.']

['Do they have good kids?', 'Not surprisingly, children raised by permissive parents tend to lack self-discipline, and the permissive parenting style is negatively associated with grades (Dornbusch, Ritter, Leiderman, Roberts, & Fraleigh, 1987).']

['What else does it lead to?', 'The permissive style may also contribute to other risky behaviors such as alcohol abuse (Bahr & Hoffman, 2010), risky sexual behavior especially among female children (Donenberg, Wilson, Emerson, & Bryant, 2002), and increased display of disruptive behaviors by male children (Parent et al., 2011).']
['What else is permissive parenting?', 'However, there are some positive outcomes associated with children raised by permissive parents.']
['What else does it mean?', 'They tend to have higher self-esteem, better social skills, and report lower levels of depression (Darling, 1999).']
['What does the uninvolved style of parenting mean?', 'With the uninvolved style of parenting, the parents are indifferent, uninvolved, and sometimes referred to as neglectful.']
['What are some things they do?', 'They don’t respond to the child’s needs and make relatively few demands.']
['How is it caused?', 'This could be because of severe depression or substance abuse, or other factors such as the parents’ extreme focus on work.']
['What else do you know about this style?', 'These parents may provide for the child’s basic needs, but little else.']

['What happens when this occurs?', 'The children raised in this parenting style are usually emotionally withdrawn, fearful, anxious, perform poorly in school, and are at an increased risk of substance abuse (Darling, 1999).']
['What is temperament?', 'Temperament refers to innate traits that influence how one thinks, behaves, and reacts with the environment.']
['What is easy temperament?', 'Children with easy temperaments demonstrate positive emotions, adapt well to change, and are capable of regulating their emotions.']
['What is difficult temperament?', 'Conversely, children with difficult temperaments demonstrate negative emotions and have difficulty adapting to change and regulating their emotions.']
['What is hard to understand?', 'Difficult children are much more likely to challenge parents, teachers, and other caregivers (Thomas, 1984).']

['How does temperament influence how people interact with one another?', 'Therefore, it’s possible that easy children (i.e., social, adaptable, and easy to soothe) tend to elicit warm and responsive parenting, while demanding, irritable, withdrawn children evoke irritation in their parents or cause their parents to withdraw (Sanson & Rothbart, 1995).']
["What's the best way you can describe Adolescence?", 'Adolescence is a socially constructed concept.']

['What is the concept of Adolescence?', 'In pre-industrial society, children were considered adults when they reached physical maturity, but today we have an extended time between childhood and adulthood called adolescence.']
['Is this a socially constructed concept?', 'Adolescence is the period of development that begins at puberty and ends at emerging adulthood, which is discussed later.']
['What do people think of this?', 'In the United States, adolescence is seen as a time to develop independence from parents while remaining connected to them.']

['What are other important aspects of Adolescence?', 'The typical age range of adolescence is from 12 to 18 years, and this stage of development also has some predictable physical, cognitive, and psychosocial milestones.']
['What is the main topic of discussion for this section?', 'As noted above, adolescence begins with puberty.']
['How does puberty vary between people?', 'While the sequence of physical changes in puberty is predictable, the onset and pace of puberty vary widely.']
['What happens during puberty?', 'Several physical changes occur during puberty, such as adrenarche and gonadarche, the maturing of the adrenal glands and sex glands, respectively.']
['What else happens during puberty?', 'Also during this time, primary and secondary sexual characteristics develop and mature.']
['What are primary sexual characteristics?', 'Primary sexual characteristics are organs specifically needed for reproduction, like the uterus and ovaries in females and testes in males.']

['What are secondary sexual characteristics?', 'Secondary sexual characteristics are physical signs of sexual maturation that do not directly involve sex organs, such as development of breasts and hips in females, and development of facial hair and a deepened voice in males.']

['What else happens during puberty?', 'Females experience menarche, the beginning of menstrual periods, usually around 12–13 years old, and males experience spermarche, the first ejaculation, around 13–14 years old.']
['what are some things we need to know about Physical Development?', 'During puberty, people experience a rapid increase in height (i.e., growth spurt).']
['how old do people get when this happens?', 'For females this begins between 8 and 13 years old, with adult height reached between 10 and 16 years old.']
['What age does it happen to males?', 'Males begin their growth spurt slightly later, usually between 10 and 16 years old, and reach their adult height between 13 and 17 years old.']
['What causes it to happen?', 'Both nature (i.e., genes) and nurture (e.g., nutrition, medications, and medical conditions) can influence height.']
['What are the main points of this article?', 'Because rates of physical development vary so widely among teenagers, puberty can be a source of pride or embarrassment.']
['What happens when boys and girls develop differently?', 'Early maturing boys tend to be stronger, taller, and more athletic than their later maturing peers.']

['Are there any other side effects?', 'They are usually more popular, confident, and independent, but they are also at a greater risk for substance abuse and early sexual activity (Flannery, Rowe, & Gulley, 1993; Kaltiala-Heino, Rimpela, Rissanen, & Rantanen, 2001).']
['What is another side effect?', 'Early maturing girls may be teased or overtly admired, which can cause them to feel self-conscious about their developing bodies.']

['What else does this lead to?', 'These girls are at a higher risk for depression, substance abuse, and eating disorders (Ge, Conger, & Elder, 2001; Graber, Lewinsohn, Seeley, & Brooks-Gunn, 1997; Striegel-Moore & Cachelin, 1999).']
['What other effects can this have?', 'Late blooming boys and girls (i.e., they develop more slowly than their peers) may feel self-conscious about their lack of physical development.']

['What are the effects of that?', 'Negative feelings are particularly a problem for late maturing boys, who are at a higher risk for depression and conflict with parents (Graber et al., 1997) and more likely to be bullied (Pollack & Shuster, 2000).']

['What is one of the most important aspects of Physical Development?', 'Psychologists and clinicians also study the impact of gender identity and the impacts of puberty on transgender and gender-nonconforming youth.']
['What impact does puberty have?', 'This is a relatively recent area of study, and the impacts should not be over-generalized.']

['How is gender identity impacted?', 'However, the research seems to indicate that transgender and gender-nonconforming youth who are supported in their identity do not have significantly higher incidences of depression or anxiety symptoms when compared to control groups, while those who are not supported exhibit more symptoms and risk factors (Olson, Durwood, & McLaughlin, 2016).']
['What impact does gender identity have?', 'Expression and exploration of gender identity can take many forms and manifest at different times depending on a wide array of factors.']
['What is the developmental stage?', 'The adolescent brain also remains under development.']
['What is important about this stage?', 'Up until puberty, brain cells continue to bloom in the frontal region.']
['What else is important about this stage?', 'Adolescents engage in increased risk-taking behaviors and emotional outbursts possibly because the frontal lobes of their brains are still developing.']

['What is the importance of the frontal lobes?', 'Recall that this area is responsible for judgment, impulse control, and planning, and it is still maturing into early adulthood (Casey, Tottenham, Liston, & Durston, 2005).']
['what stage is this discussed in?', 'More complex thinking abilities emerge during adolescence.']

['what does this mean?', 'Some researchers suggest this is due to increases in processing speed and efficiency rather than as the result of an increase in mental capacity—in other words, due to improvements in existing skills rather than development of new ones (Bjorkland, 1987; Case, 1985).']
['what are the advantages of complex thinking?', 'During adolescence, teenagers move beyond concrete thinking and become capable of abstract thought.']
["is there anything else you'd like to know?", 'Recall that Piaget refers to this stage as formal operational thought.']

['what does it mean to think abstractly?', 'Teen thinking is also characterized by the ability to consider multiple points of view, imagine hypothetical situations, debate ideas and opinions (e.g., politics, religion, and justice), and form new ideas.']
['what do teens form new ideas about?', 'In addition, it’s not uncommon for adolescents to question authority or challenge established societal norms.']

['What is cognitive empathy?', 'Cognitive empathy, also known as theory-of-mind (which we discussed earlier with regard to egocentrism), relates to the ability to take the perspective of others and feel concern for others (Shamay-Tsoory, Tomer, & Aharon-Peretz, 2005).']
