['When does cognitive empathy develop?', 'Cognitive empathy begins to increase in adolescence and is an important component of social problem solving and conflict avoidance.']

['How old do they have to be to develop this?', 'According to one longitudinal study, levels of cognitive empathy begin rising in girls around 13 years old, and around 15 years old in boys (Van der Graaff et al., 2013).']

['What are some ways parents can help their children develop this?', 'Teens who reported having supportive fathers with whom they could discuss their worries were found to be better able to take the perspective of others (Miklikowska, Duriez, & Soenens, 2011).']
['What is psychosocial development?', 'Adolescents continue to refine their sense of self as they relate to others.']
['What else did Erikson study?', 'Erikson referred to the task of the adolescent as one of identity versus role confusion.']
['How does this impact the adolescent?', 'Thus, in Erikson’s view, an adolescent’s main questions are “Who am I?” and “Who do I want to be?”']
['Why do adolescents adopt the values and roles of others?', 'Some adolescents adopt the values and roles that their parents expect for them.']
['Why do they reject the values and roles of others?', 'Other teens develop identities that are in opposition to their parents but align with a peer group.']
['What impact does this have on the individual?', 'This is common as peer relationships become a central focus in adolescents’ lives.']

['What is Psychosocial Development?', 'As adolescents work to form their identities, they pull away from their parents, and the peer group becomes very important (Shanahan, McHale, Osgood, & Crouter, 2007).']

['What does it do with the parent-child relationship?', 'Despite spending less time with their parents, most teens report positive feelings toward them (Moore, Guzman, Hair, Lippman, & Garrett, 2004).']

['What happens to the relationship?', 'Warm and healthy parent-child relationships have been associated with positive child outcomes, such as better grades and fewer school behavior problems, in the United States as well as in other countries (Hair et al., 2005).']

['What is psychosocial development?', 'It appears that most teens don’t experience adolescent storm and stress to the degree once famously suggested by G. Stanley Hall, a pioneer in the study of adolescent development.']
['What else did Hall discover?', 'Only small numbers of teens have major conflicts with their parents (Steinberg & Morris, 2001), and most disagreements are minor.']

['Why did they have minor conflicts?', 'For example, in a study of over 1,800 parents of adolescents from various cultural and ethnic groups, Barber (1994) found that conflicts occurred over day-to-day issues such as homework, money, curfews, clothing, chores, and friends.']
['What happened after that?', 'These types of arguments tend to decrease as teens develop (Galambos & Almeida, 1992).']
['What else did Hall discover?', 'There is emerging research on the adolescent brain.']
['What are some of the studies?', 'Galvan, Hare, Voss, Glover and Casey (2007) examined its role in risk-taking behavior.']
['What did they find?', 'They used fMRI to assess the readings’ relationship to risk-taking, risk perception, and impulsivity.']
['What else did they find?', 'The researchers found that there was no correlation between brain activity in the neural reward center and impulsivity and risk perception.']
['What did they find instead?', 'However, activity in that part of the brain was correlated to risk taking.']
['What did they find?', 'In other words, risk-taking adolescents experienced brain activity in the reward center.']
['What happened?', 'The idea that adolescents, however, are more impulsive than other demographics was challenged in their research, which included children and adults.']
['What is the next stage of development?', 'The next stage of development is emerging adulthood.']

['What is this stage?', 'This is a relatively newly defined period of lifespan development spanning from 18 years old to the mid-20s, characterized as an in-between time where identity exploration is focused on work and love.']
['What is one example of the study material that we are studying?', 'There are many ways to answer this question.']
['What does the content state?', 'In the United States, you are legally considered an adult at 18 years old.']

['How many years?', 'But other definitions of adulthood vary widely; in sociology, for example, a person may be considered an adult when they become self-supporting, choose a career, get married, or start a family.']
['What is the age difference?', 'The ages at which we achieve these milestones vary from person to person as well as from culture to culture.']
['How is this discussed?', 'For example, in the African country of Malawi, 15-year-old Njemile was married at 14 years old and had her first child at 15 years old.']
['Why is this significant?', 'In her culture she is considered an adult.']

['What else is significant about the content?', 'Children in Malawi take on adult responsibilities such as marriage and work (e.g., carrying water, tending babies, and working fields) as early as 10 years old.']
['What else is significant?', 'In stark contrast, independence in Western cultures is taking longer and longer, effectively delaying the onset of adult life.']
['What is the important information about emerging adulthood?', 'It seems that emerging adulthood is a product of both Western culture and our current times (Arnett, 2000).']
['Why is the trend developing this way?', 'People in higher income and more industrialized countries are living longer, allowing the freedom to take an extra decade to start a career and family.']
['What is another factor that might contribute to the development of emerging adulthood?', 'Changes in the workforce also play a role.']
['What changes?', 'For example, 50 years ago, a young adult with a high school diploma could immediately enter the work force and climb the economic ladder.']
['What has changed?', 'That is no longer the case.']
['What is the most important factor that has changed?', 'Bachelor’s and even graduate degrees are required more and more often—even for entry-level jobs (Arnett, 2000).']

['What else is going on with the emergence of adulthood?', 'In addition, many students are taking longer (five or six years) to complete a college degree as a result of working and going to school at the same time.']
['What else is changing?', 'After graduation, many young adults return to the family home because they have difficulty finding a job.']

['How does that relate to emerging adulthood?', 'The term Boomerang Generation describes recent college graduates for whom lack of adequate employment upon college graduation often leads to a return to the parental home (Davidson, 2014).']
['What other factors contribute to the development of emerging adulthood?', 'Changing cultural expectations may be the most important reason for the delay in entering adult roles.']

['What are the changes?', 'Young people are spending more time exploring their options, so they are delaying marriage and work as they change majors and jobs multiple times, putting them on a much later timetable than their parents (Arnett, 2000).']
['What is the difference between early, middle and late adulthood?', 'Adulthood begins around 20 years old and has three distinct stages: early, middle, and late.']
['What are the benefits of each stage of adulthood?', 'Each stage brings its own set of rewards and challenges.']

['What else is important about Physical Development?', 'By the time we reach early adulthood (20 to early 40s), our physical maturation is complete, although our height and weight may increase slightly.']
['What else happens in the early adulthood?', 'In young adulthood, our physical abilities are at their peak, including muscle strength, reaction time, sensory abilities, and cardiac functioning.']
['What else happens during this phase?', 'Most professional athletes are at the top of their game during this stage.']
['What else happens?', 'Many women have children in the young adulthood years, so they may see additional weight gain and breast changes.']
['What does middle adulthood mean?', 'Middle adulthood extends from the 40s to the 60s.']
['What is the physical decline?', 'Physical decline is gradual.']
['What happens in middle adulthood?', 'The skin loses some elasticity, and wrinkles are among the first signs of aging.']
['What else does it mean to age?', 'Visual acuity decreases during this time.']
['Are there other declines?', 'Women experience a gradual decline in fertility as they approach the onset of menopause, the end of the menstrual cycle, around 50 years old.']
['What happens after that?', 'Both men and women tend to gain weight: in the abdominal area for men and in the hips and thighs for women.']
['What other declines?', 'Hair begins to thin and turn gray.']
['When do people begin to approach late adulthood?', 'Late adulthood is considered to extend from the 60s on.']
['What is late adulthood?', 'This is the last stage of physical change.']
['What is it?', 'The skin continues to lose elasticity, reaction time slows further, and muscle strength diminishes.']
['What else happens?', 'Smell, taste, hearing, and vision, so sharp in our twenties, decline significantly.']
['Does it get worse?', 'The brain may also no longer function at optimal levels, leading to problems like memory loss, dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease in later years.']
['What is cognitive development?', 'Because we spend so many years in adulthood (more than any other stage), cognitive changes are numerous.']

['How are the changes numerous?', 'In fact, research suggests that adult cognitive development is a complex, ever changing process that may be even more active than cognitive development in infancy and early childhood (Fischer, Yan, & Stewart, 2003).']

['What is cognitive development?', 'Unlike our physical abilities, which peak in our mid-20s and then begin a slow decline, our cognitive abilities remain steady throughout early and middle adulthood.']

['What does it mean to have crystallized intelligence?', 'Our crystallized intelligence (information, skills, and strategies we have gathered through a lifetime of experience) tends to hold steady as we age—it may even improve.']

['What other benefits of cognitive development are there?', 'For example, adults show relatively stable to increasing scores on intelligence tests until their mid-30s to mid-50s (Bayley & Oden, 1955).']

['How does fluid intelligence change?', 'However, in late adulthood we begin to experience a decline in another area of our cognitive abilities—fluid intelligence (information processing abilities, reasoning, and memory).']
['What changes do these have?', 'These processes become slower.']
['What role does activity play?', 'Mental and physical activity seems to play a part.']

['Why does that seem to play a part?', 'Research has found adults who engage in mentally and physically stimulating activities experience less cognitive decline and have a reduced incidence of mild cognitive impairment and dementia (Hertzog, Kramer, Wilson, & Lindenberger, 2009; Larson et al., 2006; Podewils et al., 2005).']
['What are some of the recent studies on cognitive development?', 'Researchers have examined the aging brain by comparing it to brain functioning in younger people.']
['What are some examples?', 'Forstmann and colleagues (2011) compared elderly participants to younger participants, who in the study were asked to report the direction of movement of a set of dots.']
['What was asked of them?', 'They were given feedback regarding speed and accuracy.']
['What did the study find?', 'The researchers found that older participants made more errors and were slower due to degeneration of corticostriatal connections.']
['How did the study change how we view aging?', 'In other words, the decreased ability typically assigned to elderly people may be due to circumstances in the brain beyond their control.']
['What else can we learn about aging?', 'Interestingly, other researchers have found similarities in spatial representations when comparing children aged 6–7 to those over the age of 80.']
['Why is this?', 'Ruggiero, D’Errico, and Iachini (2016) reported that this is due to neurodegeneration in older adults and immature neurology in young children.']
['What is dementia?', 'Many elderly people experience dementia, changes in the brain that negatively affect cognition.']
["What is Alzheimer's?", 'Alzheimer’s disease is one type of dementia, initially studied by medical researcher Solomon Carter Fuller.']
['What is the genetic basis of it?', 'Alzheimer’s disease has a genetic basis.']
['What happens with Plaques?', 'Plaques in the brain are due to cell death, which then causes those affected with the disease severe forgetfulness.']
['What happens to people with dementia?', 'A person can forget how to walk, talk, and eventually eat.']

["What is the relationship between Alzheimer's and Nutrition?", 'The disease can be mitigated by assessing environmental factors (exposure to lead, iron, and zinc increase risk) and nutritional factors (the Mediterranean diet lowers risk) (Arora, Mittal, & Kakkar, 2015).']
['What can you do to help?', 'Although there is no cure, there is hope.']
['What is the hope?', 'Cognitive rehabilitation can offset mild cognitive impairment, as it can evolve into dementia.']
['Is this an effective way to help?', 'Garcia-Betances, Jimenez-Mixco, Arredondo, and Cabrera-Umpierrez (2015) examined the use of virtual reality as a possible cognitive rehabilitative method.']
['What do these researches say?', 'They suggested that virtual reality technology should involve daily living activities, memory, and language, among other considerations.']
['What theories about the social and emotional aspects of aging do you find helpful?', 'There are many theories about the social and emotional aspects of aging.']
['What are some aspects of healthy aging?', 'Some aspects of healthy aging include activities, social connectedness, and the role of a person’s culture.']

['How can we find meaning?', 'According to many theorists, including George Vaillant (2002), who studied and analyzed over 50 years of data, we need to have and continue to find meaning throughout our lives.']

['What is some ways we find meaning in our lives?', 'For those in early and middle adulthood, meaning is found through work (Sterns & Huyck, 2001) and family life (Markus, Ryff, Curan, & Palmersheim, 2004).']
['How does family life relate to mental health?', 'These areas relate to the tasks that Erikson referred to as generativity and intimacy.']
['What is another aspect of mental health?', 'As mentioned previously, adults tend to define themselves by what they do—their careers.']

['What is a benefit of having good jobs?', 'Earnings peak during this time, yet job satisfaction is more closely tied to work that involves contact with other people, is interesting, provides opportunities for advancement, and allows some independence (Mohr & Zoghi, 2006) than it is to salary (Iyengar, Wells, & Schwartz, 2006).']
['What does this study teach us?', 'Positive relationships with significant others in our adult years have been found to contribute to a state of well-being (Ryff & Singer, 2009).']

['What do we learn about adult relationships?', 'Most adults in the United States identify themselves through their relationships with family—particularly with spouses, children, and parents (Markus et al., 2004).']

['What do we learn about children and parents?', 'While raising children can be stressful, especially when they are young, research suggests that parents reap the rewards down the road, as adult children tend to have a positive effect on parental well-being (Umberson, Pudrovska, & Reczek, 2010).']
['What does this study tell us about married life?', 'Having a stable marriage has also been found to contribute to well-being throughout adulthood (Vaillant, 2002).']
['What are the aspects of positive aging?', 'Another aspect of positive aging is believed to be social connectedness and social support.']

['What does socioemotional selectivity theory mean?', 'As we get older, socioemotional selectivity theory suggests that our social support and friendships dwindle in number, but remain as close, if not more close than in our earlier years (Carstensen, 1992).']
["What is the story's ending?", 'Every story has an ending.']
['What does death mark the end of?', 'Death marks the end of your life story.']
['What does our culture have to do with death?', 'Our culture and individual backgrounds influence how we view death.']
['Why do some people fear death?', 'In some cultures, death is accepted as a natural part of life and is embraced.']

['How do other cultures deal with death?', 'In contrast, until about 50 years ago in the United States, a doctor might not inform someone that they were dying, and the majority of deaths occurred in hospitals.']
['When did hospice care start?', 'In 1967 that reality began to change with Cicely Saunders, who created the first modern hospice in England.']

['What does hospice care focus on?', 'The aim of hospice is to help provide a death with dignity and pain management in a humane and comfortable environment, which is usually outside of a hospital setting.']
['What year did hospice care first start in the U.S?', 'In 1974, Florence Wald founded the first hospice in the United States.']
['How much is hospice care in use?', 'Today, hospice provides care for 1.65 million Americans and their families.']
['What does hospice care do for people?', 'Because of hospice care, many terminally ill people are able to spend their last days at home.']

['What is the purpose of a hospice?', 'Research has indicated that hospice care is beneficial for the patient (Brumley, Enquidanos, & Cherin, 2003; Brumley et al., 2007; Godkin, Krant, & Doster, 1984) and for the patient’s family (Rhodes, Mitchell, Miller, Connor, & Teno, 2008; Godkin et al., 1984).']

['Why is it beneficial?', 'Hospice patients report high levels of satisfaction with hospice care because they are able to remain at home and are not completely dependent on strangers for care (Brumley et al., 2007).']
['Are they happy there?', 'In addition, hospice patients tend to live longer than non-hospice patients (Connor, Pyenson, Fitch, Spence, & Iwasaki, 2007; Temel et al., 2010).']
['What benefits do they receive?', 'Family members receive emotional support and are regularly informed of their loved one’s treatment and condition.']
['Does it reduce the burden?', 'The family member’s burden of care is also reduced (McMillan et al., 2006).']

['How do they cope?', 'Both the patient and the patient’s family members report increased family support, increased social support, and improved coping while receiving hospice services (Godkin et al., 1984).']
['what did you study?', 'Elizabeth Kübler-Ross (1969), who worked with the founders of hospice care, described the process of an individual accepting his own death.']
['what were the stages?', 'She proposed five stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance.']
['what is so special about these stages?', 'Most individuals experience these stages, but the stages may occur in different orders, depending on the individual.']
['what else can you tell me about these stages?', 'In addition, not all people experience all of the stages.']

['why do some people fail to experience all the stages?', 'It is also important to note that some psychologists believe that the more a dying person fights death, the more likely they are to remain stuck in the denial phase.']
['what happens if they remain in the denial phase?', 'This could make it difficult for the dying person to face death with dignity.']
['does he have a reason for this?', 'However, other psychologists believe that not facing death until the very end is an adaptive coping mechanism for some people.']

['what is the main idea of this study material?', 'Whether due to illness or old age, not everyone facing death or the loss of a loved one experiences the negative emotions outlined in the Kübler-Ross model (Nolen-Hoeksema & Larson, 1999).']

['what are some of the studies on this topic?', 'For example, research suggests that people with religious or spiritual beliefs are better able to cope with death because of their hope in an afterlife and because of social support from religious or spiritual associations (Hood, Spilka, Hunsberger, & Corsuch, 1996; McIntosh, Silver, & Wortman, 1993; Paloutzian, 1996; Samarel, 1991; Wortman & Park, 2008).']

['What are some other significant facts about the study material?', 'A prominent example of a person creating meaning through death is Randy Pausch, who was a well-loved and respected professor at Carnegie Mellon University.']

['What happened in his final years?', 'Diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer in his mid-40s and given only 3–6 months to live, Pausch focused on living in a fulfilling way in the time he had left.']
['What did he do in his last years?', 'Instead of becoming angry and depressed, he presented his now famous last lecture called “Really Achieving Your Childhood Dreams.”']
['What did he tell people?', 'In his moving, yet humorous talk, he shares his insights on seeing the good in others, overcoming obstacles, and experiencing zero gravity, among many other things.']

['Did his lecture help people?', 'Despite his terminal diagnosis, Pausch lived the final year of his life with joy and hope, showing us that our plans for the future still matter, even if we know that we are dying.']
['What is death and dying?', 'As individuals become more knowledgeable about medical procedures and practices, some people want to ensure that their wishes and desires are known in advance.']
['Why do they want this known?', 'This ensures that if the person ever becomes incapacitated or can no longer express themselves, their loved ones will know what they want.']

['What else is important to know about death and dying?', 'For this reason, a person might write a living will or advance directive, which is a written legal document that details specific interventions a person wants.']
['What does the document detail?', 'For example, a person in the last stages of a terminal illness may not want to receive life-extending treatments.']
['What else should I know about death and dying?', 'A person may also include a Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) Order, which they would share this with family and close friends.']

['What is a DNR order?', 'A DNR Order states that if a person stops breathing or their heart stops beating, medical personnel such as doctors and nurses are not to take steps to revive or resuscitate the patient.']

['How else can I learn about death and dying?', 'A living will can also include a health care proxy, which appoints a specific person to make medical decisions for you if you are unable to speak for yourself.']
['What else does the article tell me about death and dying?', 'People’s desire for living wills and DNRs are often influenced by their religion, culture, and upbringing.']
['What is motivation?', 'Motivation describes the wants or needs that direct behavior toward a goal.']
['What types of motivation are there?', 'In addition to biological motives, motivations can be intrinsic (arising from internal factors) or extrinsic (arising from external factors) (Figure 10.2).']

['What are the differences between intrinsic and extrinsic motivation?', 'Intrinsically motivated behaviors are performed because of the sense of personal satisfaction that they bring, while extrinsically motivated behaviors are performed in order to receive something from others.']
['What kind of motivation is the topic?', 'Think about why you are pursuing an education.']
['Are you doing this because it is important to you?', 'If so, then you are intrinsically motivated.']

['What is intrinsic motivation?', 'However, if you are here because you want to get a college degree to make yourself more marketable for a high-paying career or to satisfy the demands of your parents, then your motivation is more extrinsic in nature.']

["What's your most important information about motivation?", 'In reality, our motivations are often a mix of both intrinsic and extrinsic factors, but the nature of the mix of these factors might change over time (often in ways that seem counter-intuitive).']

['What is counterintuitive about this statement?', 'There is an old adage: “Choose a job that you love, and you will never have to work a day in your life,” meaning that if you enjoy your occupation, work doesn’t seem like . . . well, work.']
['What did the research say about this?', 'Some research suggests that this isn’t necessarily the case (Daniel & Esser, 1980; Deci, 1972; Deci, Koestner, & Ryan, 1999).']

['What did they find that led to this?', 'According to this research, receiving some sort of extrinsic reinforcement (i.e., getting paid) for engaging in behaviors that we enjoy leads to those behaviors being thought of as work no longer providing that same enjoyment.']
['What does this mean?', 'As a result, we might spend less time engaging in these reclassified behaviors in the absence of any extrinsic reinforcement.']
['How else do people differ in motivation?', 'For example, Odessa loves baking, so in her free time, she bakes for fun.']
['How do you know that?', 'Oftentimes, after stocking shelves at her grocery store job, she often whips up pastries in the evenings because she enjoys baking.']
['What did she do at the store?', 'When a coworker in the store’s bakery department leaves his job, Odessa applies for his position and gets transferred to the bakery department.']
['What else happened?', 'Although she enjoys what she does in her new job, after a few months, she no longer has much desire to concoct tasty treats in her free time.']
['What happened to her motivation?', 'Baking has become work in a way that changes her motivation to do it (Figure 10.3).']
['What was her overjustification?', 'What Odessa has experienced is called the overjustification effect—intrinsic motivation is diminished when extrinsic motivation is given.']
['How is this harmful?', 'This can lead to extinguishing the intrinsic motivation and creating a dependence on extrinsic rewards for continued performance (Deci et al., 1999).']

['What is intrinsic motivation', 'Other studies suggest that intrinsic motivation may not be so vulnerable to the effects of extrinsic reinforcements, and in fact, reinforcements such as verbal praise might actually increase intrinsic motivation (Arnold, 1976; Cameron & Pierce, 1994).']

['How would that benefit Odessa?', 'In that case, Odessa’s motivation to bake in her free time might remain high if, for example, customers regularly compliment her baking or cake decorating skills.']
['What is the motivation?', 'These apparent discrepancies in the researchers’ findings may be understood by considering several factors.']
['What are the factors?', 'For one, physical reinforcement (such as money) and verbal reinforcement (such as praise) may affect an individual in very different ways.']
['What are those different ways?', 'In fact, tangible rewards (i.e., money) tend to have more negative effects on intrinsic motivation than do intangible rewards (i.e., praise).']
['What else do the factors have to do with motivation?', 'Furthermore, the expectation of the extrinsic motivator by an individual is crucial:']
['How is it crucial?', 'If the person expects to receive an extrinsic reward, then intrinsic motivation for the task tends to be reduced.']

['What happens to the person?', 'If, however, there is no such expectation, and the extrinsic motivation is presented as a surprise, then intrinsic motivation for the task tends to persist (Deci et al., 1999).']
['How does motivation influence people?', 'In addition, culture may influence motivation.']

['What can a culture influence?', 'For example, in collectivistic cultures, it is common to do things for your family members because the emphasis is on the group and what is best for the entire group, rather than what is best for any one individual (Nisbett, Peng, Choi, & Norenzayan, 2001).']

['What is the consequence of this?', 'This focus on others provides a broader perspective that takes into account both situational and cultural influences on behavior; thus, a more nuanced explanation of the causes of others’ behavior becomes more likely.']
['What are some other cultures?', '(You will learn more about collectivistic and individualistic cultures when you learn about social psychology.)']

['What can you tell me about intrinsic motivation?', 'In educational settings, students are more likely to experience intrinsic motivation to learn when they feel a sense of belonging and respect in the classroom.']

['How does that effect learning?', 'This internalization can be enhanced if the evaluative aspects of the classroom are de-emphasized and if students feel that they exercise some control over the learning environment.']

['How else can they be stimulated to learn?', 'Furthermore, providing students with activities that are challenging, yet doable, along with a rationale for engaging in various learning activities can enhance intrinsic motivation for those tasks (Niemiec & Ryan, 2009).']
["What's an example of a challenge?", 'Consider Hakim, a first-year law student with two courses this semester: Family Law and Criminal Law.']
["What's one thing the professor did to make Hakim discouraged?", 'The Family Law professor has a rather intimidating classroom:']
["What's one thing he does to intimidate students?", 'He likes to put students on the spot with tough questions, which often leaves students feeling belittled or embarrassed.']
['What else was intimidating about the classroom?', 'Grades are based exclusively on quizzes and exams, and the instructor posts results of each test on the classroom door.']
["What's a different type of class?", 'In contrast, the Criminal Law professor facilitates classroom discussions and respectful debates in small groups.']
['How does the Criminal Law professor help Hakim?', 'The majority of the course grade is not exam-based, but centers on a student-designed research project on a crime issue of the student’s choice.']

['What is the research on?', 'Research suggests that Hakim will be less intrinsically motivated in his Family Law course, where students are intimidated in the classroom setting, and there is an emphasis on teacher-driven evaluations.']

['What is the research on?', 'Hakim is likely to experience a higher level of intrinsic motivation in his Criminal Law course, where the class setting encourages inclusive collaboration and a respect for ideas, and where students have more influence over their learning activities.']
['Who is William James?', 'William James (1842–1910) was an important contributor to early research into motivation, and he is often referred to as the father of psychology in the United States.']
['How did he look at motivation?', 'James theorized that behavior was driven by a number of instincts, which aid survival (Figure 10.4).']
['What are instincts?', 'From a biological perspective, an instinct is a species-specific pattern of behavior that is not learned.']
["Was James's theory correct?", 'There was, however, considerable controversy among James and his contemporaries over the exact definition of instinct.']
['How many instincts did he propose?', 'James proposed several dozen special human instincts, but many of his contemporaries had their own lists that differed.']

['What were some of the examples he suggested?', 'A mother’s protection of her baby, the urge to lick sugar, and hunting prey were among the human behaviors proposed as true instincts during James’s era.']

["Did James's theory get criticized?", 'This view—that human behavior is driven by instincts—received a fair amount of criticism because of the undeniable role of learning in shaping all sorts of human behavior.']

['Did scientists ever conduct testing on this?', 'In fact, as early as the 1900s, some instinctive behaviors were experimentally demonstrated to result from associative learning (recall when you learned about Watson’s conditioning of fear response in “Little Albert”) (Faris, 1921).']
['What was an early theory of motivation?', 'Another early theory of motivation proposed that the maintenance of homeostasis is particularly important in directing behavior.']
['What is homeostasis?', 'You may recall from your earlier reading that homeostasis is the tendency to maintain a balance, or optimal level, within a biological system.']
['What is it?', 'In a body system, a control center (which is often part of the brain) receives input from receptors (which are often complexes of neurons).']
['What happens with the input from receptors?', 'The control center directs effectors (which may be other neurons) to correct any imbalance detected by the control center.']
['What is one theory of motivation?', 'According to the drive theory of motivation, deviations from homeostasis create physiological needs.']
['What happens next in the drive theory?', 'These needs result in psychological drive states that direct behavior to meet the need and, ultimately, bring the system back to homeostasis.']
['What are some examples of deviations from homeostasis?', 'For example, if it’s been a while since you ate, your blood sugar levels will drop below normal.']

['What happens to the body when blood sugar drops below normal?', 'This low blood sugar will induce a physiological need and a corresponding drive state (i.e., hunger) that will direct you to seek out and consume food (Figure 10.5).']
['What happens after eating?', 'Eating will eliminate the hunger, and, ultimately, your blood sugar levels will return to normal.']
['How does the drive theory help us develop habits?', 'Interestingly, drive theory also emphasizes the role that habits play in the type of behavioral response in which we engage.']
['What is a habit?', 'A habit is a pattern of behavior in which we regularly engage.']

['What makes us more likely to develop a habit?', 'Once we have engaged in a behavior that successfully reduces a drive, we are more likely to engage in that behavior whenever faced with that drive in the future (Graham & Weiner, 1996).']
['What do the extensions of drive theory refer to?', 'Extensions of drive theory take into account levels of arousal as potential motivators.']
['Why is this theory helpful?', 'As you recall from your study of learning, these theories assert that there is an optimal level of arousal that we all try to maintain (Figure 10.6).']
['Why do we try to maintain an optimal level of arousal?', 'If we are underaroused, we become bored and will seek out some sort of stimulation.']
['If we are overaroused, what will we seek out?', 'On the other hand, if we are overaroused, we will engage in behaviors to reduce our arousal (Berlyne, 1960).']
['Why would we want to reduce arousal?', 'Most students have experienced this need to maintain optimal levels of arousal over the course of their academic career.']
['Why would students want to reduce arousal?', 'Think about how much stress students experience toward the end of spring semester.']
['Why is there stress?', 'They feel overwhelmed with seemingly endless exams, papers, and major assignments that must be completed on time.']
['Why do they yearn for the break?', 'They probably yearn for the rest and relaxation that awaits them over the extended summer break.']
['Why do they need to keep themselves motivated?', 'However, once they finish the semester, it doesn’t take too long before they begin to feel bored.']
['Why do they need to get back into the class?', 'Generally, by the time the next semester is beginning in the fall, many students are quite happy to return to school.']
['What is the theory?', 'This is an example of how arousal theory works.']

['What does arousal have to do with motivation?', 'Research shows that moderate arousal is generally best; when arousal is very high or very low, performance tends to suffer (Yerkes & Dodson, 1908).']
['What does arousal have to do with motivation?', 'Think of your arousal level regarding taking an exam for this class.']
['What does your arousal level look like?', 'If your level is very low, such as boredom and apathy, your performance will likely suffer.']
['How does boredom impact performance?', 'Similarly, a very high level, such as extreme anxiety, can be paralyzing and hinder performance.']
['What is the second example?', 'Consider the example of a softball team facing a tournament.']
['What happened?', 'They are favored to win their first game by a large margin, so they go into the game with a lower level of arousal and get beat by a less skilled team.']
['What is optimal arousal level?', 'But optimal arousal level is more complex than a simple answer that the middle level is always best.']

['What is the best arousal level?', 'Researchers Robert Yerkes (pronounced “Yerk-EES”) and John Dodson discovered that the optimal arousal level depends on the complexity and difficulty of the task to be performed (Figure 10.7).']

['What is the relationship between arousal and task complexity?', 'This relationship is known as Yerkes-Dodson law, which holds that a simple task is performed best when arousal levels are relatively high and complex tasks are best performed when arousal levels are lower.']

['What is self-efficacy?', 'Self-efficacy is an individual’s belief in their own capability to complete a task, which may include a previous successful completion of the exact task or a similar task.']
['What is the relationship between self-efficacy and social motivation?', 'Albert Bandura (1994) theorized that an individual’s sense of self-efficacy plays a pivotal role in motivating behavior.']

['What can you tell me about social motivation?', 'Bandura argues that motivation derives from expectations that we have about the consequences of our behaviors, and ultimately, it is the appreciation of our capacity to engage in a given behavior that will determine what we do and the future goals that we set for ourselves.']

['What does self-efficacy tell me?', 'For example, if you have a sincere belief in your ability to achieve at the highest level, you are more likely to take on challenging tasks and to not let setbacks dissuade you from seeing the task through to the end.']

['what other theorists have worked on this material?', 'A number of theorists have focused their research on understanding social motives (McAdams & Constantian, 1983; McClelland & Liberman, 1949; Murray et al., 1938).']
['what kinds of motives do they have?', 'Among the motives they describe are needs for achievement, affiliation, and intimacy.']
['how do they drive their actions?', 'It is the need for achievement that drives accomplishment and performance.']
['what else do they want?', 'The need for affiliation encourages positive interactions with others, and the need for intimacy causes us to seek deep, meaningful relationships.']
['what are their domains?', 'Henry Murray et al. (1938) categorized these needs into domains.']
['what kind of domains are there?', 'For example, the need for achievement and recognition falls under the domain of ambition.']
['are there other domains?', 'Dominance and aggression were recognized as needs under the domain of human power, and play was a recognized need in the domain of interpersonal affection.']

['What is Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs?', 'While the theories of motivation described earlier relate to basic biological drives, individual characteristics, or social contexts, Abraham Maslow (1943) proposed a hierarchy of needs that spans the spectrum of motives ranging from the biological to the individual to the social.']
['What is a pyramid?', 'These needs are often depicted as a pyramid (Figure 10.8).']
['What are the top three levels in Maslow’s pyramid of needs?', 'At the base of the pyramid are all of the physiological needs that are necessary for survival.']
['What are the next two levels?', 'These are followed by basic needs for security and safety, the need to be loved and to have a sense of belonging, and the need to have self-worth and confidence.']

['What is the top tier of the pyramid?', 'The top tier of the pyramid is self-actualization, which is a need that essentially equates to achieving one’s full potential, and it can only be realized when needs lower on the pyramid have been met.']

['Are there other similarities between the levels and what is on the top of the pyramid?', 'To Maslow and humanistic theorists, self-actualization reflects the humanistic emphasis on positive aspects of human nature.']

['What happened to Maslow?', 'Maslow suggested that this is an ongoing, life-long process and that only a small percentage of people actually achieve a self-actualized state (Francis & Kritsonis, 2006; Maslow, 1943).']
['What is the hierarchy of needs about?', 'According to Maslow (1943), one must satisfy lower-level needs before addressing those needs that occur higher in the pyramid.']

['Why is that?', 'So, for example, if someone is struggling to find enough food to meet their nutritional requirements, it is quite unlikely that they would spend an inordinate amount of time thinking about whether others viewed them as a good person or not.']
['What would they focus on?', 'Instead, all of their energies would be geared toward finding something to eat.']

['What are some other things about the hierarchy of needs?', 'However, it should be pointed out that Maslow’s theory has been criticized for its subjective nature and its inability to account for phenomena that occur in the real world (Leonard, 1982).']

['Did they make any other changes?', 'Other research has more recently addressed that late in life, Maslow proposed a self-transcendence level above self-actualization—to represent striving for meaning and purpose beyond the concerns of oneself (Koltko-Rivera, 2006).']
['Is there any other interesting information?', 'For example, people sometimes make self-sacrifices in order to make a political statement or in an attempt to improve the conditions of others.']

['Did someone famous go on a hunger strike?', 'Mohandas K. Gandhi, a world-renowned advocate for independence through nonviolent protest, on several occasions went on hunger strikes to protest a particular situation.']
['What can starving do to a person?', 'People may starve themselves or otherwise put themselves in danger displaying higher-level motives beyond their own needs.']
['Why is hunger important?', 'Eating is essential for survival, and it is no surprise that a drive like hunger exists to ensure that we seek out sustenance.']

['What else is important in this article?', 'While this chapter will focus primarily on the physiological mechanisms that regulate hunger and eating, powerful social, cultural, and economic influences also play important roles.']
['What else is covered?', 'This section will explain the regulation of hunger, eating, and body weight, and we will discuss the adverse consequences of disordered eating.']
['What is hunger?', 'There are a number of physiological mechanisms that serve as the basis for hunger.']
['What is the process when a stomach is empty?', 'When our stomachs are empty, they contract.']
['Why do they contract?', 'Typically, a person then experiences hunger pangs.']
['Why do we feel hunger pangs?', 'Chemical messages travel to the brain, and serve as a signal to initiate feeding behavior.']

['Why do we eat?', 'When our blood glucose levels drop, the pancreas and liver generate a number of chemical signals that induce hunger (Konturek et al., 2003; Novin, Robinson, Culbreth, & Tordoff, 1985) and thus initiate feeding behavior.']
['What does fullness have to do with eating?', 'For most people, once they have eaten, they feel satiation, or fullness and satisfaction, and their eating behavior stops.']
['What other mechanisms control satiation?', 'Like the initiation of eating, satiation is also regulated by several physiological mechanisms.']

['What other mechanisms control eating?', 'As blood glucose levels increase, the pancreas and liver send signals to shut off hunger and eating (Drazen & Woods, 2003; Druce, Small, & Bloom, 2004; Greary, 1990).']

["What else happens to control the body's ability to satiate?", 'The food’s passage through the gastrointestinal tract also provides important satiety signals to the brain (Woods, 2004), and fat cells release leptin, a satiety hormone.']
['What is the brain involved in?', 'The various hunger and satiety signals that are involved in the regulation of eating are integrated in the brain.']

['How does the brain regulate eating?', 'Research suggests that several areas of the hypothalamus and hindbrain are especially important sites where this integration occurs (Ahima & Antwi, 2008; Woods & D’Alessio, 2008).']
['What else does the brain do?', 'Ultimately, activity in the brain determines whether or not we engage in feeding behavior (Figure 10.9).']

['How does metabolism affect body weight?', 'Our body weight is affected by a number of factors, including gene-environment interactions, and the number of calories we consume versus the number of calories we burn in daily activity.']
['What happens if the calories we consume exceed the calories we burn?', 'If our caloric intake exceeds our caloric use, our bodies store excess energy in the form of fat.']
['What happens if we consume less calories than we burn?', 'If we consume fewer calories than we burn off, then stored fat will be converted to energy.']
['What does energy expenditure do?', 'Our energy expenditure is obviously affected by our levels of activity, but our body’s metabolic rate also comes into play.']
['What is the metabolic rate?', 'A person’s metabolic rate is the amount of energy that is expended in a given period of time, and there is tremendous individual variability in our metabolic rates.']
['What affect does the metabolic rate have on your body weight?', 'People with high rates of metabolism are able to burn off calories more easily than those with lower rates of metabolism.']

["What's the main idea of Metabolism and Body Weight?", 'We all experience fluctuations in our weight from time to time, but generally, most people’s weights fluctuate within a narrow margin, in the absence of extreme changes in diet and/or physical activity.']
['How is this known?', 'This observation led some to propose a set-point theory of body weight regulation.']
['What does the set-point theory suggest?', 'The set-point theory asserts that each individual has an ideal body weight, or set point, which is resistant to change.']

['Why is that?', 'This set-point is genetically predetermined and efforts to move our weight significantly from the set-point are resisted by compensatory changes in energy intake and/or expenditure (Speakman et al., 2011).']
['Why did the pythagorean theory not have much empirical support?', 'Some of the predictions generated from this particular theory have not received empirical support.']

["What is one of the predictions it doesn't support?", 'For example, there are no changes in metabolic rate between individuals who had recently lost significant amounts of weight and a control group (Weinsier et al., 2000).']

["How many other theories don't support the pythagorean theory?", 'In addition, the set-point theory fails to account for the influence of social and environmental factors in the regulation of body weight (Martin-Gronert & Ozanne, 2013; Speakman et al., 2011).']
['Why is the set-point theory controversial?', 'Despite these limitations, set-point theory is still often used as a simple, intuitive explanation of how body weight is regulated.']
['What else can you tell me about the pythagorean theory?', 'See Psychological Disorders for further discussion about eating disorders.']
['What is Obesity?', 'When someone weighs more than what is generally accepted as healthy for a given height, they are considered overweight or obese.']

['How does a person know whether or not they are overweight?', 'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), an adult with a body mass index (BMI) between 25 and 29.9 is considered overweight (Figure 10.10).']
['What else can you tell me about obesity?', 'An adult with a BMI of 30 or higher is considered obese (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2012).']
['How is morbid obesity defined?', 'People who are so overweight that they are at risk for death are classified as morbidly obese.']
['What does having a BMI over 40 mean?', 'Morbid obesity is defined as having a BMI over 40.']

['Are there any other things you can tell me about obesity?', 'Note that although BMI has been used as a healthy weight indicator by the World Health Organization (WHO), the CDC, and other groups, its value as an assessment tool has been questioned.']
['What is the value of BMI to them?', 'The BMI is most useful for studying populations, which is the work of these organizations.']
['Why is that?', 'It is less useful in assessing an individual since height and weight measurements fail to account for important factors like fitness level.']

['What else can you tell me about the weight index?', 'An athlete, for example, may have a high BMI because the tool doesn’t distinguish between the body’s percentage of fat and muscle in a person’s weight.']
['What are some examples of consequences that obesity has?', 'Being extremely overweight or obese is a risk factor for several negative health consequences.']

['What are the health consequences?', 'These include, but are not limited to, an increased risk for cardiovascular disease, stroke, Type 2 diabetes, liver disease, sleep apnea, colon cancer, breast cancer, infertility, and arthritis.']

['Are there any ways to combat this problem?', 'Given that it is estimated that in the United States around forty percent of the adult population is obese and that nearly three-quarters of adults and one in six children qualify as overweight (CDC, 2018), there is substantial interest in trying to understand how to combat this important public health concern.']

['How does obesity cause health problems?', 'You have already read that both genes and environment are important factors for determining body weight, and if more calories are consumed than expended, excess energy is stored as fat.']
['What other factors contribute to obesity?', 'However, socioeconomic status and the physical environment must also be considered as contributing factors (CDC, 2012).']

['What environment can make one obese?', 'For example, an individual who lives in a neighborhood with high crime rates and few food options may never feel comfortable walking or biking to work or to the local market.']
['Why not feel comfortable walking or biking?', 'This might limit the amount of physical activity in which they engage.']

['What else could contribute to obesity?', 'Similarly, some people may not be able to afford healthy food options from their market, or these options may be unavailable (especially in urban areas or poorer neighborhoods); therefore, some people must rely primarily on available, inexpensive, high fat, and high calorie fast food as their primary source of nutrition.']
['What can you tell me about the treatment for obesity?', 'Generally, people are encouraged to try to maintain and improve health through a combination of both diet and exercise.']
['How successful do they usually do that?', 'While some people are very successful with these approaches, many are not.']

['What else can you tell me about obesity?', 'In cases in which a person has had no success with repeated attempts to reduce weight or is at risk for death because of obesity, bariatric surgery may be recommended.']

['What does bariatric surgery involve?', 'Bariatric surgery is a type of surgery specifically aimed at weight reduction, and it involves modifying the gastrointestinal system to reduce the amount of food that can be eaten and/or limiting how much of the digested food can be absorbed (Figure 10.11) (Mayo Clinic, 2013).']

['Is bariatric surgery more effective than diet and exercise?', 'A recent meta-analysis suggests that bariatric surgery is more effective than non-surgical treatment for obesity in the two-years immediately following the procedure, but to date, no long-term studies yet exist (Gloy et al., 2013).']

['What is the most important fact?', 'While nearly two out of three US adults struggle with issues related to being overweight, a smaller, but significant, portion of the population has eating disorders that typically result in being normal weight or underweight.']
['What is the most important information in this paragraph?', 'Often, these individuals are fearful of gaining weight.']
['What is the most important information in this paragraph?', 'Individuals who have bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa face many adverse health consequences (Mayo Clinic, 2012a, 2012b).']
['What are eating disorders?', 'People suffering from bulimia nervosa engage in binge eating behavior that is followed by an attempt to compensate for the large amount of food consumed.']
['How do they compensate for the food?', 'Purging the food by inducing vomiting or through the use of laxatives are two common compensatory behaviors.']
['How else do they compensate?', 'Some affected individuals engage in excessive amounts of exercise to compensate for their binges.']
['How is their body affected?', 'Bulimia is associated with many adverse health consequences that can include kidney failure, heart failure, and tooth decay.']

['Are there any other negative health effects?', 'In addition, these individuals often suffer from anxiety and depression, and they are at an increased risk for substance abuse (Mayo Clinic, 2012b).']

['Are there a lot of people who suffer from this disorder?', 'The lifetime prevalence rate for bulimia nervosa is estimated at around 1% for women and less than 0.5% for men (Smink, van Hoeken, & Hoek, 2012).']

['What are disorders?', 'As of the 2013 release of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, fifth edition, Binge eating disorder is a disorder recognized by the American Psychiatric Association (APA).']

['What else can you tell me about this disorder?', 'Unlike with bulimia, eating binges are not followed by inappropriate behavior, such as purging, but they are followed by distress, including feelings of guilt and embarrassment.']
['How do these feelings compare to overeating?', 'The resulting psychological distress distinguishes binge eating disorder from overeating (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013).']
['What is Anorexia?', 'Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by the maintenance of a body weight well below average through starvation and/or excessive exercise.']

['What kind of body image does anorexic people have?', 'Individuals with anorexia nervosa often have a distorted body image, referenced in literature as a type of body dysmorphia, meaning that they view themselves as overweight even though they are not.']

['How does anorexia affect their health?', 'Like bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa is associated with a number of significant negative health outcomes: bone loss, heart failure, kidney failure, amenorrhea (cessation of the menstrual period), reduced function of the gonads, and in extreme cases, death.']

['What else can anorexics do?', 'Furthermore, there is an increased risk for a number of psychological problems, which include anxiety disorders, mood disorders, and substance abuse (Mayo Clinic, 2012a).']
['How common is this?', 'Estimates of the prevalence of anorexia nervosa vary from study to study but generally range from just under one percent to just over four percent in women.']
['Does it happen to men?', 'Generally, prevalence rates are considerably lower for men (Smink et al., 2012).']

['What were some examples of eating disorders?', 'While both anorexia and bulimia nervosa occur in people from many different cultures, White females from Western societies tend to be the most at-risk population.']

['Did they cite any sources that supported the theories?', 'Recent research indicates that females between the ages of 15 and 19 are most at risk, and it has long been suspected that these eating disorders are culturally-bound phenomena that are related to messages of a thin ideal often portrayed in popular media and the fashion world (Figure 10.13) (Smink et al., 2012).']

['What else did they discuss?', 'While social factors play an important role in the development of eating disorders, there is also evidence that genetic factors may predispose people to these disorders (Collier & Treasure, 2004).']
['What is sexual behavior like?', "Like food, sex is an important part of many people's lives."]
['Why is sexual behavior important?', 'From an evolutionary perspective, the reason is obvious—perpetuation of the species.']
['Is reproduction the only reason for sexual behavior?', 'Sexual behavior in humans, however, involves much more than reproduction.']
['What are some of the most important factors in sexual behavior?', 'This section provides an overview of research that has been conducted on human sexual behavior and motivation.']
['How does this section end?', 'This section will close with a discussion of issues related to gender identity and expression and sexual orientation.']
['What is important to know about this topic?', 'Much of what we know about the physiological mechanisms that underlie sexual behavior and motivation comes from animal research.']
['What are some other important parts of this material?', 'As you’ve learned, the hypothalamus plays an important role in motivated behaviors, and sex is no exception.']

['What do scientists study about the hypothalamus?', 'In fact, lesions to an area of the hypothalamus called the medial preoptic area completely disrupt a male rat’s ability to engage in sexual behavior.']
['What is surprising about this?', 'Surprisingly, medial preoptic lesions do not change how hard a male rat is willing to work to gain access to a sexually receptive female (Figure 10.14).']
['What are these observations?', 'This suggests that the ability to engage in sexual behavior and the motivation to do so may be mediated by neural systems distinct from one another.']
['what was the content about?', 'Animal research suggests that limbic system structures such as the amygdala and nucleus accumbens are especially important for sexual motivation.']
['what did the research show?', 'Damage to these areas results in a decreased motivation to engage in sexual behavior, while leaving the ability to do so intact (Figure 10.15) (Everett, 1990).']
['what was the research?', 'Similar dissociations of sexual motivation and sexual ability have also been observed in the female rat (Becker, Rudick, & Jenkins, 2001; Jenkins & Becker, 2001).']
['What is significant about this material?', 'Although human sexual behavior is much more complex than that seen in rats, some parallels between animals and humans can be drawn from this research.']

['What is a common denominator between rats and humans?', 'The worldwide popularity of drugs used to treat erectile dysfunction (Conrad, 2005) speaks to the fact that sexual motivation and the ability to engage in sexual behavior can also be dissociated in humans.']

['What are other parallels?', 'Moreover, disorders that involve abnormal hypothalamic function are often associated with hypogonadism (reduced function of the gonads) and reduced sexual function (e.g., Prader-Willi syndrome).']

['What happens to the hypothalamus?', 'Given the hypothalamus’s role in endocrine function, it is not surprising that hormones secreted by the endocrine system also play important roles in sexual motivation and behavior.']
['What else does the study find?', 'For example, many animals show no sign of sexual motivation in the absence of the appropriate combination of sex hormones from their gonads.']

['Are there any other parallels between animals and humans?', 'While this is not the case for humans, there is considerable evidence that sexual motivation for all genders varies as a function of circulating testosterone levels (Bhasin, Enzlin, Coviello, & Basson, 2007; Carter, 1992; Sherwin, 1988).']
["When did Kinsey's Research begin?", 'Before the late 1940s, access to reliable, empirically-based information on sex was limited.']

['What was the main source of information before 1940?', 'Physicians were considered authorities on all issues related to sex, despite the fact that they had little to no training in these issues, and it is likely that most of what people knew about sex had been learned either through their own experiences or by talking with their peers.']

["Who led Kinsey's Research?", 'Convinced that people would benefit from a more open dialogue on issues related to human sexuality, Dr. Alfred Kinsey of Indiana University initiated large-scale survey research on the topic (Figure 10.16).']

["How did Kinsey's research benefit the public?", 'The results of some of these efforts were published in two books—Sexual Behavior in the Human Male and Sexual Behavior in the Human Female—which were published in 1948 and 1953, respectively (Bullough, 1998).']
['What is significant about the research?', 'At the time, the Kinsey reports were quite sensational.']
['What did they tell?', 'Never before had the American public seen its private sexual behavior become the focus of scientific scrutiny on such a large scale.']

['Why were they sensational?', 'The books, which were filled with statistics and scientific lingo, sold remarkably well to the general public, and people began to engage in open conversations about human sexuality.']
['What was the reaction?', 'As you might imagine, not everyone was happy that this information was being published.']
['How did the public react?', 'In fact, these books were banned in some countries.']
['Why were they banned?', 'Ultimately, the controversy resulted in Kinsey losing funding that he had secured from the Rockefeller Foundation to continue his research efforts (Bancroft, 2004).']

['What is so interesting about this research?', 'Although Kinsey’s research has been widely criticized as being riddled with sampling and statistical errors (Jenkins, 2010), there is little doubt that this research was very influential in shaping future research on human sexual behavior and motivation.']
['What else was he researching?', 'Kinsey described a remarkably diverse range of sexual behaviors and experiences reported by the volunteers participating in his research.']

['What else did he find?', 'Behaviors that had once been considered exceedingly rare or problematic were demonstrated to be much more common and innocuous than previously imagined (Bancroft, 2004; Bullough, 1998).']

['What was the most important point of his research?', 'Among the results of Kinsey’s research were the findings that women are as interested and experienced in sex as men, that both males and females masturbate without adverse health consequences, and that relationships and sexual acts between people of the same sex and/or the same gender are fairly common (Bancroft, 2004).']

['Was his research important?', 'Kinsey also developed a continuum known as the Kinsey scale that is still commonly used today to categorize an individual’s sexual orientation, which is an individual’s emotional, romantic, and erotic attractions to other people or no people (Jenkins, 2010).']

['Who did Masters and Johnson study?', 'In 1966, William Masters and Virginia Johnson published a book detailing the results of their observations of nearly 700 people who agreed to participate in their study of physiological responses during sexual behavior.']

['What was unique about their study?', 'Unlike Kinsey, who used personal interviews and surveys to collect data, Masters and Johnson observed people having intercourse in a variety of positions, and they observed people masturbating, manually or with the aid of a device.']

['How was this data collected?', 'While this was occurring, researchers recorded measurements of physiological variables, such as blood pressure and respiration rate, as well as measurements of sexual arousal, such as vaginal lubrication and penile tumescence (swelling associated with an erection).']
['How many sexual acts did they observe?', 'In total, Masters and Johnson observed nearly 10,000 sexual acts as a part of their research (Hock, 2008).']

['What was the focus of the Masters and Johnson study?', 'Based on these observations, Masters and Johnson divided the sexual response cycle into four phases that are fairly similar in men and women: excitement, plateau, orgasm, and resolution (Figure 10.17).']

['What are the four phases?', 'The excitement phase is the arousal phase of the sexual response cycle, and it is marked by erection of the penis or clitoris and lubrication and expansion of the vaginal canal.']

['What else happens during the excitement phase?', 'During plateau, the vagina swells further and blood flow to the labia minora increases, and the penis becomes fully erect and may exhibit pre-ejaculatory fluid.']
['What else occurs during the plateau phase?', 'People experience increases in muscle tone during this time.']
['What happens during the orgasm phase?', 'Orgasm is marked in females by rhythmic contractions of the pelvis and uterus along with increased muscle tension.']

['What else happens during this phase?', 'In males, pelvic contractions are accompanied by a buildup of seminal fluid near the urethra that is ultimately forced out by contractions of genital muscles, (i.e., ejaculation).']
['What happens during resolution?', 'Resolution is the relatively rapid return to an unaroused state accompanied by a decrease in blood pressure and muscular relaxation.']
['What is the refractory period?', 'The refractory period is a period of time that follows an orgasm during which an individual is incapable of experiencing another orgasm.']

['How long does the refractory period last?', 'The duration of the refractory period can vary dramatically from individual to individual with some refractory periods as short as several minutes and others as long as a day.']
['Do the refractory periods get shorter with age?', 'As people age, their refractory periods tend to span longer periods of time.']

['What did they find?', 'In addition to the insights that their research provided with regards to the sexual response cycle and the multi-orgasmic potential of females, Masters and Johnson also collected important information about reproductive anatomy.']

['How did they find this?', 'Their research demonstrated the oft-cited statistic of the average size of a flaccid and an erect penis (3 and 6 inches, respectively) as well as dispelling long-held beliefs about relationships between the size of an erect penis and its ability to provide sexual pleasure to a partner.']
['Why did they dispel this?', 'Furthermore, they determined that the vagina is a very elastic structure that can conform to penises of various sizes (Hock, 2008).']
['Were these findings controversial?', 'In a similar manner to Kinsey’s work and other studies, Masters and Johnson’s research has been criticized, built on, and in some cases proven wrong.']
['Is their research considered accurate today?', 'The research represents an important element of the history of sexual research, and is not viewed as entirely accurate today.']
['What is sexual orientation?', 'As mentioned earlier, a person’s sexual orientation is their emotional, romantic, and erotic attraction toward other people or no people.']

['Did it include anyone outside of heterosexual?', 'While the majority of people identify as heterosexual, there is a sizable population of people within the United States who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, pansexual, asexual, or other non-hetero sexualities.']

['What are the major differences?', 'Bisexual people are attracted to people of their own gender and another gender; pansexual people experience attraction without regard to sex, gender identity or gender expression; asexual people do not experience sexual attraction or have little or no interest in sexual activity.']
['What is queer?', 'Queer is an umbrella term used to describe sexual orientation, gender identity, or gender expression.']
['What else can you tell me about sexual orientation?', 'Other descriptive terms may not refer to a sexual attraction, but rather a romantic one.']
['How do they differ?', 'For example, an aromantic person does not experience romantic attraction; this is different from asexuality, which refers to a lack of sexual attraction.']
['What is queer?', 'And some sexual orientations do not refer to gender in their description (PFLAG, 2021).']

['What else can you tell me about sexual orientation?', 'It is important to acknowledge and understand that many of these orientations exist on on a spectrum, and there may be no specific term to describe how an individual feels.']
['What is sexual orientation?', 'Some of these terms have been associated in abbreviations such as LGBTQ (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer or questioning).']

['What are LGBTQ abbreviations?', 'In some cases, people and organizations may add "I" to represent intersex people (described below), and "A" for asexual or aromantic people (or sometimes for "allies"), as well as one "P" to describe pansexual people and sometimes another "P" to describe polysexual people.']
['How do people and organizations define sexual orientation?', 'Finally, some people and organizations add a plus sign (+) to represent other possible identities or orientations.']

['What is a plus sign (+)?', 'Sexuality and gender terminology are constantly changing, and may mean different things to different people; they are not universal, and each individual defines them for themselves (UC Davis LGBTQIA Resource Center 2020).']
['what is sexual orientation?', 'Issues of sexual orientation have long fascinated scientists interested in determining what causes one individual to be straight while another is gay.']
['are there any theories about why it is so difficult to determine?', 'For many years, people believed that these differences arose because of different socialization and familial experiences.']

['what have the results of studies shown?', 'However, research has consistently demonstrated that the family backgrounds and experiences are very similar among straight people and LGBTQ people (Bell, Weinberg, & Hammersmith, 1981; Ross & Arrindell, 1988).']

['What is the evidence for sexual orientation having a genetic component?', 'Genetic and biological mechanisms have also been proposed, and the balance of research evidence suggests that sexual orientation has an underlying biological component.']

["What is the evidence that it's genetic?", 'For instance, over the past 25 years, research has demonstrated gene-level contributions to sexual orientation (Bailey & Pillard, 1991; Hamer, Hu, Magnuson, Hu, & Pattatucci, 1993; Rodriguez-Larralde & Paradisi, 2009), with some researchers estimating that genes account for at least half of the variability seen in human sexual orientation (Pillard & Bailey, 1998).']

['What other evidence is there?', 'Other studies report differences in brain structure and function among those with different sexual orientations (Allen & Gorski, 1992; Byne et al., 2001; Hu et al., 2008; LeVay, 1991; Ponseti et al., 2006; Rahman & Wilson, 2003a; Swaab & Hofman, 1990), and even differences in basic body structure and function have been observed (Hall & Kimura, 1994; Lippa, 2003; Loehlin & McFadden, 2003; McFadden & Champlin, 2000; McFadden & Pasanen, 1998; Rahman & Wilson, 2003b).']
['Are there any other factors involved?', 'In aggregate, the data suggest that to a significant extent, sexual orientations are something with which we are born.']

['What are some misconceptions about sexual orientation?', 'Regardless of how sexual orientation is determined, research has made clear that sexual orientation is not a choice, but rather it is a relatively stable characteristic of a person that cannot be changed.']

['How is it thought that people can change their sexual orientation?', 'Claims of effective conversion therapy have received wide criticism from the research community due to significant concerns with research design, recruitment of experimental participants, and interpretation of data.']

['Can there really be no evidence that people can change their sexual orientation?', 'As such, there is no credible scientific evidence to suggest that individuals can change their sexual orientation (Jenkins, 2010).']

['What is the introduction to Misunderstandings about Sexual Orientation?', 'Dr. Robert Spitzer, the author of one of the most widely-cited examples of conversion therapy, apologized to both the scientific community and the LGBTQ community for his mistakes, and he publically recanted his own paper in a public letter addressed to the editor of Archives of Sexual Behavior in the spring of 2012 (Carey, 2012).']
['Did Spitzer write any other papers or books?', 'In this letter, Spitzer wrote,']
['Why did people confuse sexual orientation with gender identity?', 'Many people conflate sexual orientation with gender identity because of misconceptions and attitudes that exist about sexuality.']
['What does the instructor tell you?', 'In reality, these are two related, but different, aspects of who we are.']
['What is gender identity?', 'Gender identity refers to one’s sense of being male, female, neither of these, both of these, or another gender.']
['Why does it correspond to sex?', 'Generally, our gender identities correspond to our chromosomal and phenotypic sex, but this is not always the case.']
['Why is it not always the case?', 'Transgender people’s gender identity differs from the sex they were assigned at birth.']
['Why does it differ?', 'Transgender people may use a range of terms to describe themselves, including abbreviations (e.g. trans) or terms such as non-binary.']
['What does gender dysphoria mean?', 'When individuals do not feel comfortable identifying with the gender associated with their biological sex, then they may experience gender dysphoria.']

['What is gender dysphoria?', 'Gender dysphoria is a diagnostic category in the fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) that describes individuals who do not identify as the gender that most people would assume they are.']
['How is it defined?', 'This dysphoria must persist for at least six months and result in significant distress or dysfunction to meet DSM-5 diagnostic criteria.']

['Does anyone have to change genders in order to be diagnosed with the condition?', 'In order for children to be assigned this diagnostic category, they must verbalize their desire to become the other gender.']

['Do all transgender people experience gender dysphoria?', 'It is important to note that not all transgender people experience gender dysphoria, and that its diagnostic categorization is not universally accepted.']

['Are there other ways of categorizing gender dysphoria?', 'For example, in 2019, the World Health Organization reclassified “gender identity disorder” as “gender incongruence,” and categorized it under sexual health rather than a mental disorder.']
['What does DSM-5 stand for?', 'However, health and mental health professionals indicate that the presence of the diagnostic category does assist in supporting those who need treatment or help.']

['What is gender identity?', 'Some transgender individuals may undertake a process of transition, in which they move from living in a way that is more aligned with the sex assigned at birth to living in a way that is aligned with their gender identity.']
['What is transition?', "Transitioning may take the form of social, legal, or medical aspects of someone's life, but not everyone undertakes any or all types of transition."]
['What is a social transition?', "Social transition may involve the person's presentation, name, pronouns, and relationships."]
['What is a legal transition?', 'Legal transition can include changing their gender on government or other official documents, changing their legal name, and so on.']

['What is a physical transition?', 'Some people may undergo a physical or medical transition, in which they change their outward, physical, or sexual characteristics in order for their physical being to better align with their gender identity (UCSF Transgender Care 2019).']

['What else is there to know about gender identity?', 'Not all transgender individuals choose to alter their bodies: many will maintain their original anatomy but may present themselves to society as another gender.']
['How do they present themselves?', 'This is typically done by adopting the dress, hairstyle, mannerisms, or other characteristics typically assigned to another gender.']

['What other information can you provide?', 'It is important to note that people who cross-dress, or wear clothing that is traditionally assigned to a gender different from their biological sex, are not necessarily transgender.']
['Why is that?', "Cross-dressing is typically a form of self-expression or personal style, and it does not indicate a person's gender identity or that they are transgender (TSER 2021)."]

['What is intersex?', 'Intersex is a general term used to describe people whose sex traits, reproductive anatomy, hormones, or chromosomes are different from the usual two ways human bodies develop.']
['What is significant about the intersex issue?', 'Some intersex traits are recognized at birth, while others are not recognizable until puberty or later in life (interACT 2021).']

['What are some of the most important characteristics of intersex?', 'Intersex and transgender are not interchangeable terms; many transgender people have no intersex traits, and many intersex people do not consider themselves transgender.']
['What is cisgender?', 'Those who identify with the sex they were assigned at birth are often referred to as cisgender, utilizing the Latin prefix "cis," which means "on the same side."']
['What is transgender?', '(The prefix "trans" means "across.")']
['What do cisgender people think?', 'Many cisgender people do not self-identify as such.']

['Do cis people think differently from transgender people?', "As with transgender people, the term or usage of cisgender does not indicate a person's sexual orientation, gender, or gender expression (TSER 2021)."]

['What are some important facts about gender identity?', 'Our scientific knowledge and general understanding about gender identity continue to evolve, and young people today have more opportunity to explore and openly express different ideas about what gender means than previous generations.']

['Does gender identity vary across generations?', 'Recent studies indicate that the majority of millennials (those ages 18–34) regard gender as a spectrum instead of a strict male/female binary, and that 12% identify as transgender or gender non-conforming.']
['What are some other interesting facts?', 'Additionally, more people know others who use gender-neutral pronouns (such as they/them) (Kennedy, 2017).']
['Does this change in language have a meaning?', 'This change in language may indicate that millennials and Generation Z people understand the experience of gender itself differently.']
