['What is the next step for gender identity?', 'As young people lead this change, other changes are emerging in a range of spheres, from public bathroom policies to retail organizations.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'For example, some retailers are starting to change traditional gender-based marketing of products, such as removing “pink and blue” clothing and toy aisles.']
['Does this change help or harm?', 'Even with these changes, those who exist outside of traditional gender norms face difficult challenges.']
['Do people still discriminate against trans people?', 'Even people who vary slightly from traditional norms are often the target of discrimination and violence.']
['What does that mean?', 'Issues related to sexual orientation and gender identity are very much influenced by sociocultural factors.']
['Are they defined by a cultural norm or by a personal opinion?', 'Even the ways in which we define sexual orientation and gender vary from one culture to the next.']

['What is a cultural norm?', 'While in the United States heterosexuality has historically been viewed as the norm (making it a heteronormative society), there are societies that have different attitudes regarding LGBTQ people.']

['Does gender identity depend on your social status?', 'In fact, in some instances, periods of exclusively same-sex sexual behavior are socially prescribed as a part of normal development and maturation.']

['What are some other cultural factors that influence gender?', 'For example, in parts of New Guinea, young boys are expected to engage in sexual behavior with other boys for a given period of time because it is believed that doing so is necessary for these boys to become men (Baldwin & Baldwin, 1989).']
["How does gender identity compare to one's ethnicity?", 'There has historically been a two-gendered culture in the United States.']

['How does one become identified as either male or female?', 'We have tended to classify an individual as either male or female according to the sex they were assigned at birth, leading the United States to be considered a cisnormative society.']
['What is one factor that influences gender identity?', 'However, in some cultures there are additional gender variants resulting in more than two gender categories.']
['What is a prominent example?', 'For example, in Thailand, you can be male, female, or kathoey.']
['What does kathoey mean?', 'A kathoey is an individual who would be described as intersex or transgender in the United States (Tangmunkongvorakul, Banwell, Carmichael, Utomo, & Sleigh, 2010).']
['What is it about?', 'As we move through our daily lives, we experience a variety of emotions.']
['What are emotions?', 'An emotion is a subjective state of being that we often describe as our feelings.']

['How do emotions impact our lives?', 'Emotions result from the combination of subjective experience, expression, cognitive appraisal, and physiological responses (Levenson, Carstensen, Friesen, & Ekman, 1991).']

['What are some other things that we need to know about emotions?', 'However, as discussed later in the chapter, the exact order in which the components occur is not clear, and some parts may happen at the same time.']
['What is an example of this?', 'An emotion often begins with a subjective (individual) experience, which is a stimulus.']
['What kind of stimulus?', 'Often the stimulus is external, but it does not have to be from the outside world.']
['What are some other examples?', 'For example, it might be that one thinks about war and becomes sad, even though they never experienced war.']
['What is expression?', 'Emotional expression refers to the way one displays an emotion and includes nonverbal and verbal behaviors (Gross, 1999).']
['What else is part of emotion?', 'One also performs a cognitive appraisal in which a person tries to determine the way they will be impacted by a situation (Roseman & Smith, 2001).']
['What else is important?', 'In addition, emotions include physiological responses, such as possible changes in heart rate, sweating, etc. (Soussignan, 2002).']
['What is emotion?', 'The words emotion and mood are sometimes used interchangeably, but psychologists use these words to refer to two different things.']

['How does emotion differ from mood?', 'Typically, the word emotion indicates a subjective, affective state that is relatively intense and that occurs in response to something we experience (Figure 10.20).']
['How do emotions affect the way we perceive things?', 'Emotions are often thought to be consciously experienced and intentional.']
['How is mood different from emotion?', 'Mood, on the other hand, refers to a prolonged, less intense, affective state that does not occur in response to something we experience.']
['How do moods affect us?', 'Mood states may not be consciously recognized and do not carry the intentionality that is associated with emotion (Beedie, Terry, Lane, & Devonport, 2011).']
['Can you tell me more about mood?', 'Here we will focus on emotion, and you will learn more about mood in the chapter that covers psychological disorders.']
['What is emotion?', 'We can be at the heights of joy or in the depths of despair.']
['Why would we feel the way we do?', 'We might feel angry when we are betrayed, fear when we are threatened, and surprised when something unexpected happens.']

['What theories do you know of about emotion?', 'This section will outline some of the most well-known theories explaining our emotional experience and provide insight into the biological bases of emotion.']
['What else is there in this section?', 'This section closes with a discussion of the ubiquitous nature of facial expressions of emotion and our abilities to recognize those expressions in others.']
['How are the theories of emotion classified?', 'Our emotional states are combinations of physiological arousal, psychological appraisal, and subjective experiences.']
['What are the theories of emotions?', 'Together, these are the components of emotion, and our experiences, backgrounds, and cultures inform our emotions.']
['Does emotion change based on our experiences?', 'Therefore, different people may have different emotional experiences even when faced with similar circumstances.']

['What are some other theories of emotions?', 'Over time, several different theories of emotion, shown in Figure 10.21, have been proposed to explain how the various components of emotion interact with one another.']
['What was the James-Lange Theory of Emotion?', 'The James-Lange theory of emotion asserts that emotions arise from physiological arousal.']
['What are the physiological mechanisms arousal produces?', 'Recall what you have learned about the sympathetic nervous system and our fight or flight response when threatened.']

['What happens after your fight or flight response?', 'If you were to encounter some threat in your environment, like a venomous snake in your backyard, your sympathetic nervous system would initiate significant physiological arousal, which would make your heart race and increase your respiration rate.']
['What type of emotion would you have as a result?', 'According to the James-Lange theory of emotion, you would only experience a feeling of fear after this physiological arousal had taken place.']
['What else can you tell me about the James-Lange theory?', 'Furthermore, different arousal patterns would be associated with different feelings.']

['What is an example of a theory of emotion?', 'Other theorists, however, doubted that the physiological arousal that occurs with different types of emotions is distinct enough to result in the wide variety of emotions that we experience.']
["What is a theory of emotion that wasn't quite as accurate?", 'Thus, the Cannon-Bard theory of emotion was developed.']

['What happened after the Cannon-Bard theory of emotion was developed?', 'According to this view, physiological arousal and emotional experience occur simultaneously, yet independently (Lang, 1994).']
['What was an example of physiological arousal?', 'So, when you see the venomous snake, you feel fear at exactly the same time that your body mounts its fight or flight response.']
['What else was said about this theory?', 'This emotional reaction would be separate and independent of the physiological arousal, even though they co-occur.']

['What is a hypothesis in the Theories of Emotion?', 'The facial feedback hypothesis proposes that your facial expression can actually affect your emotional experience (Adelman & Zajonc, 1989; Boiger & Mesquita, 2012; Buck, 1980; Capella, 1993; Soussignan, 2001).']

['what evidence supports the theory?', 'Research investigating the facial feedback hypothesis suggested that suppression of facial expression of emotion lowered the intensity of some emotions experienced by participants (Davis, Senghas, & Ochsner, 2009).']

['how did he test this?', 'Havas, Glenberg, Gutowski, Lucarelli, and Davidson (2010) used Botox injections to paralyze facial muscles and limit facial expressions, including frowning, and they found that depressed people reported less depression after their frowning muscles were paralyzed.']
['What else did the researcher test?', 'Other research found that the intensities of facial expressions affected the emotional reactions (Soussignan, 2002).']

['what else was studied?', 'In other words, if something insignificant occurs and you smile as if you just won lottery, you will actually be happier about the little thing than you would be if you only had a tiny smile.']
['Did he study this?', 'Conversely, if you walk around frowning all the time, it might cause you to have less positive emotions than you would if you had smiled.']
['what else did they study?', 'Interestingly, Soussignan (2002) also reported physiological arousal differences associated with the intensities of one type of smile.']
['Who were G. Maraon Posadillo and adrenaline?', 'G. Marañon Posadillo was a Spanish physician who studied the psychological effects of adrenaline to create a model for the experience of emotion.']
['What was the model?', "Marañon's model preceded Schachter's two-factor or arousal-cognition theory of emotion (Cornelius, 1991)."]

['What was the Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion?', 'The Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion is another variation on theories of emotions that takes into account both physiological arousal and the emotional experience.']
['Did it say how emotions are composed?', 'According to this theory, emotions are composed of two factors: physiological and cognitive.']
['Is there more information about the physiological factors?', 'In other words, physiological arousal is interpreted in context to produce the emotional experience.']

['What is an example of the interpretation?', 'In revisiting our example involving the venomous snake in your backyard, the two-factor theory maintains that the snake elicits sympathetic nervous system activation that is labeled as fear given the context, and our experience is that of fear.']
['Is there more information about the physiology factor?', 'If you had labeled your sympathetic nervous system activation as joy, you would have experienced joy.']
['How do the cognitive factors work?', 'The Schachter-Singer two-factor theory depends on labeling the physiological experience, which is a type of cognitive appraisal.']

["What was Arnold's theory about?", 'Magda Arnold was the first theorist to offer an exploration of the meaning of appraisal, and to present an outline of what the appraisal process might be and how it relates to emotion (Roseman & Smith, 2001).']

['How does this theory work?', 'The key idea of appraisal theory is that you have thoughts (a cognitive appraisal) before you experience an emotion, and the emotion you experience depends on the thoughts you had (Frijda, 1988; Lazarus, 1991).']
['How is that related to emotions?', 'If you think something is positive, you will have more positive emotions about it than if your appraisal was negative, and the opposite is true.']
['What else does the theory explain?', 'Appraisal theory explains the way two people can have two completely different emotions regarding the same event.']

['How does the theory work?', 'For example, suppose your psychology instructor selected you to lecture on emotion; you might see that as positive, because it represents an opportunity to be the center of attention, and you would experience happiness.']
['What else do you see in the example?', 'However, if you dislike speaking in public, you could have a negative appraisal and experience discomfort.']

['What type of emotions do Schachter and Singer study?', 'Schachter and Singer believed that physiological arousal is very similar across the different types of emotions that we experience, and therefore, the cognitive appraisal of the situation is critical to the actual emotion experienced.']

['Are there other studies or articles about Schachter and Singer?', 'In fact, it might be possible to misattribute arousal to an emotional experience if the circumstances were right (Schachter & Singer, 1962).']
['What type of experiment did Schachter and Singer do?', 'They performed a clever experiment to test their idea.']
['What was their experiment?', 'A group of men participating in the experiment were randomly assigned to one of several groups.']

['What happened with those in the experiment groups?', 'Some of the participants received injections of epinephrine that caused bodily changes that mimicked the fight-or-flight response of the sympathetic nervous system; however, only some of these men were told to expect these reactions as side effects of the injection.']

['What were the other groups?', 'The other men that received injections of epinephrine were told either that the injection would have no side effects or that it would result in a side effect unrelated to a sympathetic response, such as itching feet or headache.']
['What happened after the injection?', 'After receiving these injections, participants waited in a room with someone else they thought was another subject in the research project.']
['Did they have any other part in the experiment?', 'In reality, the other person was a confederate (someone working on behalf of) of the researcher.']
['How did the confederate make them feel?', 'The confederate engaged in scripted displays of euphoric or angry behavior (Schachter & Singer, 1962).']

['What were the conclusions?', 'When those participants who were told that they should expect to feel symptoms of physiological arousal were asked about any emotional changes that they had experienced related to either euphoria or anger (depending on the way the confederate behaved), they reported none.']

['How did they respond?', 'However, the men who weren’t expecting physiological arousal as a function of the injection were more likely to report that they experienced euphoria or anger as a function of their assigned confederate’s behavior.']

['What else did you find interesting?', 'While everyone who received an injection of epinephrine experienced the same physiological arousal, only those who were not expecting the arousal used context to interpret the arousal as a change in emotional state (Schachter & Singer, 1962).']

['What is a physiological response?', 'Strong emotional responses are associated with strong physiological arousal, which caused some theorists to suggest that the signs of physiological arousal, including increased heart rate, respiration rate, and sweating, might be used to determine whether someone is telling the truth or not.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects about the article?', 'A polygraph, or lie detector test, measures the physiological arousal of an individual responding to a series of questions.']

['How does that work?', 'Someone trained in reading these tests would look for answers to questions that are associated with increased levels of arousal as potential signs that the respondent may have been dishonest on those answers.']

['What is the validity of polygraphs?', 'While polygraphs are still commonly used, their validity and accuracy are highly questionable because there is no evidence that lying is associated with any particular pattern of physiological arousal (Saxe & Ben-Shakhar, 1999).']

['What are some key aspects of this document?', 'The relationship between our experiencing of emotions and our cognitive processing of them, and the order in which these occur, remains a topic of research and debate.']
['What is the cognitive-mediational theory?', 'Lazarus (1991) developed the cognitive-mediational theory that asserts our emotions are determined by our appraisal of the stimulus.']
['What happens after appraisal?', 'This appraisal mediates between the stimulus and the emotional response, and it is immediate and often unconscious.']
['What happens after that?', 'In contrast to the Schachter-Singer model, the appraisal precedes a cognitive label.']
['What does the appraisal concept mean?', 'You will learn more about Lazarus’s appraisal concept when you study stress, health, and lifestyle.']
['What are some other theories of emotions?', 'However, there are other views of emotions that also emphasize the cognitive processes.']
['What are your first few words?', 'Return to the example of being asked to lecture by your professor.']
['What would you have to do when asked?', 'Even if you do not enjoy speaking in public, you probably could manage to do it.']

['How can you be sure to speak?', 'You would purposefully control your emotions, which would allow you to speak, but we constantly regulate our emotions, and much of our emotion regulation occurs without us actively thinking about it.']
['What is automatic emotion regulation?', 'Mauss and her colleagues studied automatic emotion regulation (AER), which refers to the non-deliberate control of emotions.']
['What is non-deliberate control?', 'It is simply not reacting with your emotions, and AER can affect all aspects of emotional processes.']

['How does this affect emotions?', 'AER can influence the things you attend to, your appraisal, your choice to engage in an emotional experience, and your behaviors after an emotion is experienced (Mauss, Bunge, & Gross, 2007; Mauss, Levenson, McCarter, Wilhelm, & Gross, 2005).']

['What are some of the other cognitive processes that affect emotion?', 'AER is similar to other automatic cognitive processes in which sensations activate knowledge structures that affect functioning.']
['How do knowledge structures effect functioning?', 'These knowledge structures can include concepts, schemas, or scripts.']

['What does AER stand for?', 'The idea of AER is that people develop an automatic process that works like a script or schema, and the process does not require deliberate thought to regulate emotions.']
['How does this work?', 'AER works like riding a bicycle.']
['What are the similarities?', 'Once you develop the process, you just do it without thinking about it.']
['How can you avoid getting burned?', 'AER can be adaptive or maladaptive and has important health implications (Hopp, Troy, & Mauss, 2011).']

['What can you do about this?', 'Adaptive AER leads to better health outcomes than maladaptive AER, primarily due to experiencing or mitigating stressors better than people with maladaptive AERs (Hopp, Troy, & Mauss, 2011).']
['What is the negative aspect of this?', 'Alternatively, maladaptive AERs may be critical for maintaining some psychological disorders (Hopp, Troy, & Mauss, 2011).']

['What other benefits has this resulted in?', 'Mauss and her colleagues found that strategies could reduce negative emotions, which in turn should increase psychological health (Mauss, Cook, Cheng, & Gross, 2007; Mauss, Cook, & Gross, 2007; Shallcross, Troy, Boland, & Mauss, 2010; Troy, Shallcross, & Mauss, 2013; Troy, Wilhelm, Shallcross, & Mauss, 2010).']

['Are there any other significant findings?', 'Mauss has also suggested there are problems with the way emotions are measured, but she believes most of the aspects of emotions that are typically measured are useful (Mauss, et al., 2005; Mauss & Robinson, 2009).']
['How do you measure emotions?', 'However, another way of considering emotions challenges our entire understanding of emotions.']
["What was Barrett's philosophy?", 'After about three decades of interdisciplinary research, Barrett argued that we do not understand emotions.']
['What did she propose?', 'She proposed that emotions were not built into your brain at birth, but rather they were constructed based on your experiences.']
['What does the constructivist theory say?', 'Emotions in the constructivist theory are predictions that construct your experience of the world.']
['What is a concept?', 'In chapter 7 you learned that concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences.']
['What does Barrett say about emotions?', 'Barrett extended that to include emotions as concepts that are predictions (Barrett, 2017).']
['What else did she say?', 'Two identical physiological states can result in different emotional states depending on your predictions.']
['What are some examples of prediction?', 'For example, your brain predicting a churning stomach in a bakery could lead to you constructing hunger.']
['What other examples?', 'However, your brain predicting a churning stomach while you were waiting for medical test results could lead your brain to construct worry.']
['Why is it different?', 'Thus, you can construct two different emotions from the same physiological sensations.']
['What is a condcutivist?', 'Rather than emotions being something over which you have no control, you can control and influence your emotions.']
['What is the main idea of Theories of Emotion?', 'Two other prominent views arise from the work of Robert Zajonc and Joseph LeDoux.']

['What is the importance of Robert Zajonc?', 'Zajonc asserted that some emotions occur separately from or prior to our cognitive interpretation of them, such as feeling fear in response to an unexpected loud sound (Zajonc, 1998).']

['Was there any other significant theory in the topic of Theories of Emotion?', 'He also believed in what we might casually refer to as a gut feeling—that we can experience an instantaneous and unexplainable like or dislike for someone or something (Zajonc, 1980).']
['What is another theory on Theories of Emotion?', 'LeDoux also views some emotions as requiring no cognition: some emotions completely bypass contextual interpretation.']

['Did Joseph LeDoux have any other theories on Theories of Emotion?', 'His research into the neuroscience of emotion has demonstrated the amygdala’s primary role in fear (Cunha, Monfils, & LeDoux, 2010; LeDoux 1996, 2002).']

['What is the role of amygdala in fear?', 'A fear stimulus is processed by the brain through one of two paths: from the thalamus (where it is perceived) directly to the amygdala or from the thalamus through the cortex and then to the amygdala.']
['What is the significance of these paths?', 'The first path is quick, while the second enables more processing about details of the stimulus.']
['What else is significant about the neuroscience of emotion?', 'In the following section, we will look more closely at the neuroscience of emotional response.']
['What is the most important information in our study material?', 'Earlier, you learned about the limbic system, which is the area of the brain involved in emotion and memory (Figure 10.22).']
['What is the limbic system?', 'The limbic system includes the hypothalamus, thalamus, amygdala, and the hippocampus.']
['Why is it important?', 'The hypothalamus plays a role in the activation of the sympathetic nervous system that is a part of any given emotional reaction.']
['What else does it do?', 'The thalamus serves as a sensory relay center whose neurons project to both the amygdala and the higher cortical regions for further processing.']
['What else does it do?', 'The amygdala plays a role in processing emotional information and sending that information on (Fossati, 2012).']
['Does it integrate emotions?', 'The hippocampus integrates emotional experience with cognition (Femenía, Gómez-Galán, Lindskog, & Magara, 2012).']

['What are the main aspects of Amygdala?', 'The amygdala has received a great deal of attention from researchers interested in understanding the biological basis for emotions, especially fear and anxiety (Blackford & Pine, 2012; Goosens & Maren, 2002; Maren, Phan, & Liberzon, 2013).']
['What else can you tell me about Amygdala?', 'The amygdala is composed of various subnuclei, including the basolateral complex and the central nucleus (Figure 10.23).']
['What is basolateral complex?', 'The basolateral complex has dense connections with a variety of sensory areas of the brain.']
['What else can you tell me about Amygdala?', 'It is critical for classical conditioning and for attaching emotional value to learning processes and memory.']

['What else can you tell me about Amygdala?', 'The central nucleus plays a role in attention, and it has connections with the hypothalamus and various brainstem areas to regulate the autonomic nervous and endocrine systems’ activity (Pessoa, 2010).']

['How can animal research be applied to the study of Amygdala?', 'Animal research has demonstrated that there is increased activation of the amygdala in rat pups that have odor cues paired with electrical shock when their mother is absent.']
['What does this lead to?', 'This leads to an aversion to the odor cue that suggests the rats learned to fear the odor cue.']
['Why does the rat prefer the shock?', 'Interestingly, when the mother was present, the rats actually showed a preference for the odor cue despite its association with an electrical shock.']
['What is that preference associated with?', 'This preference was associated with no increases in amygdala activation.']

['What is this telling us about the amygdala?', 'This suggests a differential effect on the amygdala by the context (the presence or absence of the mother) determined whether the pups learned to fear the odor or to be attracted to it (Moriceau & Sullivan, 2006).']

['What is this study about?', 'Raineki, Cortés, Belnoue, and Sullivan (2012) demonstrated that, in rats, negative early life experiences could alter the function of the amygdala and result in adolescent patterns of behavior that mimic human mood disorders.']
['What happened in the study?', 'In this study, rat pups received either abusive or normal treatment during postnatal days 8–12.']
['How did the abusive treatment affect them?', 'There were two forms of abusive treatment.']
['What did one form involve?', 'The first form of abusive treatment had an insufficient bedding condition.']

['How did it affect their behavior?', 'The mother rat had insufficient bedding material in her cage to build a proper nest that resulted in her spending more time away from her pups trying to construct a nest and less times nursing her pups.']

['Why did she do that?', 'The second form of abusive treatment had an associative learning task that involved pairing odors and an electrical stimulus in the absence of the mother, as described above.']
['What is the control group?', 'The control group was in a cage with sufficient bedding and was left undisturbed with their mothers during the same time period.']
['Did it cause any behavioral issues?', 'The rat pups that experienced abuse were much more likely to exhibit depressive-like symptoms during adolescence when compared to controls.']
['How was it linked to this?', 'These depressive-like behaviors were associated with increased activation of the amygdala.']
['What are some interesting aspects about this material?', 'Human research also suggests a relationship between the amygdala and psychological disorders of mood or anxiety.']

['Are there any more interesting aspects about this relationship?', 'Changes in amygdala structure and function have been demonstrated in adolescents who are either at-risk or have been diagnosed with various mood and/or anxiety disorders (Miguel-Hidalgo, 2013; Qin et al., 2013).']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about this research?', 'It has also been suggested that functional differences in the amygdala could serve as a biomarker to differentiate individuals suffering from bipolar disorder from those suffering from major depressive disorder (Fournier, Keener, Almeida, Kronhaus, & Phillips, 2013).']
['What is the hippocampus involved in?', 'As mentioned earlier, the hippocampus is also involved in emotional processing.']

['What are some other things that the hippocampus is involved in?', 'Like the amygdala, research has demonstrated that hippocampal structure and function are linked to a variety of mood and anxiety disorders.']

['What are some of the disorders that involve changes in hippocampal structure?', 'Individuals suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) show marked reductions in the volume of several parts of the hippocampus, which may result from decreased levels of neurogenesis and dendritic branching (the generation of new neurons and the generation of new dendrites in existing neurons, respectively) (Wang et al., 2010).']

['Is there any connection between PTSD and the hippocampal volume?', 'While it is impossible to make a causal claim with correlational research like this, studies have demonstrated behavioral improvements and hippocampal volume increases following either pharmacological or cognitive-behavioral therapy in individuals suffering from PTSD (Bremner & Vermetten, 2004; Levy-Gigi, Szabó, Kelemen, & Kéri, 2013).']
["What's a topic discussed in this section?", 'Culture can impact the way in which people display emotion.']

['What are some examples of cultural displays?', 'A cultural display rule is one of a collection of culturally specific standards that govern the types and frequencies of displays of emotions that are acceptable (Malatesta & Haviland, 1982).']
['Why do people have different cultural displays?', 'Therefore, people from varying cultural backgrounds can have very different cultural display rules of emotion.']

['How are the displays different?', 'For example, research has shown that individuals from the United States express negative emotions like fear, anger, and disgust both alone and in the presence of others, while Japanese individuals only do so while alone (Matsumoto, 1990).']

['What else do they display?', 'Furthermore, individuals from cultures that tend to emphasize social cohesion are more likely to engage in suppression of emotional reaction so they can evaluate which response is most appropriate in a given context (Matsumoto, Yoo, & Nakagawa, 2008).']
['What else can you tell me about this information?', 'Other distinct cultural characteristics might be involved in emotionality.']
['What other factors might affect emotion processing?', 'For instance, there may be gender differences involved in emotional processing.']

['How much evidence do you have that this is true?', 'While research into gender differences in emotional display is equivocal, there is some evidence that people of different genders may differ in regulation of emotions (McRae, Ochsner, Mauss, Gabrieli, & Gross, 2008).']

['What are some of the studies?', 'Paul Ekman (1972) researched a New Guinea man who was living in a preliterate culture using stone implements, and which was isolated and had never seen any outsiders before.']

['What did he find?', 'Ekman asked the man to show what his facial expression would be if: (1) friends visited, (2) his child had just died, (3) he was about to fight, (4) he stepped on a smelly dead pig.']
['What were the findings?', 'After Ekman’s return from New Guinea, he researched facial expressions for more than four decades.']
['What else did he find?', 'Despite different emotional display rules, our ability to recognize and produce facial expressions of emotion appears to be universal.']

['What else did he find?', 'In fact, even congenitally blind individuals produce the same facial expression of emotions, despite their never having the opportunity to observe these facial displays of emotion in other people.']

['What else did Ekman find?', 'This would seem to suggest that the pattern of activity in facial muscles involved in generating emotional expressions is universal, and indeed, this idea was suggested in the late 19th century in Charles Darwin’s book The Expression of Emotions in Man and Animals (1872).']
['What is so universal about facial expressions?', 'In fact, there is substantial evidence for seven universal emotions that are each associated with distinct facial expressions.']
['What are these?', 'These include: happiness, surprise, sadness, fright, disgust, contempt, and anger (Figure 10.24) (Ekman & Keltner, 1997).']
['What can you tell me about facial expression?', 'Of course, emotion is not only displayed through facial expression.']
['What are other ways of expressing emotions?', 'We also use the tone of our voices, various behaviors, and body language to communicate information about our emotional states.']
['What is body language?', 'Body language is the expression of emotion in terms of body position or movement.']

['Does body language convey emotion?', 'Research suggests that we are quite sensitive to the emotional information communicated through body language, even if we’re not consciously aware of it (de Gelder, 2006; Tamietto et al., 2009).']
['What does this mean?', 'Personality refers to the long-standing traits and patterns that propel individuals to consistently think, feel, and behave in specific ways.']
['What else does it explain?', 'Our personality is what makes us unique individuals.']

['What else does it tell me about personality?', 'Each person has an idiosyncratic pattern of enduring, long-term characteristics and a manner in which they interact with other individuals and the world around them.']
['What can you tell me about your personality?', 'Our personalities are thought to be long term, stable, and not easily changed.']
['Where did the word personality come from?', 'The word personality comes from the Latin word persona.']
['What did the persona do?', 'In the ancient world, a persona was a mask worn by an actor.']

['What did the mask represent?', 'While we tend to think of a mask as being worn to conceal one’s identity, the theatrical mask was originally used to either represent or project a specific personality trait of a character (Figure 11.2).']
['What are some historical perspectives?', 'The concept of personality has been studied for at least 2,000 years, beginning with Hippocrates in 370 BCE (Fazeli, 2012).']

['How did he view the concept of personality?', 'Hippocrates theorized that personality traits and human behaviors are based on four separate temperaments associated with four fluids (“humors”) of the body: choleric temperament (yellow bile from the liver), melancholic temperament (black bile from the kidneys), sanguine temperament (red blood from the heart), and phlegmatic temperament (white phlegm from the lungs) (Clark & Watson, 2008; Eysenck & Eysenck, 1985; Lecci & Magnavita, 2013; Noga, 2007).']

['What other people saw the same concept?', 'Centuries later, the influential Greek physician and philosopher Galen built on Hippocrates’s theory, suggesting that both diseases and personality differences could be explained by imbalances in the humors and that each person exhibits one of the four temperaments.']

['Are there any examples from the concept?', 'For example, the choleric person is passionate, ambitious, and bold; the melancholic person is reserved, anxious, and unhappy; the sanguine person is joyful, eager, and optimistic; and the phlegmatic person is calm, reliable, and thoughtful (Clark & Watson, 2008; Stelmack & Stalikas, 1991).']
['Did they have other theories?', 'Galen’s theory was prevalent for over 1,000 years and continued to be popular through the Middle Ages.']

['What did the skull have to do with this?', 'In 1780, Franz Gall, a German physician, proposed that the distances between bumps on the skull reveal a person’s personality traits, character, and mental abilities (Figure 11.3).']

['How did he make this claim?', 'According to Gall, measuring these distances revealed the sizes of the brain areas underneath, providing information that could be used to determine whether a person was friendly, prideful, murderous, kind, good with languages, and so on.']

['Why was this dismissed?', 'Initially, phrenology was very popular; however, it was soon discredited for lack of empirical support and has long been relegated to the status of pseudoscience (Fancher, 1979).']

['What happened in the 20th century?', 'In the centuries after Galen, other researchers contributed to the development of his four primary temperament types, most prominently Immanuel Kant (in the 18th century) and psychologist Wilhelm Wundt (in the 19th century) (Eysenck, 2009; Stelmack & Stalikas, 1991; Wundt, 1874/1886) (Figure 11.4).']

['What did Kant think of temperament?', 'Kant agreed with Galen that everyone could be sorted into one of the four temperaments and that there was no overlap between the four categories (Eysenck, 2009).']
["What was Wundt's take on temperament?", 'He developed a list of traits that could be used to describe the personality of a person from each of the four temperaments.']
['What were the traits he developed?', 'However, Wundt suggested that a better description of personality could be achieved using two major axes: emotional/nonemotional and changeable/unchangeable.']
['What are those axes?', 'The first axis separated strong from weak emotions (the melancholic and choleric temperaments from the phlegmatic and sanguine).']
['Who were the unchangeable ones?', 'The second axis divided the changeable temperaments (choleric and sanguine) from the unchangeable ones (melancholic and phlegmatic) (Eysenck, 2009).']

["What is Freud's perspective of personality?", 'Sigmund Freud’s psychodynamic perspective of personality was the first comprehensive theory of personality, explaining a wide variety of both normal and abnormal behaviors.']

['What is the major idea of his perspective?', 'According to Freud, unconscious drives influenced by sex and aggression, along with childhood sexuality, are the forces that influence our personality.']
['How did his perspective on personality evolve?', 'Freud attracted many followers who modified his ideas to create new theories about personality.']

['What did his followers believe?', 'These theorists, referred to as neo-Freudians, generally agreed with Freud that childhood experiences matter, but they reduced the emphasis on sex and focused more on the social environment and effects of culture on personality.']

['Did this change how psychologists looked at personality?', 'The perspective of personality proposed by Freud and his followers was the dominant theory of personality for the first half of the 20th century.']
['what was one major theory?', 'Other major theories then emerged, including the learning, humanistic, biological, evolutionary, trait, and cultural perspectives.']
['what did they explore?', 'In this chapter, we will explore these various perspectives on personality in depth.']
['Who is Sigmund Freud?', 'Sigmund Freud (1856–1939) is probably the most controversial and misunderstood psychological theorist.']
["What is the most important thing to know about Freud's theory?", 'When reading Freud’s theories, it is important to remember that he was a medical doctor, not a psychologist.']

['How did he get into this field?', 'There was no such thing as a degree in psychology at the time that he received his education, which can help us understand some of the controversy over his theories today.']

['What is the history of his theory?', 'However, Freud was the first to systematically study and theorize the workings of the unconscious mind in the manner that we associate with modern psychology.']
['Who is Josef Breuer?', 'In the early years of his career, Freud worked with Josef Breuer, a Viennese physician.']
['Why is this important?', 'During this time, Freud became intrigued by the story of one of Breuer’s patients, Bertha Pappenheim, who was referred to by the pseudonym Anna O. (Launer, 2005).']

['What was the story about?', 'Anna O. had been caring for her dying father when she began to experience symptoms such as partial paralysis, headaches, blurred vision, amnesia, and hallucinations (Launer, 2005).']
['What were the symptoms called?', 'In Freud’s day, these symptoms were commonly referred to as hysteria.']
['Why did she visit Breuer?', 'Anna O. turned to Breuer for help.']
['How did Breuer treat her?', 'He spent 2 years (1880–1882) treating Anna O. and discovered that allowing her to talk about her experiences seemed to bring some relief of her symptoms.']
['How was the talk therapy received?', 'Anna O. called his treatment the “talking cure” (Launer, 2005).']
['What else did he do with Freud?', 'Despite the fact that Freud never met Anna O., her story served as the basis for the 1895 book, Studies on Hysteria, which he co-authored with Breuer.']

['What did Freud think of Anna O.?', 'Based on Breuer’s description of Anna O.’s treatment, Freud concluded that hysteria was the result of sexual abuse in childhood and that these traumatic experiences had been hidden from consciousness.']
['What was the disagreement?', 'Breuer disagreed with Freud, which soon ended their work together.']
['What did Freud do after the disagreement?', 'However, Freud continued to work to refine talk therapy and build his theory on personality.']
['Did you know what Freud thought?', 'To explain the concept of conscious versus unconscious experience, Freud compared the mind to an iceberg (Figure 11.5).']
["How did Freud's theory differ from other scientists?", 'He said that only about one-tenth of our mind is conscious, and the rest of our mind is unconscious.']
['What is the unconscious mind?', 'Our unconscious refers to that mental activity of which we are unaware and are unable to access (Freud, 1923).']
['What is the repression?', 'According to Freud, unacceptable urges and desires are kept in our unconscious through a process called repression.']
['What kind of repression?', 'For example, we sometimes say things that we don’t intend to say by unintentionally substituting another word for the one we meant.']
['Why would you do that?', 'You’ve probably heard of a Freudian slip, the term used to describe this.']
['What does the slip mean?', 'Freud suggested that slips of the tongue are actually sexual or aggressive urges, accidentally slipping out of our unconscious.']
["What do you think of Freud's theory?", 'Speech errors such as this are quite common.']

['Do people make them?', 'Seeing them as a reflection of unconscious desires, linguists today have found that slips of the tongue tend to occur when we are tired, nervous, or not at our optimal level of cognitive functioning (Motley, 2002).']

['What is one of the most important concepts in this chapter?', 'According to Freud, our personality develops from a conflict between two forces: our biological aggressive and pleasure-seeking drives versus our internal (socialized) control over these drives.']
['What is the result of our internal control over these forces?', 'Our personality is the result of our efforts to balance these two competing forces.']
['How do we understand these forces?', 'Freud suggested that we can understand this by imagining three interacting systems within our minds.']
['What are the three systems?', 'He called them the id, ego, and superego (Figure 11.6).']
['What is the unconscious id?', 'The unconscious id contains our most primitive drives or urges, and is present from birth.']
['What does it do?', 'It directs impulses for hunger, thirst, and sex.']
['Does it act in the best interests of people?', 'Freud believed that the id operates on what he called the “pleasure principle,” in which the id seeks immediate gratification.']
['What does it do to control impulses?', 'Through social interactions with parents and others in a child’s environment, the ego and superego develop to help control the id.']
['What is superego?', 'The superego develops as a child interacts with others, learning the social rules for right and wrong.']
['What else does the superego do?', 'The superego acts as our conscience; it is our moral compass that tells us how we should behave.']
['How does it tell us how to behave?', 'It strives for perfection and judges our behavior, leading to feelings of pride or—when we fall short of the ideal—feelings of guilt.']
['What is the ego?', 'In contrast to the instinctual id and the rule-based superego, the ego is the rational part of our personality.']
['How does it function?', 'Its job is to balance the demands of the id and superego in the context of reality; thus, it operates on what Freud called the “reality principle.”']
['What is reality?', 'The ego helps the id satisfy its desires in a realistic way.']

['What is one of the topics in this section?', 'The id and superego are in constant conflict, because the id wants instant gratification regardless of the consequences, but the superego tells us that we must behave in socially acceptable ways.']
['What happens when they are in conflict?', 'Thus, the ego’s job is to find the middle ground.']
['How is the ego helpful?', 'It helps satisfy the id’s desires in a rational way that will not lead us to feelings of guilt.']
['How is the ego healthy?', 'According to Freud, a person who has a strong ego, which can balance the demands of the id and the superego, has a healthy personality.']

['What are some ways that it imbalances?', 'Freud maintained that imbalances in the system can lead to neurosis (a tendency to experience negative emotions), anxiety disorders, or unhealthy behaviors.']
['Are there other ways the ego gets imbalanced?', 'For example, a person who is dominated by their id might be narcissistic and impulsive.']

['What does the superego influence?', 'A person with a dominant superego might be controlled by feelings of guilt and deny themselves even socially acceptable pleasures; conversely, if the superego is weak or absent, a person might become a psychopath.']

["Are there any other ways the superego can influence one's character?", 'An overly dominant superego might be seen in an over-controlled individual whose rational grasp on reality is so strong that they are unaware of their emotional needs, or, in a neurotic who is overly defensive (overusing ego defense mechanisms).']
['What are defense mechanisms?', 'Freud believed that feelings of anxiety result from the ego’s inability to mediate the conflict between the id and superego.']
['What happens when the ego fails?', 'When this happens, Freud believed that the ego seeks to restore balance through various protective measures known as defense mechanisms (Figure 11.7).']
['What can defense mechanisms do?', 'When certain events, feelings, or yearnings cause an individual anxiety, the individual wishes to reduce that anxiety.']
['What are defense mechanisms?', 'To do that, the individual’s unconscious mind uses ego defense mechanisms, unconscious protective behaviors that aim to reduce anxiety.']
['What is an example of defense mechanisms?', 'The ego, usually conscious, resorts to unconscious strivings to protect the ego from being overwhelmed by anxiety.']
['What can defense mechanisms do?', 'When we use defense mechanisms, we are unaware that we are using them.']
['What can defense mechanisms do?', 'Further, they operate in various ways that distort reality.']
['Who uses defense mechanisms?', 'According to Freud, we all use ego defense mechanisms.']
['what is defense mechanisms?', 'While everyone uses defense mechanisms, Freud believed that overuse of them may be problematic.']
['how do you use them to help?', 'For example, let’s say Joe is a high school football player.']
['why is he interested in football?', 'Deep down, Joe feels sexually attracted to males.']
['why does he keep this hidden?', 'His conscious belief is that being gay is immoral and that if he were gay, his family would disown him and he would be ostracized by his peers.']
['why does he feel gay?', 'Therefore, there   is a conflict between his conscious beliefs (being gay is wrong and will result in being ostracized) and his unconscious urges (attraction to males).']
['do these feelings bother him?', 'The idea that he might be gay causes Joe to have feelings of anxiety.']
['what did he do to avoid his feelings?', 'Joe may find himself acting very “macho,” making gay jokes, and picking on a school peer who is gay.']
['why does he pick on gay peer?', 'This way, Joe’s unconscious impulses are further submerged.']
['What are the types of defense mechanisms?', 'There are several different types of defense mechanisms.']
['What is the difference between them?', 'For instance, in repression, anxiety-causing memories from consciousness are blocked.']

['Why would you block anxiety-causing memories?', 'As an analogy, let’s say your car is making a strange noise, but because you do not have the money to get it fixed, you just turn up the radio so that you no longer hear the strange noise.']
['How do you cope with that?', 'Eventually you forget about it.']
['Why are we similar to the analogy?', 'Similarly, in the human psyche, if a memory is too overwhelming to deal with, it might be repressed and thus removed from conscious awareness (Freud, 1920).']
['What can happen if you fail to remove the memory from consciousness?', 'This repressed memory might cause symptoms in other areas.']
['what are defense mechanisms?', 'Another defense mechanism is reaction formation, in which someone expresses feelings, thoughts, and behaviors opposite to their inclinations.']
['what are some examples of reaction formation?', 'In the above example, Joe made fun of a gay peer while himself being attracted to males.']
['what are some examples of regression?', 'In regression, an individual acts much younger than their age.']
['how old is it that they act like a baby?', 'For example, a four-year-old child who resents the arrival of a newborn sibling may act like a baby and revert to drinking out of a bottle.']
['what is projection?', 'In projection, a person refuses to acknowledge her own unconscious feelings and instead sees those feelings in someone else.']
['what are some other defense mechanisms?', 'Other defense mechanisms include rationalization, displacement, and sublimation.']

['What is the relation between psychology and childhood?', 'Freud believed that personality develops during early childhood: Childhood experiences shape our personalities as well as our behavior as adults.']
['How does Freud describe the development?', 'He asserted that we develop via a series of stages during childhood.']

['What does he say about the stages?', 'Each of us must pass through these childhood stages, and if we do not have the proper nurturing and parenting during a stage, we will be stuck, or fixated, in that stage, even as adults.']

['What is the Stages of Psychosexual Development about?', 'In each psychosexual stage of development, the child’s pleasure-seeking urges, coming from the id, are focused on a different area of the body, called an erogenous zone.']
['What are the stages?', 'The stages are oral, anal, phallic, latency, and genital (Table 11.1).']
['What is controversial about this?', 'Freud’s psychosexual development theory is quite controversial.']

['What is important about his theory?', 'To understand the origins of the theory, it is helpful to be familiar with the political, social, and cultural influences of Freud’s day in Vienna at the turn of the 20th century.']

['Why did this influence his theory?', 'During this era, a climate of sexual repression, combined with limited understanding and education surrounding human sexuality, heavily influenced Freud’s perspective.']
['What were his conclusions?', 'Given that sex was a taboo topic, Freud assumed that negative emotional states (neuroses) stemmed from suppression of unconscious sexual and aggressive urges.']

['What else is significant about his theory?', 'For Freud, his own recollections and interpretations of patients’ experiences and dreams were sufficient proof that psychosexual stages were universal events in early childhood.']
['What is the oral stage?', 'In the oral stage (birth to 1 year), pleasure is focused on the mouth.']
['What happens in the mouth?', 'Eating and the pleasure derived from sucking (nipples, pacifiers, and thumbs) play a large part in a baby’s first year of life.']
['What else do we know about the oral stage?', 'At around 1 year of age, babies are weaned from the bottle or breast, and this process can create conflict if not handled properly by caregivers.']

['How can the oral stage be affected in older children?', 'According to Freud, an adult who smokes, drinks, overeats, or bites her nails is fixated in the oral stage of her psychosexual development; she may have been weaned too early or too late, resulting in these fixation tendencies, all of which seek to ease anxiety.']
["What's the anal stage?", 'After passing through the oral stage, children enter what Freud termed the anal stage (1–3 years).']

['What else can you tell me about the anal stage?', 'In this stage, children experience pleasure in their bowel and bladder movements, so it makes sense that the conflict in this stage is over toilet training.']
['What else can you tell me about this stage?', 'During this stage of development, children work to master control of themselves.']
['How do parents handle toilet training?', 'Freud suggested that success at the anal stage depended on how parents handled toilet training.']
['What else did he suggest?', 'Parents who offer praise and rewards encourage positive results and can help children feel competent.']

['How else can they help?', 'Parents who are harsh in toilet training can cause a child to become so fearful of soiling that they over-control and become fixated at the anal stage, leading to the development of an anal-retentive personality.']
['What does anal-retentive personality mean?', 'The anal-retentive personality is stingy and stubborn, has a compulsive need for order and neatness, and might be considered a perfectionist.']

['What else can you tell me about the toilet stage?', 'If parents are too lenient in toilet training, the child may fail to develop sufficient self-control, become fixated at this stage, and develop an anal-expulsive personality.']
['What does that personality do?', 'The anal-expulsive personality is messy, careless, disorganized, and prone to emotional outbursts.']

['How is Phallic Stage related to the Pythagorean theorem', 'Freud’s third stage of psychosexual development is the phallic stage (3–6 years), corresponding to the age when children become aware of their bodies and recognize the differences between boys and girls.']
['What area of the body is the erogenous zone?', 'The erogenous zone in this stage is the genitals.']
['What is conflict?', 'Conflict arises when the child feels a desire for the opposite-sex parent, and jealousy and hatred toward the same-sex parent.']

['What does a boy want from his mother?', "For boys, this is called the Oedipus complex, involving a boy's desire for his mother and his urge to replace his father who is seen as a rival for the mother’s attention."]
['What else is important about the Oedipus complex?', 'At the same time, the boy is afraid his father will punish him for his feelings, so he experiences castration anxiety.']
['When does the conflict end?', 'The Oedipus complex is successfully resolved when the boy begins to identify with his father as an indirect way to have the mother.']
['Why is this important?', 'Failure to resolve the Oedipus complex may result in fixation and development of a personality that might be described as vain and overly ambitious.']
['What did we learn about this stage?', 'Girls experience a comparable conflict in the phallic stage—the Electra complex.']
['Who proposed this concept?', 'The Electra complex, while often attributed to Freud, was actually proposed by Freud’s protégé, Carl Jung (Jung & Kerenyi, 1963).']
['What did we learn about the Electra complex?', 'A girl desires the attention of her father and wishes to take her mother’s place.']
['What else did we learn about the Electra complex?', 'Jung also said that girls are angry with the mother for not providing them with a penis—which he termed penis envy.']

['What was his approach to the Electra complex?', 'While Freud initially embraced the Electra complex as a parallel to the Oedipus complex, he later rejected it, yet it remains as a cornerstone of Freudian theory, thanks in part to academics in the field (Freud, 1931/1968; Scott, 2005).']
['What are the main points of the Latency Period?', 'Following the phallic stage of psychosexual development is a period known as the latency period (6 years to puberty).']
['What is the latency period?', 'This period is not considered a stage, because sexual feelings are dormant as children focus on other pursuits, such as school, friendships, hobbies, and sports.']
['What other areas of development does this period focus on?', 'Children generally engage in activities with peers of the same sex, which serves to consolidate a child’s gender-role identity.']
['What was the final stage of adolescence?', 'The final stage is the genital stage (from puberty on).']
['What is the genital stage?', 'In this stage, there is a sexual reawakening as the incestuous urges resurface.']
['What is the re-awakening?', 'The young person redirects these urges to other, more socially acceptable partners (who often resemble the other-sex parent).']
['What is the mature sexual interests?', 'People in this stage have mature sexual interests, which for Freud meant a strong desire for the opposite sex.']
['What was the conclusion?', 'Individuals who successfully completed the previous stages, reaching the genital stage with no fixations, are said to be well-balanced, healthy adults.']

['What is Freud?', 'While most of Freud’s ideas have not found support in modern research, and several contemporary researchers rejected his premises, we cannot discount the contributions that Freud has made to the field of psychology.']

['What does the article say?', 'It was Freud who pointed out that a large part of our mental life is influenced by the experiences of early childhood and takes place outside of our conscious awareness; his theories paved the way for others.']

["How did Freud's views influence his work on genital development?", "While Freud's focus on biological drives led him to emphasize the impact of sociocultural factors on personality development, his followers quickly realized that biology alone could not account for the diversity they encountered as the practice of psychoanalysis spread during the time of the Nazi Holocaust."]

['How did the Holocaust affect his views?', 'The antisemitism which was prevalent during this period of time may have led mainstream psychoanalysts to focus primarily on the universality of the psychological structures of the mind.']
['What is the most important fact about this topic?', 'Freud attracted many followers who modified his ideas to create new theories about personality.']

['What were these theories?', 'These theorists, referred to as neo-Freudians, generally agreed with Freud that childhood experiences matter, but deemphasized sex, focusing more on the social environment and effects of culture on personality.']
['Who were the neo-freudians?', 'Four notable neo-Freudians include Alfred Adler, Erik Erikson, Carl Jung (pronounced “Yoong”), and Karen Horney (pronounced “HORN-eye”).']

['What is interesting about Alfred Adler?', 'Alfred Adler, a colleague of Freud’s and the first president of the Vienna Psychoanalytical Society (Freud’s inner circle of colleagues), was the first major theorist to break away from Freud (Figure 11.8).']
['What is the main idea of Alfred Adler?', 'He subsequently founded a school of psychology called individual psychology, which focuses on our drive to compensate for feelings of inferiority.']
['What is his most important research?', 'Adler (1937, 1956) proposed the concept of the inferiority complex.']
['What is inferiority complex?', 'An inferiority complex refers to a person’s feelings that they lack worth and don’t measure up to the standards of others or of society.']
['Why is the inferiority complex important?', 'Adler’s ideas about inferiority represent a major difference between his thinking and Freud’s.']

['What is the difference between their ideas?', 'Freud believed that we are motivated by sexual and aggressive urges, but Adler (1930, 1961) believed that feelings of inferiority in childhood are what drive people to attempt to gain superiority and that this striving is the force behind all of our thoughts, emotions, and behaviors.']

['what was he most known for?', 'Adler also believed in the importance of social connections, seeing childhood development emerging through social development rather than the sexual stages Freud outlined.']
['what else was he known for?', 'Adler noted the inter-relatedness of humanity and the need to work together for the betterment of all.']

['what was his message?', 'He said, “The happiness of mankind lies in working together, in living as if each individual had set himself the task of contributing to the common welfare” (Adler, 1964, p. 255) with the main goal of psychology being “to recognize the equal rights and equality of others” (Adler, 1961, p. 691).']

['what are some of the things he wrote?', 'With these ideas, Adler identified three fundamental social tasks that all of us must experience: occupational tasks (careers), societal tasks (friendship), and love tasks (finding an intimate partner for a long-term relationship).']
['what else is significant about his work?', 'Rather than focus on sexual or aggressive motives for behavior as Freud did, Adler focused on social motives.']
['what else is important?', 'He also emphasized conscious rather than unconscious motivation, since he believed that the three fundamental social tasks are explicitly known and pursued.']
['what is meant by conscious rather than unconscious?', 'That is not to say that Adler did not also believe in unconscious processes—he did—but he felt that conscious processes were more important.']
['What is significant about the study of Alfred Adler?', 'One of Adler’s major contributions to personality psychology was the idea that our birth order shapes our personality.']

['What did Adler find out about birth order?', 'He proposed that older siblings, who start out as the focus of their parents’ attention but must share that attention once a new child joins the family, compensate by becoming overachievers.']

['What else did Adler have to say about birth order?', 'The youngest children, according to Adler, may be spoiled, leaving the middle child with the opportunity to minimize the negative dynamics of the youngest and oldest children.']
["Did Adler's theories gain a lot of attention?", 'Despite popular attention, research has not conclusively confirmed Adler’s hypotheses about birth order.']

['What happened in Vienna?', 'As an art school dropout with an uncertain future, young Erik Erikson met Freud’s daughter, Anna Freud, while he was tutoring the children of an American couple undergoing psychoanalysis in Vienna.']
['Did he meet Anna Freud and where did this relationship go?', 'It was Anna Freud who encouraged Erikson to study psychoanalysis.']

['When did he leave Vienna?', 'Erikson received his diploma from the Vienna Psychoanalytic Institute in 1933, and as Nazism spread across Europe, he fled the country and immigrated to the United States that same year.']

['What are his main theories?', 'As you learned when you studied lifespan development, Erikson later proposed a psychosocial theory of development, suggesting that an individual’s personality develops throughout the lifespan—a departure from Freud’s view that personality is fixed in early life.']

["What else did he have to say about Freud's theories?", 'In his theory, Erikson emphasized the social relationships that are important at each stage of personality development, in contrast to Freud’s emphasis on sex.']
['What other theories did Erikson have?', 'Erikson identified eight stages, each of which represents a conflict or developmental task (Table 11.2).']
['What else did Erikson have to say about his theories?', 'The development of a healthy personality and a sense of competence depend on the successful completion of each task.']
['Who was Carl Jung?', 'Carl Jung (Figure 11.9) was a Swiss psychiatrist and protégé of Freud, who later split off from Freud and developed his own theory, which he called analytical psychology.']

['What is the theory of analytical psychology about?', 'The focus of analytical psychology is on working to balance opposing forces of conscious and unconscious thought, and experience within one’s personality.']

['How is this done?', 'According to Jung, this work is a continuous learning process—mainly occurring in the second half of life—of becoming aware of unconscious elements and integrating them into consciousness.']
['Why did he split from Freud?', 'Jung’s split from Freud was based on two major disagreements.']
['Why was he so against psychoanalysis?', 'First, Jung, like Adler and Erikson, did not accept that sexual drive was the primary motivator in a person’s mental life.']
['What else did he disagree about with Freud?', 'Second, although Jung agreed with Freud’s concept of a personal unconscious, he thought it to be incomplete.']
['What did he think of the personal unconscious?', 'In addition to the personal unconscious, Jung focused on the collective unconscious.']

['What is the collective unconscious?', 'The collective unconscious is a universal version of the personal unconscious, holding mental patterns, or memory traces, which are common to all of us (Jung, 1928).']

['What do these archetypes mean?', 'These ancestral memories, which Jung called archetypes, are represented by universal themes in various cultures, as expressed through literature, art, and dreams (Jung).']
['What are the universal themes?', 'Jung said that these themes reflect common experiences of people the world over, such as facing death, becoming independent, and striving for mastery.']

['How can the archetypes be identified?', 'Jung (1964) believed that through biology, each person is handed down the same themes and that the same types of symbols—such as the hero, the maiden, the sage, and the trickster—are present in the folklore and fairy tales of every culture.']

['What can you do with the archetypes?', 'In Jung’s view, the task of integrating these unconscious archetypal aspects of the self is part of the self-realization process in the second half of life.']

['How is self-realization accomplished?', 'With this orientation toward self-realization, Jung parted ways with Freud’s belief that personality is determined solely by past events and anticipated the humanistic movement with its emphasis on self-actualization and orientation toward the future.']
['What is Carl Jung?', 'Jung also proposed two attitudes or approaches toward life: extroversion and introversion (Jung, 1923) (Table 11.3).']
['Are these important?', 'These ideas are considered Jung’s most important contributions to the field of personality psychology, as almost all models of personality now include these concepts.']
['What are these?', 'If you are an extrovert, then you are a person who is energized by being outgoing and socially oriented:']
['What else do they do?', 'You derive your energy from being around others.']

['Do they get on well with others?', 'If you are an introvert, then you are a person who may be quiet and reserved, or you may be social, but your energy is derived from your inner psychic activity.']
['What else is significant about the two attitudes?', 'Jung believed a balance between extroversion and introversion best served the goal of self-realization.']
["What is one of Carl Jung's concepts?", 'Another concept proposed by Jung was the persona, which he referred to as a mask that we adopt.']
['How does Jung say that we create this persona?', 'According to Jung, we consciously create this persona; however, it is derived from both our conscious experiences and our collective unconscious.']
['What do we need to be in order to create this persona?', 'Jung believed that it is a compromise between who we really are (our true self) and what society expects us to be.']
['How do we hide our true self from the world?', 'We hide those parts of ourselves that are not aligned with society’s expectations.']
['what was she known for?', 'Karen Horney was one of the first women trained as a Freudian psychoanalyst.']
['what else did you find interesting?', 'During the Great Depression, Horney moved from Germany to the United States, and subsequently moved away from Freud’s teachings.']

['What did she try to do instead?', 'Like Jung, Horney believed that each individual has the potential for self-realization and that the goal of psychoanalysis should be moving toward a healthy self rather than exploring early childhood patterns of dysfunction.']
['why was she more egalitarian?', 'Horney also disagreed with the Freudian idea that girls have penis envy and are jealous of male biological features.']

['why were girls jealous of male features?', 'According to Horney, any jealousy is most likely culturally based, due to the greater privileges that men often have, meaning that the differences between men’s and women’s personalities are culturally based, not biologically based.']
['What else did she have to say?', 'She further suggested that men have womb envy, because they cannot give birth.']
["What are some of Horney's theories?", 'Horney’s theories focused on the role of unconscious anxiety.']
['What are some examples?', 'She suggested that normal growth can be blocked by basic anxiety stemming from needs not being met, such as childhood experiences of loneliness and/or isolation.']
['How can a person overcome this anxiety?', 'Horney suggested three styles of coping (Table 11.4).']
['What else can you tell me about her theories?', 'The first coping style, moving toward people, relies on affiliation and dependence.']

['How does it help the person?', 'These children become dependent on their parents and other caregivers in an effort to receive attention and affection, which provides relief from anxiety (Burger, 2008).']
['How does this work?', 'When these children grow up, they tend to use this same coping strategy to deal with relationships, expressing an intense need for love and acceptance (Burger, 2008).']
['What are some examples of this style?', 'The second coping style, moving against people, relies on aggression and assertiveness.']

['What are some examples of this style?', 'Children with this coping style find that fighting is the best way to deal with an unhappy home situation, and they deal with their feelings of insecurity by bullying other children (Burger, 2008).']
['What is this style used for?', 'As adults, people with this coping style tend to lash out with hurtful comments and exploit others (Burger, 2008).']
['What other styles of coping are there?', 'The third coping style, moving away from people, centers on detachment and isolation.']
['How does it work?', 'These children handle their anxiety by withdrawing from the world.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'They need privacy and tend to be self-sufficient.']

['What are some things people do with this style?', 'When these children are adults, they continue to avoid such things as love and friendship, and they also tend to gravitate toward careers that require little interaction with others (Burger, 2008).']

['What are the learning approaches?', 'In contrast to the psychodynamic approaches of Freud and the neo-Freudians, which relate personality to inner (and hidden) processes, the learning approaches focus only on observable behavior.']
['What else do you find interesting about these approaches?', 'This illustrates one significant advantage of the learning approaches over psychodynamics:']
['Are there any more advantages to this approach?', 'Because learning approaches involve observable, measurable phenomena, they can be scientifically tested.']
['What is the Behavioral perspective?', 'Behaviorists do not believe in biological determinism:']
['They do not believe in genes and are less interested in inherited characteristics.', 'They do not see personality traits as inborn.']
['They do not see personality traits as inborn.', 'Instead, they view personality as significantly shaped by the reinforcements and consequences outside of the organism.']
['What is the key concept in the Behavioral perspective?', 'In other words, people behave in a consistent manner based on prior learning.']

['Who is B. F. Skinner?', 'B. F. Skinner, a strict behaviorist, believed that environment was solely responsible for all behavior, including the enduring, consistent behavior patterns studied by personality theorists.']

['What is the Behavioral Perspective?', 'As you may recall from your study on the psychology of learning, Skinner proposed that we demonstrate consistent behavior patterns because we have developed certain response tendencies (Skinner, 1953).']
['What does the psychology of learning have to do with The Behavioral Perspective?', 'In other words, we learn to behave in particular ways.']
['What does a consequence have to do with our behaviors?', 'We increase the behaviors that lead to positive consequences, and we decrease the behaviors that lead to negative consequences.']
['Who was Skinner?', 'Skinner disagreed with Freud’s idea that personality is fixed in childhood.']
['Who disagreed with Freud?', 'He argued that personality develops over our entire life, not only in the first few years.']

['What can personality change over time?', 'Our responses can change as we come across new situations; therefore, we can expect more variability over time in personality than Freud would anticipate.']
['What is an example of variability?', 'For example, consider a young woman, Greta, a risk taker.']
['How is Greta a risk taker?', 'She drives fast and participates in dangerous sports such as hang gliding and kiteboarding.']
['What does the variability mean?', 'But after she gets married and has children, the system of reinforcements and punishments in her environment changes.']
['How does she change her behaviors?', 'Speeding and extreme sports are no longer reinforced, so she no longer engages in those behaviors.']
['Is this a change in personality?', 'In fact, Greta now describes herself as a cautious person.']
["What was Bandura's stance on social-cognitive psychology?", 'Albert Bandura agreed with Skinner that personality develops through learning.']

['How did he disagree with Skinner?', 'He disagreed, however, with Skinner’s strict behaviorist approach to personality development, because he felt that thinking and reasoning are important components of learning.']
['What was his method?', 'He presented a social-cognitive theory of personality that emphasizes both learning and cognition as sources of individual differences in personality.']

['What were the main concepts of his theory?', 'In social-cognitive theory, the concepts of reciprocal determinism, observational learning, and self-efficacy all play a part in personality development.']

['What is reciprocal determinism?', 'In contrast to Skinner’s idea that the environment alone determines behavior, Bandura (1990) proposed the concept of reciprocal determinism, in which cognitive processes, behavior, and context all interact, each factor influencing and being influenced by the others simultaneously (Figure 11.10).']
['What are cognitive processes?', 'Cognitive processes refer to all characteristics previously learned, including beliefs, expectations, and personality characteristics.']
['What is behavior?', 'Behavior refers to anything that we do that may be rewarded or punished.']
['What is context?', 'Finally, the context in which the behavior occurs refers to the environment or situation, which includes rewarding/punishing stimuli.']
['What is this all about?', 'Consider, for example, that you’re at a festival and one of the attractions is bungee jumping from a bridge.']
["What is the behavior that you're describing?", 'In this example, the behavior is bungee jumping.']
['What is the result of this behavior?', 'Cognitive factors that might influence this behavior include your beliefs and values, and your past experiences with similar behaviors.']
['What does context mean?', 'Finally, context refers to the reward structure for the behavior.']
['What else do you find interesting?', 'According to reciprocal determinism, all of these factors are in play.']
["What was Bandura's biggest contribution?", 'Bandura’s key contribution to learning theory was the idea that much learning is vicarious.']
['What is observational learning?', 'We learn by observing someone else’s behavior and its consequences, which Bandura called observational learning.']
['What type of personality development does this theory discuss?', 'He felt that this type of learning also plays a part in the development of our personality.']
['Why is this theory important?', 'Just as we learn individual behaviors, we learn new behavior patterns when we see them performed by other people or models.']

['Who are the models?', 'Drawing on the behaviorists’ ideas about reinforcement, Bandura suggested that whether we choose to imitate a model’s behavior depends on whether we see the model reinforced or punished.']

['What is the theory about?', 'Through observational learning, we come to learn what behaviors are acceptable and rewarded in our culture, and we also learn to inhibit deviant or socially unacceptable behaviors by seeing what behaviors are punished.']
['What are the principles of reciprocal determinism at work in observational learning?', 'We can see the principles of reciprocal determinism at work in observational learning.']

['What are the principles of reciprocal determinism?', 'For example, personal factors determine which behaviors in the environment a person chooses to imitate, and those environmental events in turn are processed cognitively according to other personal factors.']

['How do they determine which behaviors?', 'One person may experience receiving attention as reinforcing, and that person may be more inclined to imitate behaviors such as boasting when a model has been reinforced.']
['Why does that person do that?', 'For others, boasting may be viewed negatively, despite the attention that might result—or receiving heightened attention may be perceived as being scrutinized.']
['How does the person respond to this?', 'In either case, the person may be less likely to imitate those behaviors even though the reasons for not doing so would be different.']

["What was Bandura's approach to this topic?", 'Bandura (1977, 1995) has studied a number of cognitive and personal factors that affect learning and personality development, and most recently has focused on the concept of self-efficacy.']
['What was self-efficacy?', 'Self-efficacy is our level of confidence in our own abilities, developed through our social experiences.']
