['How does self-efficacy affect us?', 'Self-efficacy affects how we approach challenges and reach goals.']

['What is it in relation to observational learning?', 'In observational learning, self-efficacy is a cognitive factor that affects which behaviors we choose to imitate as well as our success in performing those behaviors.']

['What is self-efficacy?', 'People who have high self-efficacy believe that their goals are within reach, have a positive view of challenges seeing them as tasks to be mastered, develop a deep interest in and strong commitment to the activities in which they are involved, and quickly recover from setbacks.']

['What kinds of things do they get into?', 'Conversely, people with low self-efficacy avoid challenging tasks because they doubt their ability to be successful, tend to focus on failure and negative outcomes, and lose confidence in their abilities if they experience setbacks.']
['What kinds of situations are you talking about?', 'Feelings of self-efficacy can be specific to certain situations.']
['How so?', 'For instance, a student might feel confident in her ability in English class but much less so in math class.']
['What is locus of control?', 'Julian Rotter (1966) proposed the concept of locus of control, another cognitive factor that affects learning and personality development.']
['What does this mean?', 'Distinct from self-efficacy, which involves our belief in our own abilities, locus of control refers to our beliefs about the power we have over our lives.']
['What are the different views on this?', 'In Rotter’s view, people possess either an internal or an external locus of control (Figure 11.11).']

['What happens to someone with an internal locus of control?', 'Those of us with an internal locus of control (“internals”) tend to believe that most of our outcomes are the direct result of our efforts.']
['What happens to someone with an external locus of control?', 'Those of us with an external locus of control (“externals”) tend to believe that our outcomes are outside of our control.']
['Why does this happen?', 'Externals see their lives as being controlled by other people, luck, or chance.']
['What does this have to do with your behavior?', 'For example, say you didn’t spend much time studying for your psychology test and went out to dinner with friends instead.']
['What happens to you after the test?', 'When you receive your test score, you see that you earned a D.']

['Why did you fail?', 'If you possess an internal locus of control, you would most likely admit that you failed because you didn’t spend enough time studying and decide to study more for the next test.']

['How will you deal with the failing grade?', 'On the other hand, if you possess an external locus of control, you might conclude that the test was too hard and not bother studying for the next test, because you figure you will fail it anyway.']

['How does having an internal locus of control affect your life?', 'Researchers have found that people with an internal locus of control perform better academically, achieve more in their careers, are more independent, are healthier, are better able to cope, and are less depressed than people who have an external locus of control (Benassi, Sweeney, & Durfour, 1988; Lefcourt, 1982; Maltby, Day, & Macaskill, 2007; Whyte, 1977, 1978, 1980).']
['What is a specific fact about the paper you are currently reading?', 'Walter Mischel was a student of Julian Rotter and taught for years at Stanford, where he was a colleague of Albert Bandura.']

['What else is interesting about this paper?', 'Mischel surveyed several decades of empirical psychological literature regarding trait prediction of behavior, and his conclusion shook the foundations of personality psychology.']
['What was his conclusion?', 'Mischel found that the data did not support the central principle of the field—that a person’s personality traits are consistent across situations.']
['Did he have an impact on psychology?', 'His report triggered a decades-long period of self-examination, known as the person-situation debate, among personality psychologists.']
['What does Walter Mischel suggest about the person-situation debate?', 'Mischel suggested that perhaps we were looking for consistency in the wrong places.']

['What are the wrong places?', 'He found that although behavior was inconsistent across different situations, it was much more consistent within situations—so that a person’s behavior in one situation would likely be repeated in a similar one.']
['What are the correct places?', 'And as you will see next regarding his famous “marshmallow test,” Mischel also found that behavior is consistent in equivalent situations across time.']
["What is one of Mischel's most notable contributions to personality psychology?", 'One of Mischel’s most notable contributions to personality psychology was his ideas on self-regulation.']

['What is self-regulation?', 'According to Lecci & Magnavita (2013), “Self-regulation is the process of identifying a goal or set of goals and, in pursuing these goals, using both internal (e.g., thoughts and affect) and external (e.g., responses of anything or anyone in the environment) feedback to maximize goal attainment” (p. 6.3).']
['What is will power?', 'Self-regulation is also known as will power.']
['What does will power refer to?', 'When we talk about will power, we tend to think of it as the ability to delay gratification.']
['What are some examples of this?', 'For example, Bettina’s teenage son made strawberry cupcakes, and they looked delicious.']
['How did Bettina feel about them?', 'However, Bettina forfeited the pleasure of eating one, because she is training for a 5K race and wants to be fit and do well in the race.']
['Why did Mischel conduct this experiment?', 'This is the question Mischel investigated in his now-classic marshmallow test.']
['What was he studying?', 'Mischel designed a study to assess self-regulation in young children.']
['what was the marshmallow study?', 'In the marshmallow study, Mischel and his colleagues placed a preschool child in a room with one marshmallow on the table.']

["What was the child's situation?", 'The children were told they could either eat the marshmallow now, or wait until the researcher returned to the room, and then they could have two marshmallows (Mischel, Ebbesen & Raskoff, 1972).']
['What happened next?', 'This was repeated with hundreds of preschoolers.']
['What did he find?', 'What Mischel and his team found was that young children differ in their degree of self-control.']
['What did he do after that?', 'The children who had more self-control in preschool (the ones who waited for the bigger reward) were more successful in high school.']

['What did they do after high school?', 'They had higher SAT scores, had positive peer relationships, and were less likely to have substance abuse issues; as adults, they also had more stable marriages (Mischel, Shoda, & Rodriguez, 1989; Mischel et al., 2010).']

['What did they fail at?', 'On the other hand, those children who had poor self-control in preschool (the ones who grabbed the one marshmallow) were not as successful in high school, and they were found to have academic and behavioral problems.']

['What else was found?', 'A more recent study using a larger and more representative sample found  associations between early delay of gratification (Watts, Duncan, & Quan, 2018) and measures of achievement in adolescence.']

['What was their findings?', "However, researchers also found that the associations were not as strong as those reported during Mischel's initial experiment and were quite sensitive to situational factors such as early measures of cognitive capacity, family background, and home environment."]
['What else did they find?', 'This research suggests that consideration of situational factors is important to better understand behavior.']
['What are some interesting things about this study?', 'Today, the debate is mostly resolved, and most psychologists consider both the situation and personal factors in understanding behavior.']
['What was his position on the debate?', 'For Mischel (1993), people are situation processors.']
['What did the marshmallow test prove to Mischel?', 'The children in the marshmallow test each processed, or interpreted, the rewards structure of that situation in their own way.']
['What did he say about the debate?', 'Mischel’s approach to personality stresses the importance of both the situation and the way the person perceives the situation.']

['What did he do after the marshmallow test?', 'Instead of behavior being determined by the situation, people use cognitive processes to interpret the situation and then behave in accordance with that interpretation.']

['What is a humanistic approach?', 'As the “third force” in psychology, humanism is touted as a reaction both to the pessimistic determinism of psychoanalysis, with its emphasis on psychological disturbance, and to the behaviorists’ view of humans passively reacting to the environment, which has been criticized as making people out to be personality-less robots.']

['What are the benefits of the humanistic approach?', 'It does not suggest that psychoanalytic, behaviorist, and other points of view are incorrect but argues that these perspectives do not recognize the depth and meaning of human experience, and fail to recognize the innate capacity for self-directed change and transforming personal experiences.']
['What can be told about the individual?', 'This perspective focuses on how healthy people develop.']

['What are the most important aspects of this approach?', 'One pioneering humanist, Abraham Maslow, studied people who he considered to be healthy, creative, and productive, including Albert Einstein, Eleanor Roosevelt, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln, and others.']

['What does he study?', 'Maslow (1950, 1970) found that such people share similar characteristics, such as being open, creative, loving, spontaneous, compassionate, concerned for others, and accepting of themselves.']

['What is the hierarchy of needs?', "When you studied motivation, you learned about one of the best-known humanistic theories, Maslow's hierarchy of needs theory, in which Maslow proposes that human beings have certain needs in common and that these needs must be met in a certain order."]
['What are the top three needs?', 'The highest need is the need for self-actualization, which is the achievement of our fullest potential.']
['What are the other needs?', 'Maslow differentiated between needs that motivate us to fulfill something that is missing and needs that inspire us to grow.']
['What happens after you have not met one of your needs?', 'He believed that many emotional and behavioral concerns arise as a result of failing to meet these hierarchical needs.']
["What's one important fact about this article?", 'Another humanistic theorist was Carl Rogers.']
['What else does he have to say?', 'One of Rogers’s main ideas about personality regards self-concept, our thoughts and feelings about ourselves.']
['Does he believe that our thoughts can change?', 'How would you respond to the question, “Who am I?” Your answer can show how you see yourself.']
['Does it show how you see the world?', 'If your response is primarily positive, then you tend to feel good about who you are, and you see the world as a safe and positive place.']
["What's one thing you learned from this article?", 'If your response is mainly negative, then you may feel unhappy with who you are.']
['Does he tell us anything else about self concept?', 'Rogers further divided the self into two categories: the ideal self and the real self.']
['What are the ideal self and the real self?', 'The ideal self is the person that you would like to be; the real self is the person you actually are.']
['Did he explain this to you?', 'Rogers focused on the idea that we need to achieve consistency between these two selves.']
['How does this help?', 'We experience congruence when our thoughts about our real self and ideal self are very similar—in other words, when our self-concept is accurate.']
['How is this important to us?', 'High congruence leads to a greater sense of self-worth and a healthy, productive life.']
['Why does that help?', 'Parents can help their children achieve this by giving them unconditional positive regard, or unconditional love.']
['What other ways can we help ourselves achieve this?', 'According to Rogers (1980), “As persons are accepted and prized, they tend to develop a more caring attitude towards themselves” (p. 116).']

['What other things did Rogers say about self concept?', 'Conversely, when there is a great discrepancy between our ideal and actual selves, we experience a state Rogers called incongruence, which can lead to maladjustment.']
['What are some of his other theories?', 'Both Rogers’s and Maslow’s theories focus on individual choices and do not believe that biology is deterministic.']

['What are some of the most important details of this title?', 'Psychologists who favor the biological approach believe that inherited predispositions as well as physiological processes can be used to explain differences in our personalities (Burger, 2008).']
['What is Evolutionary psychology?', 'Evolutionary psychology relative to personality development looks at personality traits that are universal, as well as differences across individuals.']
['What are the adaptive differences?', 'In this view, adaptive differences have evolved and then provide a survival and reproductive advantage.']
['What are the individual differences?', 'Individual differences are important from an evolutionary viewpoint for several reasons.']
['Is there any more information about the individual differences?', 'Certain individual differences, and the heritability of these characteristics, have been well documented.']

['What is there more information about the relationship between personality traits and evolution?', 'David Buss has identified several theories to explore this relationship between personality traits and evolution, such as life-history theory, which looks at how people expend their time and energy (such as on bodily growth and maintenance, reproduction, or parenting).']

['What other theories are there?', 'Another example is costly signaling theory, which examines the honesty and deception in the signals people send one another about their quality as a mate or friend (Buss, 2009).']

['What is the importance of twin studies?', 'In the field of behavioral genetics, the Minnesota Study of Twins Reared Apart—a well-known study of the genetic basis for personality—conducted research with twins from 1979 to 1999.']

['What was found?', 'In studying 350 pairs of twins, including pairs of identical and fraternal twins reared together and apart, researchers found that identical twins, whether raised together or apart, have very similar personalities (Bouchard, 1994; Bouchard, Lykken, McGue, Segal, & Tellegen, 1990; Segal, 2012).']
['What did this find?', 'These findings suggest the heritability of some personality traits.']
['What does that mean?', 'Heritability refers to the proportion of difference among people that is attributed to genetics.']

['What does that mean?', 'Some of the traits that the study reported as having more than a 0.50 heritability ratio include leadership, obedience to authority, a sense of well-being, alienation, resistance to stress, and fearfulness.']

['What was the conclusion?', 'The implication is that some aspects of our personalities are largely controlled by genetics; however, it’s important to point out that traits are not determined by a single gene, but by a combination of many genes, as well as by epigenetic factors that control whether the genes are expressed.']
['What is temperment?', 'Most contemporary psychologists believe temperament has a biological basis due to its appearance very early in our lives (Rothbart, 2011).']

['Who said this?', 'As you learned when you studied lifespan development, Thomas and Chess (1977) found that babies could be categorized into one of three temperaments: easy, difficult, or slow to warm up.']

['What else is the basis of temperament?', 'However, environmental factors (family interactions, for example) and maturation can affect the ways in which children’s personalities are expressed (Carter et al., 2008).']

['What is temperament?', 'Research suggests that there are two dimensions of our temperament that are important parts of our adult personality—reactivity and self-regulation (Rothbart, Ahadi, & Evans, 2000).']

['What does the definition of reactivity mean?', 'Reactivity refers to how we respond to new or challenging environmental stimuli; self-regulation refers to our ability to control that response (Rothbart & Derryberry, 1981; Rothbart, Sheese, Rueda, & Posner, 2011).']
['How does one get reactivity?', 'For example, one person may immediately respond to new stimuli with a high level of anxiety, while another barely notices it.']
['What are trait theorists?', 'Trait theorists believe personality can be understood via the approach that all people have certain traits, or characteristic ways of behaving.']
['Are there any different trait theorists?', 'Early trait theorists tried to describe all human personality traits.']
['Can you tell me something interesting?', 'For example, one trait theorist, Gordon Allport (Allport & Odbert, 1936), found 4,500 words in the English language that could describe people.']
['What did he do with these words?', 'He organized these personality traits into three categories: cardinal traits, central traits, and secondary traits.']
['What do cardinal traits mean?', 'A cardinal trait is one that dominates your entire personality, and hence your life—such as Ebenezer Scrooge’s greed and Mother Theresa’s altruism.']
['Are there many of them?', 'Cardinal traits are not very common:']
['What does this mean?', 'Few people have personalities dominated by a single trait.']
['Are there more?', 'Instead, our personalities typically are composed of multiple traits.']
['How does this work?', 'Central traits are those that make up our personalities (such as loyal, kind, agreeable, friendly, sneaky, wild, and grouchy).']
['Are there any other types of traits?', 'Secondary traits are those that are not quite as obvious or as consistent as central traits.']
['What are some examples of these traits?', 'They are present under specific circumstances and include preferences and attitudes.']

['What kinds of preferences do they have?', 'For example, one person gets angry when people try to tickle him; another can only sleep on the left side of the bed; and yet another always orders her salad dressing on the side.']
['What about attitudes?', 'And you—although not normally an anxious person—feel nervous before making a speech in front of your English class.']
['What type of traits are studied in psychology?', 'In an effort to make the list of traits more manageable, Raymond Cattell (1946, 1957) narrowed down the list to about 171 traits.']

['Are there any other characteristics that are studied?', 'However, saying that a trait is either present or absent does not accurately reflect a person’s uniqueness, because all of our personalities are actually made up of the same traits; we differ only in the degree to which each trait is expressed.']

['How many traits are studied?', 'Cattell (1957) identified 16 factors or dimensions of personality: warmth, reasoning, emotional stability, dominance, liveliness, rule-consciousness, social boldness, sensitivity, vigilance, abstractedness, privateness, apprehension, openness to change, self-reliance, perfectionism, and tension (Table 11.5).']
['What else can you tell me about the traits?', 'He developed a personality assessment based on these 16 factors, called the 16PF.']
['How do you use this?', 'Instead of a trait being present or absent, each dimension is scored over a continuum, from high to low.']
['Does it tell you how warm you are?', 'For example, your level of warmth describes how warm, caring, and nice to others you are.']
['Do you have to be warm?', 'If you score low on this index, you tend to be more distant and cold.']
['Do you have to be supportive?', 'A high score on this index signifies you are supportive and comforting.']

['Who were trait theorists?', 'Psychologists Hans and Sybil Eysenck were personality theorists (Figure 11.12) who focused on temperament, the inborn, genetically based personality differences that you studied earlier in the chapter.']
['What did they believe about personality?', 'They believed personality is largely governed by biology.']

['What was the theory about?', 'The Eysencks (Eysenck, 1990, 1992; Eysenck & Eysenck, 1963) viewed people as having two specific personality dimensions: extroversion/introversion and neuroticism/stability.']

['What is extroversion?', 'According to their theory, people high on the trait of extroversion are sociable and outgoing, and readily connect with others, whereas people high on the trait of introversion have a higher need to be alone, engage in solitary behaviors, and limit their interactions with others.']

['What is neuroticism?', 'In the neuroticism/stability dimension, people high on neuroticism tend to be anxious; they tend to have an overactive sympathetic nervous system and, even with low stress, their bodies and emotional state tend to go into a flight-or-fight reaction.']
['What is stability?', 'In contrast, people high on stability tend to need more stimulation to activate their flight-or-fight reaction and are considered more emotionally stable.']
['How do these two dimensions apply to people?', 'Based on these two dimensions, the Eysencks’ theory divides people into four quadrants.']

['What is an example of one of these quadrants?', 'These quadrants are sometimes compared with the four temperaments described by the Greeks: melancholic, choleric, phlegmatic, and sanguine (Figure 11.13).']
['What is the third dimension of personality?', 'Later, the Eysencks added a third dimension: psychoticism versus superego control (Eysenck, Eysenck & Barrett, 1985).']

['What are the different types of psychotic individuals?', 'In this dimension, people who are high on psychoticism tend to be independent thinkers, cold, nonconformists, impulsive, antisocial, and hostile, whereas people who are high on superego control tend to have high impulse control—they are more altruistic, empathetic, cooperative, and conventional (Eysenck, Eysenck & Barrett, 1985).']
["What was the controversy about Cattell's 16-factor system?", 'While Cattell’s 16 factors may be too broad, the Eysenck’s two-factor system has been criticized for being too narrow.']

['Why does the 16-factor system have to be so wide?', 'Another personality theory, called the Five Factor Model, effectively hits a middle ground, with its five factors referred to as the Big Five personality factors.']
['What is the Five Factor Model?', 'It is the most popular theory in personality psychology today and the most accurate approximation of the basic personality dimensions (Funder, 2001).']
['What are the five factors?', 'The five factors are openness to experience, conscientiousness, extroversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism (Figure 11.14).']
['How do you remember the five factors?', 'A helpful way to remember the factors is by using the mnemonic OCEAN.']
['What is the Five Factor Model?', 'In the Five Factor Model, each person has each factor, but they occur along a spectrum.']
['What kind of experience do open people have?', 'Openness to experience is characterized by imagination, feelings, actions, and ideas.']
['What type of people are curious?', 'People who score high on this factor tend to be curious and have a wide range of interests.']
['What kind of people are conscientious?', 'Conscientiousness is characterized by competence, self-discipline, thoughtfulness, and achievement-striving (goal-directed behavior).']
['What kind of people are responsible?', 'People who score high on this factor are hardworking and dependable.']

['What kind of success do conscientious people have?', 'Numerous studies have found a positive correlation between conscientiousness and academic success (Akomolafe, 2013; Chamorro-Premuzic & Furnham, 2008; Conrad & Patry, 2012; Noftle & Robins, 2007; Wagerman & Funder, 2007).']
['What kind of people are extroverted?', 'Extroversion is characterized by sociability, assertiveness, excitement-seeking, and emotional expression.']
['What kind of people are sociable?', 'People who score high on this factor are usually described as outgoing and warm.']

['Are there any interesting facts that are related to the information in this article?', 'Not surprisingly, people who score high on both extroversion and openness are more likely to participate in adventure and risky sports due to their curious and excitement-seeking nature (Tok, 2011).']
['What is the fourth factor?', 'The fourth factor is agreeableness, which is the tendency to be pleasant, cooperative, trustworthy, and good-natured.']

['Does agreeableness contribute to any careers?', 'People who score low on agreeableness tend to be described as rude and uncooperative, yet one recent study reported that men who scored low on this factor actually earned more money than men who were considered more agreeable (Judge, Livingston, & Hurst, 2012).']
['What is the fifth factor?', 'The last of the Big Five factors is neuroticism, which is the tendency to experience negative emotions.']
['What kind of people are described with negative emotions?', 'People high on neuroticism tend to experience emotional instability and are characterized as angry, impulsive, and hostile.']
['What else is unique about the fifth factor?', 'Watson and Clark (1984) found that people reporting high levels of neuroticism also tend to report feeling anxious and unhappy.']
['Are there any other interesting facts?', 'In contrast, people who score low in neuroticism tend to be calm and even-tempered.']
['What are the big five personality traits?', 'The Big Five personality factors each represent a range between two extremes.']
['How are people categorized?', 'In reality, most of us tend to lie somewhere midway along the continuum of each factor, rather than at polar ends.']

['Does this matter for people as they age?', 'It’s important to note that the Big Five factors are relatively stable over our lifespan, with some tendency for the factors to increase or decrease slightly.']

['Are there any specific examples of this?', 'Researchers have found that conscientiousness increases through young adulthood into middle age, as we become better able to manage our personal relationships and careers (Donnellan & Lucas, 2008).']
['Does agreeableness increase with age?', 'Agreeableness also increases with age, peaking between 50 to 70 years (Terracciano, McCrae, Brant, & Costa, 2005).']
['Do any of these traits decrease with age?', 'Neuroticism and extroversion tend to decline slightly with age (Donnellan & Lucas; Terracciano et al.).']

['What other research has been done on these traits?', 'Additionally, The Big Five factors have been shown to exist across ethnicities, cultures, and ages, and may have substantial biological and genetic components (Jang, Livesley, & Vernon, 1996; Jang et al., 2006; McCrae & Costa, 1997; Schmitt et al., 2007).']
['what other model is there?', 'Another model of personality traits is the HEXACO model.']

['what is the hexaco model?', 'HEXACO is an acronym for six broad traits: honesty-humility, emotionality, extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, and openness to experience (Anglim & O’Connor, 2018).']
['what is this about?', 'Table 11.6 provides a brief overview of each trait.']
['What was the information you studied about in this chapter?', 'As you have learned in this chapter, personality is shaped by both genetic and environmental factors.']
['What factors shape your personality?', 'The culture in which you live is one of the most important environmental factors that shapes your personality (Triandis & Suh, 2002).']
['What does culture mean?', 'The term culture refers to all of the beliefs, customs, art, and traditions of a particular society.']

['How does culture impact your personality?', 'Culture is transmitted to people through language as well as through the modeling of culturally acceptable and nonacceptable behaviors that are either rewarded or punished (Triandis & Suh, 2002).']
['What are some more facts about culture?', 'With these ideas in mind, personality psychologists have become interested in the role of culture in understanding personality.']
['What else do personality psychologists research?', 'They ask whether personality traits are the same across cultures or if there are variations.']
['Are personality traits the same across cultures?', 'It appears that there are both universal and culture-specific aspects that account for variation in people’s personalities.']
['What is the main idea of the paper?', 'Western ideas about personality may not be applicable to other cultures (Benet-Martinez & Oishi, 2008).']
['How do we know this?', 'In fact, there is evidence that the strength of personality traits varies across cultures.']
['What are some examples of cultural differences?', 'Let’s take a look at some of the Big Five factors (conscientiousness, neuroticism, openness, and extroversion) across cultures.']

['What kind of difference are you talking about?', 'As you will learn when you study social psychology, Asian cultures are more collectivist, and people in these cultures tend to be less extroverted.']

['What are some other examples?', 'People in Central and South American cultures tend to score higher on openness to experience, whereas Europeans score higher on neuroticism (Benet-Martinez & Karakitapoglu-Aygun, 2003).']
['What is significant about this study?', 'According to a study by Rentfrow and colleagues, there also seem to be regional personality differences within the United States (Figure 11.15).']

['What are the differences?', 'Researchers analyzed responses from over 1.5 million individuals in the United States and found that there are three distinct regional personality clusters: Cluster 1, which is in the Upper Midwest and Deep South, is dominated by people who fall into the “friendly and conventional” personality; Cluster 2, which includes the West, is dominated by people who are more relaxed, emotionally stable, calm, and creative; and Cluster 3, which includes the Northeast, has more people who are stressed, irritable, and depressed.']
['Why are they open?', 'People who live in Clusters 2 and 3 are also generally more open (Rentfrow et al., 2013).']
['What other sources of information are available?', 'One explanation for the regional differences is selective migration (Rentfrow et al., 2013).']
['What is selective migration?', 'Selective migration is the concept that people choose to move to places that are compatible with their personalities and needs.']

['What are the behavioural characteristics of people with positive coping styles?', 'For example, a person high on the agreeable scale would likely want to live near family and friends, and would choose to settle or remain in such an area.']
['What else can be learned from the study?', 'In contrast, someone high on openness would prefer to settle in a place that is recognized as diverse and innovative (such as California).']

['What is the significance of this study?', 'Further, Rentfrow, Jost, Gosling, & Potter (2009) noted an overlap between geographical regions and personality characteristics that goes beyond the often-used explanations of religion, racial diversity, and education.']
['What else can you tell me about this article?', 'Their research suggests that the psychological profile of a region is closely related to that of its residents.']

["How can that be used to explain the state's economic vitality?", 'They found that levels of openness and conscientiousness in a state may predict voting patterns, indicating that there are correlations between geographic regions and personality differences between liberals and conservatives relating to political views, levels of economic vitality, and entrepreneurial rates.']
['What are the basic differences between them?', 'Individualist cultures and collectivist cultures place emphasis on different basic values.']
['What kind of values do they have?', 'People who live in individualist cultures tend to believe that independence, competition, and personal achievement are important.']

['Which countries are these values mostly rooted in?', 'Individuals in Western nations such as the United States, England, and Australia score high on individualism (Oyserman, Coon, & Kemmelmier, 2002).']
['What are the values of a collectivist person?', 'People who live in collectivist cultures value social harmony, respectfulness, and group needs over individual needs.']
['What kind of values do the people in Asia have?', 'Individuals who live in countries in Asia, Africa, and South America score high on collectivism (Hofstede, 2001; Triandis, 1995).']
['What do these values influence?', 'These values influence personality.']

['What are the studies on this?', 'For example, Yang (2006) found that people in individualist cultures displayed more personally oriented personality traits, whereas people in collectivist cultures displayed more socially oriented personality traits.']
['Did any others make this study?', 'Frewer and Bleus (1991) conducted a study of the Eysenk Personality Inventory in a collectivist culture using Papua New Guinean university students.']
['What were the findings of this study?', 'They found that the results of the personality inventory were only relevant when analyzed within the context of a collectivist society.']

['What other studies?', 'Similarly, Dana (1986) suggested that personality assessment services for Native Americans are often provided without a proper recognition of culture-specific responses and a tribe-specific frame of reference.']

['What can we learn from these studies?', 'Assessors need to have more than a general knowledge of history, tribal differences, contemporary culture on reservations, and levels of acculturation in order to interpret psychological test responses with a minimal bias.']

['What are the approaches?', 'There are three approaches that can be used to study personality in a cultural context, the cultural-comparative approach; the indigenous approach; and the combined approach, which incorporates elements of both views.']

['How is the cultural-comparative approach different?', 'Since ideas about personality have a Western basis, the cultural-comparative approach seeks to test Western ideas about personality in other cultures to determine whether they can be generalized and if they have cultural validity (Cheung van de Vijver, & Leong, 2011).']

['How is this applied to the study?', 'For example, recall from the previous section on the trait perspective that researchers used the cultural-comparative approach to test the universality of McCrae and Costa’s Five Factor Model.']
['How did it do?', 'They found applicability in numerous cultures around the world, with the Big Five factors being stable in many cultures (McCrae & Costa, 1997; McCrae et al., 2005).']

['Does the indigenous approach have its own name?', 'The indigenous approach came about in reaction to the dominance of Western approaches to the study of personality in non-Western settings (Cheung et al., 2011).']

['What is the indigenous approach?', 'Because Western-based personality assessments cannot fully capture the personality constructs of other cultures, the indigenous model has led to the development of personality assessment instruments that are based on constructs relevant to the culture being studied (Cheung et al., 2011).']

['What is the third approach?', 'The third approach to cross-cultural studies of personality is the combined approach, which serves as a bridge between Western and indigenous psychology as a way of understanding both universal and cultural variations in personality (Cheung et al., 2011).']
['What are the characters in your story?', 'Roberto, Mikhail, and Nat are college friends and all want to be police officers.']
['What is he like?', 'Roberto is quiet and shy, lacks self-confidence, and usually follows others.']
['What is he like?', 'He is a kind person, but lacks motivation.']
['What is he like?', 'Mikhail is loud and boisterous, a leader.']
['What is he like?', 'He works hard, but is impulsive and drinks too much on the weekends.']
['What is she like?', 'Nat is thoughtful and well liked.']
['What is she like?', 'They are trustworthy, but are very methodical and therefore have difficulty making quick decisions.']
['What type of personality assessments are used?', 'A police officer’s job is very high in stress, and law enforcement agencies want to make sure they hire the right people.']
['Why would a personality test be used?', 'Personality testing is often used for this purpose—to screen applicants for employment and job training.']
['What are other applications of personality testing?', 'Personality tests are also used in criminal cases and custody battles, and to assess psychological disorders.']
['What other types of personality tests exist?', 'This section explores the best known among the many different types of personality tests.']
['What are self-report inventories?', 'Self-report inventories are a kind of objective test used to assess personality.']
['What type of test do they use?', 'They typically use multiple-choice items or numbered scales, which represent a range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree).']
['Who developed this type of scale?', 'They often are called Likert scales after their developer, Rensis Likert (1932) (Figure 11.16).']
['What other benefits are there?', 'Self-report inventories are generally easy to administer and cost effective.']

['What are the drawbacks?', 'There is also an increased likelihood of test takers being inclined to answer in ways that are intentionally or unintentionally more socially desirable, exaggerated, biased, or misleading.']
['What can happen as a result?', 'For example, someone applying for a job will likely try to present themselves in a positive light, perhaps as an even better candidate than they actually are.']

['What is the first self-report inventory mentioned?', 'One of the most widely used personality inventories is the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI), first published in 1943, with 504 true/false questions, and updated to the MMPI-2 in 1989, with 567 questions.']

['What happened to the MMPI?', 'The original MMPI was based on a small, limited sample, composed mostly of Minnesota farmers and psychiatric patients; the revised inventory was based on a more representative, national sample to allow for better standardization.']
['How long does it take to complete?', 'The MMPI-2 takes 1–2 hours to complete.']

['What are some results of the MMPI-2?', 'Responses are scored to produce a clinical profile composed of 10 scales: hypochondriasis, depression, hysteria, psychopathic deviance (social deviance), masculinity versus femininity, paranoia, psychasthenia (obsessive/compulsive qualities), schizophrenia, hypomania, and social introversion.']
['What is the most important result of the MMPI-2?', 'There is also a scale to ascertain risk factors for alcohol abuse.']
['What else is interesting in this article?', 'In 2008, the test was again revised, using more advanced methods, to the MMPI-2-RF.']
['What else can you tell me about the revised version?', 'This version takes about one-half the time to complete and has only 338 questions (Figure 11.17).']
['What other benefits can be said about the revised version?', 'Despite the new test’s advantages, the MMPI-2 is more established and is still more widely used.']
['How is it administered?', 'Typically, the tests are administered by computer.']

['What kinds of use does it have?', 'Although the MMPI was originally developed to assist in the clinical diagnosis of psychological disorders, it is now also used for occupational screening, such as in law enforcement, and in college, career, and marital counseling (Ben-Porath & Tellegen, 2008).']
['What are the different diagnostic scales?', 'In addition to clinical scales, the tests also have validity and reliability scales.']
['What are these scales used for?', '(Recall the concepts of reliability and validity from your study of psychological research.)']

['What other scales are included?', 'One of the validity scales, the Lie Scale (or “L” Scale), consists of 15 items and is used to ascertain whether the respondent is “faking good” (underreporting psychological problems to appear healthier).']

['How does the scale determine if one is fake?', 'For example, if someone responds “yes” to a number of unrealistically positive items such as “I have never told a lie,” they may be trying to “fake good” or appear better than they actually are.']

['What does reliability scale measure?', 'Reliability scales test an instrument’s consistency over time, assuring that if you take the MMPI-2-RF today and then again 5 years later, your two scores will be similar.']
['Who studied the MMPI-2-RF?', 'Beutler, Nussbaum, and Meredith (1988) gave the MMPI to newly recruited police officers and then to the same police officers 2 years later.']

['Why was the study done on police officers?', 'After 2 years on the job, police officers’ responses indicated an increased vulnerability to alcoholism, somatic symptoms (vague, unexplained physical complaints), and anxiety.']
['What else did the study show?', 'When the test was given an additional 2 years later (4 years after starting on the job), the results suggested  high risk for alcohol-related difficulties.']
['What are projective tests?', 'Another method for assessment of personality is projective testing.']
['What does this testing examine?', 'This kind of test relies on one of the defense mechanisms proposed by Freud—projection—as a way to assess unconscious processes.']

['What happens in projective testing?', 'During this type of testing, a series of ambiguous cards is shown to the person being tested, who then is encouraged to project their feelings, impulses, and desires onto the cards—by telling a story, interpreting an image, or completing a sentence.']

['How does it work?', 'Many projective tests have undergone standardization procedures (for example, Exner, 2002) and can be used to access whether someone has unusual thoughts or a high level of anxiety, or is likely to become volatile.']

['What are some of the test names?', 'Some examples of projective tests are the Rorschach Inkblot Test, the Thematic Apperception Test (TAT), the Contemporized-Themes Concerning Blacks test, the TEMAS (Tell-Me-A-Story), and the Rotter Incomplete Sentence Blank (RISB).']
['What is unique about the projective testing?', 'Projective tests are less subject to intentional distortion; it is hard to fake “good" because it is not obvious what a "good” answer is.']
['Can you describe what the downside is?', 'Projective tests are more time consuming for the evaluator than self-report inventories.']
['What are the scores?', 'If an evaluator scores the Rorschach using the Exner scoring system, the test is considered a valid and reliable measure.']
['Why is it not reliable?', 'However, the validity of the other projective tests is questionable, and the results are often not usable for court cases (Goldstein, n.d.).']
['What is the Rorschach Inkblot Test?', 'The Rorschach Inkblot Test was developed in 1921 by a Swiss psychologist named Hermann Rorschach (pronounced “ROAR-shock”).']
['What is the Rorschach?', 'It is a series of symmetrical inkblot cards that are presented to a client by a psychologist.']
['What does the psychologist do?', 'Upon presentation of each card, the psychologist asks the client, “What might this be?”']
['What can you learn about this test?', 'What the test-taker sees reveals unconscious feelings and struggles (Piotrowski, 1987; Weiner, 2003).']
['How can you use the Rorschach?', 'The Rorschach has been standardized using the Exner system and is effective in measuring depression, psychosis, and anxiety.']

['What is the first of these tests?', 'A second projective test is the Thematic Apperception Test (TAT), created in the 1930s by Henry Murray, an American psychologist, and a psychoanalyst named Christiana Morgan.']
['What does it look like?', 'A person taking the TAT is shown 8–12 ambiguous pictures and is asked to tell a story about each picture (Figure 11.18).']
['What is a story?', 'The stories give insight into their social world, revealing hopes, fears, interests, and goals.']
['How is this used?', 'The storytelling format helps to lower a person’s resistance divulging unconscious personal details (Cramer, 2004).']

['What does this reveal?', 'The TAT has been used in clinical settings to evaluate psychological disorders; more recently, it has been used in counseling settings to help clients gain a better understanding of themselves and achieve personal growth.']

['What else is interesting in this article?', 'Standardization of test administration is virtually nonexistent among clinicians, and the test tends to be modest to low on validity and reliability (Aronow, Weiss, & Rezinkoff, 2001; Lilienfeld, Wood, & Garb, 2000).']
['Is there a downside to this?', 'Despite these shortcomings, the TAT has been one of the most widely used projective tests.']

['What is the rotter incomplete sentence blank?', 'A third projective test is the Rotter Incomplete Sentence Blank (RISB) developed by Julian Rotter in 1950 (recall his theory of locus of control, covered earlier in this chapter).']
['How is this used?', 'There are three forms of this test for use with different age groups: the school form, the college form, and the adult form.']
["What's the study material about?", 'The tests include 40 incomplete sentences that people are asked to complete as quickly as possible (Figure 11.19).']
['How quickly can they complete it?', 'The average time for completing the test is approximately 20 minutes, as responses are only 1–2 words in length.']
['What does it find out?', 'This test is similar to a word association test, and like other types of projective tests, it is presumed that responses will reveal desires, fears, and struggles.']
['How is this test used?', 'The RISB is used in screening college students for adjustment problems and in career counseling (Holaday, Smith, & Sherry, 2010; Rotter & Rafferty 1950).']
['What are Projective Tests?', 'For many decades, these traditional projective tests have been used in cross-cultural personality assessments.']
['How did they work?', 'However, it was found that test bias limited their usefulness (Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']

['Why did the tests not work?', 'It is difficult to assess the personalities and lifestyles of members of widely divergent ethnic/cultural groups using personality instruments based on data from a single culture or race (Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']

['What were the examples of bias?', 'For example, when the TAT was used with African-American test takers, the result was often shorter story length and low levels of cultural identification (Duzant, 2005).']

['What did this mean?', 'Therefore, it was vital to develop other personality assessments that explored factors such as race, language, and level of acculturation (Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']

['What else happened during this time?', 'To address this need, Robert Williams developed the first culturally specific projective test designed to reflect the everyday life experiences of African Americans (Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']
['How is it named?', 'The updated version of the instrument is the Contemporized-Themes Concerning Blacks Test (C-TCB) (Williams, 1972).']
['What is different about the C-TCB?', 'The C-TCB contains 20 color images that show scenes of African-American lifestyles.']

['How did it work?', 'When the C-TCB was compared with the TAT for African Americans, it was found that use of the C-TCB led to increased story length, higher degrees of positive feelings, and stronger identification with the C-TCB (Hoy, 1997; Hoy-Watkins & Jenkins-Moore, 2008).']
['What was your next assignment?', 'The TEMAS Multicultural Thematic Apperception']
['What is the TEMAS test?', 'Test is another tool designed to be culturally relevant to minority groups, especially Hispanic youths.']

['What other materials did you use?', 'TEMAS—standing for “Tell Me a Story” but also a play on the Spanish word temas (themes)—uses images and storytelling cues that relate to minority culture (Constantino, 1982).']
['What is social psychology?', 'Social psychology examines how people affect one another, and it looks at the power of the situation.']

['What else is it focused on?', 'According to the American Psychological Association (n.d.), social psychologists "are interested in all aspects of personality and social interaction, exploring the influence of interpersonal and group relationships on human behavior."']
['What else is this chapter about?', "Throughout this chapter, we will examine how the presence of other individuals and groups of people impacts a person's behaviors, thoughts, and feelings."]
['What can you tell me about the social situations?', 'Essentially, people will change their behavior to align with the social situation at hand.']
['What are some other interesting things about this section?', 'If we are in a new situation or are unsure how to behave, we will take our cues from other individuals.']
['What is social psychology?', 'The field of social psychology studies topics at both the intra- and interpersonal levels.']

['What do intrapersonal topics include?', 'Intrapersonal topics (those that pertain to the individual) include emotions and attitudes, the self, and social cognition (the ways in which we think about ourselves and others).']

['What are some interpersonal topics?', 'Interpersonal topics (those that pertain to dyads and groups) include helping behavior (Figure 12.2), aggression, prejudice and discrimination, attraction and close relationships, and group processes and intergroup relationships.']

['What is social psychology?', 'Social psychologists focus on how people conceptualize and interpret situations and how these interpretations influence their thoughts, feelings, and behaviors (Ross & Nisbett, 1991).']
['What does social psychology study?', 'Thus, social psychology studies individuals in a social context and how situational variables interact to influence behavior.']

['What can we learn about it?', 'In this chapter, we discuss the intrapersonal processes of self-presentation, cognitive dissonance and attitude change, and the interpersonal processes of conformity and obedience, aggression and altruism, and, finally, love and attraction.']
['What is it about?', 'Behavior is a product of both the situation (e.g., cultural influences, social roles, and the presence of bystanders) and of the person (e.g., personality characteristics).']
['What are the consequences of these factors on behavior?', 'Subfields of psychology tend to focus on one influence or behavior over others.']
['What does situationism mean?', 'Situationism is the view that our behavior and actions are determined by our immediate environment and surroundings.']
['What is the oppositve viewpoint?', 'In contrast, dispositionism holds that our behavior is determined by internal factors (Heider, 1958).']
['What is an internal factor?', 'An internal factor is an attribute of a person and includes personality traits and temperament.']
['What is a factor of social psychology?', 'Social psychologists have tended to take the situationist perspective, whereas personality psychologists have promoted the dispositionist perspective.']

['How is this different from other theories?', 'Modern approaches to social psychology, however, take both the situation and the individual into account when studying human behavior (Fiske, Gilbert, & Lindzey, 2010).']

['Are there more aspects to this topic?', 'In fact, the field of social-personality psychology has emerged to study the complex interaction of internal and situational factors that affect human behavior (Mischel, 1977; Richard, Bond, & Stokes-Zoota, 2003).']
['What is the predominant cultural approach?', 'In the United States, the predominant culture tends to favor a dispositional approach in explaining human behavior.']

['How does the dispositional approach work?', 'We tend to think that people are in control of their own behaviors, and, therefore, any behavior change must be due to something internal, such as their personality, habits, or temperament.']
['What is the problem with this approach?', 'According to some social psychologists, people tend to overemphasize internal factors as explanations—or attributions—for the behavior of other people.']

['What do people tend to overemphasize?', 'They tend to assume that the behavior of another person is a trait of that person, and to underestimate the power of the situation on the behavior of others.']
['What else do they underestimate?', 'They tend to fail to recognize when the behavior of another is due to situational variables, and thus to the person’s state.']
['What is this called?', 'This erroneous assumption is called the fundamental attribution error (Ross, 1977; Riggio & Garcia, 2009).']

['What does the error mean?', 'To better understand, imagine this scenario: Jamie returns home from work, and opens the front door to a happy greeting from spouse Morgan who inquires how the day has been.']
['What is the most common response?', 'The most common response is that Jamie is a mean, angry, or unfriendly person (traits).']
['What is this called?', 'This is an internal or dispositional explanation.']
['What else do people overemphasize?', 'However, imagine that Jamie was just laid off from work due to company downsizing.']
['What happens next?', 'Your revised explanation might be that Jamie was frustrated and disappointed about being laid off and was therefore in a bad mood (state).']
['What is this called?', 'This is now an external or situational explanation for Jamie’s behavior.']
['What does fundamental attribution error mean?', 'The fundamental attribution error is so powerful that people often overlook obvious situational influences on behavior.']
['What is a classic example?', 'A classic example was demonstrated in a series of experiments known as the quizmaster study (Ross, Amabile, & Steinmetz, 1977).']
['What did the quizmaster study find?', 'Student participants were randomly assigned to play the role of a questioner (the quizmaster) or a contestant in a quiz game.']
['How was this done?', 'Questioners developed difficult questions to which they knew the answers, and they presented these questions to the contestants.']
['How well did the contestants do?', 'The contestants answered the questions correctly only 4 out of 10 times (Figure 12.3).']
['Did they get a bad grade?', 'After the task, the questioners and contestants were asked to rate their own general knowledge compared to the average student.']

['How did the questioners and contestants rate their knowledge?', 'Questioners did not rate their general knowledge higher than the contestants, but the contestants rated the questioners’ intelligence higher than their own.']
['How was the study conducted?', 'In a second study, observers of the interaction also rated the questioner as having more general knowledge than the contestant.']
['What is the conclusion of the study?', 'The obvious influence on performance is the situation.']
['What does that mean?', 'The questioners wrote the questions, so of course they had an advantage.']
['Who made the internal attribution?', 'Both the contestants and observers made an internal attribution for the performance.']
['How did the contestants and observers make that attribution?', 'They concluded that the questioners must be more intelligent than the contestants.']
['What is the halo effect?', 'The halo effect refers to the tendency to let the overall impression of an individual color the way in which we feel about their character.']
['How does it affect us?', 'For instance, we might assume that people who are physically attractive are more likely to be good people than less attractive individuals.']

['How else might it affect us?', 'Another example of how the halo effect might manifest would involve assuming that someone whom we perceive to be outgoing or friendly has a better moral character than someone who is not.']
['what is fundamental attribution error?', 'As demonstrated in the examples above, the fundamental attribution error is considered a powerful influence in how we explain the behaviors of others.']

['what is the most important aspect of this study?', 'However, it should be noted that some researchers have suggested that the fundamental attribution error may not be as powerful as it is often portrayed.']

['what is the weakness?', 'In fact, a recent review of more than 173 published studies suggests that several factors (e.g., high levels of idiosyncrasy of the character and how well hypothetical events are explained) play a role in determining just how influential the fundamental attribution error is (Malle, 2006).']
['What are some important concepts in this study material?', 'You may be able to think of examples of the fundamental attribution error in your life.']
['Do people generally make the fundamental attribution error?', 'Research suggests that they do not.']

['Do some people make the fundamental attribution error more than others?', 'People from an individualistic culture, that is, a culture that focuses on individual achievement and autonomy, have the greatest tendency to commit the fundamental attribution error.']
['How is this characterized?', 'Individualistic cultures, which tend to be found in western countries such as the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom, promote a focus on the individual.']
['What are the underlying characteristics of this bias?', 'Therefore, a person’s disposition is thought to be the primary explanation for her behavior.']

['Does it mean the individual does it for her own good?', 'In contrast, people from a collectivistic culture, that is, a culture that focuses on communal relationships with others, such as family, friends, and community (Figure 12.4), are less likely to commit the fundamental attribution error (Markus & Kitayama, 1991; Triandis, 2001).']

['What is a cultural factor?', 'Collectivistic cultures, which tend to be found in east Asian countries and in Latin American and African countries, focus on the group more than on the individual (Nisbett, Peng, Choi, & Norenzayan, 2001).']

["Why does this affect one's understanding of others?", 'This focus on others provides a broader perspective that takes into account both situational and cultural influences on behavior; thus, a more nuanced explanation of the causes of others’ behavior becomes more likely.']
['Are there any other interesting aspects of this article?', 'Table 12.1 summarizes compares individualistic and collectivist cultures.']

['What else do you find interesting in this document?', 'Masuda and Nisbett (2001) demonstrated that the kinds of information that people attend to when viewing visual stimuli (e.g., an aquarium scene) can differ significantly depending on whether the observer comes from a collectivistic versus an individualistic culture.']

['What else did they demonstrate?', 'Japanese participants were much more likely to recognize objects that were presented when they occurred in the same context in which they were originally viewed.']
['Did they find anything else interesting?', 'Manipulating the context in which object recall occurred had no such impact on American participants.']
['Did any other research find this?', 'Other researchers have shown similar differences across cultures.']

['Do they explain what happened?', 'For example, Zhang, Fung, Stanley, Isaacowitz, and Zhang (2014) demonstrated differences in the ways that holistic thinking might develop between Chinese and American participants, and Ramesh and Gelfand (2010) demonstrated that job turnover rates are more related to the fit between a person and the organization in which they work in an Indian sample, but the fit between the person and their specific job was more predictive of turnover in an American sample.']
['What are some examples of actor-observer bias?', 'Returning to our earlier example, Jamie was laid off, but an observer would not know.']

['Why does an observer assume the person has a disposition?', 'So a naïve observer would tend to attribute Jamie’s hostile behavior to Jamie’s disposition rather than to the true, situational cause.']
['Why do we assume that the person has a disposition?', 'One reason is that we often don’t have all the information we need to make a situational explanation for another person’s behavior.']
["What happens when we don't have all the information?", 'Due to this lack of information we have a tendency to assume the behavior is due to a dispositional, or internal, factor.']
["Is there anything else interesting that you'd like to share with me?", 'When it comes to explaining our own behaviors, however, we have much more information available to us.']
['What does a situational explanation look like?', 'You might say you were very tired or feeling unwell and needed quiet time—a situational explanation.']

['Why is the actor-observer bias important?', 'The actor-observer bias is the phenomenon of attributing other people’s behavior to internal factors (fundamental attribution error) while attributing our own behavior to situational forces (Jones & Nisbett, 1971; Nisbett, Caputo, Legant, & Marecek, 1973; Choi & Nisbett, 1998).']
['Why do we think that?', 'As actors of behavior, we have more information available to explain our own behavior.']
['Does it have anything to do with our gender?', 'However as observers, we have less information available; therefore, we tend to default to a dispositionist perspective.']

['What else did we learn about the Actor-Observer Bias?', 'One study on the actor-observer bias investigated reasons male participants gave for why they liked their girlfriend (Nisbett et al., 1973).']

['What were the results of that study?', 'When asked why participants liked their own girlfriend, participants focused on internal, dispositional qualities of their girlfriends (for example, her pleasant personality).']
['Were there any other results?', 'The participants’ explanations rarely included causes internal to themselves, such as dispositional traits (for example, “I need companionship.”).']

['Was there anything else interesting about this study?', 'In contrast, when speculating why a male friend likes his girlfriend, participants were equally likely to give dispositional and external explanations.']
['What did this all mean?', 'This supports the idea that actors tend to provide few internal explanations but many situational explanations for their own behavior.']
['What were the findings of this study?', 'In contrast, observers tend to provide more dispositional explanations for a friend’s behavior (Figure 12.5).']
['What is self-serving bias?', 'We can understand self-serving bias by digging more deeply into attribution, a belief about the cause of a result.']

['What is the model of attribution?', 'One model of attribution proposes three main dimensions: locus of control (internal versus external), stability (stable versus unstable), and controllability (controllable versus uncontrollable).']
['What is stability?', 'In this context, stability refers to the extent in which the circumstances that result in a given outcome are changeable.']
['What are considered stable?', 'The circumstances are considered stable if they are unlikely to change.']
['What is controllability?', 'Controllability refers to the extent to which the circumstances that are associated with a given outcome can be controlled.']
['What are things that can be controlled?', 'Obviously, those things that we have the power to control would be labeled controllable (Weiner, 1979).']

['What are self-serving biases?', 'Following an outcome, self-serving biases are those attributions that enable us to see ourselves in a favorable light (for example, making internal attributions for success and external attributions for failures).']

['What does the example explain?', 'When you do well at a task, for example acing an exam, it is in your best interest to make a dispositional attribution for your behavior (“I’m smart,”) instead of a situational one (“The exam was easy,”).']

['What is self-serving bias?', 'Self-serving bias is the tendency to explain our successes as due to dispositional (internal) characteristics, but to explain our failures as due to situational (external) factors.']
['Is this culturally specific?', 'Again, this is culture dependent.']
['Why do people do this?', 'This bias serves to protect self-esteem.']

['How is it advantageous to do this?', 'You can imagine that if people always made situational attributions for their behavior, they would never be able to take credit and feel good about their accomplishments.']
['What is the purpose of self-serving bias?', 'Consider the example of how we explain our favorite sports team’s wins.']

['What do you know about how we explain our team’s wins?', 'Research shows that we make internal, stable, and controllable attributions for our team’s victory (Figure 12.6) (Grove, Hanrahan, & McInman, 1991).']

['How do we make internal, stable, and controllable attributions?', 'For example, we might tell ourselves that our team is talented (internal), consistently works hard (stable), and uses effective strategies (controllable).']
['What else did you learn about self-serving bias?', 'In contrast, we are more likely to make external, unstable, and uncontrollable attributions when our favorite team loses.']

['How do we make external, unstable, and uncontrollable attributions?', 'For example, we might tell ourselves that the other team has more experienced players or that the referees were unfair (external), the other team played at home (unstable), and the cold weather affected our team’s performance (uncontrollable).']
['What are some things you can tell me about this study material?', 'One consequence of westerners’ tendency to provide dispositional explanations for behavior is victim blame (Jost & Major, 2001).']
['What does victim blame mean?', 'When people experience bad fortune, others tend to assume that they somehow are responsible for their own fate.']
['What is the just world hypothesis?', 'A common ideology, or worldview, in the United States is the just-world hypothesis.']
['What is this?', 'The just-world hypothesis is the belief that people get the outcomes they deserve (Lerner & Miller, 1978).']

['How is the just world hypothesis formed?', 'In order to maintain the belief that the world is a fair place, people tend to think that good people experience positive outcomes, and bad people experience negative outcomes (Jost, Banaji, & Nosek, 2004; Jost & Major, 2001).']

['Why is this so prevalent?', 'The ability to think of the world as a fair place, where people get what they deserve, allows us to feel that the world is predictable and that we have some control over our life outcomes (Jost et al., 2004; Jost & Major, 2001).']
['What does this control mean?', 'For example, if you want to experience positive outcomes, you just need to work hard to get ahead in life.']
['How can the hypotheses about justice benefit people?', 'One negative consequence is people’s tendency to blame poor individuals for their plight.']
['What does this do for the poor?', 'These dispositional explanations are clear examples of the fundamental attribution error.']

['Why does this lead to poverty?', 'Blaming poor people for their poverty ignores situational factors that impact them, such as high unemployment rates, recession, poor educational opportunities, and the familial cycle of poverty (Figure 12.7).']
['What else is there?', 'Other research shows that people who hold just-world beliefs have negative attitudes toward people who are unemployed and people living with AIDS (Sutton & Douglas, 2005).']
["What happens when you don't have just-world views?", 'In the United States and other countries, victims of sexual assault may find themselves blamed for their abuse.']

['How can this be fixed?', 'Victim advocacy groups, such as Domestic Violence Ended (DOVE), attend court in support of victims to ensure that blame is directed at the perpetrators of sexual violence, not the victims.']
['What is social psychology?', 'As you’ve learned, social psychology is the study of how people affect one another’s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']

['What is social psychology?', 'We have discussed situational perspectives and social psychology’s emphasis on the ways in which a person’s environment, including culture and other social influences, affect behavior.']

['What do you know about situational perspectives?', 'In this section, we examine situational forces that have a strong influence on human behavior including social roles, social norms, and scripts.']
['Why do people use scripts?', 'We discuss how humans use the social environment as a source of information, or cues, on how to behave.']

['Why do situational influences influence people?', 'Situational influences on our behavior have important consequences, such as whether we will help a stranger in an emergency or how we would behave in an unfamiliar environment.']
['What is social roles?', 'One major social determinant of human behavior is our social roles.']
['What is a social role?', 'A social role is a pattern of behavior that is expected of a person in a given setting or group (Hare, 2003).']
['What are some of the social roles people have?', 'Each one of us has several social roles.']
['What other social roles?', 'You may be, at the same time, a student, a parent, an aspiring teacher, a son or daughter, a spouse, and a lifeguard.']
['What is the definition of a social role?', 'Social roles are defined by culturally shared knowledge.']
['What is culturally shared knowledge?', 'That is, nearly everyone in a given culture knows what behavior is expected of a person in a given role.']

['What are some examples of social roles?', 'If you look around a college classroom you will likely see students engaging in studious behavior, taking notes, listening to the professor, reading the textbook, and sitting quietly at their desks (Figure 12.8).']

['What social role do the students have?', 'Of course you may see students deviating from the expected studious behavior such as texting on their phones or using Facebook on their laptops, but in all cases, the students that you observe are attending class—a part of the social role of students.']
['What did you learn about Social Roles?', 'Social roles, and our related behavior, can vary across different settings.']
['How do you change your behavior in one situation and another?', 'Now imagine how you behave when you are engaged in the role of employee at your workplace.']
['Is it similar to how you behave when you are engaged in the role of parent?', 'It is very likely that your behavior will be different.']
['How so?', 'Perhaps you are more relaxed and outgoing with your family, making jokes and doing silly things.']

['Do you make jokes about something when at work?', 'But at your workplace you might speak more professionally, and although you may be friendly, you are also serious and focused on getting the work completed.']

['What are other examples of how social roles influence our behavior?', 'These are examples of how our social roles influence and often dictate our behavior to the extent that identity and personality can vary with context (that is, in different social groups) (Malloy, Albright, Kenny, Agatstein & Winquist, 1997).']
['What are Social Norms?', 'As discussed previously, social roles are defined by a culture’s shared knowledge of what is expected behavior of an individual in a specific role.']
['What does this shared knowledge come from?', 'This shared knowledge comes from social norms.']

['What are social norms?', 'A social norm is a group’s expectation of what is appropriate and acceptable behavior for its members—how they are supposed to behave and think (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955; Berkowitz, 2004).']

['What kinds of norms exist?', 'In our discussion of social roles we noted that colleges have social norms for students’ behavior in the role of student and workplaces have social norms for employees’ behaviors in the role of employee.']
['Where else do social norms exist?', 'Social norms are everywhere including in families, gangs, and on social media outlets.']
['What is Scripts?', 'Because of social roles, people tend to know what behavior is expected of them in specific, familiar settings.']
['What is a script?', 'A script is a person’s knowledge about the sequence of events expected in a specific setting (Schank & Abelson, 1977).']
['How can you use this?', 'For example, at a restaurant in the United States, if we want the server’s attention, we try to make eye contact.']
['What else do you notice in this script?', 'In Brazil, you would make the sound “psst” to get the server’s attention.']
['What other aspects do you see?', 'You can see the cultural differences in scripts.']
['How do they differ?', 'To an American, saying “psst” to a server might seem rude, yet to a Brazilian, trying to make eye contact might not seem an effective strategy.']
['What do you learn from this?', 'Scripts are important sources of information to guide behavior in given situations.']
['What other scenarios do you see?', 'This could be uncomfortable and confusing.']

['What is Zimbardo’s Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'The famous Stanford prison experiment, conducted by social psychologist Philip Zimbardo and his colleagues at Stanford University, demonstrated the power of social roles, social norms, and scripts.']

['When did the experiment take place?', 'In the summer of 1971, an advertisement was placed in a California newspaper asking for male volunteers to participate in a study about the psychological effects of prison life.']

['What were the results of the experiment?', 'More than 70 men volunteered, and these volunteers then underwent psychological testing to eliminate candidates who had underlying psychiatric issues, medical issues, or a history of crime or drug abuse.']
['What did the psychological testing include?', 'The pool of volunteers was whittled down to 24 healthy male college students.']
['How was the experiment conducted?', 'Each student was paid $15 per day (equivalent to about $80 today) and was randomly assigned to play the role of either a prisoner or a guard in the study.']
['what is the Stanford prison experiment?', 'A mock prison was constructed in the basement of the psychology building at Stanford.']

['how was the experiment conducted?', 'Participants assigned to play the role of prisoners were “arrested” at their homes by Palo Alto police officers, booked at a police station, and subsequently taken to the mock prison.']
['how long did it last?', 'The experiment was scheduled to run for several weeks.']
['how did the experiment go?', 'To the surprise of the researchers, both the “prisoners” and “guards” assumed their roles with zeal.']
['what else is important?', 'On the second day of the experiment, the guards forced the prisoners to strip, took their beds, and isolated the ringleaders using solitary confinement.']

['did they discipline them?', 'In a relatively short time, the guards came to harass the prisoners in an increasingly sadistic manner, through a complete lack of privacy, lack of basic comforts such as mattresses to sleep on, and through degrading chores and late-night counts.']
['What was the experiment about?', 'The prisoners, in turn, began to show signs of severe anxiety and hopelessness—they began tolerating the guards’ abuse.']

['How did he discover this?', 'Even the Stanford professor who designed the study and was the head researcher, Philip Zimbardo, found himself acting as if the prison was real and his role, as prison supervisor, was real as well.']
['How long was this experiment?', 'After only six days, the experiment had to be ended due to the participants’ deteriorating behavior.']
['What else was interesting?', 'Zimbardo explained,']

['What was the Stanford Prison Experiment about?', 'The Stanford Prison Experiment has been used as a memorable demonstration of the incredible power that social roles, norms, and scripts have in affecting human behavior.']
['Was the experiment popular?', 'However, multiple aspects of the study have been subject to criticism since its inception.']
['What were some of the criticisms?', 'The nature of these criticisms range from ethical concerns to issues of generalizability (Bartels, Milovich, & Moussier, 2016; Griggs, 2014; Le Texier, 2019).']
['What else did critics say?', 'One criticism is that the way students were recruited for the experiment may have impacted the outcome (Carnahan & McFarland, 2007).']
['What else did the critics say?', 'Another criticism questions the conclusions that can be drawn from the study.']
['What else is important about this experiment?', 'Zimbardo appears to have provided specific guidelines of the types of behaviors that were expected of the guards (Zimbardo, 2007).']

['What was the research conclusion?', 'Subsequent research suggests that such guidelines likely created an expectation of the types of behavior that Zimbardo reported observing in the Stanford Prison Experiment (Bartels, 2019), and that given these expectations, the guards simply acted as they thought they were expected to act.']
['Did he try to replicate it?', 'It has also been problematic that attempts to replicate aspects of the study have not been successful.']
['What happened to the guards?', 'For example, when no guidelines were presented to the guards, researchers documented different outcomes than those observed by Zimbardo.']
['What else is important?', '(Reicher & Haslam, 2006).']

['What were the results of this study?', 'The Stanford Prison Experiment has some parallels with the abuse of prisoners of war by U.S. Army troops and CIA personnel at the Abu Ghraib prison in 2003 and 2004 during the Iraq War.']
['Why are there parallels?', 'The offenses at Abu Ghraib were documented by photographs of the abuse, some taken by the abusers themselves (Figure 12.10).']
['What does this study cover?', 'Social psychologists have documented how the power of the situation can influence our behaviors.']
['What do you mean by that?', 'Now we turn to how the power of the situation can influence our attitudes and beliefs.']
['What is attitude?', 'Attitude is our evaluation of a person, an idea, or an object.']
['What do we have attitudes about?', 'We have attitudes for many things ranging from products that we might pick up in the supermarket to people around the world to political policies.']
['What kind of attitudes do we have?', 'Typically, attitudes are favorable or unfavorable: positive or negative (Eagly & Chaiken, 1993).']
