['How are they categorized?', 'And, they have three components: an affective component (feelings), a behavioral component (the effect of the attitude on behavior), and a cognitive component (belief and knowledge) (Rosenberg & Hovland, 1960).']
['Why is that?', 'For example, you may hold a positive attitude toward recycling.']

['What does this mean?', 'This attitude should result in positive feelings toward recycling (such as “It makes me feel good to recycle” or “I enjoy knowing that I make a small difference in reducing the amount of waste that ends up in landfills”).']
['Are there other examples?', 'Certainly, this attitude should be reflected in our behavior:']
["You don't recycle a lot.", 'You actually recycle as often as you can.']

['Are there any other examples?', 'Finally, this attitude will be reflected in favorable thoughts (for example, “Recycling is good for the environment” or “Recycling is the responsible thing to do”).']
['what are attitudes and beliefs?', 'Our attitudes and beliefs are not only influenced by external forces, but also by internal influences that we control.']

['what are some other internal influences?', 'Like our behavior, our attitudes and thoughts are not always changed by situational pressures, but they can be consciously changed by our own free will.']
['what else did you learn about attitudes and beliefs?', 'In this section we discuss the conditions under which we would want to change our own attitudes and beliefs.']

['What did the scientists find?', 'Social psychologists have documented that feeling good about ourselves and maintaining positive self-esteem is a powerful motivator of human behavior (Tavris & Aronson, 2008).']

['what does positive self-esteem mean?', 'In the United States, members of the predominant culture typically think very highly of themselves and view themselves as good people who are above average on many desirable traits (Ehrlinger, Gilovich, & Ross, 2005).']
['Why does self-esteem matter?', 'Often, our behavior, attitudes, and beliefs are affected when we experience a threat to our self-esteem or positive self-image.']

['What did Festinger define?', 'Psychologist Leon Festinger (1957) defined cognitive dissonance as psychological discomfort arising from holding two or more inconsistent attitudes, behaviors, or cognitions (thoughts, beliefs, or opinions).']

['How was dissonance caused?', 'Festinger’s theory of cognitive dissonance states that when we experience a conflict in our behaviors, attitudes, or beliefs that runs counter to our positive self-perceptions, we experience psychological discomfort (dissonance).']

['How does dissonance affect people?', 'For example, if you believe smoking is bad for your health but you continue to smoke, you experience conflict between your belief and behavior (Figure 12.11).']

['What is the name of one researcher who analyzed dissonance?', 'Later research documented that only conflicting cognitions that threaten individuals’ positive self-image cause dissonance (Greenwald & Ronis, 1978).']

['What else is known about dissonance?', 'Additional research found that dissonance is not only psychologically uncomfortable but also can cause physiological arousal (Croyle & Cooper, 1983) and activate regions of the brain important in emotions and cognitive functioning (van Veen, Krug, Schooler, & Carter, 2009).']
['How is dissonance associated with behavior?', 'When we experience cognitive dissonance, we are motivated to decrease it because it is psychologically, physically, and mentally uncomfortable.']
['How does one reduce dissonance?', 'We can reduce cognitive dissonance by bringing our cognitions, attitudes, and behaviors in line—that is, making them harmonious.']
['How is this accomplished?', 'This can be done in different ways, such as:']
['what are some other examples?', 'A classic example of cognitive dissonance is Joaquin, a 20-year-old who enlists in the military.']

['What happened during boot camp?', 'During boot camp he is awakened at 5:00 a.m., is chronically sleep deprived, yelled at, covered in sand flea bites, physically bruised and battered, and mentally exhausted (Figure 12.12).']
['What was he doing after boot camp?', 'It gets worse.']
['How bad was it?', 'Recruits that make it to week 11 of boot camp have to do 54 hours of continuous training.']
['What happened after that?', 'Not surprisingly, Joaquin is miserable.']
['Does it make him miserable?', 'No one likes to be miserable.']
['Are there any other significant aspects in this passage?', 'In this type of situation, people can change their beliefs, their attitudes, or their behaviors.']
['What is the last option?', 'The last option, a change of behaviors, is not available to Joaquin.']
['Why not?', 'He has signed on to the military for four years, and he cannot legally leave.']
['Did you write down anything else?', 'If Joaquin keeps thinking about how miserable he is, it is going to be a very long four years.']
['What else is interesting about this paragraph?', 'He will be in a constant state of cognitive dissonance.']
['How does this affect him?', 'As an alternative to this misery, Joaquin can change his beliefs or attitudes.']
['What can he do?', 'He can tell himself, “I am becoming stronger, healthier, and sharper.']
['What else can he tell himself?', 'I am learning discipline and how to defend myself and my country.']
['How else can he tell himself?', 'What I am doing is really important.”']
['How does this affect him?', 'If this is his belief, he will realize that he is becoming stronger through his challenges.']
['What does this do for him?', 'He then will feel better and not experience cognitive dissonance, which is an uncomfortable state.']
['What did you learn about the military example?', 'The military example demonstrates the observation that a difficult initiation into a group influences us to like the group more.']

['What did you learn about the justification of effort?', 'Another social psychology concept, justification of effort, suggests that we value goals and achievements that we put a lot of effort into.']
['What is the theory?', 'According to this theory, if something is difficult for us to achieve, we believe it is more worthwhile.']
['What is an example?', 'For example, if you move to an apartment and spend hours assembling a dresser you bought from Ikea, you will value that more than a fancier dresser someone else bought you.']
['What are other examples?', 'We do not want to have wasted time and effort to join a group that we eventually leave.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'A classic experiment by Aronson and Mills (1959) demonstrated this justification of effort effect.']
['What happened in 1959?', 'College students volunteered to join a campus group that would meet regularly to discuss the psychology of sex.']
['What was the experiment?', 'Participants were randomly assigned to one of three conditions: no initiation, an easy initiation, and a difficult initiation into the group.']
['What was the experiment?', 'After participating in the first discussion, which was deliberately made very boring, participants rated how much they liked the group.']

['Did they like the group?', 'Participants who underwent a difficult initiation process to join the group rated the group more favorably than did participants with an easy initiation or no initiation (Figure 12.13).']
['How can it be applied to education?', 'Similar effects can be seen in a more recent study of how student effort affects course evaluations.']

['What other things did you find interesting?', 'Heckert, Latier, Ringwald-Burton, and Drazen (2006) surveyed 463 undergraduates enrolled in courses at a midwestern university about the amount of effort that their courses required of them.']
['What was the survey about?', 'In addition, the students were also asked to evaluate various aspects of the course.']

['What were the results?', 'Given what you’ve just read, it will come as no surprise that those courses that were associated with the highest level of effort were evaluated as being more valuable than those that did not.']

['Are there any other interesting findings?', 'Furthermore, students indicated that they learned more in courses that required more effort, regardless of the grades that they received in those courses (Heckert et al., 2006).']

['What kind of information does the study material contain?', 'Here is one: Maria and Marco live in Fairfield County, Connecticut, which is one of the wealthiest areas in the United States and has a very high cost of living.']
['How does the couple earn money?', 'Maria telecommutes from home and Marco does not work outside of the home.']
['How much does the house cost?', 'They rent a very small house for more than $3000 a month.']
['What else can you tell me about the couple?', 'Marco shops at consignment stores for clothes and economizes when possible.']

['What else is unique about their situation?', 'When asked why they do not move to a less expensive location, since Maria telecommutes, they respond that Fairfield County is beautiful, they love the beaches, and they feel comfortable there.']

['What are some examples?', 'In the previous section we discussed that the motivation to reduce cognitive dissonance leads us to change our attitudes, behaviors, and/or cognitions to make them consonant.']
['what is persuasion?', 'Persuasion is the process of changing our attitude toward something based on some kind of communication.']
['What type of communication?', 'Much of the persuasion we experience comes from outside forces.']
['How does this approach work?', 'The topic of persuasion has been one of the most extensively researched areas in social psychology (Fiske et al., 2010).']
['What type of research has been done on this topic?', 'During the Second World War, Carl Hovland extensively researched persuasion for the U.S. Army.']
['When did he do this?', 'After the war, Hovland continued his exploration of persuasion at Yale University.']
['How was his work useful?', 'Out of this work came a model called the Yale attitude change approach, which describes the conditions under which people tend to change their attitudes.']

['What were the conditions?', 'Hovland demonstrated that certain features of the source of a persuasive message, the content of the message, and the characteristics of the audience will influence the persuasiveness of a message (Hovland, Janis, & Kelley, 1953).']

['What is Yale Attitude Change Approach?', 'Features of the source of the persuasive message include the credibility of the speaker (Hovland & Weiss, 1951) and the physical attractiveness of the speaker (Eagly & Chaiken, 1975; Petty, Wegener, & Fabrigar, 1997).']
['What is credibility?', 'Thus, speakers who are credible, or have expertise on the topic, and who are deemed as trustworthy are more persuasive than less credible speakers.']
['What is attractiveness?', 'Similarly, more attractive speakers are more persuasive than less attractive speakers.']
['What is an example?', 'The use of famous actors and athletes to advertise products on television and in print relies on this principle.']
['What else is significant?', 'The immediate and long term impact of the persuasion also depends, however, on the credibility of the messenger (Kumkale & Albarracín, 2004).']

['What is the content of this article about?', 'Features of the message itself that affect persuasion include subtlety (the quality of being important, but not obvious) (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986; Walster & Festinger, 1962); sidedness (that is, having more than one side) (Crowley & Hoyer, 1994; Igou & Bless, 2003; Lumsdaine & Janis, 1953); timing (Haugtvedt & Wegener, 1994; Miller & Campbell, 1959), and whether both sides are presented.']
['What is the subtlety?', 'Messages that are more subtle are more persuasive than direct messages.']
['What is the timing?', 'Arguments that occur first, such as in a debate, are more influential if messages are given back-to-back.']

['What else can you tell me about the timing?', 'However, if there is a delay after the first message, and before the audience needs to make a decision, the last message presented will tend to be more persuasive (Miller & Campbell, 1959).']

['What does the study show?', 'Features of the audience that affect persuasion are attention (Albarracín & Wyer, 2001; Festinger & Maccoby, 1964), intelligence, self-esteem (Rhodes & Wood, 1992), and age (Krosnick & Alwin, 1989).']
['How does attention relate to persuasion?', 'In order to be persuaded, audience members must be paying attention.']

['What is intelligence?', 'People with lower intelligence are more easily persuaded than people with higher intelligence; whereas people with moderate self-esteem are more easily persuaded than people with higher or lower self-esteem (Rhodes & Wood, 1992).']
['How does age relate to persuasion?', 'Finally, younger adults aged 18–25 are more persuadable than older adults.']
['What is Elaboration Likelihood Model?', 'An especially popular model that describes the dynamics of persuasion is the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986).']

['What does the model describe?', 'The elaboration likelihood model considers the variables of the attitude change approach—that is, features of the source of the persuasive message, contents of the message, and characteristics of the audience are used to determine when attitude change will occur.']

['What are the two routes?', 'According to the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion, there are two main routes that play a role in delivering a persuasive message: central and peripheral (Figure 12.15).']
['What is the central route?', 'The central route is logic driven and uses data and facts to convince people of an argument’s worthiness.']
['What evidence is used?', 'For example, a car company seeking to persuade you to purchase their model will emphasize the car’s safety features and fuel economy.']
['What is the indirect route?', 'This is a direct route to persuasion that focuses on the quality of the information.']

['What happens next?', 'In order for the central route of persuasion to be effective in changing attitudes, thoughts, and behaviors, the argument must be strong and, if successful, will result in lasting attitude change.']

['What is the central route to persuasion?', 'The central route to persuasion works best when the target of persuasion, or the audience, is analytical and willing to engage in processing of the information.']
['What is an example of the elaboration likelihood model in action?', 'One example is buying a computer.']

['What are some other examples?', 'It is likely, for example, that small business owners might be especially influenced by the focus on the computer’s quality and features such as processing speed and memory capacity.']
['What is the peripheral route?', 'The peripheral route is an indirect route that uses peripheral cues to associate positivity with the message (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986).']

['What can peripheral cues do?', 'Instead of focusing on the facts and a product’s quality, the peripheral route relies on association with positive characteristics such as positive emotions and celebrity endorsement.']
['What types of celebrity endorsements?', 'For example, having a popular athlete advertise athletic shoes is a common method used to encourage young adults to purchase the shoes.']
['What else is unique about peripheral route?', 'This route to attitude change does not require much effort or information processing.']
['How does this route affect perception?', 'This method of persuasion may promote positivity toward the message or product, but it typically results in less permanent attitude or behavior change.']
['Why is that?', 'The audience does not need to be analytical or motivated to process the message.']
['How does the audience respond to this route?', 'In fact, a peripheral route to persuasion may not even be noticed by the audience, for example in the strategy of product placement.']
['What is product placement?', 'Product placement refers to putting a product with a clear brand name or brand identity in a TV show or movie to promote the product (Gupta & Lord, 1998).']
['What shows does this happen in?', 'For example, one season of the reality series American Idol prominently showed the panel of judges drinking out of cups that displayed the Coca-Cola logo.']
['What else happens in this method?', 'Another example is clothing: A retailer may focus on celebrities that are wearing the same style of clothing.']

['What are some interesting facts about this study?', 'Researchers have tested many persuasion strategies that are effective in selling products and changing people’s attitude, ideas, and behaviors.']
['Who are some of the scientists?', 'One effective strategy is the foot-in-the-door technique (Cialdini, 2001; Pliner, Hart, Kohl, & Saari, 1974).']

['How does this technique work?', 'Using the foot-in-the-door technique, the persuader gets a person to agree to bestow a small favor or to buy a small item, only to later request a larger favor or purchase of a bigger item.']

['Does this technique work for everyone?', 'The foot-in-the-door technique was demonstrated in a study by Freedman and Fraser (1966) in which participants who agreed to a post small sign in their yard or sign a petition were more likely to agree to put a large sign in their yard than people who declined the first request (Figure 12.16).']

['Is there anything else interesting about this study?', 'Research on this technique also illustrates the principle of consistency (Cialdini, 2001): Our past behavior often directs our future behavior, and we have a desire to maintain consistency once we have committed to a behavior.']

['What is foot-in-the-door technique?', 'A common application of foot-in-the-door is when teens ask their parents for a small permission (for example, extending curfew by a half hour) and then asking them for something larger.']
['Why is this useful?', 'Having granted the smaller request increases the likelihood that parents will acquiesce with the later, larger request.']
['What is the foot-in-the-door technique?', 'For example, say that you are buying the latest model smartphone, and the salesperson suggests you purchase the best data plan.']
['What does this mean for you?', 'You agree to this.']
['What is another example?', 'The salesperson then suggests a bigger purchase—the three-year extended warranty.']
['What does this mean?', 'After agreeing to the smaller request, you are more likely to also agree to the larger request.']
['Where did this technique originate?', 'You may have encountered this if you have bought a car.']

['How does it work in car sales?', 'When salespeople realize that a buyer intends to purchase a certain model, they might try to get the customer to pay for many or most available options on the car.']

['How can you identify the foot-in-the-door technique in sales?', 'Another example of the foot-in-the-door technique would be applied to an individual in the market for a used car who decides to buy a fully loaded new car.']
['Why did the buyer buy a fully loaded new car?', 'Because the salesperson convinced the buyer that they need a car that has all of the safety features that were not available in the used car.']
['What was the first thing that you were asked to learn?', 'In this section, we discuss additional ways in which people influence others.']

['What did they discuss in the section?', 'The topics of conformity, social influence, obedience, and group processes demonstrate the power of the social situation to change our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']

['How did they demonstrate the power of social situations?', 'We begin this section with a discussion of a famous social psychology experiment that demonstrated how susceptible humans are to outside social pressures.']
['What is conformity?', 'Solomon Asch conducted several experiments in the 1950s to determine how people are affected by the thoughts and behaviors of other people.']
['How did he do this?', 'In one study, a group of participants was shown a series of printed line segments of different lengths: a, b, and c (Figure 12.17).']
['Why were there four segments?', 'Participants were then shown a fourth line segment: x.']
['What was their task?', 'They were asked to identify which line segment from the first group (a, b, or c) most closely resembled the fourth line segment in length.']
['What was the sample?', 'Each group of participants had only one true, naïve subject.']
['What else was important?', 'The remaining members of the group were confederates of the researcher.']
['What is a confederate?', 'A confederate is a person who is aware of the experiment and works for the researcher.']

['What do they do?', 'Confederates are used to manipulate social situations as part of the research design, and the true, naïve participants believe that confederates are, like them, uninformed participants in the experiment.']
['What was the result of this experiment?', 'In Asch’s study, the confederates identified a line segment that was obviously shorter than the target line—a wrong answer.']
['What happened after that?', 'The naïve participant then had to identify aloud the line segment that best matched the target line segment.']
['What are some key points from the study?', 'Asch (1955) found that 76% of participants conformed to group pressure at least once by indicating the incorrect line.']
['What is conformity?', 'Conformity is the change in a person’s behavior to go along with the group, even if he does not agree with the group.']

['What is the Asch effect?', 'Research shows that the size of the majority, the presence of another dissenter, and the public or relatively private nature of responses are key influences on conformity.']
['What is the size of the majority?', 'The size of the majority:']
['What happens when there is a large majority?', 'The greater the number of people in the majority, the more likely an individual will conform.']
['What is an upper limit?', 'There is, however, an upper limit: a point where adding more members does not increase conformity.']
["What was the number of people in Asch's study?", 'In Asch’s study, conformity increased with the number of people in the majority—up to seven individuals.']
['When did this happen?', 'At numbers beyond seven, conformity leveled off and decreased slightly (Asch, 1955).']
['What is the presence of another dissenter?', 'The presence of another dissenter:']
['What happens when there is only one dissenter?', 'If there is at least one dissenter, conformity rates drop to near zero (Asch, 1955).']
['What are other factors?', 'The public or private nature of the responses:']

['What does this mean?', 'When responses are made publicly (in front of others), conformity is more likely; however, when responses are made privately (e.g., writing down the response), conformity is less likely (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955).']

['How is it used in everyday life?', 'The finding that conformity is more likely to occur when responses are public than when they are private is the reason government elections require voting in secret, so we are not coerced by others (Figure 12.18).']
['Does it apply to anyone?', 'The Asch effect can be easily seen in children when they have to publicly vote for something.']

['Does it have any benefits for them?', 'For example, if the teacher asks whether the children would rather have extra recess, no homework, or candy, once a few children vote, the rest will comply and go with the majority.']
['How does it impact them?', 'In a different classroom, the majority might vote differently, and most of the children would comply with that majority.']
['What is compliance?', 'When someone’s vote changes if it is made in public versus private, this is known as compliance.']
['Can this be considered a form of conformity?', 'Compliance can be a form of conformity.']
['What else can you tell me about compliance?', 'Compliance is going along with a request or demand, even if you do not agree with the request.']
['Why does this happen?', 'In Asch’s studies, the participants complied by giving the wrong answers, but privately did not accept that the obvious wrong answers were correct.']
['Did you find this material helpful?', 'The correct answer to the line segment question was obvious, and it was an easy task.']

['Did you have any other thoughts about the material?', 'Researchers have categorized the motivation to conform into two types: normative social influence and informational social influence (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955).']
['What are the normative social influences?', 'In normative social influence, people conform to the group norm to fit in, to feel good, and to be accepted by the group.']

['What is an informational social influence?', 'However, with informational social influence, people conform because they believe the group is competent and has the correct information, particularly when the task or situation is ambiguous.']
['What did the Asch study say?', 'Since the line judgment task was unambiguous, participants did not need to rely on the group for information.']
['What else did the study find?', 'Instead, participants complied to fit in and avoid ridicule, an instance of normative social influence.']
['What can you tell me about informational social influence?', 'An example of informational social influence may be what to do in an emergency situation.']
['What should I do in an emergency situation?', 'Imagine that you are in a movie theater watching a film and what seems to be smoke comes in the theater from under the emergency exit door.']
['What can you tell me about this situation?', 'You are not certain that it is smoke—it might be a special effect for the movie, such as a fog machine.']
['What do you think?', 'When you are uncertain you will tend to look at the behavior of others in the theater.']
['Why do you say that?', 'If other people show concern and get up to leave, you are likely to do the same.']
['How do I leave the theater?', 'However, if others seem unconcerned, you are likely to stay put and continue watching the movie (Figure 12.19).']
['What does the Asch effect mean?', 'Many students say they would not conform, that the study is outdated, and that people nowadays are more independent.']
['How is this true?', 'To some extent this may be true.']
['Is the study still accurate?', 'Research suggests that overall rates of conformity may have reduced since the time of Asch’s research.']
['Why did it reduce?', 'Furthermore, efforts to replicate']
['What did they discover?', 'Asch’s study have made it clear that many factors determine how likely it is that someone will demonstrate conformity to the group.']
['What are these factors?', 'These factors include the participant’s age, gender, and socio-cultural background (Bond & Smith, 1996; Larsen, 1990; Walker & Andrade, 1996).']
['What is conformity?', 'Conformity is one effect of the influence of others on our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']
['What is an example of obedience?', 'Another form of social influence is obedience to authority.']
['What is obedience?', 'Obedience is the change of an individual’s behavior to comply with a demand by an authority figure.']
['How is obedience different from conformity?', 'People often comply with the request because they are concerned about a consequence if they do not comply.']
['What did Milgram study?', 'To demonstrate this phenomenon, we review another classic social psychology experiment.']
['who was stanley milgram?', 'Stanley Milgram was a social psychology professor at Yale who was influenced by the trial of Adolf Eichmann, a Nazi war criminal.']

['what was his experiment?', 'Eichmann’s defense for the atrocities he committed was that he was “just following orders.” Milgram (1963) wanted to test the validity of this defense, so he designed an experiment and initially recruited 40 men for his experiment.']
['what were the volunteers in charge of?', 'The volunteer participants were led to believe that they were participating in a study to improve learning and memory.']
['what were they being told?', 'The participants were told that they were to teach other students (learners) correct answers to a series of test items.']
['what else were they taught?', 'The participants were shown how to use a device that they were told delivered electric shocks of different intensities to the learners.']
['what did they do after the shocks were delivered?', 'The participants were told to shock the learners if they gave a wrong answer to a test item—that the shock would help them to learn.']
['how was the effect on the learners?', 'The participants believed they gave the learners shocks, which increased in 15-volt increments, all the way up to 450 volts.']
['what was done to the participants?', 'The participants did not know that the learners were confederates and that the confederates did not actually receive shocks.']
['What was the experiment?', 'In response to a string of incorrect answers from the learners, the participants obediently and repeatedly shocked them.']
['Did the experiment show anything about obedience?', 'The confederate learners cried out for help, begged the participant teachers to stop, and even complained of heart trouble.']

['What happened after they complained?', 'Yet, when the researcher told the participant-teachers to continue the shock, 65% of the participants continued the shock to the maximum voltage and to the point that the learner became unresponsive (Figure 12.20).']
['What was the experiment about?', 'Several variations of the original Milgram experiment were conducted to test the boundaries of obedience.']
['Was there any conclusion?', 'When certain features of the situation were changed, participants were less likely to continue to deliver shocks (Milgram, 1965).']

['What changes did they make?', 'For example, when the setting of the experiment was moved to an off-campus office building, the percentage of participants who delivered the highest shock dropped to 48%.']
['What other things did the experiment do?', 'When the learner was in the same room as the teacher, the highest shock rate dropped to 40%.']
['How about touching?', 'When the teachers’ and learners’ hands were touching, the highest shock rate dropped to 30%.']
['What else did they change?', 'When the researcher gave the orders by phone, the rate dropped to 23%.']
['Was there anything else important to know?', 'These variations show that when the humanity of the person being shocked was increased, obedience decreased.']
['What else was discovered?', 'Similarly, when the authority of the experimenter decreased, so did obedience.']
['Was the experiment successful?', 'This case is still very applicable today.']
['What was the study about?', 'In a study by Martin and Bull (2008), midwives privately filled out a questionnaire regarding best practices and expectations in delivering a baby.']
['What did they ask?', 'Then, a more senior midwife and supervisor asked the junior midwives to do something they had previously stated they were opposed to.']
['Was the test successful?', 'Most of the junior midwives were obedient to authority, going against their own beliefs.']
['What were the other studies?', 'Burger (2009) partially replicated this study.']
['What did the findings show?', "He found among a multicultural sample of women and men that their levels of obedience matched Milgram's research."]

['Was the study replicated?', "Doliński et al. (2017) performed a replication of Burger's work in Poland and controlled for the gender of both participants and learners, and once again, results that were consistent with Milgram's original work were observed."]
['What is groupthink?', 'When in group settings, we are often influenced by the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors of people around us.']
['What influences this behavior?', 'Whether it is due to normative or informational social influence, groups have power to influence individuals.']
['What is groupthink?', 'Another phenomenon of group conformity is groupthink.']
['What does groupthink consist of?', 'Groupthink is the modification of the opinions of members of a group to align with what they believe is the group consensus (Janis, 1972).']

['Does groupthink make good decisions?', 'In group situations, the group often takes action that individuals would not perform outside the group setting because groups make more extreme decisions than individuals do.']
['Does groupthink lead to bad decisions?', 'Moreover, groupthink can hinder opposing trains of thought.']
['What happens as a result?', 'This elimination of diverse opinions contributes to faulty decision by the group.']
['What does groupthink mean?', 'There are several causes of groupthink, which makes it preventable.']

['What is one cause of groupthink?', 'When the group is highly cohesive, or has a strong sense of connection, maintaining group harmony may become more important to the group than making sound decisions.']
['What other causes of groupthink are there?', 'If the group leader is directive and makes his opinions known, this may discourage group members from disagreeing with the leader.']
['What other causes of groupthink are there?', 'If the group is isolated from hearing alternative or new viewpoints, groupthink may be more likely.']

['what were the strategies to improve group decision making?', 'There are several strategies that can improve group decision making including seeking outside opinions, voting in private, having the leader withhold position statements until all group members have voiced their views, conducting research on all viewpoints, weighing the costs and benefits of all options, and developing a contingency plan (Janis, 1972; Mitchell & Eckstein, 2009).']
['What is it?', 'Another phenomenon that occurs within group settings is group polarization.']
['Whose theory was this?', 'Group polarization (Teger & Pruitt, 1967) is the strengthening of an original group attitude after the discussion of views within a group.']
["How does it strengthen a group's initial attitude?", 'That is, if a group initially favors a viewpoint, after discussion the group consensus is likely a stronger endorsement of the viewpoint.']
['Is there anything else you want to know about this theory?', 'Conversely, if the group was initially opposed to a viewpoint, group discussion would likely lead to stronger opposition.']
['What is the biggest takeaway from this theory?', 'Group polarization explains many actions taken by groups that would not be undertaken by individuals.']

['How is it applied in everyday settings?', 'Group polarization can be observed at political conventions, when platforms of the party are supported by individuals who, when not in a group, would decline to support them.']
['Why did they do this?', 'Recently, some theorists have argued that group polarization may be partly responsible for the extreme political partisanship that seems ubiquitous in modern society.']

['Why do they have such extreme views?', 'Given that people can self-select media outlets that are most consistent with their own political views, they are less likely to encounter opposing viewpoints.']
['Does this affect their political views?', 'Over time, this leads to a strengthening of their own perspective and of hostile attitudes and behaviors towards those with different political ideals.']

['How does this affect society?', 'Remarkably, political polarization leads to open levels of discrimination that are on par with, or perhaps exceed, racial discrimination (Iyengar & Westwood, 2015).']
['What else do you find interesting in the article?', 'A more everyday example is a group’s discussion of how attractive someone is.']

['What are social traps?', 'Social traps refer to situations that arise when individuals or groups of individuals behave in ways that are not in their best interest and that may have negative, long-term consequences.']
['How does a social trap affect its victim?', 'However, once established, a social trap is very difficult to escape.']
['Do you have any examples of social traps?', 'For example, following World War II, the United States and the former Soviet Union engaged in a nuclear arms race.']

['What were the effects of the arms race?', "While the presence of nuclear weapons is not in either party's best interest, once the arms race began, each country felt the need to continue producing nuclear weapons to protect itself from the other."]
['what can you tell me about this group project?', 'Imagine you were just assigned a group project with other students whom you barely know.']
['what can you tell me about the group project?', 'Everyone in your group will get the same grade.']
['what can you tell me about Social loafing?', 'Social loafing involves a reduction in individual output on tasks where contributions are pooled.']
['why does this happen?', "Because each individual's efforts are not evaluated, individuals can become less motivated to perform well."]

['what can you tell me about how to stop social loafing?', 'Karau and Williams (1993) and Simms and Nichols (2014) reviewed the research on social loafing and discerned when it was least likely to happen.']

['what else can you tell me about how to prevent social loafing?', 'The researchers noted that social loafing could be alleviated if, among other situations, individuals knew their work would be assessed by a manager (in a workplace setting) or instructor (in a classroom setting), or if a manager or instructor required group members to complete self-evaluations.']
['What were some of the results found by Shepperd & Taylor?', 'The likelihood of social loafing in student work groups increases as the size of the group increases (Shepperd & Taylor, 1999).']
['What other research has been done?', 'According to Kamau and Williams (1993), college students were the population most likely to engage in social loafing.']

['What else did they find?', 'Their study also found that women and participants from collectivistic cultures were less likely to engage in social loafing, explaining that their group orientation may account for this.']

['What kind of research do you have on social loafing?', 'College students could work around social loafing or “free-riding” by suggesting to their professors use of a flocking method to form groups.']

['How does flocking work?', 'Harding (2018) compared groups of students who had self-selected into groups for class to those who had been formed by flocking, which involves assigning students to groups who have similar schedules and motivations.']
['How did this work?', 'Not only did she find that students reported less “free riding,” but that they also did better in the group assignments compared to those whose groups were self-selected.']
['What was important about the title Social Loafing?', 'Interestingly, the opposite of social loafing occurs when the task is complex and difficult (Bond & Titus, 1983; Geen, 1989).']

['Why does social loafing occur?', 'In a group setting, such as the student work group, if your individual performance cannot be evaluated, there is less pressure for you to do well, and thus less anxiety or physiological arousal (Latané, Williams, & Harkens, 1979).']
['What happens when there is less anxiety or physiological arousal?', 'This puts you in a relaxed state in which you can perform your best, if you choose (Zajonc, 1965).']

['Why do people want to perform their best?', 'If the task is a difficult one, many people feel motivated and believe that their group needs their input to do well on a challenging project (Jackson & Williams, 1985).']
['What is Deindividuation?', 'Another way that being part of a group can affect behavior is exhibited in instances in which deindividuation occurs.']

['How does this affect behavior?', 'Deindividuation refers to situations in which a person may feel a sense of anonymity and therefore a reduction in accountability and sense of self when among others.']

['What else can you tell me about deindividuation?', 'Deindividuation is often pointed to in cases in which mob or riot-like behaviors occur (Zimbardo, 1969), but research on the subject and the role that deindividuation plays in such behaviors has resulted in inconsistent results (as discussed in Granström, Guvå, Hylander, & Rosander, 2009).']
['What is human conflict?', 'Human conflict can result in crime, war, and mass murder, such as genocide.']
['What is the root cause?', 'Prejudice and discrimination often are root causes of human conflict, which explains how strangers come to hate one another to the extreme of causing others harm.']
['Does this affect other people?', 'Prejudice and discrimination affect everyone.']

['What do we learn about prejudice and discrimination in this section?', 'In this section we will examine the definitions of prejudice and discrimination, examples of these concepts, and causes of these biases.']
['What does this content include?', 'As we discussed in the opening story of Trayvon Martin, humans are very diverse and although we share many similarities, we also have many differences.']
['How do these differences influence people?', 'The social groups we belong to help form our identities (Tajfel, 1974).']
['What can cause people to be prejudiced?', 'These differences may be difficult for some people to reconcile, which may lead to prejudice toward people who are different.']
['What is prejudice?', 'Prejudice is a negative attitude and feeling toward an individual based solely on one’s membership in a particular social group (Allport, 1954; Brown, 2010).']
['Is prejudice common?', 'Prejudice is common against people who are members of an unfamiliar cultural group.']

['Can we help stop prejudice?', 'Thus, certain types of education, contact, interactions, and building relationships with members of different cultural groups can reduce the tendency toward prejudice.']
['Does being around other people make it harder to be prejudiced?', 'In fact, simply imagining interacting with members of different cultural groups might affect prejudice.']

['What can be done about prejudice?', 'Indeed, when experimental participants were asked to imagine themselves positively interacting with someone from a different group, this led to an increased positive attitude toward the other group and an increase in positive traits associated with the other group.']
['Can imagining interactions make people less prejudiced?', 'Furthermore, imagined social interaction can reduce anxiety associated with inter-group interactions (Crisp & Turner, 2009).']
['What are some examples of social groups?', 'Social groups can include gender, race, ethnicity, nationality, social class, religion, sexual orientation, profession, and many more.']
['Can one be a member of multiple social groups?', 'And, as is true for social roles, you can simultaneously be a member of more than one social group.']
['What are some examples of prejudice?', 'An example of prejudice is having a negative attitude toward people who are not born in the United States.']

['How would someone who is not born in the U.S. feel?', 'Although people holding this prejudiced attitude do not know all people who were not born in the United States, they dislike them due to their status as foreigners.']

['What does prejudice mean?', 'Prejudice often begins in the form of a stereotype—that is, a specific belief or assumption about individuals based solely on their membership in a group, regardless of their individual characteristics.']
['How does prejudice affect people?', 'Stereotypes become overgeneralized and applied to all members of a group.']

['How can stereotypes affect people?', 'For example, someone holding prejudiced attitudes toward older adults, may believe that older adults are slow and incompetent (Cuddy, Norton, & Fiske, 2005; Nelson, 2004).']
['What can be done to avoid a stereotype?', 'We cannot possibly know each individual person of advanced age to know that all older adults are slow and incompetent.']

['What does prejudice lead to?', 'Therefore, this negative belief is overgeneralized to all members of the group, even though many of the individual group members may in fact be spry and intelligent.']
['What kind of stereotypes might be present?', 'Another example of a well-known stereotype involves beliefs about racial differences among athletes.']

['How do people interpret this?', 'As Hodge, Burden, Robinson, and Bennett (2008) point out, Black athletes are often believed to be more athletic, yet less intelligent, than their White counterparts.']
['How can this be debunked?', 'These beliefs persist despite a number of high profile examples to the contrary.']
['What are some negative effects of this?', 'Sadly, such beliefs often influence how these athletes are treated by others and how they view themselves and their own capabilities.']
['How can you prevent this?', 'Whether or not you agree with a stereotype, stereotypes are generally well-known within a given culture (Devine, 1989).']
['What is discrimination?', 'Sometimes people will act on their prejudiced attitudes toward a group of people, and this behavior is known as discrimination.']

['What are the results of that discrimination?', 'Discrimination is negative action toward an individual as a result of one’s membership in a particular group (Allport, 1954; Dovidio & Gaertner, 2004).']

['Why is that?', 'As a result of holding negative beliefs (stereotypes) and negative attitudes (prejudice) about a particular group, people often treat the target of prejudice poorly, such as excluding older adults from their circle of friends.']
['What can discrimination do to someone?', 'In this way, discrimination is a form of oppression.']
['What are examples of discrimination?', 'An example of a psychologist experiencing gender discrimination is found in the life and studies of Mary Whiton Calkins.']

['What can you tell me about her experience?', 'Calkins was given special permission to attend graduate seminars at Harvard (at that time in the late 1880s, Harvard did not accept women) and at one point was the sole student of the famous psychologist William James.']

['Did she succeed in her studies?', 'She passed all the requirements needed for a PhD and was described by psychologist Hugo Münsterberg as “one of the strongest professors of psychology in this country.”']
["Why didn't she get the PhD?", 'However, Harvard refused to grant Calkins a PhD because she was a woman (Harvard University, 2019).']
['What are the characteristics of stereotypes?', 'Table 12.3 summarizes the characteristics of stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination.']

['How is it related to the world at large?', 'So far, we’ve discussed stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination as negative thoughts, feelings, and behaviors because these are typically the most problematic.']

['Is there anything else important about the content?', 'However, it is important to also point out that people can hold positive thoughts, feelings, and behaviors toward individuals based on group membership; for example, they would show preferential treatment for people who are like themselves—that is, who share the same gender, race, or favorite sports team.']
['What is the content of this material about?', 'When we meet strangers we automatically process three pieces of information about them: their race, gender, and age (Ito & Urland, 2003).']

['What else is important in the text?', 'Although these secondary characteristics are important in forming a first impression of a stranger, the social categories of race, gender, and age provide a wealth of information about an individual.']
['What are some examples of these secondary characteristics?', 'This information, however, often is based on stereotypes.']
['What happens to people with different stereotypes?', 'We may have different expectations of strangers depending on their race, gender, and age.']

['What does racism mean?', 'Racism is prejudice and discrimination against an individual based solely on one’s membership in a specific racial group (such as toward African Americans, Asian Americans, Latinos, Native Americans, European Americans).']

['What are some examples of prejudice?', 'Research suggests cultural stereotypes for Asian Americans include cold, sly, and intelligent; for Latinos, cold and unintelligent; for European Americans, cold and intelligent; and for African Americans, aggressive, athletic, and more likely to be law breakers (Devine & Elliot, 1995; Fiske, Cuddy, Glick, & Xu, 2002; Sommers & Ellsworth, 2000; Dixon & Linz, 2000).']
['What is racism?', 'Racism exists for many racial and ethnic groups.']

['What are some examples of racism?', 'For example, Black people are significantly more likely to have their vehicles searched during traffic stops than White people, particularly when Black people are driving in predominately White neighborhoods, a phenomenon often termed “DWB” or “driving while Black” (Rojek, Rosenfeld, & Decker, 2012).']
['Who are the targets of racism?', 'Mexican Americans and other Latino groups also are targets of racism from the police and other members of the community.']

['What does racism have to do with shopper security?', 'For example, when purchasing items with a personal check, Latino shoppers are more likely than White shoppers to be asked to show formal identification (Dovidio et al., 2010).']

['What does it say about the role of racial discrimination in America?', 'In one case of alleged harassment by the police, several East Haven, Connecticut, police officers were arrested on federal charges due to reportedly continued harassment and brutalization of Latinos.']
['What was the consequence of these accusations?', 'When the accusations came out, the mayor of East Haven was asked, “What are you doing for the Latino community today?”']
['What did the mayor respond?', 'The Mayor responded, “I might have tacos when I go home, I’m not quite sure yet” (“East Haven Mayor,” 2012).']

['What else did this have to do with the accusations?', 'This statement undermines the important issue of racial profiling and police harassment of Latinos, while belittling Latino culture by emphasizing an interest in a food product stereotypically associated with Latinos.']

['What else do you find interesting about racism?', 'Racism is prevalent toward many other groups in the United States including Native Americans, Arab Americans, Jewish Americans, and Asian Americans.']
['What type of racism is this?', 'One reason modern forms of racism, and prejudice in general, are hard to detect is related to the dual attitudes model (Wilson, Lindsey, & Schooler, 2000).']

['What is dual attitudes model?', 'Humans have two forms of attitudes: explicit attitudes, which are conscious and controllable, and implicit attitudes, which are unconscious and uncontrollable (Devine, 1989; Olson & Fazio, 2003).']

['How are these attitudes formed?', 'Because holding egalitarian views is socially desirable (Plant & Devine, 1998), most people do not show extreme racial bias or other prejudices on measures of their explicit attitudes.']

['What is most interesting in this passage?', 'However, measures of implicit attitudes often show evidence of mild to strong racial bias or other prejudices (Greenwald, McGee, & Schwartz, 1998; Olson & Fazio, 2003).']
['what is sexism?', 'Sexism is prejudice and discrimination toward individuals based on their sex.']
['what is the main type of sexism?', 'Typically, sexism takes the form of men holding biases against women, but anyone can show sexism toward their own or the other sex.']
['is there any other type of sexism?', 'Like racism, sexism may be subtle and difficult to detect.']
['can you tell me about one specific example of sexism?', 'Common forms of sexism in modern society include gender role expectations, such as expecting women to be the caretakers of the household.']
['are there other types of sexism?', 'Sexism also includes people’s expectations for how members of a gender group should behave.']

['what are these expectations?', 'For example, women are expected to be friendly, passive, and nurturing, and when women behave in an unfriendly, assertive, or neglectful manner they often are disliked for violating their gender role (Rudman, 1998).']

['what about the male counterpart?', 'Research by Laurie Rudman (1998) finds that when female job applicants self-promote, they are likely to be viewed as competent, but they may be disliked and are less likely to be hired because they violated gender expectations for modesty.']

['can you elaborate on what the double bind refers to?', 'In this way, women are sometimes blamed for wage and employment inequality, but they would be viewed negatively for trying to overcome them, a phenomenon sometimes referred to as the double bind.']
['how can sexism affect them?', 'Sexism can exist on a societal level such as in hiring, employment opportunities, and education.']

['how does it affect them in employment opportunities?', 'Women are less likely to be hired or promoted in male-dominated professions such as engineering, aviation, and construction (Figure 12.22) (Blau, Ferber, & Winkler, 2010; Ceci & Williams, 2011).']
['can you tell me a lot more about this?', 'Think about your family members’ jobs or careers.']
['What is ageism?', 'People often form judgments and hold expectations about people based on their age.']
['What happens when these judgments are based on age?', 'These judgments and expectations can lead to ageism, or prejudice and discrimination toward individuals based solely on their age.']
['What else do you know about ageism?', 'Think of expectations you hold for older adults.']

['What other things do you think about older adults?', 'Ageism is widespread in U.S. culture (Nosek, 2005), and a common ageist attitude toward older adults is that they are incompetent, physically weak, and slow (Greenberg, Schimel, & Martens, 2002) and some people consider older adults less attractive.']

['Are older people better or worse off because of ageism?', 'Chang, Kannoth, Levy, Wang, Lee, and Levy (2020) reported on relationships between ageism and health outcomes over a 40-year-plus period from countries around the world.']
['What does the study say?', 'Across 11 health domains, people over 50 were likely to experience ageism most often in the form of being denied access to health services and work opportunities.']

['Can older adults still get jobs?', 'Some cultures, however, including some Asian, Latino, and African American cultures, both outside and within the United States afford older adults respect and honor.']
['What is ageism?', 'Typically, ageism occurs against older adults, but ageism also can occur toward younger adults.']
['What is ageism against younger workers?', 'Raymer, Reed, Spiegel, and Purvanova (2017) examined ageism against younger workers.']

['What did they find?', 'They found that older workers endorsed negative stereotypes of younger workers, believing that they had more work deficit characteristics (including perceptions of incompetence).']

['What was homophobia?', 'Another form of prejudice is homophobia: an umbrella term referring to prejudice and discrimination of individuals based solely on their sexual orientation, which is often applied to bisexual, lesbian, gay, and other non-heterosexual people.']

['What was transphobia?', 'Transphobia is the hatred or fear of those who are perceived to break or blur stereotypical gender roles, often expressed as stereotyping, discrimination, harassment and/or violence.']
['How did people feel about these issues?', 'Like ageism, homophobia is a widespread prejudice in U.S. society that is tolerated by many people (Herek & McLemore, 2013; Nosek, 2005).']

['What did they do to stop the prejudice?', 'Negative feelings often result in discrimination, such as the exclusion of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ+) people from social groups and the avoidance of LGBTQ+ neighbors and co-workers.']

['What else did they say?', 'This discrimination also extends to employers deliberately declining to hire qualified LGBTQ+ job applicants, a practice officially outlawed by a 2020 Surpreme Court decision but which remains a significant issue.']
['Why do prejudices and discrimination exist?', 'Prejudice and discrimination persist in society due to social learning and conformity to social norms.']

['What do social norms mean?', 'Children learn prejudiced attitudes and beliefs from society: their parents, teachers, friends, the media, and other sources of socialization, such as social media (O’Keeffe & Clarke-Pearson, 2011).']

['What pressures?', 'If certain types of prejudice and discrimination are acceptable in a society, there may be normative pressures to conform and share those prejudiced beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors.']
['What examples?', 'For example, public and private schools are still somewhat segregated by social class.']

['What happened there?', 'Historically, only children from wealthy families could afford to attend private schools, whereas children from middle- and low-income families typically attended public schools.']
['What do you mean by stereotypes?', 'When we hold a stereotype about a person, we have expectations that they will fulfill that stereotype.']
['What are self-fulfilling prophecies?', 'A self-fulfilling prophecy is an expectation held by a person that alters their behavior in a way that tends to make it true.']
['How do stereotypes and self-fulfilling prophecies affect behavior?', 'When we hold stereotypes about a person, we tend to treat the person according to our expectations.']
['What happens if we treat people the wrong way?', 'This treatment can influence the person to act according to our stereotypic expectations, thus confirming our stereotypic beliefs.']

['What else did you find interesting?', 'Research by Rosenthal and Jacobson (1968) found that disadvantaged students whose teachers expected them to perform well had higher grades than disadvantaged students whose teachers expected them to do poorly.']
['What was the purpose of this study material?', 'Consider this example of cause and effect in a self-fulfilling prophecy:']

['What was the example?', 'If an employer expects an openly gay job applicant to be incompetent, the potential employer might treat the applicant negatively during the interview by engaging in less conversation, making little eye contact, and generally behaving coldly toward the applicant (Hebl, Foster, Mannix, & Dovidio, 2002).']

['What happened after the employer treated the applicant negatively?', 'In turn, the job applicant will perceive that the potential employer dislikes him, and he will respond by giving shorter responses to interview questions, making less eye contact, and generally disengaging from the interview.']

['What happens if the employer perceives this negative behavior?', 'After the interview, the employer will reflect on the applicant’s behavior, which seemed cold and distant, and the employer will conclude, based on the applicant’s poor performance during the interview, that the applicant was in fact incompetent.']
['How does the self-fulfilling prophecy effect the applicant?', 'Thus, the employer’s stereotype—gay people are incompetent and do not make good employees—is reinforced.']
['How does the example effect the applicant?', 'Treating individuals according to stereotypic beliefs can lead to prejudice and discrimination.']
['What is an example of how self-fulfilling prophecy can work?', 'Another dynamic that can reinforce stereotypes is confirmation bias.']

['What is confirmation bias?', 'When interacting with the target of our prejudice, we tend to pay attention to information that is consistent with our stereotypic expectations and ignore information that is inconsistent with our expectations.']

['How does this effect our perception of the target of our prejudice?', 'In this process, known as confirmation bias, we seek out information that supports our stereotypes and ignore information that is inconsistent with our stereotypes (Wason & Johnson-Laird, 1972).']

['How does it affect a job interview?', 'In the job interview example, the employer may not have noticed that the job applicant was friendly and engaging, and that he provided competent responses to the interview questions in the beginning of the interview.']

['Why did they ignore that?', 'Instead, the employer focused on the job applicant’s performance in the later part of the interview, after the applicant changed his demeanor and behavior to match the interviewer’s negative treatment.']
['What are the out groups?', 'As discussed previously in this section, we all belong to a gender, race, age, and social economic group.']
['What are the in groups?', 'These groups provide a powerful source of our identity and self-esteem (Tajfel & Turner, 1979).']
['What do they provide for us?', 'These groups serve as our in-groups.']
['What is an in-group?', 'An in-group is a group that we identify with or see ourselves as belonging to.']
['What is an out group?', 'A group that we don’t belong to, or an out-group, is a group that we view as fundamentally different from us.']
['Are there any examples in this paragraph?', 'For example, if you are a woman, your gender in-group includes all women, and your gender out-group includes all men (Figure 12.23).']
['What are the reasons behind this view?', 'People often view gender groups as being fundamentally different from each other in personality traits, characteristics, social roles, and interests.']

['What happens when you belong to a group?', 'Because we often feel a strong sense of belonging and emotional connection to our in-groups, we develop in-group bias: a preference for our own group over other groups.']

['What happens when people prefer their own group?', 'This in-group bias can result in prejudice and discrimination because the out-group is perceived as different and is less preferred than our in-group.']
['What is one example of a destructive behavior?', 'One function of prejudice is to help us feel good about ourselves and maintain a positive self-concept.']
['What do we do to maintain a positive self-concept?', 'This need to feel good about ourselves extends to our in-groups:']
['What do we want to feel good and protect our in-groups?', 'We want to feel good and protect our in-groups.']
['What does this mean?', 'We seek to resolve threats individually and at the in-group level.']
['How do we resolve threats?', 'This often happens by blaming an out-group for the problem.']
['What is scapegoating?', 'Scapegoating is the act of blaming an out-group when the in-group experiences frustration or is blocked from obtaining a goal (Allport, 1954).']
['What was this chapter about?', 'Throughout this chapter we have discussed how people interact and influence one another’s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors in both positive and negative ways.']

['What else did we discuss?', 'People can work together to achieve great things, such as helping each other in difficult times: consider how educators and healthcare workers went to great lengths to help others during the COVID-19 pandemic.']

['What were some other examples?', 'People also can do great harm to one another, such as conforming to group norms that are immoral and obeying authority to the point of murder: consider the mass conformity of Nazis during WWII.']
['What did we discuss in this section?', 'In this section we will discuss a negative side of human behavior—aggression.']
['What can we learn from this article?', 'A number of researchers have explored ways to reduce prejudice.']
['Which one was the first?', 'One of the earliest was a study by Sherif et al. (1961) known as the Robbers Cave experiment.']

['What was the study about?', 'They found that when two opposing groups at a camp worked together toward a common goal, prejudicial attitudes between the groups decreased (Gaertner, Dovidio, Banker, Houlette, Johnson, & McGlynn, 2000).']
['What can you tell me about the common goal?', 'Focusing on superordinate goals was the key to attitude change in the research.']
['How can people have superordinate goals?', 'Another study examined the jigsaw classroom, a technique designed by Aronson and Bridgeman in an effort to increase success in desegregated classrooms.']
['What can you tell me about this technique?', 'In this technique, students work on an assignment in groups inclusive of various races and abilities.']

['How did they work in groups?', 'They are assigned tasks within their group, then collaborate with peers from other groups who were assigned the same task, and then report back to their original group.']

['What other studies have been done?', 'Walker and Crogan (1998) noted that the jigsaw classroom reduced potential for prejudice in Australia, as diverse students worked together on projects needing all of the pieces to succeed.']
['What can you tell me about these studies?', 'This research suggests that anything that can allow individuals to work together toward common goals can decrease prejudicial attitudes.']
['What can you tell me about the real-world application?', 'Obviously, the application of such strategies in real-world settings would enhance opportunities for conflict resolution.']
['What does Aggression mean?', 'Humans engage in aggression when they seek to cause harm or pain to another person.']
['What causes aggression?', 'Aggression takes two forms depending on one’s motives: hostile or instrumental.']
['What are the two types of aggression?', 'Hostile aggression is motivated by feelings of anger with intent to cause pain; a fight in a bar with a stranger is an example of hostile aggression.']

['Are there more examples?', 'In contrast, instrumental aggression is motivated by achieving a goal and does not necessarily involve intent to cause pain (Berkowitz, 1993); a contract killer who murders for hire displays instrumental aggression.']
['What theories are there about aggression?', 'There are many different theories as to why aggression exists.']
['Are there any common themes among the theories?', 'Some researchers argue that aggression serves an evolutionary function (Buss, 2004).']
['What other theories are there?', 'Men are more likely than women to show aggression (Wilson & Daly, 1985).']

['What are some of the main conclusions of the various theories?', 'From the perspective of evolutionary psychology, human male aggression, like that in nonhuman primates, likely serves to display dominance over other males, both to protect a mate and to perpetuate the male’s genes (Figure 12.24).']

['Can you give me some examples of aggression?', 'Sexual jealousy is part of male aggression; males endeavor to make sure their mates are not copulating with other males, thus ensuring their own paternity of the female’s offspring.']
['What else is important about the theory of aggression?', 'Although aggression provides an obvious evolutionary advantage for men, women also engage in aggression.']

['What other things can you tell me about the female theory of aggression?', 'Women typically display more indirect forms of aggression, with their aggression serving as a means to an end (Dodge & Schwartz, 1997).']
['Can you give me some examples of indirect aggression?', 'For example, women may express their aggression covertly by communication that impairs the social standing of another person.']
['What are other theories?', 'Another theory that explains one of the functions of human aggression is frustration aggression theory (Dollard, Doob, Miller, Mowrer, & Sears, 1939).']
['How does this theory help explain aggression?', 'This theory states that when humans are prevented from achieving an important goal, they become frustrated and aggressive.']
['What does Bullying mean?', 'Another form of aggression is bullying.']

['What is the most significant aspect of child development?', 'As you learn in your study of child development, socializing and playing with other children is beneficial for children’s psychological development.']
['Are there other benefits of playing with others?', 'However, as you may have experienced as a child, not all play behavior has positive outcomes.']
['What are some instances of bad behavior?', 'Some children are aggressive and want to play roughly.']
['Do other children use abusive words?', 'Other children are selfish and do not want to share toys.']
['Are there any other instances of bad behavior that are more common than others?', 'One form of negative social interactions among children that has become a national concern is bullying.']
['What does bullying involve?', 'Bullying is repeated negative treatment of another person, often an adolescent, over time (Olweus, 1993).']
['What else do you find interesting?', 'A one-time incident in which one child hits another child on the playground would not be considered bullying: Bullying is repeated behavior.']
['How do children react to bullying?', 'The negative treatment typical in bullying is the attempt to inflict harm, injury, or humiliation, and bullying can include physical or verbal attacks.']
['What else do you want to know?', 'However, bullying doesn’t have to be physical or verbal, it can be psychological.']
['Does gender play a factor in bullying?', 'Research finds gender differences in how girls and boys bully others (American Psychological Association, 2010; Olweus, 1993).']
['What do boys do in comparison to girls?', 'Boys tend to engage in direct, physical aggression such as physically harming others.']
['How do girls bully?', 'Girls tend to engage in indirect, social forms of aggression such as spreading rumors, ignoring, or socially isolating others.']
['What are the three parties involved?', 'Bullying involves three parties: the bully, the victim, and witnesses or bystanders.']
['What does the imbalance of power involve?', 'The act of bullying involves an imbalance of power with the bully holding more power—physically, emotionally, and/or socially over the victim.']
['What was the positive side of bullying?', 'The experience of bullying can be positive for the bully, who may enjoy a boost to self-esteem.']
['Why is bullying negative?', 'However, there are several negative consequences of bullying for the victim, and also for the bystanders.']
['What does being bullied cause?', 'Being the victim of bullying is associated with decreased mental health, including experiencing anxiety and depression (APA, 2010).']
['What else is happening?', 'Victims of bullying may underperform in schoolwork (Bowen, 2011).']
['What other effect?', 'Bullying also can result in the victim dying by suicide (APA, 2010).']
['What are the patterns that have been identified in children who are at a greater risk for being', 'Children who are emotionally reactive are at a greater risk for being bullied.']
['Why are children who are emotionally reactive at risk?', 'Bullies may be attracted to children who get upset easily because the bully can quickly get an emotional reaction from them.']
['Are there any other traits that have been identified?', 'Children who are different from others are likely to be targeted for bullying.']

['Are there any other characteristics that have been identified?', 'Children who are overweight, cognitively impaired, or racially or ethnically different from their peer group may be at higher risk.']
['Do LGBT children face more risks?', 'Gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender teens are at very high risk of being bullied and hurt due to their sexual orientation.']
['What does cyberbullying mean?', 'With widely available mobile technology and social networking media, a new form of bullying has emerged: cyberbullying.']
['How is cyberbullying different from bullying?', 'Cyberbullying, like bullying, is repeated behavior that is intended to cause psychological or emotional harm to another person.']
['Does cyberbullying have consequences?', 'What is unique about cyberbullying is that it is typically covert, concealed, done in private, and the bully can remain anonymous.']

['How does this benefit the bully?', 'This anonymity gives the bully power, and the victim may feel helpless, unable to escape the harassment, and unable to retaliate (Spears, Slee, Owens, & Johnson, 2009).']

['Does cyberbullying exist?', 'About one in three middle and high school students report that they have experienced cyberbullying (Patchin, 2016; Patchin, 2019), with some studies indicating that nearly three in five teens have experienced some type of online abusive behavior such as non-repeated name-calling or being sent unsolicited links or images (Anderson, 2018).']

['What is cyberbullying?', 'Cyberbullying can take many forms, including harassing a victim by spreading rumors, creating a website defaming the victim, threatening the victim, or teasing the victim (Spears et al., 2009).']

['What kind of victim are we talking about here?', 'Overall, LGBTQ youth are targeted at a higher rate than heterosexual and cisgender youth, and members of minority populations overall are more likely to be cyberbullying victims (Hinjuda & Patchin, 2020).']
['What type of victim do you mean?', 'In terms of gender, experiences vary in terms of both the prevelance and types of cyberbullying experienced and perpetrated.']
['Are there gender preferences as far as cyberbullying goes?', 'In cyberbullying, it is more common for girls to be the bullies and victims.']
['Are girls more likely to become cyberbullies?', 'Interestingly, girls who become cyberbullies often have been the victims of cyberbullying at one time (Vandebosch & Van Cleemput, 2009).']

["Does gender matter in the victim's experience?", 'Girls were more likely to say someone spread rumors about them online while boys were more likely to say that someone threatened to hurt them online (Patchin, 2019).']

['What else do you need to know?', 'The effects of cyberbullying are just as harmful as traditional bullying and include the victim feeling frustration, anger, sadness, helplessness, powerlessness, and fear.']
['What else are the victims experiencing?', 'Victims will also experience lower self-esteem (Hoff & Mitchell, 2009; Spears et al., 2009).']

['What else should you know about cyberbullying?', 'Furthermore, recent research suggests that both cyberbullying victims and perpetrators are more likely to experience suicidal ideation, and they are more likely to attempt suicide than individuals who have no experience with cyberbullying (John, 2019).']

['Do people ever file for damages?', 'Cyberbullying is a form of aggression and, depending on the messages and methods, can be considered harassment, stalking, or assault—all subject to prosecution.']

['Is there anything else interesting?', 'Finally, while much of the concern and research regarding cyberbullying centers on adolescents, adults (particularly college students) are frequent victims and perpetrators.']
['What is the Bystander Effect about?', 'The discussion of bullying highlights the problem of witnesses not intervening to help a victim.']
['Who published The Bystander Effect?', 'Researchers Latané and Darley (1968) described a phenomenon called the bystander effect.']
['What is the bystander effect?', 'The bystander effect is a phenomenon in which a witness or bystander does not volunteer to help a victim or person in distress.']
['What is happening to the victim?', 'Instead, they just watch what is happening.']
['Why do they do this?', 'Social psychologists hold that we make these decisions based on the social situation, not our own personality variables.']
['What was the case study?', 'The impetus behind the bystander effect was the murder of a young woman named Kitty Genovese in 1964.']
['What happened after that?', 'The story of her tragic death took on a life of its own when it was reported that none of her neighbors helped her or called the police when she was being attacked.']
['Why did they not?', 'However, Kassin (2017) noted that her killer was apprehended due to neighbors who called the police when they saw him committing a burglary days later.']

['What did Kassin say?', 'Not only did bystanders indeed intervene in her murder (one man who shouted at the killer, a woman who said she called the police, and a friend who comforted her in her last moments), but other bystanders intervened in the capture of the murderer.']
['What was the cause?', 'Social psychologists claim that diffusion of responsibility is the likely explanation.']

['What is the diffusion of responsibility?', 'Diffusion of responsibility is the tendency for no one in a group to help because the responsibility to help is spread throughout the group (Bandura, 1999).']

['What does it mean?', 'Because there were many witnesses to the attack on Genovese, as evidenced by the number of lit apartment windows in the building, individuals assumed someone else must have already called the police.']
['What was the cause of that?', 'The responsibility to call the police was diffused across the number of witnesses to the crime.']
['How does it work?', 'In general, the greater the number of bystanders, the less likely any one person will help.']

['Why are you interested in prosocial behavior?', 'You’ve learned about many of the negative behaviors of social psychology, but the field also studies many positive social interactions and behaviors.']
['What are these?', 'Researchers have documented several features of the situation that influence whether we form relationships with others.']
['What else?', 'There are also universal traits that humans find attractive in others.']

['What is in this section?', 'In this section we discuss conditions that make forming relationships more likely, what we look for in friendships and romantic relationships, the different types of love, and a theory explaining how our relationships are formed, maintained, and terminated.']
['What is prosocial behavior?', 'Voluntary behavior with the intent to help other people is called prosocial behavior.']
['What are some of the reasons why people volunteer?', 'Research suggests there are many other reasons.']
['What is altruism?', 'Altruism is people’s desire to help others even if the costs outweigh the benefits of helping.']
["What's important about altruism?", 'In fact, people acting in altruistic ways may disregard the personal costs associated with helping (Figure 12.26).']

['Did you find an example of altruism in action?', 'For example, news accounts of the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center in New York reported an employee in the first tower helped his co-workers make it to the exit stairwell.']
['What was the person doing when he helped his co-workers?', 'After helping a co-worker to safety he went back in the burning building to help additional co-workers.']
['How did the person react?', 'In this case the costs of helping were great, and the hero lost his life in the destruction (Stewart, 2002).']
['What are some interesting aspects of this study material?', 'Some researchers suggest that altruism operates on empathy.']
['What is empathy?', 'Empathy is the capacity to understand another person’s perspective, to feel what they feel.']
['How does empathy contribute to altruism?', 'An empathetic person makes an emotional connection with others and feels compelled to help (Batson, 1991).']
['What is another interesting point from this article?', 'Other researchers argue that altruism is a form of selfless helping that is not motivated by benefits or feeling good about oneself.']
