['How is this different from the previous view?', 'Certainly, after helping, people feel good about themselves, but some researchers argue that this is a consequence of altruism, not a cause.']

['What is the opposite of altruism?', 'Other researchers argue that helping is always self-serving because our egos are involved, and we receive benefits from helping (Cialdini, Brown, Lewis, Luce, & Neuberg 1997).']
['What else was interesting?', 'It is challenging to determine experimentally the true motivation for helping, whether it is largely self-serving (egoism) or selfless (altruism).']
['What challenge did this pose?', 'Thus, a debate on whether pure altruism exists continues.']
['What can you tell me about the most important relationship you have?', 'You might be surprised to learn that the answer is simple: the people with whom you have the most contact.']
['Is there anything else you can tell me about the most important factor?', 'This most important factor is proximity.']
['What else can you tell me about proximity?', 'You are more likely to be friends with people you have regular contact with.']

['What else can you tell me about proximity?', 'For example, there are decades of research that shows that you are more likely to become friends with people who live in your dorm, your apartment building, or your immediate neighborhood than with people who live farther away (Festinger, Schachler, & Back, 1950).']
['Is there anything else you can tell me about proximity?', 'It is simply easier to form relationships with people you see often because you have the opportunity to get to know them.']
['Why is this important?', 'Similarity is another factor that influences who we form relationships with.']
['Why is that?', 'We are more likely to become friends or lovers with someone who is similar to us in background, attitudes, and lifestyle.']
['What else can you tell me about opposites attract?', 'In fact, there is no evidence that opposites attract.']
['What does the evidence say?', 'Rather, we are attracted to people who are most like us (Figure 12.27) (McPherson, Smith-Lovin, & Cook, 2001).']
['How is that relevant?', 'Sharing things in common will certainly make it easy to get along with others and form connections.']

['What can you tell me about how similarity affects relationships?', 'When you and another person share similar music taste, hobbies, food preferences, and so on, deciding what to do with your time together might be easy.']

['What is homophily?', 'Homophily is the tendency for people to form social networks, including friendships, marriage, business relationships, and many other types of relationships, with others who are similar (McPherson et al., 2001).']
['What are homophily and heterophily?', 'But, homophily limits our exposure to diversity (McPherson et al., 2001).']
['Why is it important to have heterophily?', 'By forming relationships only with people who are similar to us, we will have homogenous groups and will not be exposed to different points of view.']

['Does heterophily mean that we will have a diverse group?', 'In other words, because we are likely to spend time with those who are most like ourselves, we will have limited exposure to those who are different than ourselves, including people of different races, ethnicities, social-economic status, and life situations.']
['What is the topic of the next page?', 'Once we form relationships with people, we desire reciprocity.']
['What is reciprocity?', 'Reciprocity is the give and take in relationships.']
['What is the give and take?', 'We contribute to relationships, but we expect to receive benefits as well.']
['How do we receive benefits?', 'That is, we want our relationships to be a two way street.']
['Why is that?', 'We are more likely to like and engage with people who like us back.']
['What else does it mean to have two way street?', 'Self-disclosure is part of the two way street.']
['What is self-disclosure?', 'Self-disclosure is the sharing of personal information (Laurenceau, Barrett, & Pietromonaco, 1998).']
['What do we do with this personal information?', 'We form more intimate connections with people with whom we disclose important information about ourselves.']

['How does that affect the relationships?', 'Indeed, self-disclosure is a characteristic of healthy intimate relationships, as long as the information disclosed is consistent with our own views (Cozby, 1973).']

['What have you studied?', 'We have discussed how proximity and similarity lead to the formation of relationships, and that reciprocity and self-disclosure are important for relationship maintenance.']
['What is Attraction?', 'Researchers have documented several characteristics that humans find attractive.']
['What are some characteristics that people look for in potential lovers?', 'First we look for friends and lovers who are physically attractive.']
['Are physical characteristics universal?', 'People differ in what they consider attractive, and attractiveness is culturally influenced.']

['What are some universally attractive features?', 'Research, however, suggests that some universally attractive features in women include large eyes, high cheekbones, a narrow jaw line, a slender build (Buss, 1989), and a lower waist-to-hip ratio (Singh, 1993).']
['What are some attractive features for men?', 'For men, attractive traits include being tall, having broad shoulders, and a narrow waist (Buss, 1989).']

['What is the connection between body symmetry and attractiveness?', 'Both men and women with high levels of facial and body symmetry are generally considered more attractive than asymmetric individuals (Fink, Neave, Manning, & Grammer, 2006; Penton-Voak et al., 2001; Rikowski & Grammer, 1999).']

['What are some other characteristics that people look for?', 'Social traits that people find attractive in potential female mates include warmth, affection, and social skills; in males, the attractive traits include achievement, leadership qualities, and job skills (Regan & Berscheid, 1997).']
["What are the characteristics that people don't look for?", 'Although humans want mates who are physically attractive, this does not mean that we look for the most attractive person possible.']

['What does this mean?', 'In fact, this observation has led some to propose what is known as the matching hypothesis which asserts that people tend to pick someone they view as their equal in physical attractiveness and social desirability (Taylor, Fiore, Mendelsohn, & Cheshire, 2011).']
['What can you tell me about this hypothesis?', 'For example, you and most people you know likely would say that a very attractive movie star is out of your league.']
['What does this mean?', 'So, even if you had proximity to that person, you likely would not ask them out on a date because you believe you likely would be rejected.']
['How does this play into the hypothesis?', 'People weigh a potential partner’s attractiveness against the likelihood of success with that person.']

['What does this mean for people?', 'If you think you are particularly unattractive (even if you are not), you likely will seek partners that are fairly unattractive (that is, unattractive in physical appearance or in behavior).']

['What are the three parts of Sternberg’s triangular theory?', 'We typically love the people with whom we form relationships, but the type of love we have for our family, friends, and lovers differs.']
['Who developed the triangular theory?', 'Robert Sternberg (1986) proposed that there are three components of love: intimacy, passion, and commitment.']
['What is the triangle composed of?', 'These three components form a triangle that defines multiple types of love: this is known as Sternberg’s triangular theory of love (Figure 12.28).']
['What is intimacy?', 'Intimacy is the sharing of details and intimate thoughts and emotions.']
['What is passion?', 'Passion is the physical attraction—the flame in the fire.']
['What is commitment?', 'Commitment is standing by the person—the “in sickness and health” part of the relationship.']

['What is the theory?', 'Sternberg (1986) states that a healthy relationship will have all three components of love—intimacy, passion, and commitment—which is described as consummate love (Figure 12.29).']
['What else does Sternberg say?', 'However, different aspects of love might be more prevalent at different life stages.']
['What other aspects of love are there?', 'Other forms of love include liking, which is defined as having intimacy but no passion or commitment.']
['What else is there about liking?', 'Infatuation is the presence of passion without intimacy or commitment.']
['What else is there about empty love?', 'Empty love is having commitment without intimacy or passion.']
['What is the opposite of passion?', 'Companionate love, which is characteristic of close friendships and family relationships, consists of intimacy and commitment but no passion.']
['What is the opposite of commitment?', 'Romantic love is defined by having passion and intimacy, but no commitment.']
['What is the opposite of intimacy?', 'Finally, fatuous love is defined by having passion and commitment, but no intimacy, such as a long term sexual love affair.']
['What is the term social exchange?', 'Social Exchange']
['What is social exchange about?', 'Theory.']
['What else did you study?', 'We have discussed why we form relationships, what attracts us to others, and different types of love.']
['How do people perceive romantic relationships?', 'One theory that provides an explanation is social exchange theory.']

['What else did you study?', 'According to social exchange theory, we act as naïve economists in keeping a tally of the ratio of costs and benefits of forming and maintaining a relationship with others (Figure 12.30) (Rusbult & Van Lange, 2003).']
['What is Sternberg’s Triangular Theory of Love?', 'People are motivated to maximize the benefits of social exchanges, or relationships, and minimize the costs.']

['What else is interesting?', 'People prefer to have more benefits than costs, or to have nearly equal costs and benefits, but most people are dissatisfied if their social exchanges create more costs than benefits.']
['What was the biggest takeaway from this?', 'Let’s discuss an example.']
['What did the example demonstrate?', 'If you have ever decided to commit to a romantic relationship, you probably considered the advantages and disadvantages of your decision.']
['What other factors do you consider in the decision?', 'You may have considered having companionship, intimacy, and passion, but also being comfortable with a person you know well.']

['Why is the relationship painful?', 'You may think that over time boredom from being with only one person may set in; moreover, it may be expensive to share activities such as attending movies and going to dinner.']
['What else did you like about this article?', 'However, the benefits of dating your romantic partner presumably outweigh the costs, or you wouldn’t continue the relationship.']

['What other information do you need to know to answer the question?', 'In 2019, people who worked in the United States spent an average of about 42–54 hours per week working (Bureau of Labor Statistics—U.S. Department of Labor, 2019).']
['What other activities do they spend time doing?', 'Sleeping was the only other activity they spent more time on with an average of about 43–62 hours per week.']
['What is interesting about this information?', 'The workday is a significant portion of workers’ time and energy.']
['What else does it influence them to do?', 'It impacts their lives and their family’s lives in positive and negative physical and psychological ways.']

['What is industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Industrial and organizational (I-O) psychology is a branch of psychology that studies how human behavior and psychology affect work and how they are affected by work.']

['what type of contexts do industrial and organizational psychologists work in?', 'Industrial and organizational psychologists work in four main contexts: academia, government, consulting firms, and business.']
['What type of education does a industrial and organizational psychologist need?', 'Most I-O psychologists have a master’s or doctorate degree.']

['What other types of fields are related to industrial and organizational psychology?', 'The field of I-O psychology can be divided into three broad areas (Figure 13.2 and Figure 13.3): industrial, organizational, and human factors.']

['What is the biggest contribution to industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Industrial psychology is concerned with describing job requirements and assessing individuals for their ability to meet those requirements.']

['What other fields does industrial and organizational psychology focus on?', 'In addition, once employees are hired, industrial psychology studies and develops ways to train, evaluate, and respond to those evaluations.']

['What are the legal aspects of industrial and organizational psychology?', 'As a consequence of its concern for candidate characteristics, industrial psychology must also consider issues of legality regarding discrimination in hiring.']
['What is organization psychology?', 'Organizational psychology is a discipline interested in how the relationships among employees affect those employees and the performance of a business.']
['What type of research does organization psychology focus on?', 'This includes studying worker satisfaction, motivation, and commitment.']

['What else does organization psychology study?', 'This field also studies management, leadership, and organizational culture, as well as how an organization’s structures, management and leadership styles, social norms, and role expectations affect individual behavior.']

['Are there any other subjects that organization psychology studies?', 'As a result of its interest in worker wellbeing and relationships, organizational psychology also considers the subjects of harassment, including sexual harassment, and workplace violence.']

['What is human factors psychology?', 'Human factors psychology is the study of how workers interact with the tools of work and how to design those tools to optimize workers’ productivity, safety, and health.']

['What else can you tell me about human factors psychology?', 'These studies can involve interactions as straightforward as the fit of a desk, chair, and computer to a human having to sit on the chair at the desk using the computer for several hours each day.']
['What else can you tell me about human factors?', 'They can also include the examination of how humans interact with complex displays and their ability to interpret them accurately and quickly.']
['What is ergonomics?', 'In Europe, this field is referred to as ergonomics.']
['What is occupational health psychology?', 'Occupational health psychology (OHP) deals with the stress, diseases, and disorders that can affect employees as a result of the workplace.']

['What is the difference between occupational health psychology and organizational psychology?', 'As such, the field is informed by research from the medical, biological, psychological, organizational, human factors, human resources, and industrial fields.']

['What are the things that occupational health psychology and organizational psychology do?', 'Individuals in this field seek to examine the ways in which the organization affects the quality of work life for an employee and the responses that employees have towards their organization or as a result of their organization’s influence on them.']

['How does it impact their overall life?', 'The responses for employees are not limited to the workplace as there may be some spillover into their personal lives outside of work, especially if there is not good work-life balance.']

['What does occupational health psychology aim to do?', 'The ultimate goal of an occupational health psychologist is to improve the overall health and well-being of an individual, and, as a result, increase the overall health of the organization (Society for Occupational Health Psychology, 2020).']
['When was HWP developed?', 'In 2009, the field of humanitarian work psychology (HWP) was developed as the brainchild of a small group of I-O psychologists who met at a conference.']

['How did the group work together?', 'Realizing they had a shared set of goals involving helping those who are underserved and underprivileged, the I-O psychologists formally formed the group in 2012 and have approximately 300 members worldwide.']
['What were the goals of the group?', 'Although this is a small number, the group continues to expand.']
['What do they help people with?', 'The group seeks to help marginalized members of society, such as people with low-income, find work.']
['What other benefits does the group provide?', 'In addition, they help to determine ways to deliver humanitarian aid during major catastrophes.']

['What else can the group do?', 'The Humanitarian Work Psychology group can also reach out to those in the local community who do not have the knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) to be able to find gainful employment that would enable them to not need to receive aid.']

['How else does the group help people?', 'In both cases, humanitarian work psychologists try to help the underserved individuals develop KSAs that they can use to improve their lives and their current situations.']

['What is the focus of their work?', 'When ensuring these underserved individuals receive training or education, the focus is on skills that, once learned, will never be forgotten and can serve individuals throughout their lifetimes as they seek employment (APA, 2016).']
['What is a field in I-O psychology?', 'Table 13.1 summarizes the main fields in I-O psychology, their focuses, and jobs within each field.']
['When did this development start?', 'Industrial and organizational psychology had its origins in the early 20th century.']

['Who were the early psychologists?', 'Several influential early psychologists studied issues that today would be categorized as industrial psychology: James Cattell (1860–1944), Hugo Münsterberg (1863–1916), Walter Dill Scott (1869–1955), Robert Yerkes (1876–1956), Walter Bingham (1880–1952), and Lillian Gilbreth (1878–1972).']
['Who influenced them?', 'Cattell, Münsterberg, and Scott had been students of Wilhelm Wundt, the father of experimental psychology.']
['What was their biggest contribution?', 'Some of these researchers had been involved in work in the area of industrial psychology before World War I.']

['What was his main contribution?', 'Cattell’s contribution to industrial psychology is largely reflected in his founding of a psychological consulting company, which is still operating today called the Psychological Corporation, and in the accomplishments of students at Columbia in the area of industrial psychology.']

['What was his most famous work?', 'In 1913, Münsterberg published Psychology and Industrial Efficiency, which covered topics such as employee selection, employee training, and effective advertising.']
['Who was Scott?', 'Scott was one of the first psychologists to apply psychology to advertising, management, and personnel selection.']
['What year did this take place?', 'In 1903, Scott published two books: The Theory of Advertising and Psychology of Advertising.']
['How was he successful?', 'They are the first books to describe the use of psychology in the business world.']
['What else did he do?', 'By 1911 he published two more books, Influencing Men in Business and Increasing Human Efficiency in Business.']
['What else did he do?', 'In 1916 a newly formed division in the Carnegie Institute of Technology hired Scott to conduct applied research on employee selection (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

["What's the most interesting part of this document?", 'The focus of all this research was in what we now know as industrial psychology; it was only later in the century that the field of organizational psychology developed as an experimental science (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']
['What are some other interesting parts of the document?', 'In addition to their academic positions, these researchers also worked directly for businesses as consultants.']

['What is the history of industrial psychology?', 'When the United States entered World War I in April 1917, the work of psychologists working in this discipline expanded to include their contributions to military efforts.']
['Who is Richard Yerkes?', 'At that time Yerkes was the president of the 25-year-old American Psychological Association (APA).']
['What is the American Psychological Association?', 'The APA is a professional association in the United States for clinical and research psychologists.']
['How do they represent the field?', 'Today the APA performs a number of functions including holding conferences, accrediting university degree programs, and publishing scientific journals.']
['What kind of work did he do?', 'Yerkes organized a group under the Surgeon General’s Office (SGO) that developed methods for screening and selecting enlisted men.']
['Did he have any successful tests?', 'They developed the Army Alpha test to measure mental abilities.']
['Was there any other tests?', 'The Army Beta test was a non-verbal form of the test that was administered to illiterate and non-English-speaking draftees.']
['Who else was involved?', 'Scott and Bingham organized a group under the Adjutant General’s Office (AGO) with the goal to develop selection methods for officers.']

['What was their project?', 'They created a catalogue of occupational needs for the Army, essentially a job-description system and a system of performance ratings and occupational skill tests for officers (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']
['Was it successful?', 'After the war, work on personnel selection continued.']

['Did they test anything?', 'For example, Millicent Pond researched the selection of factory workers, comparing the results of pre-employment tests with various indicators of job performance (Vinchur & Koppes, 2014).']

["What's important about the development?", 'From 1929 to 1932 Elton Mayo (1880–1949) and his colleagues began a series of studies at a plant near Chicago, Western Electric’s Hawthorne Works (Figure 13.4).']

['What did they study?', 'This long-term project took industrial psychology beyond just employee selection and placement to a study of more complex problems of interpersonal relations, motivation, and organizational dynamics.']
['What was significant about these studies?', 'These studies mark the origin of organizational psychology.']

['Why did he focus on psychological factors?', 'They began as research into the effects of the physical work environment (e.g., level of lighting in a factory), but the researchers found that the psychological and social factors in the factory were of more interest than the physical factors.']
['What did his studies include?', 'These studies also examined how human interaction factors, such as supervisorial style, increased or decreased productivity.']

['What is important about the Hawthorne effect?', 'Analysis of the findings by later researchers led to the term the Hawthorne effect, which describes the increase in performance of individuals who are aware they are being observed by researchers or supervisors (Figure 13.5).']

['What did the Hawthorne effect find?', 'What the original researchers found was that any change in a variable, such as lighting levels, led to an improvement in productivity; this was true even when the change was negative, such as a return to poor lighting.']
['How did Hawthorne effect work?', 'The effect faded when the attention faded (Roethlisberg & Dickson, 1939).']

['What did the Hawthorne effect do?', 'The Hawthorne-effect concept endures today as an important experimental consideration in many fields and a factor that has to be controlled for in an experiment.']

['How else is Hawthorne effect used?', 'In other words, an experimental treatment of some kind may produce an effect simply because it involves greater attention of the researchers on the participants (McCarney et al., 2007).']
['What did industrial and organizational psychology study?', 'In the 1930s, researchers began to study employees’ feelings about their jobs.']

['What other aspects of industrial and organizational psychology did it study?', 'Kurt Lewin also conducted research on the effects of various leadership styles, team structure, and team dynamics (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['Who was Kurt Lewin?', 'Lewin is considered the founder of social psychology and much of his work and that of his students produced results that had important influences in organizational psychology.']

['What else was Lewin known for?', 'Lewin and his students’ research included an important early study that used children to study the effect of leadership style on aggression, group dynamics, and satisfaction (Lewin, Lippitt, & White, 1939).']

['What else did Lewin do?', 'Lewin was also responsible for coining the term group dynamics, and he was involved in studies of group interactions, cooperation, competition, and communication that bear on organizational psychology.']

['Did any of the individuals or institutions mentioned above participate in influencing the development of industrial and organizational', 'Parallel to these studies in industrial and organizational psychology, the field of human factors psychology was also developing.']

['Did one person have the biggest impact on this development?', 'Frederick Taylor was an engineer who saw that if one could redesign the workplace there would be an increase in both output for the company and wages for the workers.']
['What is the name of his work?', 'In 1911 he put forward his theory in a book titled, The Principles of Scientific Management (Figure 13.6).']
['What did his book have to do with industrial psychology?', 'His book examines management theories, personnel selection and training, as well as the work itself, using time and motion studies.']
['What else was Taylor known for?', 'Taylor argued that the principle goal of management should be to make the most money for the employer, along with the best outcome for the employee.']

['What did he believe the best outcome was?', 'He believed that the best outcome for the employee and management would be achieved through training and development so that each employee could provide the best work.']
['What else did he do?', 'He believed that by conducting time and motion studies for both the organization and the employee, the best interests of both were addressed.']
['What was the meaning of time and motion studies?', 'Time-motion studies were methods aimed to improve work by dividing different types of operations into sections that could be measured.']
['What was the use of this data?', 'These analyses were used to standardize work and to check the efficiency of people and equipment.']
['What is personnel selection?', 'Personnel selection is a process used by recruiting personnel within the company to recruit and select the best candidates for the job.']
['What else does personnel selection have to do with training?', 'Training may need to be conducted depending on what skills the hired candidate has.']
['Why is this?', 'Often companies will hire someone with the personality that fits in with others but who may be lacking in skills.']
['Does this make a difference in the selection process?', 'Skills can be taught, but personality cannot be easily changed.']
['What was one of the examples of Taylor’s theory in action?', 'One of the examples of Taylor’s theory in action involved workers handling heavy iron ingots.']
['How did Taylor get these workers to work more efficiently?', 'Taylor showed that the workers could be more productive by taking work rests.']

['How did his idea benefit them?', 'This method of rest increased worker productivity from 12.5 to 47.0 tons moved per day with less reported fatigue as well as increased wages for the workers who were paid by the ton.']
["How was the company's cost reduced?", 'At the same time, the company’s cost was reduced from 9.2 cents to 3.9 cents per ton.']

['Why was the workers not as happy with their work as before?', 'Despite these increases in productivity, Taylor’s theory received a great deal of criticism at the time because it was believed that it would exploit workers and reduce the number of workers needed.']

['What else did people think about his theory?', 'Also controversial was the underlying concept that only a manager could determine the most efficient method of working, and that while at work, a worker was incapable of this.']

['Why was this theory controversial?', 'Taylor’s theory was underpinned by the notion that a worker was fundamentally lazy and the goal of Taylor’s scientific management approach was to maximize productivity without much concern for worker well-being.']
['Who was criticizing his theory?', 'His approach was criticized by unions and those sympathetic to workers (Van De Water, 1997).']
['What happened to Gilbreth?', 'Gilbreth was another influential I-O psychologist who strove to find ways to increase productivity (Figure 13.7).']

['What was her study on productivity?', 'Using time and motion studies, Gilbreth and her husband, Frank, worked to make workers more efficient by reducing the number of motions required to perform a task.']
['How did she apply these methods to the workplace?', 'She not only applied these methods to industry but also to the home, office, shops, and other areas.']
['What were the results of these experiments?', 'She investigated employee fatigue and time management stress and found many employees were motivated by money and job satisfaction.']

['Did she have any publications?', 'In 1914, Gilbreth wrote the book title, The Psychology of Management: The Function of the Mind in Determining, Teaching, and Installing Methods of Least Waste, and she is known as the mother of modern management.']

['Did she develop other methods of increasing productivity?', 'Some of Gilbreth’s contributions are still in use today: you can thank her for the idea to put shelves inside on refrigerator doors, and she also came up with the concept of using a foot pedal to operate the lid of trash can (Gilbreth, 1914, 1998; Koppes, 1997; Lancaster, 2004).']

['Did she receive any recognition?', 'Gilbreth was the first woman to join the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in 1926, and in 1966 she was awarded the Hoover Medal of the American Society of Civil Engineers.']
['What was the impact of Taylor and Gilbreth?', 'Taylor and Gilbreth’s work improved productivity, but these innovations also improved the fit between technology and the human using it.']
['How is this study known?', 'The study of machine–human fit is known as ergonomics or human factors psychology.']
['What did World War II lead to?', 'World War II also drove the expansion of industrial psychology.']

['What was the expansion of industrial psychology?', 'Bingham was hired as the chief psychologist for the War Department (now the Department of Defense) and developed new systems for job selection, classification, training, ad performance review, plus methods for team development, morale change, and attitude change  (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['Where else did industrial psychology expand?', 'Other countries, such as Canada and the United Kingdom, likewise saw growth in I-O psychology during World War II (McMillan, Stevens, & Kelloway, 2009).']
['Did research occur after WWII?', 'In the years after the war, both industrial psychology and organizational psychology became areas of significant research effort.']
['Did the research lead to positive results?', 'Concerns about the fairness of employment tests arose, and the ethnic and gender biases in various tests were evaluated with mixed results.']
['What else happened after WWII?', 'In addition, a great deal of research went into studying job satisfaction and employee motivation (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']
['What year was this?', 'The research and work of I-O psychologists in the areas of employee selection, placement, and performance appraisal became increasingly important in the 1960s.']
['Did the civil rights act help them with this?', 'When Congress passed the 1964 Civil Rights Act, Title VII covered what is known as equal employment opportunity.']

['What was equal employment opportunity?', 'This law protects employees against discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin, as well as discrimination against an employee for associating with an individual in one of these categories.']

['What is an important thing to know about this article?', 'There are many reasons for organizations to be interested in I/O so that they can better understand the psychology of their workers, which in turn helps them understand how their organizations can become more productive and competitive.']

['What are some of the reasons?', 'For example, most large organizations are now competing on a global level, and they need to understand how to motivate workers in order to achieve high productivity and efficiency.']
['Why do they need to understand diversity?', 'Most companies also have a diverse workforce and need to understand the psychological complexity of the people in these diverse backgrounds.']
['What was the Civil Rights Movement?', 'Today, I-O psychology is a diverse and deep field of research and practice, as you will learn about in the rest of this chapter.']

['What was the field of research and practice?', 'The Society for Industrial and Organizational Psychology (SIOP), a division of the APA, lists 8,000 members (SIOP, 2014) and the Bureau of Labor Statistics—U.S. Department of Labor (2013) has projected this profession will have the greatest growth of all job classifications in the 20 years following 2012.']

['Was this a popular field?', 'On average, a person with a master’s degree in industrial-organizational psychology will earn over $80,000 a year, while someone with a doctorate will earn over $110,000 a year (Khanna, Medsker, & Ginter, 2012).']
['What is industrial psychology?', 'The branch of I-O psychology known as industrial psychology focuses on identifying and matching persons to tasks within an organization.']
['What does this involve?', 'This involves job analysis, which means accurately describing the task or job.']
['What are these characteristics?', 'Then, organizations must identify the characteristics of applicants for a match to the job analysis.']
['What else does it involve?', 'It also involves training employees from their first day on the job throughout their tenure within the organization, and appraising their performance along the way.']
['What is it about?', 'Often, this is done with the help of I-O psychologists.']
['What are the results of this?', 'There are two related but different approaches to job analysis—you may be familiar with the results of each as they often appear on the same job advertisement.']
['What is one of the different approaches?', 'The first approach is task-oriented and lists in detail the tasks that will be performed for the job.']
['What is done after that?', 'Each task is typically rated on scales for how frequently it is performed, how difficult it is, and how important it is to the job.']
['Who does this?', 'The second approach is worker-oriented.']
['What is this about?', 'This approach describes the characteristics required of the worker to successfully perform the job.']
['What is this called?', 'This second approach has been called job specification (Dierdorff & Wilson, 2003).']
['What is a KSA?', 'For job specification, the knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) that the job requires are identified.']
['What is the purpose of a job analysis?', 'Observation, surveys, and interviews are used to obtain the information required for both types of job analysis.']
['What are some examples of observation?', 'It is possible to observe someone who is proficient in a position and analyze what skills are apparent.']

['What are some examples of surveys?', 'Another approach used is to interview people presently holding that position, their peers, and their supervisors to get a consensus of what they believe are the requirements of the job.']
["What can the description have to do with an employee's motivation?", 'Research suggests that it can depend on the nature of the descriptions and the source for the job analysis.']

['Is there any evidence of that?', 'For example, Dierdorff & Wilson (2003) found that job analyses developed from descriptions provided by people holding the job themselves were the least reliable; however, they did not study or speculate why this was the case.']
['What is the DOL?', 'The United States Department of Labor maintains a database of previously compiled job analyses for different jobs and occupations.']
['What else is interesting about this section?', 'This allows the I-O psychologist to access previous analyses for nearly any type of occupation.']
['What is the O*Net?', 'This system is called O*Net (accessible at www.onetonline.org).']
['How does the O*Net work?', 'The site is open and you can see the KSAs that are listed for your own position or one you might be curious about  (Figure 13.8).']

['What does this information provide?', 'Each occupation lists the tasks, knowledge, skills, abilities, work context, work activities, education requirements, interests, personality requirements, and work styles that are deemed necessary for success in that position.']
['What else can you find on this site?', 'You can also see data on average earnings and projected job growth in that industry.']

['What is Candidate Analysis and Testing?', 'Once a company identifies potential candidates for a position, the candidates’ knowledge, skills, and other abilities must be evaluated and compared with the job description.']
['What can be done to evaluate these candidates?', 'These evaluations can involve testing, an interview, and work samples or exercises.']

['What can the interviews involve?', 'You learned about personality tests in the chapter on personality; in the I-O context, they are used to identify the personality characteristics of the candidate in an effort to match those to personality characteristics that would ensure good performance on the job.']
['How do you match the candidates with the jobs?', 'For example, a high rating of agreeableness might be desirable in a customer support position.']
['What kind of rating would this give you?', 'However, it is not always clear how best to correlate personality characteristics with predictions of job performance.']
["Why isn't it clear how to correlate them?", 'It might be that too high of a score on agreeableness is actually a hindrance in the customer support position.']
['What is a hindrance?', 'For example, if a customer has a misperception about a product or service, agreeing with their misperception will not ultimately lead to resolution of their complaint.']

['What else can you tell me about the test?', 'Any use of personality tests should be accompanied by a verified assessment of what scores on the test correlate with good performance (Arthur, Woehr, & Graziano, 2001).']
['What other tests can be used?', 'Other types of tests that may be given to candidates include IQ tests, integrity tests, and physical tests, such as drug tests or physical fitness tests.']
['What else does this material include?', 'To better understand the hiring process, let’s consider an example case.']
['What happened in the example case?', 'A company determined it had an open position and advertised it.']
['What happened after the advertisement?', 'The human resources (HR) manager directed the hiring team to start the recruitment process.']
['What did the HR manager do next?', 'Imani saw the advertisement and submitted her résumé, which went into the collection of candidate résumés.']

['How did the HR manager analyze and test her?', 'The HR team reviewed the candidates’ credentials and provided a list of the best potential candidates to the department manager, who reached out to them (including Imani) to set up individual interviews.']
['What are interviews?', 'Most jobs for mid-size to large-size businesses in the United States require a personal interview as a step in the selection process.']
['What are the advantages of interviews?', 'Because interviews are commonly used, they have been the subject of considerable research by industrial psychologists.']
['What is the purpose of interviewing?', 'Information derived from job analysis usually forms the basis for the types of questions asked.']
['What is the benefit of interviews?', 'Interviews can provide a more dynamic source of information about the candidate than standard testing measures.']
['What is the downside of interviews?', 'Importantly, social factors and body language can influence the outcome of the interview.']

['What is the social factor?', 'These include influences, such as the degree of similarity of the applicant to the interviewer and nonverbal behaviors, such as hand gestures, head nodding, and smiling (Bye, Horverak, Sandal, Sam, & Vivjer, 2014; Rakić, Steffens, & Mummendey, 2011).']
['what are interviews?', 'There are two types of interviews: unstructured and structured.']
['what are unstructured interviews?', 'In an unstructured interview, the interviewer may ask different questions of each different candidate.']
['what kind of questions?', 'One candidate might be asked about her career goals, and another might be asked about his previous work experience.']
['how are the questions asked?', 'In an unstructured interview, the questions are often, though not always, unspecified beforehand.']
['how are the responses scored?', 'And in an unstructured interview the responses to questions asked are generally not scored using a standard system.']

['what are structured interviews?', 'In a structured interview, the interviewer asks the same questions of every candidate, the questions are prepared in advance, and the interviewer uses a standardized rating system for each response.']
['what is the rating system?', 'With this approach, the interviewer can accurately compare two candidates’ interviews.']

['did he do a lot of research?', 'In a meta-analysis of studies examining the effectiveness of various types of job interviews, McDaniel, Whetzel, Schmidt & Maurer (1994) found that structured interviews were more effective at predicting subsequent job performance of the job candidate.']
['What is an interview?', 'Let’s return to our example case.']
['What did she do for her first interview?', 'For her first interview, Imani was interviewed by a team of employees at the company.']
['Why did they want to hire her?', 'She was one of five candidates interviewed that day for the position.']
['How was the interview conducted?', 'Each interviewee was asked the same list of questions, by the same people, so the interview experience was as consistent as possible across applicants.']
['How long was the interview?', 'At the end of the interviews, the HR team met and reviewed the answers given by Imani and the other candidates.']

['Who else was interviewed?', 'The HR team then identified a few new qualified candidates and conducted a new round of initial interviews, while the first group of potential hires waited to hear back from the company.']
['What is Training?', 'Training is an important element of success and performance in many jobs.']

['What is an example of training?', 'Most jobs begin with an orientation period during which the new employee is provided information regarding the company history, policies, and administrative protocols such as time tracking, benefits, and reporting requirements.']

['What is the orientation period about?', 'An important goal of orientation training is to educate the new employee about the organizational culture, the values, visions, hierarchies, norms and ways the company’s employees interact—essentially how the organization is run, how it operates, and how it makes decisions.']

['What else is training about?', 'There will also be training that is specific to the job the individual was hired to do, or training during the individual’s period of employment that teaches aspects of new duties, or how to use new physical or software tools.']

['How is it conducted?', 'Much of these kinds of training will be formalized for the employee; for example, orientation training is often accomplished using software presentations, group presentations by members of the human resources department or with people in the new hire’s department (Figure 13.9).']
['What is mentoring?', 'Mentoring is a form of informal training in which an experienced employee guides the work of a new employee.']
['How does mentoring work?', 'In some situations, mentors will be formally assigned to a new employee, while in others a mentoring relationship may develop informally.']
['What else did we learn in Training?', 'Mentoring effects on the mentor and the employee being mentored, the protégé, have been studied in recent years.']

['What other studies have been done?', 'In a review of mentoring studies, Eby, Allen, Evans, Ng, & DuBois (2008) found significant but small effects of mentoring on performance (i.e., behavioral outcomes), motivation and satisfaction, and actual career outcomes.']

['How did that study help?', 'In a more detailed review, Allen, Eby, Poteet, Lentz, & Lima (2004) found that mentoring positively affected a protégé’s compensation and number of promotions compared with non-mentored employees.']
['How else was it beneficial?', 'In addition, protégés were more satisfied with their careers and had greater job satisfaction.']
['Did these studies show a positive effect?', 'All of the effects were small but significant.']

['What else did we learn?', 'Eby, Durley, Evans, & Ragins (2006) examined mentoring effects on the mentor and found that mentoring was associated with greater job satisfaction and organizational commitment.']
['Did there any other studies?', 'Gentry, Weber, & Sadri (2008) found that mentoring was positively related with performance ratings by supervisors.']
['What else was found?', 'Allen, Lentz, & Day (2006) found in a comparison of mentors and non-mentors that mentoring led to greater reported salaries and promotions.']

['What was the research?', 'Researchers have worked to understand the impacts of gender, race, and ethnicity on mentoring relationships,  especially whether outcomes differ based on the gender or racial/ethnic makeup of the mentor-mentee pair.']

['What was the result?', 'Overall, women and members of underrepresented racial/ethnic populations do not lack access to mentors, but they do lack access to mentors of the same gender, race, and ethnicity, because the senior roles in many organizations are made up of White men (MLDC, 2010).']

['What were the results of the mentoring?', 'Results from these studies are mixed, but generally suggest that pairings made up of two people of the same gender or race/ethnicity have better psychosocial outcomes, such as a feeling of more support (Koberg, Boss, & Goodman, 1998; Allen et al, 2006).']

['What was more important?', 'On the other hand, women and people of color typically experience greater career advancement or higher pay when mentored by people of a different gender or race/ethnicity (Parks-Yancy, 2012).']
['What is another aspect of mentoring?', 'A 2003 study by Arthur, Bennett, Edens, and Bell examined multiple other studies to determine how effective organizational training is.']

['What is a measure of how effective it was?', 'Their results showed that training was effective, based on four types of measurement: (1) the immediate response of the employee to the training effort, (2) testing at the end of training to demonstrate that learning outcomes were met, (3) behavioral measurements of job activities by supervisors, and (4) results such as productivity and profits.']
['What types of training were studied?', 'The examined studies represented diverse forms of training including self-instruction, lecture and discussion, and computer assisted training.']
['What does that mean?', 'Industrial and organizational psychologists are typically involved in designing performance-appraisal systems for organizations.']
['What do they evaluate?', 'These systems are designed to evaluate whether each employee is performing satisfactorily.']

['How are they evaluated?', 'Industrial and organizational psychologists study, research, and implement ways to make work evaluations as fair and positive as possible; they also work to decrease the subjectivity involved with performance ratings.']

['What does being evaluated do for them?', 'Fairly evaluated work helps employees do their jobs better, improves the likelihood of people being in the right jobs for their talents, maintains fairness, and identifies company and individual training needs.']
['What did you find out during your study?', 'In our example case, Imani was offered the position and was hired with a 90-day probation period.']
['What did the probation period entail?', 'During that time, she met with her supervisor to discuss her performance and the expectations of the position and her growth.']
['What were the results of their discussions?', 'At the end of the 90 days, it was determined that Imani was meeting the expectations of her employer and had passed her probationary period.']
['What did she do at the end of her probation?', 'Imani was excited to now have a permanent job.']

['What does the content discuss?', 'Performance appraisals are typically documented several times a year, often with a formal process and an annual face-to-face brief meeting between an employee and their supervisor.']

['what else does it discuss?', 'It is important that the original job analysis play a role in performance appraisal as well as any goals that have been set by the employee or by the employee and supervisor.']

['what else does the article cover?', 'The meeting is often used for the supervisor to communicate specific concerns about the employee’s performance and to positively reinforce elements of good performance.']
['what else is discussed in the article?', 'It may also be used to discuss specific performance rewards, such as a pay increase, or consequences of poor performance, such as a probationary period.']
['do they also discuss firing the employee?', 'Part of the function of performance appraisals for the organization is to document poor performance to bolster decisions to terminate an employee.']

['What does evaluating employees refer to?', 'Performance appraisals are becoming more complex processes within organizations and are often used to motivate employees to improve performance and expand their areas of competence, in addition to assessing their job performance.']

['What can performance appraisals be used to assess?', 'In this capacity, performance appraisals can be used to identify opportunities for training or whether a particular training program has been successful.']
['What is 360 degree feedback appraisal?', 'One approach to performance appraisal is called 360-degree feedback appraisal (Figure 13.10).']

['Why is 360 degree feedback appraisal different?', 'In this system, the employee’s appraisal derives from a combination of ratings by supervisors, peers, employees supervised by the employee, and from the employee herself.']
['Do other people give ratings as well?', 'Occasionally, outside observers may be used as well, such as customers.']

['How is 360 degree feedback appraisal different?', 'The purpose of 360-degree system is to give the employee (who may be a manager) and supervisor different perspectives of the employee’s job performance; the system should help employees make improvements through their own efforts or through training.']

['How is 360 degree feedback appraisal used?', 'The system is also used in a traditional performance-appraisal context, providing the supervisor with more information with which to make decisions about the employee’s position and compensation (Tornow, 1993a).']

['What is 360-degree evaluation?', 'Few studies have assessed the effectiveness of 360-degree methods, but Atkins and Wood (2002) found that the self and peer ratings were unreliable as an assessment of an employee’s performance and that even supervisors tended to underrate employees that gave themselves modest feedback ratings.']

['What can you tell me about the studies about this evaluation?', 'However, a different perspective sees this variability in ratings as a positive in that it provides for greater learning on the part of the employees as they and their supervisor discuss the reasons for the discrepancies (Tornow, 1993b).']

['What does evaluating employees refer to?', 'In theory, performance appraisals should be an asset for an organization wishing to achieve its goals, and most employees will actually solicit feedback regarding their jobs if it is not offered (DeNisi & Kluger, 2000).']

['Does this theory work in practice?', 'However, in practice, many performance evaluations are disliked by organizations, employees, or both (Fletcher, 2001), and few of them have been adequately tested to see if they do in fact improve performance or motivate employees (DeNisi & Kluger, 2000).']

['What are some of the problems with evaluating employees?', 'One of the reasons evaluations fail to accomplish their purpose in an organization is that performance appraisal systems are often used incorrectly or are of an inappropriate type for an organization’s particular culture (Schraeder, Becton, & Portis, 2007).']
['What is an organization’s culture?', 'An organization’s culture is how the organization is run, how it operates, and how it makes decisions.']
['What does it consist of?', 'It is based on the collective values, hierarchies, and how individuals within the organization interact.']

['How can organizations combat this problem?', 'Examining the effectiveness of performance appraisal systems in particular organizations and the effectiveness of training for the implementation of the performance appraisal system is an active area of research in industrial psychology (Fletcher, 2001).']
['What is a bias?', 'In an ideal hiring process, an organization would generate a job analysis that accurately reflects the requirements of the position, and it would accurately assess candidates’']
["skills and qualities (which is not an exact science, it's a broad term),", 'KSAs to determine who the best individual is to carry out the job’s requirements.']
['How can you be sure?', 'For many reasons, hiring decisions in the real world are often made based on factors other than matching a job analysis to KSAs.']

['Why might the other factor be influenced?', 'As mentioned earlier, interview rankings can be influenced by other factors: similarity to the interviewer (Bye, Horverak, Sandal, Sam, & Vijver, 2014) and the regional accent of the interviewee (Rakić, Steffens, & Mummendey 2011).']
['Who are the studies?', 'A study by Agerström & Rooth (2011) examined hiring managers’ decisions to invite equally qualified non-obese and obese job applicants to an interview.']
['How was it assessed?', 'The decisions of the hiring managers were based on photographs of the two applicants.']

['What did they find?', 'The study found that hiring managers that scored high on a test of negative associations with overweight people displayed a bias in favor of inviting the equally qualified non-obese applicant but not inviting the obese applicant.']

['How does the association test work?', 'The association test measures automatic or subconscious associations between an individual’s negative or positive values and, in this case, the body-size attribute.']

['What is the most important piece of evidence?', 'A meta-analysis of experimental studies found that physical attractiveness benefited individuals in various job-related outcomes such as hiring, promotion, and performance review (Hosoda, Stone-Romero, & Coats, 2003).']
['Who else is involved?', 'They also found that the strength of the benefit appeared to be decreasing with time between the late 1970s and the late 1990s.']
['What is bias and protections?', 'Some hiring criteria may be related to a particular group an applicant belongs to and not individual abilities.']
['What can be done about it?', 'Unless membership in that group directly affects potential job performance, a decision based on group membership is discriminatory (Figure 13.11).']

['What else can be done to combat discrimination?', 'To combat hiring discrimination, in the United States there are numerous city, state, and federal laws that prevent hiring based on various group-membership criteria.']
['What are some restrictions?', 'They cannot even ask questions that might shed some light on these attributes, such as where you were born or who you live with.']
['What else are restrictions?', 'These are only a few of the restrictions that are in place to prevent discrimination in hiring.']
['How are these laws enforced?', 'In the United States, federal anti-discrimination laws are administered by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC).']

['What is the EEOC?', "The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) is responsible for enforcing federal laws that make it illegal to discriminate against a job applicant or an employee because of the person's race, color, religion, sex (including pregnancy), sexual orientation, national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information."]
['Did they give any examples of the laws that were passed?', 'Figure 13.12 provides some of the legal language from laws that have been passed to prevent discrimination.']
['What is this about?', 'The United States has several specific laws regarding fairness and avoidance of discrimination.']
['What is one of those laws?', 'The Equal Pay Act requires that equal pay for men and women in the same workplace who are performing equal work.']
['What do they say about equal pay?', 'Despite the law, persistent inequities in earnings between men and women exist.']
['What did they study?', 'Corbett & Hill (2012) studied one facet of the gender gap by looking at earnings in the first year after college in the United States.']
['What did they find?', 'Just comparing the earnings of women to men, women earn about 82 cents for every dollar a man earns in their first year out of college.']

['What is equal pay?', 'However, some of this difference can be explained by education, career, and life choices, such as choosing majors with lower earning potential or specific jobs within a field that have less responsibility.']

['Are there any other factors that come into play?', 'When these factors were corrected the study found an unexplained seven-cents-on-the-dollar gap in the first year after college that can be attributed to gender discrimination in pay.']
['What are some other studies?', 'This approach to analysis of the gender pay gap, called the human capital model, has been criticized.']
['What else was found?', 'Lips (2013) argues that the education, career, and life choices can, in fact, be constrained by necessities imposed by gender discrimination.']
['What does she say?', 'This suggests that removing these factors entirely from the gender gap equation leads to an estimate of the size of the pay gap that is too small.']
['What are some of the topics in this chapter?', 'Act of 1964 makes it illegal to treat individuals unfavorably because of their race or color of their skin:']

['What happens when the act is violated?', 'An employer cannot discriminate based on skin color, hair texture, or other immutable characteristics, which are traits of an individual that are fundamental to their identity, in hiring, benefits, promotions, or termination of employees.']
['What other topics do they cover?', 'The Pregnancy Discrimination']

['What does this do?', 'Act of 1978 amends the Civil Rights Act; it prohibits job (e.g., employment, pay, and termination) discrimination of a woman because she is pregnant as long as she can perform the work required.']
['Did this make it illegal?', 'The Supreme Court ruling in Griggs v. Duke Power Co. made it illegal under Title VII of the Civil Rights']

['Is it illegal to discriminate based on race?', 'Act to include educational requirements in a job description (e.g., high school diploma) that negatively impacts one race over another if the requirement cannot be shown to be directly related to job performance.']
['Do they do this often?', 'The EEOC (2014) received more than 94,000 charges of various kinds of employment discrimination in 2013.']
['What else is interesting?', 'Many of the filings are for multiple forms of discrimination and include charges of retaliation for making a claim, which itself is illegal.']
['How does this work?', 'Only a small fraction of these claims become suits filed in a federal court, although the suits may represent the claims of more than one person.']
['What happens when someone sues?', 'In 2013, there were 148 suits filed in federal courts.']

['What is the EEOC?', 'Based on a 2020 Supreme Court ruling regarding the application of the Civil Rights Act, federal legislation now protects employees in the private sector from discrimination related to sexual orientation and gender identity.']
['Who are these groups?', 'These groups include lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender individuals.']

['What evidence supports these claims?', 'There is evidence of discrimination derived from surveys of workers, studies of complaint filings, wage comparison studies, and controlled job-interview studies (Badgett, Sears, Lau, & Ho, 2009).']

['What other laws protect these people?', 'Prior to the ruling, federal legislation protected federal employees from such discrimination; the District of Columbia and 20 states have laws protecting public and private employees from discrimination for sexual orientation (American Civil Liberties Union, n.d).']
['What else do these laws protect?', 'Most of the states with these laws also protect against discrimination based on gender identity.']
['What is gender identity?', 'Gender identity refers to one’s sense of being male, female, neither of these, both of these, or another gender.']
['When did the Supreme Court rule in Civil Rights?', "While the Supreme Court's Civil Rights"]

['', 'Act interpretation is regarded as a landmark outcome for LGBTQ people, it will be continually tested by organizations that for various reasons see a need to exclude LGBTQ people from employment or service.']

['What is it about churches?', 'The First Amendment protects religious organizations from some aspects of anti-discrimination laws, and some recent court decisions have expanded these exceptions so that certain ministries, schools, or other organizations could avoid employing or serving LGBTQ people.']
['What does the act protect?', 'The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 states people may not be discriminated against due to the nature of their disability.']
['What is a disability?', 'A disability is defined as a physical or mental impairment that limits one or more major life activities such as hearing, walking, and breathing.']
['What does it require of the employer?', 'An employer must make reasonable accommodations for the performance of the job of an employee with disabilities.']
['What kinds of accommodations are allowed?', 'This might include making the work facility accessible with ramps, providing readers for blind personnel, or allowing for more frequent breaks.']
['What kind of impairment is a disability?', 'The ADA has now been expanded to include individuals with alcoholism, former drug use, obesity, or psychiatric disabilities.']

['What is the premise of this act?', "The premise of the law is that individuals with disabilities can contribute to an organization and they cannot be discriminated against because of their disabilities (O'Keefe & Bruyere, 1994)."]
["What's the next title we should look at?", 'The Civil Rights Act and the Age Discrimination in Employment']

["What's the final title we should look at?", 'Act make provisions for bona fide occupational qualifications (BFOQs), which are requirements of certain occupations for which denying an individual employment would otherwise violate the law.']
['How is this similar to BFOQ?', 'For example, there may be cases in which religion, national origin, age, and sex are bona fide occupational qualifications.']
['What can I learn about race?', 'There are no BFOQ exceptions that apply to race, although the first amendment protects artistic expressions, such as films, in making race a requirement of a role.']

['What else can I learn about religion?', 'Clearcut examples of BFOQs would be hiring someone of a specific religion for a leadership position in a worship facility, or for an executive position in religiously affiliated institutions, such as the president of a university with religious ties.']
['How about age?', 'Age has been determined to be a BFOQ for airline pilots; hence, there are mandatory retirement ages for safety reasons.']
['What else?', 'Sex has been determined as a BFOQ for guards in male prisons.']

['What are some of the questions that are asked in this article?', 'Sex or gender is the most common reason for invoking a BFOQ as a defense against accusing an employer of discrimination (Manley, 2009).']
['What is a BFOQ?', 'Courts have established a three-part test for sex-related BFOQs that are often used in other types of legal cases for determining whether a BFOQ exists.']
['How are the parts of the test?', 'The first of these is whether all or substantially all women would be unable to perform a job.']

['What does the second part of the test look like?', 'This is the reason most physical limitations, such as “able to lift 30 pounds,” fail as reasons to discriminate because most women are able to lift this weight.']

['What other factors make a claim of BFOQ likely to fail?', 'The second test is the “essence of the business” test, in which having to choose the other gender would undermine the essence of the business operation.']
['Did this test have success?', 'This test was the reason the now defunct Pan American World Airways (i.e., Pan Am) was told it could not hire only women flight attendants.']
['Was there any reason for this?', 'Hiring men would not have undermined the essense of this business.']
['Why is it so difficult to have a BFOQ?', 'On a deeper level, this means that hiring cannot be made purely on customers’ or others’ preferences.']

['What else does the test look like?', 'The third and final test is whether the employer cannot make reasonable alternative accommodations, such as reassigning staff so that a woman does not have to work in a men-only part of a jail or other gender-specific facility.']

['Do any companies have problems making the change?', 'Privacy concerns are a major reason why discrimination based on gender is upheld by the courts, for example in situations such as hires for nursing or custodial staff (Manley, 2009).']
['What else does the article talk about?', 'Most cases of BFOQs are decided on a case-by-case basis and these court decisions inform policy and future case decisions.']
['What is organization psychology?', 'Organizational psychology is the second major branch of study and practice within the discipline of industrial and organizational psychology.']
['What does organization psychology study?', 'In organizational psychology, the focus is on social interactions and their effect on the individual and on the functioning of the organization.']

['What are some social interactions?', 'In this section, you will learn about the work organizational psychologists have done to understand job satisfaction, different styles of management, different styles of leadership, organizational culture, and teamwork.']
['What is the difference between the three types of job satisfaction?', 'Some people love their jobs, some people tolerate their jobs, and some people cannot stand their jobs.']
['What does job satisfaction mean?', 'Job satisfaction describes the degree to which individuals enjoy their job.']
['Who first said this?', 'It was described by Edwin Locke (1976) as the state of feeling resulting from appraising one’s job experiences.']

['What does that mean?', 'While job satisfaction results from both how we think about our work (our cognition) and how we feel about our work (our affect) (Saari & Judge, 2004), it is described in terms of affect.']
['How can we enjoy our work?', 'Job satisfaction is impacted by the work itself, our personality, and the culture we come from and live in (Saari & Judge, 2004).']

['What are some important points of this content?', 'Job satisfaction is typically measured after a change in an organization, such as a shift in the management model, to assess how the change affects employees.']
['What other types of assessments are conducted?', 'It may also be routinely measured by an organization to assess one of many factors expected to affect the organization’s performance.']

['What other types of assessments are conducted?', 'In addition, polling companies like Gallup regularly measure job satisfaction on a national scale to gather broad information on the state of the economy and the workforce (Saad, 2012).']
['How is satisfaction measured?', 'Job satisfaction is measured using questionnaires that employees complete.']

['What questions do you see on the questionnaires?', 'Sometimes a single question might be asked in a very straightforward way to which employees respond using a rating scale, such as a Likert scale, which was discussed in the chapter on personality.']

['How does a Likert scale work?', 'A Likert scale (typically) provides five possible answers to a statement or question that allows respondents to indicate their positive-to-negative strength of agreement or strength of feeling regarding the question or statement.']

['What are the possible answers to a question like that?', 'Thus the possible responses to a question such as “How satisfied are you with your job today?” might be “Very satisfied,” “Somewhat satisfied,” “Neither satisfied, nor dissatisfied,” “Somewhat dissatisfied,” and “Very dissatisfied.”']

['What else is included in the questionnaires?', 'More commonly the survey will ask a number of questions about the employee’s satisfaction to determine more precisely why they are satisfied or dissatisfied.']
['What is the purpose of these questionnaires?', 'Sometimes these surveys are created for specific jobs; at other times, they are designed to apply to any job.']

['How is satisfaction measured?', 'Job satisfaction can be measured at a global level, meaning how satisfied in general the employee is with work, or at the level of specific factors intended to measure which aspects of the job lead to satisfaction (Table 13.2).']

['What is one important factor of job satisfaction?', 'Research has suggested that the work-content factor, which includes variety, difficulty level, and role clarity of the job, is the most strongly predictive factor of overall job satisfaction (Saari & Judge, 2004).']

['what other factors do people rely on to decide job satisfaction?', 'In contrast, there is only a weak correlation between pay level and job satisfaction (Judge, Piccolo, Podsakoff, Shaw, & Rich, 2010).']
['What else is significant about the correlation between pay level and job satisfaction?', 'Judge et al. (2010) suggest that individuals adjust or adapt to higher pay levels:']
['why do they suggest that?', 'Higher pay no longer provides the satisfaction the individual may have initially felt when their salary increased.']

['What is the relationship between job satisfaction and performance?', 'Measures of job satisfaction are somewhat correlated with job performance; in particular, they appear to relate to organizational citizenship or discretionary behaviors on the part of an employee that further the goals of the organization (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']

['What is the relationship between job satisfaction and life satisfaction?', 'Job satisfaction is related to general life satisfaction, although there has been limited research on how the two influence each other or whether personality and cultural factors affect both job and general life satisfaction.']

['What other research has there been on this relationship?', 'One carefully controlled study suggested that the relationship is reciprocal: Job satisfaction affects life satisfaction positively, and vice versa (Judge & Watanabe, 1993).']
['How can an organization control life satisfaction?', 'Of course, organizations cannot control life satisfaction’s influence on job satisfaction.']

['What is the relationship between job satisfaction and withdrawal behaviors?', 'Job satisfaction, specifically low job satisfaction, is also related to withdrawal behaviors, such as leaving a job or absenteeism (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']
['What is the relationship with turnover?', 'The relationship with turnover itself, however, is weak (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']

['How can an organization control performance?', 'Finally, it appears that job satisfaction is related to organizational performance, which suggests that implementing organizational changes to improve employee job satisfaction will improve organizational performance (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']
['What are some of the benefits and drawbacks to the study of job satisfaction?', 'There is opportunity for more research in the area of job satisfaction.']

['What are some other examples?', 'For example, Weiss (2002) suggests that the concept of job satisfaction measurements have combined both emotional and cognitive concepts, and measurements would be more reliable and show better relationships with outcomes like performance if the measurement of job satisfaction separated these two possible elements of job satisfaction.']
['What is the relationship between job satisfaction and stress?', 'Job stress affects job satisfaction.']
['What is job stress?', 'Job stress, or job strain, is caused by specific stressors in an occupation.']
['How is the term stress used?', 'Stress can be an ambiguous term as it is used in common language.']

['What is the definition of stress?', 'Stress is the perception and response of an individual to events judged as overwhelming or threatening to the individual’s well-being (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005).']
['Who creates stress?', 'The events themselves are the stressors.']

['What is some examples of stressors?', 'Stress is a result of an employee’s perception that the demands placed on them exceed their ability to meet them (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005), such as having to fill multiple roles in a job or life in general, workplace role ambiguity, lack of career progress, lack of job security, lack of control over work outcomes, isolation, work overload, discrimination, harassment, and bullying (Colligan & Higgins, 2005).']
['Are there any gender differences in job stress?', 'The stressors are different for women than men and these differences are a significant area of research (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005).']
['What are the consequences of stress?', 'Job stress leads to poor employee health, job performance, and family life (Colligan & Higgins, 2005).']
['What is job insecurity?', 'As already mentioned, job insecurity contributes significantly to job stress.']
['How is job insecurity being dealt with?', 'Two increasing threats to job security are downsizing events and corporate mergers.']
['What are the resulting changes?', 'Businesses typically involve I-O psychologists in planning for, implementing, and managing these types of organizational change.']

['What is downsizing?', 'Downsizing is an increasingly common response to a business’s pronounced failure to achieve profit goals, and it involves laying off a significant percentage of the company’s employees.']

['Are there any other important aspects of downsizing?', 'Industrial-organizational psychologists may be involved in all aspects of downsizing: how the news is delivered to employees (both those being let go and those staying), how laid-off employees are supported (e.g., separation packages), and how retained employees are supported.']

["What's the most important aspect of retained employees support?", 'The latter is important for the organization because downsizing events affect the retained employee’s intent to quit, organizational commitment, and job insecurity (Ugboro, 2006).']

['What type of corporations can downsize and grow?', 'In addition to downsizing as a way of responding to outside strains on a business, corporations often grow larger by combining with other businesses.']

['How do they combine?', 'This can be accomplished through a merger (i.e., the joining of two organizations of equal power and status) or an acquisition (i.e., one organization purchases the other).']
['What are some differences between an acquisition and a merger?', 'In an acquisition, the purchasing organization is usually the more powerful or dominant partner.']
['Can you name a couple examples of these?', 'In both cases, there is usually a duplication of services between the two companies, such as two accounting departments and two sales forces.']
['How does this effect the workforce?', 'Both departments must be merged, which commonly involves a reduction of staff (Figure 13.14).']
['How does this affect employees?', 'This leads to organizational processes and stresses similar to those that occur in downsizing events.']

['Can you name other reasons?', 'Mergers require determining how the organizational culture will change, to which employees also must adjust (van Knippenberg, van Knippenberg, Monden, & de Lima, 2002).']

['What is one negative aspect of this?', 'There can be additional stress on workers as they lose their connection to the old organization and try to make connections with the new combined group (Amiot, Terry, Jimmieson, & Callan, 2006).']
['What is a good way to handle the stress?', 'Research in this area focuses on understanding employee reactions and making practical recommendations for managing these organizational changes.']

['What is work-family balance?', 'Many people juggle the demands of work life with the demands of their home life, whether it be caring for children or taking care of an elderly parent; this is known as work-family balance.']

['What can people do to achieve work-family balance?', 'We might commonly think about work interfering with family, but it is also the case that family responsibilities may conflict with work obligations (Carlson, Kacmar, & Williams, 2000).']
['How is this accomplished?', 'Greenhaus and Beutell (1985) first identified three sources of work–family conflicts:']

["What's the main idea behind this?", 'Women often have greater responsibility for family demands, including home care, child care, and caring for aging parents, yet men in the United States are increasingly assuming a greater share of domestic responsibilities.']
['Who gets the majority of the work load?', 'However, research has documented that women report greater levels of stress from work–family conflict (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005).']
['What does this mean?', 'There are many ways to decrease work–family conflict and improve people’s job satisfaction (Posig & Kickul, 2004).']
