['What are some ways to decrease work–family conflict?', 'These include support in the home, which can take various forms: emotional (listening), practical (help with chores).']
['What does workplace support include?', 'Workplace support can include understanding supervisors, flextime, leave with pay, and telecommuting.']

['What is flextime?', 'Flextime usually involves a requirement of core hours spent in the workplace around which the employee may schedule their arrival and departure from work to meet family demands.']

['What is telecommuting?', 'Telecommuting involves employees working at home and setting their own hours, which allows them to work during different parts of the day, and to spend part of the day with their family; this may also be known as ecommuting, working remotely, flexible workspace, or simply working from home.']
['What did people think of these choices?', 'Recall that Yahoo! had a policy of allowing employees to telecommute and then rescinded the policy.']
['What else can workplace support include?', 'There are also organizations that have onsite daycare centers, and some companies even have onsite fitness centers and health clinics.']
['What else is mentioned?', 'In a study of the effectiveness of different coping methods, Lapierre & Allen (2006) found practical support from home more important than emotional support.']

['What is your favorite part of this article?', 'They also found that immediate-supervisor support for a worker significantly reduced work–family conflict through such mechanisms as allowing an employee the flexibility needed to fulfill family obligations.']

['Did they find that any other options worked well?', 'In contrast, flextime did not help with coping and telecommuting actually made things worse, perhaps reflecting the fact that being at home intensifies the conflict between work and family because with the employee in the home, the demands of family are more evident.']
['What are the relevant articles?', 'Posig & Kickul (2004) identify exemplar corporations with policies designed to reduce work–family conflict.']

['What are some examples of the policies they identify?', 'Examples include IBM’s policy of three years of job-guaranteed leave after the birth of a child, Lucent Technologies offer of one year’s childbirth leave at half pay, and SC Johnson’s program of concierge services for daytime errands.']
['What is a significant portion of I-O research?', 'A significant portion of I-O research focuses on management and human relations.']

['What is a leadership behavior?', 'Douglas McGregor (1960) combined scientific management (a theory of management that analyzes and synthesizes workflows with the main objective of improving economic efficiency, especially labor productivity) and human relations into the notion of leadership behavior.']
['What is the Theory X and Theory Y?', 'His theory lays out two different styles called Theory X and Theory Y.']
['What is Theory X?', 'In the Theory X approach to management, managers assume that most people dislike work and are not innately self-directed.']
['What is the approach?', 'Theory X managers perceive employees as people who prefer to be led and told which tasks to perform and when.']
['How do they perform tasks?', 'Their employees have to be watched carefully to be sure that they work hard enough to fulfill the organization’s goals.']
['How does Theory X influence people?', 'Theory X workplaces will often have employees punch a clock when arriving and leaving the workplace: Tardiness is punished.']

['Does the workplace force employees to stay late?', 'Supervisors, not employees, determine whether an employee needs to stay late, and even this decision would require someone higher up in the command chain to approve the extra hours.']
['Do supervisors enforce this?', 'Theory X supervisors will ignore employees’ suggestions for improved efficiency and reprimand employees for speaking out of order.']
['What else is a result of this?', 'These supervisors blame efficiency failures on individual employees rather than the systems or policies in place.']
['What are some other practices?', 'Managerial goals are achieved through a system of punishments and threats rather than enticements and rewards.']

['What else is unique about this approach?', 'Managers are suspicious of employees’ motivations and always suspect selfish motivations for their behavior at work (e.g., being paid is their sole motivation for working).']
['What is the Theory Y approach?', 'In the Theory Y approach, on the other hand, managers assume that most people seek inner satisfaction and fulfillment from their work.']
['What is a major component of Theory Y?', 'Employees function better under leadership that allows them to participate in, and provide input about, setting their personal and work goals.']

['How do they participate in the setting of their work goals?', 'In Theory Y workplaces, employees participate in decisions about prioritizing tasks; they may belong to teams that, once given a goal, decide themselves how it will be accomplished.']
['What other aspects of Theory Y interest you?', 'In such a workplace, employees are able to provide input on matters of efficiency and safety.']

['What are some examples of Theory Y?', 'One example of Theory Y in action is the policy of Toyota production lines that allows any employee to stop the entire line if a defect or other issue appears, so that the defect can be fixed and its cause remedied (Toyota Motor Manufacturing, 2013).']
['What other aspects of Theory Y will be interesting to you?', 'A Theory Y workplace will also meaningfully consult employees on any changes to the work process or management system.']
['What else will Theory Y do for the organization?', 'In addition, the organization will encourage employees to contribute their own ideas.']
['What is Theory X?', 'McGregor (1960) characterized Theory X as the traditional method of management used in the United States.']
['What was the theory about?', 'He argued that a Theory Y approach was needed to improve organizational output and the wellbeing of individuals.']
['How did Theory Y differ from the traditional method?', 'Table 13.3 summarizes how these two management approaches differ.']

['What types of management styles do managers use?', 'Another management style was described by Donald Clifton, who focused his research on how an organization can best use an individual’s strengths, an approach he called strengths-based management.']
['What was the research?', 'He and his colleagues interviewed 8,000 managers and concluded that it is important to focus on a person’s strengths, not their weaknesses.']
['What is a strength?', 'A strength is a particular enduring talent possessed by an individual that allows them to provide consistent, near-perfect performance in tasks involving that talent.']
['What is the greatest opportunity for growth?', 'Clifton argued that our strengths provide the greatest opportunity for growth (Buckingham & Clifton, 2001).']
['What are some examples of strengths?', 'An example of a strength is public speaking or the ability to plan a successful event.']
['Is this a common practice?', 'The strengths-based approach is very popular although its effect on organization performance is not well-studied.']

['What else has this approach to management led to?', 'However, Kaiser & Overfield (2011) found that managers often neglected improving their weaknesses and overused their strengths, both of which interfered with performance.']
['What kind of management is discussed?', 'Leadership is an important element of management.']
['What kinds of leadership styles are discussed?', 'Leadership styles have been of major interest within I-O research, and researchers have proposed numerous theories of leadership.']
['What does Bass have to do with leadership?', 'Bass (1985) popularized and developed the concepts of transactional leadership versus transformational leadership styles.']

['What is transactional leadership?', 'In transactional leadership, the focus is on supervision and organizational goals, which are achieved through a system of rewards and punishments (i.e., transactions).']
['What does this mean?', 'Transactional leaders maintain the status quo:']
['What do these leaders do?', 'They are managers.']
['What is the most important thing to know?', 'This is in contrast to the transformational leader.']
['What is transformational leadership?', 'People who have transformational leadership possess four attributes to varying degrees:']

['What are the attributes?', 'They are charismatic (highly liked role models), inspirational (optimistic about goal attainment), intellectually stimulating (encourage critical thinking and problem solving), and considerate (Bass, Avolio, & Atwater, 1996).']

['What are the key ideas?', 'As women increasingly take on leadership roles in corporations, questions have arisen as to whether there are differences in leadership styles between men and women (Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen, 2003).']
['What were the research findings?', 'Eagly & Johnson (1990) conducted a meta-analysis to examine gender and leadership style.']

['What were the results of the study?', 'They found, to a slight but significant degree, that women tend to practice an interpersonal style of leadership (i.e., she focuses on the morale and welfare of the employees) and men practice a task-oriented style (i.e., he focuses on accomplishing tasks).']

['What was the biggest drawback of their study?', 'However, the differences were less pronounced when one looked only at organizational studies and excluded laboratory experiments or surveys that did not involve actual organizational leaders.']

['What other findings were made?', 'Larger gender-related differences were observed when leadership style was categorized as democratic or autocratic, and these differences were consistent across all types of studies.']

['What was their reasoning?', 'The authors suggest that similarities between genders in leadership styles are attributable to different genders needing to conform to the organization’s culture; additionally, they propose that gender-related differences reflect inherent differences in the strengths each gender brings to bear on leadership practice.']

['Did they find anything else interesting?', 'In another meta-analysis of leadership style, Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen (2003) found that women tended to exhibit the characteristics of transformational leaders, while men were more likely to be transactional leaders.']

['What are the differences in styles?', 'However, the differences are not absolute; for example, women were found to use methods of reward for performance more often than men, which is a component of transactional leadership.']
['What were the findings of their study?', 'The differences they found were relatively small.']

['What else was important?', 'As Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen (2003) point out, research shows that transformational leadership approaches are more effective than transactional approaches, although individual leaders typically exhibit elements of both approaches.']
['How does this relate to psychology?', 'A new and emerging area of research within psychology focuses on leadership and the relationship with leaders from the perspective of a follower.']

['what is the relationship?', 'This “followership” research suggests that studies need to examine the leader-follower relationship in both directions—instead of focusing only on leadership—to better understand the dynamics of the relationship.']
['how does this help?', 'Put differently, people are individuals, and because they are different, there probably is no single best leadership-follower dynamic between leaders and followers.']
['are people similar?', 'For instance, think about the differences between yourself and someone you know well.']
['how are they different?', 'Maybe one of you likes a lot of structure and other seems to work best with less structure.']

['what else is interesting about the article?', 'Perhaps, one of you is ready to try a new restaurant at any time and the other prefers to go to the tried-and-true place that you’ve visited so many times the servers know your order before you place it.']

['What are the characteristics of individual followers?', 'Some early research has discovered that the characteristics of individual followers will result in different types of relationships with a leader depending on the leadership style.']
['What is the main takeaway from this research?', 'It appears that not all leadership styles work well with all follower types.']
['What type of follower is being referred to?', 'One characteristic of followers, for example, is their degree of extroversion.']

['How is this influenced by leadership?', 'Previous research suggests that individuals with a high degree of extroversion would need a larger amount of interaction with their leaders in order to function well; however, other research suggests this may not necessarily be the case and instead other factors may be at work (Phillips & Bedeian; Bauer et al, 2006).']
['What characteristics of followers are listed in this article?', 'Another characteristic of followers is their individual need for growth.']

['What are some ways in which leaders might help to provide growth opportunities?', 'For followers who have a strong desire to learn and grow within their organization, a leader who provides developmental opportunities might be better received than one who does not.']

['What is a disadvantage of leaders who are pushing for growth?', 'In addition, for those followers who are low on growth and need strength, leaders who push them to grow may make them less satisfied followers as they feel forced into further development and training, possibly signaling a lower level of achievement from their supervisor.']

['What can leaders do to help growth?', 'Training for leaders in both helping employees who have a strong drive for growth and those who do not appears to be helpful in improving the relationship between both types of followers and their leaders (Schyns, Kroon, & Moors, 2008).']
['Which of the following statements is not an example of a leader-follower relationship?', 'Finally, an employee’s need for leadership is an important component of the leader-follower relationship.']

['How does one define this?', 'Some individuals are significantly more autonomous than others and as a result do not respond as well to leaders who provide a lot of structure and rigidity of processes, in turn reducing the quality of their relationship with their leader.']

['What are some examples of this?', 'Other employees who are high in need for leadership have a better relationship with their leader if they are provided with a well-structured environment with clear responsibilities and little ambiguity in their work.']

['Are there some specific characteristics of people who are high in leadership need?', 'These followers work best in situations where they feel they can comfortably perform the work with little requirement to think outside of the guidelines that have been provided.']

['Does a leader have to be an authority figure?', 'For these individuals, having a leader who is able to set a clear path forward for the employee with little need for deviation promotes a strong positive leader-follower relationship (Felfe & Schyns, 2006).']

['What was this document about?', 'The workplace today is rapidly changing due to a variety of factors, such as shifts in technology, economics, foreign competition, globalization, and workplace demographics.']
['How should a manager handle this?', 'Organizations need to respond quickly to changes in these factors.']

['How can teams be utilized?', 'Many companies are responding to these changes by structuring their organizations so that work can be delegated to work teams, which bring together diverse skills, experience, and expertise.']
['Why is this beneficial?', 'This is in contrast to organizational structures that have individuals at their base (Naquin & Tynan, 2003).']
['What is the team-based approach?', 'In the team-based approach, teams are brought together and given a specific task or goal to accomplish.']

['What else can you tell me about this?', 'Despite their burgeoning popularity, team structures do not always deliver greater productivity—the work of teams is an active area of research (Naquin & Tynan, 2003).']
['How did this happen?', 'There are many contributing factors.']
['What other factors contribute to poor teamwork?', 'For example, teams can mask team members that are not working (i.e., social loafing).']

['What other factors contribute to poor teamwork?', 'Teams can be inefficient due to poor communication; they can have poor decision-making skills due to conformity effects; and, they can have conflict within the group.']
['What are the other factors?', 'The popularity of teams may in part result from the team halo effect:']
['How does this help?', 'Teams are given credit for their successes.']
['What are the other factors?', 'but individuals within a team are blamed for team failures (Naquin & Tynan, 2003).']
['What are some team diversity features?', 'One aspect of team diversity is their gender mix.']
['What does this mean?', 'Researchers have explored whether gender mix has an effect on team performance.']

['What else does this research reveal?', 'On the one hand, diversity can introduce communication and interpersonal-relationship problems that hinder performance, but on the other hand diversity can also increase the team’s skill set, which may include skills that can actually improve team member interactions.']

['What other studies do you know of that say this?', 'Hoogendoorn, Oosterbeek, & van Praag (2013) studied project teams in a university business school in which the gender mix of the teams was manipulated.']
['How did they do this?', 'They found that gender-balanced teams performed better, as measured by sales and profits, than teams made up mostly by men.']
['What else did they find?', 'The study did not have enough data to determine the relative performance of teams with more women than men.']
['What other studies are there?', 'The study was unsuccessful in identifying which mechanism (interpersonal relationships, learning, or skills mixes) accounted for performance improvement.']
['what is a work team?', 'There are three basic types of teams: problem resolution teams, creative teams, and tactical teams.']

['what does a problem resolution team do?', 'Problem resolution teams are created for the purpose of solving a particular problem or issue; for example, the diagnostic teams at the Centers for Disease Control.']
['what does a creative team do?', 'Creative teams are used to develop innovative possibilities or solutions; for example, design teams for car manufacturers create new vehicle models.']
['what does a tactical team do?', 'Tactical teams are used to execute a well-defined plan or objective, such as a police or FBI SWAT team handling a hostage situation (Larson & LaFasto, 1989).']

['what is a virtual team?', 'One area of active research involves a fourth kind of team—the virtual team; these studies examine how groups of geographically disparate people brought together using digital communications technology function (Powell, Piccoli, & Ives, 2004).']

['is a virtual team useful?', 'Even before the COVID-19 pandemic, virtual teams were more common due to the growing globalization of organizations and the use of consulting and partnerships facilitated by digital communication.']
['What is organization culture?', 'Each company and organization has an organizational culture.']
['What is an organization culture?', 'Organizational culture encompasses the values, visions, hierarchies, norms, and interactions among its employees.']
['What is a company culture?', 'It is how an organization is run, how it operates, and how it makes decisions—the industry in which the organization participates may have an influence.']
['Does the culture of an organization vary between different departments?', 'Different departments within one company can develop their own subculture within the organization’s culture.']

['How can you recognize these three layers of culture?', 'Ostroff, Kinicki, and Tamkins (2003) identify three layers in organizational culture: observable artifacts, espoused values, and basic assumptions.']

['What are some examples of observable artifacts?', 'Observable artifacts are the symbols, language (jargon, slang, and humor), narratives (stories and legends), and practices (rituals) that represent the underlying cultural assumptions.']
['What are some examples of espoused values?', 'Espoused values are concepts or beliefs that the management or the entire organization endorses.']
['What are some examples of basic assumptions?', 'They are the rules that allow employees to know which actions they should take in different situations and which information they should adhere to.']
['How do you determine which rules employees must adhere to?', 'These basic assumptions generally are unobservable and unquestioned.']
['What kinds of research have been conducted about company culture?', 'Researchers have developed survey instruments to measure organizational culture.']

['Why is this important?', 'With the workforce being a global marketplace, your company may have a supplier in Korea and another in Honduras and have employees in the United States, China, and South Africa.']
['Are there different cultural differences?', 'You may have coworkers of different religious, ethnic, or racial backgrounds than yourself.']
['Is this all about race?', 'Your coworkers may be from different places around the globe.']
['Do we have anything else to learn?', 'Many workplaces offer diversity training to help everyone involved bridge and understand cultural differences.']
['What is diversity training?', 'Diversity training educates participants about cultural differences with the goal of improving teamwork.']

['How do we reduce prejudice?', 'There is always the potential for prejudice between members of two groups, but the evidence suggests that simply working together, particularly if the conditions of work are set carefully that such prejudice can be reduced or eliminated.']
['What can you tell me about this research?', 'Pettigrew and Tropp (2006) conducted a meta-analysis to examine the question of whether contact between groups reduced prejudice between those groups.']
['What else was known about this study?', 'They found that there was a moderate but significant effect.']

['What did they say about how to achieve the effect?', 'They also found that, as previously theorized, the effect was enhanced when the two groups met under conditions in which they have equal standing, common goals, cooperation between the groups, and especially support on the part of the institution or authorities for the contact.']
['What was one of the negative aspects of organization culture?', 'One well-recognized negative aspect of organizational culture is a culture of harassment, including sexual harassment.']

['What was the policy?', 'Most organizations of any size have developed sexual harassment policies that define sexual harassment (or harassment in general) and the procedures the organization has set in place to prevent and address it when it does occur.']

['How did they treat employees?', 'Thus, in most jobs you have held, you were probably made aware of the company’s sexual harassment policy and procedures, and may have received training related to the policy.']
['How did the policy affect them?', 'The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (n.d.) provides the following description of sexual harassment:']
['What are some examples of sexual harassment?', 'One form of sexual harassment is called quid pro quo.']
['What is quid pro quo?', 'Quid pro quo means you give something to get something, and it refers to a situation in which organizational rewards are offered in exchange for sexual favors.']
['What is the most common instance of this type of harassment?', 'Quid pro quo harassment is often between an employee and a person with greater power in the organization.']

['What else is one example of quid pro quo?', 'For example, a supervisor might request an action, such as a kiss or a touch, in exchange for a promotion, a positive performance review, or a pay raise.']
['What is another example of sexual harassment?', 'Another form of sexual harassment is the threat of withholding a reward if a sexual request is refused.']
['What is a hostile environment?', 'Hostile environment sexual harassment is another type of workplace harassment.']
['What does this mean?', 'In this situation, an employee experiences conditions in the workplace that are considered hostile or intimidating.']
['What is an example?', 'For example, a work environment that allows offensive language or jokes or displays sexually explicit images.']
['What is harassment?', 'Isolated occurrences of these events do not constitute harassment, but a pattern of repeated occurrences does.']
['What is a violation of organization policy?', 'In addition to violating organizational policies against sexual harassment, these forms of harassment are illegal.']

['What is violence in the workplace?', 'Workplace violence is any act or threat of physical violence, harassment, intimidation, or other threatening, disruptive behavior that occurs at the workplace.']
['What other forms of violence can be considered?', 'It ranges from threats and verbal abuse to physical assaults and even homicide (Occupational Safety & Health Administration, 2014).']
['Who is a target of workplace violence?', 'There are different targets of workplace violence: a person could commit violence against coworkers, supervisors, or property.']
['How can you recognize these warning signs?', 'Warning signs often precede such actions: intimidating behavior, threats, sabotaging equipment, or radical changes in a coworker’s behavior.']
['What happens when intimidation is not enough?', 'Often there is intimidation and then escalation that leads to even further escalation.']
['What is the best way to deal with this type of threat?', 'It is important for employees to involve their immediate supervisor if they ever feel intimidated or unsafe.']
['What is the most common form of violence in the workplace?', 'Murder is the second leading cause of death in the workplace.']
['How about sexual assault?', 'It is also the primary cause of death for women in the workplace.']
['Is there any other form of violence in the workplace?', 'Every year there are nearly two million workers who are physically assaulted or threatened with assault.']
['Who murders women in the workplace?', 'Many are murdered in domestic violence situations by boyfriends or husbands who chose the woman’s workplace to commit their crimes.']
['What are the triggers?', 'There are many triggers for workplace violence.']
['What is a significant trigger?', 'A significant trigger is the feeling of being treated unfairly, unjustly, or disrespectfully.']
['What were some of the studies that were cited?', 'In a research experiment, Greenberg (1993) examined the reactions of students who were given pay for a task.']
['What was the purpose of this study?', 'In one group, the students were given extensive explanations for the pay rate.']
['What did the second group receive?', 'In the second group, the students were given a curt uninformative explanation.']
['Why did they have this reaction?', 'The students were made to believe the supervisor would not know how much money the student withdrew for payment.']
['How did the study go?', 'The rate of stealing (taking more pay than they were told they deserved) was higher in the group who had been given the limited explanation.']
['What did this have to do with the study?', 'This is a demonstration of the importance of procedural justice in organizations.']
['What does procedural justice mean?', 'Procedural justice refers to the fairness of the processes by which outcomes are determined in conflicts with or among employees.']

['What is significant about this?', 'In another study by Greenberg & Barling (1999), they found a history of aggression and amount of alcohol consumed to be accurate predictors of workplace violence against a coworker.']
['Why does this happen?', 'Aggression against a supervisor was predicted if a worker felt unfairly treated or untrusted.']
['What else was observed?', 'Job security and alcohol consumption predicted aggression against a subordinate.']

['What else was mentioned?', 'To understand and predict workplace violence, Greenberg & Barling (1999) emphasize the importance of considering the employee target of aggression or violence and characteristics of both the workplace characteristics and the aggressive or violent person.']
['What is human factors psychology?', 'Human factors psychology (or ergonomics, a term that is favored in Europe) is the third subject area within industrial and organizational psychology.']

['What does workplace design involve?', 'This field is concerned with the integration of the human-machine interface in the workplace, through design, and specifically with researching and designing machines that fit human requirements.']
['What integration does this mean?', 'The integration may be physical or cognitive, or a combination of both.']

['What is an example of workplace design?', 'Anyone who needs to be convinced that the field is necessary need only try to operate an unfamiliar television remote control or use a new piece of software for the first time.']

['What other aspects of workplace design are involved?', 'Whereas the two other areas of I-O psychology focus on the interface between the worker and team, group, or organization, human factors psychology focuses on the individual worker’s interaction with a machine, work station, information displays, and the local environment, such as lighting.']

['Who was involved in workplace design?', 'In the United States, human factors psychology has origins in both psychology and engineering; this is reflected in the early contributions of Lillian Gilbreth (psychologist and engineer) and her husband Frank Gilbreth (engineer).']

['What are the topics of our study?', 'Human factor professionals are involved in design from the beginning of a project, as is more common in software design projects, or toward the end in testing and evaluation, as is more common in traditional industries (Howell, 2003).']
['What else do they have to do with design?', 'Another important role of human factor professionals is in the development of regulations and principles of best design.']
['What regulations and principles do they develop?', 'These regulations and principles are often related to work safety.']

['What work safety issues have they worked on?', 'For example, the Three Mile Island nuclear accident lead to Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) requirements for additional instrumentation in nuclear facilities to provide operators with more critical information and increased operator training (United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, 2013).']

['What other regulations have they developed?', 'The American National Standards Institute (ANSI, 2000), an independent developer of industrial standards, develops many standards related to ergonomic design, such as the design of control-center workstations that are used for transportation control or industrial process control.']
['What does workplace design have to do with human factors psychology?', 'Many of the concerns of human factors psychology are related to workplace safety.']
['What safety concerns are related to workplace design?', 'These concerns can be studied to help prevent work-related injuries of individual workers or those around them.']

['What safety protocols are related to work-related injuries?', 'Safety protocols may also be related to activities, such as commercial driving or flying, medical procedures, and law enforcement, that have the potential to impact the public.']
['What kind of workplace is this?', 'One of the methods used to reduce accidents in the workplace is a checklist.']
['What kind of checklists are used?', 'The airline industry is one industry that uses checklists.']

['What is a checklist used for?', 'Pilots are required to go through a detailed checklist of the different parts of the aircraft before takeoff to ensure that all essential equipment is working correctly.']
['How do they know that?', 'Astronauts also go through checklists before takeoff.']

['What kind of safety checklists are there?', 'The surgical safety checklist shown in Figure 13.15 was developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and serves as the basis for many checklists at medical facilities.']
['What is the main idea of this section?', 'Safety concerns also lead to limits to how long an operator, such as a pilot or truck driver, is allowed to operate the equipment.']
['What limits are they trying to get rid of?', 'Recently the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) introduced limits for how long a pilot is allowed to fly without an overnight break.']
['What did Howell write?', 'Howell (2003) outlines some important areas of research and practice in the field of human factors.']
['What was in Table 13.4?', 'These are summarized in Table 13.4.']

['What are some other important aspects of this section?', 'As an example of research in human factors psychology Bruno & Abrahão (2012) examined the impact of the volume of operator decisions on the accuracy of decisions made within an information security center at a banking institution in Brazil.']
['How did the study proceed?', 'The study examined a total of about 45,000 decisions made by 35 operators and 4 managers over a period of 60 days.']

['What were the results of this study?', 'Their study found that as the number of decisions made per day by the operators climbed, that is, as their cognitive effort increased, the operators made more mistakes in falsely identifying incidents as real security breaches (when, in reality, they were not).']
['What else did this study find?', 'Interestingly, the opposite mistake of identifying real intrusions as false alarms did not increase with increased cognitive demand.']
['What was the conclusion of this study?', 'This appears to be good news for the bank, since false alarms are not as costly as incorrectly rejecting a genuine threat.']

['What were some other important studies?', 'These kinds of studies combine research on attention, perception, teamwork, and human–computer interactions in a field of considerable societal and business significance.']
['What are some other examples of important studies?', 'This is exactly the context of the events that led to the massive data breach for Target in the fall of 2013.']

['What happened during the Target breach?', 'Indications are that security personnel received signals of a security breach but did not interpret them correctly, thus allowing the breach to continue for two weeks until an outside agency, the FBI, informed the company (Riley, Elgin, Lawrence, & Matlack, 2014).']

['What does stress mean?', 'The term stress as it relates to the human condition first emerged in scientific literature in the 1930s, but it did not enter the popular vernacular until the 1970s (Lyon, 2012).']

['What is stress?', 'Today, we often use the term loosely in describing a variety of unpleasant feeling states; for example, we often say we are stressed out when we feel frustrated, angry, conflicted, overwhelmed, or fatigued.']
['Are there any other ways that stress is defined?', 'Despite the widespread use of the term, stress is a fairly vague concept that is difficult to define with precision.']
['What is stress?', 'Researchers have had a difficult time agreeing on an acceptable definition of stress.']
['What are some definitions?', 'Some have conceptualized stress as a demanding or threatening event or situation (e.g., a high-stress job, overcrowding, and long commutes to work).']
['What is the stimulus-based definition?', 'Such conceptualizations are known as stimulus-based definitions because they characterize stress as a stimulus that causes certain reactions.']

['Are they problematic?', 'Stimulus-based definitions of stress are problematic, however, because they fail to recognize that people differ in how they view and react to challenging life events and situations.']

['How else does it differ?', 'For example, a conscientious student who has studied diligently all semester would likely experience less stress during final exams week than would a less responsible, unprepared student.']
['What is stress?', 'Others have conceptualized stress in ways that emphasize the physiological responses that occur when faced with demanding or threatening situations (e.g., increased arousal).']

['How does that definition differ from previous ones?', 'These conceptualizations are referred to as response-based definitions because they describe stress as a response to environmental conditions.']

['What does this mean?', 'For example, the endocrinologist Hans Selye, a famous stress researcher, once defined stress as the “response of the body to any demand, whether it is caused by, or results in, pleasant or unpleasant conditions” (Selye, 1976, p. 74).']

['What is response based?', 'Selye’s definition of stress is response-based in that it conceptualizes stress chiefly in terms of the body’s physiological reaction to any demand that is placed on it.']
['What are other definitions?', 'Neither stimulus-based nor response-based definitions provide a complete definition of stress.']

['What does stimulus based mean?', 'Many of the physiological reactions that occur when faced with demanding situations (e.g., accelerated heart rate) can also occur in response to things that most people would not consider to be genuinely stressful, such as receiving unanticipated good news: an unexpected promotion or raise.']

['What is stress?', 'A useful way to conceptualize stress is to view it as a process whereby an individual perceives and responds to events that they appraise as overwhelming or threatening to their well-being (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']

['How can an individual perceive and respond to stressful events?', 'A critical element of this definition is that it emphasizes the importance of how we appraise—that is, judge—demanding or threatening events (often referred to as stressors); these appraisals, in turn, influence our reactions to such events.']
['How can we appraise stressors?', 'Two kinds of appraisals of a stressor are especially important in this regard: primary and secondary appraisals.']
['What is a primary appraisal?', 'A primary appraisal involves judgment about the degree of potential harm or threat to well-being that a stressor might entail.']

['What is a challenge?', 'A stressor would likely be appraised as a threat if one anticipates that it could lead to some kind of harm, loss, or other negative consequence; conversely, a stressor would likely be appraised as a challenge if one believes that it carries the potential for gain or personal growth.']

['How do we perceive and respond to stress?', 'For example, an employee who is promoted to a leadership position would likely perceive the promotion as a much greater threat if they believed the promotion would lead to excessive work demands than if they viewed it as an opportunity to gain new skills and grow professionally.']
['What other examples of stressors do you have?', 'Similarly, a college student on the cusp of graduation may face the change as a threat or a challenge (Figure 14.2).']

['What are secondary appraisals?', 'The perception of a threat triggers a secondary appraisal: judgment of the options available to cope with a stressor, as well as perceptions of how effective such options will be (Lyon, 2012) (Figure 14.3).']

['What does self-efficacy have to do with stress?', 'As you may recall from what you learned about self-efficacy, an individual’s belief in their ability to complete a task is important (Bandura, 1994).']
['Why does it matter how an individual perceives a threat?', 'A threat tends to be viewed as less catastrophic if one believes something can be done about it (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']

['What is an example of a positive secondary appraisal?', 'Imagine that two middle-aged people, Robin and Madhuri, perform breast self-examinations one morning and each notices a lump on the lower region of their left breast.']
['What did Robin and Madhuri notice?', 'Although both view the breast lump as a potential threat (primary appraisal), their secondary appraisals differ considerably.']
['How does Robin feel?', 'In considering the breast lump, some of the thoughts racing through Robin’s mind are, “Oh my God, I could have breast cancer!']
['What did Madhuri feel?', 'I’ve heard that experience is awful!']
['What are some examples of negative secondary appraisals?', 'My partner and I won’t have enough money to pay the mortgage.']
['What will happen if that is the case?', 'Oh, this is just horrible…I can’t deal with it!”']
['How does Madhuri feel?', 'On the other hand, Madhuri thinks, “Hmm, this may not be good.']
['How does Madhuri proceed?', 'Although most times these things turn out to be benign, I need to have it checked out.']
['What is the positive secondary appraisal?', 'If it turns out to be breast cancer, there are doctors who can take care of it because the medical technology today is quite advanced.']
['What does Madhuri think?', 'I’ll have a lot of different options, and I’ll be just fine.”']

['What is significant about this?', 'Clearly, Robin and Madhuri have different outlooks on what might turn out to be a very serious situation: Robin seems to think that little could be done about it, whereas Madhuri believes that, worst case scenario, a number of options that are likely to be effective would be available.']
['What is happening here?', 'As such, Robin would clearly experience greater stress than would Madhuri.']

['What is stress?', 'To be sure, some stressors are inherently more stressful than others in that they are more threatening and leave less potential for variation in cognitive appraisals (e.g., objective threats to one’s health or safety).']
['What are some examples of threatening events?', 'Nevertheless, appraisal will still play a role in augmenting or diminishing our reactions to such events (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['What is stress?', 'If a person appraises an event as harmful and believes that the demands imposed by the event exceed the available resources to manage or adapt to it, the person will subjectively experience a state of stress.']
['What else should I know about stress?', 'In contrast, if one does not appraise the same event as harmful or threatening, she is unlikely to experience stress.']
['What else does the definition say?', 'According to this definition, environmental events trigger stress reactions by the way they are interpreted and the meanings they are assigned.']
['How is stress defined?', 'In short, stress is largely in the eye of the beholder: it’s not so much what happens to you as it is how you respond (Selye, 1976).']
['Why might there be benefits to good stress?', 'Although stress carries a negative connotation, at times it may be of some benefit.']

['What might stress be of some benefit to us?', 'Stress can motivate us to do things in our best interests, such as study for exams, visit the doctor regularly, exercise, and perform to the best of our ability at work.']
['What else do we know about good stress?', 'Indeed, Selye (1974) pointed out that not all stress is harmful.']
["Why isn't stress harmful?", 'He argued that stress can sometimes be a positive, motivating force that can improve the quality of our lives.']

['What is this positive stress?', 'This kind of stress, which Selye called eustress (from the Greek eu = “good”), is a good kind of stress associated with positive feelings, optimal health, and performance.']
['Does stress contribute to performance?', 'A moderate amount of stress can be beneficial in challenging situations.']
['What challenging situations?', 'For example, athletes may be motivated and energized by pregame stress, and students may experience similar beneficial stress before a major exam.']
['Does stress have any positive effects?', 'Indeed, research shows that moderate stress can enhance both immediate and delayed recall of educational material.']

['What is one example of this?', 'Participants in one study who memorized a scientific text passage showed improved memory of the passage immediately after exposure to a mild stressor as well as one day following exposure to the stressor (Hupbach & Fieman, 2012).']
['How is stress associated with performance?', 'Increasing one’s level of stress will cause performance to change in a predictable way.']

['Can you tell me the example?', 'As shown in Figure 14.4, as stress increases, so do performance and general well-being (eustress); when stress levels reach an optimal level (the highest point of the curve), performance reaches its peak.']

['What does it mean to be at the top of your game?', 'A person at this stress level is colloquially at the top of their game, meaning they feel fully energized, focused, and can work with minimal effort and maximum efficiency.']

['Are there any other important aspects about stress?', 'But when stress exceeds this optimal level, it is no longer a positive force—it becomes excessive and debilitating, or what Selye termed distress (from the Latin dis = “bad”).']
['What is distress?', 'People who reach this level of stress feel burned out; they are fatigued, exhausted, and their performance begins to decline.']
['Why is performance declining?', 'If the stress remains excessive, health may begin to erode as well (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
['What is an example of distress?', 'A good example of distress is severe test anxiety.']

['What happens in a test?', 'When students are feeling very stressed about a test, negative emotions combined with physical symptoms may make concentration difficult, thereby negatively affecting test scores.']
['What is significant about this passage?', 'Stress is everywhere and, as shown in Figure 14.5, it has been on the rise over the last several years.']
['How do people react to this stress?', 'Each of us is acquainted with stress—some are more familiar than others.']

['What are some ways people react to stress?', 'In many ways, stress feels like a load you just can’t carry—a feeling you experience when, for example, you have to drive somewhere in a blizzard, when you wake up late the morning of an important job interview, when you run out of money before the next pay period, and before taking an important exam for which you realize you are not fully prepared.']

['What is stress?', 'Stress is an experience that evokes a variety of responses, including those that are physiological (e.g., accelerated heart rate, headaches, or gastrointestinal problems), cognitive (e.g., difficulty concentrating or making decisions), and behavioral (e.g., drinking alcohol, smoking, or taking actions directed at eliminating the cause of the stress).']

['What is stress like?', 'Although stress can be positive at times, it can have deleterious health implications, contributing to the onset and progression of a variety of physical illnesses and diseases (Cohen & Herbert, 1996).']

['what is the significance of stress in humans?', 'The scientific study of how stress and other psychological factors impact health falls within the realm of health psychology, a subfield of psychology devoted to understanding the importance of psychological influences on health, illness, and how people respond when they become ill (Taylor, 1999).']

['what are some examples of stress?', 'Health psychology emerged as a discipline in the 1970s, a time during which there was increasing awareness of the role behavioral and lifestyle factors play in the development of illnesses and diseases (Straub, 2007).']

['what other topics are discussed in this article?', 'In addition to studying the connection between stress and illness, health psychologists investigate issues such as why people make certain lifestyle choices (e.g., smoking or eating unhealthy food despite knowing the potential adverse health implications of such behaviors).']
['are there any other interesting topics discussed?', 'Health psychologists also design and investigate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at changing unhealthy behaviors.']

['what are some other areas of interest?', 'Perhaps one of the more fundamental tasks of health psychologists is to identify which groups of people are especially at risk for negative health outcomes, based on psychological or behavioral factors.']

['what can psychology do to help identify these groups?', 'For example, measuring differences in stress levels among demographic groups and how these levels change over time can help identify populations who may have an increased risk for illness or disease.']

['What is the Prevalence of Stress?', 'Figure 14.6 depicts the results of three national surveys in which several thousand individuals from different demographic groups completed a brief stress questionnaire; the surveys were administered in 1983, 2006, and 2009 (Cohen & Janicki-Deverts, 2012).']
['What was the most prevalent category of stress?', 'All three surveys demonstrated higher stress in women than in men.']

['What other factors can contribute to stress?', 'Unemployed individuals reported high levels of stress in all three surveys, as did those with less education and income; retired persons reported the lowest stress levels.']

['Are there any other interesting facts in this article?', 'However, from 2006 to 2009 the greatest increase in stress levels occurred among men, Hispanic people aged 45–64, college graduates, and those with full-time employment.']

['Why did the level of stress increase?', 'One interpretation of these findings is that concerns surrounding the 2008–2009 economic downturn (e.g., threat of or actual job loss and substantial loss of retirement savings) may have been especially stressful to college-educated employed men with limited time remaining in their working careers.']
['What is significant about this title?', 'As previously stated, scientific interest in stress goes back nearly a century.']

['What else did we learn about early contributions to stress?', 'One of the early pioneers in the study of stress was Walter Cannon, an eminent American physiologist at Harvard Medical School (Figure 14.7).']
['What did he study?', 'In the early part of the 20th century, Cannon was the first to identify the body’s physiological reactions to stress.']
['What does the study material have to do with a dog?', 'Imagine that you are hiking in the beautiful mountains of Colorado on a warm and sunny spring day.']
['Why does it have to be in Colorado?', 'At one point during your hike, a large, frightening-looking black bear appears from behind a stand of trees and sits about 50 yards from you.']
['What is the bear like?', 'The bear notices you, sits up, and begins to lumber in your direction.']
['What do you think of this encounter?', 'In addition to thinking, “This is definitely not good,” a constellation of physiological reactions begins to take place inside you.']
['What else happens in your body?', 'Prompted by a deluge of epinephrine (adrenaline) and norepinephrine (noradrenaline) from your adrenal glands, your pupils begin to dilate.']

['What else does your body do?', 'Your heart starts to pound and speeds up, you begin to breathe heavily and perspire, you get butterflies in your stomach, and your muscles become tense, preparing you to take some kind of direct action.']

['What can Cannon do to help?', 'Cannon proposed that this reaction, which he called the fight-or-flight response, occurs when a person experiences very strong emotions—especially those associated with a perceived threat (Cannon, 1932).']

['What does the fight-or-flight reaction do?', 'During the fight-or-flight response, the body is rapidly aroused by activation of both the sympathetic nervous system and the endocrine system (Figure 14.8).']
['Why is it aroused?', 'This arousal helps prepare the person to either fight or flee from a perceived threat.']

['What is the fight-or-flight response?', 'According to Cannon, the fight-or-flight response is a built-in mechanism that assists in maintaining homeostasis—an internal environment in which physiological variables such as blood pressure, respiration, digestion, and temperature are stabilized at levels optimal for survival.']

['Why is it an adaptive mechanism?', 'Thus, Cannon viewed the fight-or-flight response as adaptive because it enables people to adjust internally and externally to threats in their environment, allowing them to continue to be alive and overcome the threat.']
['What happened with Hans Selye?', 'Another important early contributor to the stress field was Hans Selye, mentioned earlier.']
['Why was he considered important?', 'He would eventually become one of the world’s foremost experts in the study of stress (Figure 14.9).']
['What is his career background?', 'As a young assistant in the biochemistry department at McGill University in the 1930s, Selye was engaged in research involving sex hormones in rats.']

['What did he discover?', 'Although he was unable to find an answer for what he was initially researching, he incidentally discovered that when exposed to prolonged negative stimulation (stressors)—such as extreme cold, surgical injury, excessive muscular exercise, and shock—the rats showed signs of adrenal enlargement, thymus and lymph node shrinkage, and stomach ulceration.']
['What else did he discover?', 'Selye realized that these responses were triggered by a coordinated series of physiological reactions that unfold over time during continued exposure to a stressor.']
['What else is important to know about Selye?', 'These physiological reactions were nonspecific, which means that regardless of the type of stressor, the same pattern of reactions would occur.']
["What was Selye's discovery?", 'What Selye discovered was the general adaptation syndrome, the body’s nonspecific physiological response to stress.']

['What are the three stages of the general adaptation syndrome?', 'The general adaptation syndrome, shown in Figure 14.10, consists of three stages: (1) alarm reaction, (2) stage of resistance, and (3) stage of exhaustion (Selye, 1936; 1976).']

['What is alarm reaction?', 'Alarm reaction describes the body’s immediate reaction upon facing a threatening situation or emergency, and it is roughly analogous to the fight-or-flight response described by Cannon.']

['What does it mean?', 'During an alarm reaction, you are alerted to a stressor, and your body alarms you with a cascade of physiological reactions that provide you with the energy to manage the situation.']
['What is a common example of alarm reaction?', 'A person who wakes up in the middle of the night to discover her house is on fire, for example, is experiencing an alarm reaction.']
['How do the stages of resistance differ from cellular immunity?', 'If exposure to a stressor is prolonged, the organism will enter the stage of resistance.']
['What are the stages of resistance?', 'During this stage, the initial shock of alarm reaction has worn off and the body has adapted to the stressor.']
['What happens in the resistance stage?', 'Nevertheless, the body also remains on alert and is prepared to respond as it did during the alarm reaction, although with less intensity.']
["How can you apply Selye's general adaptation syndrome to situations?", 'For example, suppose a child who went missing is still missing 72 hours later.']

['Why are they still missing?', 'Although the parents would obviously remain extremely disturbed, the magnitude of physiological reactions would likely have diminished over the 72 intervening hours due to some adaptation to this event.']
['How do stress and the general adaptation syndrome relate?', 'If exposure to a stressor continues over a longer period of time, the stage of exhaustion ensues.']

['What does exhaustion mean?', 'At this stage, the person is no longer able to adapt to the stressor: the body’s ability to resist becomes depleted as physical wear takes its toll on the body’s tissues and organs.']
['What else happens at the stage of exhaustion?', 'As a result, illness, disease, and other permanent damage to the body—even death—may occur.']

['What is the biggest point of this article?', 'If a missing child still remained missing after three months, the long-term stress associated with this situation may cause a parent to literally faint with exhaustion at some point or even to develop a serious and irreversible illness.']

['What does the study say?', 'In short, Selye’s general adaptation syndrome suggests that stressors tax the body via a three-phase process—an initial jolt, subsequent readjustment, and a later depletion of all physical resources—that ultimately lays the groundwork for serious health problems and even death.']

['Is there anything else interesting?', 'It should be pointed out, however, that this model is a response-based conceptualization of stress, focusing exclusively on the body’s physical responses while largely ignoring psychological factors such as appraisal and interpretation of threats.']

['Who is Selye?', 'Nevertheless, Selye’s model has had an enormous impact on the field of stress because it offers a general explanation for how stress can lead to physical damage and, thus, disease.']

['What does it say about health?', 'As we shall discuss later, prolonged or repeated stress has been implicated in development of a number of disorders such as hypertension and coronary artery disease.']

['What are the physiological mechanisms of stress?', 'The physiological mechanisms of stress are extremely complex, but they generally involve the work of two systems—the sympathetic nervous system and the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis.']

['What are the symptoms of stress?', 'When a person first perceives something as stressful (Selye’s alarm reaction), the sympathetic nervous system triggers arousal via the release of adrenaline from the adrenal glands.']
['What is the release of adrenaline used for?', 'Release of these hormones activates the fight-or-flight responses to stress, such as accelerated heart rate and respiration.']

['How is the HPA axis involved with stress?', 'At the same time, the HPA axis, which is primarily endocrine in nature, becomes especially active, although it works much more slowly than the sympathetic nervous system.']

['What is the chemistry involved in this response?', 'In response to stress, the hypothalamus (one of the limbic structures in the brain) releases corticotropin-releasing factor, a hormone that causes the pituitary gland to release adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) (Figure 14.11).']

['What happens when ACTH is released?', 'The ACTH then activates the adrenal glands to secrete a number of hormones into the bloodstream; an important one is cortisol, which can affect virtually every organ within the body.']
['What role does cortisol play?', 'Cortisol is commonly known as a stress hormone and helps provide that boost of energy when we first encounter a stressor, preparing us to run away or fight.']
['What can you tell me about this hormone?', 'However, sustained elevated levels of cortisol weaken the immune system.']

['What are some important facts about this article?', 'In short bursts, this process can have some favorable effects, such as providing extra energy, improving immune system functioning temporarily, and decreasing pain sensitivity.']
['How does prolonged stress affect the body?', 'However, extended release of cortisol—as would happen with prolonged or chronic stress—often comes at a high price.']
['What are some of the harmful effects?', 'High levels of cortisol have been shown to produce a number of harmful effects.']

['What harmful effects?', 'For example, increases in cortisol can significantly weaken our immune system (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005), and high levels are frequently observed among depressed individuals (Geoffroy, Hertzman, Li, & Power, 2013).']

['What is the basis of stress?', 'In summary, a stressful event causes a variety of physiological reactions that activate the adrenal glands, which in turn release epinephrine, norepinephrine, and cortisol.']

['What happens when the adrenal glands release cortisol?', 'These hormones affect a number of bodily processes in ways that prepare the stressed person to take direct action, but also in ways that may heighten the potential for illness.']
['What is the Physiological Basis of Stress?', 'When stress is extreme or chronic, it can have profoundly negative consequences.']

['What negative consequences can it have?', 'For example, stress often contributes to the development of certain psychological disorders, including post-traumatic stress disorder, major depressive disorder, and other serious psychiatric conditions.']
['What other consequences can stress have?', 'Additionally, we noted earlier that stress is linked to the development and progression of a variety of physical illnesses and diseases.']

['What physical illnesses?', 'For example, researchers in one study found that people injured during the September 11, 2001, World Trade Center disaster or who developed post-traumatic stress symptoms afterward later suffered significantly elevated rates of heart disease (Jordan, Miller-Archie, Cone, Morabia, & Stellman, 2011).']

['What other diseases can stress cause?', 'Another investigation yielded that self-reported stress symptoms among aging and retired Finnish food industry workers were associated with morbidity 11 years later.']
['What happened as a result of that?', 'This study also predicted the onset of musculoskeletal, nervous system, and endocrine and metabolic disorders (Salonen, Arola, Nygård, & Huhtala, 2008).']

['Did they also find other things that stress caused?', 'Another study reported that male South Korean manufacturing employees who reported high levels of work-related stress were more likely to catch the common cold over the next several months than were those employees who reported lower work-related stress levels (Park et al., 2011).']
['What else can it do?', 'Later, you will explore the mechanisms through which stress can produce physical illness and disease.']
['What is stress?', 'For an individual to experience stress, they must first encounter a potential stressor.']
['What are some stressors?', 'In general, stressors can be placed into one of two broad categories: chronic and acute.']

['What happens during chronic stress?', 'Chronic stressors include events that persist over an extended period of time, such as caring for a parent with dementia, long-term unemployment, or imprisonment.']

['What happens during acute stress?', 'Acute stressors involve brief focal events that sometimes continue to be experienced as overwhelming well after the event has ended, such as falling on an icy sidewalk and breaking your leg (Cohen, Janicki-Deverts, & Miller, 2007).']
['What else can stressors do?', 'Whether chronic or acute, potential stressors come in many shapes and sizes.']

['How many can stressors be?', 'They can include major traumatic events, significant life changes, daily hassles, as well as other situations in which a person is regularly exposed to threat, challenge, or danger.']
['What kind of traumatic events are we studying?', 'Some stressors involve traumatic events or situations in which a person is exposed to actual or threatened death or serious injury.']

['Who was exposed to these events?', 'Stressors in this category include exposure to military combat, threatened or actual physical assaults (e.g., physical attacks, sexual assault, robbery, childhood abuse), terrorist attacks, natural disasters (e.g., earthquakes, floods, hurricanes), and automobile accidents.']

['Who had the most exposure?', 'Men, non-White people, and individuals in lower socioeconomic status (SES) groups report experiencing a greater number of traumatic events than do women, White people, and individuals in higher SES groups (Hatch & Dohrenwend, 2007).']

['What did these events do to them?', 'Some individuals who are exposed to stressors of extreme magnitude develop post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a chronic stress reaction characterized by experiences and behaviors that may include intrusive and painful memories of the stressor event, jumpiness, persistent negative emotional states, detachment from others, angry outbursts, and avoidance of reminders of the event (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013).']
['What does it mean to have experienced life changes?', 'Most stressors that we encounter are not nearly as intense as the ones described above.']

['How does the stressor affect us?', 'Many potential stressors we face involve events or situations that require us to make changes in our ongoing lives and require time as we adjust to those changes.']
['What are some examples?', 'Examples include death of a close family member, marriage, divorce, and moving (Figure 14.12).']

['What is the first thing you learn about this article?', 'In the 1960s, psychiatrists Thomas Holmes and Richard Rahe wanted to examine the link between life stressors and physical illness, based on the hypothesis that life events requiring significant changes in a person’s normal life routines are stressful, whether these events are desirable or undesirable.']
['What is the SRRS?', 'They developed the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS), consisting of 43 life events that require varying degrees of personal readjustment (Holmes & Rahe, 1967).']

['What is an example of eustress?', 'Many life events that most people would consider pleasant (e.g., holidays, retirement, marriage) are among those listed on the SRRS; these are examples of eustress.']

['What is stressing?', 'Holmes and Rahe also proposed that life events can add up over time, and that experiencing a cluster of stressful events increases one’s risk of developing physical illnesses.']

['What does life change mean?', 'In developing their scale, Holmes and Rahe asked 394 participants to provide a numerical estimate for each of the 43 items; each estimate corresponded to how much readjustment participants felt each event would require.']
['Did they find the scale helpful?', 'These estimates resulted in mean value scores for each event—often called life change units (LCUs) (Rahe, McKeen, & Arthur, 1967).']
['What was the scale?', 'The numerical scores ranged from 11 to 100, representing the perceived magnitude of life change each event entails.']
['What other events do they look at?', 'Death of a spouse ranked highest on the scale with 100 LCUs, and divorce ranked second highest with 73 LCUs.']
['What else did they find out?', 'In addition, personal injury or illness, marriage, and job termination also ranked highly on the scale with 53, 50, and 47 LCUs, respectively.']
['What other events were listed?', 'Conversely, change in residence (20 LCUs), change in eating habits (15 LCUs), and vacation (13 LCUs) ranked low on the scale (Table 14.1).']
['What else were some of the events?', 'Minor violations of the law ranked the lowest with 11 LCUs.']
['What else did they do?', 'To complete the scale, participants checked yes for events experienced within the last 12 months.']
['How was the scale re-calculated?', 'LCUs for each checked item are totaled for a score quantifying the amount of life change.']
['What else did they find out?', 'Agreement on the amount of adjustment required by the various life events on the SRRS is highly consistent, even cross-culturally (Holmes & Masuda, 1974).']

['What is Life Changes?', 'Extensive research has demonstrated that accumulating a high number of life change units within a brief period of time (one or two years) is related to a wide range of physical illnesses (even accidents and athletic injuries) and mental health problems (Monat & Lazarus, 1991; Scully, Tosi, & Banning, 2000).']
['What else does this article have to do with?', 'In an early demonstration, researchers obtained LCU scores for U.S. and Norwegian Navy personnel who were about to embark on a six-month voyage.']

['Was this a successful test?', 'A later examination of medical records revealed positive (but small) correlations between LCU scores prior to the voyage and subsequent illness symptoms during the ensuing six-month journey (Rahe, 1974).']

['What other results were there?', 'In addition, people tend to experience more physical symptoms, such as backache, upset stomach, diarrhea, and acne, on specific days in which self-reported LCU values are considerably higher than normal, such as the day of a family member’s wedding (Holmes & Holmes, 1970).']

['What was the SRRS?', 'The Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS) provides researchers a simple, easy-to-administer way of assessing the amount of stress in people’s lives, and it has been used in hundreds of studies (Thoits, 2010).']
['Was the scale criticized?', 'Despite its widespread use, the scale has been subject to criticism.']

['Why was it criticised?', 'First, many of the items on the SRRS are vague; for example, death of a close friend could involve the death of a long-absent childhood friend that requires little social readjustment (Dohrenwend, 2006).']
['What else was wrong with the scale?', 'In addition, some have challenged its assumption that undesirable life events are no more stressful than desirable ones (Derogatis & Coons, 1993).']

['How did they challenge this assumption?', 'However, most of the available evidence suggests that, at least as far as mental health is concerned, undesirable or negative events are more strongly associated with poor outcomes (such as depression) than are desirable, positive events (Hatch & Dohrenwend, 2007).']
['What other criticism was there?', 'Perhaps the most serious criticism is that the scale does not take into consideration respondents’ appraisals of the life events it contains.']
['What is an appraisal?', 'As you recall, appraisal of a stressor is a key element in the conceptualization and overall experience of stress.']
['What is an appraisal?', 'Being fired from work may be devastating to some but a welcome opportunity to obtain a better job for others.']

['What was the final conclusion of this article?', 'The SRRS remains one of the most well-known instruments in the study of stress, and it is a useful tool for identifying potential stress-related health outcomes (Scully et al., 2000).']
['What might be the problem with having stress in our lives?', 'Potential stressors do not always involve major life events.']

['What are some of the stressors?', 'Daily hassles—the minor irritations and annoyances that are part of our everyday lives (e.g., rush hour traffic, lost keys, obnoxious coworkers, inclement weather, arguments with friends or family)—can build on one another and leave us just as stressed as life change events (Figure 14.13) (Kanner, Coyne, Schaefer, & Lazarus, 1981).']

['What are the main ideas of Hassles?', 'Researchers have demonstrated that the frequency of daily hassles is actually a better predictor of both physical and psychological health than are life change units.']

['What is the evidence of that?', 'In a well-known study of San Francisco residents, the frequency of daily hassles was found to be more strongly associated with physical health problems than were life change events (DeLongis, Coyne, Dakof, Folkman, & Lazarus, 1982).']

['What else is known about hassles?', 'In addition, daily minor hassles, especially interpersonal conflicts, often lead to negative and distressed mood states (Bolger, DeLongis, Kessler, & Schilling, 1989).']
['What else does it discuss?', 'Cyber hassles that occur on social media may represent a modern and evolving source of stress.']

['What else do they have to say?', 'In one investigation, social media stress was tied to loss of sleep in adolescents, presumably because ruminating about social media caused a physiological stress response that increased arousal (van der Schuur, Baumgartner, & Sumter, 2018).']
['What else does the article discuss?', 'Clearly, daily hassles can add up and take a toll on us both emotionally and physically.']
['What subject is the material about?', 'OCCUPATION-RELATED']
['What does OCCUPATION-RELATED mean?', 'Stressors.']
['what is stress?', 'Stressors can include situations in which one is frequently exposed to challenging and unpleasant events, such as difficult, demanding, or unsafe working conditions.']
['what are some examples of stress?', 'Although most jobs and occupations can at times be demanding, some are clearly more stressful than others (Figure 14.14).']
['who are the examples?', 'For example, most people would likely agree that a firefighter’s work is inherently more stressful than that of a florist.']

['what is one more example?', 'Equally likely, most would agree that jobs containing various unpleasant elements, such as those requiring exposure to loud noise (heavy equipment operator), constant harassment and threats of physical violence (prison guard), perpetual frustration (bus driver in a major city), or those mandating that an employee work alternating day and night shifts (hotel desk clerk), are much more demanding—and thus, more stressful—than those that do not contain such elements.']
['what is a specific stressor?', 'Table 14.2 lists several occupations and some of the specific stressors associated with those occupations (Sulsky & Smith, 2005).']

['what is the most important point?', 'Although the specific stressors for these occupations are diverse, they seem to share some common denominators such as heavy workload and uncertainty about and lack of control over certain aspects of a job.']

['what does stress contribute to?', 'Chronic occupational stress contributes to job strain, a work situation that combines excessive job demands and workload with little discretion in decision making or job control (Karasek & Theorell, 1990).']

['what else does it contribute to?', 'Clearly, many occupations other than the ones listed in Table 14.2 involve at least a moderate amount of job strain in that they often involve heavy workloads and little job control (e.g., inability to decide when to take breaks).']
['what are some examples of those occupations?', 'Such jobs are often low-status and include those of factory workers, postal clerks, supermarket cashiers, taxi drivers, and short-order cooks.']

['what is job strain?', 'Job strain can have adverse consequences on both physical and mental health; it has been shown to be associated with increased risk of hypertension (Schnall & Landsbergis, 1994), heart attacks (Theorell et al., 1998), recurrence of heart disease after a first heart attack (Aboa-Éboulé et al., 2007), significant weight loss or gain (Kivimäki et al., 2006), and major depressive disorder (Stansfeld, Shipley, Head, & Fuhrer, 2012).']

['how can job strain impact health?', 'A longitudinal study of over 10,000 British civil servants reported that workers under 50 years old who earlier had reported high job strain were 68% more likely to later develop heart disease than were those workers under 50 years old who reported little job strain (Chandola et al., 2008).']

['What does burnout mean?', 'Some people who are exposed to chronically stressful work conditions can experience job burnout, which is a general sense of emotional exhaustion and cynicism in relation to one’s job (Maslach & Jackson, 1981).']
['Does burnout occur with anyone in particular?', 'Job burnout occurs frequently among those in human service jobs (e.g., social workers, teachers, therapists, and police officers).']
['What does burnout consist of?', 'Job burnout consists of three dimensions.']

['What is the first dimension?', 'The first dimension is exhaustion—a sense that one’s emotional resources are drained or that one is at the end of their rope and has nothing more to give at a psychological level.']

['What is the second dimension?', 'Second, job burnout is characterized by depersonalization: a sense of emotional detachment between the worker and the recipients of their services, often resulting in callous, cynical, or indifferent attitudes toward these individuals.']

['What is the third dimension?', 'Third, job burnout is characterized by diminished personal accomplishment, which is the tendency to evaluate one’s work negatively by, for example, experiencing dissatisfaction with one’s job-related accomplishments or feeling as though one has categorically failed to influence others’ lives through one’s work.']

['What is a significant fact about this article?', 'Job strain appears to be one of the greatest risk factors leading to job burnout, which is most commonly observed in workers who are older (ages 55–64), unmarried, and whose jobs involve manual labor.']

['What else is a factor in job burnout?', 'Heavy alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, being overweight, and having a physical or lifetime mental disorder are also associated with job burnout (Ahola, et al., 2006).']
['What else is there to know about this topic?', 'In addition, depression often co-occurs with job burnout.']

['How does this affect the workplace?', 'One large-scale study of over 3,000 Finnish employees reported that half of the participants with severe job burnout had some form of depressive disorder (Ahola et al., 2005).']

['What else is important about job burnout?', 'Job burnout is often precipitated by feelings of having invested considerable energy, effort, and time into one’s work while receiving little in return (e.g., little respect or support from others or low pay) (Tatris, Peeters, Le Blanc, Schreurs, & Schaufeli, 2001).']
['What are some examples of Hassles?', 'As an illustration, consider Tyre, a nursing assistant who worked in a nursing home.']
['What happened to Tyre?', 'Tyre worked long hours for little pay in a difficult facility.']

['What was the problem with the facility?', "Tyre's supervisor was domineering, unpleasant, and unsupportive, as well as disrespectful of Tyre's personal time, frequently informing them at the last minute they must work several additional hours after their shift ended or report to work on weekends."]
['What else did Tyre experience?', 'Tyre had very little autonomy at work.']
['What was one thing Tyre had to do?', 'They had little input in day-to-day duties and how to perform them, and was not permitted to take breaks unless explicitly told by their supervisor.']
['What other things happened to Tyre?', 'Tyre did not feel as though their hard work was appreciated, either by supervisory staff or by the residents of the home.']
['What else is significant about the example?', 'Tyre was very unhappy over the low pay, and felt that many of the residents treated them disrespectfully.']
['What were the struggles of his parents?', 'After several years,']
['Tyre and Dee Dee began to hate their job.', 'Tyre began to hate their job.']
['What caused this?', 'Tyre dreaded going to work in the morning, and gradually developed a callous, hostile attitude toward many of the residents.']
['How did this affect his parents?', 'Eventually, they began to feel they could no longer help the nursing home residents.']
