['How did they solve this?', 'Tyre’s absenteeism from work increased, and one day they decided that they had had enough and quit.']
['What did Tyre do after leaving the nursing home?', 'Tyre now has a job in sales, vowing never to work in nursing again.']
['What is Hassles about?', 'Finally, our close relationships with friends and family—particularly the negative aspects of these relationships—can be a potent source of stress.']

['What are some negative aspects of close relationships?', 'Negative aspects of close relationships can include conflicts such as disagreements or arguments, lack of emotional support or confiding, and lack of reciprocity.']
['What can happen as a result of the negative aspects?', 'All of these can be overwhelming, threatening to the relationship, and thus stressful.']
['How does stress affect you?', 'Such stressors can take a toll both emotionally and physically.']

['What other effects do negative relationships have?', 'A longitudinal investigation of over 9,000 British civil servants found that those who at one point had reported the highest levels of negative interactions in their closest relationship were 34% more likely to experience serious heart problems (fatal or nonfatal heart attacks) over a 13–15 year period, compared to those who experienced the lowest levels of negative interaction (De Vogli, Chandola & Marmot, 2007).']
['what is this section about?', 'In this section, we will discuss stress and illness.']
['what is stress?', 'As stress researcher Robert Sapolsky (1998) describes,']
['What is the stress response?', 'The stress response, as noted earlier, consists of a coordinated but complex system of physiological reactions that are called upon as needed.']

['What reactions are needed?', 'These reactions are beneficial at times because they prepare us to deal with potentially dangerous or threatening situations (for example, recall our old friend, the fearsome bear on the trail).']
['Why are physiological reactions beneficial?', 'However, health is affected when physiological reactions are sustained, as can happen in response to ongoing stress.']

['What is the meaning of chronic stress?', 'If the reactions that compose the stress response are chronic or if they frequently exceed normal ranges, they can lead to cumulative wear and tear on the body, in much the same way that running your air conditioner on full blast all summer will eventually cause wear and tear on it.']

['What are some ways chronic stress can damage the body?', 'For example, the high blood pressure that a person under considerable job strain experiences might eventually take a toll on their heart and set the stage for a heart attack or heart failure.']

['What are some other things chronic stress can damage?', 'Also, someone exposed to high levels of the stress hormone cortisol might become vulnerable to infection or disease because of weakened immune system functioning (McEwen, 1998).']
['What is psychophysiological disorders?', 'Physical disorders or diseases whose symptoms are brought about or worsened by stress and emotional factors are called psychophysiological disorders.']

['How does stress affect the body?', 'The physical symptoms of psychophysiological disorders are real and they can be produced or exacerbated by psychological factors (hence the psycho and physiological in psychophysiological).']
['What are some common disorders?', 'A list of frequently encountered psychophysiological disorders is provided in Table 14.3.']
['What is one important study in this title?', 'Friedman and Booth-Kewley (1987) statistically reviewed 101 studies to examine the link between personality and illness.']
['What does this study say about personality?', 'They proposed the existence of disease-prone personality characteristics, including depression, anger/hostility, and anxiety.']

['What did this study say about depression?', 'Indeed, a study of over 61,000 Norwegians identified depression as a risk factor for all major disease-related causes of death (Mykletun et al., 2007).']

['What else is significant about depression?', 'In addition, neuroticism—a personality trait that reflects how anxious, moody, and sad one is—has been identified as a risk factor for chronic health problems and mortality (Ploubidis & Grundy, 2009).']
['How are they diagnosed?', 'Below, we discuss two kinds of psychophysiological disorders about which a great deal is known: cardiovascular disorders and asthma.']

['Do they both lead to a variety of illnesses?', 'First, however, it is necessary to turn our attention to a discussion of the immune system—one of the major pathways through which stress and emotional factors can lead to illness and disease.']
['What is the immune system?', 'In a sense, the immune system is the body’s surveillance system.']

['What is the body’s surveillance system for?', 'It consists of a variety of structures, cells, and mechanisms that serve to protect the body from invading microorganisms that can harm or damage the body’s tissues and organs.']

['Does the immune system make us healthy?', 'When the immune system is working as it should, it keeps us healthy and disease free by eliminating harmful bacteria, viruses, and other foreign substances that have entered the body (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
['What do the immune system errors include?', 'Sometimes, the immune system will function erroneously.']
['What will the immune system erroneously do?', 'For example, sometimes it can go awry by mistaking your body’s own healthy cells for invaders and repeatedly attacking them.']
['Why does the immune system mistaking its own cells for invaders attack?', 'When this happens, the person is said to have an autoimmune disease, which can affect almost any part of the body.']
['Why do people have autoimmune diseases?', 'How an autoimmune disease affects a person depends on what part of the body is targeted.']

['What is an example of how the body part gets targeted?', 'For instance, rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disease that affects the joints, results in joint pain, stiffness, and loss of function.']
['How does the body react to it?', 'Systemic lupus erythematosus, an autoimmune disease that affects the skin, can result in rashes and swelling of the skin.']

['What other diseases do the immune system cause?', 'Grave’s disease, an autoimmune disease that affects the thyroid gland, can result in fatigue, weight gain, and muscle aches (National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases [NIAMS], 2012).']
['What are immune system errors?', 'In addition, the immune system may sometimes break down and be unable to do its job.']
['What is this job called?', 'This situation is referred to as immunosuppression, the decreased effectiveness of the immune system.']
['What can happen if the immune system is ineffective?', 'When people experience immunosuppression, they become susceptible to any number of infections, illness, and diseases.']

['What can be an example of immunosuppression?', 'For example, acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is a serious and lethal disease that is caused by human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which greatly weakens the immune system by infecting and destroying antibody-producing cells, thus rendering an untreated person vulnerable to any of a number of opportunistic infections (Powell, 1996).']

['What are some of the important facts about Stressors and Immune Function?', 'The question of whether stress and negative emotional states can influence immune function has captivated researchers for over three decades, and discoveries made over that time have dramatically changed the face of health psychology (Kiecolt-Glaser, 2009).']
['What is psychoneuroimmunology?', 'Psychoneuroimmunology is the field that studies how psychological factors such as stress influence the immune system and immune functioning.']

['When was this discipline first developed?', 'The term psychoneuroimmunology was first coined in 1981, when it appeared as the title of a book that reviewed available evidence for associations between the brain, endocrine system, and immune system (Zacharie, 2009).']

['What is the connection between brain and immune system?', 'To a large extent, this field evolved from the discovery that there is a connection between the central nervous system and the immune system.']

['What are some things you learned about stressors and immune function?', 'Some of the most compelling evidence for a connection between the brain and the immune system comes from studies in which researchers demonstrated that immune responses in animals could be classically conditioned (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['What is an example of this?', 'For example, Ader and Cohen (1975) paired flavored water (the conditioned stimulus) with the presentation of an immunosuppressive drug (the unconditioned stimulus), causing sickness (an unconditioned response).']
['Did it work?', 'Not surprisingly, rats exposed to this pairing developed a conditioned aversion to the flavored water.']

['What else is notable about this study?', 'However, the taste of the water itself later produced immunosuppression (a conditioned response), indicating that the immune system itself had been conditioned.']
['Were other studies done?', 'Many subsequent studies over the years have further demonstrated that immune responses can be classically conditioned in both animals and humans (Ader & Cohen, 2001).']
['What else do you learn about the studies?', 'Thus, if classical conditioning can alter immunity, other psychological factors should be capable of altering it as well.']

['What is Stressors and Immune Function?', 'Hundreds of studies involving tens of thousands of participants have tested many kinds of brief and chronic stressors and their effects on the immune system (e.g., public speaking, medical school examinations, unemployment, marital discord, divorce, death of spouse, burnout and job strain, caring for a relative with Alzheimer’s disease, and exposure to the harsh climate of Antarctica).']

['What effect do the studies have?', 'It has been repeatedly demonstrated that many kinds of stressors are associated with poor or weakened immune functioning (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005; Kiecolt-Glaser, McGuire, Robles, & Glaser, 2002; Segerstrom & Miller, 2004).']
['What else are you studying right now?', 'When evaluating these findings, it is important to remember that there is a tangible physiological connection between the brain and the immune system.']
['What is that connection?', 'For example, the sympathetic nervous system innervates immune organs such as the thymus, bone marrow, spleen, and even lymph nodes (Maier, Watkins, & Fleshner, 1994).']

['What else does the paper say about this connection?', 'Also, we noted earlier that stress hormones released during hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis activation can adversely impact immune function.']

['What else does this mean?', 'One way they do this is by inhibiting the production of lymphocytes, white blood cells that circulate in the body’s fluids that are important in the immune response (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['What are some of the examples of stressors and immune function?', 'Some of the more dramatic examples demonstrating the link between stress and impaired immune function involve studies in which volunteers were exposed to viruses.']

['What does this research suggest?', 'The rationale behind this research is that because stress weakens the immune system, people with high stress levels should be more likely to develop an illness compared to those under little stress.']
['Is there any proof of this theory?', 'In one memorable experiment using this method, researchers interviewed 276 healthy volunteers about recent stressful experiences (Cohen et al., 1998).']

['What were the volunteers asked?', 'Following the interview, these participants were given nasal drops containing the cold virus (in case you are wondering why anybody would ever want to participate in a study in which they are subjected to such treatment, the participants were paid $800 for their trouble).']

['What was found in the study?', 'When examined later, participants who reported experiencing chronic stressors for more than one month—especially enduring difficulties involving work or relationships—were considerably more likely to have developed colds than were participants who reported no chronic stressors (Figure 14.15).']
['How did it work?', 'In another study, older volunteers were given an influenza virus vaccination.']

['What did they find?', 'Compared to controls, those who were caring for a spouse with Alzheimer’s disease (and thus were under chronic stress) showed poorer antibody response following the vaccination (Kiecolt-Glaser, Glaser, Gravenstein, Malarkey, & Sheridan, 1996).']

['What are some of the other articles in the study material?', 'Other studies have demonstrated that stress slows down wound healing by impairing immune responses important to wound repair (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005).']
['What other evidence is there?', 'In one study, for example, skin blisters were induced on the forearm.']
['What was the effect?', 'Subjects who reported higher levels of stress produced lower levels of immune proteins necessary for wound healing (Glaser et al., 1999).']

['What happens if we stress?', 'Stress, then, is not so much the sword that kills the knight, so to speak; rather, it’s the sword that breaks the knight’s shield, and your immune system is that shield.']
["What's the cardiovascular system?", 'The cardiovascular system is composed of the heart and blood circulation system.']

['What is an example of a cardiovascular disorder?', 'For many years, disorders that involve the cardiovascular system—known as cardiovascular disorders—have been a major focal point in the study of psychophysiological disorders because of the cardiovascular system’s centrality in the stress response (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
['What are some other examples of cardiovascular disorders?', 'Heart disease is one such condition.']

['How common is heart disease?', 'Each year, heart disease causes approximately one in three deaths in the United States, and it is the leading cause of death in the developed world (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2011; Shapiro, 2005).']

['What are the symptoms?', 'The symptoms of heart disease vary somewhat depending on the specific kind of heart disease one has, but they generally involve angina—chest pains or discomfort that occur when the heart does not receive enough blood (Office on Women’s Health, 2009).']
['How does it feel?', 'The pain often feels like the chest is being pressed or squeezed; burning sensations in the chest and shortness of breath are also commonly reported.']
['What else does it feel like?', 'Such pain and discomfort can spread to the arms, neck, jaws, stomach (as nausea), and back (American Heart Association [AHA], 2012a) (Figure 14.17).']
['What is a risk factor for heart disease?', 'A major risk factor for heart disease is hypertension, which is high blood pressure.']
['What causes high blood pressure?', 'Hypertension forces a person’s heart to pump harder, thus putting more physical strain on the heart.']
['What can high blood pressure lead to?', 'If left unchecked, hypertension can lead to a heart attack, stroke, or heart failure; it can also lead to kidney failure and blindness.']

['What else is significant about high blood pressure?', 'Hypertension is a serious cardiovascular disorder, and it is sometimes called the silent killer because it has no symptoms—one who has high blood pressure may not even be aware of it (AHA, 2012b).']
['What is a risk factor for cardiovascular disorders?', 'Many risk factors contributing to cardiovascular disorders have been identified.']

['What are the risks?', 'These risk factors include social determinants such as aging, income, education, and employment status, as well as behavioral risk factors that include unhealthy diet, tobacco use, physical inactivity, and excessive alcohol consumption; obesity and diabetes are additional risk factors (World Health Organization [WHO], 2013).']

['what is the importance of stress?', 'Over the past few decades, there has been much greater recognition and awareness of the importance of stress and other psychological factors in cardiovascular health (Nusair, Al-dadah, & Kumar, 2012).']

['what are the different kinds of stress?', 'Indeed, exposure to stressors of many kinds has also been linked to cardiovascular problems; in the case of hypertension, some of these stressors include job strain (Trudel, Brisson, & Milot, 2010), natural disasters (Saito, Kim, Maekawa, Ikeda, & Yokoyama, 1997), marital conflict (Nealey-Moore, Smith, Uchino, Hawkins, & Olson-Cerny, 2007), and exposure to high traffic noise levels at one’s home (de Kluizenaar, Gansevoort, Miedema, & de Jong, 2007).']
['who has hypertension?', 'Perceived discrimination appears to be associated with hypertension among African Americans (Sims et al., 2012).']

['how do you increase your stress?', 'In addition, laboratory-based stress tasks, such as performing mental arithmetic under time pressure, immersing one’s hand into ice water (known as the cold pressor test), mirror tracing, and public speaking have all been shown to elevate blood pressure (Phillips, 2011).']
['What can be learned from this?', 'Sometimes research ideas and theories emerge from seemingly trivial observations.']
['How did Friedman come up with his theory?', 'In the 1950s, cardiologist Meyer Friedman was looking over his waiting room furniture, which consisted of upholstered chairs with armrests.']
['Why did he think they were good?', 'Friedman decided to have these chairs reupholstered.']

['Did this work?', 'When the man doing the reupholstering came to the office to do the work, he commented on how the chairs were worn in a unique manner—the front edges of the cushions were worn down, as were the front tips of the arm rests.']

['Why were they worn down?', 'It seemed like the cardiology patients were tapping or squeezing the front of the armrests, as well as literally sitting on the edge of their seats (Friedman & Rosenman, 1974).']

['What did Friedman do in his work?', 'After researching this matter, Friedman and his colleague, Ray Rosenman, came to understand that people who are prone to heart disease tend to think, feel, and act differently than those who are not.']
['What types of people are at risk of heart disease?', 'These individuals tend to be intensively driven workaholics who are preoccupied with deadlines and always seem to be in a rush.']

['Are they always in a rush?', 'According to Friedman and Rosenman, these individuals exhibit Type A behavior pattern; those who are more relaxed and laid-back were characterized as Type B (Figure 14.18).']

['What else did he do in his work?', 'In a sample of Type As and Type Bs, Friedman and Rosenman were startled to discover that heart disease was over seven times more frequent among the Type As than the Type Bs (Friedman & Rosenman, 1959).']

['What are some things you will need to know before studying this material?', 'The major components of the Type A pattern include an aggressive and chronic struggle to achieve more and more in less and less time (Friedman & Rosenman, 1974).']

["What else is the 'type'?", 'Specific characteristics of the Type A pattern include an excessive competitive drive, chronic sense of time urgency, impatience, and hostility toward others (particularly those who get in the person’s way).']
['What type of personality does the content describe?', 'An example of a person who exhibits Type A behavior pattern is Jeffrey.']
['What was his personality like?', 'Even as a child, Jeffrey was intense and driven.']
['What kind of accomplishments did he have?', 'He excelled at school, was captain of the swim team, and graduated with honors from an Ivy League college.']
['What else did you find interesting about this article?', 'Jeffrey never seems able to relax; he is always working on something, even on the weekends.']
['What about his work-life balance?', 'However, Jeffrey always seems to feel as though there are not enough hours in the day to accomplish all he feels he should.']

['How does this effect his relationships with others?', 'He volunteers to take on extra tasks at work and often brings his work home with him; he often goes to bed frustrated late at night because he feels that he has not done enough.']

['Why does this effect his friends and family?', 'Jeffrey is quick tempered with his coworkers; he often becomes noticeably agitated when dealing with those coworkers he feels work too slowly or whose work does not meet his standards.']
['What else is significant?', 'He typically reacts with hostility when interrupted at work.']
['What did this do to his health?', 'He has experienced problems in his marriage over his lack of time spent with family.']
['Does he have any other problems with his mental health?', 'When caught in traffic during his commute to and from work, Jeffrey incessantly pounds on his horn and swears loudly at other drivers.']
['What was the biggest challenge of his life?', 'When Jeffrey was 52, he suffered his first heart attack.']

['What else is important about the content of this page?', 'By the 1970s, a majority of practicing cardiologists believed that Type A behavior pattern was a significant risk factor for heart disease (Friedman, 1977).']

['what is significant about this opinion?', 'Indeed, a number of early longitudinal investigations demonstrated a link between Type A behavior pattern and later development of heart disease (Rosenman et al., 1975; Haynes, Feinleib, & Kannel, 1980).']
['What is this article about?', 'Subsequent research examining the association between Type A and heart disease, however, failed to replicate these earlier findings (Glassman, 2007; Myrtek, 2001).']

['Why was this theory not confirmed?', 'Because Type A theory did not pan out as well as they had hoped, researchers shifted their attention toward determining if any of the specific elements of Type A predict heart disease.']

['What are type A and type B?', 'Extensive research clearly suggests that the anger/hostility dimension of Type A behavior pattern may be one of the most important factors in the development of heart disease.']

['What are some studies about anger?', 'This relationship was initially described in the Haynes et al. (1980) study mentioned above: Suppressed hostility was found to substantially elevate the risk of heart disease for both men and women.']
['Are there any other studies?', 'Also, one investigation followed over 1,000 male medical students from 32 to 48 years.']

['What happened during this study?', 'At the beginning of the study, these men completed a questionnaire assessing how they react to pressure; some indicated that they respond with high levels of anger, whereas others indicated that they respond with less anger.']

['What results did the study come up with?', 'Decades later, researchers found that those who earlier had indicated the highest levels of anger were over 6 times more likely than those who indicated less anger to have had a heart attack by age 55, and they were 3.5 times more likely to have experienced heart disease by the same age (Chang, Ford, Meoni, Wang, & Klag, 2002).']
['Can anger cause any other health problems?', 'From a health standpoint, it clearly does not pay to be an angry person.']

['What is an example of a type B personality?', 'After reviewing and statistically summarizing 35 studies from 1983 to 2006, Chida and Steptoe (2009) concluded that the bulk of the evidence suggests that anger and hostility constitute serious long-term risk factors for adverse cardiovascular outcomes among both healthy individuals and those already suffering from heart disease.']

['What is the evidence for this?', 'One reason angry and hostile moods might contribute to cardiovascular diseases is that such moods can create social strain, mainly in the form of antagonistic social encounters with others.']
['What does this mean?', 'This strain could then lay the foundation for disease-promoting cardiovascular responses among hostile individuals (Vella, Kamarck, Flory, & Manuck, 2012).']
['What kind of patterns do you see with hostility?', 'In this transactional model, hostility and social strain form a cycle (Figure 14.19).']

['What are some examples of types?', 'For example, suppose Kaitlin has a hostile disposition; she has a cynical, distrustful attitude toward others and often thinks that other people are out to get her.']

['What else would you tell me about her behavior?', 'She is very defensive around people, even those she has known for years, and she is always looking for signs that others are either disrespecting or belittling her.']

['What other interesting information did you find in this article?', 'In the shower each morning before work, she often mentally rehearses what she would say to someone who said or did something that angered her, such as making a political statement that was counter to her own ideology.']
['Does she do this for a reason?', 'As Kaitlin goes through these mental rehearsals, she often grins and thinks about the retaliation on anyone who will irk her that day.']

['What are some characteristics of Type B individuals?', 'Socially, she is confrontational and tends to use a harsh tone with people, which often leads to very disagreeable and sometimes argumentative social interactions.']
['Do they tend to get into conflict with others?', 'As you might imagine, Kaitlin is not especially popular with others, including coworkers, neighbors, and even members of her own family.']

['How does she treat them?', 'They either avoid her at all costs or snap back at her, which causes Kaitlin to become even more cynical and distrustful of others, making her disposition even more hostile.']

['Do they suffer health consequences?', 'Kaitlin’s hostility—through her own doing—has created an antagonistic environment that cyclically causes her to become even more hostile and angry, thereby potentially setting the stage for cardiovascular problems.']

['What is Type B?', 'In addition to anger and hostility, a number of other negative emotional states have been linked with heart disease, including negative affectivity and depression (Suls & Bunde, 2005).']

['What is negative affectivity?', 'Negative affectivity is a tendency to experience distressed emotional states involving anger, contempt, disgust, guilt, fear, and nervousness (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988).']
['What else is known about negative affectivity?', 'It has been linked with the development of both hypertension and heart disease.']
['What is a study about negative affectivity?', 'For example, over 3,000 initially healthy participants in one study were tracked longitudinally, up to 22 years.']

['What was found about the study?', 'Those with higher levels of negative affectivity at the time the study began were substantially more likely to develop and be treated for hypertension during the ensuing years than were those with lower levels of negative affectivity (Jonas & Lando, 2000).']

['What else was discovered?', 'In addition, a study of over 10,000 middle-aged London-based civil servants who were followed an average of 12.5 years revealed that those who earlier had scored in the upper third on a test of negative affectivity were 32% more likely to have experienced heart disease, heart attack, or angina over a period of years than were those who scored in the lowest third (Nabi, Kivimaki, De Vogli, Marmot, & Singh-Manoux, 2008).']
['What else is known about negative affectivity?', 'Hence, negative affectivity appears to be a potentially vital risk factor for the development of cardiovascular disorders.']
['What is the importance of depression and the heart?', 'For centuries, poets and folklore have asserted that there is a connection between moods and the heart (Glassman & Shapiro, 1998).']

['What has this lead to?', 'You are no doubt familiar with the notion of a broken heart following a disappointing or depressing event and have encountered that notion in songs, films, and literature.']

['How did we learn about depression and heart disease?', 'Perhaps the first to recognize the link between depression and heart disease was Benjamin Malzberg (1937), who found that the death rate among institutionalized patients with melancholia (an archaic term for depression) was six times higher than that of the population.']

['Did we find more?', 'A classic study in the late 1970s looked at over 8,000 people diagnosed with manic-depressive disorder (now classified as bipolar disorder) in Denmark, finding a nearly 50% increase in deaths from heart disease among these patients compared with the general Danish population (Weeke, 1979).']

['What was the most important study?', 'By the early 1990s, evidence began to accumulate showing that depressed individuals who were followed for long periods of time were at increased risk for heart disease and cardiac death (Glassman, 2007).']

['Did we find any more research?', 'In one investigation of over 700 Denmark residents, those with the highest depression scores were 71% more likely to have experienced a heart attack than were those with lower depression scores (Barefoot & Schroll, 1996).']
['What was one of the studies we reviewed?', 'Figure 14.20 illustrates the gradation in risk of heart attacks for both men and women.']
['What are some of the most interesting things about depression and the heart?', 'After more than two decades of research, it is now clear that a relationship exists:']

['What other information is important about depression and the heart?', 'Patients with heart disease have more depression than the general population, and people with depression are more likely to eventually develop heart disease and experience higher mortality than those who do not have depression (Hare, Toukhsati, Johansson, & Jaarsma, 2013); the more severe the depression, the higher the risk (Glassman, 2007).']
['What other information is important?', 'Consider the following:']

['What are some facts about depression and the heart?', 'In one study, death rates from cardiovascular problems was substantially higher in depressed people; depressed men were 50% more likely to have died from cardiovascular problems, and depressed women were 70% more likely (Ösby, Brandt, Correia, Ekbom, & Sparén, 2001).']

['Did they find any other studies about the relationship between depression and the heart?', 'A statistical review of 10 longitudinal studies involving initially healthy individuals revealed that those with elevated depressive symptoms have, on average, a 64% greater risk of developing heart disease than do those with fewer symptoms (Wulsin & Singal, 2003).']

['How many studies have been done on the subject?', 'A study of over 63,000 registered nurses found that those with more depressed symptoms when the study began were 49% more likely to experience fatal heart disease over a 12-year period (Whang et al., 2009).']

['How does depression affect the heart?', 'The American Heart Association, fully aware of the established importance of depression in cardiovascular diseases, several years ago recommended routine depression screening for all heart disease patients (Lichtman et al., 2008).']
['What else does the AHA recommend about depression?', 'Recently, they have recommended including depression as a risk factor for heart disease patients (AHA, 2014).']

['What does depression have to do with the heart?', 'Although the exact mechanisms through which depression might produce heart problems have not been fully clarified, a recent investigation examining this connection in early life has shed some light.']

['What did the investigation find?', 'In an ongoing study of childhood depression, adolescents who had been diagnosed with depression as children were more likely to be obese, smoke, and be physically inactive than were those who had not received this diagnosis (Rottenberg et al., 2014).']

['What is the most important part of this article?', 'One implication of this study is that depression, especially if it occurs early in life, may increase the likelihood of living an unhealthy lifestyle, thereby predisposing people to an unfavorable cardiovascular disease risk profile.']

['What does it say?', 'It is important to point out that depression may be just one piece of the emotional puzzle in elevating the risk for heart disease, and that chronically experiencing several negative emotional states may be especially important.']

['Does it tell me more about these negative emotional states?', 'A longitudinal investigation of Vietnam War veterans found that depression, anxiety, hostility, and trait anger each independently predicted the onset of heart disease (Boyle, Michalek, & Suarez, 2006).']

['What does this study reveal?', 'However, when each of these negative psychological attributes was combined into a single variable, this new variable (which researchers called psychological risk factor) predicted heart disease more strongly than any of the individual variables.']

['What does this mean?', 'Thus, rather than examining the predictive power of isolated psychological risk factors, it seems crucial for future researchers to examine the effects of combined and more general negative emotional and psychological traits in the development of cardiovascular illnesses.']
['What is Asthma?', 'Asthma is a chronic and serious disease in which the airways of the respiratory system become obstructed, leading to great difficulty expelling air from the lungs.']

['What causes the obstruction?', 'The airway obstruction is caused by inflammation of the airways (leading to thickening of the airway walls) and a tightening of the muscles around them, resulting in a narrowing of the airways (Figure 14.21) (American Lung Association, 2010).']

['How do the airways become obstructed?', 'Because airways become obstructed, a person with asthma will sometimes have great difficulty breathing and will experience repeated episodes of wheezing, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and coughing, the latter occurring mostly during the morning and night (CDC, 2006).']

['What do we know about asthma?', 'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), around 4,000 people die each year from asthma-related causes, and asthma is a contributing factor to another 7,000 deaths each year (CDC, 2013a).']
['What are some other things we know about asthma?', 'The CDC has revealed that asthma affects 18.7 million U.S. adults and is more common among people with lower income levels (CDC, 2013b).']
['What are the rising asthma rates?', 'Especially concerning is that asthma is on the rise, with rates of asthma increasing 157% between 2000 and 2010 (CDC, 2013b).']
['What are the symptoms of asthma attacks?', 'Asthma attacks are acute episodes in which an asthma sufferer experiences the full range of symptoms.']

['What can cause an asthma attack?', 'Asthma exacerbation is often triggered by environmental factors, such as air pollution, allergens (e.g., pollen, mold, and pet hairs), cigarette smoke, airway infections, cold air or a sudden change in temperature, and exercise (CDC, 2013b).']

['What else can cause asthma?', 'Certain regions and neighborhoods are known for having notably high rates of asthma and related diseases due to high rates of concentrated pollution and low air quality.']

['What are examples of places where asthma is high?', 'For example, Long Beach, California and Bronx, New York contain "asthma alleys" due to the density of trucking, power plants, factories, sewage  works, or other agents of air pollution.']

['What can be known about the causes of Asthma?', 'Psychological factors appear to play an important role in asthma (Wright, Rodriguez, & Cohen, 1998), although some believe that psychological factors serve as potential triggers in only a subset of asthma patients (Ritz, Steptoe, Bobb, Harris, & Edwards, 2006).']

['What kind of psychological factors do people suffer from?', 'Many studies over the years have demonstrated that some people with asthma will experience asthma-like symptoms if they expect to experience such symptoms, such as when breathing an inert substance that they (falsely) believe will lead to airway obstruction (Sodergren & Hyland, 1999).']

['How can psychological factors be cured?', 'As stress and emotions directly affect immune and respiratory functions, psychological factors likely serve as one of the most common triggers of asthma exacerbation (Trueba & Ritz, 2013).']

['What is the main topic?', 'People with asthma tend to report and display a high level of negative emotions such as anxiety, and asthma attacks have been linked to periods of high emotionality (Lehrer, Isenberg, & Hochron, 1993).']

['How is anxiety linked to asthma?', 'In addition, high levels of emotional distress during both laboratory tasks and daily life have been found to negatively affect airway function and can produce asthma-like symptoms in people with asthma (von Leupoldt, Ehnes, & Dahme, 2006).']

['What is another example of anxiety being linked to asthma?', 'In one investigation, 20 adults with asthma wore preprogrammed wristwatches that signaled them to breathe into a portable device that measures airway function.']

['Are there other examples of the emotionality being linked to asthma?', 'Results showed that higher levels of negative emotions and stress were associated with increased airway obstruction and self-reported asthma symptoms (Smyth, Soefer, Hurewitz, Kliment, & Stone, 1999).']

['What are some examples of depression being linked to asthma?', 'In addition, D’Amato, Liccardi, Cecchi, Pellegrino, & D’Amato (2010) described a case study of an 18-year-old man with asthma whose girlfriend had broken up with him, leaving him in a depressed state.']
['What did the girlfriend do to leave him depressed?', 'She had also unfriended him on Facebook, while friending other young males.']
["What did the young man do to regain his girlfriend's friendship?", 'Eventually, the young man was able to “friend” her once again and could monitor her activity through Facebook.']
['Why did he experience symptoms?', 'Subsequently, he would experience asthma symptoms whenever he logged on and accessed her profile.']
['How did he deal with the symptoms?', 'When he later resigned not to use Facebook any longer, the asthma attacks stopped.']

['What does the study mean?', 'This case suggests that the use of Facebook and other forms of social media may represent a new source of stress—it may be a triggering factor for asthma attacks, especially in depressed asthmatic individuals.']

['What stressors are linked to the development of asthma?', 'Exposure to stressful experiences, particularly those that involve parental or interpersonal conflicts, has been linked to the development of asthma throughout the lifespan.']

['How are children affected by stress?', 'A longitudinal study of 145 children found that parenting difficulties during the first year of life increased the chances that the child developed asthma by 107% (Klinnert et al., 2001).']

['How are adults affected by stress?', 'In addition, a cross-sectional study of over 10,000 Finnish college students found that high rates of parent or personal conflicts (e.g., parental divorce, separation from spouse, or severe conflicts in other long-term relationships) increased the risk of asthma onset (Kilpeläinen, Koskenvuo, Helenius, & Terho, 2002).']

['Are there other studies demonstrating this link?', 'Further, a study of over 4,000 middle-aged men who were interviewed in the early 1990s and again a decade later found that breaking off an important life partnership (e.g., divorce or breaking off relationship from parents) increased the risk of developing asthma by 124% over the time of the study (Loerbroks, Apfelbacher, Thayer, Debling, & Stürmer, 2009).']
['What exactly is a headache?', 'A headache is a continuous pain anywhere in the head and neck region.']

['What are some common causes of headaches?', 'Inflammation of the sinuses caused by an infection or allergic reaction can cause sinus headaches, which are experienced as pain in the cheeks and forehead.']
['What are some other causes?', 'Migraine headaches are a type of headache thought to be caused by blood vessel swelling and increased blood flow (McIntosh, 2013).']
['What are migraines?', 'Migraines are characterized by severe pain on one or both sides of the head, an upset stomach, and disturbed vision.']
['How often do people suffer from migraines?', 'They are more frequently experienced by women than by men (American Academy of Neurology, 2014).']

['What are tension headaches?', 'Tension headaches are triggered by tightening/tensing of facial and neck muscles; they are the most commonly experienced kind of headache, accounting for about 42% of all headaches worldwide (Stovner et al., 2007).']

['Is tension headaches common?', 'In the United States, well over one-third of the population experiences tension headaches each year, and 2–3% of the population suffers from chronic tension headaches (Schwartz, Stewart, Simon, & Lipton, 1998).']

['What causes headaches?', 'A number of factors can contribute to tension headaches, including sleep deprivation, skipping meals, eye strain, overexertion, muscular tension caused by poor posture, and stress (MedicineNet, 2013).']

['Are there any known causes of headaches?', 'Although there is uncertainty regarding the exact mechanisms through which stress can produce tension headaches, stress has been demonstrated to increase sensitivity to pain (Caceres & Burns, 1997; Logan et al., 2001).']

['Is there any evidence of the relationship between sensitivity and stress?', 'In general, tension headache sufferers, compared to non-sufferers, have a lower threshold for and greater sensitivity to pain (Ukestad & Wittrock, 1996), and they report greater levels of subjective stress when faced with a stressor (Myers, Wittrock, & Foreman, 1998).']

['What are the effects of stress on sensitivity?', 'Thus, stress may contribute to tension headaches by increasing pain sensitivity in already-sensitive pain pathways in tension headache sufferers (Cathcart, Petkov, & Pritchard, 2008).']
['What does stress mean?', 'As we learned in the previous section, stress—especially if it is chronic—takes a toll on our bodies and can have enormously negative health implications.']
['How can you deal with stress?', 'When we experience events in our lives that we appraise as stressful, it is essential that we use effective coping strategies to manage our stress.']
['What is coping?', 'Coping refers to mental and behavioral efforts that we use to deal with problems relating to stress.']
['How many different coping styles are there?', 'Lazarus and Folkman (1984) distinguished two fundamental kinds of coping: problem-focused coping and emotion-focused coping.']
['How do the two styles differ?', 'In problem-focused coping, one attempts to manage or alter the problem that is causing one to experience stress (i.e., the stressor).']

['What happens if you manage the problem?', 'Problem-focused coping strategies are similar to strategies used in everyday problem-solving: they typically involve identifying the problem, considering possible solutions, weighing the costs and benefits of these solutions, and then selecting an alternative (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']
['What kind of problems are they trying to solve?', 'As an example, suppose Bradford receives a midterm notice that he is failing statistics class.']
['Why would he be stressed?', 'If Bradford adopts a problem-focused coping approach to managing his stress, he would be proactive in trying to alleviate the source of the stress.']

['What will he do?', 'He might contact his professor to discuss what must be done to raise his grade, he might also decide to set aside two hours daily to study statistics assignments, and he may seek tutoring assistance.']
['Is there anything else interesting?', 'A problem-focused approach to managing stress means we actively try to do things to address the problem.']
['How is it structured?', 'Emotion-focused coping, in contrast, consists of efforts to change or reduce the negative emotions associated with stress.']

['What are the efforts?', 'These efforts may include avoiding, minimizing, or distancing oneself from the problem, or positive comparisons with others (“I’m not as bad off as she is”), or seeking something positive in a negative event (“Now that I’ve been fired, I can sleep in for a few days”).']

['How can you change your emotions?', 'In some cases, emotion-focused coping strategies involve reappraisal, whereby the stressor is construed differently (and somewhat self-deceptively) without changing its objective level of threat (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']
['What is an example?', 'For example, a person sentenced to federal prison who thinks, “This will give me a great chance to network with others,” is using reappraisal.']

['Can you give me an example of another emotion focused coping style?', 'If Bradford adopted an emotion-focused approach to managing his midterm deficiency stress, he might watch a comedy movie, play video games, or spend hours on social media to take his mind off the situation.']
['Are there any other aspects of the article that I should know?', 'In a certain sense, emotion-focused coping can be thought of as treating the symptoms rather than the actual cause.']

['What is the problem-focused coping model?', 'While many stressors elicit both kinds of coping strategies, problem-focused coping is more likely to occur when encountering stressors we perceive as controllable, while emotion-focused coping is more likely to predominate when faced with stressors that we believe we are powerless to change (Folkman &  Lazarus, 1980).']
['What is the emotion-focused coping model?', 'Clearly, emotion-focused coping is more effective in dealing with uncontrollable stressors.']
['Can you give me an example of a problem-focused and emotion-focused coping?', 'For example, the stress you experience when a loved one dies can be overwhelming.']
['What did you do about it?', 'You are simply powerless to change the situation as there is nothing you can do to bring this person back.']
['What is the emotion-focused coping?', 'The most helpful coping response is emotion-focused coping aimed at minimizing the pain of the grieving period.']
['What is the benefit of the stressor?', 'Fortunately, most stressors we encounter can be modified and are, to varying degrees, controllable.']

['What is the effect of stress?', 'A person who cannot stand her job can quit and look for work elsewhere; a middle-aged divorcee can find another potential partner; the freshman who fails an exam can study harder next time, and a breast lump does not necessarily mean that one is fated to die of breast cancer.']

["What's the first thing you want me to know about your study material?", 'The desire and ability to predict events, make decisions, and affect outcomes—that is, to enact control in our lives—is a basic tenet of human behavior (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['What does Albert Bandura say about control?', 'Albert Bandura (1997) stated that “the intensity and chronicity of human stress is governed largely by perceived control over the demands of one’s life” (p. 262).']

['Does Albert Bandura say this in a scientific manner?', 'As cogently described in his statement, our reaction to potential stressors depends to a large extent on how much control we feel we have over such things.']

['What is perceived control?', 'Perceived control is our beliefs about our personal capacity to exert influence over and shape outcomes, and it has major implications for our health and happiness (Infurna & Gerstorf, 2014).']

['What kind of implications do we have?', 'Extensive research has demonstrated that perceptions of personal control are associated with a variety of favorable outcomes, such as better physical and mental health and greater psychological well-being (Diehl & Hay, 2010).']
['How do these positive outcomes affect our lives?', 'Greater personal control is also associated with lower reactivity to stressors in daily life.']

['Are there any studies on the matter?', 'For example, researchers in one investigation found that higher levels of perceived control at one point in time were later associated with lower emotional and physical reactivity to interpersonal stressors (Neupert, Almeida, & Charles, 2007).']

['What other studies have been done?', 'Further, a daily diary study with 34 older widows found that their stress and anxiety levels were significantly reduced on days during which the widows felt greater perceived control (Ong, Bergeman, & Bisconti, 2005).']

['What is Control and Stress about?', 'People who report higher levels of perceived control view their health as controllable, thereby making it more likely that they will better manage their health and engage in behaviors conducive to good health (Bandura, 2004).']

["How does perceived control contribute to one's overall health?", 'Not surprisingly, greater perceived control has been linked to lower risk of physical health problems, including declines in physical functioning (Infurna, Gerstorf, Ram, Schupp, & Wagner, 2011), heart attacks (Rosengren et al., 2004), and both cardiovascular disease incidence (Stürmer, Hasselbach, & Amelang, 2006) and mortality from cardiac disease (Surtees et al., 2010).']

['What else do researchers and medical professionals think about perceived control?', 'In addition, longitudinal studies of British civil servants have found that those in low-status jobs (e.g., clerical and office support staff) in which the degree of control over the job is minimal are considerably more likely to develop heart disease than those with high-status jobs or considerable control over their jobs (Marmot, Bosma, Hemingway, & Stansfeld, 1997).']

['What is it about?', 'The link between perceived control and health may provide an explanation for the frequently observed relationship between social class and health outcomes (Kraus, Piff, Mendoza-Denton, Rheinschmidt, & Keltner, 2012).']

['What can you tell me about the relationship between social class and health outcomes?', 'In general, research has found that more affluent individuals experience better health partly because they tend to believe that they can personally control and manage their reactions to life’s stressors (Johnson & Krueger, 2006).']

['What can you tell me about their perception of control?', 'Perhaps buoyed by the perceived level of control, individuals of higher social class may be prone to overestimating the degree of influence they have over particular outcomes.']

['What kind of influences do they overestimate?', 'For example, those of higher social class tend to believe that their votes have greater sway on election outcomes than do those of lower social class, which may explain higher rates of voting in more affluent communities (Krosnick, 1990).']

['What is a good example of lower social standing?', 'Other research has found that a sense of perceived control can protect less affluent individuals from poorer health, depression, and reduced life-satisfaction—all of which tend to accompany lower social standing (Lachman & Weaver, 1998).']
['What does social support mean?', 'The need to form and maintain strong, stable relationships with others is a powerful, pervasive, and fundamental human motive (Baumeister & Leary, 1995).']

['What is an example of social support?', 'Building strong interpersonal relationships with others helps us establish a network of close, caring individuals who can provide social support in times of distress, sorrow, and fear.']
['What type of relationships does this relate to?', 'Social support can be thought of as the soothing impact of friends, family, and acquaintances (Baron & Kerr, 2003).']

['What can you describe this support as?', 'Social support can take many forms, including advice, guidance, encouragement, acceptance, emotional comfort, and tangible assistance (such as financial help).']

['How can social support be beneficial?', 'Thus, other people can be very comforting to us when we are faced with a wide range of life stressors, and they can be extremely helpful in our efforts to manage these challenges.']
['What else can social support help us achieve?', 'Even in nonhuman animals, species mates can offer social support during times of stress.']

['What kind of social support do animals give?', 'For example, elephants seem to be able to sense when other elephants are stressed and will often comfort them with physical contact—such as a trunk touch—or an empathetic vocal response (Krumboltz, 2014).']

['What kind of support is it?', 'Scientific interest in the importance of social support first emerged in the 1970s when health researchers developed an interest in the health consequences of being socially integrated (Stroebe & Stroebe, 1996).']
['Why did they study this?', 'Interest was further fueled by longitudinal studies showing that social connectedness reduced mortality.']
['Was there anything else interesting about the study?', 'In one classic study, nearly 7,000 Alameda County, California, residents were followed over 9 years.']

['What was the result of that study?', 'Those who had previously indicated that they lacked social and community ties were more likely to die during the follow-up period than those with more extensive social networks.']
['Did it lead to isolation?', 'Compared to those with the most social contacts, isolated men and women were, respectively, 2.3 and 2.8 times more likely to die.']

['What kind of factors played a role?', 'These trends persisted even after controlling for a variety of health-related variables, such as smoking, alcohol consumption, self-reported health at the beginning of the study, and physical activity (Berkman & Syme, 1979).']
['What is social support?', 'Since the time of that study, social support has emerged as one of the well-documented psychosocial factors affecting health outcomes (Uchino, 2009).']

['Can you tell me more about this topic?', 'A statistical review of 148 studies conducted between 1982 and 2007 involving over 300,000 participants concluded that individuals with stronger social relationships have a 50% greater likelihood of survival compared to those with weak or insufficient social relationships (Holt-Lunstad, Smith, & Layton, 2010).']

['What other well-known risk factors for mortality were mentioned?', 'According to the researchers, the magnitude of the effect of social support observed in this study is comparable with quitting smoking and exceeded many well-known risk factors for mortality, such as obesity and physical inactivity (Figure 14.23).']

['What did you learn about Social Support?', 'A number of large-scale studies have found that individuals with low levels of social support are at greater risk of mortality, especially from cardiovascular disorders (Brummett et al., 2001).']

['What did the studies show?', 'Further, higher levels of social supported have been linked to better survival rates following breast cancer (Falagas et al., 2007) and infectious diseases, especially HIV infection (Lee & Rotheram-Borus, 2001).']
["Can Social Support help someone who doesn't know anyone?", 'In fact, a person with high levels of social support is less likely to contract a common cold.']

['What else did you learn about social support?', 'In one study, 334 participants completed questionnaires assessing their sociability; these individuals were subsequently exposed to a virus that causes a common cold and monitored for several weeks to see who became ill.']
['What was the outcome?', 'Results showed that increased sociability was linearly associated with a decreased probability of developing a cold (Cohen, Doyle, Turner, Alper, & Skoner, 2003).']
['What are friends?', 'For many of us, friends are a vital source of social support.']

['Why do people want to get together?', 'Many students who leave home to attend and live at college experience drastic reductions in their social support, which makes them vulnerable to anxiety, depression, and loneliness.']

['Do social media actually increase loneliness?', 'Social media can sometimes be useful in navigating these transitions (Raney & Troop Gordon, 2012) but might also cause increases in loneliness (Hunt, Marx, Lipson, & Young, 2018).']
['Why is that?', 'For this reason, many colleges have designed first-year programs, such as peer mentoring (Raymond & Shepard, 2018), that can help students build new social networks.']
['What is the purpose of family support?', 'For some people, our families—especially our parents—are a major source of social support.']

['What is one of the main reasons for social support?', 'Social support appears to work by boosting the immune system, especially among people who are experiencing stress (Uchino, Vaughn, Carlisle, & Birmingham, 2012).']

['What is the importance of social support for people?', 'In a pioneering study, spouses of cancer patients who reported high levels of social support showed indications of better immune functioning on two out of three immune functioning measures, compared to spouses who were below the median on reported social support (Baron, Cutrona, Hicklin, Russell, & Lubaroff, 1990).']

['Does social support have any other benefits?', 'Studies of other populations have produced similar results, including those of spousal caregivers of dementia sufferers, medical students, elderly adults, and cancer patients (Cohen & Herbert, 1996; Kiecolt-Glaser, McGuire, Robles, & Glaser, 2002).']

['What else is significant about the material?', 'In addition, social support has been shown to reduce blood pressure for people performing stressful tasks, such as giving a speech or performing mental arithmetic (Lepore, 1998).']

['What was one study in this area?', 'In these kinds of studies, participants are usually asked to perform a stressful task either alone, with a stranger present (who may be either supportive or unsupportive), or with a friend present.']

['What happens if people have friends with them?', 'Those tested with a friend present generally exhibit lower blood pressure than those tested alone or with a stranger (Fontana, Diegnan, Villeneuve, & Lepore, 1999).']

['What is another study?', 'In one study, 112 female participants who performed stressful mental arithmetic exhibited lower blood pressure when they received support from a friend rather than a stranger, but only if the friend was a male (Phillips, Gallagher, & Carroll, 2009).']

['Why does this happen?', 'Although these findings are somewhat difficult to interpret, the authors mention that it is possible that females feel less supported and more evaluated by other females, particularly females whose opinions they value.']

["What is social support and how does it affect one's health?", 'Taken together, the findings above suggest one of the reasons social support is connected to favorable health outcomes is because it has several beneficial physiological effects in stressful situations.']

['Why does it have these beneficial physiological effects?', 'However, it is also important to consider the possibility that social support may lead to better health behaviors, such as a healthy diet, exercising, smoking cessation, and cooperation with medical regimens (Uchino, 2009).']

['What were some of the topics covered in the article?', 'Beyond having a sense of control and establishing social support networks, there are numerous other means by which we can manage stress (Figure 14.24).']
['What else does the article say about reducing stress?', 'A common technique people use to combat stress is exercise (Salmon, 2001).']

['What is the article about exercise?', 'It is well-established that exercise, both of long (aerobic) and short (anaerobic) duration, is beneficial for both physical and mental health (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['How does exercise help to reduce stress?', 'There is considerable evidence that physically fit individuals are more resistant to the adverse effects of stress and recover more quickly from stress than less physically fit individuals (Cotton, 1990).']

['Does this information support claims about fitness?', 'In a study of more than 500 Swiss police officers and emergency service personnel, increased physical fitness was associated with reduced stress, and regular exercise was reported to protect against stress-related health problems (Gerber, Kellman, Hartman, & Pühse, 2010).']
['What can you tell me about stress reduction techniques?', 'One reason exercise may be beneficial is because it might buffer some of the deleterious physiological mechanisms of stress.']

['What are the physiological mechanisms of stress?', 'One study found rats that exercised for six weeks showed a decrease in hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal responsiveness to mild stressors (Campeau et al., 2010).']

['Did rats have any other benefits?', 'In high-stress humans, exercise has been shown to prevent telomere shortening, which may explain the common observation of a youthful appearance among those who exercise regularly (Puterman et al., 2010).']
['What other benefits do humans have?', 'Further, exercise in later adulthood appears to minimize the detrimental effects of stress on the hippocampus and memory (Head, Singh, & Bugg, 2012).']

['Are there any other benefits?', 'Among cancer survivors, exercise has been shown to reduce anxiety (Speck, Courneya, Masse, Duval, & Schmitz, 2010) and depressive symptoms (Craft, VanIterson, Helenowski, Rademaker, & Courneya, 2012).']
['What else can you tell me about stress reduction techniques?', 'Clearly, exercise is a highly effective tool for regulating stress.']

['When was the relaxation response technique developed?', 'In the 1970s, Herbert Benson, a cardiologist, developed a stress reduction method called the relaxation response technique (Greenberg, 2006).']
['What is the relaxation response technique?', 'The relaxation response technique combines relaxation with transcendental meditation, and consists of four components (Stein, 2001):']
['What was the biofeedback?', 'Another technique to combat stress, biofeedback, was developed by Gary Schwartz at Harvard University in the early 1970s.']

['What was this technique used for?', 'Biofeedback is a technique that uses electronic equipment to accurately measure a person’s neuromuscular and autonomic activity—feedback is provided in the form of visual or auditory signals.']

['What else did the article say?', 'The main assumption of this approach is that providing somebody biofeedback will enable the individual to develop strategies that help gain some level of voluntary control over what are normally involuntary bodily processes (Schwartz & Schwartz, 1995).']

['How did this technique work?', 'A number of different bodily measures have been used in biofeedback research, including facial muscle movement, brain activity, and skin temperature, and it has been applied successfully with individuals experiencing tension headaches, high blood pressure, asthma, and phobias (Stein, 2001).']
['What is the content about?', 'Although the study of stress and how it affects us physically and psychologically is fascinating, it is—admittedly—somewhat of a grim topic.']
['What other topics are there in the study material?', 'Psychology is also interested in the study of a more upbeat and encouraging approach to human affairs—the quest for happiness.']
['What is the significance of happiness?', 'America’s founders declared that its citizens have an unalienable right to pursue happiness.']
['What is the definition of happiness?', 'When asked to define the term, people emphasize different aspects of this elusive state.']
['How do people define happiness?', 'Indeed, happiness is somewhat ambiguous and can be defined from different perspectives (Martin, 2012).']

['What is one perspective?', 'Some people, especially those who are highly committed to their religious faith, view happiness in ways that emphasize virtuosity, reverence, and enlightened spirituality.']

['What else do people look for in happiness?', 'Others see happiness as primarily contentment—the inner peace and joy that come from deep satisfaction with one’s surroundings, relationships with others, accomplishments, and oneself.']

['How else do people define happiness?', 'Still others view happiness mainly as pleasurable engagement with their personal environment—having a career and hobbies that are engaging, meaningful, rewarding, and exciting.']
['What else is important about the definition of happiness?', 'These differences, of course, are merely differences in emphasis.']
["What are people's perspectives on happiness?", 'Most people would probably agree that each of these views, in some respects, captures the essence of happiness.']

['What are the elements of happiness?', 'Some psychologists have suggested that happiness consists of three distinct elements: the pleasant life, the good life, and the meaningful life, as shown in Figure 14.25 (Seligman, 2002; Seligman, Steen, Park, & Peterson, 2005).']
['What does the pleasant life consist of?', 'The pleasant life is realized through the attainment of day-to-day pleasures that add fun, joy, and excitement to our lives.']
['What types of pleasures do we enjoy?', 'For example, evening walks along the beach and a fulfilling sex life can enhance our daily pleasure and contribute to the pleasant life.']

['What other benefits do the pleasures have?', 'The good life is achieved through identifying our unique skills and abilities and engaging these talents to enrich our lives; those who achieve the good life often find themselves absorbed in their work or their recreational pursuits.']

['What makes the meaningful life happen?', 'The meaningful life involves a deep sense of fulfillment that comes from using our talents in the service of the greater good: in ways that benefit the lives of others or that make the world a better place.']

['What happens when you have all three elements?', 'In general, the happiest people tend to be those who pursue the full life—they orient their pursuits toward all three elements (Seligman et al., 2005).']

['What is the most important element of happiness according to our study material?', 'For practical purposes, a precise definition of happiness might incorporate each of these elements: an enduring state of mind consisting of joy, contentment, and other positive emotions, plus the sense that one’s life has meaning and value (Lyubomirsky, 2001).']

['What else is included in the definition?', 'The definition implies that happiness is a long-term state—what is often characterized as subjective well-being—rather than merely a transient positive mood we all experience from time to time.']
['What is lasting happiness?', 'It is this enduring happiness that has captured the interests of psychologists and other social scientists.']
["What's interesting about this topic?", 'The study of happiness has grown dramatically in the last three decades (Diener, 2013).']
['What kind of questions have been asked in this field?', 'One of the most basic questions that happiness investigators routinely examine is this:']

['What can be learned about human happiness?', 'The average person in the world tends to be relatively happy and tends to indicate experiencing more positive feelings than negative feelings (Diener, Ng, Harter, & Arora, 2010).']

['What does this mean?', 'When asked to evaluate their current lives on a scale ranging from 0 to 10 (with 0 representing “worst possible life” and 10 representing “best possible life”), people in more than 150 countries surveyed from 2010–2012 reported an average score of 5.2.']

['What does that mean?', 'People who live in North America, Australia, and New Zealand reported the highest average score at 7.1, whereas those living Sub-Saharan Africa reported the lowest average score at 4.6 (Helliwell, Layard, & Sachs, 2013).']

['What are some of the happiest countries?', 'Worldwide, the five happiest countries are Denmark, Norway, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and Sweden; the United States is ranked 17th happiest (Figure 14.26) (Helliwell et al., 2013).']
['When was this research done?', 'Several years ago, a Gallup survey of more than 1,000 U.S. adults found that 52% reported that they were “very happy.”']
['What else did they find?', 'In addition, more than 8 in 10 indicated that they were “very satisfied” with their lives (Carroll, 2007).']
['How has this research changed?', 'However, a recent poll found that only 42% of American adults report being "very happy."']

['How has this research influenced people?', 'The groups that show the greatest declines in happiness are people of color, those who have not completed a college education, and those who politically identify as Democrats or independents (McCarthy, 2020).']
['What does this research say about the economy?', 'These results suggest that challenging economic conditions may be related to declines in happiness.']
['What does this mean?', "Of course, this interpretation implies that happiness is closely tied to one's finances."]
['Did you do any research into this?', 'Extensive research over the years has examined this question.']
['What were some of the findings?', 'One finding is that age is related to happiness:']
['What are some other findings?', 'Life satisfaction usually increases the older people get, but there do not appear to be gender differences in happiness (Diener, Suh, Lucas, & Smith, 1999).']

['What else can you tell me about these findings?', 'Although it is important to point out that much of this work has been correlational, many of the key findings (some of which may surprise you) are summarized below.']
['What is one factor?', 'Family and other social relationships appear to be key factors correlated with happiness.']
['What is the evidence for this?', 'Studies show that married people report being happier than those who are single, divorced, or widowed (Diener et al., 1999).']
['Is there anything else interesting that you could tell me?', 'Happy individuals also report that their marriages are fulfilling (Lyubomirsky, King, & Diener, 2005).']
['What about other studies?', 'In fact, some have suggested that satisfaction with marriage and family life is the strongest predictor of happiness (Myers, 2000).']

['What are some other factors?', 'Happy people tend to have more friends, more high-quality social relationships, and stronger social support networks than less happy people (Lyubomirsky et al., 2005).']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Happy people also have a high frequency of contact with friends (Pinquart & Sörensen, 2000).']
['Does this paper provide any evidence for the idea of happiness?', 'In general, extensive research suggests that the answer is yes, but with several caveats.']

['How so?', 'While a nation’s per capita gross domestic product (GDP) is associated with happiness levels (Helliwell et al., 2013), changes in GDP (which is a less certain index of household income) bear little relationship to changes in happiness (Diener, Tay, & Oishi, 2013).']

['What else did they say about happiness?', 'On the whole, residents of affluent countries tend to be happier than residents of poor countries; within countries, wealthy individuals are happier than poor individuals, but the association is much weaker (Diener & Biswas-Diener, 2002).']

['What else did they say about happiness?', 'To the extent that it leads to increases in purchasing power, increases in income are associated with increases in happiness (Diener, Oishi, & Ryan, 2013).']
['What else is notable about this article?', 'However, income within societies appears to correlate with happiness only up to a point.']

['What does the point refer to?', 'In a study of over 450,000 U.S. residents surveyed by the Gallup Organization, Kahneman and Deaton (2010) found that well-being rises with annual income, but only up to $75,000.']
['What is the significance of that?', 'The average increase in reported well-being for people with incomes greater than $75,000 was null.']

['What else is significant about this study?', 'As implausible as these findings might seem—after all, higher incomes would enable people to indulge in Hawaiian vacations, prime seats as sporting events, expensive automobiles, and expansive new homes—higher incomes may impair people’s ability to savor and enjoy the small pleasures of life (Kahneman, 2011).']

['How did they prove this?', 'Indeed, researchers in one study found that participants exposed to a subliminal reminder of wealth spent less time savoring a chocolate candy bar and exhibited less enjoyment of this experience than did participants who were not reminded of wealth (Quoidbach, Dunn, Petrides, & Mikolajczak, 2010).']
['what other information did we learn?', 'Happy people, compared to those who are less happy, are more likely to graduate from college and secure more meaningful and engaging jobs.']
['what else did we learn about happy people?', 'Once they obtain a job, they are also more likely to succeed (Lyubomirsky et al., 2005).']
['what other information were we given?', 'While education shows a positive (but weak) correlation with happiness, intelligence is not appreciably related to happiness (Diener et al., 1999).']
['Does it say how happiness is measured in this study?', 'In general, the answer is yes (Hackney & Sanders, 2003).']
['Is there anything interesting about religiosity in the study?', 'However, the relationship between religiosity and happiness depends on societal circumstances.']

['What are the societal circumstances?', 'Nations and states with more difficult living conditions (e.g., widespread hunger and low life expectancy) tend to be more highly religious than societies with more favorable living conditions.']

['How do those societal circumstances affect happiness?', 'Among those who live in nations with difficult living conditions, religiosity is associated with greater well-being; in nations with more favorable living conditions, religious and nonreligious individuals report similar levels of well-being (Diener, Tay, & Myers, 2011).']
['What is one factor related to happiness?', 'Clearly the living conditions of one’s nation can influence factors related to happiness.']
['What are some other factors related to happiness?', 'To the extent that people possess characteristics that are highly valued by their culture, they tend to be happier (Diener, 2012).']

['What other factors are mentioned?', 'For example, self-esteem is a stronger predictor of life satisfaction in individualistic cultures than in collectivistic cultures (Diener, Diener, & Diener, 1995), and extraverted people tend to be happier in extraverted cultures than in introverted cultures (Fulmer et al., 2010).']
['What is this about?', 'So we’ve identified many factors that exhibit some correlation to happiness.']
['What are some other examples of factors?', 'Researchers have studied both parenthood and physical attractiveness as potential contributors to happiness, but no link has been identified.']

['Did they identify any link between these factors?', 'Although people tend to believe that parenthood is central to a meaningful and fulﬁlling life, aggregate findings from a range of countries indicate that people who do not have children are generally happier than those who do (Hansen, 2012).']

['What else did they find?', 'And although one’s perceived level of attractiveness seems to predict happiness, a person’s objective physical attractiveness is only weakly correlated with their happiness (Diener, Wolsic, & Fujita, 1995).']
['What else did you study regarding Life Events and Happiness?', 'An important point should be considered regarding happiness.']
['What was the important point?', 'People are often poor at affective forecasting: predicting the intensity and duration of their future emotions (Wilson & Gilbert, 2003).']

['What else can you tell me about people being poor at affective forecasting?', 'In one study, nearly all newlywed spouses predicted their marital satisfaction would remain stable or improve over the following four years; despite this high level of initial optimism, their marital satisfaction actually declined during this period (Lavner, Karner, & Bradbury, 2013).']

['What else did you find out about people being poor at forecasting?', 'In addition, we are often incorrect when estimating how our long-term happiness would change for the better or worse in response to certain life events.']

['What can you tell me about how we are wrong about future emotions?', 'For example, it is easy for many of us to imagine how euphoric we would feel if we won the lottery, were asked on a date by an attractive celebrity, or were offered our dream job.']

['What was one example of this?', 'It is also easy to understand how long-suffering fans of the Chicago Cubs baseball team, which had not won a World Series championship since 1908, thought they would feel permanently elated when their team finally won another World Series in 2016.']
['How about another example?', 'Likewise, it is easy to predict that we would feel permanently miserable if we suffered a disabling accident or if a romantic relationship ended.']
['What is sensory adaptation?', 'However, something similar to sensory adaptation often occurs when people experience emotional reactions to life events.']

['What is one example of this?', 'In much the same way our senses adapt to changes in stimulation (e.g., our eyes adapting to bright light after walking out of the darkness of a movie theater into the bright afternoon sun), we eventually adapt to changing emotional circumstances in our lives (Brickman & Campbell, 1971; Helson, 1964).']
['What is another example?', 'When an event that provokes positive or negative emotions occurs, at first we tend to experience its emotional impact at full intensity.']

['Are there other examples?', 'We feel a burst of pleasure following such things as a marriage proposal, birth of a child, acceptance to law school, an inheritance, and the like; as you might imagine, lottery winners experience a surge of happiness after hitting the jackpot (Lutter, 2007).']
['What else?', 'Likewise, we experience a surge of misery following widowhood, a divorce, or a layoff from work.']

['What does this lead to?', 'In the long run, however, we eventually adjust to the emotional new normal; the emotional impact of the event tends to erode, and we eventually revert to our original baseline happiness levels.']

['What else can you tell me about sensory adaptation?', 'Thus, what was at first a thrilling lottery windfall or World Series championship eventually loses its luster and becomes the status quo (Figure 14.27).']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'Indeed, dramatic life events have much less long-lasting impact on happiness than might be expected (Brickman, Coats, & Janoff-Bulman, 1978).']

['What is life events and happiness?', 'Recently, some have raised questions concerning the extent to which important life events can permanently alter people’s happiness set points (Diener, Lucas, & Scollon, 2006).']
['What are the questions?', 'Evidence from a number of investigations suggests that, in some circumstances, happiness levels do not revert to their original positions.']
