['What is the other research on it?', 'However, there is strong evidence that traumatic experiences can cause people to experience states of dissociation, suggesting that dissociative states—including the adoption of multiple personalities—may serve as a psychologically important coping mechanism for threat and danger (Dalenberg et al., 2012).']

['What is the most important thing to know about disorders in childhood?', 'Most of the disorders we have discussed so far are typically diagnosed in adulthood, although they can and sometimes do occur during childhood.']

['What else do you think is important about disorders in childhood?', 'However, there are a group of conditions that, when present, are diagnosed early in childhood, often before the time a child enters school.']

['What is this group of conditions called?', 'These conditions are listed in the DSM-5 as neurodevelopmental disorders, and they involve developmental problems in personal, social, academic, and intellectual functioning (APA, 2013).']
['How is this group of conditions treated?', 'While they are often diagnosed in childhood, many people live with them throughout adulthood.']
['What are two examples of these disorders?', 'In this section, we will discuss two such disorders: attention deficit/ hyperactivity disorder and autism.']
['What is a characteristic about Diego?', 'Diego is always active, from the time he wakes up in the morning until the time he goes to bed at night.']
['What was his childhood like?', 'His mother reports that he came out the womb kicking and screaming, and he has not stopped moving since.']
['What else did he do?', 'He has a sweet disposition, but always seems to be in trouble with his teachers, parents, and after-school program counselors.']
['What was the result of all his wandering?', 'He seems to accidentally break things; he lost his jacket three times last winter, and he never seems to sit still.']
['What did the teachers think about Diego?', 'His teachers believe he is a smart child, but he never finishes anything he starts and is so impulsive that he does not seem to learn much in school.']
['What is ADHD?', 'Diego likely has attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']
['What causes ADHD?', 'The symptoms of this disorder were first described by Hans Hoffman in the 1920s.']

['What was his description?', 'While taking care of his son while his wife was in the hospital giving birth to a second child, Hoffman noticed that the boy had trouble concentrating on his homework, had a short attention span, and had to repeatedly go over easy homework to learn the material (Jellinek & Herzog, 1999).']

['How was it identified?', 'Later, it was discovered that many hyperactive children—those who are fidgety, restless, socially disruptive, and have trouble with impulse control—also display short attention spans, problems with concentration, and distractibility.']
['How was that discovered?', 'By the 1970s, it had become clear that many children who display attention problems often also exhibit signs of hyperactivity.']

['What did it mean?', 'In recognition of such findings, the DSM-III (published in 1980) included a new disorder: attention deficit disorder with and without hyperactivity, now known as attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']
['What is ADHD?', 'A child with ADHD shows a constant pattern of inattention and/or hyperactive and impulsive behavior that interferes with normal functioning (APA, 2013).']

['How is attention deficit characterized?', 'Some of the signs of inattention include great difficulty with and avoidance of tasks that require sustained attention (such as conversations or reading), failure to follow instructions (often resulting in failure to complete school work and other duties), disorganization (difficulty keeping things in order, poor time management, sloppy and messy work), lack of attention to detail, becoming easily distracted, and forgetfulness.']

['How is hyperactivity characterized?', 'Hyperactivity is characterized by excessive movement, and includes fidgeting or squirming, leaving one’s seat in situations when remaining seated is expected, having trouble sitting still (e.g., in a restaurant), running about and climbing on things, blurting out responses before another person’s question or statement has been completed, difficulty waiting one’s turn for something, and interrupting and intruding on others.']
['How do you know that your child has ADHD?', 'Frequently, the hyperactive child comes across as noisy and boisterous.']

['What other symptoms do you see?', 'The child’s behavior is hasty, impulsive, and seems to occur without much forethought; these characteristics may explain why adolescents and young adults diagnosed with ADHD receive more traffic tickets and have more automobile accidents than do others (Thompson, Molina, Pelham, & Gnagy, 2007).']

['Did you find the content helpful?', 'ADHD occurs in about 8% of children (Danielson et al, 2016), and studies estimate that for about 60% of these people, ADHD continues into adulthood (Sibley et al 2016).']

['What other information was helpful?', 'On the average, boys are 3 times more likely to have ADHD than are girls; however, such findings might reflect the greater propensity of boys to engage in aggressive and antisocial behavior and thus incur a greater likelihood of being referred to psychological clinics (Barkley, 2006).']
['What happens if they do have ADHD?', 'Children with ADHD face severe academic and social challenges.']

['How do they do in school?', 'Compared to their non-ADHD counterparts, children with ADHD have lower grades and standardized test scores and higher rates of expulsion, grade retention, and dropping out (Loe & Feldman, 2007).']
['What else do they have problems with?', 'they also are less well-liked and more often rejected by their peers (Hoza et al., 2005).']
['What are some common problems that come from ADHD?', 'Children with ADHD face considerably worse long-term outcomes than do those children who do not have ADHD.']

['What other types of problems?', 'Adults diagnosed with ADHD in childhood, but not treated for ADHD, have been reported to have poor outcomes in a wide range of areas of life, including social function, education, criminality, alcohol use, substance use, and occupational outcomes (Arnold et al, 2015).']

['What are some of the other types?', 'In one investigation, 135 adults who had been identified as having ADHD symptoms in the 1970s were contacted decades later and interviewed (Klein et al., 2012).']
['What did they find?', 'Compared to a control sample of 136 participants who had never been diagnosed with ADHD, those who were diagnosed as children:']

['What are the consequences?', 'had worse educational attainment (more likely to have dropped out of high school and less likely to have earned a bachelor’s degree); had lower socioeconomic status; held less prestigious occupational positions; were more likely to be unemployed; made considerably less in salary; scored worse on a measure of occupational functioning (indicating, for example, lower job satisfaction, poorer work relationships, and more firings); scored worse on a measure of social functioning (indicating, for example, fewer friendships and less involvement in social activities); were more likely to be divorced; and were more likely to have non-alcohol-related substance abuse problems.']
['What did they study?', '(Klein et al., 2012)']
['What is one of the problems that they can have with their lives?', 'Longitudinal studies also show that children diagnosed with ADHD are at higher risk for substance abuse problems.']
['How does substance abuse happen?', 'One study reported that childhood ADHD predicted later drinking problems, daily smoking, and use of marijuana and other illicit drugs (Molina & Pelham, 2003).']

['What is another issue related to substance abuse?', 'The risk of substance abuse problems appears to be even greater for those with ADHD who also exhibit antisocial tendencies (Marshal & Molina, 2006).']
['What are the major findings in this study?', 'Diagnosis, treatment, and general awareness of ADHD has certainly improved in the decades since the people in the above studies were diagnosed.']
['What other studies have been done?', 'Studies that include more recent outcomes show positive effects of treatment as opposed to non-treatment (Harpin, 2013; Arnold 2015).']
['What were other major findings?', 'In most cases, the same studies indicate that more research and work needs to be undertaken to understand the most effect treatments and their impacts.']
['What was genetics?', 'Family and twin studies indicate that genetics play a significant role in the development of ADHD.']

['What were the results of twin studies?', 'Burt (2009), in a review of 26 studies, reported that the median rate of concordance for identical twins was .66 (one study reported a rate of .90), whereas the median concordance rate for fraternal twins was .20.']

['What other aspects of genetics are mentioned?', 'This study also found that the median concordance rate for unrelated (adoptive) siblings was .09; although this number is small, it is greater than 0, thus suggesting that the environment may have at least some influence.']
['What did genetics contribute to?', 'Another review of studies concluded that the heritability of inattention and hyperactivity were 71% and 73%, respectively (Nikolas & Burt, 2010).']

['What does the study say about dopamine?', 'The specific genes involved in ADHD are thought to include at least two that are important in the regulation of the neurotransmitter dopamine (Gizer, Ficks, & Waldman, 2009), suggesting that dopamine may be important in ADHD.']

['Does this help with ADHD?', 'Indeed, medications used in the treatment of ADHD, such as methylphenidate (Ritalin) and amphetamine with dextroamphetamine (Adderall), have stimulant qualities and elevate dopamine activity.']

['What is the theory?', 'People with ADHD show less dopamine activity in key regions of the brain, especially those associated with motivation and reward (Volkow et al., 2009), which provides support to the theory that dopamine deficits may be a vital factor in the development this disorder (Swanson et al., 2007).']

['What are some of the underlying neurological causes of ADHD?', 'Brain imaging studies have shown that children with ADHD exhibit abnormalities in their frontal lobes, an area in which dopamine is in abundance.']
['What abnormalities?', 'Compared to children without ADHD, those with ADHD appear to have smaller frontal lobe volume, and they show less frontal lobe activation when performing mental tasks.']
['What can you tell me about the frontal lobe?', 'Recall that one of the functions of the frontal lobes is to inhibit our behavior.']

['Is there anything else interesting you could tell me about the frontal lobe?', 'Thus, abnormalities in this region may go a long way toward explaining the hyperactive, uncontrolled behavior of ADHD.']
['what kind of things caused ADHD?', 'By the 1970s, many had become aware of the connection between nutritional factors and childhood behavior.']
['what kind of foods were bad for them?', 'At the time, much of the public believed that hyperactivity was caused by sugar and food additives, such as artificial coloring and flavoring.']
['why did they believe that?', 'Undoubtedly, part of the appeal of this hypothesis was that it provided a simple explanation of (and treatment for) behavioral problems in children.']

['did they prove it was sugar?', 'A statistical review of 16 studies, however, concluded that sugar consumption has no effect at all on the behavioral and cognitive performance of children (Wolraich, Wilson, & White, 1995).']
['were there any other studies?', 'Additionally, although food additives have been shown to increase hyperactivity in non-ADHD children, the effect is rather small (McCann et al., 2007).']

['did any study prove smoking causes ADHD?', 'Numerous studies, however, have shown a significant relationship between exposure to nicotine in cigarette smoke during the prenatal period and ADHD (Linnet et al., 2003).']
['did they find any other studies on smoking and ADHD?', 'Maternal smoking during pregnancy is associated with the development of more severe symptoms of the disorder (Thakur et al., 2013).']
['Do you know what it means to ADHD?', 'No.']

['What kind of family environment has it had on individuals with ADHD?', 'Remember, the genetics studies discussed above suggested that the family environment does not seem to play much of a role in the development of this disorder; if it did, we would expect the concordance rates to be higher for fraternal twins and adoptive siblings than has been demonstrated.']

['What else can be inferred about the family environment?', 'All things considered, the evidence seems to point to the conclusion that ADHD is triggered more by genetic and neurological factors and less by social or environmental ones.']
['Who was first to observe autistic children?', 'A seminal paper published in 1943 by psychiatrist Leo Kanner described an unusual neurodevelopmental condition he observed in a group of children.']

['What did Kanner find?', 'He called this condition early infantile autism, and it was characterized mainly by an inability to form close emotional ties with others, speech and language abnormalities, repetitive behaviors, and an intolerance of minor changes in the environment and in normal routines (Bregman, 2005).']
["How was Kanner's work incorporated into the current definition of autism?", 'What the DSM-5 refers to as autism spectrum disorder today, is a direct extension of Kanner’s work.']
['What was autism spectrum disorder?', 'Autism spectrum disorder is probably the most misunderstood of the neurodevelopmental disorders.']

['What symptoms do people with autism have?', 'Children with this disorder show signs of significant disturbances in three main areas: (a) deficits in social interaction, (b) deficits in communication, and (c) repetitive patterns of behavior or interests.']
['How is the population affected by autism?', 'These disturbances appear early in life and cause serious impairments in functioning (APA, 2013).']

['How is social interaction affected?', 'The child with autism spectrum disorder might exhibit deficits in social interaction by not initiating conversations with other children or turning their head away when spoken to.']
['What other things did the child do?', 'Typically, these children do not make eye contact with others and seem to prefer playing alone rather than with others.']

['What can you tell me about their communication skills?', 'In some cases, it is almost as though these individuals live in a personal and isolated social world others are simply not privy to or able to penetrate.']

['What are some other characteristics?', 'Communication deficits can range from a complete lack of speech, to one word responses (e.g., saying “Yes” or “No” when replying to questions or statements that require additional elaboration), to echoed speech (e.g., parroting what another person says, either immediately or several hours or even days later), to difficulty maintaining a conversation because of an inability to reciprocate others’ comments.']

['What is an example of nonverbal cues?', 'These deficits can also include problems in using and understanding nonverbal cues (e.g., facial expressions, gestures, and postures) that facilitate normal communication.']
['What are the characteristics of autism?', 'Repetitive patterns of behavior or interests can be exhibited a number of ways.']

['What do these behaviors consist of?', 'The child might engage in stereotyped, repetitive movements (rocking, head-banging, or repeatedly dropping an object and then picking it up), or they might show great distress at small changes in routine or the environment.']
['What kind of interests do they have?', 'In some cases, the person with autism spectrum disorder might show highly restricted and fixated interests that appear to be abnormal in their intensity.']
['How can these interests be abnormal?', 'For instance, the person might learn and memorize every detail about something even though doing so serves no apparent purpose.']
['What else is important about autism?', 'Importantly, autism spectrum disorder is not the same thing as intellectual disability, although these two conditions are often comorbid.']
['Is intelligence involved?', 'The DSM-5 specifies that the symptoms of autism spectrum disorder are not caused or explained by intellectual disability.']

['What is autism?', 'Autism spectrum disorder is referred to in everyday language as autism; in fact, the disorder was termed “autistic disorder” in earlier editions of the DSM, and its diagnostic criteria were much narrower than those of autism spectrum disorder.']

['What is spectrum?', 'The qualifier “spectrum” in autism spectrum disorder is used to indicate that individuals with the disorder can show a range, or spectrum, of symptoms that vary in their magnitude and severity: some severe, others less severe.']

["Did the DSM include asperger's?", 'The previous edition of the DSM included a diagnosis of Asperger’s disorder, generally recognized as a less severe form of autistic disorder; individuals diagnosed with Asperger’s disorder were described as having average or high intelligence and a strong vocabulary, but exhibiting impairments in social interaction and social communication, such as talking only about their special interests (Wing, Gould, & Gillberg, 2011).']

['Why was it dropped?', 'However, because research has failed to demonstrate that Asperger’s disorder differs qualitatively from autistic disorder, the DSM-5 does not include it, which is prompting concerns among some parents that their children may no longer be eligible for special services (“Asperger’s Syndrome Dropped,” 2012).']

["What kind of impact does autism have on an individual's life?", 'Some individuals with autism spectrum disorder, particularly those with better language and intellectual skills, can live and work independently as adults.']
['What kind of impairment?', 'However, most do not because the symptoms remain sufficient to cause serious impairment in many realms of life (APA, 2013).']

['What other important information can you provide about the Life Problems From Autism Spectrum Disorder?', 'Current estimates from the Center for Disease Control and Prevention’s Autism and Developmental Disabilities Monitoring Network indicate that 1 in 59 children in the United States has autism spectrum disorder; the disorder is 4 times more common among boys (1 in 38) than in girls (1 in 152) (Baio et al, 2018).']
['Did autism rate increase since the 1980s?', 'Rates of autistic spectrum disorder have increased dramatically since the 1980s.']

['How has autism rate increased?', 'For example, California saw an increase of 273% in reported cases from 1987 through 1998 (Byrd, 2002); between 2000 and 2008, the rate of autism diagnoses in the United States increased 78% (CDC, 2012).']

['What caused the increase?', 'Although it is difficult to interpret this increase, it is possible that the rise in prevalence is the result of the broadening of the diagnosis, increased efforts to identify cases in the community, and greater awareness and acceptance of the diagnosis.']

['What is the impact on families?', 'In addition, mental health professionals are now more knowledgeable about autism spectrum disorder and are better equipped to make the diagnosis, even in subtle cases (Novella, 2008).']

['Why do we study this title?', 'The exact causes of autism spectrum disorder remain unknown despite massive research efforts over the last two decades (Meek, Lemery-Chalfant, Jahromi, & Valiente, 2013).']

['What did this research entail?', 'Autism appears to be strongly influenced by genetics, as identical twins show concordance rates of 60%–90%, whereas concordance rates for fraternal twins and siblings are 5%–10% (Autism Genome Project Consortium, 2007).']
['Who have been implicated in this?', 'Many different genes and gene mutations have been implicated in autism (Meek et al., 2013).']

['How are the genes involved?', 'Among the genes involved are those important in the formation of synaptic circuits that facilitate communication between different areas of the brain (Gauthier et al., 2011).']

['What else is involved?', 'A number of environmental factors are also thought to be associated with increased risk for autism spectrum disorder, at least in part, because they contribute to new mutations.']

['Why are these factors involved?', 'These factors include exposure to pollutants, such as plant emissions and mercury, urban versus rural residence, and vitamin D deficiency (Kinney, Barch, Chayka, Napoleon, & Munir, 2009).']

['What was the controversy about?', 'In the late 1990s, a prestigious medical journal published an article purportedly showing that autism is triggered by the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine.']
['What did people say?', 'These findings were very controversial and drew a great deal of attention, sparking an international forum on whether children should be vaccinated.']

['What happened after that?', 'In a shocking turn of events, some years later the article was retracted by the journal that had published it after evidence of fraud and unethical practices on the part of the lead researcher.']
['Why was it retracted?', 'Despite the retraction, the reporting in popular media led to concerns about a possible link between vaccines and autism persisting.']

['Were there any studies of vaccines and autism?', 'A recent survey of parents, for example, found that roughly a third of respondents expressed such a concern (Kennedy, LaVail, Nowak, Basket, & Landry, 2011); and perhaps fearing that their children would develop autism, more than 10% of parents of young children refuse or delay vaccinations (Dempsey et al., 2011).']
['What happened next?', 'Some parents of children with autism mounted a campaign against scientists who refuted the vaccine-autism link.']

['Did anyone get involved?', 'Even politicians and several well-known celebrities weighed in; for example, actress Jenny McCarthy (who believed that a vaccination caused her son’s autism) co-authored a book on the matter.']
['How was this done?', 'However, there is no scientific evidence that a link exists between autism and vaccinations (Hughes, 2007).']

['Were there any other studies of the topic?', 'Indeed, a recent study compared the vaccination histories of 256 children with autism spectrum disorder with that of 752 control children across three time periods during their first two years of life (birth to 3 months, birth to 7 months, and birth to 2 years) (DeStefano, Price, & Weintraub, 2013).']
['What did they do?', 'At the time of the study, the children were between 6 and 13 years old, and their prior vaccination records were obtained.']

['What were they looking for?', 'Because vaccines contain immunogens (substances that fight infections), the investigators examined medical records to see how many immunogens children received to determine if those children who received more immunogens were at greater risk for developing autism spectrum disorder.']

['Did they find anything?', 'The results of this study, a portion of which are shown in Figure 15.19, clearly demonstrate that the quantity of immunogens from vaccines received during the first two years of life were not at all related to the development of autism spectrum disorder.']
['What else did they find?', 'There is not a relationship between vaccinations and autism spectrum disorders.']

['What else does this material include?', 'Since the proliferation of the Internet in the 1990s, parents have been constantly bombarded with online information that can become magnified and take on a life of its own.']

['What is the Internet Information about?', 'The enormous volume of electronic information pertaining to autism spectrum disorder, combined with how difficult it can be to grasp complex scientific concepts, can make separating good research from bad challenging (Downs, 2008).']

['What is bad research?', 'Notably, the study that fueled the controversy reported that 8 out of 12 children—according to their parents—developed symptoms consistent with autism spectrum disorder shortly after receiving a vaccination.']

['Is this the only study of this type?', 'To conclude that vaccines cause autism spectrum disorder on this basis, as many did, is clearly incorrect for a number of reasons, not the least of which is because correlation does not imply causation, as you’ve learned.']

['What is it about?', 'Additionally, as was the case with diet and ADHD in the 1970s, the notion that autism spectrum disorder is caused by vaccinations is appealing to some because it provides a simple explanation for this condition.']
['Why are there no simple explanations?', 'Like all disorders, however, there are no simple explanations for autism spectrum disorder.']
['Why not?', 'Although the research discussed above has shed some light on its causes, science is still a long way from complete understanding of the disorder.']
['What is personality?', 'The term personality refers loosely to one’s stable, consistent, and distinctive way of thinking about, feeling, acting, and relating to the world.']

['What are personality disorders?', 'People with personality disorders exhibit a personality style that differs markedly from the expectations of their culture, is pervasive and inflexible, begins in adolescence or early adulthood, and causes distress or impairment (APA, 2013).']

['What kinds of things do personality disorders cause?', 'Generally, individuals with these disorders exhibit enduring personality styles that are extremely troubling and often create problems for them and those with whom they come into contact.']

['Are there other problems caused by personality disorders?', 'Their maladaptive personality styles frequently bring them into conflict with others, disrupt their ability to develop and maintain social relationships, and prevent them from accomplishing realistic life goals.']
['What are the 3 clusters?', 'The DSM-5 recognizes 10 personality disorders, organized into 3 different clusters.']
['What are the disorders in cluster A?', 'Cluster A disorders include paranoid personality disorder, schizoid personality disorder, and schizotypal personality disorder.']
['What is unique about these disorders?', 'People with these disorders display a personality style that is odd or eccentric.']

['What are the disorders in cluster B?', 'Cluster B disorders include antisocial personality disorder, histrionic personality disorder, narcissistic personality disorder, and borderline personality disorder.']
['What is unique about these disorders?', 'People with these disorders usually are impulsive, overly dramatic, highly emotional, and erratic.']

['What are the disorders in cluster C?', 'Cluster C disorders include avoidant personality disorder, dependent personality disorder, and obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (which is not the same thing as obsessive-compulsive disorder).']
['What is unique about these disorders?', 'People with these disorders often appear to be nervous and fearful.']
['What is the description of each of these disorders?', 'Table 15.2 provides a description of each of the DSM-5 personality disorders:']

['What are personality disorders?', 'Slightly over 9% of the U.S. population suffers from a personality disorder, with avoidant and schizoid personality disorders the most frequent (Lezenweger, Lane, Loranger, & Kessler, 2007).']
['Are there other personality disorders?', 'Two of these personality disorders, borderline personality disorder and antisocial personality disorder, are regarded by many as especially problematic.']

['What is borderline personality disorder?', 'The “borderline” in borderline personality disorder was originally coined in the late 1930s in an effort to describe patients who appeared anxious, but were prone to brief psychotic experiences—that is, patients who were thought to be literally on the borderline between anxiety and psychosis (Freeman, Stone, Martin, & Reinecke, 2005).']
['What does borderline mean now?', 'Today, borderline personality disorder has a completely different meaning.']

['What is the difference between borderline and schizotypal?', 'Borderline personality disorder is characterized chiefly by instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, and mood, as well as marked impulsivity (APA, 2013).']

['What else is different about borderline personality disorder?', 'People with borderline personality disorder cannot tolerate the thought of being alone and will make frantic efforts (including making suicidal gestures and engaging in self-mutilation) to avoid abandonment or separation (whether real or imagined).']

['How are their relationships?', 'Their relationships are intense and unstable; for example, a romantic partner may be idealized early in a relationship, but then later vilified at the slightest sign they appear to no longer show interest.']

['What else is there to know about the condition?', 'These individuals have an unstable view of self and, thus, might suddenly display a shift in personal attitudes, interests, career plans, and choice of friends.']

['What else might be different about them?', 'For example, a law school student may, despite having invested tens of thousands of dollars toward earning a law degree and despite having performed well in the program, consider dropping out and pursuing a career in another field.']

['What other changes in their life are typical?', 'People with borderline personality disorder may be highly impulsive and may engage in reckless and self-destructive behaviors such as excessive gambling, spending money irresponsibly, substance abuse, engaging in unsafe sex, and reckless driving.']
['What else is different about them?', 'They sometimes show intense and inappropriate anger that they have difficulty controlling, and they can be moody, sarcastic, bitter, and verbally abusive.']

['How common is this disorder?', 'The prevalence of borderline personality disorder in the U.S. population is estimated to be around 1.4% (Lezenweger et al., 2007), but the rates are higher among those who use mental health services; approximately 10% of mental health outpatients and 20% of psychiatric inpatients meet the criteria for diagnosis (APA, 2013).']
['What are the effects of this disorder?', 'Additionally, borderline personality disorder is comorbid with anxiety, mood, and substance use disorders (Lezenweger et al., 2007).']
['What is the biological basis for borderline personality disorder?', 'Genetic factors appear to be important in the development of borderline personality disorder.']

['What other evidence supports this claim?', 'For example, core personality traits that characterize this disorder, such as impulsivity and emotional instability, show a high degree of heritability (Livesley, 2008).']
['What else?', 'Also, the rates of borderline personality disorder among relatives of people with this disorder have been found to be as high as 24.9% (White, Gunderson, Zanarani, & Hudson, 2003).']

['Are there other factors?', 'Individuals with borderline personality disorder report experiencing childhood physical, sexual, and/or emotional abuse at rates far greater than those observed in the general population (Afifi et al., 2010), indicating that environmental factors are also crucial.']

['What is the most important thing to know about genetic factors and environmental factors?', 'These findings would suggest that borderline personality disorder may be determined by an interaction between genetic factors and adverse environmental experiences.']

['What about atypical traits?', 'Consistent with this hypothesis, one study found that the highest rates of borderline personality disorder were among individuals with a borderline temperament (characterized by high novelty seeking and high harm-avoidance) and those who experienced childhood abuse and/or neglect (Joyce et al., 2003).']
['What is the moral compass?', 'Most human beings live in accordance with a moral compass, a sense of right and wrong.']
['What do individuals learn?', 'Most individuals learn at a very young age that there are certain things that should not be done.']
['What does the moral compass teach?', 'We learn that we should not lie or cheat.']
['We learn that we should not steal.', 'We are taught that it is wrong to take things that do not belong to us, and that it is wrong to exploit others for personal gain.']
['What does antisocial personality disorder have to do with morality?', 'People with antisocial personality disorder, however, do not seem to have a moral compass.']
['How do they act?', 'These individuals act as though they neither have a sense of nor care about right or wrong.']
['Are they ever caught doing it?', 'Not surprisingly, these people represent a serious problem for others and for society in general.']

['What do you learn about Antisocial Personality Disorder?', 'According to the DSM-5, the individual with antisocial personality disorder shows no regard at all for other people’s rights or feelings.']

['What is the lack of regard for others?', 'This lack of regard is exhibited a number of ways and can include repeatedly performing illegal acts, lying to or conning others, impulsivity and recklessness, irritability and aggressiveness toward others, and failure to act in a responsible way (e.g., leaving debts unpaid) (APA, 2013).']

['What else do you learn about Antisocial Personality Disorder?', 'People with this disorder have no remorse over their misdeeds; these people will hurt, manipulate, exploit, and abuse others and not feel any guilt.']

['How old do people need to be to have Antisocial Personality Disorder?', 'Signs of this disorder can emerge early in life; however, a person must be at least 18 years old to be diagnosed with antisocial personality disorder.']
['What are some characteristics of an antisocial personality?', 'People with antisocial personality disorder seem to view the world as self-serving and unkind.']
['What else is significant about this person?', 'They seem to think that they should use whatever means necessary to get by in life.']
['What do they believe about others?', 'They tend to view others not as living, thinking, feeling beings, but rather as pawns to be used or abused for a specific purpose.']
['What else is significant about them?', 'They often have an over-inflated sense of themselves and can appear extremely arrogant.']
['How else are they perceived?', 'They frequently display superficial charm; for example, without really meaning it they might say exactly what they think another person wants to hear.']
['Why do they say that?', 'They lack empathy: they are incapable of understanding the emotional point-of-view of others.']

['What other characteristics are significant?', 'People with this disorder may become involved in illegal enterprises, show cruelty toward others, leave their jobs with no plans to obtain another job, have multiple sexual partners, repeatedly get into fights with others, and show reckless disregard for themselves and others (e.g., repeated arrests for driving while intoxicated) (APA, 2013).']
['How is this disorder classified?', 'The DSM-5 has included an alternative model for conceptualizing personality disorders based on the traits identified in the Five Factor Model of personality.']
['What are the traits?', 'This model addresses the level of personality functioning such as impairments in self (identity or self-direction) and interpersonal (empathy or intimacy) functioning.']

['Are there other factors?', 'In the case of antisocial personality disorder, the DSM-5 identifies the predominant traits of antagonism (such as disregard for others’ needs, manipulative or deceitful behavior) and disinhibition (characterized by impulsivity, irresponsibility, and risk-taking) (Harwood, Schade, Krueger, Wright, & Markon, 2012).']

['What are the other characteristics?', 'A psychopathology specifier is also included that emphasizes traits such as attention seeking and low anxiousness (lack of concern about negative consequences for risky or harmful behavior) (Crego & Widiger, 2014).']

['What are some of the risk factors for antisocial personality disorder?', 'Antisocial personality disorder is observed in about 3.6% of the population; the disorder is much more common among men, with a 3 to 1 ratio of men to women, and it is more likely to occur in men who are younger, widowed, separated, divorced, of lower socioeconomic status, who live in urban areas, and who live in the western United States (Compton, Conway, Stinson, Colliver, & Grant, 2005).']

['What are some of the risk factors for women?', 'Compared to men with antisocial personality disorder, women with the disorder are more likely to have experienced emotional neglect and sexual abuse during childhood, and they are more likely to have had parents who abused substances and who engaged in antisocial behaviors themselves (Alegria et al., 2013).']

['What is the source of this information?', 'Family, twin, and adoption studies suggest that both genetic and environmental factors influence the development of antisocial personality disorder, as well as general antisocial behavior (criminality, violence, aggressiveness) (Baker, Bezdjian, & Raine, 2006).']

['Did this information change over time?', 'Personality and temperament dimensions that are related to this disorder, including fearlessness, impulsive antisociality, and callousness, have a substantial genetic influence (Livesley & Jang, 2008).']

['Who else supports this?', 'Adoption studies clearly demonstrate that the development of antisocial behavior is determined by the interaction of genetic factors and adverse environmental circumstances (Rhee & Waldman, 2002).']

['Is there anything else worth mentioning?', 'For example, one investigation found that adoptees of biological parents with antisocial personality disorder were more likely to exhibit adolescent and adult antisocial behaviors if they were raised in adverse adoptive family environments (e.g., adoptive parents had marital problems, were divorced, used drugs, and had legal problems) than if they were raised in a more normal adoptive environment (Cadoret, Yates, Ed, Woodworth, & Stewart, 1995).']

['What are the other aspects of antisocial personality disorder?', 'Researchers who are interested in the importance of environment in the development of antisocial personality disorder have directed their attention to such factors as the community, the structure and functioning of the family, and peer groups.']
['What are those factors?', 'Each of these factors influences the likelihood of antisocial behavior.']

['What is the most interesting information about antisocial personality disorder?', 'One longitudinal investigation of more than 800 Seattle-area youth measured risk factors for violence at 10, 14, 16, and 18 years of age (Herrenkohl et al., 2000).']
['What are the risk factors for violence?', 'The risk factors examined included those involving the family, peers, and community.']
['What was the study about?', 'A portion of the findings from this study are provided in Figure 15.20.']
['What is a type of emotion associated with antisocial behavior?', 'Those with antisocial tendencies do not seem to experience emotions the way most other people do.']
['What does this mean?', 'These individuals fail to show fear in response to environment cues that signal punishment, pain, or noxious stimulation.']
['What type of emotion are these?', 'For instance, they show less skin conductance (sweatiness on hands) in anticipation of electric shock than do people without antisocial tendencies (Hare, 1965).']
['What is skin conductance?', 'Skin conductance is controlled by the sympathetic nervous system and is used to assess autonomic nervous system functioning.']
['Is it important to know this?', 'When the sympathetic nervous system is active, people become aroused and anxious, and sweat gland activity increases.']
['How is this used?', 'Thus, increased sweat gland activity, as assessed through skin conductance, is taken as a sign of arousal or anxiety.']

['What else can be learned about conductance?', 'For those with antisocial personality disorder, a lack of skin conductance may indicate the presence of characteristics such as emotional deficits and impulsivity that underlie the propensity for antisocial behavior and negative social relationships (Fung et al., 2005).']

['How do the different types of behaviors relate to the other groups?', 'Another example showing that those with antisocial personality disorder fail to respond to environmental cues comes from a recent study by Stuppy-Sullivan and Baskin-Sommers (2019).']
['What was the study?', 'The researchers studied cognitive and reward factors associated with antisocial personality disorder dysfunction in 119 incarcerated males.']
['What was the study about?', 'Each subject was administered three tasks targeting different aspects of cognition and reward.']

['How did it work?', 'High-magnitude rewards tended to impair perception in those with antisocial personality disorder, worsened executive function when they were consciously aware of the high rewards, and worsened inhibition when the tasks placed high demand on working memory.']

['What did you learn in this section?', 'Before we explore the various approaches to therapy used today, let’s begin our study of therapy by looking at how many people experience mental illness and how many receive treatment.']
['What is the percentage that experienced mental illness?', 'According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (2017), 18.9% of U.S. adults experienced mental illness in 2017.']

['What about children?', 'For teens (ages 13–18), the rate is similar to that of adults, and for children ages 8–15, current estimates suggest that approximately 13% experience mental illness in a given year (National Institute of Mental Health [NIMH], 2017).']

['What is significant about the data?', 'According to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), in 2017, 14.8% of adults received treatment for a mental health issue (NIMH, 2017).']

['How do you interpret the data?', 'These percentages, shown in Figure 16.2, reflect the number of adults who received care in inpatient and outpatient settings and/or used prescription medication for psychological disorders.']
['What are mental health services?', 'Children and adolescents also receive mental health services.']

['How much is mental health services?', "The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) found that approximately half (50.6%) of children with mental disorders had received treatment for their disorder within the past year (NIMH, n.d.)."]
['Does treatment depend on the age of the child?', 'However, there were some differences between treatment rates by category of disorder (Figure 16.3).']

['What are the differences between treatment rates?', 'For example, children with anxiety disorders were least likely to have received treatment in the past year, while children with ADHD or a conduct disorder were more likely to receive treatment.']

['What is the content about?', 'Let’s take a look at the history of mental health treatment from the past (with some questionable approaches in light of modern understanding of mental illness) to where we are today.']
['How has treatment with mental illness been viewed historically?', 'For much of history, people with mental illness have been treated very poorly.']
['What has mental illness been viewed as?', 'It was believed that mental illness was caused by demonic possession, witchcraft, or an angry god (Szasz, 1960).']
['How has the illness been treated?', 'For example, in medieval times, abnormal behaviors were viewed as a sign that a person was possessed by demons.']
['How was the possessed person treated?', 'If someone was considered to be possessed, there were several forms of treatment to release spirits from the individual.']
['What were the most common treatments?', 'The most common treatment was exorcism, often conducted by priests or other religious figures:']
['What did these exorcisms consist of?', 'Incantations and prayers were said over the person’s body, and they may have been given some medicinal drinks.']

['How did the person release demons?', 'Another form of treatment for extreme cases of mental illness was trephining: A small hole was made in the afflicted individual’s skull to release spirits from the body.']
['What else was used to treat mental illness?', 'Most people treated in this manner died.']
['What other forms of treatment were used?', 'In addition to exorcism and trephining, other practices involved execution or imprisonment of people with psychological disorders.']
['What was the punishment for those with mental illness?', 'Still others were left to be homeless beggars.']
['How has mental illness been treated in the past?', 'Generally speaking, most people who exhibited strange behaviors were greatly misunderstood and treated cruelly.']

['What other theories were used in this article?', 'The prevailing theory of psychopathology in earlier history was the idea that mental illness was the result of demonic possession by either an evil spirit or an evil god because early beliefs incorrectly attributed all unexplainable phenomena to deities deemed either good or evil.']

["What was the main point of the content you're studying?", 'From the late 1400s to the late 1600s, a common belief perpetuated by some religious organizations was that some people made pacts with the devil and committed horrible acts, such as eating babies (Blumberg, 2007).']
['What was the consequence of this?', 'These people were considered to be witches and were tried and condemned by courts—they were often burned at the stake.']

['What else did this claim cause?', 'Worldwide, it is estimated that tens of thousands of mentally ill people were killed after being accused of being witches or under the influence of witchcraft (Hemphill, 1966)']
['What was the treatment like in the past?', 'By the 18th century, people who were considered odd and unusual were placed in asylums (Figure 16.4).']

['What were the asylums like?', 'Asylums were the first institutions created for the specific purpose of housing people with psychological disorders, but the focus was ostracizing them from society rather than treating their disorders.']
['Did they receive any other treatment?', 'Often these people were kept in windowless dungeons, beaten, chained to their beds, and had little to no contact with caregivers.']
['What was the treatment like?', 'In the late 1700s, a French physician, Philippe Pinel, argued for more humane treatment of people with mental illness.']
['Did he say what?', 'He suggested that they be unchained and talked to, and that’s just what he did for patients at La Salpêtrière in Paris in 1795 (Figure 16.5).']
['How did this change the treatment?', 'Patients benefited from this more humane treatment, and many were able to leave the hospital.']
['What kind of change was going on in treatment?', 'In the 19th century, Dorothea Dix led reform efforts for mental health care in the United States (Figure 16.6).']

['Why did she want to reform it?', 'She investigated how those who are mentally ill and poor were cared for, and she discovered an underfunded and unregulated system that perpetuated abuse of this population (Tiffany, 1891).']
['What was she able to accomplish in this work?', 'Horrified by her findings, Dix began lobbying various state legislatures and the U.S. Congress for change (Tiffany, 1891).']
['What happened after her lobbying?', 'Her efforts led to the creation of the first mental asylums in the United States.']
['What happened during the 20th century?', 'Despite reformers’ efforts, however, a typical asylum was filthy, offered very little treatment, and often kept people for decades.']
['What kind of treatment was available?', 'At Willard Psychiatric Center in upstate New York, for example, one treatment was to submerge patients in cold baths for long periods of time.']

['What else happened during that time?', 'Electroshock treatment was also used, and the way the treatment was administered often broke patients’ backs; in 1943, doctors at Willard administered 1,443 shock treatments (Willard Psychiatric Center, 2009).']
['Was electroshock effective?', '(Electroshock is now called electroconvulsive treatment, and the therapy is still used, but with safeguards and under anesthesia.']
["What did they do with the patient's brain?", 'A brief application of electric stimulus is used to produce a generalized seizure.']
['What were some effects of the cold baths?', 'Controversy continues over its effectiveness versus the side effects.)']
['Why were patients so cold?', 'Many of the wards and rooms were so cold that a glass of water would be frozen by morning (Willard Psychiatric Center, 2009).']
['Did the asylum get shut down?', 'Willard’s doors were not closed until 1995.']
['What was the biggest change in treatment?', 'Conditions like these remained commonplace until well into the 20th century.']
['What is interesting about the past?', 'Starting in 1954 and gaining popularity in the 1960s, antipsychotic medications were introduced.']
['What were antipsychotics used for?', 'These proved a tremendous help in controlling the symptoms of certain psychological disorders, such as psychosis.']

['What type of psychological disorders were treated with antipsychotics?', 'Psychosis was a common diagnosis of individuals in mental hospitals, and it was often evidenced by symptoms like hallucinations and delusions, indicating a loss of contact with reality.']

["What did the 1960's consist of?", 'Then in 1963, Congress passed and John F. Kennedy signed the Mental Retardation Facilities and Community Mental Health Centers Construction Act, which provided federal support and funding for community mental health centers (National Institutes of Health, 2013).']
['What were community mental health centers?', 'This legislation changed how mental health services were delivered in the United States.']

['How did it change the delivery of care?', 'It started the process of deinstitutionalization, the closing of large asylums, by providing for people to stay in their communities and be treated locally.']
['What was the population like before these measures?', 'In 1955, there were 558,239 severely mentally ill patients institutionalized at public hospitals (Torrey, 1997).']
['What did deinstitutionalization do to the population?', 'By 1994, by percentage of the population, there were 92% fewer hospitalized individuals (Torrey, 1997).']
['What other information about mental health treatment today?', 'Today, there are community mental health centers across the nation.']

['What do they offer?', 'They are located in neighborhoods near the homes of clients, and they provide large numbers of people with mental health services of various kinds and for many kinds of problems.']

['What were their problems?', 'Unfortunately, part of what occurred with deinstitutionalization was that those released from institutions were supposed to go to newly created centers, but the system was not set up effectively.']

["Why wasn't the system set up effectively?", 'Centers were underfunded, staff was not trained to handle severe illnesses such as schizophrenia, there was high staff burnout, and no provision was made for the other services people needed, such as housing, food, and job training.']
['What happened as a result?', 'Without these supports, those people released under deinstitutionalization often ended up homeless.']
['What were the results of this?', 'Even today, a large portion of the homeless population is considered to be mentally ill (Figure 16.7).']
['How large is the portion?', 'Statistics show that 26% of homeless adults living in shelters experience mental illness (U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development [HUD], 2011).']
['Why do people have mental health issues?', 'Mental health issues are also significant concerns regarding those involved in the corrections system.']

['How many people are in the corrections system with mental health issues?', 'According to a 2006 special report by the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS), approximately 705,600 adults with mental health issues were incarcerated in the state prison system, and another 78,800 were incarcerated in the federal prison system.']
['Which other corrections systems?', 'A further 479,000 were in local jails.']

['Why does that happen?', 'According to the study, “people with mental illnesses are overrepresented in probation and parole populations at estimated rates ranging from two to four times the general population” (Prins & Draper, 2009, p. 23).']
['Is there a solution to this issue?', 'The correctional system faces increasing burdens in managing and supporting people with mental health issues (Torrey et al., 2014).']

['Are there any other important points to note in the article?', 'The incarceration experience itself exacerbates existing issues, triggers disturbances, or leads to long term effects such as PTSD, depression, or other disorders.']

['Can you tell me more about that?', 'While incarcerated, people are often subjected to or witness violence or sexual assault, face isolation from family, and endure other physical or emotional traumas (Edgemon & Clay-Warner, 2019).']

['What are some facts about mental health treatment today?', 'Today, instead of asylums, there are psychiatric hospitals run by state governments and local community hospitals focused on short-term care.']

['What is the average length of stay in a hospital?', 'In all types of hospitals, the emphasis is on short-term stays, with the average length of stay being less than two weeks and often only several days.']

['What can be done to improve the quality of care?', 'This is partly due to the very high cost of psychiatric hospitalization, which can be about $800 to $1000 per night (Stensland, Watson, & Grazier, 2012).']
['What other reasons are behind the shorter stays?', 'Therefore, insurance coverage often limits the length of time a person can be hospitalized for treatment.']
['What else is relevant in this material?', 'Usually individuals are hospitalized only if they are an imminent threat to themselves or others.']
['What does it cover?', 'Most people who have mental illnesses are not hospitalized.']
['What is their treatment?', 'If someone is feeling very depressed, complains of hearing voices, or feels anxious all the time, they might seek psychological treatment.']
['Who might refer them?', 'A friend, spouse, or parent might refer someone for treatment.']
['Who do they see first?', 'The individual might go see their primary care physician first and then be referred to a mental health practitioner.']

['Which people need treatment?', 'Some people seek treatment because they are involved with the state’s child protective services—that is, their children have been removed from their care due to abuse or neglect.']
['Why are they removed?', 'The parents might be referred to psychiatric or substance abuse facilities and the children would likely receive treatment for trauma.']
['What do these facilities provide?', 'If the parents are interested in and capable of becoming better parents, the goal of treatment might be family reunification.']

['How would that benefit the child?', 'For other children whose parents are unable to change—for example, the parent or parents who are heavily addicted to drugs and refuse to enter treatment—the goal of therapy might be to help the children adjust to foster care and/or adoption (Figure 16.8).']
['What are some of the issues that may compel people to seek mental health treatment?', 'Some people seek therapy because the criminal justice system referred them or required them to go.']
['What are some of these requirements?', 'For some individuals, for example, attending weekly counseling sessions might be a condition of parole.']
['Are these sessions mandatory or voluntary?', 'If an individual is mandated to attend therapy, they are seeking services involuntarily.']
['What does involuntary mean?', 'Involuntary treatment refers to therapy that is not the individual’s choice.']
['How can you avoid this?', 'Other individuals might voluntarily seek treatment.']
['What does voluntary mean?', 'Voluntary treatment means the person chooses to attend therapy to obtain relief from symptoms.']
['What is psychological treatment?', 'Psychological treatment can occur in a variety of places.']
['Where might they go?', 'An individual might go to a community mental health center or a practitioner in private or community practice.']
['Who else might a child go to?', 'A child might see a school counselor, school psychologist, or school social worker.']
['Where else might they go?', 'An incarcerated person might receive group therapy in prison.']
['How does that work?', 'There are many different types of treatment providers, and licensing requirements vary from state to state.']

['Are there any other types of treatment providers?', 'Besides psychologists and psychiatrists, there are clinical social workers, marriage and family therapists, and trained religious personnel who also perform counseling and therapy.']
['What does that mean?', 'A range of funding sources pay for mental health treatment: health insurance, government, and private pay.']
['Did insurance always pay for mental health treatment?', 'In the past, even when people had health insurance, the coverage would not always pay for mental health services.']

['How did this change?', 'This changed with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008, which requires group health plans and insurers to make sure there is parity of mental health services (U.S. Department of Labor, n.d.).']

['How does that work?', 'This means that co-pays, total number of visits, and deductibles for mental health and substance use treatment need to be equal to and cannot be more restrictive or harsher than those for physical illnesses and medical/surgical problems.']

['What are some of the main points in the material?', 'Finding treatment sources is also not always easy: there may be limited options, especially in rural areas and low-income urban areas; waiting lists; poor quality of care available for indigent patients; and financial obstacles such as co-pays, deductibles, and time off from work.']

['What is another important point of this material?', 'Over 85% of the l,669 federally designated mental health professional shortage areas are rural; often primary care physicians and law enforcement are the first-line mental health providers (Ivey, Scheffler, & Zazzali, 1998), although they do not have the specialized training of a mental health professional, who often would be better equipped to provide care.']
['How are treatment sources not always easy?', 'Availability, accessibility, and acceptability (the stigma attached to mental illness) are all problems in rural areas.']

['Are there any other problems?', 'Approximately two-thirds of those with symptoms receive no care at all (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2005; Wagenfeld, Murray, Mohatt, & DeBruiynb, 1994).']

['How has this changed?', 'At the end of 2013, the U.S. Department of Agriculture announced an investment of $50 million to help improve access and treatment for mental health problems as part of the Obama administration’s effort to strengthen rural communities.']

['What are the objectives of therapy?', 'One of the goals of therapy is to help a person stop repeating and reenacting destructive patterns and to start looking for better solutions to difficult situations.']
['What is the poem that has been used to illustrate this goal?', 'This goal is reflected in the following poem:']
['What are the two types of therapy mentioned in our study material?', 'Two types of therapy are psychotherapy and biomedical therapy.']
['What kind of health issues are treated with psychotherapy?', 'Both types of treatment help people with mental health issues, such as depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia.']
['What are the advantages of psychotherapy?', 'Psychotherapy is a psychological treatment that employs various methods to help someone overcome personal problems, or to attain personal growth.']
['Why was psychotherapy developed?', 'In modern practice, it has evolved into what is known as psychodynamic therapy, which will be discussed later.']
['What is biomedical therapy?', 'Biomedical therapy involves medication and/or medical procedures to treat psychological disorders.']

['What is the next step in our study?', 'First, we will explore the various psychotherapeutic orientations outlined in Table 16.1 (many of these orientations were discussed in the Introduction chapter).']
['what is psychanalysis?', 'Psychoanalysis was developed by Sigmund Freud and was the first form of psychotherapy.']
['what is notable about it?', 'It was the dominant therapeutic technique in the early 20th century, but it has since waned significantly in popularity.']

['how does he feel about it?', 'Freud believed most of our psychological problems are the result of repressed impulses and trauma experienced in childhood, and he believed psychoanalysis would help uncover long-buried feelings.']

['what is a typical session like?', 'In a psychoanalyst’s office, you might see a patient lying on a couch speaking of dreams or childhood memories, and the therapist using various Freudian methods such as free association and dream analysis (Figure 16.9).']
['what does the patient do?', 'In free association, the patient relaxes and then says whatever comes to mind at the moment.']
['what is different about free association?', 'However, Freud felt that the ego would at times try to block, or repress, unacceptable urges or painful conflicts during free association.']
['what happens if the patient refuses to express it?', 'Consequently, a patient would demonstrate resistance to recalling these thoughts or situations.']
['how does dream analysis work?', 'In dream analysis, a therapist interprets the underlying meaning of dreams.']
['What is psychoanalysis?', 'Psychoanalysis is a therapy approach that typically takes years.']
['How does it work?', 'Over the course of time, the patient reveals a great deal about himself to the therapist.']

['What happens during this process?', 'Freud suggested that during this patient-therapist relationship, the patient comes to develop strong feelings for the therapist—maybe positive feelings, maybe negative feelings.']
['How are they expressed?', 'Freud called this transference: the patient transfers all the positive or negative emotions associated with the patient’s other relationships to the psychoanalyst.']
['What is the best example of this?', 'For example, Crystal is seeing a psychoanalyst.']
['What happens during this therapy?', 'During the years of therapy, she comes to see her therapist as a father figure.']
['Why does she do this?', 'She transfers her feelings about her father onto her therapist, perhaps in an effort to gain the love and attention she did not receive from her own father.']

['What are the psychodynamic perspectives?', 'Today, Freud’s psychoanalytical perspective has been expanded upon by the developments of subsequent theories and methodologies: the psychodynamic perspective.']

['What are some important features of this perspective?', 'This approach to therapy remains centered on the role of people’s internal drives and forces, but treatment is less intensive than Freud’s original model.']
['What is it about?', 'Play therapy is often used with children since they are not likely to sit on a couch and recall their dreams or engage in traditional talk therapy.']
['What is play therapy?', 'This technique uses a therapeutic process of play to “help clients prevent or resolve psychosocial difficulties and achieve optimal growth” (O’Connor, 2000, p. 7).']
['What else is unique about play therapy?', 'The idea is that children play out their hopes, fantasies, and traumas while using dolls, stuffed animals, and sandbox figurines (Figure 16.10).']
['What are some other important things to know about this therapy?', 'Play therapy can also be used to help a therapist make a diagnosis.']

['What helps make this diagnosis?', 'The therapist observes how the child interacts with toys (e.g., dolls, animals, and home settings) in an effort to understand the roots of the child’s disturbed behavior.']
['What are some of the different aspects of play therapy?', 'Play therapy can be nondirective or directive.']

['What does non-directive play therapy mean?', 'In nondirective play therapy, children are encouraged to work through their problems by playing freely while the therapist observes (LeBlanc & Ritchie, 2001).']

['What does directive play therapy mean?', 'In directive play therapy, the therapist provides more structure and guidance in the play session by suggesting topics, asking questions, and even playing with the child (Harter, 1977).']
['What does psychoanalysis refer to?', 'In psychoanalysis, therapists help their patients look into their past to uncover repressed feelings.']

['How is behavior therapy different from psychoanalysis?', 'In behavior therapy, a therapist employs principles of learning to help clients change undesirable behaviors—rather than digging deeply into one’s unconscious.']

['What kinds of undesirable behaviors does behavior therapy help change?', 'Therapists with this orientation believe that dysfunctional behaviors, like phobias and bedwetting, can be changed by teaching clients new, more constructive behaviors.']
['How is behavior therapy taught?', 'Behavior therapy employs both classical and operant conditioning techniques to change behavior.']
['What is a type of behavior therapy?', 'One type of behavior therapy utilizes classical conditioning techniques.']
['What do therapists believe?', 'Therapists using these techniques believe that dysfunctional behaviors are conditioned responses.']
['What is the result of conditioning?', 'Applying the conditioning principles developed by Ivan Pavlov, these therapists seek to recondition their clients and thus change their behavior.']
['Who is Emmie?', 'Emmie is eight years old, and frequently wets her bed at night.']
['What is going on with Emmie?', 'She’s been invited to several sleepovers, but she won’t go because of her problem.']
['How can she change her behavior?', 'Using a type of conditioning therapy, Emmie begins to sleep on a liquid-sensitive bed pad that is hooked to an alarm.']
['What happens with the liquid-sensitive bed pad?', 'When moisture touches the pad, it sets off the alarm, waking up Emmie.']
['Why does this happen?', 'When this process is repeated enough times, Emmie develops an association between urinary relaxation and waking up, and this stops the bedwetting.']
['How long has this gone on for?', 'Emmie has now gone three weeks without wetting her bed and is looking forward to her first sleepover this weekend.']

['What is one of the most important things you learned in this section?', 'One commonly used classical conditioning therapeutic technique is counterconditioning: a client learns a new response to a stimulus that has previously elicited an undesirable behavior.']
['What are some examples of counterconditioning?', 'Two counterconditioning techniques are aversive conditioning and exposure therapy.']
['What is aversive conditioning?', 'Aversive conditioning uses an unpleasant stimulus to stop an undesirable behavior.']
['What are some examples of undesirable behaviors?', 'Therapists apply this technique to eliminate addictive behaviors, such as  smoking, nail biting, and drinking.']

['What are some examples of the negative stimulus?', 'In aversion therapy, clients will typically engage in a specific behavior (such as nail biting) and at the same time are exposed to something unpleasant, such as a mild electric shock or a bad taste.']
['How does aversion therapy work?', 'After repeated associations between the unpleasant stimulus and the behavior, the client can learn to stop the unwanted behavior.']
['What is the purpose of aversion therapy?', 'Aversion therapy has been used effectively for years in the treatment of alcoholism (Davidson, 1974; Elkins, 1991; Streeton & Whelan, 2001).']
['How does it work?', 'One common way this occurs is through a chemically based substance known as Antabuse.']

['What are the side effects?', 'When a person takes Antabuse and then consumes alcohol, uncomfortable side effects result including nausea, vomiting, increased heart rate, heart palpitations, severe headache, and shortness of breath.']
['How does it work?', 'Antabuse is repeatedly paired with alcohol until the client associates alcohol with unpleasant feelings, which decreases the client’s desire to consume alcohol.']
['How does it work?', 'Antabuse creates a conditioned aversion to alcohol because it replaces the original pleasure response with an unpleasant one.']

['What is exposure therapy?', 'In exposure therapy, a therapist seeks to treat clients’ fears or anxiety by presenting them with the object or situation that causes their problem, with the idea that they will eventually get used to it.']
['Does exposure therapy have to take place in the real world?', 'This can be done via reality, imagination, or virtual reality.']
['Who was the first person to report exposure therapy?', 'Exposure therapy was first reported in 1924 by Mary Cover Jones, who is considered the mother of behavior therapy.']
['What was her case?', 'Jones worked with a boy named Peter who was afraid of rabbits.']
['What did Jones do?', 'Her goal was to replace Peter’s fear of rabbits with a conditioned response of relaxation, which is a response that is incompatible with fear (Figure 16.11).']
['How did she achieve this?', 'Jones began by placing a caged rabbit on the other side of a room with Peter while he ate his afternoon snack.']
['How did Peter feel when the rabbit was there?', 'Over the course of several days, Jones moved the rabbit closer and closer to where Peter was seated with his snack.']
['What happened after that?', 'After two months of being exposed to the rabbit while relaxing with his snack, Peter was able to hold the rabbit and pet it while eating (Jones, 1924).']
['What is systematically desensitization?', 'Thirty years later, Joseph Wolpe (1958) refined Jones’s techniques, giving us systematic desensitization.']
['How does systematically desensitization work?', 'Using this method, a person creates a hierarchy of anxiety, ranging from the least-anxiety-producing stimulus to the feared object.']
['What are some examples of these activities?', 'These activities are paired with relaxation techniques, which are taught to the client beforehand and used during the graduated exposures.']
['What is the concept behind relaxation techniques?', 'The idea is that a person cannot be nervous and relaxed at the same time.']

['How can relaxation techniques help reduce fear?', 'Therefore, if they can learn to relax when they are facing environmental stimuli that make them nervous or fearful, they can eventually eliminate the unwanted fear response.']
['What is one example of the hierarchy of anxiety?', '(Figure 16.12).']
['What kind of behavior is being analyzed?', 'For example, Jayden is terrified of elevators.']
['What caused the fear?', 'Nothing bad has ever happened to him on an elevator, but he’s so afraid of elevators that he will always take the stairs.']

['How big of an issue is this?', 'That wasn’t a problem when Jayden worked on the second floor of an office building, but now he has a new job—on the 29th floor of a skyscraper in downtown Los Angeles.']
['What can he do about this problem?', 'Jayden knows he can’t climb 29 flights of stairs in order to get to work each day, so he decided to see a behavior therapist for help.']
['What does the behavior therapist do?', 'The therapist asks Jayden to first construct a hierarchy of elevator-related situations that elicit fear and anxiety.']

['What situations does he create?', 'They range from situations of mild anxiety such as being nervous around the other people in the elevator, to the fear of getting an arm caught in the door, to panic-provoking situations such as getting trapped or the cable snapping.']
['What happens after he constructs this hierarchy?', 'Next, the therapist uses progressive relaxation.']
['What does progressive relaxation consist of?', 'They teach Jayden how to relax each of his muscle groups so that he achieves a drowsy, relaxed, and comfortable state of mind.']
['What happens to him once he is relaxed?', 'Once he’s in this state, the therapist asks Jayden to imagine a mildly anxiety-provoking situation.']
['What kind of situation?', 'Jayden is standing in front of the elevator thinking about pressing the call button.']
['What do you do when Jayden is given a new scenario?', 'If this scenario causes Jayden anxiety, he lifts his finger.']
['Does Jayden do anything else during the scenario?', 'The therapist would then tell Jayden to forget the scene and return to his relaxed state.']
['How many times does this scenario happen?', 'They repeat this scenario over and over until Jayden can imagine himself pressing the call button without anxiety.']

['What are some other scenarios Jayden experiences?', 'Over time the therapist and Jayden use progressive relaxation and imagination to proceed through all of the situations on Jayden’s hierarchy until he becomes desensitized to each one.']

['What does Jayden practice after he has desensitized?', 'After this, Jayden and the therapist begin to practice what he only previously envisioned in therapy, gradually going from pressing the button to actually riding an elevator.']
['How does Jayden progress?', 'The goal is that Jayden will soon be able to take the elevator all the way up to the 29th floor of his office without feeling any anxiety.']

['what kind of virtual reality exposure therapy is being discussed?', 'Sometimes, it’s too impractical, expensive, or embarrassing to re-create anxiety- producing situations, so a therapist might employ virtual reality exposure therapy by using a simulation to help conquer fears.']

['what type of anxiety disorders does this therapy treat?', 'Virtual reality exposure therapy has been used effectively to treat numerous anxiety disorders such as the fear of public speaking, claustrophobia (fear of enclosed spaces), aviophobia (fear of flying), and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), a trauma and stressor-related disorder (Gerardi, Cukor, Difede, Rizzo, & Rothbaum, 2010).']
['What are some of the things you learned in this lesson?', 'Some behavior therapies employ operant conditioning.']
['What is operant conditioning?', 'Recall what you learned about operant conditioning:']
['What does operant conditioning involve?', 'We have a tendency to repeat behaviors that are reinforced.']
['When these behaviors are not reinforced, what happens to them?', 'They become extinguished.']
['How do these principles apply to behavioral treatment?', 'These principles, defined by Skinner as operant conditioning, can be applied to help people with a wide range of psychological problems.']
['What is operant conditioning?', 'One popular operant conditioning intervention is called the token economy.']

['What does this involve?', 'This involves a controlled setting where individuals are reinforced for desirable behaviors with tokens, such as a poker chip, that can be exchanged for items or privileges.']
['What does the token economy have to do with mental health?', 'Token economies are often used in psychiatric hospitals to increase patient cooperation and activity levels.']

['What is a token economy?', 'Patients are rewarded with tokens when they engage in positive behaviors (e.g., making their beds, brushing their teeth, coming to the cafeteria on time, and socializing with other patients).']
['How do they use the tokens?', 'They can later exchange the tokens for extra TV time, private rooms, visits to the canteen, and so on (Dickerson, Tenhula, & Green-Paden, 2005).']
['What is cognitive therapy?', 'Cognitive therapy is a form of psychotherapy that focuses on how a person’s thoughts lead to feelings of distress.']
['What is the idea behind cognitive therapy?', 'The idea behind cognitive therapy is that how you think determines how you feel and act.']
['How do cognitive therapists help their clients?', 'Cognitive therapists help their clients change dysfunctional thoughts in order to relieve distress.']
['How do they help their clients change dysfunctional thoughts?', 'They help a client see how they misinterpret a situation (cognitive distortion).']
['How do you say that?', 'For example, a client may overgeneralize.']
['What else might they overgeneralize?', 'Because a person failed one test in Psychology 101, they feel stupid and worthless.']
['What is the role of these thoughts?', 'These thoughts then cause their mood to worsen.']
['What else does a cognitive therapist look for?', 'Therapists also help clients recognize when they blow things out of proportion.']

['What is the purpose of blowing things out of proportion?', 'Because Ray failed his Psychology 101 test, he has concluded that he’s going to fail the entire course and probably flunk out of college altogether.']
['Why does he fail the entire course?', 'These errors in thinking have contributed to Ray’s feelings of distress.']
['What will he do next?', 'His therapist will help him challenge these irrational beliefs, focus on their illogical basis, and correct them with more logical and rational thoughts and beliefs.']
['What does cognitive therapy consist of?', 'Cognitive therapy was developed by psychiatrist Aaron Beck in the 1960s.']

['What did Beck do with cognitive therapy?', 'His initial focus was on depression and how a client’s self-defeating attitude served to maintain a depression despite positive factors in her life (Beck, Rush, Shaw, & Emery, 1979) (Figure 16.13).']

['What else is significant about the study of cognitive therapy?', 'Through questioning, a cognitive therapist can help a client recognize dysfunctional ideas, challenge catastrophizing thoughts about themselves and their situations, and find a more positive way to view things (Beck, 2011).']
['What is a cognitive behavioral therapy?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapists focus much more on present issues than on a patient’s childhood or past, as in other forms of psychotherapy.']

['What are some famous patients?', 'One of the first forms of cognitive-behavioral therapy was rational emotive therapy (RET), which was founded by Albert Ellis and grew out of his dislike of Freudian psychoanalysis (Daniel, n.d.).']
['What else is interesting about this therapy?', 'Behaviorists such as Joseph Wolpe also influenced Ellis’s therapeutic approach (National Association of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapists, 2009).']
['What does cognitive-behavioral therapy focus on?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) helps clients examine how their thoughts affect their behavior.']
['What other things does it try to change?', 'It aims to change cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors.']
