['How does this therapy help people?', 'In essence, this approach is designed to change the way people think as well as how they act.']

['What is the difference between this and cognitive therapy?', 'It is similar to cognitive therapy in that CBT attempts to make individuals aware of their irrational and negative thoughts and helps people replace them with new, more positive ways of thinking.']

['How is it different from behavior therapy?', 'It is also similar to behavior therapies in that CBT teaches people how to practice and engage in more positive and healthy approaches to daily situations.']

['What are some disorders this therapy is used to treat?', 'In total, hundreds of studies have shown the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy in the treatment of numerous psychological disorders such as depression, PTSD, anxiety disorders, eating disorders, bipolar disorder, and substance abuse (Beck Institute for Cognitive Behavior Therapy, n.d.).']

['Can this therapy help people with suicidal thoughts?', 'For example, CBT has been found to be effective in decreasing levels of hopelessness and suicidal thoughts in previously suicidal teenagers (Alavi, Sharifi, Ghanizadeh, & Dehbozorgi, 2013).']
['How does this help in military personnel?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy has also been effective in reducing PTSD in specific populations, such as transit workers (Lowinger & Rombom, 2012).']
['What does this acquaint you with?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy aims to change cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors using techniques like the ABC model.']
['What is this model?', 'With this model, there is an Action (sometimes called an activating event), the Belief about the event, and the Consequences of this belief.']
['How do you apply the ABC model to a specific situation?', 'Let’s say Jon and Joe both go to a party.']
['What happened after they left the party?', 'Jon and Joe each have met an interesting person at the party and spend a few hours chatting with them.']
['Did they exchange contact information?', "At the end of the party, Jon and Joe ask to exchange phone numbers with the person they've been talking to, and the request is refused."]
['What happened next?', 'Both Jon and Joe are surprised, as they thought things were going well.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'Let’s say Jon tells himself he is a loser, or is ugly, or “has no game.”']
['What are his consequences?', 'Jon then gets depressed and decides not to go to another party, which starts a cycle that keeps him depressed.']
['Does it work with Joe?', 'Joe tells himself that he had bad breath, goes out and buys a new toothbrush, goes to another party, and meets someone new.']
['What happened next in the lesson?', 'Jon’s belief about what happened results in a consequence of further depression, whereas Joe’s belief does not.']
['Why does Jon feel this way?', 'Jon is internalizing the attribution or reason for the rebuffs, which triggers his depression.']
['How can he change this?', 'On the other hand, Joe is externalizing the cause, so his thinking does not contribute to feelings of depression.']
['What does cognitive behavioral therapy do?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy examines specific maladaptive and automatic thoughts and cognitive distortions.']
['What are the distortions?', 'Some examples of cognitive distortions are all-or-nothing thinking, overgeneralization, and jumping to conclusions.']

['What kind of generalization?', 'In overgeneralization, someone takes a small situation and makes it huge—for example, instead of saying, “This particular person was not interested in me,” the man says, “I am ugly, a loser, and no one is ever going to be interested in me.”']
['What are the problems with this method?', 'All or nothing thinking, which is a common type of cognitive distortion for people suffering from depression, reflects extremes.']
['How do they use extremes?', 'In other words, everything is black or white.']
['What is another example of this?', 'After being turned down for a date, Jon begins to think, “No woman will ever go out with me.']
['What did he think?', 'I’m going to be alone forever.”']
['How does he feel?', 'He begins to feel anxious and sad as he contemplates his future.']

['What are the three kinds of distortions?', 'The third kind of distortion involves jumping to conclusions—assuming that people are thinking negatively about you or reacting negatively to you, even though there is no evidence.']
['What is the example?', 'Consider the example of Savannah and Hillaire, who recently met at a party.']
['How did they meet?', 'They have a lot in common, and Savannah thinks they could become friends.']
['What did Savannah do?', 'She calls Hillaire to invite her for coffee.']
['What happened next?', 'Since Hillaire doesn’t answer, Savannah leaves her a message.']
['Why did she leave her message?', 'Several days go by and Savannah never hears back from her potential new friend.']
['What did Savannah do?', 'Maybe Hillaire never received the message because she lost her phone or she is too busy to return the phone call.']
['What happened next?', 'But if Savannah believes that Hillaire didn’t like Savannah or didn’t want to be her friend, she is demonstrating the cognitive distortion of jumping to conclusions.']
['what is cognitive-behavioral therapy?', 'One client said this about his cognitive-behavioral therapy:']
['What is humanistic therapy?', 'Humanistic psychology focuses on helping people achieve their potential.']
['What are their potentials?', 'So it makes sense that the goal of humanistic therapy is to help people become more self-aware and accepting of themselves.']
['What is another interesting thing in this article?', 'In contrast to psychoanalysis, humanistic therapists focus on conscious rather than unconscious thoughts.']
['What else is notable about humanistic therapy?', 'They also emphasize the patient’s present and future, as opposed to exploring the patient’s past.']
['What is a Rogerian?', 'Psychologist Carl Rogers developed a therapeutic orientation known as Rogerian, or client-centered therapy.']
['What is the difference between patient and client?', 'Note the change from patients to clients.']
['Why was that important?', 'Rogers (1951) felt that the term patient suggested the person seeking help was sick and looking for a cure.']

['What else did he say?', 'Since this is a form of nondirective therapy, a therapeutic approach in which the therapist does not give advice or provide interpretations but helps the person to identify conflicts and understand feelings, Rogers (1951) emphasized the importance of the person taking control of his own life to overcome life’s challenges.']
['What was client-centered therapy about?', 'In client-centered therapy, the therapist uses the technique of active listening.']
['What is active listening?', 'In active listening, the therapist acknowledges, restates, and clarifies what the client expresses.']

['What else was special about client-centered therapy?', 'Therapists also practice what Rogers called unconditional positive regard, which involves not judging clients and simply accepting them for who they are.']

['What does this involve?', 'Rogers (1951) also felt that therapists should demonstrate genuineness, empathy, and acceptance toward their clients because this helps people become more accepting of themselves, which results in personal growth.']
['What is the purpose of this article?', 'For anyone considering therapy, these are important questions.']
['what are the three factors?', 'According to the American Psychological Association, three factors work together to produce successful treatment.']
['What is the first factor?', 'The first is the use of evidence-based treatment that is deemed appropriate for your particular issue.']
['What is the second factor?', 'The second important factor is the clinical expertise of the psychologist or therapist.']
['What is the third factor?', 'The third factor is your own characteristics, values, preferences, and culture.']

['What is the difference between psychotherapy and counseling?', 'Many people begin psychotherapy feeling like their problem will never be resolved; however, psychotherapy helps people see that they can do things to make their situation better.']
['How can you make your situation better?', 'Psychotherapy can help reduce a person’s anxiety, depression, and maladaptive behaviors.']

['Does it help with other issues?', 'Through psychotherapy, individuals can learn to engage in healthy behaviors designed to help them better express emotions, improve relationships, think more positively, and perform more effectively at work or school.']
['What do the studies say?', 'Many studies have explored the effectiveness of psychotherapy.']

['What is an example of what one study found?', 'For example, one large-scale study that examined 16 meta-analyses of CBT reported that it was equally effective or more effective than other therapies in treating PTSD, generalized anxiety disorder, depression, and social phobia (Butlera, Chapmanb, Formanc, & Becka, 2006).']

['What other studies have explored the effectiveness of psychotherapy?', 'Another study found that CBT was as effective at treating depression (43% success rate) as prescription medication (50% success rate) compared to the placebo rate of 25% (DeRubeis et al., 2005).']
['Which other studies are also out there?', 'Another meta-analysis found that psychodynamic therapy was also as effective at treating these types of psychological issues as CBT (Shedler, 2010).']

['What is the most important information in this article?', 'However, no studies have found one psychotherapeutic approach more effective than another (Abbass, Kisely, & Kroenke, 2006; Chorpita et al., 2011), nor have they shown any relationship between a client’s treatment outcome and the level of the clinician’s training or experience (Wampold, 2007).']

['What other interesting information is in the article?', 'Regardless of which type of psychotherapy an individual chooses, one critical factor that determines the success of treatment is the person’s relationship with the psychologist or therapist.']
['What do biomedical therapies deal with?', 'Individuals can be prescribed biologically based treatments or psychotropic medications that are used to treat mental disorders.']
['What else is interesting about this therapy?', 'While these are often used in combination with psychotherapy, they also are taken by individuals not in therapy.']
['What is it called when someone does not go to therapy for these disorders?', 'This is known as biomedical therapy.']
['What are the medications used?', 'Medications used to treat psychological disorders are called psychotropic medications and are prescribed by medical doctors, including psychiatrists.']
['Who can prescribe them?', 'In Louisiana and New Mexico, psychologists are able to prescribe some types of these medications (American Psychological Association, 2014).']
['What kind of medications do doctors prescribe?', 'Different types and classes of medications are prescribed for different disorders.']

['What kind of medication does a doctor prescribe?', 'An individual with depression might be given an antidepressant, an individual with bipolar disorder might be given a mood stabilizer, and an individual with schizophrenia might be given an antipsychotic.']
['What are these medications used for?', 'These medications treat the symptoms of a psychological disorder by altering the levels or effects of neurotransmitters.']

['What kinds of medications are there?', 'For example, each type of antidepressant affects a different neurotransmitter, such as SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor) antidepressants that increase the level of the neurotransmitter serotonin, and SNRI (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) antidepressants that increase the levels of both serotonin and norepinephrine.']
['What else is interesting about these medications?', 'They can help people feel better so that they can function on a daily basis, but they do not cure the disorder.']
['Does medication last forever?', 'Some people may only need to take a psychotropic medication for a short period of time.']
['Do some people need to take it forever?', 'Others with severe disorders like bipolar disorder or schizophrenia may need to take psychotropic medication for a long time.']

['What are psychotropic medications?', 'Psychotropic medications are a popular treatment option for many types of disorders, and research suggests that they are most effective when combined with psychotherapy.']
['What are some of the disorders they are used for?', 'This is especially true for the most common mental disorders, such as depressive and anxiety disorders (Cuijpers et al, 2014).']

['Is there a downside to these medications?', 'When considering adding medication as a treatment option, individuals should know that some psychotropic medications have very concerning side effects.']
['How are they administered?', 'Table 16.2 shows the commonly prescribed types of medications, how they are used, and some of the potential side effects that may occur.']

['Which is one biologically based treatment?', 'Another biologically based treatment that continues to be used, although infrequently, is electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) (formerly known by its unscientific name as electroshock therapy).']
['What is it used for?', 'It involves using an electrical current to induce seizures to help alleviate the effects of severe depression.']

['Why is that the case?', 'The exact mechanism is unknown, although it does help alleviate symptoms for people with severe depression who have not responded to traditional drug therapy (Pagnin, de Queiroz, Pini, & Cassano, 2004).']
['What happens next?', 'About 85% of people treated with ECT improve (Reti, n.d.).']
['Why not?', 'However, the memory loss associated with repeated administrations has led to it being implemented as a last resort (Donahue, 2000; Prudic, Peyser, & Sackeim, 2000).']

['What other treatments are available?', 'A more recent alternative is transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), a procedure approved by the FDA in 2008 that uses magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain to improve depression symptoms; it is used when other treatments have not worked (Mayo Clinic, 2012).']
['What is an intake?', 'Once a person seeks treatment, whether voluntarily or involuntarily, they have an intake done to assess their clinical needs.']
['What is an intake?', 'An intake is the therapist’s first meeting with the client.']

['What does an intake consist of?', 'The therapist gathers specific information to address the client’s immediate needs, such as the presenting problem, the client’s support system, and insurance status.']
['What is an intake like?', 'The therapist informs the client about confidentiality, fees, and what to expect in treatment.']
['What is confidentiality?', 'Confidentiality means the therapist cannot disclose confidential communications to any third party unless mandated or permitted by law to do so.']
['What else happens during an intake?', 'During the intake, the therapist and client will work together to discuss treatment goals.']
['What will the goals consist of?', 'Then a treatment plan will be formulated, usually with specific measurable objectives.']
['What else will they discuss?', 'Also, the therapist and client will discuss how treatment success will be measured and the estimated length of treatment.']
['What kind of therapy is used?', 'There are several different modalities of treatment (Figure 16.14): Individual therapy, family therapy, couples therapy, and group therapy are the most common.']

['How is it different from individual therapy?', 'In individual therapy, also known as individual psychotherapy or individual counseling, the client and clinician meet one-on-one (usually from 45 minutes to 1 hour).']
['What happens during the session?', 'These meetings typically occur weekly or every other week, and sessions are conducted in a confidential and caring environment (Figure 16.15).']

['What else happens in these sessions?', 'The clinician will work with clients to help them explore their feelings, work through life challenges, identify aspects of themselves and their lives that they wish to change, and set goals to help them work towards these changes.']
['How long does it last?', 'A client might see a clinician for only a few sessions, or the client may attend individual therapy sessions for a year or longer.']
['What other information about the article are you interested in?', 'The amount of time spent in therapy depends on the needs of the client as well as her personal goals.']
['What is group therapy?', 'In group therapy, a clinician meets together with several clients with similar problems (Figure 16.16).']
['What does group therapy accomplish?', 'When children are placed in group therapy, it is particularly important to match clients for age and problems.']

['What are some of the benefits of group therapy?', 'One benefit of group therapy is that it can help decrease a client’s shame and isolation about a problem while offering needed support, both from the therapist and other members of the group (American Psychological Association, 2014).']
['Does the text provide any examples of how group therapy can help?', 'A nine-year-old sexual abuse victim, for example, may feel very embarrassed and ashamed.']
['What does group therapy do to him?', 'If he is placed in a group with other sexually abused boys, he will realize that he is not alone.']
['How about another example of how group therapy can help?', 'A child struggling with poor social skills would likely benefit from a group with a specific curriculum to foster special skills.']
['Is there another example?', 'A woman suffering from post-partum depression could feel less guilty and more supported by being in a group with similar women.']
['What are some advantages of group therapy?', 'Group therapy also has some specific limitations.']

['What limitations does group therapy have?', 'Members of the group may be afraid to speak in front of other people because sharing secrets and problems with complete strangers can be stressful and overwhelming.']
['What else might be a problem with the group therapy?', 'There may be personality clashes and arguments among group members.']

['What other limitations might group therapy have?', 'There could also be concerns about confidentiality: Someone from the group might share what another participant said to people outside of the group.']
['what are some benefits of group therapy?', 'Another benefit of group therapy is that members can confront each other about their patterns.']
['what problems does it help with?', 'For those with some types of problems, such as sexual abusers, group therapy is the recommended treatment.']
['how does it help?', 'Group treatment for this population is considered to have several benefits:']
['What are psycho-educational groups?', 'Groups that have a strong educational component are called psycho-educational groups.']

['What are the educational aspects?', 'For example, a group for children whose parents have cancer might discuss in depth what cancer is, types of treatment for cancer, and the side effects of treatments, such as hair loss.']
['Where do they get this education?', 'Often, group therapy sessions with children take place in school.']
['Who leads the sessions?', 'They are led by a school counselor, a school psychologist, or a school social worker.']
['What issues do the groups discuss?', 'Groups might focus on test anxiety, social isolation, self-esteem, bullying, or school failure (Shechtman, 2002).']

['Does the study of group therapy give any benefit?', 'Whether the group is held in school or in a clinician’s office, group therapy has been found to be effective with children facing numerous kinds of challenges (Shechtman, 2002).']

['What can we learn about group therapy?', 'During a group session, the entire group could reflect on an individual’s problem or difficulties, and others might disclose what they have done in that situation.']

['What else does this teach?', 'When a clinician is facilitating a group, the focus is always on making sure that everyone benefits and participates in the group and that no one person is the focus of the entire session.']

['What else do we know about group therapy?', 'Groups can be organized in various ways: some have an overarching theme or purpose, some are time-limited, some have open membership that allows people to come and go, and some are closed.']
['What else can you tell me about this?', 'Some groups are structured with planned activities and goals, while others are unstructured:']
['What is unstructured?', 'There is no specific plan, and group members themselves decide how the group will spend its time and on what goals it will focus.']
['Why is this important?', 'This can become a complex and emotionally charged process, but it is also an opportunity for personal growth (Page & Berkow, 1994).']
['What are the different types of Couples Therapy?', 'Couples therapy involves two people in an intimate relationship who are having difficulties and are trying to resolve them (Figure 16.17).']
['How is a couple viewed by psychotherapists?', 'The couple may be dating, partnered, engaged, or married.']
['What is one therapy used?', 'The primary therapeutic orientation used in couples counseling is cognitive-behavioral therapy (Rathus & Sanderson, 1999).']
['What are some aspects of this therapy?', 'Couples meet with a therapist to discuss conflicts and/or aspects of their relationship that they want to change.']
['How are they able to change their relationship?', 'The therapist helps them see how their individual backgrounds, beliefs, and actions are affecting their relationship.']

['What happens next?', 'Often, a therapist tries to help the couple resolve these problems, as well as implement strategies that will lead to a healthier and happier relationship, such as how to listen, how to argue, and how to express feelings.']
['What is the last thing you heard about Couples Therapy?', 'However, sometimes, after working with a therapist, a couple will realize that they are too incompatible and will decide to separate.']
['Can you tell me more about this?', 'Some couples seek therapy to work out their problems, while others attend therapy to determine whether staying together is the best solution.']
['What is the problem with volatile relationships?', 'Counseling couples in a high-conflict and volatile relationship can be difficult.']

['What else is difficult?', 'In fact, psychologists Peter Pearson and Ellyn Bader, who founded the Couples Institute in Palo Alto, California, have compared the experience of the clinician in couples’ therapy to be like “piloting a helicopter in a hurricane” (Weil, 2012, para. 7).']
['What is family therapy?', 'Family therapy is a special form of group therapy, consisting of one or more families.']
['What is the systems approach?', 'Although there are many theoretical orientations in family therapy, one of the most predominant is the systems approach.']

['What does the systems approach mean?', 'The family is viewed as an organized system, and each individual within the family is a contributing member who creates and maintains processes within the system that shape behavior (Minuchin, 1985).']
['What is the main idea of this section?', 'Each member of the family influences and is influenced by the others.']
['What is the result of this approach?', 'The goal of this approach is to enhance the growth of each family member as well as that of the family as a whole.']
['What can a family therapy help?', 'Often, dysfunctional patterns of communication that develop between family members can lead to conflict.']
['Can the dysfunctional patterns be resolved?', 'A family with this dynamic might wish to attend therapy together rather than individually.']
['What else is a common complaint?', 'In many cases, one member of the family has problems that detrimentally affect everyone.']
['Can you tell me more about the problems?', 'For example, a mother’s depression, teen daughter’s eating disorder, or father’s alcohol dependence could affect all members of the family.']

['Can these family members also be helped?', 'The therapist would work with all members of the family to help them cope with the issue, and to encourage resolution and growth in the case of the individual family member with the problem.']
['what is family therapy?', 'With family therapy, the nuclear family (i.e., parents and children) or the nuclear family plus whoever lives in the household (e.g., grandparent) come into treatment.']
['What happens during this session?', 'Family therapists work with the whole family unit to heal the family.']
['Is there any other information?', 'There are several different types of family therapy.']

['What are the different types of therapy?', 'In structural family therapy, the therapist examines and discusses the boundaries and structure of the family: who makes the rules, who sleeps in the bed with whom, how decisions are made, and what are the boundaries within the family.']
['What causes the problems?', 'In some families, the parents do not work together to make rules, or one parent may undermine the other, leading the children to act out.']
['What happens after that?', 'The therapist helps them resolve these issues and learn to communicate more effectively.']
['What does family therapy consist of?', 'In strategic family therapy, the goal is to address specific problems within the family that can be dealt with in a relatively short amount of time.']

['How does a family therapist fix the problems?', 'Typically, the therapist would guide what happens in the therapy session and design a detailed approach to resolving each member’s problem (Madanes, 1991).']
['What are some examples?', 'Addiction is often viewed as a chronic disease (Figure 16.18).']

['What is an addiction?', 'The choice to use a substance is initially voluntary; however, because chronic substance use can permanently alter the neural structure in the prefrontal cortex, an area of the brain associated with decision-making and judgment, a person becomes driven to use drugs and/or alcohol (Muñoz-Cuevas, Athilingam, Piscopo, & Wilbrecht, 2013).']
['What happens after the addiction?', 'This helps explain why relapse rates tend to be high.']

['What are the relapse rates?', 'About 40%–60% of individuals relapse, which means they return to abusing drugs and/or alcohol after a period of improvement (National Institute on Drug Abuse [NIDA], 2008).']
['What is substance-related treatment?', 'The goal of substance-related treatment is to help a person with an addiction stop compulsive drug-seeking behaviors (NIDA, 2012).']
['What does this mean?', 'This means a person with addiction will need long-term treatment, similar to a person battling a chronic physical disease such as hypertension or diabetes.']
['What kind of treatment is it?', 'Treatment usually includes behavioral therapy and/or medication, depending on the individual (NIDA, 2012).']

['What other treatment is used?', 'Specialized therapies have also been developed for specific types of substance-related disorders, including alcohol, cocaine, and opioids (McGovern & Carroll, 2003).']
['How is it different from incarceration?', 'Substance-related treatment is considered much more cost-effective than incarceration or not treating those with addictions (NIDA, 2012) (Figure 16.19).']
['What is this topic about?', 'Specific factors make substance-related treatment much more effective.']
['What are some of these factors?', 'One factor is duration of treatment.']

['How long does treatment last?', 'Generally, a person with addict needs to be in treatment for at least three months to achieve a positive outcome (Simpson, 1981; Simpson, Joe, & Bracy, 1982; NIDA, 2012).']
['What other factors make a treatment more effective?', 'This is due to the psychological, physiological, behavioral, and social aspects of abuse (Simpson, 1981; Simpson et al., 1982; NIDA, 2012).']

['What can you tell me about behavioral aspect of addiction?', 'While in treatment, a person with addiction might receive behavior therapy, which can help motivate the person with addiction to participate in the treatment program and teach strategies for dealing with cravings and how to prevent relapse.']
['What about social aspects of addiction?', 'Also, treatment needs to be holistic and address multiple needs, not just the drug addiction.']

['What is holistic treatment?', 'This means that treatment will address factors such as communication, stress management, relationship issues, parenting, vocational concerns, and legal concerns (McGovern & Carroll, 2003; NIDA, 2012).']

['What is the most common method of treatment?', 'While individual therapy is used in the treatment of substance-related disorders, group therapy is the most widespread treatment modality (Weiss, Jaffee, de Menil, & Cogley, 2004).']

['What are some reasons that this method of treatment is most commonly used?', 'The rationale behind using group therapy for addiction treatment is that people with addiction are much more likely to maintain sobriety in a group format.']

['Why is this?', 'It has been suggested that this is due to the rewarding and therapeutic benefits of the group, such as support, affiliation, identification, and even confrontation (Center for Substance Abuse Treatment, 2005).']

['What else can you tell me about group therapy?', 'For teenagers, the whole family often needs to participate in treatment to address issues such as family dynamics, communication, and relapse prevention.']
['What other things do they need to address in treatment?', 'Family involvement in teen drug addiction is vital.']
['What is vital about family involvement?', 'Research suggests that greater parental involvement is correlated with a greater reduction in use by teen substance abusers.']
['How else do family members participate?', 'Also, mothers who participated in treatment displayed better mental health and greater warmth toward their children (Bertrand et al., 2013).']
['What other things should be done in a group setting?', 'However, neither individual nor group therapy has been found to be more effective (Weiss et al., 2004).']

['What else can you tell me about group therapy?', 'Regardless of the type of treatment service, the primary focus is on abstinence or at the very least a significant reduction in use (McGovern & Carroll, 2003).']

['What medications are used for addiction?', 'Treatment also usually involves medications to detox a person with addiction safely after an overdose, to prevent seizures and agitation that often occur in detox, to prevent reuse of the drug, and to manage withdrawal symptoms.']
['What else does this article contain?', 'Getting off drugs often involves the use of drugs—some of which can be just as addictive.']
['What is detox?', 'Detox can be difficult and dangerous.']
['What is the most common comorbid disorder?', 'Frequently, a person with an addiction to drugs and/or alcohol has an additional psychological disorder.']
['What does it mean to have comorbid disorders?', 'Saying a person has comorbid disorders means the individual has two or more diagnoses.']
['What can two diagnoses have in common?', 'This can often be a substance-related diagnosis and another psychiatric diagnosis, such as depression, bipolar disorder, or schizophrenia.']

['Are there any other important things about comorbid disorders?', 'These individuals fall into the category of mentally ill and chemically addicted (MICA)—their problems are often chronic and expensive to treat, with limited success.']
['What happens to them?', 'Compared with the overall population, people who use illicit drugs or misuse prescription drugs are twice as likely to have a mood or anxiety disorder.']

['What is the main idea of this article?', 'Drug use can cause symptoms of mood and anxiety disorders and the reverse is also true—people with debilitating symptoms of a psychiatric disorder may self-medicate and misuse substances.']
['What is comorbidity?', 'In cases of comorbidity, the best treatment is thought to address both (or multiple) disorders simultaneously (NIDA, 2012).']
['How is comorbidity treated?', 'Behavior therapies are used to treat comorbid conditions, and in many cases, psychotropic medications are used along with psychotherapy.']

['What medications are used?', 'For example, evidence suggests that bupropion (trade names: Wellbutrin and Zyban), approved for treating depression and nicotine dependence, might also help reduce craving and use of the drug methamphetamine (NIDA, 2011).']
['What else is known about these medications?', 'However, more research is needed to better understand how these medications work—particularly when combined in patients with comorbidities.']
['What is the sociocultural perspective?', 'The sociocultural perspective looks at you, your behaviors, and your symptoms in the context of your culture and background.']
['What are some examples of cultural factors?', 'For example, José is an 18-year-old Hispanic male from a traditional family.']
["What is José's disorder?", 'José comes to treatment because of depression.']
['What are some other interesting facts about José?', 'During the intake session, he reveals that he is gay and is nervous about telling his family.']
['Why is he nervous about telling his family?', 'He also discloses that he is concerned because his religious background has taught him that being gay is wrong.']

['What is the most important thing you know about this chapter?', 'Mental health professionals must develop cultural competence (Figure 16.20), which means they must understand and address issues of race, culture, and ethnicity.']
['What else must they do?', 'They must also develop strategies to effectively address the needs of various populations for which Eurocentric therapies have limited application (Sue, 2004).']

['What other things should they know?', 'For example, a counselor whose treatment focuses on individual decision making may be ineffective at helping a Chinese client with a collectivist approach to problem solving (Sue, 2004).']

['What is the main idea?', 'Multicultural counseling and therapy aims to offer both a helping role and process that uses modalities and defines goals consistent with the life experiences and cultural values of clients.']

['What is multicultural counseling?', 'It strives to recognize client identities to include individual, group, and universal dimensions, advocate the use of universal and culture-specific strategies and roles in the healing process, and balances the importance of individualism and collectivism in the assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of client and client systems (Sue, 2001).']
['What does the sociocultural model help people do?', 'This therapeutic perspective integrates the impact of cultural and social norms, starting at the beginning of treatment.']

['What does this include?', 'Therapists who use this perspective work with clients to obtain and integrate information about their cultural patterns into a unique treatment approach based on their particular situation (Stewart, Simmons, & Habibpour, 2012).']
['What are other forms of sociocultural therapy?', 'Sociocultural therapy can include individual, group, family, and couples treatment modalities.']

['What are the barriers to treatment?', 'Statistically, ethnic minorities tend to utilize mental health services less frequently than White, middle-class Americans (Alegría et al., 2008; Richman, Kohn-Wood, & Williams, 2007).']
['What is the reason for this?', 'Perhaps the reason has to do with access and availability of mental health services.']

['What are other barriers to treatment?', 'Ethnic minorities and individuals of low socioeconomic status (SES) report that barriers to services include lack of insurance, transportation, and time (Thomas & Snowden, 2002).']

['How is this addressed?', 'However, researchers have found that even when income levels and insurance variables are taken into account, ethnic minorities are far less likely to seek out and utilize mental health services.']
['What else does the research show?', 'And when access to mental health services is comparable across ethnic and racial groups, differences in service utilization remain (Richman et al., 2007).']

['What are some important characteristics of anorexia nervosa in this study?', 'In a study involving thousands of women, it was found that the prevalence rate of anorexia was similar across different races, but that bulimia nervosa was more prevalent among Hispanic and African American women when compared with non-Hispanic']
['Black', 'White people (Marques et al., 2011).']

['What was an important finding from this study?', 'Although they have similar or higher rates of eating disorders, Hispanic and African American women with these disorders tend to seek and engage in treatment far less than White women.']

['What are the barriers to treatment?', 'These findings suggest ethnic disparities in access to care, as well as clinical and referral practices that may prevent Hispanic and African American women from receiving care, which could include lack of bilingual treatment, stigma, fear of not being understood, family privacy, and lack of education about eating disorders.']
['What type of balance does mental health services reflect?', 'Perceptions and attitudes toward mental health services may also contribute to this imbalance.']

['Why are people afraid to seek treatment?', 'A recent study at King’s College, London, found many complex reasons why people do not seek treatment: self-sufficiency and not seeing the need for help, not seeing therapy as effective, concerns about confidentiality, and the many effects of stigma and shame (Clement et al., 2014).']

['How can treatment help someone with mental health problems?', 'And in another study, African Americans exhibiting depression were less willing to seek treatment due to fear of possible psychiatric hospitalization as well as fear of the treatment itself (Sussman, Robins, & Earls, 1987).']

['What are the feelings of those who do not seek treatment?', 'Instead of mental health treatment, many African Americans prefer to be self-reliant or use spiritual practices (Snowden, 2001; Belgrave & Allison, 2010).']

['What type of spiritual practices are used?', 'For example, it has been found that the Black church plays a significant role as an alternative to mental health services by providing prevention and treatment-type programs designed to enhance the psychological and physical well-being of its members (Blank, Mahmood, Fox, & Guterbock, 2002).']

['What is one of the barriers?', 'Additionally, people belonging to ethnic groups that already report concerns about prejudice and discrimination are less likely to seek services for a mental illness because they view it as an additional stigma (Gary, 2005; Townes, Cunningham, & Chavez-Korell, 2009; Scott, McCoy, Munson, Snowden, & McMillen, 2011).']
['What other challenges do they face?', 'For example, in one recent study of 462 older Korean Americans (over the age of 60) many participants reported suffering from depressive symptoms.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects about this study?', 'However, 71% indicated they thought depression was a sign of personal weakness, and 14% reported that having a mentally ill family member would bring shame to the family (Jang, Chiriboga, & Okazaki, 2009).']
['What are some other barriers to treatment?', 'Language differences are a further barrier to treatment.']

['What other barriers to treatment exist?', 'In the previous study on Korean Americans’ attitudes toward mental health services, it was found that there were no Korean-speaking mental health professionals where the study was conducted (Orlando and Tampa, Florida) (Jang et al., 2009).']

['What is another barrier to treatment?', 'Because of the growing number of people from ethnically diverse backgrounds, there is a need for therapists and psychologists to develop knowledge and skills to become culturally competent (Ahmed, Wilson, Henriksen, & Jones, 2011).']
['What is culturally competent?', 'Those providing therapy must approach the process from the context of the unique culture of each client (Sue & Sue, 2007).']
Average
